title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: BERGENFIELD: OFFICIAL ACCUSED OF ARSON Bergenfield's chief financial officer, scheduled for replacement, has been charged with setting fire to the car of the borough tax clerk, whom he blamed for costing him his job, the authorities said yesterday. The financial officer, John Mosca Jr., 51, was charged with aggravated arson and stalking, said the Bergen County prosecutor, John L. Molinelli. Mr. Mosca, of Paramus, is free on bail. After a shift in the Borough Council majority from Democrat to Republican in November, Mr. Mosca was told that his term would be allowed to expire. Mr. Mosca went to the clerk's house in Mahwah and set her car on fire around 1 a.m. on Monday, prosecutors said. (AP)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Chickens Ordered Killed To Stem Virus
description: State officials have ordered the destruction of one million egg-producing hens and expanded a poultry quarantine to stem the spread of the Exotic New Castle Disease in California's $3 billion poultry industry. New cases of the disease, which is harmless to humans, were found in San Bernardino, Los Angeles and San Diego Counties. More than 100,000 commercial chickens have already been destroyed as a result of the virus. The quarantine was expanded to San Diego County after tests confirmed an outbreak at a farm with 75,000 hens, and to Orange County, as a precaution. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMBALL, ERNEST ROBBINS, M.D.
description: KIMBALL-Ernest Robbins, M.D., 93, a pediatrician and pioneer in the scientific documentation of the medical and psychological benefits of breastfeeding, passed away December 27, 2002 of complications resulting from aplastic anemia. Born in Arlington, MA, Dr. Kimball went on to become a respected pediatrician and writer as well as a loving husband, father, grandfather, great grandfather and a special friend to children. He graduated from Harvard University in 1931, received his medical degree from Yale Medical School in 1936 and completed his residency in Cleveland, Ohio. During World War II, Dr. Kimball became a Commanding Officer, as a research pathologist with the First Medical Laboratory, traveling just behind the front lines from North Africa in 1942 to the European Theater. A week after VE Day in 1945, he was assigned to the Dachau death camp in Germany and became the commanding officer. He performed autopsies on non-combatants to assess the diseases that GIs were exposed to, Dr. Kimball and his men tried to provide comfort to the death camp survivors. He said, ''Sadly that first day, all we were able to do was to help them to get warm. Food did not arrive until a few days later.'' Dr. Kimball was amazed at the vitality of the young babies throughout ravaged Europe. Noting while their emaciated mothers were suffering from malnutrition, their breast-fed babies were relatively healthy. When Dr. Kimball returned to the states, he settled in Evanston and Glenview, IL, Marthas Vineyard, MA. and later retired to Jacksonville with his wife of 61 years, Alicia Barber Kimball, who died March 15 of this year, in Jacksonville. Dr. Kimball began his private practice medical career in Evanston, IL. He was Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Northwestern University Medical School in Chicago, IL. Dr. Kimball was on the staff of Childrens Memorial, St. Francis and Evanston Hospitals and for over twenty years, donated one day per week at the Infant Welfare Agency of Chicago. While practicing in the Chicago area, Dr. Kimball helped found the Evanston Hospital Breast Milk Bank, which was taken over as Junior League Project and was soon in touch with the founding mothers of La Leche League International, as one of the groups two medical advisors. Dr. Kimball received the Founders Award from La Leche League in 1997, the fourth, International Award given in forty years. He also received La Leches Excellence Award in 1991. As a research pathologist and commanding officer of the first medical laboratory in WWII, Dr. Kimball also went on to write about the benefits of breastfeeding and early childhood staged access to the world. In 1968, Dr. Kimball and his wife cofounded a not - for - profit ranch for physical and recreational therapy and lifetime residency for children with mental and physical disabilities in Zion, AR. Dr. Kimballs family includes his daughter, Alicia Wilson Kimball of Jacksonville Beach and Chicago; son, Ernest Robbins Kimball III, M.D. of Jacksonville Beach; son, David Custis Kimball of Boca Raton, FL: eight grandchildren, Gilbert Valentine of Chicago, David Valentine of New York City; Ernest Robbins Kimball, IV of Jacksonville, Timothy Kimball of Jacksonville, Jonathon Kimball of Jacksonville and Michael Kimball of Jacksonville; Elizabeth Kimball of Boca Raton and Henry David Kimball of Boca Raton as well as a great grandson, Gilbert Robbins ''Chip'' Valentine of Chicago. A private family memorial service will be held in the Chapel of Christ Episcopal Church, 400 San Juan Drive, Ponte Vedra, FL on January 11, 2003. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Christ Episcopal Church, Easy-K Foundation (disability), La Leche League of Jacksonville, Or La Leche League International, Schaumburg, IL. Services under the direction and care of Quinn-Shalz, A Family Funeral Home & Cremation Centre, Jacksonville Beach, Florida, 904-249-1100, www.quinn-shalz.com.

title: Artichoke's Cousin Gaining Recognition
description: Recipes for cardoons have been sneaking their way into cookbooks, including ''The Babbo Cookbook'' by Mario Batali (Clarkson N. Potter, 2002). Mr. Batali calls them one of his ''fave vegetables'' because of their ''very sexy flavor.'' The cardoon is related to the artichoke and looks like celery you would not want to buy -- grayish, with a kind of matte finish. It tastes of celery and artichokes, with a hint of licorice. The stalks should be peeled and cooked before using in gratins, pasta sauces or grilled with a buttery glaze. Cardoons are sold at Fairway and at Agata & Valentina for 89 cents a pound, at Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory for $1.29.

title: An Air Vent Leads to Tasty Moroccan Cooking
description: Traditional terra cotta tagines have no glazing on the underside of the lid, to allow evaporating steam to be absorbed by the clay and concentrate the sauce. Now, new ones from Tangiers, Morocco, are completely glazed, but accomplish the same purpose with a tiny air vent for the escaping steam. They are also sturdier and have ridges in the dish to prevent food from sticking. The drawback is that the evaporation can happen too rapidly. ''Moroccan cooks put a sprig of thyme in the hole to reduce it,'' said Kim Koenig-Ouassil, above, with her husband, Rachid Ouassil. The couple sell the tagines at their Moroccan store, Sheherazade. They are $35, $45 and $55. The small size holds food for four. Sheherazade, which also sells decorative tagines used only for serving, is at 121 Orchard Street (Delancey Street) on the Lower East Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEY, JOHN ROBERT
description: KENNEY-John Robert. Died in New York City on Christmas morning. Born January 1, 1927 to Catherine and John Kenney in Hinsdale, IL, he graduated as valedictorian from Hartford High School in Wisconsin. From 1945-1946, he served in the US army in Japan. He received his undergraduate degree in 1949 from Yale University, and graduated from Yale Law School in 1952. He began his career with the Cincincatti law firm of Taft, Stetinius, and Hollister and in 1955 joined the legal staff of the Travelers Insurance Company in Hartford, CT. When he retired in 1987, he was the Corporate Secretary and Associate General Counsel there. He served on the Board of Education and Democratic Town Committee in Canton, CT and was on the boards of the Greater Hartford Community Council and the Foreign Policy Association in Hartford. After retiring from Travelers, he began a second career as an addiction counselor at Smithers Addiction Treatment Center in New York. He is survived by his wife, Alice, his brother, Lawrence, his sister, Suzanne, five daughters, Elizabeth, Ann, Rebecca, Ellen and Catherine, and eleven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 1PM on Sunday, January 19 at The Yale Club of New York City, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: Backstage at the Pataki Inaugural
description: For the beginning of his third term, Gov. George Pataki plans a low-key inauguration today in Albany. That is understandable, given the state's current condition. New York faces a deficit of $2 billion in its current budget with another $10 billion next year. After two terms in office, he still has far more unfulfilled promises than accomplishments. And despite his drumbeat about how, after Sept. 11, 2001, we all have to weather these difficult times together, the truth is that the state of New York State is Mr. Pataki's mess, and he has now been granted one more term to clean it up.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: PRIEST PLEADS GUILTY TO CHILD RAPE A suspended Roman Catholic priest pleaded guilty to three counts of child rape and was sentenced to 12 to 15 years in prison. The priest, the Rev. Ronald H. Paquin, 61, has been in jail since May, when he was indicted. The victim said Father Paquin abused him from 1989 to 1992, starting when he was a 12-year-old parishioner at St. John the Baptist Church in Haverhill, Mass. Pleading for leniency, Father Paquin told the judge that he himself was abused by a priest as a teenager. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY HELPS FINANCE MOBILE HOME MAKER
description: The Oakwood Homes Corporation, a mobile home maker that filed for bankruptcy last month, won court permission for $215 million in financing from Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and other creditors. Berkshire Hathaway, Greenwich Capital Financial Products Inc. and Ranch Capital agreed to lend Oakwood $215 million to finance operations during its reorganization. Judge Peter J. Walsh of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Delaware approved the package at a hearing yesterday. Berkshire Hathaway will become Oakwood's largest shareholder when it emerges from bankruptcy, the company said. Oakwood's committee of unsecured creditors had sought an alternate $215 million package from other lenders. Oakwood filed for Chapter 11 protection on Nov. 15, citing slumping sales and an increase in bad loans.

Mr. Erdogan, the leader of the governing Justice and Development Party, was banned from holding political office after he read a poem that a court said incited religious hatred. He has signaled he will stand as a candidate in by-elections on Feb. 9, and if he wins a seat, he will become eligible to be appointed prime minister. (AP)

title: For a Meat Sauce, Soy Tries to Deceive
description: I am not a big fan of soy-protein meat pretenders, but as the French say, ''You mustn't die an idiot.'' So I tried Karma'Licious Veggie Bolognese pasta sauce, and was pleasantly surprised. It tastes like a rich meat sauce, with no soy flavor, and the texture could fool any card-carrying carnivore. Tama Herman, with tongue in cheek, named her company Mad Cow, and took a year to develop the sauce. She also makes a mushroom version, but the evidence of mushrooms was fleeting. The sauces are low in sodium as jarred sauces go (170 milligrams in a half-cup, less than half that of a typical jar). They are $7 for a 24-ounce jar at Westerly Natural Market, 911 Eighth Avenue (54th Street);

title: New Year's Time
description: Somehow it's always a surprise when the old calendar comes to an end and it's time to hang up a new one. It hardly seems possible that all those days, so empty and abundant just a year ago, have now been used up. To an electronic calendar -- the kind you find on computers and P.D.A.'s and cellphones -- all years are equal, just one screen among many, businesslike, circumspect, immaculate. When the electronic year quietly rolls over, there's no sense of transition, nothing like the act of taking down a kitchen calendar stained with the year's events, the months dog-eared and paper-clipped, the days pasted over with stick-on reminders for dental appointments and the dogs' heartworm pills. A calendar like that is full of emendations and erasures and crossings-out, a record of changes of plan and purpose. If only the past were as easily emended.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Forestry Company Fined In Migrant Deaths
description: The United States Department of Labor has levied a $17,000 fine against the company that employed 14 Central American forestry workers who were killed in September when the van they were traveling in to their jobs skidded off a bridge and plunged into the Allagash Wilderness Waterway. The farm labor contractor, Evergreen Forestry Services, based in Idaho, violated the law by failing to provide safe transportation, neglecting to register the van and the driver and not including the van on a departmental certificate. The department said it had also started proceedings to rescind the right of Evergreen Forestry to operate as a labor contractor. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: CHIQUITA IS CONSIDERING CLOSING PANAMANIAN UNIT
description: Chiquita Brands International Inc., the banana grower, said yesterday that it might close a money-losing Panamanian unit unless a union reconsidered the company's proposal to sell the business. Chiquita said it would cut off financing today to the Puerto Armuelles Fruit unit, which employs 3,200 workers and has accumulated about $90 million in losses in six years. Without the support, Armuelles can operate briefly but will be closed if an agreement cannot be reached, Chiquita said. A proposal to sell Armuelles' banana farms to a worker-owned cooperative was rejected by the Sitrachilco labor union, Chiquita said. The company, based in Cincinnati, said in September that it would reorganize or close Armuelles as part of its plan to cut $150 million in costs by 2004. Union officials in Panama could not be reached for comment.

description: The 8,500 flight attendants at Air Canada have approved a labor contract with the airline that will improve wages, pensions and job security. Flight attendants voted 68 percent in favor of the settlement, which was reached with the help of a mediator on Dec. 4 after a year of negotiations, said Ken Hopper, a spokesman for the Canadian Union of Public Employees. The contract includes a wage increase of 10 percent by Aug. 31, 2005, bringing the average flight attendant salary to 43,000 Canadian dollars ($27,200) a year, Mr. Hopper said. Flight attendants working for Air Canada in 2000, when it bought Canadian Airlines, will share a bonus of 25.8 million Canadian dollars, the union said.

title: Accounting Board to Review Treatment of Stock Options
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board said yesterday that it planned to decide in the first quarter of 2003 whether to overhaul rules that allow American companies to avoid treating stock options as a compensation expense.

title: Bilingual Nursery School
description: As mothers of bilingual toddlers, JENNIFER FRIEDMAN and JENNIFER WOODRUFF were determined to place their children in a nursery school that would foster both languages. While options abound in French and Italian, there were no programs in Spanish, they said, so they decided to create their own. Next fall, Ms. Friedman, a bilingual speech-language pathologist, and Ms. Woodruff, a former teacher and principal, will open La Escuelita on the Upper West Side.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Success of Jets' Offense Quiets the Critics of Hackett
description: There was the public spat with Vinny Testaverde. And the time Wayne Chrebet said the offense was so predictable that his friends could call the plays watching the game on television. Then there was Kevin Mawae wondering aloud why the Jets did not run more, and Chrebet saying he had almost no relationship with Paul Hackett, the Jets' offensive coordinator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, LEON A.
description: GREEN-Leon A. A long time resident of Pleasantville, died on Dec. 28, 2002 at home surrounded by his family. He was 89. Mr. Green was born on August 1st, 1913 in Paris, France to Bernard and Scarlet Houbermann Grunzveig. Leon attended New York City public schools and worked for the New York Times for twenty-eight years before retiring in 1989. Mr. Green served in the U.S. Coast Guard on the U.S.S. Evansville during WWII in the North Atlantic and the South Pacific. He attained the rank of Electricians Mate 3rd Class and received the American Area Campaign Medal and the Victory Medal. On July 8, 1950, he married Mary Ficorelli in Brooklyn, NY. Mr Green is survived by his wife Mary, his children Brad of Canton, OH, Andrea Woliver of Clinton, CT, Susan Green of Cortland Manor, NY, his brother Marvin of Lusby, MD, five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. He is predeceased by his sisters Lillian, Anne and Sara and a brother George. A funeral service was held at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name to the Westchester ARC, 121 Westmoreland Avenue, White Plains, New York, 10606 would be appreciated.

title: Beyond Backpacks
description: To the Editor:

title: The City Life; Surveying the Future at Ground Zero
description: Pushing in toward glittering window displays, holiday crowds are elbowing and gaping six-deep at intriguing depictions of what so far amount to nothing more than a shrewd bet on New York's ability to prevail, not just survive. ''Bad men knocked down the two big buildings and we can't put them back, but we're trying to find something better,'' a mother gently explains to a child. The lad stares through the window glass in confusion but obvious wonder, too. The seasonal mechanical elves and snow scenes may be missing. But look: there are delightfully glowing toy buildings, nine versions of them towering elegantly and defiantly enough above a miniature Manhattan to tease anyone with an imagination, particularly the city's young at heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'KEEFE, SR.
description: O'KEEFE-Sr. Maureen, Little Sisters of the Assumption. On December 29. Entered the Order in 1953. A lifelong dedication to the sick, poor and needy as a caretaker in the home. She obtained an MSW from Fordham and became skilled in law & government to better serve those without access to either in hopes to better their lives. She has touched many hearts. Remembrances to: Little Sisters of the Assumption, 100 Gladstone Avenue, Walden, New York 12586.

title: Nets Look to Activate Kittles and Childs
description: On a seven-game winning streak, the Nets will head out on the road beginning in Miami tonight with the possibility of activating Kerry Kittles and Chris Childs from the injured list.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: PHONE STAKE SOLD The BT Group has agreed to sell its 21 percent stake in SmarTone Telecommunications Holdings, a Hong Kong mobile phone company, for $1 billion Hong Kong dollars ($128 million) to Sun Hung Kai Properties , a Hong Kong real estate developer. The deal is part of an effort by BT to withdraw from markets around the world to focus on its core British customers and try to reduce debt. The transaction, valued at 8.50 Hong Kong dollars ($1.09) a share, will increase Sun Hung Kai's stake in SmarTone to 51 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: I.B.M. Adds $3.95 Billion to Pension Plan
description: I.B.M. said tonight that it had paid $3.95 billion in cash and stock to fill a deficit in its United States employee pension plan, its first contribution in seven years.

title: Tyco, After the Glitter and the Agile Math
description: So what does Tyco International look like without the accounting gimmickry? Tyco's chief executive, Edward D. Breen, acknowledged yesterday that it is not the fast-growth, high-margin collection of assets that L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive, loved to compare to General Electric.

title: Third Member of McGreevey's Inner Circle Resigns
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey's chief counsel resigned today, the third member of his inner circle to leave in recent weeks as Mr. McGreevey seeks to revitalize his administration after a bumpy first year.

title: A Military Draft, For Equality's Sake?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: CHIP INVESTMENT Samsung Electronics intends to invest $1.5 billion in technology for producing memory chips for computers and flash memory chips for mobile communications devices. Samsung, which also makes other electronics products, said that in several months it would begin making chips from 12-inch silicon wafers rather than the 8-inch wafers now in widespread use by semiconductor manufacturers. Samsung controls 30 percent of the world market in memory chips. Micron Technologies, in second place, has 17.2 percent and Hynix Semiconductor, at No. 3, has 13 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: On the Lower East Side, Italian Loud and Clear
description: SOMETIMES it feels like an endless task, plowing through the blizzard of new Italian restaurants that falls continually on New York. Unlike snowflakes, though, many of these restaurants seem identical, with interchangeable menus so soporific that it is only the blaring music that keeps you awake. But every once in a while a place draws away from the hypnotic procession.

title: A Military Draft, For Equality's Sake?
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Shift in Giants' Kicking Unit
description: The Giants' kicking units are like an improvisational comedic troupe, the characters changing constantly. Dan O'Leary, the long snapper, is out after tearing a thumb ligament, and Trey Junkin, a 41-year-old with 19 years of experience, is in just days before the playoff game Sunday against San Francisco.

title: Many Offers Hernandez Can Refuse
description: Jose Hernandez had the best year of his 10-year career last season and cannot find a team that will give him more than one year and $2 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, FREDA
description: ROSENBLATT-Freda. 102, died peacefully on December 31, 2002. Beloved aunt of Gerald, Sheldon, Wally and Irene and grand aunt of Kevin, Jamie and Jennifer. A lifelong piano teacher and original member of the Edwine Behre and Adamant Vermont Piano Schools. Secretary of the Theodore Leschetizky Association. Author of Physio Rhythmic Tonal Technique in Performance. Services Friday, 11 A.M. at the Plaza, 90th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An Arts Abroad article yesterday about an exhibition of American Indian art at the Muse des Beaux-Arts in Rouen, France, misspelled the surname of the museum director. He is Laurent Salom, not Salom.

title: Wall St. Down a 3rd Year, Leaving Fewer Optimists
description: Stocks in the United States plunged in 2002 amid fears of war and terrorism, a weak economy, rising oil prices and dozens of corporate scandals. It was the third consecutive annual decline, the first time that has happened in 60 years.

title: Kenya's Urgent Task
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Teenager Killed In Shooting
description: A 19-year-old man was killed and four other men were wounded in a shooting spree in the Bronx yesterday, the police said. They were shot on a street in Highbridge about 4 p.m., said a spokesman, Officer Louis Camacho. Two victims were taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center. One, the 19-year-old, was pronounced dead on arrival, said a hospital administrator, Charles Ignatius. The other, a man shot in the foot, was in stable condition by evening. The other three victims suffered gunshot wounds to the legs and drove themselves to Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, where they were in stable condition, said James Dunne, a hospital administrator. The police were investigating whether the shootings were the result of a feud. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Starting 3rd Term, Pataki Calls for Unity During Fiscal 'Crisis'
description: George Elmer Pataki was sworn in for his third term as New York State governor today, challenging New Yorkers to confront the state's dire fiscal problems with the same sense of unity they exhibited after the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Dissident's Strong Critique
description: The opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, criticized the government in the strongest terms she has used since her release in May from 19 months of house arrest. At a news conference, she said government officials ''who are trying to stop us from achieving reconciliation'' had organized a pattern of disruptions and harassment during her just-completed tour of Rakhine State, the fifth trip she has made to meet supporters since her release. She also criticized the government for failing to join her in promised talks. ''I suppose they are reluctant to do something because they do not think it will work in their favor,'' she said. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Two Chefs, One Broth
description: PATRICIA YEO and Pino Maffeo, above, share more than the knives, ovens and counter space at Pazo in Midtown: they each have the title of executive chef. That is a rarity in restaurant kitchens, where one single, strong hand is usually at the helm. Melissa Clark takes a look at several chefs who are willing to share the headaches, but also the power. For this job, micromanagers and control freaks need not apply.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Keansburg: Under Fire, Police Chief Exits
description: A police chief who came under fire for using a racial slur about black people retired early from the Keansburg Police Department effective yesterday. Police Chief Michael P. Kennedy used the slur on May 2 while giving orders to police officers, referring to a crowd of people as potential troublemakers. He apologized and lost about $9,500 in pay over the incident, but the N.A.A.C.P. and other community groups continued to call for his ouster. Efforts to find Chief Kennedy's home phone number were not successful; he was not at the station yesterday afternoon, said Patrolman Robert Sheehan, who answered a call seeking comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Richard Horner, 82, Broadway Producer
description: Richard Horner, a Broadway theater owner and producer who won a Tony Award for the 1974 revival of Eugene O'Neill's ''Moon for the Misbegotten,'' died on Saturday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAHY, CECELIA MARY FINN
description: FAHY-Cecelia Mary Finn. On December 28, 2002. Beloved wife of the late RADM Edward J. Fahy. Loving mother of Elizabeth Weeks of Fairfax, VA; Antoinette Gaylord of Coronado, CA; Kathleen Lindsay of Las Vegas, NV; Bridget Flint of Alexandria, VA; and RADM Edward J. Fahy Jr. of Jacksonville Beach, FL. Grandmother of eight, great-grandmother of eight. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Thursday, January 2, 2003, at The Main Chapel of the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, MD. Interment will follow at the U.S.N.A. Cemetery. For more information call Hardesty Funeral Home, 410-263-2222.

title: Hoppin' John Smiles on the New Year
description: IT'S not too late. Hoppin' John -- the pre-eminent rice and pea dish of the Western world, a nutritional marvel, the culinary touchstone of the African diaspora and a hangover remedy without equal -- needs only a few hours of preparation and can be on your table by this very evening. And what luck that is, especially for those of us who believe that 365 days of good fortune is all but guaranteed by consuming this starchy, brothy and faintly smoky dish of black-eyed peas and rice on New Year's Day.

title: The Neediest Cases; Comeback Kid Finding Help This Time Around
description: At age 7, Lennwood Pergerson decided that New York City was the place to be. ''On Wednesdays, my mother and I would ride the wicker-seat trains into New York,'' he recalled. ''We'd go shopping and eat at the Port Authority when it was fabulous. I couldn't get over it.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Unemployment Benefits
description: The State Department of Labor is accepting applications to extend residents' unemployment benefits beyond 39 weeks, in case Congress extends such benefits. Residents seeking the extension should contact their Labor Department center, officials said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Harmless Aim Above
description: Imagine the popular mockery in 1900 when the first bird census takers emerged on Christmas Day to present a pacifist alternative to the grand old ''Side Hunt'' -- the traditional killing binge in which Americans went festivally into the woods to compete in shooting as many birds and small animals as they could within the holiday. The Side Hunt faded, but the vision of the 27 pioneer bird counters led forth by Frank Chapman, an impresario of an ornithologist, has persevered unto a third generation. The current annual Christmas bird census involves a record-breaking 55,000 -- count 'em -- human participants. They are out across the nation and hemisphere bagging more than 50 million birds by eyeball.

title: Dutchess and Orange Counties Will Enforce Smoking Rules
description: Two counties in the Hudson Valley will begin enforcing new smoking restrictions in restaurants and workplaces on Wednesday.

title: President Makes Case That North Korea Is No Iraq
description: President Bush drew a sharp distinction today between the nuclear standoff with North Korea and his confrontation with Iraq, saying he was certain that weapons projects in North Korea could be stopped ''peacefully, through diplomacy.'' He said that Saddam Hussein, on the other hand, ''hasn't heard the message'' that he must disarm, or face military action.

title: Annan Opposes a Quick Attack on Iraq
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that Iraq has cooperated up to now with United Nations weapons inspectors, so it would be ''premature'' to take military action before inspectors report back on their investigations to the Security Council on Jan. 27.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKHOLDER, EDWIN V.
description: BURKHOLDER-Edwin V. Of Westport Point, MA, and formerly of New York City. Died on December 28, 2002, age 70. Beloved husband of Anne Maslen Burkholder, loving father to son, Joshua M. Burkholder, and his companion, Dannielle Thomas, daughter, Sarah K. Mullican, and her husband, Mark, daughter, Amy N. Burkholder, and her husband, Brian Long, and her daughter, Samantha N. Zucchi, and her husband, Fillippo. Loving grandfather to Joel, Katherine, Anne, Margaret, Maxwell, Anna, Alessandra, and Nicolo. Funeral Mass at Saint John The Baptist Church, Westport, MA, on Thursday January 2, 2003 at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to The Marion Public Library, 101 Library Street, Marion, KS 66861, The Westport Historical Society, PO Box 3031, Westport, MA., 02790 or The American Heart Association, Heart Gifts Processing, PO Box 3049, Syracuse, NY 13220-3049. For further information: Potter Funeral Home, Westport, MA.

title: KING PHARMACEUTICALS BUYS RIGHTS TO THREE MEDICINES
description: King Pharmaceuticals bought rights to three medicines from Aventis for $199.5 million to expand its line of brand-name prescription products. The purchase includes rights to the asthma treatments Intal and Tilade in the United States, Puerto Rico and Canada. King will be able to sell the third drug, the antibiotic Synercid, anywhere except Japan, the company said. Sales of the three brands totaled $66 million in the 12 months ended Sept. 30. Aventis will make the medications and supply them to King. Aventis, France's largest drug maker, could receive additional payments.

title: Dean Goes to Intelligence Unit
description: ROBERT HUTCHINGS, assistant dean at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, has been named chairman of the National Intelligence Council, which reports to the director of central intelligence and coordinates intelligence estimates for the president. Mr. Hutchings, 56, has been at Princeton since 1997 and will take a two-year leave of absence. A graduate of the United States Naval Academy, Mr. Hutchings previously worked at the National Intelligence Council as director of its analysis group and deputy national intelligence officer for Europe. He also served as a special adviser to the secretary of state.

title: Sports of The Times; Jets' Martin Sidesteps The Hype
description: CURTIS MARTIN may be the best running back in New York history. He may also be one of the most underrated athletes ever to play in a city that encourages and even creates celebrities. Martin does not make the gossip columns. He does his running on stairwells and empty practice fields.

title: South Opposes Pressuring North Korea, Which Hints It Will Scrap Nuclear Pact
description: North Korea strongly suggested today that it would withdraw from a treaty that prohibits it from making nuclear weapons, the latest in a series of fast-paced moves to remove its nuclear program from international controls.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Priest Pleads Guilty To Child Rape
description: A suspended Roman Catholic priest pleaded guilty to three counts of child rape and was sentenced to 12 to 15 years in prison. The priest, the Rev. Ronald H. Paquin, 61, has been in jail since May, when he was indicted. The victim said Father Paquin abused him from 1989 to 1992, starting when he was a 12-year-old parishioner at St. John the Baptist Church in Haverhill, Mass. Pleading for leniency, Father Paquin told the judge that he himself was abused by a priest as a teenager. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: The Bouquet, the Quack, the Lawsuits; Rejecting Long Island History, California Winery Fights a Duck Label
description: When Herodotus Damianos bought a failed winery in this hamlet in 1994 and named it Duck Walk, it was meant as a tribute to the days when a duck in the Hamptons was more likely to be waddling on a farm than bathing in truffle oil at a local bistro.

description: BERGSON-Jeanne H. In Palm Beach, FL, formerly of NYC. On December 30, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Arnold, devoted mother of Jane and Bob Hersh, Barbara and Stephen McGraw, loving grandmother of Jill, Andrea and Clyde.

description: The National Hockey League allows five minutes of overtime in the regular season, but the Islanders needed only 1 minute 36 seconds of the extra session tonight to end the calendar year on a winning note.

description: While architects have publicly proclaimed the World Trade Center site proposals displayed at the Winter Garden in Lower Manhattan as the greatest architecture show ever, many have privately expressed reservations about the designs' details, the handling of the competition and even the spotlight in which the contestants now stand.

Cardozo School of Law, 55 Fifth Avenue, 11th Floor, NY, NY 10003 or to the Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Avenue, Montgomery, AL. 36104.

title: Mary Wesley, Wry Novelist Of British Mores, Dies at 90
description: Mary Wesley, the popular British author whose sensual and often bitingly witty novels were not published until she reached her 70's, died on Monday in Totnes, Devon, her hometown in rural southwest England. She was 90.

title: A Catholic Crisis, Bestowed From Above
description: The nation's Roman Catholic priests will not miss the year 2002, their annus horribilis. A year ago, few could have imagined the disrepute into which the priesthood would slip following hundreds of sexual abuse cases involving clergy and a clueless response by bishops who misidentified exactly whom they were supposed to be shepherding.

title: Miami Content to Make Its Statements on the Field
description: Sixteen years ago Miami came here as the top-ranked team in the nation for a championship date against second-ranked Penn State. What did the Hurricanes do? They walked off the plane wearing battle fatigues and spent a week filling the air with enough bellicose smack talk to become the example for what is bad and wrong about college football.

description: We're beginning the new year in a deep fix.

title: Giants' Rushing Offense Becomes Progress at Work
description: The maturation of the Giants from a mediocre team to a playoff contender was incremental, subtle changes made over weeks and months. Their running game, once nonexistent, became functional and then a weapon, through technical adjustments rather than brute force.

title: Banks Comes a Long Way, and Full Circle
description: Like so many others who have gone on to distinguished athletic careers from tiny Belle Glade, Fla., Brad Banks grew up running in the area's thick muck, eating sugar cane and chasing rabbits.

title: U.S. Says 2 Companies Gave Data to China
description: The State Department has accused two leading American aerospace companies of 123 violations of export laws in connection with the transfer of satellite and rocket data to China during the 1990's.

description: There is a tradition among inmates serving long stretches in the nation's houses of correction. The new year is rung in with a little Dick Clark and a little jailhouse juice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, HERMAN L.
description: KAPLAN-Herman L. The Board of Trustees of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation is deeply saddened by the loss of Herman Kaplan (''Kappy''), an orginal Trustee of The Institute. Kappy was a cherished friend and benefactor to The Institute, and served as a dedicated Trustee for several decades. Our sincerest sympathies to his children, Ruth and Barry Singer, and Sheldon and Jeannie Kaplan. Barbara N. Kurshan, Chair of The Board Barry T. Zeman, President

title: Bush Directs Appeal for Information on 5 Sought Men
description: President Bush said today that he had directed the F.B.I. to issue the appeal for the public's help in tracking down five men who the authorities believe may have illegally slipped into the United States last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRENN, MCDONALD EDWARD, JR.
description: WRENN-McDonald Edward, Jr. A health physicist, died in his sleep in Baltimore, MD on December 19, 2002, and was buried in Norfolk, VA on December 26, 2002. In 1958, Mr. Wrenn received a B.A. with honors in physics from Princeton University, then entered the U.S. Navy, and served as a radiation protection officer. By 1966, he had received a Ph.D. from New York University in environmental health sciences, and a Master's Degree in sanitary science. He was a Professor of Environmental Medicine at New York University Medical Center, and held two positions at the University of Utah: Director of Radiobiology and Director of the Environmental Radiation and Toxicology Laboratory. Mr. Wrenn will be thoroughly missed by his wife: Elizabeth G. Sanford and her children; his sons: McDonald Edward Wrenn III, Edmund Tyler Wrenn; his nephew: Lawrence Clayton Freer III; his aunt, Margaret Mary Shield; his cousins Julie Marie Shield, Jerome Louis Karst; and all his friends and colleagues.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Brokerage Firm Acquired
description: One of France's biggest online brokerage firms, Fimatex, agreed to buy DAB Bank's Self Trade unit for 62 million euros ($65 million) to increase market share in its home market. The acquisition will be completed in the first quarter of 2003, subject to approval from regulators, Fimatex said. Fimatex, a unit of Socit Gnrale, said last month that it was in exclusive talks to buy the unit. Demand for online share trading has slumped after three years of stock market declines. DAB, which is based in Munich and is a unit of the HVB Group, bought Self Trade in 2000 for 461 million euros. In March, it wrote down the operation's book value by 100 million euros, to 170 million euros. Fimatex had 23 percent of the French market for online brokerage orders at the end of September. Its chairman, Vincent Taupin, said last week that buying Self Trade, the country's third-largest brokerage firm, would increase that to about 40 percent.

title: Oil Price Falls on Chance of More Output
description: The price of crude oil fell for a second day on speculation that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries would raise production to make up for a shortfall from Venezuela and take advantage of a 16 percent rally this month.

title: Preaching to Save Shoppers From 'Evil' of Consumerism
description: Some people may be upset that retail sales failed to meet expectations during the holiday season. Not Bill Talen.

title: Agnes Eisenberger, 79, Musicians' Manager
description: Agnes Eisenberger, a manager of classical musicians who was the president and owner of Colbert Artists Management, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 79 and lived in New York City and Pawling, N.Y.

title: France Holds Ex-Soldier Who Alerted Police to Weapons Cache at Paris Airport
description: The French authorities have detained the man who alerted the police on Saturday to a weapons cache in the car of an airport baggage handler at the main international airport here, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, DIANE B.
description: JACKSON-Diane B. The National Association of Social Workers, NYC, mourns the death of former Board Member. Her spirituality, courage, and candor inspires us. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to her family.

title: North Dakota Takes One For U.S. Team
description: On one hand, DEAN BLAIS, North Dakota's coach, wishes the United States team success in the world junior championships. On the other, he sure would like three of his best players back from that team in time for a key series against Colorado College this weekend.

title: Jets Helped Themselves, And Others
description: It's Christmas all over again at Jets headquarters, where the gifts are rolling in from teams the Jets helped with their victory Sunday over the Green Bay Packers. From the Cleveland Browns, who got into the playoffs as a wild card, Coach Herman Edwards received a bottle of Dom Prignon and a congratulatory letter. And Edwards doesn't even drink.

title: Threat Prompts Coast Guard To Ban Small Boats in Port
description: Responding to intelligence information from federal authorities about a possible terrorist attack on New York Harbor, the United States Coast Guard closed the Port of New York to pleasure craft yesterday and, along with the New York Police Department, increased harbor patrols.

title: Tackling Trade Center Design
description: While high-profile architectural firms have offered competing proposals for the World Trade Center site, students from Stuyvesant High School, just blocks from ground zero, have formed an after-school club to offer their own ideas. The club, Stuyvesant Rebuilds, met once a week last semester to discuss the architectural and environmental issues they might face in redesigning Lower Manhattan. Guest speakers included MITCHELL MOSS, a professor of urban planning at New York University, and HUGH O'NEILL, a former assistant executive director of the Port Authority. The students will build a model conforming to architectural guidelines from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation next semester and plan to submit it for review in the spring. Mark Glassman

title: National Briefing | West: California: Tobacco Companies Win Smoker Suit
description: The Philip Morris Companies and R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings won a lawsuit brought by relatives of a dead smoker, their first victory in the state after four straight losses in individual smoker cases. Judge Saundra Armstrong of Federal District Court in Oakland dismissed the suit after relatives of the smoker, Frank Robert White, finished presenting their case.

title: Salvatore Pepe, 93, Real Estate Developer
description: Salvatore Pepe, a major developer of commercial real estate in Westchester County, died on Sunday at a hospital in Greenwich, Conn. He was 93 and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

description: Bowdoin College already had the requisite alcohol-free dormitories, vegan entrees in the dining halls and state-of-the-art fitness facilities.

description: It's Sunday morning and the breakfast buffet at the Sofitel Suites -- one of five international hotels at this luxury 420-acre coastal resort -- is heaving with Brazilian families, all eagerly scooping scrambled eggs onto golden brown toast.

title: At the Top Of the Stairs, A Speakeasy Lives On
description: DIFFERENT people tell the story different ways, but it is set in the 1960's at Frankie & Johnnie's Steakhouse. To understand it, here's what you need to know about the restaurant, at 269 West 45th Street, which started in 1926 as a speakeasy during Prohibition: You walk two flights up to the dining room and once inside, it's another flight up to the restrooms. Got it?

title: New Laws Effective Today Won't Be Felt for a While
description: A host of new state laws take effect today, but New Yorkers may not notice many of them until income tax time in 2004.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: English-Language Paper To Close
description: Mexico City's leading English-language newspaper, The News, is closing, the victim of political change. Published daily since 1950, it was owned by the O'Farrill family, longtime backers of Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party. The party ran the country from 1929 until Vicente Fox won the presidency in 2000; the economic support it gave newspapers in exchange for political support has evaporated. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: For Clonaid, a Trail of Unproven Claims
description: Clonaid, the company that says it has produced the first human clone, previously made astonishing claims that were not substantiated. And the journalist whom Clonaid has appointed to authenticate its latest claim was once an intermediary between a couple who wanted cloning services and a scientist who wanted to provide them, the scientist says.

title: Out The Door
description: Merry Christmas. Get lost.

title: Chinese Official Fights Corruption, and Loses, for Now
description: When Tao Wucheng, a delegate to the national Legislature this year, was asked to investigate allegations of fraud and corruption at a private clinic in this provincial capital, he viewed it mostly as a headache. A much praised Communist Party official, he was living in a distant corner of the province, doing work on poverty relief.

title: On the Tightrope, Chef Plus Chef
description: IN professional kitchens there is a longstanding rule: there can be only one head chef. In French, the word chef means chief. And having two seems as harmonious as having two kings (remember the War of the Roses: two kings, one crown, much bloodletting?).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Dies
description: Aggreko, a British company that supplies power generators, said that its chief executive died on Monday in a car accident. The executive, Philip Harrower, 45, was driving in New Iberia, La., where Aggreko has its United States headquarters, when his BMW collided with a passenger train. Aggreko appointed its chairman, Philip Rogerson, to fill the chief executive post while it looks for a permanent replacement. Mr. Harrower joined Aggreko in 1983 and led an expansion into North America. The region now accounts for about half of the company's sales. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Subversion Charges for China Labor Leaders
description: Two prominent labor leaders who organized demonstrations on behalf of workers at a bankrupt state-run company in northeastern China have been charged with ''subverting state power,'' an offense that could result in a life sentence or the death penalty under Chinese law, a human rights monitoring group said today.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1  In his yearly report on the federal judiciary, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist called for higher judicial pay, more judgeships, and speedier filling of existing vacancies.

title: A Bargain Hunter's Best Friend
description: SEEMS only yesterday that the wine magazines were filled with snapshots of smirking winemakers announcing that their next vintage, all three barrels of it, would go for $300 a bottle. They didn't even have the decency to blush. Of course, why blush when packs of instant connoisseurs -- many of them dot-commers, bankers and businessmen of uncertain provenance -- were elbowing one another aside, waving fistfuls of green?

title: U.S. APPROVES ABBOTT LABORATORIES' ARTHRITIS DRUG
description: Abbott Laboratories won approval to sell the rheumatoid arthritis treatment Humira in the United States, the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday, allowing the company to challenge Amgen Inc. and Johnson & Johnson. Abbott developed the medication with the Cambridge Antibody Technology Group of Britain. Humira is taken as an injection every other week, while Enbrel from Amgen is taken twice a week. Johnson & Johnson's similar Remicade therapy is administered in doctors' offices.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DANA CORP., Toledo, Ohio, a maker of auto parts, sold real estate units that were part of Dana's equipment leasing and financing division to Goldman Sachs Group Inc., New York, the investment bank, for $73 million.

title: Ambassadors for Peace, Armed With Slapstick
description: When Joanna Sherman took her alternative theater company to Pakistan this spring to entertain Afghan refugees by dancing on stilts, one young boy in the crowd was not amused. ''He stared at us earnestly and asked, 'What is the meaning of this?' '' she recalled.

title: Artichoke's Cousin Gaining Recognition
description: Recipes for cardoons have been sneaking their way into cookbooks, including "The Babbo Cookbook" by Mario Batali (Clarkson N. Potter, 2002). Mr. Batali calls them one of his "fave vegetables" because of their "very sexy flavor." The cardoon is related to the artichoke and looks like celery you would not want to buy  grayish, with a kind of matte finish. It tastes of celery and artichokes, with a hint of licorice. The stalks should be peeled and cooked before using in gratins, pasta sauces or grilled with a buttery glaze. Cardoons are sold at Fairway and at Agata & Valentina for 89 cents a pound, at Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory for $1.29.

title: Discussing a Poetry Jam, While Pretty Close to Deaf
description: OUT of bed, you bourgeois slugs, for it's New Year's Day, and the Poetry Project's Marathon Reading at St. Mark's Church begins just about the time you are planning a late lunch.

title: Express Buses To Raise Fares A Dollar, to $4
description: The fare on city-subsidized private express buses will rise to $4 a ride from $3 in April as part of a deal to preserve the service on weekends and holidays, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETROFF, CRAIG JONATHAN
description: PETROFF-Craig Jonathan. Of New York City, passed away peacefully on December 27, 2002, at age 48. A man of exceptional energy, creativity, and managerial skills, Craig was the long-time general manager of Mesa Grill. During his many devoted years there, he helped to mold it into one of the finest restaurants in New York City. Before coming to New York in 1993, he managed other distinguished restaurants in Chicago, Los Angeles, Michigan, and San Francisco. Born in Marshall, Michigan, he is survived by his loving family, mother, Marjorie Hakes, father, Pondale Petroff, and siblings, Dale Petroff, Jayette Petroff, Kevin Petroff, and Shelley Petroff. He was educated in Michigan and graduated on The Deans' List from San Francisco State University (film). He was loved by his many friends and will be profoundly missed by all. A memorial service in New York City will be announced later. Contributions should be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of The Americas, New York, New York 10012, where he was a faithful volunteer.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Volcano Aftermath On Isle
description: About a third of the 450 residents of Stromboli, a southwestern Italian island, fled a day after an enormous wave caused by volcanic activity smashed boats and flooded homes. The volcano erupted on Monday for the first time since 1985, blasting rock into the sea and producing the wave. Three people were injured and flown by helicopter to hospitals in nearby Sicily, where Mount Etna, Europe's most active volcano, has been shooting out lava since quakes awoke it in October. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Mechanics At United Oppose a Cut In Pay Now
description: The machinists' union at United Airlines said yesterday that it opposed the airline's demand for short-term wage concessions because executives had not provided enough financial information for the union to make an informed decision and because the two sides had not engaged in back-and-forth negotiations.

title: Tapas Meet the Techno Set
description: SOME restaurants can make modesty seem like ambition. That's the case at Azafrn, an unassuming neighborhood spot, hardly more than a cafe, that aims to do the right thing by tapas. It's harder than it looks. In theory one of the most appealing dining styles ever created, the tapas formula is notoriously difficult to translate from Spain. Azafrn succeeds where many have failed. It's a modest success, totally in keeping with the atmosphere of the place.

title: On the Menu: A Burger, a Tantrum and a Secret Service Screening

So when word spread through Crawford this morning that President Bush was leaving his ranch for the first time in five days, there was not much mystery about where he was headed: The Coffee Station.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: TEENAGER KILLED IN SHOOTING A 19-year-old man was killed and four other men were wounded in a shooting spree in the Bronx yesterday, the police said. They were shot on a street in Highbridge about 4 p.m., said a spokesman, Officer Louis Camacho. Two victims were taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center. One, the 19-year-old, was pronounced dead on arrival, said a hospital administrator, Charles Ignatius. The other, a man shot in the foot, was in stable condition by evening. The other three victims suffered gunshot wounds to the legs and drove themselves to Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, where they were in stable condition, said James Dunne, a hospital administrator. The police were investigating whether the shootings were the result of a feud.

title: California Water Users Miss Deadline on Pact for Sharing
description: Efforts by water officials in Southern California failed today to reach a deal on water usage from the Colorado River before a midnight deadline. As a result, the Bush administration said it would cut flows from the river to the state's cities and farms beginning in January, making it the first time the federal government has imposed such a penalty.

title: TARGET SAYS GROWTH IN SALES WAS BELOW GOAL FOR MONTH
description: The Target Corporation, the discount retailer, said yesterday that sales at stores open at least a year were ''well above plan'' last week, but that growth remained far below its goal of 3 percent to 5 percent for December. Target, which is based in Minneapolis, said sales for the first four weeks of the month were strongest in the pharmacy, entertainment, toys, consumables and holiday categories. The weakest categories were men's and women's apparel and sporting goods. Target, with fiscal 2002 revenue of $39.89 billion, operates about 1,250 stores in 45 states. Its shares were unchanged at $30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANCOWITZ, GERASIMOVA IRINA, M.D., PH.D.
description: ANCOWITZ - GERASIMOVA Irina, M.D., Ph.D. passed away in Pamplona, Spain at the Clinic Universateria, after a long illness. She was born in St. Petersburg, Russia and obtained her medical degree at The First Medical School where she later became an Assistant Professor, lecturing on biology. At the same time, she was able to study, and obtain her Ph.D. in Human Genetics in 1978-one of the few in Russia to have such a degree at the time. She emigrated to the U.S. in 1979 and was able to be enrolled at the Psychiatric Institute at ColumbiaPresbyterian where she completed her four years of residency. She later qualified for, and received, her Board Certification in Psychiatry. Although she was a modest person who rarely spoke of her accomplisments, she greatly affected the lives of many people - relatives, friends and patients, to the point where her advice and counsel and healing techniques will remain with them for the rest of their lives. Irina was blessed to have a loving daughter Svetlana, who gave Irina a grandson, Enrique Jose, who was the joy of Irina's life in her last months. Thank you Irina for all you did for the people who were fortunate to have come under your wings. Memorial service for Irina on Friday, January 3 at 11 AM at St. Ignatius of Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street NYC. Burial at 2 PM Maimonides Cemetery, 90 Elmont Rd, Elmont, L.I., Cross Island Parkway to Belmont Race Track, 516-775-6222. At home, 4 PM on, after interment, at 314 Erskine Rd, Stamford, CT. Some 4,000 restaurants, including Nobu, shop at Korin, which has 5,000 items in stock, from 60-cent chopsticks to $22,000 sushi robots. But Korin also sells to the public. New wares include a linen noren, or curtain, in the picture's background, which shades from beige to pink and has abstract white cherry blossoms. It is 3 by 5 feet ($220). A silk obi, 12 by 70 inches ($139), can be used as a table runner. The green glass bowls, right, used at Nobu, are $10 (three inches) and $22 (six inches). One result of the trip is Cuban Black, a collection of seven tile murals for Ceramica Bardelli, an Italian ceramics maker. ''Cuba is such a bleached country,'' Mr. Toledo said. ''Nothing has been painted in 40 years.'' He called the country ''colorful in a black-and-white way.'' One Cuban Black (right), made of four tiles, each eight inches square, and selling for $203, shows a dog. Another, 18 tiles and $375, depicts a cat on a chair. Two other designs (18 tiles, $443; 24 tiles, $562) show plants. They are at available at Hastings Tile and Il Bagno Collection at 230 Park Avenue South (19th Street); (800) 351-0038.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: PARAMETRIC SHARES DROP AFTER REVENUE CHANGES Shares of the Parametric Technology Corporation , a maker of engineering software, fell as much as 23 percent yesterday after the company said it had booked $20 million to $25 million in sales earlier than it should have and would restate results. The sales came from maintenance contracts purchased in the last six years by companies to get technical help and updated programs, a spokesman, Tom Barth, said. The mistake was discovered after Parametric installed software that better calculates when to recognize such revenue. Companies and auditors are scrutinizing accounting practices in light of scandals at Enron and WorldCom . Software and computer-related companies like Liberate Technologies and Ariba have said in recent months that they would restate results or are reviewing the way they recognize revenue. Parametric shares fell 33 cents, or 13 percent, to $2.19.  (Bloomberg News)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Court Increases Protection Of Lynx
description: A federal judge has ruled that the Interior Department improperly applied the Endangered Species Act when it listed the Canada lynx in 2000 as threatened and not endangered, a category requiring much greater protection. The judge, Gladys Kessler of Federal District Court in Washington, ruled that the agency had failed to designate habitat critical to the survival of the lynx before deciding. She issued an order enjoining the agency from approving activities in the lynx's range until the agency had defined critical areas. Environmental groups hailed the ruling, saying it could delay logging, road building and mineral exploration projects. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Giuliani Papers To City Archives
description: The first four boxes of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's papers were delivered yesterday to the city's Municipal Archive. Mr. Giuliani originally sent his papers to a warehouse in Queens to be privately archived, in a move that was criticized by some historians. The boxes delivered yesterday contained Mr. Giuliani's schedules. They showed that before terrorists attacked the World Trade Center, Mr. Giuliani had planned to spend Sept. 11, 2001, meeting a longtime colleague, posing for photographs with new employees of the Law Department, voting in the Republican primary and attending the opening of ''The Flying Dutchman'' at the New York City Opera. title: Winter Fests: Embracing the Cold

Others, however, embrace the chill of winter, finding a certain satisfaction in the dropping of temperatures, the numbing of extremities and the stark beauty of a snow-swept landscape. For them, there is winter carnival, that celebration of all things cold. Here is a list of some of the best carnivals this winter in the United States and Canada. WENDY KNIGHT

title: RESTORATION HARDWARE STOCK FALLS 32% ON WARNING

Profit in the period, which ends Feb. 1, will be 25 to 30 cents a share, Restoration Hardware said. The company previously expected profit of as much as 42 cents a share after posting a loss of $11.6 million, or 42 cents, in the period last year. Sales growth will be less than forecast because of lower store traffic, poor weather and fewer holiday shopping days, the company said. The company disclosed the forecast after trading ended on Tuesday. Its stock price fell $1.60 yesterday, to $3.41.

The gel will be available in the United States before the end of March, Schering said. No new drugs to treat rosacea, a disorder that causes redness and pimples, have been introduced in more than 10 years, Schering said. The company's topically applied gel reduced skin inflammations in two final studies. About 14 million people in the United States have rosacea, the National Institutes of Health said. Other treatments include antibiotics.

title: Ian MacNaughton, a 'Monty Python' Director, Dies at 76
description: Ian MacNaughton, a British director who helped a group of young comedians shape ''Monty Python's Flying Circus'' into a watershed of absurdist television comedy, died on Dec. 10 in Munich after being injured in a car crash, The Times of London reported. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERNANDEZ, MIGUEL A.
description: HERNANDEZ-Miguel A., Esquire, 66, on New Year's Eve. Cherished brother to Marco and Dorsa. Beloved father, uncle, and brother-in-law who leaves a legacy of love, counsel and kindness to all. US Army Veteran, graduate of Brooklyn College, Magna Cum Laude, and Brooklyn Law. Tireless defender of the underserved of Williamsburg, Brooklyn and beyond. He will be sorely missed. Viewing at Knoll Funeral Home, Port Washington, New York.

title: Bashiqa Journal; A Sect Shuns Lettuce and Gives the Devil His Due
description: It proves tricky to extract a straight answer from the Yazidis when it comes to what, exactly, defines their sect.

title: Cloning Company Wavers on Promise of Baby's DNA Test
description: The company claiming to have produced the first human clone last week has backed away from a promise to provide genetic proof, even as it said a second clone would be born in Europe over the weekend.

title: The Best DVD's of 2002, in Which Most Directors Talk, Talk, Talk
description: You learn various things on a DVD. Dwarf-tossing was once a sport in England, or so it is said during a chat among filmmakers in one of myriad mini-documentaries on a special extended edition of Peter Jackson's ''LORD OF THE RINGS: THE FELLOWSHIP OF THE RING'' (New Line). Hands down the DVD of 2002, the four-disc set is full of asides, but it's at its best when Mr. Jackson and his two co-writers, Fran Walsh and Philippa Boyens, describe a new DVD version of the film with 30 minutes of added scenes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVA, FABIO
description: SILVA-Fabio. Antique dealer on the Upper East Side of Manhattan passed away on January 1, 2003, from complications of cardiac arrest, suffered while jogging in Central Park. Mr. Silva was born in Recife, Brazil on July 5, 1963. He received his Fine Arts degree from Hunter College. Mr. Silva began his career working at Schlesch and Garza Antiques, specializing in Northern European furniture. When Arne Schlesch retired, he continued his tradition by opening his own shop. Mr. Silva was a member of the Art and Antique Dealers League of America, Inc. At the time of his death, Mr. Silva was scheduled to officiate at the Winter Antiques Show as well as to be featured in a documentary on his life as a Brazilian antique dealer in NYC. Mr. Silva is survived by two sisters, Cristina and Ana and two brothers, Tarcizio and Cristiano of Brazil and the Asencio family of NYC. He will be greatly missed by those whose lives he has touched. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Saturday, January 4, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service private. Flowers can be sent to Rivero Funeral Home, 3344 SW 8th St, Miami, FL. 33135.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, BELLE
description: MILLER-Belle. Age 97. Beloved wife of the late Al and devoted mother of Deborah and the late Nancy. Also survived by her nephews Peter Miller, Stanley Barry Burros and their families. Graveside services today, 1 PM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: A Century Of Fords
description: It should be a big moment for car collectors -- the 100th anniversary of the Ford Motor Company. Ford is celebrating the anniversary by producing five centennial vehicles with collectors in mind. Only a few thousand will be made.

title: 36 Hours | West Palm Beach, Fla.
description: WEST PALM BEACH was long considered the negligible neighbor of the more glamorous Palm Beach, and indeed it was founded by Henry Flagler, the oil and railroad tycoon, for the workers who would build his seaside resort. In the 110 years since, West Palm Beach has had its ups and downs -- and plenty of each -- but lately it has come into its own. It has flourishing historic residential neighborhoods, many dating to the early 20th century, and its downtown, popularly referred to as Clematis Street, offers shops, restaurants, bars and clubs. A stone's throw away is the new City Place, a complex of shops and restaurants that avoided the enclosed-mall clich by straddling city streets. And south of downtown is Antiques Row, with a variety of restaurants. The Row attracts a range of shoppers, from well-known decorators, who fly in from New York and Los Angeles, to avid bargain scroungers. Downtown Lake Worth is just seven miles from Clematis Street, and the two make perfect bookends for a trip. Made famous in the 1981 movie ''Body Heat,'' Lake Worth still has a film noir feel, atmospheric and deceptively somnolent. BETH DUNLOP

description: By applying an artificially accelerated process of evolution in a test tube, a small biotechnology company has developed what it says are improved versions of two of the biotechnology industry's most successful products -- Remicade for rheumatoid arthritis and Rituxan for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

title: Iraq Says U.N. Teams Have Found No Weapons
description: The Iraqi government said today that United Nations weapons inspectors had thus far failed, after five weeks of visits to some 230 sites, to uncover any weapons of mass destruction or evidence of other prohibited programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMWELL, MAXWELL J.
description: BAUMWELL - Maxwell J. Age 87 of Marlboro, NJ. Died January 2, 2003 at his home in Marlboro, NJ. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he lived in Queens for 45 years, before moving to Marlboro 15 years ago. Mr. Baumwell was self employed as a typographer in New York, New York for 52 years, retiring in 1992. He was the President of the Typographers Association of New York, and the President of the International Typographers Association. He was inducted into the New York City School of Arts and Science Hall of Fame in 1987. He was an award winning pioneer in digital photo typography, and an avid painter. Mr Baumwell was predeceased by his beloved wife Julia in 1997. He is survived by his son Clyde, and daughter-in-law Robin Grey of Madison, NJ; his daughter Stephanie Gerstein of West Orange, NJ; his brother Earl of Great Neck, NY; and his three grandchildren, Kate, Blair and Alex. A graveside service will be held at 2PM on Friday, January 3, at Temple Beth El Cemetery in Neptune, NJ. For information Bloomfield Cooper Manalapan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, WILLIAM HARLOWE
description: MILLER-William Harlowe. 93, of Waverly Heights, Gladwyne, PA, died on December 31, 2002. Born June 9, 1909, in Plainfield, NJ, he was a former resident of Lloyd Harbor and Oyster Bay, NY, for 60 years. He graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1927, and Princeton University in 1931, where he played varsity football and crew. He served in the US Army Air Corps in WWII, retiring as a full Colonel, and was awarded the Legion of Merit. He then pursued a career with Central Hanover Bank, later Manufacturers Hanover Bank, retiring in 1974 as Senior Vice President. He was Mayor of the Village of Lloyd Harbor, NY, 1974-79 and was a Trustee of Bradford College. He is survived by his sons Ludlow, of Chestnut Hill, PA, and William H. Jr., of Norwalk, CT; a daughter Martha M. Massey, of Belmont, MA; six grandchildren, three great-grandchildren and a sister, Elizabeth Hood, of Newtown Square, PA. His wife of 63 years, Martha, died in 1997. A Memorial Service will be held at 2 PM, Tuesday, January 7, 2003 at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church, Gladwyne, PA. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Willian H. Miller '27 Wellness Fund, Phillips Exeter Academy, 20 Main Street, Exeter, NH 03833-2460.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Moody's Considers Downgrading XM Satellite
description: XM Satellite Radio Holdings is under review for a possible downgrade by Moody's Investors Service after the company, a subscription-radio service, said last week that it would borrow more. XM's $325 million in senior secured discount notes are rated Caa1, seven levels below investment grade. XM's $79 million in convertible subordinated notes are rated Caa3 and its $43 million in convertible, redeemable preferred stock is rated Ca. XM said last week that it would raise $450 million with new loans, deferral of other debt payments and sales of stock to partners, including General Motors. Without new financing, it is unlikely that XM will be able to operate beyond the first quarter of 2003, Moody's said. Shares of XM fell 2 cents, to $2.67.

title: Anxious And Obsessed With Image
description: Of all the notes sounded in the collective dream life of movies lately, the most insistent may be a faraway but steady thrum of fear. As we confront the threat of terrorism and the possibility of war at a time of economic uncertainty, which is the wiser course: to grit our teeth and imagine worst-possible scenarios, or to put on a happy face and reaffirm our faith in the future?

description: Even as the United States and Russia grow cautious about the cost of exploring other worlds, China is taking the first steps to challenging their longtime pre-eminence in space.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Police Kill Son Of Civil Rights Pioneer
description: Erin Eckford, 26, the son of an Arkansas civil rights pioneer, was shot to death by Little Rock police. The police said that Mr. Eckford refused to surrender the rifle he had been firing into the air and that he appeared to aim it at officers. The police said efforts to negotiate with Mr. Eckford and to disarm him with a beanbag gun had failed. Mr. Eckford's mother, Elizabeth, also of Little Rock, was among the nine black students who integrated Central High School in 1957 under the protection of federal troops.

title: Companies in U.S. Sing Blues As Europe Reprises 50's Hits
description: European copyright protection is expiring on a collector's trove of 1950's jazz, opera and early rock 'n' roll albums, forcing major American record companies to consider deals with bootleg labels and demand new customs barriers.

title: Revitalized McNabb Practices With Eagles
description: Donovan McNabb strode through the hallways of the Philadelphia Eagles' practice facility, showing no signs of the fractured ankle sustained a little more than six weeks ago or the limp that his coach, Andy Reid, had described. As he went from the locker room to the auditorium, he led a parade of reporters and public relations staff, and he left them in the dust.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Parametric Shares Drop After Revenue Changes
description: Shares of the Parametric Technology Corporation, a maker of engineering software, fell as much as 23 percent yesterday after the company said it had booked $20 million to $25 million in sales earlier than it should have and would restate results. The sales came from maintenance contracts purchased in the last six years by companies to get technical help and updated programs, a spokesman, Tom Barth, said. The mistake was discovered after Parametric installed software that better calculates when to recognize such revenue. Companies and auditors are scrutinizing accounting practices in light of scandals at Enron and WorldCom. Software and computer-related companies like Liberate Technologies and Ariba have said in recent months that they would restate results or are reviewing the way they recognize revenue. Parametric shares fell 33 cents, or 13 percent, to $2.19.

description: CHESSLER-Lila. On January 1, 2003. She is survived by her husband Seymour, children Wayne (Valarie) and Andrea and brother Mitch (Roz). title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: LEBANON: FEAR OF OFFENDING SAUDI ARABIA The government banned a television program on Saudi Arabia to protect its relations with the kingdom, where about 150,000 Lebanese work, Prosecutor General Adnan Addum said. He also said that Saudi Arabia had sent a letter to the Lebanese foreign ministry "on this matter." The private station New Television canceled the program — a discussion of the general situation in Saudi Arabia and the Saudi opposition — under pressure from the Lebanese government, which cut the station's satellite link.    (Agence France-Presse)

title: Search for Bigfoot Outlives The Man Who Created Him
description: No region in the country has a lower percentage of churchgoers than the Pacific Northwest. But ask people here about the existence of a camera-resistant, grooming-challenged, upright biped known as Bigfoot or Sasquatch and the true believers shout to the misty heavens in affirmation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERBUSH, SEYMOUR HERBERT
description: SILVERBUSH-Seymour Herbert, on December 29, 2002. Born August 12, 1916, in NYC. Retired independent businessman, union organizer, and veteran of WWII. Beloved husband of Elsie Wagner Silverbush for 62 years. Devoted and loving father of Jeffrey and Michael, and father-in-law of Andrea, Lenore and Aliza. Cherished grandfather of Rhona, Lori, Robert, Mark, Benjamin and Adina, and grandfather-inlaw of George and Tom. Loved and respected by all who knew him, for his generous spirit, egalitarian values, warmth, wisdom and humor. He will be deeply missed and always remembered.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: FEWER MINERS DIE ON THE JOB The number of American miners killed on the job in 2002 fell to 67, the lowest number since the government began keeping records in 1910. The Mine Safety and Health Administration said 27 of the deaths were in coal mines, down from 42 in 2001, and 40 were in copper, gold, stone and other types of mines, up from 30 in 2001. Kentucky had the most coal mine deaths, 9. (AP)

title: Germany Takes Center Stage
description: History could hardly have scripted a more highly charged moment for Germany to commence a two-year term on the United Nations Security Council. As Berlin takes its seat this week, the council is moving toward momentous decisions about Iraq. Only a few months ago, Chancellor Gerhard Schrder ran for re-election declaring his firm opposition to war with Iraq. Now, for the good of Germany and the United Nations, he must set aside campaign politics and cast Germany's votes on this critical issue on the merits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLEY, PAUL W.
description: KELLEY-Paul W., 45. Of Edison, NJ on January 1, 2003. Husband of Kristina Stankowitz Kelley. Father of Dylan Kelley. Son of Kay and William Kelley. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERSHEL, IRVING
description: TERSHEL-Irving. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Irving Tershel, beloved father of Ruth Mirvis, and father-in-law of Theodore. Ruth and Ted are cherished friends of UJA-Federation who have expressed their devotion to Jewish and humanitarian causes in countless ways. Ruth currently chairs the Interboro division of the Women's Campaign and Ted is a recent past chair of the Lawyers Division. We extend our deepest sympathies to the Tershel family; to Ruth and Ted; their sons, Jason and Eric; their daughter, Michal and her husband, Jonathan Kestenbaum; & their daughter, Julia Rachel. May his memory be a blessing. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. Joan Ginsburg, Chair of the Women's Campaign

description: As an 11-year-old playing youth football, Jeremy Newberry would receive a dollar from his father every time he knocked an opponent down and the father could see the bottom of the player's cleats.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: LUCENT REACHES SETTLEMENT WITH FORMER EXECUTIVE Lucent Technologies said yesterday that it had reached a settlement in a breach-of-contract claim with Nina Aversano, a former president of sales for North America, ending a dispute over money she claimed Lucent owed her. A separate whistle-blower claim by Ms. Aversano under the New Jersey Conscientious Employee Protection Act — in which she contended that she was forced to resign in 2000 after arguing in a detailed presentation that sales targets were unrealistic — was dismissed. Ms. Aversano's assertions helped fuel a debate over "channel stuffing," a business practice of shipping products not to real customers but to distribution channels. A spokeswoman for Lucent, the large maker of communications equipment, declined to comment. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed.    Simon Romero (NYT)
