title: Weekender | Andes, N.Y.
description: I FOUND Andes by mistake -- I drove into the village and felt an immediate affinity with the place,'' said Tom Munro, a Manhattan fashion photographer who shoots for Vogue and Details. He made a wrong turn that day three years ago, but now he owns a home in Andes, a town in Delaware County, N.Y., where unblemished farmland and rolling meadows, juxtaposed against the panoramic backdrop of the Catskill Mountains, create a landscape both pastoral and majestic.

title: Commercial Developer Jumps Into Home Rental
description: Forest City Ratner Companies, known for developing large commercial and hotel projects including the $1 billion MetroTech Center in Brooklyn and the Harlem Center, an $80 million mixed-use project on West 125th Street, is dipping into the Manhattan residential market.

title: MORGAN RESOLVES DISPUTE ON ENRON
description: J. P. Morgan Chase announced yesterday that it would receive about $580 million from insurance companies as part of a settlement resolving one of the most contentious disputes touched off by Enron's collapse.

title: A Bad Bet
description: Pro-gambling lobbyists across the country cannot believe their good fortune. The worst budgetary outlook in decades has left plenty of desperate state governments once again vulnerable to being snookered by the gambling lobby's alluring ''something-for-nothing'' sales pitch, the fiscal equivalent of a comped buffet. States should know better by now. Opposing an ill-advised expansion of legalized gambling will be a true test of leadership for governors and state legislators nationwide.

title: Struggling Seminary Is Leasing 3 Buildings to Columbia
description: Faced with a shrinking endowment, Union Theological Seminary plans to lease three of its buildings to its neighbor, Columbia University, for 49 years. It also plans to transfer its million-volume library collection to Columbia.

title: Scientists Say Orangutans Can Exhibit 'Culture'
description: Orangutans, those red-haired knuckle-dragging apes, are loping today into the upper echelons of the primate hierarchy. According to research reported in the journal Science, they exhibit what was until very recently considered a uniquely human attribute, culture.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sport Supplier Meets Goal
description: The global sportswear and sports equipment maker Adidas-Salomon met its 2002 targets of 5 percent growth in sales and a 5 percent to 10 percent gain in net profit, the company said. Sales rose to $6.7 billion in 2002. At the same time, the company said that its TaylorMade-Adidas Golf unit had acquired the Maxfli brand of golf balls and accessories from the Dunlop Slazenger Group for an undisclosed price. With the Maxfli acquisition, TaylorMade-Adidas Golf aims to strengthen its position as a fully integrated golf company. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSCHMANN, LUCILLE A.
description: BUSCHMANN - Lucille A. Loving widow of the Honorable Albert H. Buschmann Sr, Justice of the New York State Supreme Court, died December 27, 2002. Beloved mother of Mary Lu Prescott, Albert Buschmann, Angele Gilroy, Dina Buschmann and Lois Buschmann. Adored grandmother of five. Loving sisterin-law of Regina Grange and many nieces and nephews. A funeral mass will be held at 10:00 AM Monday, January 6, at Saint James Roman Catholic Church, 80 Hicksville Road, Seaford, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hospice of the Panhandle, 122 Waverly Court, Martinsburg, WV 25401. For info. Jefferson Chapel Funeral Home at 304-725-5321.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Criminal Inquiry In Tanker Mess
description: As clumps of crude oil from a tanker that foundered off the northern coast of Spain in November drifted ashore along the beaches of southwest France and headed north, the maritime authority in the northwest port city of Brest said it was opening a criminal investigation to establish responsibility. The French Society for the Protection of Birds reported that 170 seabirds had been found dead along the coast of Aquitaine, while about 100 live birds covered with oil were recovered and sent to the city of Nantes for treatment. The authorities said oil slicks from the tanker, the Prestige, had been driven toward the French coast by strong westerly winds, threatening some of France's most beautiful Atlantic beaches. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Trade Surplus Rises
description: Shipments of vehicles, semiconductors and electronic equipment pushed South Korea's trade surplus to $10.8 billion in 2002. The Ministry of Commerce said Tuesday that exports totaled $162.82 billion, up 8.2 percent from 2001, while imports cost $152.02 billion, up 7.7 percent. The United States was the biggest market, spending $31.4 billion on Korean products, while China ranked second with imports of $22.8 billion. Two-way trade rose sharply in December with exports of $15 billion, up 27.4 percent from December 2001, and imports of $14.46 billion, up 28 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: CONGO: THOUSANDS FLEE NEW FIGHTING Tens of thousands of people have been displaced as fighting has flared in the northeast Ituri region despite a truce signed there this week by three rebel groups. Displaced civilians have taken refuge in camps set up by local churches or have been taken in by local residents. Aid organizations were distributing food and medical supplies to the refugees.    (Agence France-Presse)

description: US Airways and GE Capital have reached a settlement in which GE Capital has agreed to provide additional financing in exchange for a small equity stake in US Airways.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Fundtech Cuts Jobs And Combines Units
description: Fundtech Ltd., whose software helps banks transfer money electronically, said today that it would cut jobs as it combined units that handle development, professional services and customer services. Fundtech, which has headquarters in Ramat Gan, Israel, and Jersey City, named Michael Sgroe as chief operating officer. He will run the combined groups, the company said. Mr. Sgroe was previously executive vice president and president of Fundtech's United States products and operations division. The release did not specify the number of job that would be cut. The move will help Fundtech run its global operations more efficiently, trimming expenses by $500,000 a quarter beginning the first quarter of 2003. Fundtech said it would have costs of about $900,000 in the fourth quarter related to the restructuring. Shares of Fundtech, controlled by Clal Industries and Investments, which is based in Tel Aviv, have dropped 19 percent in the last year as reduced demand forced the company to sell its software for less. A Fundtech spokesman, George Ravich, did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment.

Does Broadway Still Meet 42nd St.?

Jessica Lariviere, at the wheel, seemed to be talking to herself, and in the back, Roberta Loscalzo kept glancing from the road to a laptop computer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTELSMANN, ELIZABETH C.
description: BERTELSMANN - Elizabeth C. The administration, trustees, and alumni/ae of Bard College deeply mourn the passing of long-time friend and colleague Elizabeth Bertelsmann, who for more than 35 years was a beloved and respected member of the Bard community. A photographer, author, teacher, and generous supporter of the College, Lilo, along with her late husband, Heinz, demonstrated a profound commitment to education and community responsibility to generations of Bardians. She made a deep and lasting impact on all who knew her and will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. By the request of her family, there will be no memorial service. A memorial concert dedicated to the Bertelsmanns will be held at Bard College at a date to be announced. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, MILTON
description: PETERS-Milton. August 20, 1920 to December 31, 2002. AKA ''The Senator''. Loved his family, animals, good jokes, progressive politics, history, walking and observing the human condition. A smart, kind, thoughtful and gentle soul. We will miss him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOR, NICHOLAS J.
description: CONNOR-Nicholas J. Nicholas J. Connor, age 68, died peacefully at his home in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico on December 26, 2002 after a long illness. Son of the late Marie and Nicholas Connor of Scarsdale, beloved husband of Irma Cerezo. He is also survived by seven children, ten grandchildren and his brother and sister.

title: Parcells Says Cowboys Partnership Can't Fail
description: A coach with a history of success joined a team with a history of success today. But what about the future? The coach is Bill Parcells, who ended his three-year retirement from coaching, and his new team is the Dallas Cowboys. Everyone around here expects his comeback to return the team to glory. Parcells seemed determined and optimistic.

title: Two Exes, One House
description: WHEN Mary Alice Kellogg and her husband came to a parting of the ways 15 years ago, neither wanted to part with their weekend home, a two-bedroom bungalow out on Long Island. ''We'd had it for eight years and we both really liked it and didn't want to go through the trauma of selling, so we agreed to split it fifty-fifty -- the weekends, everything,'' said Ms. Kellogg, a New York based writer and editor who has since remarried. ''It was a healing and nice place for me. Perhaps it was that way for my former husband, too.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: China Unicom Replaces Executive Director
description: China Unicom Ltd., the nation's second-largest mobile phone company, replaced its executive director, Tan Xinghui, with Ye Fengping. Mr. Tan, also a vice president of the Hong Kong-listed company, resigned yesterday, China Unicom said, without giving a reason. The company statement did not give any details about Mr. Ye. Mr. Tan's departure is the second in six months at the director level for China Unicom, whose share price dropped 38 percent last year, the third-worst performer on the benchmark Hang Seng index.

title: Parcells Takes Job As Cowboys' Coach
description: Declaring ''we can't fail,'' Bill Parcells took over as coach of the Dallas Cowboys, hoping to revive the fortunes of a losing franchise once widely referred to as America's Team. The Cowboys' owner and general manager, Jerry Jones, is, like Parcells, a strong-willed personality, but he brought Parcells, the former Giants, Patriots and Jets coach, out of retirement with a promise of wide control over personnel in a four-year contract.

description: To the Editor:

title: Boeing Rejects Complaints on Leaks to China
description: The Boeing Company today rejected State Department complaints that it failed to guard against technology leaks to China, calling security concerns a priority for the company and promising negotiations to resolve the matter.

title: Talk of a Rescue Bid Buoys Fiat's Shares
description: Shares of Fiat surged today as investors anticipated that Roberto Colaninno, the Italian entrepreneur, would make a bid to rescue the company with an injection of fresh money.

title: ALLEGHENY ENERGY SELLS 2 BUSINESSES TO RAISE CASH
description: Allegheny Energy, a utility owner that is trying to refinance debt to avert bankruptcy, said yesterday that it had sold two Kentucky units to Constellation Energy for $22.3 million in cash. The sale frees up $54 million that Allegheny posted to guarantee power and natural gas transactions made by a unit, Alliance Energy Services, for clients, a spokesman said. Allegheny also gets back $6 million in working capital it provided to Alliance, he said. Alliance and Fellon-McCord & Associates, the other unit Constellation bought, assist manufacturers and other businesses in wholesale gas and power purchases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, WINIFRED (NEE TRIMBLE)
description: CARTER - Winifred (nee Trimble), 70, Died after a long illness on Tuesday, December 31, 2002 in Houston, TX. She was born on April 12, 1932 in New York City, NY and attended Bryn Mawr and the Sorbonne. A life long conservationist, Mrs. Carter served on the Board of the World Wildlife Fund during the 1980s. She fostered conservation biology at Texas A&M and at Duke University's Primate Center. An inveterate traveller and collector, Winnie was an avid supporter of the arts and the outdoors. She leaves a legacy of passion for nature and art. Mrs. Carter was preceded in death by her parents, Richard Trimble and Winifred Loew Trimble (nee Parkinson) and her brother, Richard Trimble, III. She is survived by her daughter Helen Runnells DuBois and her husband, Raymond, of Washington D.C.; son, Clive Runnels III, and his wife, Kathryn, of Austin, TX; sister, Mary Ann Parkins Hache, and her husband, Jean, of Paris, France and three grandchildren, Clive Runnels IV, Pierre DuBois and Mary Chester DuBois. A memorial service will be conducted at 2PM Saturday January 4, 2003 at Christ Church Cathedral, 1117 Texas Ave, Houston, TX 77002. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made in memory of Winnie Carter to St. Andrews Episcopal School, 1112 West 31 St, Austin, TX 78705 512-452-5779 or the Smithsonian National Zoo, 3001 Connecticut Ave NW, Washington DC c/o Clint Fields, 202-673-4653. Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, 1010 Bering Drive, Houston, Texas 77057.

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: CGI ACQUIRES COGNICASE FOR $210 MILLION Canada's biggest computer services company, the CGI Group , will buy a smaller rival, Cognicase Inc., after raising its offer to 281 million Canadian dollars, or $180 million. The agreement comes a month after CGI offered 265 million Canadian dollars ($170 million) in cash and stock in a hostile bid for Cognicase. CGI, which is based in Montreal, wants to expand in the United States and its purchase gives it access to Cognicase clients like the National Bank of Canada and the New York City government. Under the revised offer, CGI will pay 4.50 Canadian dollars ($2.87) in cash or shares for each share of Cognicase. CGI will also assume 48 million Canadian dollars ($30 million) in debt, a CGI spokesman, Ronald White, said yesterday. Cognicase is also based in Montreal.    (Bloomberg News)

title: Senate Report Says Rubin Acted Legally in Enron Matter
description: A report by the staff of a Senate panel has concluded that Robert E. Rubin ''did not act contrary to law'' in the weeks before Enron collapsed by suggesting to the under secretary of the Treasury that he urge major credit-rating agencies to delay issuing a downgrade of Enron.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: POLICE KILL SON OF CIVIL RIGHTS PIONEER Erin Eckford, 26, the son of an Arkansas civil rights pioneer, was shot to death by Little Rock police. The police said that Mr. Eckford refused to surrender the rifle he had been firing into the air and that he appeared to aim it at officers. The police said efforts to negotiate with Mr. Eckford and to disarm him with a beanbag gun had failed. Mr. Eckford's mother, Elizabeth, also of Little Rock, was among the nine black students who integrated Central High School in 1957 under the protection of federal troops. (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Software Budgets Will Decline, Report Says
description: Two months after saying they would spend more in 2003, information technology managers now say they plan to cut computer and software budgets this year amid renewed concerns about the economy, the Goldman Sachs Group said yesterday. A survey of 100 information-technology managers found that computer-related spending in the United States would decline 1 percent in 2003, Goldman said in a report. In October, the group's members said they planned to spend 2 percent to 3 percent more this year. Worry over the possibility of war with Iraq also led those surveyed to become more negative about their spending plans, Goldman said. Companies in manufacturing, telecommunications and finance are cutting the most, both in the United States and abroad. Security software and computers, and operating-system programs made by Microsoft will sell well in 2003, Goldman's analysts said. Demand for personal computers and database software will be less.

His sense of humor made us laugh; his smile made us smile. He was an athlete, a musician and an artist, and most of all, a thoroughly wonderful young man. And the best was yet to come. title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: BUDGET DEFICIT WIDENING Connecticut's current fiscal year deficit may now be as high as $650 million, the state's chief financial official, Marc S. Ryan, said yesterday, 30 percent higher than the $500 million deficit state lawmakers have been trying to resolve for several weeks. Mr. Ryan blamed decreasing income tax revenue. Nancy Wyman, the state comptroller, also released figures that she said showed Connecticut ending the fiscal year on June 30 at $482.3 million in the red, up by $67.4 million from an estimate last month. Gov. John G. Rowland and lawmakers are still at odds over how to reduce the $13.2 billion budget.

description: The police arrested a man yesterday on charges that he intentionally ran down an 18-year-old Queens man with his car after two groups of young men argued on a street in Astoria, investigators said. According to the police, the suspect, Felix Pacheco, 25, of Brooklyn, ran over Sidney Guerrero about 2 a.m. Wednesday. The police said Mr. Pacheco then drove off with a companion, Luis Rodriguez. Mr. Guerrero, who worked for the United Parcel Service, died at the scene. Mr. Pacheco was charged with second-degree murder and leaving the scene of an accident; Mr. Rodriguez, 20, was charged with leaving the scene of an accident. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Appeal Rejected In Treason Case
description: The Supreme Court rejected an appeal against death sentences handed down in September against a son-in-law and three grandsons of the country's former strongman, U Ne Win, who died on Dec. 4. The defendants were convicted of treason for trying to overthrow the military junta that has ruled since Mr. Ne Win stepped down in 1988. A defense lawyer said he would submit a ''special appeal.'' It is also possible that the death sentences will be commuted since Myanmar rarely carries out executions. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Reaches Settlement With Former Executive
description: Lucent Technologies said yesterday that it had reached a settlement in a breach-of-contract claim with Nina Aversano, a former president of sales for North America, ending a dispute over money she claimed Lucent owed her. A separate whistle-blower claim by Ms. Aversano under the New Jersey Conscientious Employee Protection Act -- in which she contended that she was forced to resign in 2000 after arguing in a detailed presentation that sales targets were unrealistic -- was dismissed. Ms. Aversano's assertions helped fuel a debate over ''channel stuffing,'' a business practice of shipping products not to real customers but to distribution channels. A spokeswoman for Lucent, the large maker of communications equipment, declined to comment. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Children Of Dance Become Broadway Babies
description: BRENDA the prom queen loves Eddie the prom king, but Eddie wants to play the field. Brenda and Tony fall gradually into heedless love. Judy and James, high school sweethearts, love each other, too, though their forever is cut short by James's death in Vietnam. Eddie and Tony come back from the war, broken spiritually and physically. But the boys and girls portrayed in the Broadway musical ''Movin' Out'' find their way back into something like the lives they lived before, gaining a measure of peace for themselves and one another by the end of the show.

title: MERCK WINS APPROVAL TO EXPAND USE OF ASTHMA MEDICINE
description: Merck said yesterday that it had won federal approval to sell its Singulair asthma medication as a treatment for hay fever. Merck said that with the new market, sales of the medicine could top $2 billion this year. As many as 35 million people in the United States suffer reactions that cause inflammation in nasal membranes, often leaving them with a runny nose, according to the National Institutes of Health. This seasonal rhinitis, or hay fever, is usually not serious, but it can worsen asthma and conditions like sinus infections, the institutes said. Singulair sales rose 7 percent, to $1.1 billion, in the first nine months of last year. The new allergy claim will allow Singulair to compete with Claritin, made by Schering-Plough.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDONESIA: EXPORTS LAG FORECASTS Indonesian exports rose 6.9 percent, to $4.1 billion, in November, far less than most economists expected, as a sluggish global economy and domestic concerns offset rising prices for Indonesian oil. Labor unrest, rising wages, a strengthening currency and higher shipping costs resulting from the October bomb explosion in Bali have combined to dampen demand for Indonesian goods. And while inflation in November slowed to 10 percent, price increases that the government imposed yesterday for heavily used fuels like gasoline and kerosene have some economists concerned that consumer spending could soon go the way of exports, spelling trouble for Indonesian economic growth. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Car Parts Maker Expands
description: A leading maker of car parts, Robert Bosch, bought a 13.35 percent stake in Buderus, a maker of boilers, for about 185 million euros ($191 million), reviving speculation about a takeover of Buderus. Deutsche Bank sold Robert Bosch its 7.5 percent stake for about 100 million euros, Deutsche Bank said. That values Buderus at about 1.4 billion euros, or 22 euros a share. Bosch has said it wants to reduce dependence on the car industry and expand in consumer products, where it makes about a quarter of its revenue. The German company abandoned an attempt to buy Buderus a year ago after talks with shareholders broke down.

The German company abandoned an attempt to buy Buderus a year ago after talks with shareholders broke down.

title: BUSH TO PROPOSE SWEEPING CHANGES IN MEDICARE PLAN
description: With the new Senate majority leader as a powerful ally, President Bush will propose sweeping, long-term changes in Medicare later this month when he urges Congress to provide prescription drug benefits for the elderly, administration officials say.

title: Student Arrested in DirecTV Piracy Case
description: A 19-year-old University of Chicago student was arrested in Los Angeles today and charged with stealing trade secrets from DirecTV, the nation's leading satellite television provider.

title: Shooting Victim Yelled in Vain for Help, Witnesses Say
description: Ernesto Reyes spent his final New Year's Eve the way he spent much of his life -- partly with his mother in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, but mostly at the homes of various relatives and surrogate guardians. The stopgap arrangement had worked all right for 15 years, but in the dawning hours of 2003, everything collapsed.

title: Senator Edwards Enters Race for President
description: Senator John Edwards of North Carolina said yesterday that he intended to run for president in 2004, promising that he would ''champion the cause of regular people,'' while harshly condemning President Bush's White House as being ''run for the benefit of insiders.''

title: Venezuela Outlook: Up and Down
description: With his visit to Brazil, a radiant President Hugo Chvez assured the world today that he would survive a month-old strike aimed at forcing him from power. But back home, Venezuelans were left to wonder if their country, as they know it, might not.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Members Of Muslim Group Arrested
description: The police arrested 14 leading members of a banned political Islamic group, the Muslim Brotherhood, accusing them of reviving the group's activities among university students, security officials said. Dr. Essam al-Erian, a senior leader in the group, said the government was worried about possible demonstrations against an American-led war against Iraq. The government has accused the Brotherhood, which seeks to establish an Islamic state in Egypt through constitutional means, of organizing large student demonstrations last April against Israeli actions in the West Bank. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Associated Press to Move From Rockefeller Center
description: The story of New York is written in the ever-changing names of its skyscrapers.

title: We Don't Invade Iraq. Then What?
description: For some time now, the debate over Iraq has focused on a potential war and what should follow it. What is striking is how little thought appears to have been given to the other possible outcome, the one the rest of the world continues to push and the Bush administration itself professes to favor: a nonmilitary settlement. In short, all the talk has been about the day after a war. But what about the day after a non-war?

title: Where Hills Are Alive (Rivers, Too)
description: OUTSIDE a village on the west coast of Mexico, a woman was doing her laundry with neighbors. Some pretty gourds floated by in the stream and she reached for one. Suddenly she vanished under the water. When she resurfaced, surprised but refreshed, the neighbors were gone. Years, not seconds, had passed.

title: Partners in Flight
description: America's beleaguered airlines continue to hemorrhage money at an alarming rate. After losing $7 billion in 2001, carriers are expected to report close to $9 billion in losses for 2002, the year in which both United Airlines and US Airways filed for bankruptcy. With the possibility of war on the horizon, and the economy recovering at a languid pace, no relief is in sight.

title: Jets' Offensive Line Overcomes Injuries and Tumult at Just the Right Time
description: One by one, the Packers' defense fell like dominoes, to the left and the right. And in stepped Curtis Martin, moving like a speed skater, smooth and untouched, the beneficiary of textbook drive blocking. Martin would later say the holes were bigger than they've been all season.

title: What a Draft Will Do
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Director Quits Los Alamos Under Fire
description: The director of the nation's pre-eminent nuclear weapons laboratory has resigned amid investigations of corruption and missing equipment, officials said yesterday.

title: Strother Helps Keep UConn on Course
description: Ann Strother, who was the national player of the year as a Colorado high school senior last season, remembers when she attended her first University of Connecticut basketball game on a recruiting visit. It was two years ago and the Tennessee Lady Vols were in town.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, JONATHAN
description: JOSEPH-Jonathan. Beloved son of Joyce and Stephen. Loving brother of Amy. Funeral services January 3, Friday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Association to Benefit Children, 419 E. 86 St, NY, NY 10028.

title: Dissenter Imperils Democrats' Plan to Tighten Grip on Nassau Legislature
description: Democratic hopes of strengthening a tenuous hold on the Nassau County Legislature by redrawing the district lines are suddenly jeopardized by the rebellion of one of the party's own legislators.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Human Cloning Claims Draw More Criticism
description: The contentions by a company, Clonaid, that it has created the first human clone are not buttressed by any evidence and should be viewed with the greatest skepticism, the American Association for the Advancement of Science said. The group said Clonaid's assertions threatened to derail scientists' efforts to garner support for cloning research intended to develop medical treatments. ''A knee-jerk reaction to Clonaid's claims could set back much important medical research for years,'' said Albert H. Teich, of the association's Directorate for Science and Policy Programs. Gina Kolata (NYT)

title: Van Wagner Buys Viacom Outdoor Unit
description: Van Wagner Communications in New York, which specializes in outdoor advertising, said yesterday that it had acquired the New York City telephone kiosk ad business of Viacom Outdoor in New York, part of Viacom.

title: A Minivan? That Was The Old Me
description: IN a recent Acura commercial, the fictional owner of a brand new TL Type S sedan terminates his psychoanalysis by leaving a ''Dear Sigmund'' message on his shrink's answering machine.

title: Christmas Trees Pine to Be Mulched
description: It was almost a New York Christmas tradition, bringing the season to a neat, easy and environmentally friendly finish by putting the holiday tree curbside for pickup and mulching by the city. But like so much else in these lean times, the mulching service, which cost $1.5 million last year, is history, cut with the rest of the city's composting program. Instead, in most of the city, residents are being asked to haul the trees themselves to one of 36 mulching sites beginning tomorrow.

title: Courtesans' Costumes Redeemed as Couture
description: In Belle poque Paris, discerning the difference between a courtesan and a respectable society lady was no easy matter. Not, at least, from the way they dressed. Fashion, which then reigned supreme, played no class favorites. Anyone with the necessary francs could go to the great houses like Worth or Paquin and spiff up; or for those with shallower pockets, to the new department stores that were even then knocking off couturier exclusives.

title: Israel's Soldiers Of Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: Venezuela's Chief Proposes Global Effort to End Strike
description: Venezuela's embattled president, Hugo Chvez, said today that he favored the creation of a group of ''Friends of Venezuela'' to lead an international diplomatic effort to end the monthlong general strike that has crippled oil production and brought normal activity to a halt in his country.

title: Former H&R Block Manager Accused in Identity-Theft Ring
description: A former manager of an H&R Block office in White Plains and three of her friends have been charged with running an identity-theft ring that used the names of Block customers to obtain credit cards illegally and steal thousands of dollars in cash and merchandise, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about plans to increase the fare on subsidized express buses included an erroneous figure provided by the city for the number of buses used by the seven private companies. It is about 1,325, not 4,600.

title: A Rare Chance to Take Back a Market; Johnson & Johnson's New Stent May Dominate Angioplasties
description: Few companies ever get a second chance once they fall behind the competition on a pivotal product. Johnson & Johnson is about to become an exception to that rule.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Engineering Executive Resigns
description: The troubled British engineering firm Amey said that its chief executive, Brian Staples, would resign at the end of February. Mel Ewell, the group operations director, was appointed chief operating officer and will run the company along with the acting group finance director, Eric Tracey. Under Mr. Staples, Amey overstretched its balance sheet by bidding aggressively on new projects, including an effort to modernize the London subway system. But when Amey was unable to raise the 60 million ($95.6 million) needed to provide funds for the consortium that won the subway contract, it was forced to borrow money from the group's other two members, the Bechtel Group and Jarvis. Amey has said it intends to raise enough money by June to replace that temporary financing with its own funds. In December the company lowered its profit forecasts and wrote down the value of some assets. In October, Michael Kayser, the finance director, resigned after five weeks on the job. Mr. Tracey, who was formerly a partner at Deloitte & Touche, replaced Mr. Kayser in that post. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, GEORGE
description: SOLOMON - George. The partners of Kronish Lieb Weiner & Hellman LLP mourn the passing of our beloved partner, teacher and friend, George Solomon. George was a lawyer's lawyer whose intellectual grace and personal warmth enriched our practice and our lives. We extend our condolences to his family. His wise counsel and friendship will be deeply missed.

title: Franco Mondini-Ruiz -- 'Nacho de Paz'
description: Frederieke Taylor

title: Reversing Trend, Number of Dividend Increases Grows
description: Dividend checks are getting fatter for the first time in years. But by any historical standard they remain quite small.

title: 2 Hotel Companies Form Joint Venture
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation, the third-largest hotel company in the nation, has formed a $400 million venture with the CNL Hospitality Corporation to buy and refurbish hotel properties, as it seeks to increase income from management fees.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Citigroup Investment
description: Citigroup, which said it had agreed to buy 5 percent of the Shanghai Pudong Development Bank Company for about 600 million yuan ($72.4 million), plans to double its investment, the first it has made in a Chinese lender. Citigroup said that it would develop a credit card business in Shanghai, China's wealthiest city, and take a seat on the board of Pudong, China's second-biggest publicly traded lender. A spokesman for Pudong, Shen Shi, said Citigroup planned to raise its stake to 10 percent.

title: Living Here, but Registered There; New Yorkers Dodge High Fees with Out-of-State License Plates
description: In the West Village lives a man named Harry, and Harry is on a mission.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Jacques Torres made his name in New York creating showoff desserts at Le Cirque. The mandate was clear: dazzle the customers by whatever means necessary. Hence the now-famous chocolate stove, with moving parts. The fun and the showmanship often gave a false impression of Mr. Torres, a classically trained pastry chef with a strong sense of tradition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMACK, CLEMENT ROYAL
description: McCORMACK - Clement Royal. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with all of its officers and employees, mourn the passing of our former Executive Vice President and Treasurer, Clem McCormack. Clem was a beloved friend whose contributions during his 16 years of service helped to build the strength of our company. Upon his retirement, the Board noted that his eminent career exhibited a special combination of sound business acumen with a faithful commitment to the health and human services community. We will miss him greatly. Our sincere condolences to his son, Mark, and daughters Maureen, Carol and Emily. William J. Flynn Chairman of the Board Thomas J. Moran President and CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: A U.S. Role In Military Exercise
description: The vice minister of defense, Chen Chao-min, said the United States would take part in Taiwan military exercises this summer, a move that would probably anger China, which views Taiwan as a renegade province. Citing an American policy of not discussing details of the countries' military ties, an American official declined to confirm or deny any American role in the exercises. Mr. Chen confirmed a report in The China Times in Taiwan that Americans would be involved, but did not address the specifics of the report, which said American soldiers would form an ''expatriate evacuation team'' that would stay at the headquarters for the exercise and not be in the field. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about opposition by the machinists' union at United Airlines to a demand for short-term wage concessions referred incorrectly to the employees who rejected a previous request for cutbacks, in November. They were the mechanics, who are part of the machinists' union, not the union's members over all.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Change In Christmas Tree Recycling
description: Every year, the city collects and mulches used Christmas trees in a seasonal ritual of recycling. But this year, because of budget cuts, New Yorkers will have to find some way of hauling their trees themselves to one of dozens of mulching sites. If the trees are left curbside, the Sanitation Department will simply discard them, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday shortly before feeding several trees through a chipper. But those who bring their trees, without ornaments, to the designated parks, starting tomorrow, will be offered wood chips to take home. The designated sites are listed on the Web at www.nycgovparks.org and www.nyc.gov. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: The Forgotten Forest Product: Water
description: My daughter, Mary, is a Peace Corps volunteer in a village in Mali. Each day she gets a small amount of drinking water, which she must purify, plus two buckets of water for bathing. We are far more fortunate here in the United States, a relatively water-rich nation. Yet even here, water restrictions have become the norm in some parts of the country -- in the East, where supplies once seemed inexhaustible, and in the arid West, where a number of states, along with Mexico, routinely fight over the trickle from what is now the parched Colorado River.

title: Hanukkah With Neon And Bulbs On a Grid
description: Continuing a biennial tradition that began in 1998, the Jewish Museum celebrated Hanukkah this season by opening an exhibition of light-emitting works by eight contemporary artists. Works made of gridded bulbs, neon tubes and video projections remain distributed around the museum, from the main lobby to a fourth-floor gallery where traditional menorahs are on display, providing viewers with a kind of scavenger hunt.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Five Illegal Migrants Drown
description: At least five North Africans drowned when a small rubber boat, carrying at least 40 people, sank a few yards off the southern Spanish coast. Eight of 35 migrants who managed to reach shore evaded capture; 27 were arrested. Thousands of would-be immigrants seeking a better life in Europe have drowned in the past decade while making the short but treacherous clandestine sea crossing from Morocco to Spain. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Davos Forum Seeks Accommodation With Peaceful Protesters
description: The theme of the World Economic Forum this year is trust, and the Swiss police say they will try to maintain that spirit with the protesters who have planned demonstrations against globalization during the meeting in Davos at the end of the month.

title: Cut-Rate War?
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG CITY RADIO TO SELL STATION TO HISPANIC BROADCASTING
description: Big City Radio Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell WXXY-FM of Highland Park, Ill., to the Hispanic Broadcasting Corporation for about $33 million. Hispanic Broadcasting said WXXY-FM would be simulcast with one of its other stations, WLXX-AM. Hispanic Broadcasting, based in Dallas, is the country's No. 1 operator of Spanish-language radio stations. It said that under a separate agreement Superior Broadcasting of Chicago would be allowed to hold the licenses and certain other assets of WXXY-FM, and Hispanic Broadcasting would program the station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMELSER, HAILEY MAE
description: SMELSER-Hailey Mae. Of Goldens Bridge, NY born on August 20, 2002, died on December 31, 2002. She was 4 months and 11 days old. Hailey was born with a genetic disorder known as Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA). Hailey possessed a smile and a set of the brightest, clearest most telling eyes. She communicated her life through those eyes and her gripping smile. Visitation services will be held at Beecher Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY today (Friday) from 2-4 & 7-9 & Saturday from 11 to 12. A funeral mass will be held on Saturday at 1 PM at St. Michael's Church in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Families of SMA, P.O. Box 196 Libertyville, IL 60048-0196

title: Mother Russia In Her Dens
description: My father hated Russia. No doubt the first 10 years of his life, spent there, gave him ample reasons, but what they were I never knew. When I was a boy and asked what life in Russia was like, he always pondered before answering, ''Terrible.'' Occasionally, he varied it: ''Awful.''

title: N.F.L. Playoffs | First Round
description: TOMORROW 4:30 P.M. (All Times Eastern)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Exports Lag Forecasts
description: Indonesian exports rose 6.9 percent, to $4.1 billion, in November, far less than most economists expected, as a sluggish global economy and domestic concerns offset rising prices for Indonesian oil. Labor unrest, rising wages, a strengthening currency and higher shipping costs resulting from the October bomb explosion in Bali have combined to dampen demand for Indonesian goods. And while inflation in November slowed to 10 percent, price increases that the government imposed yesterday for heavily used fuels like gasoline and kerosene have some economists concerned that consumer spending could soon go the way of exports, spelling trouble for Indonesian economic growth. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Modest Turnout in Pakistan for Anti-U.S. Demonstrations
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 3  Thousands of people in six Pakistani cities protested a possible American attack on Iraq at rallies today organized by a coalition of hard-line religious parties. But the rallies were relatively modest by Pakistani standards.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Mutilation-By-Hire Is Charged
description: A Long Island man who authorities say planned to hire someone to sexually mutilate a man who had raped his girlfriend's daughter has been arrested, officials in Queens said yesterday. An undercover officer posing as the assailant-for-hire foiled the plot, officials said. The suspect, David Quinn, 37, of Rockville Centre, was arrested Monday and charged with conspiracy. About four months ago, investigators heard of Mr. Quinn's plans and the Queens district attorney arranged for an undercover detective to pose as an assailant. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Recent Attacks in Yemen Seen As Sign of Large Terror Cell
description: The investigation into two high-profile attacks in Yemen in the last week, including the killing of three American missionaries, suggests that a larger cell of Islamic militants has been planning to strike at other foreigners as well as secular-minded politicians, a security official said today.

title: Floods Wreak Havoc Across Europe
description: VIENNA, Jan. 3  Fierce winds and rain cut a destructive swath across Europe today and Thursday, killing at least two people, flooding parts of Germany and Belgium, and halting traffic on the swollen Rhine River.

title: Zany Doings On a Ranch, All in Verse
description: Falling somewhere between Red Sox championships and tsunamis on the gauge of frequency, verse plays are of sufficient rarity to merit escape from casual dismissal.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNILEVER, London, the maker of Dove soap and Lipton tea, completed the sale of its Iberia Foods division to Brooklyn Bottling Group, New York, a distributor of Caribbean and Latino foods. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bush Plays Down Rift With Allies Over U.S. Stance on North Korea
description: President Bush discounted American differences with Asian nations today on how to handle the nuclear standoff with North Korea.

title: City Council's Unapologetically Demanding Voice
description: IT'S no wonder, really, that Education Department officials refused to show up at City Councilwoman Eva S. Moskowitz's hearings.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rain Wreaks Havoc
description: Floods from continual rainfall closed down village main streets, inundated regional roads and some major highways and drastically curtailed train service across England and Wales, but the Environment Agency said a predicted end to the downpours this weekend would probably save hundreds of homes in the southeast that had been threatened with being washed away. ''We may have missed major flooding by a whisker,'' said Ray Kemp, the agency's spokesman. The Met Office, Britain's weather agency, reported that rainfall in England and Wales in December had been 27 percent above average. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Political Memo; Democrats Use Job Chart To Try to Skewer Bush
description: Call it incomplete, unfair, misleading or even, as White House officials attest, utterly meaningless.

title: RIVAL'S PAYMENTS HELP SHORE UP ENTREMED'S FINANCES
description: EntreMed said yesterday that it would get $27 million from a rival, Celgene, for rights to its thalidomide-derived drugs, giving Entremed enough money to operate into next year. The news set off a gain of 40 percent in EntreMed's share price. EntreMed will raise $16.8 million with convertible stock and warrants that give Celgene a stake of as much as 49 percent. Celgene, which licensed thalidomide from EntreMed in 1998 to develop a cancer drug, will gain full rights to related compounds excluded by that agreement. EntreMed has been struggling to raise capital to finance its research. The transaction ends a legal dispute between the companies over patent rights, EntreMed said. Celgene has made a $10 million cash payment to EntreMed related to that settlement. Shares of EntreMed rose 34 cents, to $1.20.

title: Illuminations
description: Ingo Maurer isn't called the poet of light for nothing.

title: New Designs
Where the Spirit Moves You
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Poor Woman Is Gone And Her Castle's Besieged
description: Behind crumbling walls and a maze of trees, the ruins of a 12th-century castle loom over the Teifi River, a relic of wars between Welsh armies and invading English kings.

title: Dr. Eleanor J. Gibson, 92, a Pioneer in Perception Studies
description: Dr. Eleanor J. Gibson, a psychology professor at Cornell who made advances in the study of perception and learning processes in children, died on Dec. 30 in Columbia, S.C. She was 92.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the shooting of a 15-year-old boy early on New Year's Day in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to remarks by Jim Anderson, a spokesman for the city's Department of Homeless Services. He said workers at a homeless shelter had called 911 after hearing gunshots -- not after seeing the chase, because they did not see it.

title: Construction Spending Up In November
description: Construction spending rose for a third consecutive month in November as the lowest mortgage rates in three decades spurred record home sales.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Officers Face Child Sex Charges
description: Two Cambridgeshire police officers who played roles in a search for two missing 10-year-old girls last August that draw national attention are to stand trial on unrelated child sex charges. Brian Stevens, 41, and Anthony Goodridge, 34, are accused of possessing and distributing indecent images of children; Mr. Stevens is also charged with indecent assault on two girls under 16. Both men, now suspended from the force, provided support to the family of one of the girls, whose bodies were found in a ditch 13 days after their disappearance, and Mr. Stevens read a poem at her funeral. A former school janitor has been charged with the killings. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Secrecy vs. Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Notebook; Texas in His Heart, Iraq on His Mind
description: When President Bush emerged in a giant gymnasium here today to rousing cheers of ''hoo-ah'' -- the all-purpose Army cry of approval -- he did not have the relaxed air of a man who has been on vacation for 13 days now.

description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Dec. 27 about rising prices of generic drugs, and a related chart, misattributed calculations of increases for generic and brand-name drugs. While they were based on sales data from IMS Health, a health care information company, they were computed by The Times. The article also misstated the name for the generic equivalent of the antibiotic Keflex. It is cephalexin; cephalosporin is the broader class of antibiotic.

description: Thousands of people in six Pakistani cities protested today against a possible American attack on Iraq at rallies organized by a coalition of hard-line religious parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOB, EVA
description: JACOB-Eva. Of Tenafly, NJ on January 2nd. Beloved wife of Ludwig. Devoted mother of Peter and Philippe. Dear sister of Ernest Herz. Loving grandmother of Natalie, Benjamin and Danielle. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St, Englelwood, NJ Sunday, 11:30.

title: Drug firms accused of devising women's malady
description: PARIS:  The British Medical Journal touched off a major controversy Friday when it published an article charging that pharmaceutical companies had invented a new condition called female sexual dysfunction so they could create a vast new market for drugs to treat it.

title: New Seoul Leader to Press U.S. and North to Yield a Bit
description: South Korea's president-elect, Roh Moo Hyun, a former labor negotiator, is preparing a compromise proposal that would require both North Korea and the United States to accept concessions to resolve the standoff over the Communist state's nuclear program, an aide said today.

title: Jailed by Pinochet, She Now Runs the Military
description: IT is a measure of how much this country has changed that Michelle Bachelet today works from an office that once belonged to Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the dictator whose forces tortured her father to death nearly 30 years ago.

title: KENNETH COLE RAISES FORECAST FOR FOURTH QUARTER
description: Kenneth Cole Productions Inc., the designer of fashions and accessories, said yesterday that it expected its fourth-quarter revenue and earnings to exceed its previous outlook and current Wall Street estimates. Kenneth Cole said its results were helped by better oversight of promotions and inventory and a positive reaction by consumers to its holiday lineup. The company, which is based in New York, raised its fourth-quarter earnings forecast to at least 36 cents a share, up from its previous projection of 32 cents to 34 cents a share. The company also raised its revenue projection to $117 million to $118 million from its previous outlook of $108 million to $110 million. Kenneth Cole's stock rose $1.57 a share, to $23.57.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMACK, CLEMENT ROYAL
description: McCORMACK - Clement Royal. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with all of its officers and employees, mourn the passing of our former Executive Vice President and Treasurer, Clem McCormack. Clem was a beloved friend whose contributions during his 16 years of service helped to build the strength of our company. Upon his retirement, the Board noted that his eminent career exhibited a special combination of sound business acumen with a faithful commitment to the health and human services community. Moran President and CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

title: Spurned Lover Stabs Woman And Child to Death, Police Say
description: Sook Kim had come home to her family on Christmas Eve, to her husband and two young daughters, but she could not escape the wrath of the man she had once chosen over them, the police said yesterday.

title: Surgeons Explain Reasons for Their Walkout
description: An ambulance with lights flashing and siren screaming wheeled into the Weirton Medical Center here on Thursday afternoon, carrying a 30-year-old steelworker writhing in pain.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about booty taken by Iraq from Kuwait in 1991 misstated the year of a black Cadillac that may once have belonged to Kuwaiti royalty and is now turning heads in Baghdad. It was a 1962 model, not a 1955.

title: Short Crew Has a Tall Order: Outplay Harrison
description: The Jets' receivers cannot help but stay tuned today when they do not have the ball. Marvin Harrison of the Indianapolis Colts is one of those players who turn heads, even those of his peers. You would have to total the receptions of the Jets' top three receivers -- Laveranues Coles (89), Wayne Chrebet (51) and Santana Moss (30) -- to better Harrison's league-record 143 catches this season. And none of the Jets' receivers can match Harrison's 11 receiving touchdowns.

title: In New York Region, 2003 Starts Off Wet and White
description: The first storm of the new year and the second in 10 days rolled into the region yesterday, giving Connecticut and upstate New York a second big helping of holiday snow and coating roadways farther south with ice.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the killing of an elderly Israeli man near a West Bank village misstated his age in some copies. As the article said, the man was 73, not 70.

title: For Immigrant Family, No Easy Journeys
description: Yan Hua Zheng was worried about the crabs: they might not survive a 20-hour bus ride. She knew that her two daughters, who moved to the mountains of north Georgia two months earlier, missed fresh crab, a Fujianese favorite, but the crabs are no good unless they go into the pot alive.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Every day there is no peace is another day that I will not get to see my mother.''

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Partial Settlement In Profiling Suit
description: The state police have agreed to policy changes designed to prevent troopers from singling out minority drivers in a partial settlement of a racial-profiling lawsuit. The state police agreed to distribute brochures to drivers who are pulled over, informing them how to file a racial-profiling complaint; create a police-citizen panel on the issue; set up a toll-free number for complaints; and inform drivers that they have a right to refuse consent to search vehicles. The state police did not admit wrongdoing. The agreement needs approval from the state Board of Public Works. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: An Open Mind Amid Growling Ideologues
description: In 1955, the French sociologist and historian Raymond Aron began a book with an epigraph from Karl Marx: ''Religion is the sigh of the creature overwhelmed by misfortune, the sentiment of a heartless world, and the soul of soulless conditions. It is the opium of the people.'' For Marx, religion was a profound expression of distress and suffering, offering comfort when none could be found; but it was also a delusion, dulling awareness of the true causes of misery.

title: Ghosts of Games Past Haunting Manning
description: Peyton Manning knows he will hear it when he walks onto the field at Giants Stadium to begin stretching for Saturday's playoff game against the Jets. He has heard it since he was a highly visible quarterback at the University of Tennessee, that somehow his career is unfulfilled, that his achievements have never met expectations.

title: Weather Turns Dangerous and Deadly Across Europe
description: Fierce winds and rain cut a destructive swath across Europe in the past two days, killing at least two people, flooding parts of Germany and Belgium, and halting traffic on the swollen Rhine River.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Maker's Profit Rises
description: The world's No. 2 steel company, Pohang Iron and Steel, led a global surge in the industry last year, posting a fourth-quarter operating income of $560 million, more than twice the $260 million reported for the period of 2001. The company, which is known as Posco and ranks behind Arcelor of Luxembourg among global steel makers, did not disclose net income but said that sales for the quarter were up 20 percent from the period a year earlier despite a 10 percent price increase in July. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Mets Seek Hillenbrand in Deal With Boston and Montreal
description: The Mets, the Boston Red Sox and the Montreal Expos have discussed a three-way trade that would send third baseman Shea Hillenbrand from Boston to the Mets and either Bartolo Coln or Javier Vazquez, both starters, from Montreal to the Red Sox, an official of one team said last night.

title: Today's Visions of the Science of Tomorrow
description: At the end of every year, John Brockman, a literary agent and the publisher of Edge.org, a Web site devoted to science, poses a question to leading scientists, writers and futurists. In 2002, he asked respondents to imagine that they had been nominated as White House science adviser and that President Bush had sought their answer to ''What are the pressing scientific issues for the nation and the world, and what is your advice on how I can begin to deal with them?'' Here are excerpts of some of the responses.

description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about North Carolina State's victory over Notre Dame in the Gator Bowl misspelled the surname of a Notre Dame offensive tackle. He is Brennan Curtin, not Curtain.

title: For St. John's and Seton Hall, Season Starts Now
description: Six times St. John's has won this season, and six times the team did not have any reason to feel good about itself. Victories over Stony Brook, Fordham, Fairfield, St. Francis of New York, Hofstra and Niagara do little for the ego, and they do not reduce the sting of losing the two games so far that have meant something.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: MALAYSIA: AFTER DELAY, U.S. TO ISSUE VISAS The American Embassy in Kuala Lumpur said it would issue hundreds of visas that had been held back for months because of increased security fears in the United States. It said the approvals would include "virtually all" of about 150 backlogged visas for students wishing to study in the United States. Malaysia, a predominantly Muslim nation and an ally in the United States' campaign against terror, has complained about visa delays and about the aggressive security checks of its citizens at American airports.    Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: New Era Succeeds Years of Solitude
description: Alberto Fuguet's latest novel has no metaphysical butterflies, no levitating grandmothers, no flying carpets -- indeed, none of the fantastic imagery that is most commonly associated with Latin American literature.

title: Backup Goalie By Day Is Star For One Night
description: Corey Schwab made the most of one of his rare starts in goal for the Devils tonight. The backup to Martin Brodeur, Schwab came up with a 2-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs at Continental Arena, his first shutout of the season and the fifth of his career.

title: Neighbor Sentenced to Death For Kidnapping and Killing Girl
description: A judge in San Diego sentenced David Westerfield to death today for the kidnapping and murder of 7-year-old Danielle van Dam.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: A Fugitive Sighting
description: James J. Bulger, a fugitive Boston mobster, was seen in London in September, said the F.B.I., which released composite images of what Mr. Bulger might look like. Mr. Bulger, 73, was seen by a businessman he befriended in 1994. The man learned that Mr. Bulger, who is known as Whitey, was a fugitive a week after the September sighting. Mr. Bulger became a fugitive in 1995 after being told by an F.B.I. agent that he was to be indicted on racketeering charges. He has since been charged in 21 murders. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Field of Dreams: Bad Ones
description: The weather and the field will provide some extra suspense for today's first-round playoff game between the Jets and the Indianapolis Colts.

title: A Democrat to Lead a G.O.P. Majority? Only in Suffolk
description: The predictably unpredictable Suffolk County Legislature has done it again. Despite having a 10-to-8 Republican majority, it picked a Democrat yesterday as its presiding officer.

title: Layoffs at Verizon
description: To the Editor:

title: Ailey's Talent, in Grief And in Sly Celebration
description: Alvin Ailey was a better choreographer than he gave himself credit for. The work of creating a dance tended to drive him into comical yet heart-rending despair. And so it was good to have a reminder of his genius in a program the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented Thursday night at City Center in Manhattan, where the company is performing through tomorrow.

title: Sid Gillman, 91, Innovator Of Passing Strategy in Football
description: Sid Gillman, the longtime professional and college football coach who was considered a master of the passing game, died yesterday morning in Los Angeles. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINOTT, GINSBURG, DAVID
description: GINOTT - GINSBURG - David. A Greenwich resident passed away at the Westchester Medical Center on Wednesday, January 1, 2003 after having suffered a heart attack. He was 58. Born in Tel Aviv, Israel on August 30, 1944. He was the son of the late Abraham and Gela Ginsburg. Mr. Ginott was President of Rayburn Musical Instrument Co. of Boston and was the founder and president of the E.M. Winston Band Instruments Co. and several other musical instruments companies. He was an avid supporter of music education and supported school programs throughout the northeast and around the world. As a man of generous spirit and sensitivity to the needs of others he was an ardent supporter of many charities in the United States and Israel, particularly Tzohar, which educates disabled and disadvantaged children, and the Ken Foundation, which trains guide dogs for the disabled. In addition, Mr. Ginott was a veteran of the IDF and maintained close ties with Israel throughout his life. He was a lover of musical culture and was deeply involved in the restoration of the Louis Armstrong Archives at Queens College. He is survived by his wife Ronni Ginott of Green wich, CT, his two daughters Jamie and Lindsay Ginott both of Greenwich, CT, and his sister Haya Cohen of Tel Aviv, Israel. A funeral service will be held at Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT on Sunday, January 5, 2003 at 1:30 PM. Burial will follow at Riversville Cemetery, Greenwich, CT. Contributions can be made to: Or Chadash/ American Friends of Tzohar Attn: Rabbi Avraham Schecter, 1431 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11230.

title: Philharmonic Begins 2003 With a Toast to the Past
description: Now that everyone has finished ringing out the old, Lorin Maazel and the New York Philharmonic devoted their first concert of 2003 to ringing it back in. The pillars of Mr. Maazel's program on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall (it is to be repeated on Tuesday night) were the Grieg Piano Concerto and the Beethoven Fifth Symphony, works from the upper reaches of the classical music hit parade. The most recent work was William Bolcom's ''Ragomania: A Classic Festival-Overture,'' composed for the Boston Pops in 1982.

title: Beliefs; A perennial Internet item this time of year: divining secrets in 'Twelve Days of Christmas.'
description: Today is the 11th day of Christmas, and your true love sent you what? Eleven pipers piping? Oh, no, those are really Jesus' 11 faithful apostles (the 12 minus Judas, who betrayed him).

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO CLIMBS. The dollar fell for the seventh day in eight against the euro on concern proposed tax cuts will add to the U.S. budget and trade deficits. In New York, the dollar weakened to $1.0416 euro, from $1.0360 on Thursday.

title: Israel's Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomson Signs With Rangers
description: The right-hander John Thomson and the Texas Rangers agreed yesterday to $1.3 million, one-year contract.

title: Man Is Charged in Death From Stray Bullet
description: The police have charged a man with murder after a stray bullet that they say was fired from his gun last Saturday killed a woman in her Brooklyn apartment.

title: Political Memo; With No '04 Front-Runner, Democrats Inch Toward Line
description: Democratic candidates for president seem to be popping up everywhere these days.

title: Reading in the New Year
description: The New York City schools chancellor, Joel Klein, has gotten off to an impressive start in his attempt to restructure the largest school system in the country. Four months into his rookie year, the chancellor has cut the once-bloated central bureaucracy to the bone and proposed a series of reforms that could eventually change everything -- from how schools are planned and built to the way principals are recruited, trained and paid. But his main goal in the coming year must be to fix a wildly uneven instructional system that too often fails to perform the first function of a school: teaching young children to read.

title: SILICON GRAPHICS TO PAY ADDED PENALTIES TO U.S.
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. will pay additional penalties of about $182,000 to settle charges by the Commerce Department that the company sold computers to a Russian government laboratory without an export license. Silicon Graphics, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., disclosed the fine yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Last month, the company agreed to pay a $1 million fine to settle a Justice Department investigation into the same matter. The settlements resolve charges related to the sale of four computers to a Russian government laboratory in 1996. The Commerce Department's claims also covered administrative and paperwork violations related to sales to several other countries.

title: Students Online During Lectures
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisis in Korea Stirs Debate In a Borough In New Jersey
description: They tape American flags to their front doors, sprinkle English words into their banter and turn emotional when speaking of their adopted homeland. But for many of the 36,000 Korean-Americans who have settled in and around this tidy, blue-collar borough, the growing crisis on the Korean peninsula is provoking anxiety, stirring passionate debate and straining allegiances as never before.

title: A December to Remember For Adam Wildavsky
description: In a lifetime, few players have the pleasure of winning three significant events in a calendar month. That feat was achieved in December by Adam Wildavsky, long a constructive force on the New York bridge scene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREDERICKS, LOUISE S.
description: FREDERICKS-Louise S. January 1, 2003. Daughter of the late George Stieffater and the late Eva Bradshaw Stieffater and sister of the late Virginia Stieffater and the late George Bradshaw Stieffater. Funeral services Monday, January 6, 10 AM, at St. James the Less, Scarsdale, New York.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: When In Vienna . . .
description: Foreigners who plan to stay in Austria for an extended period will have to prove they can speak German. Under an immigration law that came into force this week, they must take German courses and classes on the Austrian political and social system. Those who do not take the courses within four years will forfeit their right to stay in Austria. The law applies to all people from outside the European Union who arrived in Austria after Jan. 1, 1998. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Al Bart, 87, a Member of Fordham's Seven Blocks of Granite
description: Al Bart, an all-American tackle on the Seven Blocks of Granite, Fordham University's famed football line of the 1930's, died last Sunday at a nursing home in Kettering, Ohio. He was 87.

title: Energy-Rich Kazakhstan Is Suffering Growing Pains
description: At the presidential palace here, a confident President Nursultan Nazarbayev strode out in December to greet foreign investors. It was all smiles for the cameras as Mr. Nazarbayev sat down with the investors, most of them oil executives, to talk about recent business developments in this vast country, rich in energy resources.

title: Making Near Beer Acceptable in Near East
description: When Heineken, the Dutch beer giant, bought Egypt's sole brewery, Al Ahram Beverages Company, for $280 million in October, most analysts thought of it as yet another Heineken acquisition of a successful monopoly. It was also the biggest deal in Egypt's financial history.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Tribe Wants Nuclear Dump Removed
description: Members of the Tao tribe on Lan Yu Island are demanding the removal of a nuclear waste dump from the island, off Taiwan's southeastern tip. The government's lease of the site expired at the end of 2002 and the tribe is refusing to renew it despite the government's offer of more financial aid. Demonstrators who threw rocks at riot police officers on New Year's Day pledged to return to the site in 15 days if no deal is reached. The government built the dump 20 years ago, when Taiwan was still under martial law, without consulting the tribe. No other community has been willing to accept the mostly low-level radioactive waste. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Unmasking Jets' Success: Their Defenses Are Disguised
description: The fiasco was etched on Ted Cottrell's face, and each week, as the yardage and the losses piled up, the crevices in his face got deeper, the bags under his eyes puffier. The Jets' defense, which Coach Herman Edwards had counted on to be the linchpin of the team, was being shredded early in the season, the simplest assignments going unfilled.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bird Flu Identified
description: Local agriculture officials said that some chickens that have recently died were carrying the H5N1 flu virus, but that it was genetically different from the H5N1 virus that killed six people in Hong Kong in 1997 and caused worldwide alarm. Chickens have died in groups at several farms in the territory over the last two weeks, including more than 1,000 at a single farm last Saturday. The authorities have responded by ordering the killing of thousands of birds, along with repeated disinfections of farms and markets. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: A Guide With Attitude
description: As the nation prepares to backtrack into the rich historical detail of the Lewis and Clark expedition, no guide is more sorely missed than Sacagawea, the teenage Indian interpreter whose role in helping negotiate the grand unknown of the West two centuries ago remains as mysterious and tantalizing as ever. Part of the problem is that while the explorers' journals offer all manner of description of the woodland life they encountered, the entries about Sacagawea focus on her indispensability more than her day-to-day individuality. Her face is on the gold dollar coin, on license plates, on product labels and more, but it's idealized, just like so many crucial details of her life. Legions of schoolchildren have yearned to know more but are offered conflicting information and myths.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPATZ, NATALIE
description: SPATZ-Natalie. January 4, 1908-June 6, 2000. Beloved, cherished, revered, adored and treasured mother ''If tears could build a stairway and memories a lane, we'd walk right up to Heaven and bring you home again.'' Happy Birthday Momma. One lifetime with you was not enough. Allen, Kenneth and Dian

title: Jurors Were Divided Over Morgan's Lawsuit
description: Jurors who were about to weigh J. P. Morgan Chase's $965 million claim against 11 insurers over Enron oil and gas trades said yesterday that they had been split before the opponents in the lawsuit reached a settlement.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about efforts by influential Democrats to counter conservative voices in the news media misidentified the network that broadcasts ''Buchanan and Press,'' with the conservative commentator Patrick J. Buchanan and Bill Press, a prominent advocate of Democratic positions. It is MSNBC, not CNN.

title: Sydney Omarr Dies at 76; Popular Astrologer and Leo
description: Sydney Omarr, an astrologer whose divinations were available in more than 200 newspapers, in 13 books a year and on a pay-per-call phone line, died on Thursday at a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMLER, PHILIP
description: KAMLER-Philip. Of NJ and Palm Beach, Founder of Kent International, Parsippany, NJ. For additional information, call ''Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel,'' 1-800-938-6372.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Holiday Road Carnage
description: Officials reported that an average of 4 people died and 193 were injured every hour in highway accidents over a seven-day New Year's holiday break. Those numbers add up to a total of 562 dead and 32,451 injured in 11,438 accidents, most of which were attributed to alcohol. It turns out that this was good news. The number of dead was down from last year's record 585. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Detailing Police Shootings, Kelly Says 3 Seem Justified
description: In an unusual 90-minute news conference, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly yesterday provided the most detailed accounts to date of the four fatal police shootings that occurred in the first two days of the new year, declaring that preliminary investigations found that three of the four shootings appeared justified.

title: United to Lay Off 1,500 More Employees
description: United Airlines said yesterday that it would lay off nearly 1,500 management and salaried employees by Jan. 19.

title: Brooklyn Man Faces Charges Of Murder in Infant Son's Death
description: The father of a 7-month-old Brooklyn boy who died on Tuesday evening was charged with murder yesterday after the city medical examiner's office reported that the child's skull had been fractured.
