description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVA, FABIO
description: SILVA-Fabio. Antique dealer on the Upper East Side of Manhattan passed away on January 1, 2003, from complications of cardiac arrest, suffered while jogging in Central Park. Mr. Silva was born in Recife, Brazil on July 5, 1963. He received his Fine Arts degree from Hunter College. Mr. Silva began his career working at Schlesch and Garza Antiques, specializing in Northern European furniture. When Arne Schlesch retired, he continued his tradition by opening his own shop. Mr. Silva was a member of the Art and Antique Dealers League of America, Inc. At the time of his death, Mr. Silva was scheduled to officiate at the Winter Antiques Show as well as to be featured in a documentary on his life as a Brazilian antique dealer in NYC. Mr. Silva is survived by two sisters, Cristina and Ana and two brothers, Tarcizio and Cristiano of Brazil and the Asencio family of NYC. He will be greatly missed by those whose lives he has touched. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Saturday, January 4, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service private. Flowers can be sent to Rivero Funeral Home, 3344 SW 8th St, Miami, FL. 33135.

title: Cloning Company Says Baby Might Not Be Tested After All
description: The company that said last week that it had produced the first human clone has backed away from a promise to provide genetic proof even as it said a second clone would be born in Europe over the weekend.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: After Delay, U.S. To Issue Visas
description: The American Embassy in Kuala Lumpur said it would issue hundreds of visas that had been held back for months because of increased security fears in the United States. It said the approvals would include ''virtually all'' of about 150 backlogged visas for students wishing to study in the United States. Malaysia, a predominantly Muslim nation and an ally in the United States' campaign against terror, has complained about visa delays and about the aggressive security checks of its citizens at American airports. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, BURTON J.
description: SINGER-Burton J. On January 2, 2003. Loving and much loved husband of Betsy (nee Abel) and the late Marcia Gerstein. Adored father of Jill, Mark and Lisa Singer. Wonderful and magical Poppy to Morgan Alexa and Kendall Brooke. Cherished brother of Felice Gritz, uncle of Lloyd and Barrie, and dear friend of Joan Wolff. A kind and gentle man, he will be deeply missed by all. Services will be held on Sunday, January 5th, at 11:30 AM, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Recent Shootings by Officers Are Anomalies, Experts Say
description: For the New York Police Department, the new year began with an exceptional set of events: four fatal shootings of civilians by officers in just the first two days.

title: Drug Proposal For Medicare Is Welcomed With Wariness
description: Officials within the insurance industry and at large employers are welcoming the Bush administration's plan for sweeping changes in the Medicare program to accompany a new prescription drug benefit. But executives cautioned yesterday that their enthusiasm for any changes to Medicare hinged on adequate financing.

title: Killing of U.N. Aide by Israel Bares Rift With Relief Agency
description: The last time Iain Hook called Israeli forces, on a cellphone from a United Nations compound in the West Bank town of Jenin, he was looking for help. Outside the compound walls, a skirmish had flared between Israel's Army and Palestinian militants. Mr. Hook and his staff were trapped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARFIELD, EVA L. (NEE ILLIONS)
description: STARFIELD-Eva L. (nee Illions). On January 2, 2003, in her 95th year. Wife of the late Martin J. Starfield, cherished mother of daughters Barbara and Phoebe, and loving grandmother of Robert, Jon, Steven and Deborah Holtzman. She is also survived by her five sisters and brothers, son-in-law Neil A. Holtzman, son-in-law Neal Nathanson and his children Katherine, John and Daniel, and seven great-grandchildren. After a career of teaching, she devoted the following 32 years not only to her family but also to her Brooklyn Heights community and to the welfare of the residents at 140 Cadman Plaza West Co-op. A gentle woman of indomitable strength and deep-seated idealism, she will be sorely missed by both family and friends.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Wider Use For Novartis Drug
description: Investors pushed up the price of Novartis shares after the European Union gave the company approval to market Glivec as the first-line treatment for newly diagnosed cases of a form of leukemia. Novartis, Switzerland's largest drug maker, won approval to use Glivec in the United States last month. An analyst at Pictet projected that Glivec sales could reach 1.4 billion Swiss francs ($1 billion) by 2006. Glivec, known in the United States as Gleevec, is one of the first therapies to use genetic knowledge to attack cancer more effectively and with fewer side effects than traditional methods. About 40,000 people in the United States are affected with the form of blood cancer known as chronic myeloid leukemia. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAINSCHIGG, JANET GEM MELL
description: JAINSCHIGG - Janet Gem mell, 94. Of Chester Village West, Chester, CT., former resident of Darien, CT., where she was a leader of historic preservation efforts and Red Cross fundraising activities died December 30. She served as Chairman of Volunteers, Darien Chapter of American Red Cross, and was past president of the Darien Historical Society. Memorial service January 25, 11AM at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Killingworth, CT. For info The Robinson, Wright & Weymer Funeral Home, 34 Main Street, Centerbrook, CT.

title: Drinking Party Raises New Concerns in Westchester
description: A New Year's Eve party that ended with the arrests of 26 teenagers on under-age-drinking charges was held in three hotel rooms rented by a man whose son drowned six years ago after a night of drinking in Manhattan, the authorities said today.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: RATE CHANGE UNLIKELY Sir Edward George, the governor of the Bank of England, said he expected no "sharp change" in British interest rates, which have held at a 39-year low of 4 percent for the last 13 months. In a radio interview, he said the British economy, which is growing more robustly than its major counterparts in Continental Europe, remained exposed to the global slowdown and would benefit most of all from "stronger recovery in the world economy." Sir Edward said he expected consumer spending and inflation in housing prices to ease without a crash in the booming real estate market. Recent data have shown Britain's manufacturing sector in continued doldrums while consumer spending, which fuels two-thirds of the economy, has slowed. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, BROTHER GERARD
description: O'BRIEN - Brother Gerard, OSF. On January 2, 2003. Beloved brother of Sister Margaret O'Brien, M.M. and Kathleen Veech. Uncle of Patricia Cocurullo and Edward Veech. Brother-in-law of Edward Veech, Sr. Reposing at Maria Regina Residence, Brentwood, N.Y. Sunday 2-5 and 7-8:30PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 11AM at Maria Regina Chapel. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York.

title: Chancellor Gives Out Report Cards, Failing 50 Principals
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein plans to hand out report cards to all of New York City's 1,100 principals, and at least 50 have received failing marks, officials said yesterday.

title: An Old Foe, Parcells, Has Dallas Buzzing
description: While Coach Bill Parcells conducted his first day of business in the Dallas Cowboys' training headquarters at Valley Ranch, a different type of dealing took place a few miles away at Texas Stadium. Overhead, the sky gleamed bright blue through that quirky hole in the roof -- it is there ''so God can watch his favorite team,'' they like to say here -- and the staff in the ticket office was making hay in the sunshine.

title: US Airways Ends a Fee
description: The US Airways Group eliminated a $30 fuel surcharge on most round-trip fares after rivals declined to match the increase added last month.

title: Police Dragnets For DNA Tests Draw Criticism
description: Recently, the police asked Shannon F. Kohler if they could swab the inside of his mouth to analyze his DNA. It was a request they made of 800 men in southern Louisiana as they searched for the serial killer who has slain four young women, leaving behind genetic material in each case.

title: Lottery Numbers
World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: President, 83, Seeks Re-Election
description: President Glafcos Clerides announced that he would seek re-election next month. He said that he wanted to see through peace talks aimed at reunifying the Greek and Turkish sectors of the island and that if he won, he would serve just 16 months instead of 5 years. Mr. Clerides, 83, whose second five-year term expires on Feb. 28, has been involved in a United Nations-brokered effort to end the island's division and form a federation. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A rock review on Thursday about a performance by Phish on New Year's Eve at Madison Square Garden referred incorrectly to a figure who made an appearance onstage. Though introduced as Tom Hanks, he was a Hanks look-alike.

description: Giants running back Tiki Barber left practice earlier than the other players today after feeling his back tighten; Coach Jim Fassel dispatched Barber to the locker room for precautionary reasons.

title: Challenged Again, Isles Surge Above .500
description: First, Islanders Coach Peter Laviolette challenged his team to reach the .500 mark before December was over. When the Islanders responded and reached that modest goal with a victory on New Year's Eve, Laviolette challenged the players to set their goals higher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, ALAN J.
description: KLEINMAN-Alan J. On January 2, 2003. Beloved husband of Jody. Devoted father of Bryan and Michael. Loving son of Betty and the late Morton. Dear brother of John and the late Ellen. Dear brotherin-law of Donna. Loving uncle of Andrea. Cherished son-inlaw of Irene and Seymour Kunis. Services Sunday, 9AM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: 2 Dead in Venezuela As Tension Mounts
description: At least two people were shot to death and dozens of other wounded in Caracas as clashes between opponents of President Hugo Chvez and pro-government groups, as a peaceful protest involving thousands deteriorated into a huge street fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMEL, CAROL J.
description: BERMEL-Carol J. On January 2, 2003 of Garden City, NY. Survived by her brother the Honorable Richard Conway Casey, her children Mary Katherine, Marcia, Charles, Ellen, Christopher, Janet, Elizabeth and Thomas and nineteen grandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave., at 12th St., Garden City, 2-4 and 7-9 PM Sunday. Mass of Christian burial, St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, 10 AM Monday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Where The Tundra Is Always Frozen
description: It will not take the Atlanta Falcons long to realize the urgency of playoff football here on the frozen tundra. ''Titletown'' is painted on a hangar at the airport, Packers flags hang in the lobby and the gift shop offers all things cheese: cheese heads, cheese helmets, even cheese bras, all of which may appear as accessories at Saturday's first-round playoff game at Lambeau Field.

title: Group Therapy at Ground Zero
description: On the day before Christmas, The New York Post slapped the headline ''Rudy Rants'' on its front page. The former mayor had panned the latest round of architectural visions for ground zero as ''confusing'' because they failed to capture ''the significance of the place'' and were ''trying to do too much.'' Is that a rant? Mr. Giuliani's real sin was that he told the truth, and in doing so violated our most pervasive form of political correctness -- the speech codes bequeathed by 9/11.

title: Sprewell Takes Charge to Direct Stunning Rally
description: For 34 minutes, the top team in the Eastern Conference had been pounding them to pieces, dunking on them, outrunning them and bullying them beneath the basket. Finally, the Knicks, down by 17 points and being booed by many of the 19,763 fans at Madison Square Garden, stomped their feet, clenched their fists and screamed ''Enough!''

title: PRE-PAID LEGAL ANNOUNCES CHANGES IN TOP RANKS
description: Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc., a seller of legal insurance, said its chief executive, Harland Stonecipher, replaced Wilburn Smith as president of the company. Mr. Smith, a 22-year employee of Pre-Paid and the president since 1997, resigned, the company said. The company, which is based in Ada, Okla., said the number of new members of its service dropped to 169,350 during the fourth quarter, a 5.6 decline from a year earlier. The company's stock fell 44 cents, to $26.18 a share.

title: Bowl Games Become Measures for Conferences' Success, Too
description: Numbers. That's all that was left after the 28 bowl games.

title: An Attack Drill Proves to Be a Real Test for Kuwaitis
description: An alarm blared, purple smoke billowed through the palm trees, and suddenly fire trucks, police vans and civil defense vehicles descended on a luxury beachside hotel one afternoon this week.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pot In Every Chicken
description: Scotland Yard said it had foiled an attempt by a friend of a gunman to smuggle marijuana to him inside a Kentucky Fried Chicken order delivered to the East London apartment where he and a hostage have been surrounded by the police for more than a week. Detectives agreed to let the friend send the food to Eli Hall, 32, as a negotiating tactic, but when they examined the order they found the drumsticks had been stuffed with cannabis. The next day, when the friend returned with a new order, the police found more of the drug and arrested Junior Skerrett, 22, charging him with possession with intent to sell. The standoff started Dec. 26 after shots were fired from the apartment at the police as they tried to remove a car. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Wyoming as Metaphor

title: ENDO IS BUYING SOME DRUG RIGHTS FROM SKYEPHARMA
description: Endo Pharmaceuticals Holdings Inc. will pay as much as $120 million to the British biotechnology company SkyePharma for the rights to sell two painkillers in the United States and Canada. Endo will pay $25 million for rights to Depomorphine and Propofol IDD-D, with options for other products, SkyePharma said. SkyePharma may get another $95 million if the products reach the market and achieve certain sales targets, the company said. Endo, which is based in Chadds Ford, Pa., wants to add products as rivals prepare to market cheaper copycat versions of a painkiller it currently sells, Percocet. The marketing agreement is the second announced this week by SkyePharma, which said on Thursday that it had sold marketing rights to its Depocyt treatment for lymphomatous meningitis to Enzon Pharmaceuticals of Bridgewater, N.J., for $12 million.

title: Lott Will Get Chairmanship Through Deal, Senators Say

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Oil Executive Named
description: Jos Eduardo Dutra, a Workers' Party senator and former union leader, was tapped to head Petrleo Brasileiro, signaling that the company may focus more on the government's economic goals than on profit. Andre Singer, a spokesman for President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, confirmed the appointment. Mr. Dutra, 43, will probably carry out Mr. da Silva's promises of having Petrobras, the state oil company, build oil platforms in Brazil and use the company to create jobs. Mr. da Silva's energy minister said this week that the government might restore price controls and fuel subsidies to stem inflation. A geologist, Mr. Dutra worked seven years at Petrobras. Mr. Dutra was a union leader, and soon became leader of Mr. da Silva's Workers' Party. In 1994, he was elected senator in Brazil's northeastern state of Sergipe and this year made an unsuccessful bid for state governor.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: OFFICERS FACE CHILD SEX CHARGES Two Cambridgeshire police officers who played roles in a search for two missing 10-year-old girls last August that draw national attention are to stand trial on unrelated child sex charges. Brian Stevens, 41, and Anthony Goodridge, 34, are accused of possessing and distributing indecent images of children; Mr. Stevens is also charged with indecent assault on two girls under 16. Both men, now suspended from the force, provided support to the family of one of the girls, whose bodies were found in a ditch 13 days after their disappearance, and Mr. Stevens read a poem at her funeral. A former school janitor has been charged with the killings.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 1,000 Arrested In Protest Against Police

The protests followed the killing of three men last weekend by the police, who said they were robbers; their families said they were innocent. Five hundred people were arrested and 50 people injured after similar protests on Tuesday. Fearing unrest, Indian Railways stopped 200 trains for 12 hours in the state. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Can the Courts Save Wilderness?
description: Environmentalists have had so little to cheer about in the last two years that any victory is worth noting. In recent weeks they have prevailed in two important court cases that represent potentially major setbacks to the Bush administration's aggressive efforts to open up big chunks of the West to development by the oil, gas, mining and timber industries. Nobody is under the illusion that two adverse rulings are going to change the administration's fundamental bias toward commercial exploitation. But it's reassuring to know that there are still a few judges left who care about the niceties of environmental law and the needs of nature.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Exports Grow In Several Nations
description: Demand for electronics from within Asia appears to be keeping the region's export engines turning even as the crucial United States market slows. Malaysia and the Philippines both reported strong export growth for November, thanks largely to higher electronics shipments to Japan, China and elsewhere in Asia. Compared with the month before, Malaysian exports in November slowed, but they were still up about 10 percent, but in the Philippines, export growth accelerated to 18 percent. Exports to the United States , however, showed a decline in both countries. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: RADIOSHACK'S PROFIT GAIN IS LESS THAN EXPECTED

Profit was 58 cents to 60 cents a share, compared with an earlier estimate of 63 cents to 68 cents, the company said. RadioShack said it still expected per-share profit to increase as much as 15 percent a year from 2003 to 2005. The company, which is based in Fort Worth, will report fourth-quarter sales on Jan. 14.

But he said he never expected to wind up in an apartment building named Brasilia in Queens, without money or family, and ill with kidney disease.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Pipelines Sold
description: Canada's largest natural gas producer, the EnCana Corporation, sold one pipeline and said it would complete the sale of a second later this month for a total of 1.6 billion Canadian dollars ($1.01 billion) to cut debt and pay for oil and gas projects. EnCana, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, completed the sale of its 70 percent share in the Cold Lake Pipeline System to the Inter Pipeline Fund for 425 million Canadian dollars, the company said. Inter Pipeline, a limited partnership operating in western Canada, now owns 85 percent of Cold Lake. EnCana will also complete the sale of its Express Pipeline System later this month.

title: Displaying An Empire For Posterity
description: As Britain's baby boomers came of age in the mid-1960's, the sun was setting on the British Empire. Instead of young Britons heading off to run the colonies as soldiers and administrators, Jamaicans, Indians, Pakistanis and other former colonial subjects began migrating in droves to Britain. It was now the turn of the ex-colonies to change the mother country. In a sense, the British Empire had come home to roost.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rate Change Unlikely
description: Sir Edward George, the governor of the Bank of England, said he expected no ''sharp change'' in British interest rates, which have held at a 39-year low of 4 percent for the last 13 months. In a radio interview, he said the British economy, which is growing more robustly than its major counterparts in Continental Europe, remained exposed to the global slowdown and would benefit most of all from ''stronger recovery in the world economy.'' Sir Edward said he expected consumer spending and inflation in housing prices to ease without a crash in the booming real estate market. Recent data have shown Britain's manufacturing sector in continued doldrums while consumer spending, which fuels two-thirds of the economy, has slowed. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: New Neighbors Proposed For White Elephant Hotel
description: Thor Magnus, a White Plains developer, has proposed to construct office and apartment buildings around Elephant Hotel in Somers, which is trying to maintain its 18th century hamlet atmosphere. The architectural features of the neighborhood surrounding the hotel, listed on the National Register of Historical Places, have been preserved since the early 19th century. Mr. Magnus has submitted a proposal to the Somers Planning Board to build 17,000 square feet of office buildings and seven one-bedroom apartments. Past development proposals around the Elephant Hotel have encountered resistance from the community. A Planning Board member, Frank Billingsley, said that Mr. Magnus is ''sensitive'' to the town's historical heritage. A hearing is scheduled on Jan. 8. YILU ZHAO

title: No Wonder They Call It the Bottom of the World
description: NOWHERE has the historical slide from tragedy to farce been more pronounced than on the icy continent of Antarctica.

title: War Names
description: I have been conditioned, after many years of reading your magazine, to wait with trepidation for the liberal sucker punch that is normally thrown three-quarters of the way through what in many cases start out as fairly sane essays. Niall Ferguson, however, never throws the punch (The Way We Live Now, Dec. 15). He examines the analogy between the British Empire and modern-day America without the mandatory bashing of the actions of the morally bankrupt ''dead white men.'' He discusses Clausewitz without a hint of post-Vietnam-era moral superiority. He instead comes to the well-argued and logical conclusion that war is in some cases the most legitimate course of action, and that our war on terror is such a case.

title: Joni Mitchell's Long and Restless Journey
description: JONI MITCHELL'S new ''Travelogue'' isn't billed as a farewell, but it's hard to see it any other way. Ms. Mitchell is 58, and her once-girlish soprano is now a frail and unsteady mezzo. This personally (not to say idiosyncratically) chosen, newly arranged collection of 22 of her songs from 1966 to 1994 presumably represents some sort of retrospective summa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARPOFF, BETTY ALDEN
description: KARPOFF-Betty Alden. Illustrator and graphic designer, of Croton on Hudson, NY, Cooper Union class of 1942, died December 28th at the age of 82 after a long illness. Survived by her husband of 58 years, Herbert; sons David and Jonathan; and grandchildren Joshua and Ruane. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Jos Gironella, 85, Author and Franco Backer
description: Jos Maria Gironella, a Spanish author who won praise in the United States for his fiction set in Spain during its civil war, died on Friday at home in Arenys de Mar, near Barcelona. He was 85.

title: Merit Pay
description: After a night of celebrating my brother's graduation in Washington, we took what should have been a $10 cab ride home. However, the cab was involved in an accident. I was angry at the driver for his poor skills, and so we left without paying the fare. But now that I've calmed down, I wonder: did we do the right thing? Jeffrey Wurtzel, Boston

title: Here Today and Here Tomorrow
description: Fashion fads may fade and fancies may pass, but only a chosen few have the staying power to make the transition from finders to keepers. Below are nine new classics for the new year, products that leapt to popularity within the last decade and have since become sartorial and beauty staples. While not as seasoned as Herms's Birkin bag or as eye-catching as Juicy Couture's velour sweatsuits, these young standards have staked their claim on closets and store shelves and can be relied upon to return season after seaon -- long after the last baguette has crumbled into obscurity.

He was hired to map out a future for United Airlines just two days after the company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection early last month.

description: Tony Dungy, the Indianapolis Colts' coach, is highly regarded for his analytical mind. But he had no answers after today's 41-0 lambasting by the Jets.

title: New York, Post-9/11 And Pre-
description: THERE may be eight million stories in the naked city. But 15 months after the destruction of the World Trade Center, the simultaneous release of Martin Scorsese's ''Gangs of New York'' and Spike Lee's ''25th Hour'' suggests that those tales are piddling subplots in a larger, more ferocious historical drama.

title: New Rochelle? No, Yonkers
description: A GOOD bit of ''Catch Me If You Can,'' the holiday hit movie directed by Steven Spielberg and starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Tom Hanks, is set in New Rochelle. The movie is based on the life of Frank Abagnale Jr., who grew up in New Rochelle in the 1960's, and at a young age began a life of of check fraud, impersonation and escape. With gumption, charm and forged credentials, Mr. Abagnale masqueraded an airline pilot, a doctor and a lawyer. He also became a master check counterfeiter, cashing millions of dollars worth of bad checks. His father, a proud Rotarian, had some disputes with the I.R.S. and fell on hard times, losing the family business, a stationery store in town. But none of the film was shot in Mr. Abagnale's hometown. Most of it was made in Hollywood. Three scenes, however, were shot in Yonkers. Mr. Hanks, as the F.B.I. agent in pursuit of Abignale, played by Mr. DiCaprio, makes a phone call at a phone booth in Larkin Park. A Laundromat at 151 Lake Ave. was used in the film too, as well as a portion of Buena Vista Street (between 108-100), which Mr. DiCaprio runs down.

title: Those Biceps Are A Girl's Best Friend
description: THE smell of Ben Gay wafted through the air, mingling with the smoke and sweat at McLoon's, a saloon in Rockville Centre. But the elbows bending on a recent evening were not at the bar. Guzzling beer was not the point.

description: IT took my husband years to turn me into an enthusiast for hiking in the woods with the kids and the dog. It took the rifle-toting, beer-swilling, stubble-bearded men in O.S.H.A. orange piled into old pickup trucks with plywood barracks on the beds only a few minutes to get me the heck out of Dodge.

title: Destiny's Child
description: I've always known that I would die at 63. I'm now 62. The year of my death was foretold in my horoscope, which was cast by my family's astrologer in 1940. Like most Calcuttans of my generation, I might not have a birth certificate, but I do have a horoscope, an older authority, calculated according to the alignments of planets at what my family remembers as the moment of my delivery. This scroll of yellow paper with Hindu astrological charts and Sanskrit writing describes my temperament, alerts me to cosmic incompatibility when looking for a husband and predicts when my life's important events, both pleasant and unpleasant, are likely to happen.

title: If You Know How to Rig a Sloop, Raise Your Hand and Get Aboard
description: In 1774, a Yale University student named David Bushnell invented the first wooden submarine, called the Turtle. It was 7 3/5frac12 4/5 feet long and 8 feet tall, just large enough to hold one man with air for 30 minutes, and it was operated by foot pedals and hand levers. Its mission was to affix 160-pound bombs to blow up the British ships that were blockading New York Harbor.

title: A Long History and Longer Menu
description: INDIAN spices could be the inspiration for the decor at Bengal Tiger. The hues of chilies, cinnamon, turmeric, fennel, mustard, cumin and coriander, to name a few, are echoed in the dazzling patchwork canopies tenting the space of the narrow dining rooms. Indian sculpture and tapestries and sconces shedding mellow light line the walls.

title: RECOVERY SEEN
description: Rutgers economists say New Jersey is emerging from recession. Although the state's unemployment rate last year was the highest in six years, at 5.6 percent, the trend recently reversed and the number of jobs grew slightly. James E. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, said the state should gain 40,000 jobs this year and each of the next four years. But he said some industries, including health care and telecommunications and other high-technology businesses, might continue to lag. Even so, the Federal Reserve Bank in Philadelphia has forecast moderate growth overall for the state this year. Jeremy Pearce

title: Dec. 29-Jan. 4: NATIONAL; FUNNY ACCOUNTING BUT NO FRAUD
description: Tyco International admitted for the first time that it had used financial gimmickry to inflate its earnings under its former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, who has been charged with looting the company of hundreds of millions of dollars. Despite acknowledging that the company pushed the rules of accounting -- employees at one division were directed in a memorandum to find cost savings by ''financial engineering'' -- internal investigators still said that they had not uncovered ''systemic or significant fraud'' that had fundamentally damaged the company. Andrew Ross Sorkin

But when a worker carried water to her she leaned over to drink and something tiny, with tightly closed eyes and skin speckled with short white hairs, wriggled from under her forearm.

description: Led by ''Spider-Man'' and bolstered at year's end by ''The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers,'' 2002 proved to be a record year at the box office. An estimated $9.3 billion flowed into the nation's cinemas, breaking the previous year's record by 11 percent. More stirring to Hollywood's blood was that even factoring in higher prices, more actual tickets were sold than at any time since the late 1950's -- nearly 1.6 billion. Rick Lyman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, ELEANOR JACK
description: GIBSON-Eleanor Jack. Died December 30, 2002, age 92. Born in Peoria, IL., she was an experimental psychologist who received the National Medal of Science in 1992. Author of five books on perception, infant developent, and reading, Dr. Gibson was educated at Smith College and held a Ph.D. from Yale. She was Susan Linn Sage Professor of Psychology Emerita at Cornell University. An elected member of the National Academy of Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, she also received 11 honorary degrees. She is survived by her sister, Emily Jack; son and daughter-in-law James J. and Lois Rauch Gibson; daughter and son-in-law Jean and David Rosenberg; and four grandchildren. Her husband, psychologist James J. Gibson, Sr. died in 1979. Memorial contributions may be made to the Gibson Lecture Series, C/O Tom Gilovich, Chair, Psychology Dept, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853. Memorial services will be held at a later date in Middlebury, VT., and Columbia, SC.

description: AFTER the American premiere of Leos Janacek's ''Jenufa'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Dec. 6, 1924, Olin Downes described the work in The New York Times as ''an opera of singular originality, navet and unevenness of invention and effect.'' ''Jenufa'' ran for only six performances, and it was not heard again at the Met for a half century.

title: A Joyous Curmudgeon Unstilled by Death
description: Nicolas Slonimsky was one of the music world's most colorful figures in the 20th century, and he occupied much of it. A composer, conductor, musicologist and prolific author and editor, the Russian-born Slonimsky died in 1995 at 101. His major legacies included several editions of Baker's Biographical Dictionary of Musicians; the classic ''Lexicon of Musical Invective'' from 1952, an endlessly engaging collection of seemingly -- or patently -- misguided evaluations of famous composers since Beethoven; and ''Slonimsky's Book of Musical Anecdotes'' from 1945, reissued last year.

If a university wants to spend money to make a better overall product, why not do it? Colleges should not be blamed for wanting to foster camaraderie on campus.

Below are nine new classics for the new year, products that leapt to popularity within the last decade and have since become sartorial and beauty staples. title: Ideas & Trends; Whose Sidewalk Is It, Anyway?
description: ASK an urban planner to define the cradle of civilization, and thoughts drift to that innocuous but vital ribbon of concrete, the sidewalk. ''Lowly, unpurposeful and random as they appear, sidewalk contacts are the small change from which a city's wealth of public life may grow,'' Jane Jacobs wrote in her classic ''The Death and Life of Great American Cities.''

title: The Best Medicine
description: In the days before bumper stickers told us to question authority, authority was one of the engines that kept society moving along. Teachers, police officers and clergy members were the people whose sudden entrance into a room made us stamp out cigarettes and stand up straight. We respected them, and with that respect came a healthy twinge of fear coupled with a desire to please. But then some teachers met chaotic classrooms with lower academic standards, some cops reached too quickly for a gun and some members of the clergy did things that defied our imagination. The people in those professions who deserved to have authority lost it in the tides of scandal. Over time we forgot that the word ''authority'' ever had a good definition. After all, American political authority had slipped with the witch hunts of McCarthy, stumbled with L.B.J. in Vietnam and fell with a resounding permanence in Watergate. Our leaders had looked us in the eye on national television, and they had lied.

title: The Illuminator
description: Among today's successful designers, Ingo Maurer is a rarity: he tells the truth. His lighting designs, whether lamps for production or one-of-a-kind installations, are widely acclaimed, yet they are not slick, nor are they conventionally pretty. Some of them even seem a bit awkward at first. But that's because they're fundamentally about one thing: casting light on human feeling. When the 70-year-old Maurer -- who is based in Munich but whose only retail store is located in SoHo -- was describing a piece he designed in 1997 for a Spanish bank, his inspiration was telling. ''Paragaudi,'' a long, rippling, illuminated ribbon of gold-plated aluminum, is a homage to Antonio Gaud, the great Catalan architect. ''He was not cool,'' Maurer notes admiringly. ''His architecture was very emotional.''

The agencies were supposed to approve a deal that would transfer water from farms in the Imperial Valley to cities in San Diego County, but last-minute demands by the farmers blocked an agreement. The cutback is the first time the Interior Department has intervened to prevent California from taking more than its standard allotment from the river. Dean E. Murphy

title: Yep, the Clash Was Musical, But Don't Tell Anyone

They were the Clash, not only one of punk's best bands but one of the best bands of any genre in the last 25 years. And there wasn't much they did confess to liking on their debut album in 1977, besides Jamaican reggae and themselves. ''You better leave town if you only wanna knock us,'' Joe Strummer sang with snarling fury. ''Nothing stands the pressure of the Clash City Rockers.''

As more international, multicultural families are created, there is hope that the world will become more tolerant. Tonight I will think about opening our home to one of these children. In this, I hope I am not alone.

title: When a Kleptocratic, Megalomanacal Dictator Goes Bad
description: 'Do you see our baby president on top of the world?'' Marat, my driver, said, pointing to the sky. I craned my neck out the window to see an immense bronze bull with an even larger black metal globe astride its horns. Finally I saw him: a comparatively tiny gold figurine, the president as baby, maybe five stories up, nuzzling the whole earth from just below the North Pole; a golden kidney bean of an infant incongruously attached to the rest of the sculpture like a raccoon clinging to the top of a tree. ''It represents our president when he was orphaned in the 1948 earthquake,'' Marat explained.

The bureau was seeking help in identifying five Middle Eastern men who were believed to have entered the United States illegally around Christmastime. Was it a serious terrorist threat, or an immigration scam? Or a false lead? Officials made it clear that they didn't know but were exercising an abundance of caution. By week's end, no one was sure whether the men had even entered the country. Neil A. Lewis

title: Kurosawa's Quiet, Tragic Bureaucrat
description: ''IKIRU'' is returned and restored, with every image in the new print of Akira Kurosawa's 1952 film clean. Alas, not even photographic repair or medical progress, however, can erase the cloudy sacs of stomach cancer in the movie's opening shot. Watanabe still must die. It has to be so: nothing less than death can sustain this classic piece of cinematic humanism. Nothing will transcend the fatal X-rays but the sheer radiance of Watanabe's face as he finds belated purpose. Or as he starts to live: ''Living'' and ''Doomed'' are the usual English titles for ''Ikiru,'' and it speaks to the film's subtlety that Kurosawa lets us see them as nearly synonyms. (In fact, in Japanese, ''ikiru'' means ''to live.'')

title: Word for Word/The Ralian Agenda; And You Figured Cloning a Human Would Be Their Biggest Challenge
description: UNDER some generalized theory of the universe, it was probably inevitable that one day a France-based sect would, among other things, worship aliens from outer space, try to clone a human and hatch a plan to settle in Israel. A few weeks ago, this pattern began to take shape. The Ralians are led by a prophet, Claude Vorilhon, who says he encountered scientist-aliens in 1973 on a volcano crater in France. The aliens renamed him Ral; they told him that they had created earth people in their own (genetic) image, and they gave him a task. No, it was not to clone a human. That feat, which the group, without providing evidence, proclaimed a success on Dec. 27, simply illustrates a truth of the universe, as expressed in one of the organization's founding tenets: ''The created will one day become creator.''

title: Historic Drama Offshore
description: In September 1920, four days into a Navy recruitment campaign, the 800-ton S-Five attempted a routine crash dive, an exercise to reach periscope depth (140 feet) in less than a minute. But an open valve allowed seawater to flood the vessel and caused it to plow into the ocean floor 48 miles off the coast of Cape May, where it remains. ''Under Pressure: The Final Voyage of Submarine S-Five,'' by A. J. Hill (Free Press, $25), is a third-person narrative compiled from Navy records and 20 first-hand accounts. Mr. Hill, a physicist who served in the Navy, now lives in Boulder, Colo. Through system failure, the book details the engineering and principles that comprised a World War I-era sub. It also recounts the survival of Lt. Cmdr. Charles M. Cooke Jr. and his crew from drowning, asphyxiation and chlorine gas poisoning. With the help of trapped crew members, William Grace, an engineer from the merchant ship General Goethals, created more than 160 holes in a 15-foot section of the stern that was above water with a sledgehammer, allowing all 40 men to be rescued. Melissa Bannon

title: Goodbye, Columbus!
description: ''The evidence is massive,'' said Gavin Menzies of his new theory. ''I've got it coming out of my eyes!'' His voice was filled with excitement, just as you'd expect from someone propounding one of the most revolutionary ideas in the history of history. A retired navy man with white hair, Menzies still has a hint of red in the eyebrows that frame his ocean-blue eyes. Dressed in a handsome sports jacket and tie, he cheerfully invited me into his stately Georgian house in the Canonbury section of London. What he had to say, his publicists had warned me in breathless e-mail messages, would make ''every history book in print obsolete.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Masters of the Keyboard
description: ''It was never my intention to turn my typewriter into a heroic figure,'' Paul Auster writes. ''That is the work of Sam Messer, a man who stepped into my house one day and fell in love with a machine.'' The charming STORY OF MY TYPEWRITER (D.A.P., $17.95) details the shared obsession of Auster and the painter Sam Messer with the writer's 40-year-old Olympia portable typewriter. Once state-of-the-art but now obsolete, Auster's well-used and oft-repaired machine has served him steadily, through more than a dozen books, and will continue to do until he can no longer find the increasingly scarce replacement parts and ribbons it requires. In more than 30 paintings and drawings, Messer demonstrates his fascination with the typewriter as an artifact and with the connection that he perceives between Auster and the mechanical tool of his trade. One fanciful painting, for instance, portrays Auster juggling the letters of the keyboard. Another depicts Spider-Man-like webs emanating from his hands and leading directly to the typewriter. Several provide a droll dramatization of Auster's daily writing routine; in these, a many-armed author simultaneously smokes, drinks, moodily puts hand to head in dour concentration, and all the while keeps typing away. But Messer's focus always remains on the typewriter itself, in paintings characterized by thick layers of bright, vibrant colors. Successive pages demonstrate just how many varied ways there are of looking at a typewriter, especially when painted in bold contrasting hues of white, yellow, purple, red, orange, and black. Messer, who teaches at Yale, displays a similar humor and affection in his Expressionist-flavored caricatures of Auster. The result of their collaboration is a whimsical delight Diane Cole

But the 49ers' Jeff Garcia, one of the league's most mobile quarterbacks, raced around the right end, where Strahan had been, for a 16-yard gain.

title: The Healing Paradox
description: Andrew Weil's defense of ''integrative'' medicine (Letters, Dec. 22) contends that physicians and patients are leaving modern medicine because too often it does not work. I, as a surgeon, will be the first to say that medicine in 2002 is far from a perfect science, but this is not why physicians are leaving the field. Rather, it is skyrocketing malpractice premiums, decreasing reimbursements despite increasing expenses, out-of-control litigation and an ever-increasing mountain of paperwork and regulations that stifle the practice of medicine.

title: TOLLS INCREASE
description: As of 6:30 a.m. on New Year's Day, drivers using cash began shelling out 17 percent more in tolls on the New Jersey Turnpike. E-ZPass users began paying 10 percent more during rush hours and on weekends and 5 percent during weekday off-peak hours. The increases are the second phase of a plan that former Gov. Christie Whitman approved in January 2000 to pay off a $917 million bond for capital improvements for the turnpike. George James

title: Dec. 29-Jan. 4: INTERNATIONAL; KENYA'S NEW GOVERNMENT
description: Voters ousted the party that has ruled Kenya since independence in 1963, electing an opposition leader, Mwai Kibaki. Daniel arap Moi, who had ruled for 24 years, stepped down in accordance with the constitution. But his handpicked successor, Uhuru Kenyatta, was soundly defeated by Mr. Kibaki, who vowed to stamp out government corruption and revive the stagnant economy. Marc Lacey

description: The comments on Rutgers, in Michael Sokolove's article (Dec. 22), might have included mention of the fact that Paul Robeson was the first Rutgers football player to be named all-American -- twice. He also won 15 letters in four different sports, won the oratorical prize all four years, made Phi Beta Kappa and was class valedictorian. He went on to get a law degree at Columbia, then became one of America's greatest actor-singers.

title: Editorial Observer; Fearing the Worst Should Anyone Produce a Cloned Baby
description: Experts increasingly suspect that a fringe cult's claim to have cloned a human baby is a publicity-seeking hoax, especially now that the group seems to be evading genetic tests that might prove its claim. The cult's deep-seated belief that space aliens created the human race by cloning is so wacko that all of its other claims become suspect. But with several renegade groups supposedly racing to produce the first cloned baby, it is almost inevitable that sooner or later someone will succeed. It's time to start preparing ourselves mentally for that eventuality.

description: SOME New Yorkers will remember Simon Russell Beale as Iago and Hamlet onstage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music several years ago. But that may be about as far as his fame has spread in the United States. He has never appeared on Broadway, and he has not yet had a film career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREEDON, RICHARD S.
description: CREEDON-Richard S. 75. Died peacefully at his home in Chatham, MA, on the afternoon of December 31, 2002. Born in Pittsburgh, PA, raised in Winchester, MA, and a longtime resident of Stamford, CT, he was the beloved husband of Joan Leader Creedon for 48 years. He is held in loving memory by his four children, two brothers, their families and his many wonderful friends. A Navy Veteran, Richard graduated from Colby College in 1952. He completed Harvard Business School's Advanced Management Program in 1970, and earned his Masters of Public Administration from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University in 1974. After starting his business career with the Richardson-Vicks Company in 1952, he moved on to further successes as an executive with Ted Bates & Company, the Squibb Corporation and Nabisco Brands, Inc. Mr. Creedon is a past chairman of the Association of National Advertisers and served on the Board of the Ad Council. Richard's contributions to his community included serving as elected member of the Board of Finance of the City of Stamford, and member of the Planning Board. He was also a Campaign Coordinator for Congressman Stuart McKinney. After Richard retired from Nabisco in 1983, he and Joan established full-time residency in Chatham, MA, where he has since served as Commissioner of the BKCS. His sensitive spirit will live within the gentle landscape and revered ocean for his loved ones to enjoy forever. A memorial and celebration of his life for family and friends is planned for June 21, 2003, in Chatham, MA. Donations will be gratefully received in Richard S. Creedon's name by the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station, P.O. Box 4777, New York, NY 10163 or online at michaeljfox.org.

title: Snow Whites
description: White cleanses the fashion palate after all that red jazz of the holidays. Around now, in the few weeks before the mud season sets in, cloth and fur coats are often seen along the avenues in the refreshing dazzle of the color of snow. They look best with matching pantsuits and hats. White was introduced for day by Andr Courrges in 1962. It is a great luxury, considering the laundry bills.

title: 'Zora Neale Hurston'
description: First and foremost a storyteller, with profound appreciation for the power of a well-crafted tale, Hurston moved to New York in 1925 and used her storytelling talent to refashion her life along mythic lines, erasing everything that didn't contribute to the new person she had determined to create. That person would have known hardships and hard times, but mostly in a general way. She might have disappointments, but they would never become obstacles. She would be tough and independent and young (in her early twenties, like her friends). Above all, she would be game for everything, full of enthusiasm and ideas. Nothing would be beyond her. She would live up to her proud heritage as a daughter of Eatonville, America's first incorporated all-black town-even if that meant starting over from scratch.

He is survived by his wife Polly Rothstein, their daughter Amy Rothstein and Daniel Melnechuk, and their son Chester Rothstein and Frances Barone. A graduate of MIT and Harvard Law School, Jesse was a senior partner in the intellectual property law firm of Amster, Rothstein & Ebenstein. That goes double for space-constrained New Yorkers, for whom having people for dinner means, more often than not, eating out. Even those with sufficient space, cash and derring-do to give a full-tilt dinner party at home are used to calling upon the likes of Sean Driscoll, the suave co-owner of Glorious Food, the august New York catering company.

title: A War for Oil?
description: Our family spent winter vacation in Colorado, and one day I saw the most unusual site: two women marching around the Aspen Mountain ski lift, waving signs protesting against war in Iraq. One sign said: ''Just War or Just Oil?'' As I watched this two-woman demonstration, I couldn't help notice the auto traffic whizzing by them: one gas-guzzling S.U.V. or Jeep after another, with even a Humvee or two tossed in for good measure. The whole scene made me wonder whether those two women weren't -- indeed -- asking the right question: Is the war that the Bush team is preparing to launch in Iraq really a war for oil?

title: AMNESTY RESULTS
description: A tax amnesty program reaped $270 million for the state, nearly double the $150 million that had been predicted, according to the Treasury Department's annual audit report issued in late December. The program, which allowed people to pay sales, income and business taxes due between 1996 and June 2002 without penalties or criminal charges, was intended to help close a $3 billion hole in the state budget. Taxpayers owing taxes for the amnesty period who did not come forward will be assessed an additional 5 percent penalty on top of the standard interest and penalty charges. Karen DeMasters

title: History in a Greenhouse
description: I HAVE very fond memories of my grandmother when I was growing up in Istanbul. I would visit her almost daily on my way back from school. She had a greenhouse with all kinds of exotic plants and a little couch by the window. We had no central heating, and when a fire got going in a stove, you would take the hot coals and put them in a contraption called a mangal, which was like a brass cup filled with ash, and carry it from room to room.

title: Science Fiction
description: COYOTE (Ace, $23.95), by Allen M. Steele, is full of pleasant surprises. It is actually three books in one, each a bracing turn on a genre staple. The first story is a near-future political thriller in which a right-wing coup has resulted in the overthrow of the constitutional government of the United States, erecting a fascist state called the United Republic of America. To awe its enemies, the republic decides to colonize a recently discovered Earth-type planet called Coyote. But a group of rebels, led by conspirators within the government's space program, plans to hijack the transport spaceship and replace the government's hand-picked colonists with 100 leading dissidents and their families. Steele manages to wring considerable suspense from this scenario, which reads like an updated version of Sinclair Lewis's antifascist novel of 1935, ''It Can't Happen Here.''

title: Dec. 29-Jan. 4: NATIONAL; THE COST OF WAR
description: Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the Bush administration's budget director, estimated that the cost of an Iraq war could be $50 billion to $60 billion, a figure similar to the cost of the 1991 Persian Gulf war. The estimate was well below one by Lawrence B. Lindsey, President Bush's former chief economic adviser, who had said last fall that an Iraq war could cost $100 billion to $200 billion. Democrats said that Mr. Daniels was playing down the cost to make a war more politically palatable. Elisabeth Bumiller

title: Dec. 29-Jan. 4: INTERNATIONAL; KILLINGS IN YEMEN
description: An assailant, identified by the authorities as Abed Abdel Razzak Kamel, smuggled a gun wrapped like a baby into a hospital run by Baptist missionaries in the town of Jibla, about 100 miles south of the capital, Sana, and killed three American workers. Mr. Kamel has been arrested. Only two days before, a gunman killed a prominent secular politician, Jarallah Omar, 60, leader of the Yemeni Socialist Party, just after he gave a speech to the Islamic Isla party congress on the need to end the nation's culture of violence. The police arrested a man identified as a former mosque preacher, Ahmed Ali Jarallah, 26, in the attack. Authorities say that the attacks may be linked and that the two suspects appear to be part of a group of Islamic militants, led by Mr. Jarallah.

This time, they were determined to go further, to fulfill the preseason predictions of greatness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARIO, ELIZABETH BOHRER
description: VARIO-Elizabeth Bohrer. A longtime Chappaqua resident, passed away January 4, 2003, at Westchester Medical Center. She was 81. Elizabeth, known as Betsy to her friends and family, was born in Manhattan, on March 19, 1921, to Dr. John V. and Laura Smith Bohrer. She resided in Shrub Oak in earlier years, but called Chappaqua home for the last 34 years. Elizabeth was an alumna of the Spense School in Manhattan and the Leland Powers School for dramatic arts in Boston. She was a parishioner and volunteer at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mt. Kisco. Prior to marrying and raising a family, she enjoyed work in the theater, both on stage and in various production positions. She was particularly proud to have performed in a number of USO shows during the 1940's. Elizabeth also worked for the New York Times during that period. Mrs. Vario is survived by her children: Victoria Vario Rowe (and her husband Charles) of Valley Cottage, NY, and John Peter Vario of Chatham, MA. Elizabeth was predeceased by her husband, Ralph S. Vario, who died in 1998. In addition, she is survived by many dear cousins, in-laws and friends, and will be missed by all who knew her. For information contact Cassidy - Flynn Funeral Home, 288 Main St, Mt. Kisco, NY; 914-666-4840. Visiting 2-6 PM, on Monday. Funeral service St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Mt. Kisco, 11 AM, Tuesday. Interment Fair Ridge Cemetery, Chappaqua. Donations may be made to The Guiding Eyes for the Blind, 611 Granite Springs Rd, Yorktown Hgts, NY 10598.

description: LEFF-Eleanor (nee Wiesen). Died at home on January 3, 2003 at the age of 94. Beloved wife of the late Carl, adored mother of Marjorie Miller and Maxine Myers; motherin-law of Morgan Miller; devoted sister of the late Lillian Leff, Seymour, Irving and Sherman Wiesen; sister-inlaw of Mae, Tobie and Shirley Wiesen; cherished grandmother of Betsy, Bob, Amy and Cindy Miller, and Mark Asher and Baruch Myers; great-grandmother of Jessica, Lindsay, Max and Mathieu Miller, David Sucherman, Shirah, Ranana, Hillel, Hanoniah, Israel, Sara Meir and Sora, Chaya, Sheina, Menachem, Schmuel, Sholem, Bat Sheva and Yosef Myers. Until her illness, she was a dedicated and resourceful leader with a marvelous capacity for optimism and fun. She was the president of the ''Junior Committee'' and board member of the NY section of the National Council of Jewish Women. She was a tireless fundraiser for the Jewish causes in which she believed and her efforts for Council and UJA/Federation were extraordinary. Her indomitable spirit and concern for those less fortunate was an integral part of her life. She was a truly spiritual and moral human being who believed and never lost her faith in God. She leaves her family and the world with a wonderful legacy. We will remember her for her devotion and generosity of spirit. We will miss her enthusiasm and critical eye. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATES, BARBARA, M.D.
description: BATES-Barbara, M.D. Died December 18, 2002 at her home in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania. A native of Auburn, New York, Dr. Bates earned her BA at Smith College in 1949, then completed medical studies and residency training at Cornell University Medical College in New York City. Barbara Bates gained national and international recognition as an outstanding professor of medicine and an activist in interdisciplinary healthcare. In the late 1960's she helped conceive and develop the then new role of nurse practitioner working to improve public access to healthcare by encouraging greater collaboration between physicians and nurses. Her best known book, ''A Guide to Physical Examination and History Taking'', first published in 1974 and continuing under her direction for seven editions became and still is the leading text in its field published in eleven languages. In 1992 she published her awarding winning study, ''Bargaining for Life, a Social History of Tuberculosis, 1876-1938.'' From 1980 until she retired in 1996, Dr. Bates held faculty positions at the University of Pennsylvania Schools of Medicine and Nursing and at the Medical College of Pennsylvania and Hahnemann. A celebration of her life and reception is planned for Sunday, February 2, 2003 beginning at 4:30 PM at the College of Physicians of Philadelphia, 19 S. 22 St, Philadelphia. Donations in Barbara Bates memory may be made to the Center for the Study of the History of Nursing at the University of Pennsylvania or to the hospice of the Visiting Nurse Association of Greater Philadelphia.

''En Attendant Godot,'' or, in its English title, ''Waiting for Godot,'' would change Beckett's life completely and would become the most profound and influential play of the last half of the 20th century.

title: Iraq's Cultural Capital
description: The ancient kingdom of Mesopotamia, which flourished in the region that became Iraq, is what textbooks like to call the birthplace of urban civilization. The Mesopotamians were the first to record their thoughts in writing, the first to divide the day into 24 hours, the first to eat off ceramic plates. Iraq is home to some of the most important landmarks of the Judeo-Christian tradition, including the reputed Garden of Eden and Ur, the birthplace of the patriarch Abraham. The area had a second flowering in the Middle Ages, when it became a capital of the Islamic world and mosques sprang up everywhere. With war in Iraq looming, many in the art historical world are worried about what might be damaged or destroyed. Below, a map of some of the country's most significant sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINOTT, GINSBURG, DAVID
description: GINOTT - GINSBURG - David. A Greenwich resident passed away at the Westchester Medical Center on Wednesday, January 1, 2003 after having suffered a heart attack. He was 58. Born in Tel Aviv, Israel on August 30, 1944. He was the son of the late Abraham and Gela Ginsburg. Mr. Ginott was President of Rayburn Musical Instrument Co. of Boston and was the founder and president of the E.M. Winston Band Instruments Co. and several other musical instruments companies. He was an avid supporter of music education and supported school programs throughout the northeast and around the world. As a man of generous spirit and sensitivity to the needs of others he was an ardent supporter of many charities in the United States and Israel, particularly Tzohar, which educates disabled and disadvantaged children, and the Ken Foundation, which trains guide dogs for the disabled. In addition, Mr. Ginott was a veteran of the IDF and maintained close ties with Israel throughout his life. He was a lover of musical culture and was deeply involved in the restoration of the Louis Armstrong Archives at Queens College. He is survived by his wife Ronni Ginott of Green wich, CT, his two daughters Jamie and Lindsay Ginott both of Greenwich, CT, and his sister Haya Cohen of Tel Aviv, Israel. A funeral service will be held at Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT on Sunday, January 5, 2003 at 1:30 PM. Burial will follow at Riversville Cemetery, Greenwich, CT. Contributions can be made to: Or Chadash/ American Friends of Tzohar Attn: Rabbi Avraham Schecter, 1431 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11230.

title: Looking for Ideas in the Land of Free Expression
description: IT was well past midnight, and Dao Anh Khanh, still jet-lagged from the trip from Vietnam, stood shivering at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge in Chinatown. He was cold and scared, but as he listened to the subway cars roaring overhead and the rain drizzling all around, his fear subsided. Sean Meehan, a percussionist he had just met at an improvisation festival, felt the urge for an outdoor jam session. As his new friend coaxed textured rhythms from a snare drum, Mr. Dao shed his coat and sang, first in low, guttural moans, then howling with the wind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKAKEL, RUSHTON WALTER
description: SKAKEL - Rushton Walter. 79, of Hobe Sound passed away, Thursday, January 2, 2003, at Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center. Born in Chicago, IL, he was a long time resident of Greenwich, CT before moving to Hobe Sound, FL in 1993. He attended Amherst College and graduated from Georgetown University where he later joined its Board of Governors. He served in the U.S. Army during WWII. He was a member of St. Christopher's Catholic Church in Hobe Sound. Mr. Skakel began his business career in St. Louis for New York-based Great Lakes Carbon Corporation and served as its chairman for over twenty years. Among his annual rituals was participating in weeklong trail rides with Rancheros Visitadores in Santa Ynez Valley, CA and visiting the Abbey of Gethsemane in Kentucky. He loved to play golf, tennis and ski. He was a generous, loving, kind man who always had a kind word to say to friend and stranger alike. He supported Hill House Senior Center in Greenwich and the Alcoholism Council of New York. His first wife, Anne Reynolds Skakel predeceased him in 1973. He is survived by his wife Anna Mae Skakel of Hobe Sound; his son Rushton W. Skakel, Jr. and his wife Helen of Bogota, Colombia; daughter, Julie Skakel of Darien, CT; son, Thomas Skakel and his wife Anne of Lennox, MA; son, John Skakel and his wife Eileen of Portland, OR; son, Michael Skakel of CT; son David Skakel and his wife Kate of Mosier, OR; and Stephen Skakel of New Canaan, CT; his stepdaughters, Elizabeth Mallozzi of New Canaan, CT and Jennifer Kennedy of Carbondale, CO; his sisters, Ethel Kennedy of McLean, VA and Ann McCooey of Greenwich, CT; 13 grandchildren and two step grandchildren. Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated, Saturday, January 4 at 11 AM at St. Christopher Catholic Church in Hobe Sound, FL. Friends may call from 4:00 to 8:00 PM at Knapp Funeral Home, Greenwich, CT, Thursday, January 9. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Mary's Catholic Church in Greenwich, CT, Friday, January 10. Interment will follow at St. Mary's Cemetery. For more information call Young & Prill Funeral Home, Stuart, 772-223-9300.

title: A New China Pattern
description: Jean-Georges Vongerichten has the most confident walk in New York. Bouncy like a boxer's yet turned out like a dancer's (he chops and slices standing in second position), its bantam-cock ebullience signals both purpose and delight. This exuberance isn't just a matter of his own critical and entrepreneurial success but the personification of the epigram ''If you love your work, you'll never have a job.'' He's about to open a new restaurant (ye gods, another?) in TriBeCa called 66, which will bring his total to five in New York alone (six counting the sandwich drop-by Lipstick Caf). If you can map the inner contentment of a man by his outward appearance and gesture, J.G.V. is an ecstatic. ''I work in my office from 9 to 12, then go to therapy,'' he says, adding, with perfect timing and a glint of hazel eye, '' . . . cooking!''

Assisted by a national boom that produced a gusher of state revenues, these executives made their names by cutting taxes and pushing for innovative solutions on welfare, education, health care and the environment.

title: Parcells Brings Bag of Fixes to a New N.F.L.
description: He stepped down as the Jets' coach three years ago, saying he had coached his final game in the National Football League. He negotiated to take over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers a year ago before withdrawing at the last minute. That time, he insisted, he was really, really through.

title: Dance Listings

Wed., 8; next Sun., 2: Keely Garfield presents "My Mother Was a Four Alarm Fire" and "Free Drinks for Ladies . . . title: Made in China, Bought in China
description: RARELY has a big international company spun its wheels as fecklessly as General Motors did when it first raced into China. Amid notions of fabled riches -- if just one in a hundred Chinese drove Chevrolets! -- G.M.'s 1992 foray collapsed after the company made about 300 pickup trucks, traded insults with its Chinese partner and entered local lore as another fool mesmerized by China's mythical market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLY, ESTELLE S.
description: BLY-Estelle S. Of New York (formerly of Great Neck) age 91. Loving widow of Saul Bly died peacefully on January 3rd, after a brief illness. Beloved mother of Linda Boxenbaum (Lewis) and Susan Obel (David). Adored grandmother of Nancy Rotenier (Robin), David Boxenbaum and Karen and Kenneth Obel (Jennifer). Loving great grandmother of Samuel and Sophie Rotenier and loving sister of Beverly Apple (Jerry). Retired for 26 years, she was the epitome of a kindergarten teacher, bringing love and good humor, sensitivity and caring to all whom she touched, regardless of age. Funeral services on Sunday, January 5 at 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Making a Clean Sweep of 2002
description: EACH year on Jan. 1, Helen Schifter, the Upper East Side socialite, strips her shelves and scours her closets, leaving no speck of lint in her wake. ''I'm a pretty ruthless editor,'' Mrs. Schifter said.

title: And Yet the More Things Change . . .
description: Dennis McNerney was sworn in New Year's Day as Bergen County executive after hitting all the right notes during his campaign: reform, an end to patronage; no more business as usual, new faces and new ideas. Get the drift?

title: QUICK BITE/Union City; Where Cuban Cowboys Grab Grub
description: New Jerseyans know all about the Wild West: West Milford, West Windsor, West Orange and the wide open plains of Scotch Plains. Ricky's Frontier celebrates the region's proud cowboy heritage. The restaurant is in Union City, home of a large Cuban population, which gives it a distinct Cuban influence. The combination is a little weird but ultimately wonderful.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: New Director at the Zimmerli

title: The Family Next Door: Furry and Full of Fun
description: Once upon a time, there were three bears: Papa Bear, Mama Bear and Baby Bear, otherwise known as Brother. One day, a sunny little girl bear arrived in their multilevel cottage, conveniently situated in a hollowed-out tree amid a shady wood. From then on the family of four -- more Dr. Seuss than Mother Goose -- lived happily ever after, but for the occasional bruised feelings or scraped paw.

title: A London Walk
description: To the Editor: No trip to London's East End (''The East End Goes Mainstream,'' Dec. 8) would be complete without a visit to Body Worlds, an anatomical exhibition of real human bodies, located in the former Old Truman Brewery on Brick Lane, Spitalfields (Aldgate East or Shoreditch tube stations). The exhibition, which continues until early February, features more than 200 ''plastinates'' of whole human bodies and organs that have been hardened by a process developed by a German, Prof. Gunther von Hagens. Some may call it gruesome, but I found it fascinating, and it is drawing huge crowds.

title: A New Volunteer's Confession
description: PEOPLE tell me I am a nice guy because I have recently started volunteering at two Yonkers organizations -- Groundwork Yonkers and the Job Readiness Program. They're wrong. I volunteer because I'm selfish.

title: Mutual Funds Report; This Time, No Lifeline In Health Stocks
description: WHEN Tenet Healthcare's stock price plunged last fall, many mutual fund managers were more than disappointed. In a dismal stock market, with drug and biotechnology stocks battered, many managers had looked to Tenet and other hospital stocks to buoy their portfolios.

title: Celebreality: The 'Stars' Are Elbowing Their Way In
description: IN the 500-channel universe, dead shows don't get to rest in peace. Yet ABC's ''Battle of the Network Stars'' has managed to vanish completely from the rerun afterlife. An occasional quasi-sports competition that ran from 1976 to 1988, ''Battle of the Network Stars'' featured teams of celebrities from ABC, CBS and NBC (back when there were just three networks) going head to head in everything from flag football to kayak racing to Simon Says. At the play-by-play mike sat Howard Cosell, his sarcasm oddly muffled. Or maybe he just didn't care anymore.

title: In the Brutal World of 'Oz,' A Rare Place for Women
description: THEY'RE standard scenarios for a prison drama: a guard makes a prisoner perform sex acts in exchange for the chance to place a phone call; a prisoner with breast cancer falls in love with the jailhouse doctor who makes the diagnosis and provides care.

He was dearly loved by his niece, Yvette, & her husband, Michael Davis, and by his many friends in New York City, Florida, California, Arizona, Ecuador & South Carolina. His devoted friend, David Maizer, will miss him most of all.

title: Editors' Note; EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article on Dec. 22 detailed negotiations that led to the $1.4 billion settlement two days earlier to revamp Wall Street research. The article described an Oct. 1 meeting of securities regulators, including Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, to discuss progress. It said the dinner started awkwardly when Mr. Spitzer described the meeting's site, an Italian-American social and sporting club in Manhattan, as looking like something from ''The Sopranos.''

title: Not a Good Winter for Birds
description: The number of wild birds that have been brought to the Mercer County Wildlife Center in Titusville has more than doubled since July -- almost all suffering from the effects of the West Nile Virus. Of 14 hawks with the disease, only 2 have survived; only 6 of the 20 great horned owls brought there are still alive.

title: The New Landmark Czar Looks Beyond Manhattan
description: The scene was a New Year's Day party at the Park Slope brownstone of Laura Hansen, the executive director of Place Matters, a nonprofit group. The conversation, fueled by bourbon and black-eyed peas (Ms. Hansen is from Tennessee), turned to one Robert B. Tierney, rumored to be the next chairman of the city Landmarks Preservation Commission. The guests, many of them architects or preservation specialists, asked the same question: ''Who is this guy?''

title: Time for Joey Pants To Take His Off
description: WHEN Joe Pantoliano was 18 and a high school senior in Hoboken, N.J., he was dyslexic and read at the level of an 8-year-old. His family had been on welfare and his unofficial stepfather was more than familiar with the inside of a prison. Mr. Pantoliano decided that acting would offer an escape from the path he was following, one of poverty with the potential for a life of crime. So he tried out for a school play.

title: Private Sector; In Times Square, at Least, Hope Sparkles
description: Those paying close attention on New Year's Eve might have noticed new Waterford crystal panels on the ball that dropped in Times Square. Each new panel is engraved with interlocking rosettes that surround the points of a star to evoke the idea of people hand in hand around the world and the theme of ''hope for courage.''

Well, my company is trashing -- uh, eliminating -- a lot of jobs because it has heartless, mercenary -- I mean competitive, profit-conscious -- managers. I can't tell you how long I'll be out of work because the economy stinks to high heaven -- uh, is highly uncertain. But the most important thing for you to know is that our lives will be completely -- I mean, not at all -- different.''

title: Here Today and Here Tomorrow

Below are nine new classics for the new year, products that leapt to popularity within the last decade and have since become sartorial and beauty staples. While not as seasoned as Herms's Birkin bag or as eye-catching as Juicy Couture's velour sweatsuits, these young standards have staked their claim on closets and store shelves and can be relied upon to return season after seaon -- long after the last baguette has crumbled into obscurity.

The rooms are basic with solar-powered lighting and private baths with shower, natural ventilation and balconies on the river. There is usually a breeze so the temperature in the shade is comfortable.

But since it hired the director and designer Julie Taymor to create the hit 1998 Broadway production of ''The Lion King,'' this entertainment company has been playing against type by enlisting devoted theater and opera talent for new work that is dedicated to the stage, not the screen.

title: Like Vivid, Alert Fish In Dances' Subtle Tides
description: The Doug Elkins Dance Company got the Altogether Different series off to a perfect start on Friday night at the Joyce Theater. This and other festivals increasingly tend to recycle work seen not so long ago in New York City and abroad. But Mr. Elkins and his endearingly down-to-earth performers and dances made a good case for the familiarity of simply settling back and enjoying the work of a mature and confident artist with no apparent agenda.

title: New York's Permanent Legislature
description: The problems with New York's State Legislature are so entrenched, so embedded in the structure and tradition in Albany that most New Yorkers believe nothing can ever change. How could it when, thanks to gerrymandering, legislators might as well be elected for life? And their permanence is matched only by their powerlessness. All the important decisions are made by three political bosses -- the governor and the leader of each legislative house. The budget is written in secret code. The lobbyists have free rein, even with government officials. The list goes on and on, with many of the worst abuses cataloged recently by Richard Prez-Pea and James McKinley Jr. of The New York Times. But a few key reforms could make all the difference and give New York's 19 million residents the government they deserve. If the Berlin Wall can come down, there is hope for Albany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGENSTEIN, PAUL
description: KLINGENSTEIN - Paul. Of Scarsdale, NY, and Longboat Key, FL, died peacefully at home on January 5, 2003, at age 88. He was surrounded by his cherished family. Loving and dearly loved husband of Selma for 56 years, devoted father of Dr. R. James Klingenstein (Susanne) and Irene Hess. Adored grandfather of David (Diane) and Suzanne Hess, and Rachel and Julie Klingenstein. Treasured brother of Max. A prominent figure in the photographic industry for more than 50 years, he later in life applied the same energy and creativity to charitable pursuits as he had to his career. A man of dignity and compassion, he was admired and respected for his warmth, wisdom and generosity. He will be missed by all who knew him and whose lives he touched. Services will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY, on Tuesday, January 7, at 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory made to the American Friends of the Hebrew University, 7280 West Palmetto Park Rd, Boca Raton, FL 33433, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTKIN, JEAN SOMERVILLE
description: KOTKIN-Jean Somerville. A leader in the American Ethical Union, the American Humanist Association, and the New York Society for Ethical Culture, she passed away at the Roosevelt Hospital of the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center in New York City on Saturday January 4, 2003. She was 80. Born Jean Somerville in Montreal, Quebec, Canada on October 30, 1922, at an early age she survived the death of her mother Elizabeth when she was three and her father John who died when she was 12. She also survived the death of her brother Jack who was killed in Belgium in World War II and her oldest brother William who died of cancer in the 1960s. She completed her high school education by the age of 16 and attended McDonald College at McGill University to obtain a teaching certificate. She supported herself first as a teacher and then later as a model with her long standing friend Frankie Goodman. Married twice, once to Fred Kerner and then Leonid Kotkin, she is survived by her first husband Fred, their son Jon Kerner, her son Garth Kotkin, her daughter Elizabeth Kotkin, her grandson Zachary Kerner, her granddaughter Connie Kotkin, her nephew Bill Somerville, her grand nephews Mark and Frank Somerville and two great grand nieces and one great grand nephew, as well as many friends and colleagues who came to know her, love her and respect her over the years. She was a member of the New York Society since 1958, serving on the Board of Trustees for over 20 years, the Board of Governors of the Ethical Culture School and the Board of the Encampment for Citizenship. She was a founding member of the Weis Ecology Center and helped to found Just Women, which assists female ex-inmates prepare to return to work. She served as the Executive Director of the American Ethical Union and as admnistrator of the Humanist Institute. Despite her incredibly busy career as an Ethical Humanist Leader-or more likely because of itshe completed her B.A. from Fordham University in religious studies at 58, her pastoral counseling training from the Post Graduate Center for Mental Health at 66, her training as a Humanist leader at 69, and her certification as a Humanist Chaplain at 76. A memorial service at the New York Society for Ethical Culture is being planned in the next several months and a memorial fund is also being considered. Details will be available from the New York Socity for Ethical Culture.
