title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MECHANIC, DR. MAYER, D.D.S.
description: MECHANIC - Dr. Mayer, D.D.S. The ''Mayer'' of HoHo-Kus. Although he was a man of prodigious energy who was hardly sick a day in his life, Mayer Mechanic, D.D.S., died on Saturday, January 4, 2003, of complications from a sudden stroke. He was 85 years old. He attended University of Michigan, where he graduated with honors. He went on to do the same at Temple University Dental School, where he received a special award for pediatric dentistry. He served two years as a dentist in the US Navy during WWII. Dr. Mechanic was a third generation Patersonian, whose grandfather, Cantor Jacob Landman, founded the first Jewish cemetery in the Silk City. However after practicing dentistry in his hometown of Paterson for over twenty years, Dr. Mechanic moved his home and dental practice to Ho-Ho-Kus. There, while shifting his reputation as the gentlest dentist in Passaic County to the gentlest dentist in Bergen County, he also caught the real estate bug. He began moonlighting from dentistry with his wife Bernadine, who was also moonlighting from her automotive parts business. Together they formed a joint partnership called Maybern Realty and went from their first project of renovating a defunct supermarket into an IBM headquarters to building many other office buildings and retail centers in Ho-Ho-Kus and surrounding towns. Dr. Mechanic earned a reputation as a great landlord by treating his tenants more as friends than tenants. He would always pick up his rental checks personally, just for the opportunity to chat with his tenants, since he was ever interested in people and their businesses. He was also a famous storyteller and would regale everyone with wonderful stories about his own life and colorful stories about the depression era. In fact, he knew so many people in town from his years as a dentist, realtor and member of the Ho-Ho-Kus Chamber of Commerce that many people fondly referred to him as the ''Mayer of Ho-Ho-Kus''something he always joked about with the real Mayor, Rusty Thompson. Dr. Mechanic is survived by his beloved wife of 59 years, Bernadine Mechanic, and by his three children: Leslie, Jonathan and Louis. He is also survived by six grandchildren: Max, Suzanne, Karen, Marc, Adam and Ross. The family requests that any doantions be sent to: The Alzheimer's Association, 919 N. Michigan Avenue, Suite 1100, Chicago, IL 60611. Services are today, 11 AM, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

Until her illness, she was a dedicated and resourceful leader with a marvelous capacity for optimism and fun. She was the president of the ''Junior Committee'' and board member of the NY section of the National Council of Jewish Women. She was a tireless fundraiser for the Jewish causes in which she believed and her efforts for Council and UJA/Federation were extraordinary. Her indomitable spirit and concern for those less fortunate was an integral part of her life. She was a truly spiritual and moral human being who believed and never lost her faith in God. She leaves her family and the world with a wonderful legacy. We will remember her for her devotion and generosity of spirit. We will miss her enthusiasm and critical eye. Adored grandmother of Craig (Karen), James (Lori), Wayne (Ragi), Jacob and Lenni. Cherished great grandmother of Olivia, Nathaniel, Samantha and Hannah. Loving aunt to many neices and nephews. We will remember with great love her spirited approach to life. Graveside service on Monday, January 6, at 1:30 PM, at the Westchester Hills Stephen Wise Free Synagogue Cemetery, 400 Sawmill River Road, Hastings-on-the-Hudson, NY.

title: North Korea Urged to Comply as 3-Way Talks Open in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 — As talks opened here today expected to produce a trilateral call for North Korean nuclear restraint, the International Atomic Energy Agency, meeting in Vienna, formally and strongly urged Pyongyang to comply with its own safeguards.

title: East New York Journal; You Think Traffic Is Jammed on the Belt Parkway? Take a Look at Aisle 9
description: Along the notoriously backed-up Belt Parkway, traffic is crazier than ever.

title: Jets Could Forward Mail To Oakland These Days
description: The table at Herman Edwards's favorite Starbucks will probably be reserved for him, and the desk clerk at the hotel will know all the players' names. The Jets, 41-0 winners over the Indianapolis Colts in a first-round playoff game, will play Sunday in a divisional game at Oakland, their home away from home. If this keeps up, the Jets will soon be able to vote in Alameda County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUART, JOZEFA MARYA MALINOWSKA
description: STUART-Jozefa Marya Malinowska. On November 23, 2002. Beloved wife of Walker Stuart. Mother of Diana, David, Sebastian and Rebecca Stuart. She was a truly extraordinary woman. Memorial celebration of her life on January 11, 2003, at Faulkner House, 255 Goddard Ave, Brookline, MA; 617-232-1175.

title: Group Says It Will Begin A Boycott Against KFC
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, the animal welfare group, begins a global boycott on Monday of KFC to seek an improvement in the lives and deaths of 700 million chickens who become the chain's fried meals every year.

title: Calmly, Maddox Leads Comeback
description: Tommy Maddox had never started an N.F.L. playoff game before today, and it showed in the first half. But he is a quarterback, and he knows quarterbacks are supposed to give speeches, so he gave one.

description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH BUDGET PLAN WOULD ELIMINATE TAX ON DIVIDENDS
description: President Bush will propose eliminating taxes on corporate dividends paid to shareholders, a measure that could cost the government $300 billion over 10 years and would be far bolder than some of his advisers had been suggesting, administration officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Landmarks Chief Named
description: Robert B. Tierney, a former official in the Koch administration, is the new chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has announced. Mr. Tierney, 59, will earn $133,000 annually in the position. He was confirmed as a commissioner by the City Council last month. Mr. Tierney succeeded Sherida A. Paulsen, who remains a member of the commission but had been its chairwoman since April 2001. The commission designates and regulates the city's landmarks. Mr. Tierney was most recently a visiting scholar at New York University's Taub Urban Research Center. He was also a government liaison for AT&T, counsel to Mayor Edward I. Koch and assistant counsel to Gov. Hugh L. Carey. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Trying Teens
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Majority Starts a Step Behind
description: Senate majority leaders usually set out their legislative goals on the first day of a Congressional session, but when the 108th Congress convenes on Tuesday, Senator Bill Frist, the incoming majority leader, will not be introducing his top 10 bills, his spokesman said today.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Guilty Plea In Wildfire Case
description: The woman charged with starting the largest wildfire in state history pleaded guilty to state arson charges. The woman, Terry Barton, 38, a former Forest Service employee, could face 12 years in prison on the state charges when she is sentenced in March. Last month in federal court, Ms. Barton pleaded guilty last month in federal court and admitted starting the 137,000-acre blaze. A federal judge has not decided whether to accept that plea and sentence her to six years in prison. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIEGLER, GERTRUDE
description: ZIEGLER-Gertrude. On January 6, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Amy Beth Goldman and Stephen. Grandmother of David and Debra. Great grandmother of Andrew, Jaime, Melissa and Randi. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: LAYOFFS ANNOUNCED AT SCHOOLS AGENCY The city's School Construction Authority will lay off about 150 employees this week, the first of 450 jobs that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to eliminate from the agency in the coming months. Most of those getting notice this week are managers, including some from the legal, project management, internal audit and executive director's offices. An additional 50 employees have resigned or taken early retirement, said William H. Goldstein, the authority's new president. In October, the mayor said that he would merge the long-troubled construction authority with the Department of Education's school facilities division, cutting 600 jobs in the process. Mr. Bloomberg and Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein also say they are eliminating 550 central administrative jobs. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKAS, DR. ERVIN
description: FARKAS-Dr. Ervin. Who lived life on his own terms, sharing his intellect and acute insight into the human condition with those fortunate enough to cross his path, passed away on January 5, 2003. A Holocaust survivor, who, as President of the World Federation of Hungarian Jews, dedicated his life to the continuation of Hungarian Jewish culture in America, was an author, editor, publisher, attorney and chessmaster. He is survived by Iby, his wife of sixty three years, sons George and Peter, daughters-in-law Betty and Leslie, grandchildren Michael, Randi, Max and Laura. He truly mattered and made a difference.

title: Primary Schools in Kenya, Fees Abolished, Are Filled to Overflowing
description: The government of the new president, Mwai Kibaki, began revamping Kenya's policies today, starting with public education and human rights, as it sought to rebuild a country that was fraying under the long rule of Daniel arap Moi.

title: Tenants Claim Evictions Were to House Homeless
description: Tenants of a Brooklyn housing project have filed a suit saying that they are being evicted to make room for homeless families being subsidized by the city. They said yesterday that they would appear in court today to seek to bar the landlord from removing other tenants, receiving new city contracts or selling the buildings.

title: Two Airlines Are Testing the Concept of Selling Meals Aloft
description: NOW that the Giants have choked so spectacularly on their way to the Super Bowl, we listen hopefully for the thwack and crack of a new season. Can that be spring training in the air, with those shouts of ''Getcha red hots!'' and ''Hey! Who wantza pretzel?''

title: China Plans To Maintain Existing Rate For Currency
description: Despite mounting pressure from the United States and Asian neighbors, Chinese officials say they plan to maintain a fixed exchange rate for the country's principal currency because it has helped China achieve strong economic growth even as wealthy countries falter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWAN, JOHN PATRICK, LT. COL., USAF (RET.)
description: ROWAN-John Patrick, Lt. Col., USAF (Ret.). The JAG Chapter of ROA records, with profound sorrow, the passing of its esteemed guiding member, ''JP.'' He will be remembered for his patriotism, integrity, honor and loyalty to his friends. Condolences to his daughters Kathleen and Maureen, his grandchildren and great-grandson. BGen Arthur Gerwin, USAF (Ret.), President Col. Philip J. Hoblin, USAF (Ret.), Secretary-Treasurer

title: Bring On the Clowns: Goofy Today, in Stores Tomorrow
description: Counterculture is hardly a word that springs to one's lips in conversation these days in any context, much less when talking about fashion. It is generally and correctly supposed that the United States apparel industry, which generates $200 billion in sales annually, has become so bland and corporatized that the number of charmingly loopy individuals of the sort given to utterances like, ''Now that's a sleeve!'' has been reduced to a few tottering die-hards.

description: To the Editor:

title: At Auto Show, All-Frills Cars Are Out in Force
description: Times are lean and the economy shaky, but the auto industry is growing increasingly intent on coming up with offerings for the ultrarich.

title: WHITE HOUSE AIDES LAUNCH A DEFENSE OF BUSH TAX PLAN
description: White House officials rolled out statistics and new details of President Bush's sweeping tax plan today in an effort to head off criticism that it favors only the rich.

description: Makeup That Is Made Up

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOAN, SALLY
description: SLOAN-Sally. Her natural beauty will long live on through her daughter Phyllis and her grandchildren. With the fondest of memories she will always be remembered. With love and affection. Hilda and Irving Sloan

title: Knight Pumps Up Panthers to End 8-Game Irish Streak
description: Brandin Knight supposedly weighs 190 pounds, but his arms are as skinny as a Wiffle bat. So when Knight flexed his muscles after a nifty layup tonight, he could have looked foolish. The sequence was something the Harlem Globetrotters could imitate, but it was crucial to Pittsburgh's scampering by Notre Dame. Knight, with his thin arms as pumped as they can get, looked just fine.

title: 3 in Hong Kong Agree to Face Charges in U.S.
description: Three men sought by the F.B.I. for having supposedly plotted to trade drugs for antiaircraft missiles agreed today to their extradition to the United States. They had initially fought extradition after their arrest three months ago.

title: An Exhibition That Borrows Brazenly
description: It sounds like a plan for drawing hordes of screaming lawyers to your door: create compilation CD's with sampled music from the likes of the Beatles, James Brown and Johnny Cash, not to mention the voice of Dan Rather; include as many songs as possible that have already sparked legal battles; do it all without getting permission from the copyright owners; and distribute the CD's at a nationally touring art exhibition.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CRACKDOWN ON GUN POSSESSION The government said it would seek a five-year minimum jail sentence for gun possession to try to stem the growth of gun crimes, which are expected to show a rise of 20 percent in figures coming out this week. The move followed public outrage over the drive-by killings of two teenage girls outside a New Year's party in Birmingham and indications that inner city areas are increasingly becoming scenes of what the police called "U.S.-style gangland violence."    Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, ALAN BRUCE, MD
description: COOPER-Alan Bruce, MD. Of lung cancer. Professor, University of Texas Medical School, Dept of Psychiatry. BA Wesleyan '49 MA '51; MD NY Med School '55. Life Fellow Am. Psychiatric & Am. Psychoanalytic Assocs.

title: New York, New York
description: It is all but official: In August 2004 the Republican Party will bring its National Convention to New York City for the first time. That's welcome news for a city hungry for the dollars that 50,000 delegates, members of the media and spectators are likely to spend, and for the showcasing that could help lure the 2012 Olympics. The decision was a victory for Mayor Michael Bloomberg, a G.O.P. convert who had worked hard to win the national conventions of both major parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENHOUSE, EUNICE
description: GREENHOUSE-Eunice. Beloved wife of Dr. Charles R. Greenhouse. Survived by daughters Shelley Lotter of Briarcliff Manor and Jamie Dresner of Short Hills; stepchildren Nancy, Wendy, and Lee Greenhouse; and seven grandchildren. Her generous spirit will be missed. Funeral at Ballard-Durand, White Plains, Wednesday, January 8, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to White Plains Hospital.

description: His tweed jacket and snappy silk foulard may have said upscale and over 40, but Takeharu Okano had the wide-eyed look of a boy in a toy shop as he toured the new shopping mall with a retro theme.

description: The National Football League announced today that its game officials erred on Sunday and that the Giants should have had one more play to save themselves from the second-worst collapse in league playoff history. The frustrated and tired Giants were more inflamed than relieved when the news passed through their locker room.

title: National Briefing | Education: University Names President
description: The University of Iowa named David J. Skorton, its vice president for research and external relations, as its next president, effective on March 1. Dr. Skorton, 53, left, is a professor of internal medicine and also of electrical and computer engineering and of biomedical engineering. Gregory H. Williams, president of the City College of New York and one of the other finalists for the Iowa presidency, said he had recently withdrawn his name from consideration. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

description: KING-Hon. Martin E. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Hon. Martin E. King. A member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. John H. FitzSimons, Pres. Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: The Nets' Streak Is at 10 Despite Kidd's Turnovers
description: No matter that the Nets came close to tripping and falling through the trapdoor of a team lurking in the N.B.A.'s lower level. No matter that Jason Kidd uncharacteristically committed 12 of the Nets' 23 turnovers.

title: Bristol Said to Be Close to Deal On Suits Over Generic BuSpar
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb is expected to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to settle lawsuits filed by more than two dozen state attorneys general, consumer groups and competitors that accuse it of illegally stalling the sale of a lower-priced version of its anxiety treatment, BuSpar, according to two officials of parties who had filed the lawsuits.

title: Saying That Hoax Is Possible, Journalist Leaves Cloning Tests
description: The science journalist who agreed to oversee tests to determine whether a 12-day-old baby is the first human clone suspended his participation yesterday, saying the entire project might be ''an elaborate hoax.''

title: Israel Won't Let Palestinian Leaders Attend London Talks
description: Israel's leaders today answered a pair of deadly suicide attacks by forbidding Palestinian leaders to leave the country for talks in London, while much of the rest of Israel took the day to mourn its dead.

title: Fallon's President In New York Quits
description: The president of the New York office of Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, is resigning, the agency said yesterday.

title: City Drops Suit to Recover Cost of Strike That Wasn't
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that the city was dropping its lawsuit against the transit workers' union for the $5 million that he said the city spent preparing for a transit strike.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates Buys Deersoft
description: The computer security provider Network Associates, looking to acquire technology to reduce the amount of spam in e-mail inboxes, said yesterday that it had bought the privately held Deersoft. Deersoft's products test incoming e-mail and pick out unwanted messages. Network Associates, which recently completed the acquisition of the 25 percent of McAfee it did not own, said it intended to integrate Deersoft technology into McAfee's products, starting in the second quarter. Network Associates shares rose $1.40, to close$18.40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, ROBERT S.
description: KAHN-Robert S. On January 4, 2003, in Boca Raton, Florida. Dear Bob: Thank you for nine wonderful year. I love you. Claire

title: Q & A
description: Golf Ball Dimples

title: 2 Leading Japan Camera Makers Are Said to Be in Merger Talks
description: The Konica Corporation said today that it was in merger talks with the Minolta Company, a deal that would form Japan's fourth-largest maker of cameras and imaging equipment.

title: Ending the Conflict in Cyprus
description: The divided Mediterranean island of Cyprus, long contorted by tensions between Turkey and Greece, can look forward to a more promising future if the Turkish Cypriot leadership accepts a United Nations peace plan. Under the plan, already welcomed by the Greek side, a united Cyprus could join the European Union next year. That would benefit Cypriots from both communities and open the way for early Turkish admission to the union. If the Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, succeeds in blocking the agreement, the pain and unfairness of Cyprus's armed partition could be locked in for years to come.

title: Company News
description: FORMER CHIEF OF HEALTHSOUTH IS RETURNING

title: The Politics Of Portfolios
description: In calling for the elimination of taxes on stock dividends, President Bush is embracing the idea that the financial health of investors, particularly the millions of people who got into the stock market for the first time over the last decade and are now suffering the consequences, will be vital both to renewed prosperity and to his own electoral success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, HAROLD
description: SACKS-Harold, 85. On January 4, 2003. Husband of the late Beverly (nee Fields). Survived by daughter, Michelle Walker, granddaughters, Lara & Blake. Your sense of humor will live in our hearts forever. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, N.Y., N.Y. 10017.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Year-End Dividend
description: Calling 2002 the worst year for stocks since 1974, the Britannic Group, a financial services company, said it would not pay a year-end dividend, and would instead use the money to bolster reserves. In London trading, shares of Britannic lost half of their value, to close at 1.64 ($2.64). The company paid a dividend of 18.5 pence a share for the first six months of 2002, and may resume payments in the second half of 2003, depending on market conditions. Britannic also said it planned to defer bonus payments to about a million policyholders this year. Reflecting the fall in stock markets, which have eroded the reserves at insurance companies around the world, Britannic said operating earnings at the Britannic Assurance unit would be significantly below expectations. It also plans to write down the carrying value of Britannic Asset Management by 50 million ($80 million.) Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: REPUBLICANS PICK NEW YORK AS SITE OF '04 CONVENTION
description: The Republican Party tentatively designated New York City today as the site of its 2004 national convention, selecting one of the most heavily Democratic cities in the nation as the place to renominate President Bush in about 18 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIBNER, ESTHER L.
description: DIBNER-Esther L. Of Portland, Maine, died on January 4th after a short illness. She was 89. Mrs. Dibner was born and raised in Brooklyn and subsequently moved to White Plains. She and her late husband, Paul A. Dibner, operated two children's summer camps in Maine, Tall Timbers, for boys, and Truda for girls. She is survived by her four children, Hart K. Dibner, Charles W. Dibner, Mauri D. Schwartz, Willa Dibner and four grandchildren. A private interment service will be held in White Plains.

title: Mamie Mobley, 81, Dies; Son, Emmett Till, Slain in 1955
description: Nearly 50 years after the death of her son, Emmett Till, who was murdered and thrown into a river in Mississippi, Mamie Till Mobley died here today, still clinging to the hope for justice. She was 81.

title: How the Spiny Lobster Finds Home: Magnetism
description: A handful of animals, like migratory birds and sea turtles, are famed for their extraordinary ability to navigate by reading small variations in the earth's magnetic field. Now it appears that a lowly invertebrate, the Caribbean spiny lobster, shares this same built-in navigational sense.

title: Chief of World's Biggest Miner, BHP, Steps Down
description: The chief executive of BHP Billiton, the world's biggest mining company, has quit after just six months on the job.

title: Murray and Carter Elected to Baseball's Hall of Fame
description: Gary Carter and Eddie Murray became the newest members of baseball's Hall of Fame today, gaining entry in an election in which no other player came close to making it.

title: An Irrelevant Proposal
description: Here's how it works. Faced with a real problem -- terrorism, the economy, nukes in North Korea -- the Bush administration's response has nothing to do with solving that problem. Instead it exploits the issue to advance its political agenda.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Challenge To Hard-Liners
description: The wife of a university lecturer sentenced to death for apostasy and members of a liberal opposition group recently released from prison have declared themselves candidates in municipal elections scheduled for Feb. 28. Zahra Behnoudi, the wife of Hashem Aghajari, is running in Tehran. Unlike candidates in other Iranian elections, candidates for local offices are not subject to vetting by the hard-line Guardian Council. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Commercials for the Super Bowl return to the tried and true.
description: JUST as the identities of Super Bowl XXXVII's two foes become clearer with each playoff matchup, so, too, do the plans of marketers for running commercials during the game, the biggest advertising event of MMIII.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, EVELYN
description: LEWIS-Evelyn. With broken hearts we mourn the loss of our most special friend. We cherish our wonderful memories of her. Evelyn will live in our hearts forever. With undying love, Lenore and Gil Horowitz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGENSTEIN, PAUL
description: KLINGENSTEIN - Paul. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem note with profound sorrow the loss of Paul Klingenstein, a dedicated American Friend. Paul and his wife Selma have been long time supporters and Benefactors of the University. Through their generous support they established the Paul and Selma Klingenstein Fellowship Fund for BioMedical Research to provide research fellowships for postgraduate students. Their commitment has also benefited the Sarasota-Manatee Chapter through the Sarasota Scholarship Fund and where Paul served as the first president and most recently as co-chair. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife Selma and the entire family. AFHU Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chair Peter T. Willner, Exec V.P. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Prof. Menachem Magidor, President Prof. Haim Rabinowitch Rector Yigal Arnon, Chair

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Cable Regulations Urged
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey proposed new regulations yesterday for the cable television industry. Under the plan, cable providers would be required to credit automatically the bills of customers whose service is interrupted for more than three hours, and to answer all telephone calls from the public within 30 seconds. Companies would also be required to schedule repairs within a four-hour period. Some companies force subscribers to wait an entire day for a service call. Karen D. Alexander, president of the New Jersey Cable Television Association, said many of the goals had already been met. David Kocieniewski (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pataki Spokeswoman Named
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has chosen Lisa Stoll, a 30-year-old political consultant who worked on his campaign advertisements last year, to be his new director of communications, aides to the governor said. She will succeed Michael McKeon, who has served as the governor's chief spokesman for two years and is leaving the administration this month. Ms. Stoll is a seasoned Republican consultant who as deputy campaign manager wrote most of Mr. Pataki's advertisements. She also held important positions during Mr. Pataki's first campaign in 1994, Senator Bob Dole's presidential campaign in 1996, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's failed re-election campaign in 1998. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, JACK
description: WEXLER-Jack. The trustees and staff of the North ShoreLong Island Jewish Health System mourn the passing of our friend and benefactor, Jack Wexler, and extend our heartfelt condolences to Ann and Robert Fromer and his entire family. Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman Michael Dowling, Pres & CEO North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Tries To Strengthen Position
description: In a bid to secure a central place in the new gadgets that are increasingly the preferred platform for digital media, Microsoft said yesterday that it would license its Windows Media technology to consumer electronics makers at lower prices and better terms than its main competitors do. Will Poole, corporate vice president of Microsoft's Windows New Media Platform division, said the goal was not to reap a huge profit but to ensure that PC's that run the Windows system work well with devices like camcorders, DVD players and portable media players that consumers want to use with them. The more prevalent its playback and security technology is on consumer devices, the better position Microsoft is in when it tries to sell its technology -- and Windows systems -- to companies that want to deliver material in digital form. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Jeeves Rejects Banner Ads
description: Ask Jeeves, an online search engine company, stopped running all banner advertisements on its Web site on Jan. 1, the company said yesterday. The move came after the company's decision in October to stop accepting pop-up ads and certain banner ads that were not based on users' keyword searches. There has been a broader shift by Web sites toward larger-format ads and ads with sound and animation, and away from traditional banner and pop-up ads. Ask Jeeves expects to make up for the loss of revenue from banner ads by drawing new users and selling more ads that appear on the search results page when users search for a keyword.

title: A Nuclear Horror Story
description: The more we learn about a case of severe corrosion discovered at a nuclear plant in Ohio last March, the more frightening the incident appears. The corrosion, which ate nearly all the way through the thick lid of a reactor, left the vessel dangerously vulnerable to rupturing. Even more alarming were the slipshod industrial practices and lax regulatory oversight that allowed it to happen. If those practices are not changed, the same pressure to keep reactors operating while ignoring warning signs may threaten the safety of nuclear plants all around the country.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about efforts to upgrade Disney's theme park stage shows misidentified the architect who designed the Hyperion Theater at the California Adventure park. He was Norman Pfeiffer of Hardy Holzmann Pfeiffer in Manhattan, not Hugh Hardy, another partner.

title: Holder Could Have Called a Timeout
description: You would prefer to remind all the players of their responsibilities every time they take the field, but it just isn't feasible, Giants Coach Jim Fassel said today. And Fassel believes that holder Matt Allen should have known to call a timeout after the team's field-goal attempt was botched at the end of Sunday's playoff game with the 49ers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLIVEN, NAOMI AND BRUCE
description: BLIVEN-Naomi and Bruce. A year without sharing your genius, your wit, your joy in giving to others. We miss you. Roz and Sheila

title: Music's Quick Reaction to 9/11 Echoed in Grammy Nominations
description: Popular music's immediate reaction to the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, echoed in the nominations for the 45th annual Grammy Awards. The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced the nominations today in a news conference at Madison Square Garden, where the awards will be given on Feb. 23 and broadcast on CBS. The Grammy ceremony itself returns to New York City this year for the first time since 1998.

title: Cut 6% More From Budgets, Agencies Told
description: Less than two months after imposing the largest property tax increase in the city's history, the Bloomberg administration has told most city agencies to find ways to cut their budgets an additional 6 percent for the 2004 fiscal year, which begins in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDELL, HELEN
description: BEDELL-Helen. On January 5. Devoted wife of the late Meyer. Beloved mother of Rina (Edward) Gladstone. Cherished grandmother of Melissa (Gregg) Steinhauser and Robert (Betsy) Schwartz. Great-grandmother of Matthew and Jon Steinhauser, Caroline and Henry Schwartz. Donations can be made in memory of Helen Bedell to Sandel Senior Center of R.V.C., 50 South Park Ave, R.V.C, N.Y. 11570 Funeral services will be ''Gutterman's'', 175 North Long Beach Rd, R.V.C,. January 7, 11:30AM.

title: Fly Ball or Frisbee, Fielder and Dog Do the Same Physics
description: When a dog goes after a sailing Frisbee -- now racing, now turning, head cocked skyward -- it looks like nothing so much as an outfielder chasing a fly ball. The resemblance is impossible to miss. Now researchers say it is laden with deeper similarities.

title: Britain Announces First Moves in Persian Gulf Buildup
description: LONDON, Jan. 7  Britain announced its first mobilization today for possible military action against Iraq, calling up 1,500 reservists to join frontline troops and reinforcing a naval task force already earmarked for the Gulf with additional vessels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITIN, BERNARD
description: LEVITIN-Bernard. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle records with sorrow the passing of the beloved father of our Honorary Trustee, Martin Levitin. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Bertram S. Schwarz, Pres.

title: A Mixed Victory for Amgen in Patent Case
description: A federal appeals court upheld a ruling today that stops Transkaryotic Therapies and Aventis from selling a rival to Amgen's anemia medication Epogen, which has sales of $2 billion a year.

title: Rhyme and Rail, and a Subway Rat's Tail
description: In the rush of news about fare increases and potential transit strikes, an interesting piece of news was overlooked in this space last year: the announcement of the winners of the Poetry in Motion contest, in which all New York City residents with poems in their hearts were invited to submit them last spring, for a chance at having their verses displayed in thousands of buses and subway cars.

title: Hewlett-Packard Combines Duties
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company in Palo Alto, Calif., said yesterday that it had consolidated worldwide interactive advertising assignments, which had been handled by as many as 80 agencies. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Jets Will Do Anything To Ruin Raider Rhythm
description: The Raiders' offense operates like a precisely timed dance, graceful crosses and smooth exchanges. Against Oakland on Dec. 2, the Jets' pass defense played like an errant cymbal, smashing into the Raiders and creating disharmony in their placid scheme.

title: Daschle, in Sharp Reversal, Decides Against Run for President
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 - Tom Daschle, the Senate Democratic leader, sharply reversed course today and said he would not seek the Democratic nomination for president in 2004.

title: FORMER CHIEF OF HEALTHSOUTH IS RETURNING
description: The HealthSouth Corporation, a leading operator of rehabilitation hospitals, said Richard Scrushy, who stepped down as chief executive in August to head a spinoff company, will return to that post. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWARTZBACK, RAYMOND H., REV.
description: SWARTZBACK - Raymond H., Rev., D.D. Pastor Emeritus First Presbyterian Church, Jamaica, New York. Raymond H. Swartzback, 79, an urban pastor who was a champion for social justice and was active in the struggle for civil rights died December 14, 2002, after a brief illness. He was a man who loved Jesus, ''the man'', and genuinely loved people, preaching, and listening to other people's stories. Ray set about to make friends of his neighbors. In this he was aided and abetted by a rare and genuine ability to practice Christian love. ''When God says, 'love thy neighbor,' he means for us to love him no matter who or what he is. The whole Christian message becomes irrelevant unless we put into action these beliefs, we say with our lips.'' Ray was one of the first leaders of Urban Ministry. In 1975 he accepted a call to the First Presbyterian Church, Jamaica, Queens, the oldest continuously worshiping Presbyterian congregation in the country. Prior to 1975 the membership of this church was 1500, but ''white flight'' had reduced the membership to 89 people. There was talk of Relocation, Abandonment, Sell-Out; however, that small band of members said, ''We will not be moved,'' and they opened their doors to the new immigrants who were moving into Jamaica, Queens. Today First Church Jamaica has a membership of over 800 from 33 birth nations. At the 333'rd Anniversary and Sanctuary Rededication in 1996 Ray counseled the congregation , ''Do not adopt a Sanctuary mentality. Do not allow this beautiful Sanctuary to become a place to play church, a soul gymnasium to practice spiritual exercises, but let it be a fueling station for involvement in the world out there.'' Mr. Swartzback was born in Baltimore, MD to John and Florence Swartzback. He graduated from City College, Baltimore, Maryville College, Maryville, TN, and McCormick Theological Seminary, Chicago, IL. Upon graduation from seminary in 1950 he was drawn to the churches of the inner-city. His first parish was a two-point mission field in Cincinnati, Ohio. In 1956 he went to Calvary Presbyterian Church, Detroit, MI, a struggling congregation in a changing neighborhood. Here he trained eleven seminary graduate interns for work in urban ministry. Later he copastored Glenville Presbyterian Church in Cleveland, OH before going to Jamaica. During the Viet-Nam War years, he accepted a call to Westminster Presbyterian Church on the College of Wooster campus, where he extended his ministry to counseling students during those turbulent years. During WW II Ray served in Europe from 1942 to 1945 as a platoon leader of the 30th Division, 117 Infantry, where he received a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart. Ray received honorary Doctor of Divinity degrees from Alma College, Alma MI, and The College of Wooster, Wooster, OH. He taught New Testament Literature at the University of Cincinnati, and for eleven years was a lecturer at the Presbyterian Institute on Industrial Relations at McCormick Seminary in Chicago. He has been identified with many ministerial, labor, and civic organizations. He is survived by his devoted wife Jane Hays Swartzback of 55 years, and three daughters Linda Pratt (Jeff) of Millersburg, OH; Carol Kirk (John) of New Marshfield; and Susan Quinones of Athens, and nine grandchildren. A scholarship fund in his name has been established at McCormick Theological Seminary, 555 S. Woodlawn, Chicago IL. The Celebration of his life will be held on January 11 at 4:00 p.m. at the First Presbyterian Church in Athens, Ohio. The Session and congregation of First Presbyterian Church in Jamaica thanks this fearless leader for his outstanding service to the church of Jesus Christ.

Will Poole, corporate vice president of Microsoft's Windows New Media Platform division, said the goal was not to reap a huge profit but to ensure that PC's that run the Windows system work well with devices like camcorders, DVD players and portable media players that consumers want to use with them. title: World Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: AIR LINK TO CHINA Chinese officials have approved the first commercial flights between Taiwan and the mainland since the end of China's civil war in 1949, three Taiwan airlines said. China Airlines, Mandarin Airlines and the Far Eastern Air Transport Corporation said two round-trip charter flights apiece from Taipei to Shanghai had been approved. They are scheduled for the Chinese New Year at the end of the month and will carry home some of the several hundred thousand Taiwan businessmen who work in Shanghai. Each plane will stop in Hong Kong, a four-hour detour Taiwan said it had insisted on because of concerns that direct flights across the Taiwan Strait could be used for an attack by China.

He will remain a strong and positive influence to those who knew and loved him. Loving husband of Blossom (nee Kornbluh Frankel), and his beloved, the late Sunny (nee Liebowitz). He is survived by daughters and sonsin-law Esther and Dr. Howard Weiner, Ruth and Ahmed Magied, Judith and Dr. Laurence Engelberg, and grandchildren Jonathan and Michael Weiner, and Daniel, Rebecca, and Rachel Engelberg, his sister, Marcia Smahl, and his mother-in-law, Elsie Liebowitz. He was stepfather to Toyin and Andrew Frankel, and Dorian and Samuel Toffler, and step-grandfather to Eugene and Lolade Frankel. Lenny served as a cryptograher in the Pacific Arena during WW II. He graduated from NYU and Brooklyn Law School. He had a long distinguished career as an attorney, helping countless individuals in their pursuit of justice and fairness. He was a member of the Government Contract Renegotiation Board, was a captain in the Madison Democratic club in Brooklyn, and was an active member of the Brooklyn Yacht Club, serving twice as Commodore, and general counsel. He was counsel to APRIL, an organization benefiting the mentally ill, and to the National Neckwear Association. He was past president of B'nai Israel of Midwood, and active in the Lion's club, B'nai Brith, and the Brooklyn Bar Association. Lenny loved his work and his boat Veritas, but above all was dedicated to his family and friends. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him.

description: Production of the Lockheed Martin Corporation's F/A-22 fighter plane has been cut by about 15 percent to help pay for a potential overrun of as much as $1 billion in development costs, according to a Defense Department order. Production now calls for 276 jets. The Air Force immediately cut 3 jets from the 23 it intended to buy this fiscal year and shifted $876 million in procurement dollars, set aside through 2006, into the development phase ''to reflect cost growth,'' the Dec. 30 document says. The proposed fiscal 2004 budget request was cut to 22 from 27 aircraft, the memo says. It was the sixth reduction since 1991 in the program, which initially called for 750 aircraft.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Trial Of Miami Officers Begins
description: Jury selection began in the federal trial of 11 Miami police officers accused of manipulating evidence or covering up crimes by fellow officers in five shootings in the late 1990's. In all the cases, prosecutors said, the defendants planted guns to make it appear that the suspects had been armed. Three suspects were killed by officers, and a fourth was wounded. Two other officers who pleaded guilty are expected to be prosecution witnesses. The trial began on the same day that Miami swore in John F. Timoney, the former chief of the Philadelphia police department, as its police chief. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: Pataki to Name Ex-Adviser To State's Highest Court
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he would appoint Susan Phillips Read, presiding judge of the State Court of Claims and a former top legal adviser to him, to the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals. If Judge Read, 55, is approved by the State Senate, as is expected, she will become the fourth woman on the seven-member panel, the first time more women than men would sit on the court.

title: French Trial With Ripples for Europe
description: Nine defendants, including the president of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, went on trial here today in connection with a decade-old banking scandal that could jeopardize Mr. Trichet's chances to become the next president of the European Central Bank.

title: Injuries Cut Down The Devils
description: The Devils will play host to Montreal tonight without two of their regulars, forward Brian Gionta and defenseman Oleg Tverdovsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFF, ELEANOR
description: LEFF-Eleanor. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Eleanor Leff, a cherished friend who expressed an unwavering commitment to Jewish and humanitarian causes. With her late husband Carl, who was a beloved leader of UJA-Federation and a founder of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, Mrs. Leff earned enormous admiration and respect for her extraordinary generosity and compassionate concern. Among her many contributions to UJA-Federation, she will be remembered for her dedicated efforts on behalf of our Women's Campaign. The Leff legacy lives on through the continuing efforts of the Leffs' daughter Marjorie Miller. Mrs. Miller shares her family's dedication to improving the lives of those less fortunate through her exceptional commitment to UJA Federation. We mourn the loss of a dear friend, and extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Miller and her husband Morgan; to Mrs. Leff's daughter Maxine Myers; to her grandchildren, Betsy, Bob, Amy, Cindy, Mark, Asher and Baruch; to her greatgrandchildren; and to the entire Leff family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay Exec VP & CEO Joan Ginsburg Women's Campaign Chair

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Miner Raised
description: The energy and mining company, Sherritt International Corporation raised its unsolicited bid for a rival, Fording Inc., increasing the cash portion of its 1.77 billion Canadian dollars ($1.13 billion) offer. Sherritt and its partner, the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, are offering 20 Canadian dollars a share in cash, up from 17.63 Canadian dollars, as part of a bid that values Fording at 35 Canadian dollars a share. The remaining 15 dollars would be units in a new income trust holding Sherritt and Fording coal mines. The new offer, the second instances of Sherritt's raising the amount of cash it is willing to pay, is an attempt to persuade shareholders to reject a counterproposal put together by Fording and Teck Cominco Ltd.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Premier Defends Curriculum Changes
description: Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee defended his government's decision to introduce a new school curriculum that critics say is biased. ''The attempt is to correct history as it is being currently taught,'' he said. ''All these years students were taught incorrect history by the opposition.'' Mr. Vajpayee, who heads the Hindu nationalist party, supported the removal of references to archaeological evidence that casts doubt on the existence of the Hindu gods Vishnu and Ram and suggests that beef was served to special guests in ancient India. Hindus consider cows to be sacred. David Rohde (NYT)

The gala finale, a stirring rendition of ''America the Beautiful,'' led by James Taylor, was still under way -- and the supper dance had yet to begin -- when Karl Rove, President Bush's political mastermind, darted out of the center's Opera House last month.

title: LIBBEY BUYS A GLASSWARE MAKER IN THE NETHERLANDS
description: Libbey Inc., the glassware maker, said yesterday that it bought a Dutch stemware maker, Royal Leerdam, from BSN Glasspack for about $44.3 million. The purchase will add 12 cents to 15 cents a share to earnings in the first year and increase annual sales $52 million to $55 million, Libbey said. Libbey had sales of about $317 million in the first nine months of 2002, up 2.9 percent from a year earlier. Royal Leerdam makes wine glasses at a factory in Leerdam, the Netherlands, where it employs about 450 people. BSN Glasspack, which is closely held, is based in Paris. Libbey, which is based in Toledo, Ohio, makes tableware at factories in California, Louisiana and Ohio.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: NO YEAR-END DIVIDEND Calling 2002 the worst year for stocks since 1974, the Britannic Group, a financial services company, said it would not pay a year-end dividend, and would instead use the money to bolster reserves. In London trading, shares of Britannic lost half of their value, to close at 1.64 ($2.64). The company paid a dividend of 18.5 pence a share for the first six months of 2002, and may resume payments in the second half of 2003, depending on market conditions. Britannic also said it planned to defer bonus payments to about a million policyholders this year. Reflecting the fall in stock markets, which have eroded the reserves at insurance companies around the world, Britannic said operating earnings at the Britannic Assurance unit would be significantly below expectations. It also plans to write down the carrying value of Britannic Asset Management by 50 million ($80 million.) Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Bomb Found At School
description: A pipe bomb was defused outside the Catholic school in North Belfast where Protestant protesters harassed students for three months in 2001 as they walked to classes because their path crossed briefly into a Protestant enclave. A Protestant paramilitary group, the Red Hand Defenders, claimed responsibility in a statement to the BBC in Belfast. The police dismantled the device shortly before students were to return to studies after the holidays. The Rev. Aidan Troy, chairman of governors at the Holy Cross School, said, ''I find it hugely disappointing to have started the new term after Christmas with this.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 2 Accused Of Document Fraud
description: A man and a woman suspected of registering their vehicle with stolen identification have been arrested on charges of identity theft and document fraud. The police identified the couple as Almira Marques Polvora, 35, of Newark and Alejandro Roberto Mayora-Ore, 24, of Belleville. They were arrested yesterday as they arrived at the Newark office of the Division of Motor Vehicles. The State Police Document Fraud Squad said that an investigation after the arrests revealed numerous falsified Social Security cards, counterfeit passports and other documents.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Air Link To China
description: Chinese officials have approved the first commercial flights between Taiwan and the mainland since the end of China's civil war in 1949, three Taiwan airlines said. China Airlines, Mandarin Airlines and the Far Eastern Air Transport Corporation said two round-trip charter flights apiece from Taipei to Shanghai had been approved. They are scheduled for the Chinese New Year at the end of the month and will carry home some of the several hundred thousand Taiwan businessmen who work in Shanghai. Each plane will stop in Hong Kong, a four-hour detour Taiwan said it had insisted on because of concerns that direct flights across the Taiwan Strait could be used for an attack by China. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

There will be two co-chairmen of the board, Herbert Kleber, professor of psychiatry and director for the division on substance abuse at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and Alan Leshner, chief executive at the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

title: DELTAGEN, A BIOTECHNOLOGY COMPANY, CUTS WORK FORCE
description: Deltagen Inc., a biotechnology company, said it reduced its work force to about 200 people as it discontinues its drug-development business and sheds two subsidiaries to save money. Deltagen, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., said it would sell or shut down its units in Salt Lake City and Strasbourg, France. The company will try to generate more cash by selling tools and services that help pharmaceutical companies develop medicines, it said. Deltagen cut its work force to 320 from 450 last year, a spokeswoman, Nina Ferrari, said. Since then, about 120 employees have left the company, been laid off or transferred to other business units, she said.

description: If you're a young jazz musician in New York, you can scrape by on sideman gigs, weddings, private students and if you're lucky, writing music for advertising. Or you can come here.

title: Pfizer Settles an Inquiry Into Ads for an Antibiotic
description: Pfizer agreed yesterday to pay $6 million to settle an investigation by 19 states into how it had advertised Zithromax, an antibiotic, to treat ear infections in children, state officials said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Protests Against Price Increases
description: Protests erupted in several cities over price increases imposed by the government on fuel, electricity and phone calls. The increases are part of a plan to phase out subsidies in accordance with Indonesia's $5 billion loan program with the International Monetary Fund. Labor unions have called for a nationwide strike on Thursday. Many executives and investors have expressed concern that the increases could reduce already weak consumer spending. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: More Worry for Mets As Reyes Hurts Leg
description: The Mets do not have a third baseman. Talks with Boston and Montreal regarding a three-way trade have stalled. The Mets are still trying to deal an outfielder to clear room on their payroll. And as they continued planning for this season, their shortstop situation became clouded over the weekend when the top prospect Jos Reyes was injured playing in the Dominican Republic.

description: AROUND 1 p.m. yesterday, 49ers Coach Steve Mariucci received word that his team had been the beneficiary of a huge break. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Slander Suit Over Dog Meat Settled
description: A slander lawsuit accusing a local television station of defaming a Korean couple by reporting that they sold dog meat for Asian cuisine has been settled out of court. As part of the agreement, reached last week, the station, WPIX-TV, Channel 11, did not admit blame, and the amount of the settlement was not disclosed, said Christine M. Bae, a lawyer for the couple. In November 2001, a WPIX reporter, Polly Kreisman, above, depicted a Sullivan County farm operated by the couple, Ju Ho and Roslyn Kim, as supplying domestic dog meat to an ''underground market.'' A spokesman for the station confirmed the settlement and would say only that the station's report was accurate in its depiction of the meat as a mix of dog and coyote. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Layoffs Announced At Schools Agency
description: The city's School Construction Authority will lay off about 150 employees this week, the first of 450 jobs that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to eliminate from the agency in the coming months. Most of those getting notice this week are managers, including some from the legal, project management, internal audit and executive director's offices. An additional 50 employees have resigned or taken early retirement, said William H. Goldstein, the authority's new president. In October, the mayor said that he would merge the long-troubled construction authority with the Department of Education's school facilities division, cutting 600 jobs in the process. Mr. Bloomberg and Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein also say they are eliminating 550 central administrative jobs. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Appeal On Microsoft Fought
description: Microsoft and the Justice Department asked a federal judge yesterday to bar two computer industry trade groups from appealing the settlement of the long-running Microsoft antitrust case, which she approved in November. The Software Information Industry Association and the Computer and Communication Industry Association, which have called for tougher restrictions on Microsoft's business practices, have asserted that the settlement does not serve the public interest and should not be permitted to stand without an appellate review. But the Justice Department said the trade associations had failed to show that they would be harmed if they could not appeal. ''Neither the federal courts nor the parties should be required to endure further proceedings at the behest of trade associations that have made only vague claims of harm to their members -- who remain nameless,'' Microsoft said in its filing. Amy Harmon (NYT)

description: A former Knicks official, Ed Tapscott, was named executive vice president of the National Basketball Association expansion team in Charlotte yesterday. Punishments would include amputating thieves' hands and stoning adulterers. The government is expected to deny the request.    David Rohde (NYT)

title: Fitting Rally Cry for Giants Is 'Wait Till Next Season'

But he chose his words carefully in the final team meeting Monday and tried to use the devastating defeat as a springboard into the 2003 season.

title: A New Year's Resolution: Guiltless Gratification
description: I HAVE never been a member of the Lite Eating Brigade. Eating is necessary; it is also pleasurable. Further, I believe the obsessive tendency to demonize certain foods is downright unhealthy. It is food-fearmongering.

title: Farewell, Sauted Foie Gras, It's Time for Steak and Spuds
description: LET'S open the menu and see what looks good to eat in the New Year. I see a juicy sirloin steak at Savannah Steak. I'm sure you could get a baked potato with that. There's a New York strip steak at M. J. Grill, an offshoot of Mark Joseph Steakhouse, and plenty of the same at Frankie & Johnnie's. Terrance Brennan, of Picholine and Artisanal fame, has just opened a seafood and chops house, where, lo and behold, one cannot help noticing the filet mignon, porterhouse and other big-shouldered members of the beef family. Just for variety, there's the 48-ounce steak at Shula's Steak House in the Westin New York, where the menu is written on a football.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: More Jews Leaving For Israel
description: The number of Jews in France who moved to Israel more than doubled last year to 2,566, the highest number since 1972, according to the Jewish Agency, which arranges immigration to Israel. Most Jews emigrating are between 16 and 35 years old, and roughly two-thirds have college degrees, the agency said. The agency's director in Paris, Menahem Gourary, attributed the trend more to Jews' desire to assure the future of Israel than to increased insecurity resulting from a spate of recent attacks on Jewish sites. Last year, Jews were frequently the target of violent attacks. In recent days, a leader of the French liberal Jewish movement, Rabbi Gabriel Farhi, was stabbed and his car was destroyed by fire. John Tagliabue (NYT)

The student was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where she was treated for an injury to her face. She was later released. A message left for a spokesman at the Department of Education was not immediately returned early this morning. Tina Kelley (NYT)

New Jerseyans who rank in the lowest 20 percent of income paid 12.4 percent of their income in taxes, while the highest 1 percent paid only 8.2 percent. (AP)

description: You'd have to be Mother Goose herself to believe that the old ''What's good for the goose is good for the gander'' line is just a matter of trading places. But tonight ''The Bachelorette'' puts that simple-minded idea to the test, as a blond former Miami Heat dancer tries to prove that a woman can be just as much of a heartless cad as a man.

The Grammy ceremony itself returns to New York from Los Angeles this year for the first time since 1998.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: New Leader To Uphold Europe Plan
description: President-elect Rolandas Paksas said he would not advocate reopening negotiations on the terms of the country's membership in the European Union. On Sunday, Mr. Paksas won an upset victory in a runoff against the president, Valdas Adamkus, who led the country's effort to join the union. Mr. Paksas, who finished well behind Mr. Adamkus in the first round two weeks ago, ran a populist campaign in which he criticized the terms of Lithuania's membership, particularly those involving agricultural subsidies, though he supported the country's candidacy. Lithuania was one of 10 Central and Eastern European nations invited last month to join the union in 2004. Mr. Paksas, a pilot who has served as prime minister and mayor of the capital, Vilnius, takes office on Feb. 26. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A Benefactor for P.S. 42
description: To the children of Public School 42 in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, Alfred E. Knobler, the philanthropist and retired chief executive of the Pilgrim Glass Corporation, is simply Grandpa Alfred. For six years, Mr. Knobler, 87, who graduated from P.S. 42 in 1928, has been a constant presence at the school, donating money and equipment and arriving every Tuesday morning to read to students.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Premier Vows To Press Reforms
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said he would continue to push his reform agenda despite growing opposition within his own party and waning support from voters. Mr. Koizumi also denied reports that he would call an early election this year if his proposals to revamp the sluggish economy were not approved. During Mr. Koizumi's 20 months in office his efforts to limit spending, raise taxes and dismantle unwieldy bureaucracies have been met with strong resistance from lawmakers in the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: Lt. Col. Steven Boylan's combat patch comes from flying helicopters in El Salvador, but his parents think his Purple Heart should come from walking the streets of Seoul.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Flat Grocery Sales
description: The Dutch grocer Royal Ahold, parent company of supermarket chains including Stop & Shop and Giant, said that its fourth-quarter sales were flat compared with the period a year earlier and repeated an estimate that annual earnings per share would decline 6 percent to 8 percent. Royal Ahold said fourth-quarter sales amounted to 16.9 billion euros, a 0.3 percent increase from the year-earlier period. Ahold is scheduled to release its earnings in early March. In addition to a weakening dollar, Ahold is facing increasing competition from discounters like Wal-Mart. Ahold's annual sales in the United States at stores open at least a year increased 0.9 percent, in contrast to a gain of 2.6 percent in 2001. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

description: The rich would make out the best, but President Bush's mammoth tax plan would give something to almost everybody.

title: Mayor Says New York Is Worth the Cost
description: Taking aim at the notion that New York's high costs discourage business growth, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city is a luxury product and that businesses should be willing to pay more to operate here.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: Jobless Rate Rises
description: The jobless rate in Uruguay hit a 30-year high of 19.8 percent in the September-to-November quarter, the government said. Blaming fall-out from the economic troubles in neighboring Argentina, the government said that the September-to-November figure was 4.3 percent higher than in the period in 2001 and up from 19.2 percent in the three months ended in October. Like neighboring Argentina, Uruguay's economy, largely based on farming, tourism and banking, is in its fifth year of recession. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Aging Chimps Face Deportation
description: The Berlin Zoo is planning to retire five middle-aged chimpanzees, age 14 to 24, because they are too sluggish and no longer amuse the public. After efforts to find a new home for them in Europe failed, a zoo near Beijing offered to take them. The planned deportation has prompted outrage, with wildlife advocates saying the zoo was heartless and only wanted to bring in cute young primates to attract visitors. The zoo rejected the charges and said it just needed more space for its gorillas and pygmy chimps. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Complaint Board Wins Case
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that the independent city agency that investigates police misconduct complaints can also prosecute the cases. The ruling by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, in a lawsuit brought by the city's five police unions, is a victory for the agency, the Civilian Complaint Review Board. The court also ruled that complaints substantiated by the agency must be heard in police administrative hearings, rather than at the city's independent Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings. The police officers' union said it was weighing an appeal. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: The Wrong Stimulant

Unfortunately, Mr. Bush wasn't convinced by his own reassurances, and went on to propose a whopping new package of tax cuts. This plan is much less about the economy than about the White House's belief that it needs to take action, any action, to show that the president cares.
