title: I.M.F. Sticks to Optimistic Forecast on World Economy
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 8  An International Monetary Fund official said here today that the organization was sticking with its optimistic forecast that the world's economy would grow 3.7 percent this year, with much of Asia doing even better, but added that there was more danger that growth would fall short of the estimate than exceed it.

title: For Frist, an Exultant but Tentative Debut
description: The door of the Senate Republican leader's suite lacked a nameplate today as its new occupant walked up, in part because he had not yet decided what it should say.

title: Israeli Arab Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Play It Again? It's Possible But Impractical in the N.F.L.
description: The National Football League has the regulatory means in place to force a replay of a game, either in its entirety or just a portion, only in extraordinary circumstances. But even Giants executives still frustrated by the team's 39-38 playoff loss to San Francisco on Sunday believe that replaying any part of that game would be impractical, unfair and probably unwise, setting a precedent that would open a Pandora's box.

title: Saturn campaign tries using alternate worlds to change its image.
description: REMEMBER the movie and song ''Town Without Pity''? An ambitious campaign to promote the struggling Saturn division of General Motors as a more youthful brand could well be called ''Town Without Parents.''

title: Conrad Hall, Cinematographer Of 'Butch Cassidy,' Dies at 76
description: Conrad L. Hall, a Hollywood cinematographer with a bohemian's soul and an artist's obsessiveness, who was nominated for nine Oscars and won two of them, three decades apart, died on Saturday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 76 and split his time between a vintage penthouse just off the Sunset Strip and a private island just off Tahiti.

title: Balducci's Flagship Closes in the Village; A New Site Is Planned
description: Balducci's, the pioneering upscale market in Greenwich Village that gave many New Yorkers their first taste of fresh basil, cilantro and other exotic edibles, has closed the storefront it occupied since the 1970's for the last time, its owner said.

title: 'Trial of the Century' Enthralls Mozambique
description: Every morning, a tale of assassins and money launderers, corrupt prosecutors and looted millions transfixes this impoverished nation. The riveting drama stars the president's son as the evil mastermind behind the murder of a crusading journalist who came too close to the truth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEL, SAMUEL BALL
description: SEIDEL-Samuel Ball. We will forever miss your intelligence, strength and friendship. Cousins John, Joan, Jean and Dean

title: Now, the Supermarket Martha
description: MARTHA STEWART has entered a new realm of domesticity, one that is even farther from East Hampton than Kmart is. On Monday, Ms. Stewart's company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, introduced a new populist recipe magazine called Everyday Food.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: CONGO: DEATH SENTENCES IN SLAYING OF PRESIDENT A military court sentenced 26 people to death for their involvement in the assassination of President Laurent Kabila two years ago. Mr. Kabila was shot and killed by a bodyguard in the presidential palace in January 2001 and replaced soon afterward by his son Joseph. The bodyguard was shot dead at the scene of the killing. Among those sentenced to death was Col. Eddy Kapend, Laurent Kabila's closest aide, who was found guilty of having organized what prosecutors said was a failed coup plot. The 26 were among 135 people who have been on trial since March. Some 40 other defendants were acquitted and about 50 were given sentences ranging from three years to life.    (Reuters)

title: Bloomberg Woos Allies in Medicaid Fight
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is seeking an alliance with local governments to tackle rising Medicaid costs, has invited the county executives of Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester to fly with him on his private plane to Albany today for the governor's State of the State address.

title: Death Penalty Found More Likely if Victim Is White
description: Blacks who kill whites are significantly more likely to face the death penalty in Maryland than are blacks who kill blacks or white killers, according to a state-sponsored study released yesterday. By itself, the study found, the race of the defendant was essentially irrelevant.

title: No Headline
description: The incoming commandant of the Marine Corps, Lt. Gen. Michael W. Hagee, said today that he had stopped wearing three military decorations because he and top aides could not find the documentation for the awards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENHOUSE, EUNICE
description: GREENHOUSE-Eunice. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Eunice Greenhouse. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Charles and to the entire family. James M. Dubin, President Richard J. Bronstein, Secy

title: Sri Lanka Faces the Divisions Within
description: Each morning, a representative of the International Committee of the Red Cross rolls back a barrier dividing two nations within one country.

title: A Classic Reconfigured
description: CONFIT began as a way to preserve a surplus. If you cook duck, goose or pork in its own fat, then bury the meat in that fat as it congeals, you create a sealed environment not unlike one created by canning. Kept in a cool place, confit does not spoil for months, making it a splendid winter staple, as well as a traditional part of a grand cassoulet.

title: Spencer Signs One-Year Deal With Indians
description: They were the words Shane Spencer always wanted to hear from a major league manager. Joe Torre never said them, and when Eric Wedge did, Spencer knew where he wanted to play.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Sunday Styles this week with an article about affluent people who are cutting expenses in the weak economy while still maintaining enviable lifestyles was published in error. It showed a family that was interviewed for the article but then not included; it was not the family of Jeff Cohen of Indianapolis.

title: Senior Executive at Merrill Leaves to Join Law Firm
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is losing another senior executive. George A. Schieren, a lawyer who defended Merrill against lawsuits over analysts' conflicts of interest and sex discrimination, has resigned as associate general counsel to join the Clifford Chance law firm in New York.

title: Search for 5 Mideast Immigrants Was Based on Made-Up Story, F.B.I. Says
description: The F.B.I. stopped its search today for five Mideastern immigrants whose photographs were sent around the world, saying it no longer believed that the five posed a threat because the original tip was apparently a hoax.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Speech on His Proposal to Stimulate the Economy
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's remarks today on his economic stimulus plan, as recorded by Federal News Service. A complete transcript is online at nytimes.com/washington.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Child Sexual Abuse Charges On Long Island
description: A Suffolk County man sodomized a 6-year-old boy after drugging him, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The man, James Teal, 38, of East Northport, was arrested on Thursday, and Donald Sparling, 50, of Islip Terrace, who the police say conspired with him, was arrested on Monday. Mr. Teal was charged with sodomy and use of a child in a sexual performance, and Mr. Sparling was charged with fifth-degree conspiracy and possession of a sexual performance of a child. The police said that Mr. Sparling had met a 13-year-old Wisconsin girl in an Internet chat room and that he had conspired with Mr. Teal to bring her to New York to be a sex slave. Mr. Sparling had a receipt for a ticket to fly the girl to New York, where he hoped to impregnate her, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: The Cake Doctor Makes a House Call
description: MAYBE it started during Thanksgiving weekend, when my stepson and his friends ate an enormous dinner and still managed to wolf down an entire box of white-fudge-covered Oreos in minutes. Or maybe it was that sobering moment when I looked at my Visa bill and realized I'd been personally sponsoring a scholarship fund for Eli Zabar's children. But my New Year's resolution was to take up baking.

title: Fugitive's Safe-Deposit Box Found in London, U.S. Says
description: The F.B.I. announced last weekend that it had found a safe-deposit box in London that belongs to James J. Bulger, the fugitive gangster, six years after being given information about the box, raising new accusations that the bureau has not been aggressive in pursuing Mr. Bulger.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Insurance Stalemate
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Joe M. Allbaugh, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, met yesterday without resolving the city's request that the agency pay for insurance coverage related to the cleanup of ground zero. The city worries that it will have to pay enormous sums resulting from lawsuits over the dust stirred up by the removal of debris. The federal agency has said it will use $1 billion to cover the four major construction companies that did the work but has resisted the city's broader request.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HELEN
description: GOLDSTEIN - Helen. At home on January 6th, 2003. Beloved wife of Wallace. Loving mother of Melanie and Hal and spouses Michael and Susie. Devoted sister to Elinor and Alan, ''sister'' to Lil, and sister-in-law to Esther and Beulah. Cherished grandmother of Jessi, Kimi, Joey, Tori, Samantha and Reed. Dear relative to nieces, nephews and cousins. Close and loyal friend to many. Funeral at Congregation Kol Ami, White Plains, Wednesday, January 8th at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco Will Spend $150 Million To Promote Brand
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the world's largest maker of equipment to link computers, will spend as much as $150 million this year to promote its brand amid increased competition. The worldwide campaign, including broadcast and print ads and direct marketing, will begin in two to three months in North America and cost $100 million to $150 million, a spokeswoman, Jeanette Gibson, said yesterday. Cisco faces tougher competition from rivals like Dell Computer. Dell, the world's biggest maker of personal computers, is now selling data switches, which are more profitable for Dell than computers, and is undercutting Cisco's prices. Shares of Cisco rose 40 cents, to $14.60.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: TRADE SURPLUS GROWS Taiwan's exports exceeded its imports by $18.05 billion last year, the island's largest surplus since 1987, as exports to China surged. Most of the exports went by way of Hong Kong, because China and Taiwan still do not permit direct air and shipping links. In a sign of Taiwan's dependence on high-tech manufacturing, its exports of computer and communications equipment and other electronic gear to all countries amounted to $70.66 billion of the $130.64 billion in total exports last year. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: New Zealanders Unveil A Radical Boat Design
description: The crowd that gathered yesterday for the unveiling of the America's Cup yachts of Team New Zealand knew something was up when the design team appeared wearing Hawaiian shirts. New Zealand, after all, is the land of sheep and fern fronds, not leis and luaus.

title: Harry Woolf, 79, Historian and Administrator
description: Harry Woolf, a historian of science who, as director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, helped triple its endowment, died at his home in Princeton on Monday. He was 79.

title: FOUR BOARD MEMBERS OF NEOFORMA PLAN TO STEP DOWN
description: Neoforma, the operator of a medical-supply Web site, said four officials who help hospitals buy medical supplies will step down from its nine-member board this year to comply with corporate governance laws. The company made the disclosure in a conference call with securities analysts yesterday. The directors work for Novation, VHA Inc. and the University HealthSystem Consortium, entities that help select medical products for nonprofit hospitals and which together own about 60 percent of Neoforma's stock. Some medical officials have questioned the propriety of the relationship in which the directors of the Web site also represent its customers. A Neoforma investor relations official, Amanda Mogin said the four board members were stepping down in response to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act and related stock-exchange rules passed last year. Ms. Mogin said that the four would serve on an advisory committee to be created by Neoforma later this year. Mary Williams Walsh (NYT)

title: Shop a Lot, Lunch a Little
description: Shopping for food can make you hungry, of course, but at Granterroirs you can buy your foie gras and eat it, too. The shop, at 30, rue de Miromesnil, just off the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honor, sells a range of truffles, foie gras products, cheeses, jams and confections. It is also a lovely spot for a light lunch Mondays through Fridays at communal tables set up in the center of the store. Open-face sandwiches, foie gras assortments and a daily plat du jour are $15 to $24. A three-course lunch is $27.50, and wines by the glass are $5 to $7. Reservations are accepted for seats until 12:30 p.m.; afterward, it is first come first served. ''But no one has ever passed out from hunger waiting,'' Jean-Franois Jimenez, the owner, said.

title: Shop Till You Drop? Enough Is Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Columbia University's decision to close its commercial Internet company, Fathom.com, referred incorrectly to eCornell, an online venture at Cornell. It remains in business.

title: Blunder on the Gridiron
description: To the Editor:

title: Company News
description: PILOTS FOR UNITED AIRLINES APPROVE 29% PAY CUT Pilots for United Airlines voted to approve the 29 percent interim pay cuts proposed by the carrier as part of its push to cut costs in bankruptcy, the pilots' union said yesterday. The 8,500 pilots are the first of United's employees to agree to the immediate, temporary pay cuts, and they did so by an overwhelming majority. Seventy-seven percent of pilots participated in the weeklong voting, and 92 percent of those approved the cuts as recommended by union leaders. As United's highest-paid union employees, the pilots will have the most taken out of their paychecks even if other unions follow suit. Flight attendants also have been voting since last week on whether to accept a 9 percent wage reduction, as agreed to by union leaders. Two smaller unions, representing flight dispatchers and meteorologists, are also conducting ratification votes on proposed 13 percent cuts. (AP)

title: Shula Can't Shake His Coaching Habits
description: At 73, Don Shula is about Angus beef and motivational speaking. His family company owns and runs 24 restaurants, but his role is largely ceremonial now that his son, Dave, the former Cincinnati Bengals coach, runs the operation.

title: U.S., in a Shift, Is Willing to Talk With North Korea About A-Arms
description: The Bush administration, shifting its approach on North Korea under pressure from allies in the region, expressed willingness today to talk with President Kim Jong Il's government about its nuclear weapons program, while still refusing to offer incentives for the program to be dismantled.

title: Rabbi Ely Pilchik, 89, Scholar and Writer
description: Rabbi Ely Emanuel Pilchik, a scholar of Judaism who retired in 1981 as senior rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J., died on Monday at a nursing home in West Orange, N.J. He was 89 and formerly lived in Short Hills.

title: Retired Aide To Mao Calls For Progress To Democracy
description: A former secretary to Mao has published a strikingly forthright call for change in a Beijing magazine this month, the latest sign of growing demands for open discussion of political reform.

title: Saturday in the Hotel With Chocolate
description: A chocolate buffet awaits just steps from the Louvre. It is served only on Saturdays from 1:30 to 5:30 p.m. at Il Palazzo, the restaurant in the Htel Normandy, 7, rue de L'chelle. Called Les Instants Chocolats, the spread, $27.50 a person, includes cakes, pastries, cookies, petits fours, mousses, candies and ice creams.  la carte chocolate desserts, including sweet gnocchi, are $10 to $13.

title: Girl, 16, Dies at School; 2nd Such Death in 2 Days
description: A 16-year-old girl died yesterday at a public school for disabled students in Staten Island, just a day after a teenager collapsed at a Bronx high school and later died.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bush Details Tax Package As Democrats Criticize Plan

title: Former Rep. Watts Opens Consulting Firm
description: Former Representative J. C. Watts Jr., the prominent black Republican, officially opened the doors today at the J. C. Watts Companies, his new lobbying and consulting firm.

title: Steinbrenner Still Swinging His Checkbook
description: George Steinbrenner touched on all of his favorite themes in accepting an award at a Manhattan hotel yesterday. He invoked several of the motivational slogans that hang in the Yankees' spring training locker room. He compared himself to General George Patton. He promised to scale back his role with the team.

title: Who Benefits From Tax Plan
description: The rich would benefit most, but President Bush's tax-cut proposal has something for almost everyone. It could be costly to state and local governments, though. Page A15.

title: Brazil Shows the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Minolta and Konica Plan to Merge by End of 2003
description: It is a two-front war of Napoleonic proportions: battling against bigger, more cash-rich rivals at home while trying to fend off leaner, hungrier competitors overseas.

title: Mayor's Plan for Schools Is Said to Close 32 District Offices
description: The Department of Education plans to regroup many of New York City's 1,200 schools into small networks and close the 32 community school district offices as part of a major restructuring of the system, an official involved in the project said yesterday.

title: Panel Calls for Vast Changes In Focus of Federal Agencies
description: Congress should grant President Bush authority to propose a sweeping reorganization of the federal government into a limited number of tightly focused departments that would have fewer political appointees and greater management flexibility, a bipartisan commission recommended today.

title: Client's Break With Lawyer Includes Arrest
description: Sixteen years ago, Marcellius Bradford helped to send three friends to prison for life by falsely confessing to the rape and murder of a medical student in exchange for a lenient sentence. Now, a year after DNA evidence exonerated all four men, Mr. Bradford faces a charge of theft by deception, accused of trying to extort money from the lawyer who proved his innocence.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: E.D.S. EXECUTIVE STEPS DOWN The Electronic Data Systems Corporation , the computer services company, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, James E. Daley, was stepping down, but would remain as the company's head of global sales and marketing. E.D.S. named Robert H. Swan, the chief financial officer of the military company TRW Inc. , to succeed Mr. Daley effective Feb. 10. The stock of E.D.S. has tumbled in recent months on a laundry list of bad news. The company said in Septemer that its third-quarter results would be a fraction of its previous estimate. E.D.S. is also the subject of an Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry. In December, the company cut its fourth-quarter forecast by 10 percent. Executives, however, denied that Mr. Daley was stepping down because of the company's problems. A company spokesman said Mr. Daley, 61, had been looking to move away from the financial officer job. (Reuters)

title: Brighton Journal; There's Life Yet in the Seaside's Tottering Old Lady
description: Brighton's West Pier was the ''pier of the realm,'' the most exuberant piece of Victorian marine architecture in England. Today, it is crumbling into the waves long ruled by Britannia and struggling to keep the last of its faded dignity from being washed away.

title: W. and Karl, Going to a Garden Party
description: The Democrats are pathetic. With Tom Daschle out, they don't even have seven dwarfs. They have six coifs, and that's not counting Hillary.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Taiwan's exports exceeded its imports by $18.05 billion last year, the island's largest surplus since 1987, as exports to China surged. Most of the exports went by way of Hong Kong, because China and Taiwan still do not permit direct air and shipping links. In a sign of Taiwan's dependence on high-tech manufacturing, its exports of computer and communications equipment and other electronic gear to all countries amounted to $70.66 billion of the $130.64 billion in total exports last year. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Bank of New York to Acquire Credit Suisse Unit for $2 Billion
description: Credit Suisse First Boston said today that it had agreed to sell its stock clearing unit to Bank of New York for $2 billion in cash.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about charges that a laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology covered up flaws in a proposed antimissile system misattributed an assertion that TRW, the defense contractor, had been ''highly misleading'' in its assessment of a prototype. Those were the words of Theodore A. Postol, a critic of the antimissile program. (What the General Accounting Office said, in two reports to Congress, was that TRW had exaggerated the performance of its system.)

title: 1998 vs. 1999 Cabernets: Call It a Draw
description: WHEN we think of Bordeaux, we think almost automatically about vintages. When someone observes, ''The 2000's may be the best since the 82's,'' no one has to ask, ''Whose 2000's?'' Bordeaux enthusiasts can recite the names of the great vintages -- and the poor ones -- back into the 19th century.

title: Wall of Apartment Building Collapses in Crown Heights
description: The rear wall of a four-story Brooklyn apartment building collapsed yesterday after construction work at a neighboring lot apparently caved in its foundation, officials said, cutting open the building like a dollhouse. Despite the calamity, all of the tenants managed to escape without serious injury.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat Lags Rivals
description: The Italian carmaker Fiat said that its sales in Italy rose 23.3 percent in December, its only monthly sales increase in 2002, but it still lagged foreign competitors. An end-of-the-year deadline for Italian car buyers to qualify for government rebates contributed to Fiat's sales increase but seemed to help its rivals even more, as sales for all carmakers rose 51.4 percent. Fiat's Italian sales fell 17.8 percent in 2002 and the auto division is expected to post an operating loss of about 1.2 billion euros ($1.2 billion) for the year. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: FEMA Criticized for Its Handling of 9/11 Claims
description: An internal review of the Federal Emergency Management Agency's performance after the Sept. 11 terror attack has concluded that the agency should have been more flexible and fair in helping people with economic losses. The agency also needs to coordinate better with other government agencies and charities in future disasters, the review concluded.

title: A Role That's Hard to Shake Off: The 9/11 Antihero
description: IN a backstage dressing room with the amenities of a prison cell, minus the toilet, Liev Schreiber sits by himself, postmatinee, as if in solitary confinement. He has the haunted air of a man recovering from a nasty experience. His costume is off. His street clothes are on. But still he sits. Sigourney Weaver, his co-star in Neil LaBute's harrowing play, ''The Mercy Seat,'' is already headed for the door, husband and daughter in tow.

title: Union at G.E. Plans Strike On Health Fee
description: The largest union at General Electric announced yesterday that it would conduct a two-day strike next week to protest the company's decision to increase its employees' out-of-pocket health expenses.

title: Blunder on the Gridiron
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAULKNER, DORA E.
description: FAULKNER-Dora E. On January 6, 2003. She leaves to mourn seven children and twelve grandchildren. Loving companion, for 37 years, of Ronald Miller of New York City. Loving sister of three brothers and four sisters. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. The family will gather Saturday, Janauary 11th, 10AM at the Southern Baptist Church, 108 St and Central Park West, N.Y.C. For further information, call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A New Route To Riches At Adelphia
description: Adelphia Communications, the cable company laid low by the excesses of its founding family, is negotiating to hire the former top executives of AT&T Broadband to bring it out of bankruptcy. And they could enjoy an exceptionally big payday for doing it.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: NEC Sells A Stake
description: The NEC Corporation will sell its entire stake in Sumitomo 3M, a venture between the 3M Company and Sumitomo Electric Industries. NEC will sell its 25 percent stake in the company for 45 billion yen ($375 million) to Nadco (Japan), a subsidiary of 3M. NEC is trying to raise cash to reduce liabilities. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: A New Reason To Celebrate
description: The Coptic Christmas was celebrated as a national holiday for the first time in the predominantly Muslim country. At a midnight Mass in Cairo attended by President Hosni Mubarak's son, the Coptic Christian patriarch, Pope Shenouda III, thanked Mr. Mubarak for his ''wise and tolerant decision'' to issue a presidential decree making the day a national holiday. Samar Aboul-Fotouh (NYT)

title: Germany to Lead Iraq Sanctions Panel
description: Despite initial opposition from the United States, the Security Council appointed Germany today to the chairmanship of the committee monitoring economic sanctions against Iraq.

title: Mets' Search for Third Baseman Hits Potential Snag
description: Talks between the Montreal Expos and Boston Red Sox about a trade that would have sent either Bartolo Colon or Javier Vazquez, both pitchers, to Boston have fallen apart. That could prevent the Mets from acquiring third baseman Shea Hillenbrand from Boston.

title: Malcolm X Trove to Schomburg Center
description: A rare cache of letters, speeches, photographs and journals belonging to Malcolm X that may yield new insights into the mind of one of the nation's most important black figures will be made available to scholars under the terms of an agreement between his family and the New York Public Library's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: New Auto Limits In Prospect Park
description: The City Transportation Department announced tighter restrictions yesterday on cars in Prospect Park. Starting Jan. 21, cars will be banned from the park on weekdays except during rush hours. Currently, cars are allowed in the park 24 hours on weekdays in the winter. From Jan. 21 to April 4, however, commuters will be able to drive through the park only between 6 and 9 a.m. and between 4 and 7 p.m., the city said. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Careful With Korea, Brash With Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: S.U.V. From Toyota in 2004 To Use Hybrid Technology
description: Toyota announced today that it would start selling a hybrid version of a small S.U.V., the RX 330 from its Lexus brand, by the end of next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, THOMAS W.
description: CARR-Thomas W., 84. Long time resident of Port Washington, NY died on January 5th in Rockville, MD. His publishing and advertising career was with Computer Decisions, Electronic Design, 50 Plus Magazines and AdWeek's Marketer's Guide to Media. He is survived by his wife, Agnes, son John and fiance, Louise, son James and wife Robin, as well as brother, Peter, from California. Services will be January 11th, at 9:30 A.M., St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington.

title: Blackface Not Meant as Slur, Ex-Officer Says
description: A former New York City police officer testified yesterday that he wore blackface on a Labor Day parade float in Queens in 1998 because he wanted to entertain people, make them laugh and win a trophy. He said he concluded that the float, called ''Black to the Future: 2098,'' was offensive only after he watched it later on television.

title: Israel's Misaimed Anger
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel has every right to respond swiftly and firmly to Palestinian terrorist outrages. But when his actions undermine the prospects for better Palestinian governing and an eventual end to the violence, neither Israel's interests nor America's are well served. Mr. Sharon unwisely decided on Monday to bar Palestinian delegates from attending a meeting in London next week that Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, hoped would encourage internal Palestinian reform. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is right to urge Mr. Sharon to reconsider.

title: Wall Street Finds It Likes Much of Bush Proposal
description: Attention getting, that is what some on Wall Street like about the tax plan that President Bush announced yesterday. Others noted that the cost means there is little hope of the federal budget returning to surplus anytime soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEY, ARTHUR J.
description: LEVEY-Arthur J., 79. San Diego, CA. formerly of NYC. Died January 6, 2003. Husband of Marsha, father of Sue Levey, Jayne Charles and her husband Stan, and Randee Weinberger, brother of Martin, uncle, grandfather, stepfather and friend. He will be forever loved and always remembered with tears and laughter. Donations in his memory can be made to the National Kidney Foundation, 30 East 33 St, NY 10016.

title: U.N. Study Sees 500,000 Iraqis Facing Injury In Case of War
description: As many as 500,000 people in Iraq could suffer injuries and require medical treatment if the United States and its allies launch a war there, according to a confidential United Nations contingency planning report made public today.

title: Union Presses Restaurants To Fire a Linen Service
description: The napkins and tablecloths used at Alain Ducasse, the ''21'' Club and La Caravelle have become the unlikely focus of a labor dispute.

title: Paris  la Carte
description: Shop a Lot, Lunch a Little

title: Omnicom Acquires Theatrical Agency
description: Further expanding its presence in entertainment marketing, the Omnicom Group in New York has acquired Serino Coyne, an agency that specializes in advertising and promoting Broadway shows and other theatrical productions. Terms were not disclosed.

title: The Anderson Valley: Behind the Redwoods, A California Dream
description: WHEN you turn off busy Route 101 at Cloverdale and head up into the hills, you leave one world behind and enter another. The lumberyard, gas stations and fast-food joints quickly disappear as Route 128 twists its way northwest through scrawny, moss-covered trees. Only a scattering of houses can be seen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, ROBERT
description: KAHN-Robert. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed Honorary Life Member, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Ronald M. Stuart, President Joyce Baumgarten, Sec'y

title: Merrill Campaign on Banking to Open
description: Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, the nation's biggest brokerage firm, is preparing a campaign to promote its move into banking. The ads, scheduled to be introduced today, will carry the theme " Total Merrill" and will try to send the message that the firm offers customers more than stocks and bonds.

title: Indonesia Opposes Military Action in Iraq
description: JAKARTA, Jan. 8  Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation, is opposed to military action to topple the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, the foreign minister said today.

title: 9/11 Respiratory Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: Verizon Tops Sprint to Gain No. 3 Spot in Long Distance
description: Less than two years after becoming the first regional Bell telephone company allowed into the long-distance market in its home territory, Verizon Communications has surpassed Sprint to become the nation's No. 3 consumer long-distance carrier by one measure.

title: Rummaging the Markets of Paris for Treasures No Store Could Hold
description: At his stall in the covered Beauvau market at the Place d'Aligre, Paul Vautrin, left, shares his passion for the finest spices and olive oils. He sells many oils, including some rarities, from stainless steel barrels, decanting them into bottles of various sizes for $11.50 to $27 a liter. He will pack any of his 120 spices in small tins. Not to be missed are his luscious green Luques olives from Provence, about $9 a pound. His stall, called Sur Les Quais, is worth a trip to the eastern edge of Paris. It is open every day except Monday; on Sundays it closes at 1 p.m.

title: Accounts
description: * American Residential Services/Rescue Rooter, Memphis, a division of ServiceMaster that sells heating, cooling, plumbing and drain-cleaning services, to the Chicago office of Cramer-Krasselt to handle brand and advertising duties, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Korea Feeling Pressure as China Grows
description: Half a century ago, the waves of Chinese coming to Korea were soldiers pouring over the Yalu River to impose Communism. Today, the waves of Chinese are delegates to trade and investment conferences or are other foot soldiers for capitalism.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Expansion Pact For Vodafone
description: The British telephone company Vodafone Group has signed an agreement with Telekom Austria to extend its brand name and services into Austria, Croatia and Slovenia. The Vodafone name will be added to Telekom Austria's wireless units in the three markets, where the former Austrian telephone monopoly has 4.26 million cellular customers. Vodafone will get revenue from the deal, a spokesman, Bobby Leach, said. The agreement extends into Austria and Croatia the Vodafone rivalry with Deutsche Telekom's T-Mobile wireless division. European mobile phone companies are competing for new customers as growth slows in Western European markets like Germany and Britain.

title: Worker in Abuse Case in Newark Juggled 107 Child Care Inquiries
description: The caseworker who closed a child abuse investigation into a mother whose son was found dead in a locked basement here on Sunday had been working on more than 100 other investigations at the same time, an official with the caseworkers' union said. That is more than six times the national standard recommended by a national child advocacy group.

title: F.B.I. Joins Search in Child-Starvation Case
description: The F.B.I. joined the search today for a woman the authorities are blaming for a case of child abuse that left one boy dead and his two brothers unfed, dehydrated and confined to an unlighted basement here.

title: Sports of The Times; Put an Expos Cap On Carter's Plaque
description: GARY CARTER is a sweet man who likes to please everybody, but the most joyous moment of his career is about to touch off hard feelings either in Montreal or New York.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: FLAT GROCERY SALES The Dutch grocer Royal Ahold, parent company of supermarket chains including Stop & Shop and Giant, said that its fourth-quarter sales were flat compared with the period a year earlier and repeated an estimate that annual earnings per share would decline 6 percent to 8 percent. Royal Ahold said fourth-quarter sales amounted to 16.9 billion euros, a 0.3 percent increase from the year-earlier period. Ahold is scheduled to release its earnings in early March. In addition to a weakening dollar, Ahold is facing increasing competition from discounters like Wal-Mart . Ahold's annual sales in the United States at stores open at least a year increased 0.9 percent, in contrast to a gain of 2.6 percent in 2001. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Roy Jenkins, British cabinet minister and political innovator, misspelled the surname of the Labor Party leader who influenced him early in his career. The leader was Hugh Gaitskell, not Gaitskill.

title: Lottery Numbers
States Fear Double Whammy From Tax Plan
description: President Bush's call to eliminate taxes on corporate dividends, a centerpiece of his economic plan, is raising alarm among state and local officials who say it could add to the growing budget pressures on states and cities.

description: Judge Is Renominated

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, MADELINE
description: RUBIN-Madeline. The Jewish Center of Atlantic Beach records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Madeline Rubin, wife of Paul Rubin. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and know no further sorrow.

title: Australian Open Seedings Announced
description: Serena Williams, seeking her fourth straight Grand Slam title, today received the women's top seeding for the Australian Open, which begins next Monday. Lleyton Hewitt was seeded first for the men.

title: Merrill Campaign On Banking to Open
description: Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, the nation's biggest brokerage firm, is preparing a campaign to promote its move into banking. The ads, scheduled to be introduced today, will carry the theme ''Total Merrill'' and will try to send the message that the firm offers customers more than stocks and bonds.

title: The TV Watch; Who Knew? Young Senator Finds Washington Is Tricky
description: One look at the buff, idealistic future senator teaching a classroom of surly prison inmates (''Look, Jamal, you gotta do the work''), and one's heart begins to sink.

title: Kicking It Over (in Their Minds); Heartbroken Giants Fans Wish in Vain for Real Replay
description: So what if the Republican convention is coming to the city? So what if the president is cutting taxes? New York area football fans knew what true deliverance meant yesterday: put the Giants back on the field and let them kick it again.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reuters Gains Subscriber
description: The Reuters Group said it had won a two-year contract to support the Credit Suisse Group's private banking business. Under the agreement, 1,500 Reuters desktop information terminals will replace the existing equipment. Installation of the service will begin in the first quarter of this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'KEEFE, JOHN
description: O'KEEFE-John. On January 7, 2003. He was 76. Loving brother of Peggy Jonas. Friends and family may call at The Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway, at 214 St. NYC Wed., 3 to 8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Margaret of Cortona Church, 5940 Riverdale Ave at 260th St., Bronx, N.Y. Thursday, 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHER, CORNELIUS (NEIL)
description: MAHER-Cornelius (Neil). Of Irvington, NY. Beloved husband of Gina. Loving father to Neil, Chris and daughter-inlaw Stephanie. Brother of Veronica Healy. Funeral Mass Friday 10 A.M. Immaculate Conception Church, Irvington, NY. Visiting Thursday 2-4 & 79. Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to Irvington Public Library.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Farewell, Pavarotti

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERR, JEAN
description: KERR-Jean. On January 5, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Loving mother of Chris, Colin, John, Gil, Greg and Kitty. Grandmother of eleven grandchildren. Visiting Thursday morning 8:30 AM-9:30 AM at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Mass Thursday 10 AM at St. Augustine Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEZANSKY, SALLY
description: MEZANSKY-Sally. At 102-1/2. A resident of South Florida for over 30 years. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Phyllis and Jack Fox and Charles. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. We love you, Mom, and will miss you always.

title: Our Towns; Tuning an Ear For Cries Unheard
description: BRIAN McQUEEN delivered the mail to the neat white house at 188 Parker Street but had no inkling of the horror brewing in the basement. Victor Hernandez, who has lived on the block for 21 years, noticed nothing amiss with the new neighbors. Pete Jimenez lives in the basement of his mother's house, which shares a wall with 188 Parker, and he is nearly brought to tears thinking that he never heard a scream or even a whimper.

title: New Senate Leader Sketches Out Priorities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  Bill Frist, the new Senate majority leader, vowed today to reduce racial disparities in health care as a means of repairing the Republican Party's reputation with minorities, publicly sketching out his priorities for the first time since being elected by the Republican caucus last month.

title: Lipper Clients to Get Some Money
description: Matt Lauer, among others, will apparently get some of his money back.

title: Honeymoon In Brazil: Market's Gift To New Chief
description: After just a week in office, President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva appears to be winning over the markets that only months ago demonized him, fearing that his leftist Workers Party could plunge Brazil and the surrounding region into economic chaos.

title: Daschle, Changing Course, Declines to Seek Presidency
description: Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, reversed course today and said he would not seek the Democratic nomination to run for president in 2004 and would instead run for re-election to the Senate from South Dakota.

title: REGIONAL MARKET: 14th Streeet; Building Gets Face-Lift As Area Turns Upscale
description: The 70,000-square-foot two-story retail building at 25 West 14th Street, empty of tenants since 1990, has been given a face lift in the last two and half years by a new owner who hopes to capitalize on the neighborhood's continued revival.

title: Factory Orders' Drop Shows Manufacturing Is Still Weak
description: Factory orders fell in November for the third time in four months, the Commerce Department reported today, an indication of weakness in most manufacturing categories.

title: Careful With Korea, Brash With Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Storage Technology Says Profit Beat Estimates
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, a maker of computer data-storage systems, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit and sales topped estimates it had raised in October. Profit was 45 cents a share, better than analysts' forecast of 36 cents, Storage Technology said in a preliminary review of its results. The company said fourth-quarter sales were about $584.1 million, more than the $552.6 million average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Demand for the company's gear, which stores and retrieves large amounts of data on computer networks, grew at the end of 2002. Product sales were 25 percent higher in the fourth quarter than in the third quarter, Storage Technology said. Revenue from services rose 2.9 percent. Storage Technology shares fell 40 cents, to $24.13.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, HAZEL M.
description: BROOKS-Hazel M. Died on December 23, 2002 in Atlanta, GA. Formerly of N.Y.C. Daughter of the late Eugene Brooks and Lola Futrell Brooks. A graduate of Fisk University, she worked for Fisk in research and public relations. Later she joined the staff of the March of Dimes/ Birth Defects, retiring in 1982. Memorial services will be held on January 15th, 2003, 11:30 A.M. at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, N.Y.C.

title: The Neediest Cases; After Loss Of Two Jobs, A Safety Net
description: Wilmer Rodriguez likes to bring his work home with him. But his family is not complaining. His wife, Lidilia, and his daughters, Marcia, 18, and Brook, 15, watch him settle in at a special table with his array of tiny tools. They look on in fascination as he mounts small diamonds and other precious stones in intricate, delicate jewelry.

title: Recipe: Banana Cream Cheese Frosting
description: Time: 5 minutes

title: N.F.L. Likely to Review All Aids to Officiating
description: One day after the National Football League acknowledged that its officials had erred in not calling pass interference in the final seconds of the Giants' 39-38 loss to San Francisco on Sunday, a league executive said that ''everything is open'' to review following the blunder.

title: UMass Making History One Game at a Time
description: To appreciate what the men's team at the University of Massachusetts has accomplished this season, it helps to know that the last time UMass beat Boston College and Boston University in the same season, Woodrow Wilson was in the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLD, BEATRICE
description: GOLD-Beatrice. Jan 8, 1994 Memories of you Mother are always in our hearts. Your loving Daughter and Family

title: U.S. Asks Pakistan to Lift U.N. Envoy's Immunity After a Violent Quarrel
description: The State Department has asked Pakistan to withdraw the diplomatic immunity of its envoy here, Munir Akram, after New York City prosecutors sought to bring misdemeanor assault charges against him as a result of a quarrel with a woman, United States and New York City officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Union Theological Seminary's plans to lease three buildings to Columbia University referred incorrectly to church affiliations during the seminary's 166-year history. It was indeed affiliated -- from 1870 to about 1900, with the Presbyterian Church.

title: U.S. Moves Toward Final Readiness for War With Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  In an important move toward final readiness for a possible war with Iraq, the American battle staff that would manage a military campaign has begun to move from Florida to a command post in the Persian Gulf state of Qatar, officials said today.

title: When Medical Care Goes Awry
description: To the Editor:

title: RAND vs. Santa Monica: the New Headquarters
description: When it is completed in the fall of 2004, the RAND Corporation's five-story, elliptical-shaped, 309,000-square-foot building may soon become a local landmark. More important to city planners, perhaps, is that the start of RAND's long-awaited project opens the door to the redevelopment of the Santa Monica Civic Center, an area where RAND, a prestigious research institute, was a major land owner until a few years ago.

title: Shop Till You Drop? Enough Is Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Carnegie's Season, With More to Come
description: The Berlin Philharmonic's first American appearances under Simon Rattle and a new Perspectives series with Emanuel Ax, Michael Tilson Thomas and Dawn Upshaw: these are some of the offerings on the 2003-4 schedule at Carnegie Hall, announced on Tuesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teenager Accused Of E-Mail Fraud
description: A teenager has been indicted on charges of stealing bank account and credit card numbers from more than 100 America Online subscribers, Queens and United States Postal Inspection Service officials said yesterday. The teenager, Shiva Sharma, 18, of Richmond Hill, is accused of charging more than $10,000 worth of electronic equipment to the subscribers' credit cards. Under a new state identity-theft law, Mr. Sharma faces up to seven years in prison if convicted. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Bush Economic Plan Has Little for New York
description: President Bush's plan for stimulating the economy offered little help to Gov. George E. Pataki and New York lawmakers struggling to close a giant shortfall in the state budget.

title: Elderly Linked to a Marked Rise in Flu Deaths
description: The death rate from influenza rose markedly in the 1990's, federal scientists reported yesterday. The explanation, they said, is that a greater proportion of the population is elderly and thus particularly susceptible to flu.

title: Apple Branches Out, Offering 2 Software Programs
description: Five years after returning to lead Apple Computer, Steven P. Jobs introduced software today in areas that others had long since ceded to Microsoft: a free Web browser tailored for the Macintosh and a $99 program for making elaborate business presentations.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Phone Outlook Lowered
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered the debt rating of NTT DoCoMo to negative from stable, citing the slow adoption of the company's third-generation phone service. The long-term debt of NTT DoCoMO, Japan's largest telecommunications company, is rated Aa1. Moody's said DoCoMo's high-speed phone service, introduced in October 2001, has attracted just 149,000 subscribers, far fewer than anticipated. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: An OPEC Move To Lift Output Of Oil Is Seen
description: In an effort to scale back high oil prices, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries appears likely to meet in Vienna as early as this weekend to discuss increasing production by up to two million barrels a day, or 8.7 percent, a senior OPEC delegate said yesterday.

title: After The Storm
description: Here's a prediction: In the end, 9/11 will have a much bigger impact on the Arab and Muslim worlds than it does on America. Lord knows, 9/11 has been a trauma for us, and our response has been to strike back and install better security. But 9/11 has been a trauma for Arabs and Muslims as well -- a shock to their systems that ranks with Napoleon's invasion of Egypt, the creation of Israel and the 1967 defeat.

title: I.B.M. in Deal To Farm Out Some PC Jobs
description: I.B.M. took another step away from its roots as a manufacturer of computers, announcing yesterday a three-year, $3.6 billion agreement with Sanmina-SCI to take over the manufacturing of some server computers and desktop personal computers and to handle custom work on notebooks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, EVELYN
description: LEWIS-Evelyn. The family of Evelyn Lewis announces with great sorrow her passing on January 5, 2003 after a long battle with cancer. She was a wonderful wife, mother, grandmother, daughter, sister and friend. She touched everyone she knew and will never be forgotten.

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb to Pay $670 Million to Settle Numerous Lawsuits
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $670 million to settle numerous lawsuits by states, consumers and competitors charging it with using illegal tactics to keep lower-priced versions of its medicines Taxol and BuSpar out of the market.

title: TV Ads Say S.U.V. Owners Support Terrorists
description: Ratcheting up the debate over sport utility vehicles, new television commercials suggest that people who buy the vehicles are supporting terrorists. The commercials are so provocative that some television stations are refusing to run them.

title: Court Rules U.S. Can Hold Citizens as 'Enemy Combatants'
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  A federal appeals court handed the Bush administration a major victory today in ruling that a wartime president has the authority to detain indefinitely a United States citizen captured as an enemy combatant on the battlefield and deny that person access to a lawyer.

title: When Medical Care Goes Awry
description: To the Editor:

title: Next Stop Cooperstown for Carter and Murray
description: When he awoke yesterday, Gary Carter said, ''I didn't know what to anticipate because I've been through it before.'' Eddie Murray, on the other hand, knew what part of his day would bring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, BERNICE
description: ROSNER-Bernice. The Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center extends heartfelt sympathy to Harriet Becker, Board Member of the Gurwin Jewish Fay J. Lindner Residences, on the loss of her mother, Bernice. Condolences to the entire family. Lawrence Simon, President, Gurwin Center Joseph Gurwin, Chairman, Gurwin Center Martin Eglow, President, Lindner Residences Herbert H. Friedman, E.V.P.

title: Israeli Arab Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Silver Pushes for Stronger Rent Controls
description: On the eve of the legislative session, the State Assembly speaker today reopened the battle over rent control, an issue that held up the state budget for months almost six years ago.

title: Scatchard's Hat Trick Lifts Isles
description: A thick red line divides eighth and ninth place on the Eastern Conference standing board in the Islanders' dressing room. For three months, the team's magnet seemed glued below the line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, ISIDORE
description: FALK-Isidore. With love and great sadness, we mourn the passing of Isidore (''Issie'') Falk on January 6, 2003, beloved husband of the late Anne Falk, cherished father of Serafina (Melvin), Rebecca (John), Maurice (Judi) and the late Michael (Barbara), adored grandfather of Nathaniel (Esther), Monica (Ira), Cindy (David), Jessica (Chaim), James, Jeremy, Michelle (William), Leslie, Annie, Harry (Claudia) and Eve, treasured great grandfather of Elizabeth, David, Emily, Joshua, Harry, Alexander, Sarah, Abigail, Abraham, Simon, Michael and Benjamin. We remember him with love, laughter and admiration. Funeral services at Park East Synagogue on January 8 at 9:30 AM. Shiva will be observed at 188 East 70th Street.

title: At a Texas Foundry, An Indifference to Life
description: It is said that only the desperate seek work at Tyler Pipe, a sprawling, rusting pipe foundry out on Route 69, just past the flea market. Behind a high metal fence lies a workplace that is part Dickens and part Darwin, a dim, dirty, hellishly hot place where men are regularly disfigured by amputations and burns, where turnover is so high that convicts are recruited from local prisons, where some workers urinate in their pants because their bosses refuse to let them step away from the manufacturing line for even a few moments.

title: Young Survivors of Cancer Battle Effects of Treatment
description: Handing a deck of cards to Sarah Ludwig, the psychologist said, ''I want you to put the cards in order by suit, but keep in a separate pile those cards with the letter T in their names.''

title: Reinforcements for Rangers
description: The injury-depleted Rangers, who play the Carolina Hurricanes at Madison Square Garden tonight, recalled forwards Jamie Lundmark and John Tripp from Hartford of the American Hockey League yesterday. To make room on the roster, the Rangers placed Petr Nedved (hip) and Ronald Petrovicky (sprained right ankle) on injured reserve.

title: Records Show Merck Unit Favored Its Parents' Drugs
description: A federal judge in New York unsealed internal records of Merck & Company yesterday that detailed favorable treatment that Medco Health Solutions, a Merck unit, gave to some of the company's most important drugs.

title: Knicks' Thomas Seeks Composure
description: The look is an ugly, menacing scowl that, like an alarm clock, sparks the Knicks into action. As soon as they see that look on Kurt Thomas's face, they rush in front of him, push him away from the referees and try, often fruitlessly, to calm him.

title: Ersatz Eligible 'Joe Millionaire' Gives Fox a Needed Ratings Hit
description: Providing another proof that reality television has a special and powerful appeal to young adult viewers, a new reality series from the Fox network, ''Joe Millionaire,'' scored the biggest ratings of any new series this season at its premiere Monday night.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MYLAN LABORATORIES INC., Pittsburgh, a maker of generic drugs, plans a three-for-two stock split on Jan. 27 to shareholders of record as of Jan. 17. Mylan's stock has climbed about 27 percent in six months.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: POLICE OFFICIAL RESIGNS A top Hartford police official, under fire after he made a remark criticized as a gay slur, has resigned. A letter of resignation submitted by Louis A. Vega, the assistant chief, was accepted on Monday by Mayor Eddie A. Perez, the mayor's spokeswoman said yesterday. Mr. Vega denied making the anti-gay remark. Mr. Vega is accused of making the remark three months ago when critics within the Police Department accused him of falsifying crime statistics in New York. He denied the New York accusation. Yesterday, Mr. Vega did not return a call for comment. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Adding On

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Front Row column on the Fashion page yesterday about the A/R Media agency's new campaign for Escada misspelled the name of the photographer for the ads. He is Steven Meisel, not Stephen.

title: Man at Center Of Bribe Case Dies of Stroke
description: For the last year, New York's powerful real estate industry has been crackling with tension as federal investigators have pressed for the names of any property owners who may have knowingly benefited from a long-running bribery scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, MARGARET DOIG
description: BRENNAN-Margaret Doig. Of Old Westbury, NY on January 7, 2003. Beloved wife of the late James A. Devoted mother of James A., Jr., (Alice), Christopher N. (Cynthia), Margaret Brennan Cobb (William), William D. (Laurie) and Timothy R. (Karen). Cherished grandmother of James R., Christopher Y., Jennifer H., and Matthew R. Loving sister of the late William S. Doig and Elizabeth Doig. Reposing Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Ave., Westbury, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:45 AM at St. Brigid's RC Church, Westbury. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Venezuela's plans to reorganize the state-owned oil company as part of an effort to recover from a strike misstated the amount of crude oil exported by the country to the United States. It was about 1.45 million barrels a day before the strike; that is about 14 percent of the United States' total imports of 11 million barrels -- not 14 percent of the 19 million barrels that the United States consumes daily.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Assemblywoman Pleads Guilty
description: Assemblywoman Gloria Davis, a senior member of the Assembly's Democratic majority, resigned yesterday after pleading guilty to bribery. Ms. Davis, a 22-year incumbent from the Bronx, will serve three months in jail for taking $24,000 from a contractor who wanted to secure an $880,000 construction deal. Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, said Ms. Davis, 64, also agreed to never again seek or hold public office, and to pay restitution of $20,000. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Ex-Merrill Executive Named To Lead Irish Drug Maker
description: Elan, the troubled Irish drug company, surprised analysts today by appointing a former Wall Street executive with no experience in the pharmaceutical industry as its new chief executive.

title: U.S. Announces Talks Aimed at Trade Pact With Central America
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  The administration announced negotiations today to create a free trade agreement with Central America within one year, a huge leap in its ambitious plans for a NAFTA-like zone throughout the Western Hemisphere.

title: The Times Appoints Frank Rich As Associate Editor and Essayist
description: Frank Rich, an Op-Ed columnist and a senior writer for The New York Times Magazine, has been appointed associate editor of the newspaper and will write a cultural essay for the front page of Arts & Leisure each Sunday beginning this spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGENSTEIN, PAUL
description: KLINGENSTEIN - Paul. Of Scarsdale, NY, and Longboat Key, FL, died peacefully at home on January 5, 2003, at age 88. He was surrounded by his cherished family. Loving and dearly loved husband of Selma for 56 years, devoted father of Dr. R. James Klingenstein (Susanne) and Irene Hess. Adored grandfather of David (Diane) and Suzanne Hess, and Rachel and Julie Klingenstein. Treasured brother of Max. A prominent figure in the photographic industry for more than 50 years, he later in life applied the same energy and creativity to charitable pursuits as he had to his career. A man of dignity and compassion, he was admired and respected for his warmth, wisdom and generosity. He will be missed by all who knew him and whose lives he touched. Services were held at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, New York, on Tuesday, January 7. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory made to the American Friends of the Hebrew University, 7280 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL. 33433, would be appreciated.

title: Devils' Nieuwendyk Ends Goal Drought
description: The lack of goals had reached an alarming stage for the Devils, who had failed to score more than two in seven straight games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOSSITER, JACQUELINE
description: NOSSITER-Jacqueline. Age 76, died Tuesday, January 7, 2003 in San Francisco, after a long illness. She was the widow of former New York Times and Washington Post reporter Bernard D. Nossiter. She is survived by her sons, Daniel of Washington, DC; Joshua of San Francisco; Adam of New Orleans; and Jonathan of New York.

title: Nassau Battle Of the Budget Hits Benefits
description: If you work for the Nassau County government as little as one year and retire at age 55, the county may have to pay your health insurance for the rest of your life.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Injunction Sought Against Labor Law
description: The Business Council of New York State said yesterday that it had asked the National Labor Relations Board to issue an injunction to prevent the state from enforcing a new law that prohibits companies from using state funds to fight unionization efforts. The council's president, Daniel B. Walsh, argued in a letter to the labor board's general counsel that federal, not state, labor law has jurisdiction in this area. State labor officials said the law was legal. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: F. William Free, 74, Ad Man Behind 'Fly Me'
description: F. William Free, an advertising executive who attracted passengers to National Airlines and protesters to his agency with one of his best-known campaigns, ''I'm Cheryl -- Fly Me,'' died on Jan. 1 at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 74, and lived in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's tough on the kids and tough on parents. They're told the disease is gone, and then after five years, the kid is failing in school. And it just seems like it's never over.''

title: Chasing Campaign Dollars
description: Whether the world is ready or not, presidential candidates are popping out all over. As each Democratic aspirant announces his ''exploratory committee,'' voters should note that the exploration is about bagging money and donors, not ideas and precinct workers. The ever-accelerating schedule of primary and caucus contests means that raising money, the tiger's milk of political success, must begin earlier too, even at the risk of the public's becoming more jaded than ever.

title: Chirac Praises Peacekeepers as Ivory Coast Role Deepens
description: A day after 30 rebels were killed and 9 French soldiers were wounded in clashes with rebels in Ivory Coast, according to French officials, President Jacques Chirac reaffirmed today the importance of French peacekeeping troops around the world.

title: Cohen Confident Before U.S. Championships
description: Sasha Cohen admits that her skating has not been perfect this season. But it has been good enough for her to qualify for her first Grand Prix final next month in St. Petersburg, Russia.

title: BUSH UNVEILS PLAN TO CUT TAX RATES AND SPUR ECONOMY
description: President Bush proposed a big and swift new round of tax cuts for individuals and small businesses today, formally presenting a plan that he said would help the economy recover but that Democrats said was largely made up of fiscally reckless and unjustified breaks for the wealthy.

title: The Pop Life; Tributaries to the Musical Mainstream
description: Last year record labels released about 27,000 CD titles in the United States. Though that it is a hefty number, it is actually low for the business, which released nearly 39,000 titles just a few years ago. Considering that only several hundred of those CD's even make the Top 40, that leaves thousands upon thousands of CD's that few people ever hear. Thus, every year, the pop music critics at The New York Times compile a list of the CD's that almost got away the previous year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Signs Anti-Graffiti Bill
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed legislation yesterday intended to deter graffiti and littering. He also signed a bill raising the annual income ceiling to qualify for property tax exemptions under the Senior Citizens Homeowners Exemption program to $21,500 from $20,500. The mayor also agreed to name 97 streets after victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack. Under the four new anti-graffiti and littering laws, those who repeatedly litter, cover public property with illegal posters or deface property with graffiti will face increased fines. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Two City Employees Arrested
description: A New York City police sergeant and a city correction officer were arrested and charged with aggravated harassment in separate domestic incidents yesterday, the authorities said. Sgt. Walter Frey of the 109th Precinct in Queens was arrested in Coram after making two phone calls to a female acquaintance in Miller Place, a Suffolk County police spokesmen said. He was suspended. The correction officer, Panathy Hill, 38, turned herself in yesterday at a station house in the Bronx. She was charged with aggravated harassment after phoning a woman she had a relationship with, Officer Louis Camacho said. Ms. Hill was later suspended, said Thomas Antenen, a Correction Department spokesman. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Arrest of Terror Suspects in London Turns Up a Deadly Toxin
description: A small quantity of the deadly toxin Ricin was found over the weekend during an antiterrorist sweep in London in which six men were arrested on suspicion of terrorism, the police said today.

title: Norwegian Hacker, 19, Is Acquitted in DVD Piracy Case
description: A teenage software programmer in Norway was acquitted of digital piracy in Oslo yesterday in a case that has drawn close scrutiny from the entertainment industry, which has been struggling to protect DVD's, online music and other forms of media from unauthorized copying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTERNACK, LILLIAN ILLIONS
description: PASTERNACK-Lillian Illions. Born 12 December, 1911. Second eldest of five siblings. Died Lenox Hill Hospital on 6 January, 2003. Teacher of many who will never forget her dedication to their development. Wife of Jack who never forgot her deep devotion to his potential during 58 years of marriage. Survived by son Fred who will never forget her determination to help him be all he could be and by grandsons, Alexander and Gregory who experienced her unconditional love. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Lenox Hill Hospital would be appreciated.

title: Just Musty Old Bottles? Not in These New Wine Shops
description: Legrand Filles et Fils, a rambling fourth-generation wine and food shop that is one of the oldest in Paris, has expanded, adding a bookstore, a wine accessory shop and a wine bar, above, where plates of charcuterie and cheeses are served. Stick to the wines by the glass, because a bottle bought in the shop will incur a $15 corkage fee. The shop is at 1, rue de la Banque near the Palais Royal.

title: Studying Race, Privilege And Intellectual Levels
description: Edmund W. Gordon, 81, could reasonably be called the premier black psychologist of his generation: a professor emeritus at both Yale and Columbia, a scholar in residence at the College Board, the head of the Institute for Urban and Minority Education at Columbia's Teachers College and the author of more than 175 scholarly articles and a dozen books.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Venezuela's plans to reorganize the state-owned oil company as part of an effort to recover from a strike misstated the amount of crude oil exported by the country to the United States. It was about 1.45 million barrels a day before the strike; that is about 14 percent of the United States' total imports of 11 million barrels  not 14 percent of the 19 million barrels that the United States consumes daily.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MAYOR SIGNS ANTI-GRAFFITI BILL Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday signed legislation intended to deter graffiti and littering. He also signed a bill raising the annual income ceiling to qualify for property tax exemptions under the Senior Citizens Homeowners Exemption program to $21,500 from $20,500. The mayor also agreed to name 97 streets after victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. Under the four new anti-graffiti and littering laws, those who repeatedly litter, cover public property with illegal posters or dabble graffiti on the landscape will face increased fines. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Steely and Steadfast, Edwards Is the Jets' Rock
description: It was Herman Edwards's version of ''Groundhog Day'' -- a swirl of the same bleak scores, the same dejected flights, a mosaic of misery, over and over again.

title: Ducasse Takes a New Road, One With Doughnuts
description: Alain Ducasse, the Michelin three-star chef, is now courting the budget-minded. He has opened a sleek little bakery and food shop, below, called BE-Boulangpicier at 73, boulevard de Courcelles. As these sorts of places go, it breaks new ground, because crusty loaves are made on the premises and a range of international products line the shelves. They include artisanal Italian pastas and a well-edited selection of condiments, cheeses and wines.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Slavery Collection To Be Shown In Mobile
description: A couple that own 15,000 slavery-era artifacts have chosen Mobile as the site of a new museum on slavery. The couple, James and Mary Petty of Gulfport, Miss., have spent the past several years amassing one of the largest collections of whips, shackles and documents relating to the American slave trade. The couple had wanted to keep the collection in Mississippi, but Mobile officials offered to help them raise money and find a building. ''Mobile really came to the table,'' Mr. Petty said. The museum is expected to open in four years. Jeffrey Gettleman (NYT)

title: Einstein Was Right on Gravity's Velocity
description: In a test critical to theories of cosmology, scientists have for the first time measured the speed at which the force of gravity moves. And, once again, it appears that Einstein has been proved right, scientists announced today at a meeting here of the American Astronomical Society.

title: Spending on Health Care Increased Sharply in 2001
description: Spending on health care is increasing at the fastest rate in a decade, reflecting greater use of hospitals and prescription drugs and the declining influence of managed care, the government reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETOFF, HANNAH
description: GETOFF-Hannah. November 8, 1915-December 27, 2002. Died at the age of 87. Devoted aunt of Peter and Tova.

title: California Curbed
description: The decision by Interior Secretary Gale Norton on New Year's Day to reduce water flows from the Colorado River to farmers in California's Imperial Valley and 17 million urban consumers in Southern California was right on the mark. Though Ms. Norton could have found ways to delay the order, doing so would only have encouraged California to continue its undisciplined and unfair diversion of water to which a half-dozen other states also have rightful claim.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: SAP Lays Off 174 In U.S.
description: SAP, the maker of business-management software, laid off 174 workers in the United States as it reorganized its sales staff and consolidated its global customer support group. The German company, which has its United States headquarters in Newtown Square, Pa., notified employees yesterday, a spokesman, Markus Berner, said. About three-quarters of the layoffs were in the United States sales force, he said. SAP is switching back to a regional focus for selling its products in the United States after about two years of an industry-based approach. In September, the company hired the former sales manager of Siebel Systems Inc., William McDermott, to head its American and Canadian businesses to try to stem a drop in revenue.

title: Bridgeport Mayor Joins List Of Corruption Defendants
description: He is the mayor of Connecticut's largest city. Not so long ago, he was considered a leading contender for the Democratic nomination for governor, a man who had built a reputation for bringing in millions of dollars in development to Bridgeport's bruised and broken downtown.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Religious Coalition Seeks Islamic Law
description: Leaders of a coalition of hard-line religious parties that won control of the government of North-West Frontier Province in elections last fall have asked the federal government for permission to begin carrying out Islamic law, The Associated Press reported. Punishments would include amputating thieves' hands and stoning adulterers. The government is expected to deny the request. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Woodson's 16th N.F.L. Season Is Oh So Sweet
description: In a season of streaks and signposts, of grinding for 972 minutes 19 seconds on a football field, it is a 98-yard dash in the Denver night that stands as the pivotal moment of the Oakland Raiders' journey.

description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE THROWS OUT ROYALTIES SUIT AGAINST EXXON MOBIL
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation said a Texas judge had thrown out the main claims in a lawsuit filed by the state seeking royalties from company wells in eastern Texas. Texas sued the company two years ago, Exxon Mobil said. The state claimed ownership of minerals under portions of the highway that crosses the Hawkins oil field. The decision ''affirms Exxon Mobil's position that these claims were without merit and should never have been brought,'' said Terry Koonce, president of the Exxon Mobil Production Company. State officials plan to appeal portions of the ruling. One reason the judge rejected the charges was the state's failure to offer evidence that the actions caused injury, Exxon Mobil said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN PELT, CHARLES BINGHAM PENROSE
description: VAN PELT-Charles Bingham Penrose. Died on January 2, 2003, at Palm Beach, FL. Born May 2, 1922 in Philadelphia. He was predeceased in death by his father Andrew Van Pelt, his mother Sarah Hannah Boles Penrose Van Pelt and his sister Sarah Hannah Boles Penrose Van Pelt. He was graduated from Groton School, Harvard University and the University of Pennsylvania Law School. He was a veteran of World War II, serving in the U.S. Army Military Intelligence in the Pacific. Survived by his wife Jane Eger Van Pelt and his daughter Jullet Evelyn Eger Van Pelt and his children Peter Turner Van Pelt, Abby Ann Van Pelt and Guy Fairfax Cary Van Pelt. Also survived by two sisters Katharine Drexel Van Pelt Beaver and Abby Ann Van Pelt Griscom, niece Helen Cutting Pilkington and her children Charles Fulton Pilkington, Justine Catherine Pilkington and Elizabeth Cutting Pilkington. Funeral services will be conducted Saturday, January 11, at 11AM, at the Church of the Redeemer, Bryn Mawr, PA, by The Reverend Canon Gary Hall and The Reverend Mr. Timothy Pickering. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to St. Christopher's Hospital for Children, Philadelphia, PA

title: President Renominating Federal Judge Lott Backed
description: President Bush said tonight that he was renominating Judge Charles W. Pickering Sr. of Mississippi to a federal appeals court, a step that will almost certainly set off a Senate debate over racial issues reminiscent of those that toppled Senator Trent Lott as majority leader.

title: Mediterranean Interlude, Without the Views
description: A SLIGHTLY mad cheeriness pervades Sciusci, an eccentric subterranean restaurant that can seem like an Italian version of Alice's tea party. ''One thing I have to tell you,'' my waiter warned one night. ''The cavatelli with fava beans -- well, we don't have fava beans, so they are using asparagus tips.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, BARBARA
description: ROBBINS-Barbara, 81 years old. Of Manhasset, N.Y. and West Palm Beach, Florida, passed away on January 6 at her Florida home. A devoted wife of 55 years to her husband Donald, a loving and caring mother to her sons Richard and James, and their wives, Nancy and Ilene, a proud and loving grandmother to her special grandchildren Jessica, Zachary, Leslie and Lucas. Loving sister to her brother Horace Linsky and an adored Aunt Barbara to her nieces and nephews. A woman of dignity and simple elegance, she exuded special interest and warmth in others, and demonstrated a courageous determination quite unique. Her love of family and friends, her love of life, will be missed by all she touched. Services at Gutterman - Warheit, Woodbury, N.Y. at 12 PM January 9.

title: Smithsonian Urged to Renew and Refocus Research Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 - The Smithsonian Institution should refocus its vast scientific research on four major areas, and it should receive more federal and private money for that mission, a commission has concluded.
