title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Blood Supply At Low Level
description: The New York Blood Center said yesterday that there was a severe shortage of O-negative blood, which is commonly used in emergencies, and that shipments to hospitals had had to be cut in half. The blood bank, which serves about 200 hospitals in New York and New Jersey, said it might also halve distribution of two other blood types, A-negative and B-negative, as supplies dwindle. Linda Levi, a spokeswoman for the center, said that supplies had dropped by about 25 percent because the Food and Drug Administration had placed a ban on imports from European countries over concern about the spread of a human variant of mad cow disease. With less than one full day's supply of O-negative on hand, the center is considering further cuts, Ms. Levi said. Information is available at (800) 933-2566 or www.nybloodcenter.org/. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: 2 Scientists Contend U.S. Suppressed Dolphin Studies
description: Two former government scientists who spent years investigating stress in dolphin populations charged this week that superiors at their federally funded laboratory shut down their research because it clashed with policy goals of the Clinton and Bush administrations.

description: ELDER-Barbara Jean (Hawkins). January 4, 2003. 73 years of age, of Manhattan. Originally from Portland, OR. A veteran of the Korean War, US Army Nurse Corps. She is survived by her husband of 45 years George, her children Scott, Janet and John and two grandchildren, William and Sierra. title: DETENTION UPHELD IN COMBATANT CASE
description: A federal appeals court handed the Bush administration a major legal victory today in ruling that a wartime president can indefinitely detain a United States citizen captured as an enemy combatant on the battlefield and deny that person access to a lawyer.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Ex-Aide To President Faces Bribe Charge
description: A judge has ordered the detention of a former minister of public works, Carlos Cruz, a longtime associate of President Ricardo Lagos, and two other officials on charges of taking bribes. Chile prides itself on having the least corrupt government in Latin America but it has been shaken in recent months by a corruption scandal in which five members of Congress have also been implicated. Mr. Lagos said that he was saddened by the arrest but, ''my government accepts the decision of the court'' and that ''nobody is above the law.'' Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: McCain and Lieberman Offer Bill to Require Cuts in Gases
description: At a packed committee hearing, Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, joined forces today to challenge the Bush administration on global warming.

title: State Contradicts Union On Load of Caseworker
description: New Jersey officials and the union representing child care caseworkers clashed yesterday over the union's assertions that the caseworker for Faheem Williams, the 7-year-old who was found starved to death in Newark last weekend, juggled 107 cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASH, SYLVIA
description: ASH-Sylvia. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend and benefactress, Sylvia Ash. Together with her beloved husband Ernest, they provided important philanthropic support to Beth Israel's Singer Division. Their generosity was recognized with the naming of the Sylvia and Ernest Ash Auditorium in 1994. She will forever be remembered by all whom have benefited from her care and compassion. To Ernest, their family and all of her loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees Continuum and Beth Israel Peter A. Kelly, President and CEO Continuum Thomas Killip, M.D. Interim President and CEO Beth Israel Martin M. Feuer, M.D. Associate Chairman of Medicine Singer Division Gerald Zelikovsky, M.D. Assistant Chairman of Urology, Singer Division

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA-PAKISTAN NUCLEAR COMPETITION India and Pakistan asserted their nuclear credentials once again yesterday, with India announcing that it would test several missiles in the next few days and Pakistan's army taking delivery of domestically produced medium-range missiles able to carry nuclear warheads. India will test a shorter-range version — 370 to 500 miles — of its surface-to-surface Agni missile, which can carry nuclear weapons. It will also test a short-range supersonic cruise missile with a range of 175 miles, developed with Russia. In Pakistan, the army took delivery of Hatf V Ghauri missiles.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Chemical Stake Sale
description: A right-wing populist billionaire, Christoph Blocher, will sell some of his stake in the specialty chemicals company EMS to increase its liquidity. The company will also unify its share structure and issue a dividend in 2002 for the first time since 1998. Mr. Blocher said that his company had a lot of cash and a strong cash flow, but that the changes were being made in case it would need to raise money at some point. A lack of liquidity prevented the company, which had an operating profit in 2001 of 163 million francs, from being quoted on Switzerland's blue-chip market index. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Ten Commandments Auction
description: After losing a court case over displaying the Ten Commandments on plaques in a courthouse, commissioners in Hamilton County voted to auction the plaques to help pay legal expenses in the case. Private groups and citizens donated $70,000 to cover most of the costs, but the county must pay $7,000.

title: Sharon Rebuffed Appeal on Palestinian Talks, Britain Says
description: LONDON, Jan. 9  Britain said today that Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon had rebuffed Prime Minister Tony Blair's personal appeal to reconsider Israel's decision to keep Palestinian negotiators from attending a British-sponsored conference in London next week. A spokesman for Mr. Blair vowed that some form of talks would go ahead as scheduled despite the Israeli ban.

title: A Head Finds Its Way Back Home; In Rare Gesture, Buddhist Leader In Taiwan Makes a Statue In China Whole
description: For 1,300 years the Akshobhya Buddha, one of four large statues of Buddha at the Four Gate Pagoda in China's Shandong Province, sat solemnly looking eastward, face locked in a beatific expression.

description: In scoring 14 unanswered points to take a 3-point lead over Providence midway through the second half tonight, St. John's showed some of the resilience it will need in road games.

title: Bush Signs Bill to Extend Unemployment Benefits
description: President Bush signed into law today an extension of unemployment benefits for about 2.5 million Americans just hours after the bill cleared the House, making the politically popular legislation the first enacted by the new Republican-controlled Congress.

title: An Antiquarian On 7th Avenue
description: LITTLE is it known that H. G. Wells's time traveler lives in Brooklyn Heights in a two-room apartment above a tailor's shop across Henry Street from a Thai restaurant.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BUFFALO: RALLY TO SUPPORT MURDER SUSPECT Abortion foes plan to mark the 30th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion nationwide with a rally for James Kopp, who is awaiting trial on murder charges in the slaying of a doctor who performed abortions. The Jan. 22 rally, coming a few weeks before the trial's expected start, is meant to convince potential jurors that the 1998 shooting of the doctor, Barnett A. Slepian, in his suburban Buffalo home was justifiable, said Jonathan O'Toole, a rally organizer, in an interview published yesterday in The Buffalo News. Neal Horsley, who runs a Web site called Abortioncams.com, said his organization would be taking photos of women visiting a city abortion clinic. Marilynn Buckham, the executive director of Buffalo's Womenservices clinic, where Dr. Slepian worked, called the plans to photograph patients "the height of trying to intimidate and terrorize women." (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Debt Review In Photo Merger
description: Moody's Investors Service put the debt ratings of the Konica Corporation on review for possible downgrade after it announced plans to merge with the Minolta Company. Minolta's debt ratings, on the other hand, could be upgraded, Moody's said, because its fiscal position may be improved by merging with Konica. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 26 about a mobile early-warning system that the United States military has deployed to Qatar to protect American and allied troops in the Persian Gulf against Iraqi missiles characterized the system incorrectly. It is a ground station that receives and processes infrared data from satellites, not a radar system.

title: Journeyman Gives Bucs A Respectable Offense
description: Tampa Bay's Brad Johnson, a well-traveled quarterback in his 11th National Football League season, has achieved such a height of celebrity locally this season that The Tampa Tribune plans to use him in a comic strip that will make its debut this week.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cruise Merger Advances
description: The board of P&O Princess Cruises recommended that shareholders accept a $5.3 billion takeover offer from the Carnival Corporation, essentially ending a battle for control of Princess by withdrawing its recommendation for a competing offer from Royal Caribbean Cruises. Princess shareholders are expected to vote on Carnival's proposal in March. The combined company would be the largest cruise ship operator, with 65 ships and 100,000 berths. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Iraq Gave No New Evidence in Arms Report, Inspector Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 9  The chief United Nations arms inspector in Iraq told the Security Council today that his team had found no "smoking gun" so far, but he also charged that the information supplied by Iraq was "devoid of any new evidence" that the country had no weapons of mass destruction.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: STORAGENETWORKS SHARES PLUNGE ON JOB CUTS Shares of StorageNetworks Inc. fell as much as 22 percent after the company said yesterday that it would cut about 110 workers, or half its staff, and a co-founder, Peter Bell, resigned as chief executive. Shares of the unprofitable provider of computer data-storage services dropped 24 cents, or about 18 percent, to $1.10. The stock has dropped 82 percent in the last year. Paul Flanagan, chief financial and operating officer of StorageNetworks, was chosen to replace Mr. Bell, who is stepping down to pursue other interests, the company said. StorageNetworks has never reported a profit since it was incorporated in 1998, Mr. Bell said in an interview in May. The people being laid off are not working on the company's Electronic Data Systems contract or on developing software products, the company said. (Bloomberg News)

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Congress To Consider Extending Internet Tax Moratorium
description: Legislation was introduced in both chambers of Congress to extend indefinitely a moratorium on Internet taxes. The current ban on federal and state taxes on online services is set to expire in November. Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, and Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California, submitted identical bills on Tuesday. ''Putting new, unfair Internet taxes on the backs of consumers is not the way to fix state and local budget troubles,'' Mr. Wyden said. ''It could seriously weaken the growing Internet economy and take jobs away from folks working for small Web companies.'' Congress passed the original ban on Internet taxes in 1998 to prevent states and local governments from imposing taxes that some thought could stunt the growth of the Web. Governors and state officials have argued that millions of dollars are lost in taxes every year when people shop on the Internet. But online retailers and technology companies, among others, say taxing online transactions could impair commerce, particularly during a recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILZIG, SIGGI B.
description: WILZIG-Siggi B. The Wilzig Family joins the people of Trust Company of NJ in mourning the loss of our patriarch and chairman. His contribution to the Bank, to NJ and to the world community is immeasurable and will be long remembered. As I have mentioned of my father before, his life was an embodiment of the American dream, coming to these shores as a Holocaust survivor and rising to become an influential business and community leader and philanthropist. He was an inspiration, a mentor and a friend. He treated the entire staff of the Bank as his family. True to his essence as a Survivor, he valiantly fought a dire illness for two years before passing away at the age of 76. He will be dearly missed by all who knew him: wife Naomi, sons Ivan and Alan of NYC, daughter Sherry Izak of Livingston, brother Erwin of FL and grandsons Jessie and Johnathon. Siggi Wilzig was born in 1926 in Krojanke, West Prussia. He was forced into the Auschwitz concentration camp at 16 years old. After the war, where he was the only survivor of his Jewish grade school class of 1,500, he came to the U.S. in 1947. In 1965, he was elected President and Chief Executive Officer of Wilshire Oil Company of Texas. Under Mr. Wilzig's leadership, Wilshire acquired a large interest in The Trust Company of NJ. He became a director of the Trust Company of NJ in 1969, and two years later was elected Chairman and President. In January 2002, Alan Wilzig was elected President and Chief Executive Officer of The Trust Company of NJ. In addition to many other charitable organizations, Siggi Wilzig served on the Board of Directors of the Daughters of Miriam Home for the Aged as well as the Jewish Home and Rehabilitation Center. Funeral Services will be held at the NJ Performing Arts Center, One Center Street, Newark, NJ at 2 PM today, Thursday, January 9, 2003. Burial will follow at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation, or The Shoah Foundation, P.O. Box 3168, Los Angeles, CA 90078, www.vhf.org, 818-776-4691 (Steven Klappholtz). The Wilzig Family will be ''Matching'' all donations. For more information, contact the Jewish Memorial Chapel 973-779-3048.

description: An article in The Arts on Monday about efforts to upgrade Disney's theme park stage shows misspelled the given name of a playwright who has been commissioned with Eric Schaeffer for a ''Snow White'' musical. She is Darrah Cloud, not Dara.

title: An Internet Official Agrees To Plead Guilty to Fraud
description: A fourth executive of the Internet real estate company Homestore agreed yesterday to plead guilty to securities fraud.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS TO PULL DRUG IN EUROPE BUT NOT IN U.S.
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company will pull the antidepressant Dutonin from the European market after 18 patients who took it died. Twenty-five cases of liver failure, including the 18 deaths, were linked to the drug worldwide, a Bristol-Myers spokesman, Bob Laverty, said. European sales make up less than 10 percent of the drug's $409 million in revenue, analysts said. The company will keep selling the drug in the United States as Serzone. The label carries the Food and Drug Administration's highest alert, which notes that liver failure has been reported. Susan Cruzan, an F.D.A. spokeswoman, said, ''The F.D.A. continues to monitor it and take everything into consideration.'' Bristol-Myers has been sued by former users of Serzone.

title: Foreign Minister in Mexico Will Quit, Frustrated by the U.S.
description: Mexico's foreign minister, Jorge G. Castaeda, will leave the government next week, frustrated over the stalemate in his country's relations with the United States since the attacks of Sept. 11 and the antiterrorism campaign born of them.

title: Sarah McClendon, Reporter At White House, Dies at 92
description: Sarah McClendon, the tiny, klaxon-voiced White House reporter who covered, pestered, lectured and often infuriated presidents since Franklin D. Roosevelt, chiefly as the leader of her one-woman McClendon News Service, died today at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center here. She was 92.

title: City Agrees to Help Care for Mentally Ill Inmates After Release
description: New York City would provide mentally ill jail inmates with treatment and other services when they were released, under an agreement signed yesterday that would settle a class-action lawsuit.

title: I.M.F. Still Sees 3.7% Growth This Year
description: An International Monetary Fund official said here today that the organization was sticking with its optimistic forecast that the world's economy would grow 3.7 percent this year, with much of Asia doing even better.

title: Draft Guidelines Released For Trade Center Memorial
description: A World Trade Center memorial should recognize each person killed in the attacks in New York, at the Pentagon and in Pennsylvania on Sept. 11, 2001, as well as those killed in the bombing at the trade center in 1993, according to a preliminary outline for the development of the memorial released yesterday.

title: Guess Announces Loss
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (Bloomberg News)  Guess Inc., a clothing retailer and designer, said today that its loss was wider than forecast last year after the company increased promotions and discounts to lure shoppers during the holidays.

title: Giving Those Callas Bootleg Tapes a Road Test
description: Of all the anecdotes that attest to Maria Callas's uncompromising artistry, the most telling concerns her performances in Verdi's ''Traviata'' in Lisbon in 1958.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ISAAC H.
description: FRIEDMAN-Isaac H., 79. Died January 5, 2003. Beloved husband of Lila. Devoted father of Elisabeth, Naomi, Richard and wife Suzanne. Loving grandfather of Adam and Steven. Loving step-father to Susan, husband Shelly, and Scott; step-grandfather to Jeffrey, Elliot, Chad and Daniel. Shiva: 212-866-5729.

title: The World Still Watches America
description: Once again, we are told, America's cultural hegemony is cracking. The latest proof: American television programs, which had dominated prime-time viewing in Europe and Asia for decades, are now being consigned to the late-night fringes of the schedule.

title: Jets Know They Have to Put Pressure on Gannon
description: It was the pivotal moment of the Jets' last playoff game in Oakland, and it happened far from the field, in the trainer's room. When defensive end John Abraham left the field with nausea in last season's first-round game, the defense went down with him. No pressure, no defensive stops. The door was opened for the Raiders' offense to shred the Jets, and the Jets' plan to overhaul their pass rush in the off-season was crystallized.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, THOMAS W.
description: CARR-Thomas W., 84. Long time resident of Port Washington, NY died on January 5th in Rockville, MD. His publishing and advertising career was with Computer Decisions, Electronic Design, 50 Plus Magazines and AdWeek's Marketer's Guide to Media. He is survived by his wife, Agnes, son John and fiance, Louise, son James and wife Robin, as well as brother, Peter, from California. Services will be January 11th, at 9:30 A.M., St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Having a black box on the label is a big deal. It's pretty astounding to go from a year ago thinking this is one of the most benign drugs to a 180-degree turn in the opposite direction.''

title: Europe Scolds 3 Nations About Budgets
description: The European Union issued a terse report card to three of its biggest members today, telling Germany, France, and Italy to do a better job of reining in their swelling budget deficits.

title: Plug and Replay: Cardless Kit Turns a PC Into a TV Recorder
description: Personal video recorders like TiVo are continuing their march into the living rooms of the land, but for TV fans who have nice big hard drives on their computers, the PC can become a personal video recorder itself. An all-in-one kit from Pinnacle Systems, PCTV Deluxe, effects that transformation, making it possible for viewers to record programs on their laptops or desktop computers and watch them whenever they want.

title: New Setback for Power Cable Between Connecticut and L.I.
description: An effort to activate an underwater electrical cable between Connecticut and Long Island has suffered a new setback: the company that owns the cable has dropped its latest attempt to turn it on.

title: U.S. Begins Talks for Trade Pact With Central Americans
description: The Bush administration officially opened negotiations today to create a free trade agreement with five Central American countries within a year, a big leap in its ambitious plans for a Nafta-like zone throughout the Western Hemisphere.

title: Bush's Transformation in Saber-Rattling Times
description: THE RIGHT MAN

title: Bush and the Economy: The Debate Heats Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, LUCRETIA JETT
description: PHILLIPS-Lucretia Jett. New York University mourns the passing of Lucretia Jett Phillips, retired professor of social work and associate dean at the Shirley M. Ehrenkranz School of Social Work. Her dedication to her students and the social work profession will be remembered by us all. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Suzanne England, Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, ISIDORE
description: FALK-Isidore. With love and great sadness, we mourn the passing of Isidore (''Issie'') Falk on January 6, 2003 at age 99. Beloved husband of the late Anne Falk. Cherished father of Serafina (Melvyn), Rebecca (John), Maurice (Judi) and the late Michael (Barbara). Adored grandfather of Nathaniel (Esther), Monica (Ira), Cindy (David), Jessica (Chaim), James, Jeremy, Michelle (William), Leslie, Annie, Harry (Claudia) and Eve. Treasured great grandfather of Elizabeth, David, Emily, Joshua, Harry, Alexander, Sarah, Abigail, Abraham, Simon, Michael and Benjamin. We remember him with love, laughter and admiration. Funeral serviceswere held at at Park East Synagogue on January 8 at 9:30 AM. Shiva will be observed at 188 East 70th Street.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Giuliani Defends Dismissals of 3 Who Wore Blackface
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani testified yesterday that as New York City mayor, he immediately called for the firing of a police officer and two firefighters for their participation in a racist 1998 Labor Day parade float because he feared the possibility of "civil unrest leading to violence and riots."

title: Pro-Palestinian Wife of Europe's Banker Upsets the Dutch
description: Here and abroad, some Palestinians treat Gretta Duisenberg like a queen. Yasir Arafat refers to Ms. Duisenberg as Her Excellency.

title: Siggi B. Wilzig, 76, Executive And Survivor of the Holocaust
description: Siggi B. Wilzig, a Holocaust survivor who arrived penniless in the United States after World War II and went on to lead an oil company and a bank, died on Tuesday at Columbia- Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: A Recharge En Route
description: The iGo Juice from Mobility Products is for frequent travelers who want it all: a single power adapter that charges laptops, hand-held devices and cellphones and works in automobiles, airplanes and indoors with standard electrical outlets.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: No Letup On Opposition
description: The government has continued to stifle opposition movements despite recent support for human rights advocates from Jimmy Carter and other international figures, an independent Cuban rights group said. Elizardo Snchez, president of the Cuban Commission for Human Rights and National Reconciliation, a nongovernmental group, told Reuters the government had arrested more advocates in the last year in an effort to crush a movement for a referendum on increased rights. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Calling North Korea
description: The Bush administration belatedly but smartly reversed direction on North Korea this week by offering to begin direct talks with Pyongyang about its nuclear weapons programs. A quick and verifiable end to the North's nuclear ambitions should be the core aim of any discussions. It was never realistic to treat this objective of American diplomacy as a condition for beginning talks.

title: A Microsoft Watch Will Provide Much More Than Time
description: Microsoft, continuing its effort to extend its reach beyond computers, today introduced designs for a new class of watch that gives more than the time and a pocket audio and video player.

title: McGreevey Lifts New Jersey's Drought Restrictions
description: New Jersey's drought emergency, and a set of water use restrictions that have waxed and waned in intensity over the last 10 months, was lifted today by Gov. James E. McGreevey.

title: Along a Well-Trod Path, Rugs for the Well-Dressed Floor
description: Christopher and Suzanne Sharp, above, have run the Rug Company in Holland Park, London, for five years. Now they have opened a branch on Wooster Street in SoHo. Isn't SoHo the home of stores like Old Navy, and, as such, overexposed? ''A bit,'' Mr. Sharp said. ''It was an emotional choice. We loved the great spaces.'' Not to mention the SoHo foot traffic.

title: Artest's Temper Becomes A Concern
description: After the Indiana Pacers' shoot-around today, Ron Artest jokingly motioned to a photographer and said, ''Give me that camera.'' Obviously, Artest, who demolished a camera in anger last Friday night at Madison Square Garden, has maintained a sense of humor about the incident.

title: Before Death Sentence, Wendy's Killer Faces Victims' Kin
description: The man behind the massacre of five people at a Wendy's restaurant in Queens faced relatives of his victims yesterday for the first time, listening to their angry accusations and then apologizing, before a judge formally sentenced him to death.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: DEBT REVIEW IN PHOTO MERGER Moody's Investors Service put the debt ratings of the Konica Corporation on review for possible downgrade after it announced plans to merge with the Minolta Company. Minolta's debt ratings, on the other hand, could be upgraded, Moody's said, because its fiscal position may be improved by merging with Konica. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about an increase in the number of companies that raised their dividends last year gave an incorrect figure from Standard & Poor's for the average decline in price in 2002 for stocks in the S.& P. 500 that paid dividends. It was 13.5 percent, not 18.4 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODNER, JOHN T., M.D., K.M.
description: GOODNER-John T., M.D., K.M. On January 7, 2003. Husband of the late Kathleen W. and Helen M. Father of Marylou and John. Grandfather of Alex. Brother of Mary Jeanne Faus. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Friday, January 10 at 10 A.M.

title: Singapore Warns of Threat From Radical Islamic Groups
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 9  Even if the United States is successful in dismantling al-Qaeda, radical Islamic groups in Southeast Asia will be capable of further terrorist acts, like the recent one in Bali, the Singaporean government said today.

title: Editorial Observer; The President Confronts the Majority Congress He Boosted to Power
description: The power of President Bush to trump Congress is something to behold as the political dynamic of majority Republican control runs the length of Pennsylvania Avenue once more. After theatrically brilliant days of leaks and teases, Mr. Bush formally unveiled his economic stimulus plan precisely in time to suck all the oxygen out of both Capitol chambers as the 108th Congress opened for business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, PEARL
description: WEINER - Pearl. Beloved wife of Henry. Mother of Marc, Susan and Brian. Mother-in-law of Janet and Amy. Grandmother of Jonathan and Jamie. Sister of Helen. Sister-in-law of Molly and Ida. Will be missed by all.

title: Vick Next in Line if Torch Is Passed
description: Before there was Michael Vick, there was Donovan McNabb. Remember? McNabb arrived in the N.F.L. from Syracuse University in 1999 as the new model of a professional quarterback. Fast feet, strong arm. A third running back, a passing wizard on the move.

title: Spiking Up Flat Landscapes
description: Where is the next ''Lovely Bones'' when it's so badly needed? Publishing people returned to their offices this week after their year-end holidaying to wintry fields of unsettling news. Book sales were flatter than desired. Just as forlorn a note was the news that one of the most important and admired independent bookstores in the country had laid off nearly 10 percent of its staff. So there was a chill on the new year before it even started, as publishers looked to a midwinter of heavy returns and less-than-hefty cash register activity.

title: 52 Straight By UConn, But Rutgers Battles
description: Looking beaten down and agitated, Connecticut Coach Geno Auriemma ranted away when the game was over. He wasn't happy with this, that or anything, so much so that he seemed to miss an important point: Connecticut won.

title: Bush and the Economy: The Debate Heats Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Ruling of Appeals Court
description: Following are excerpts from the opinion of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in the case of an American-born Saudi who was captured on an Afghan battlefield:

title: 'Freedom,' With Blood And Sweat Toweled Off
description: Oddly, ''Freedom: A History of US,'' 16 episodes charting the nation's pursuit of liberty from Bunker Hill to the World Trade Center attack, does not address the last enslaved American institution: PBS.

title: Final Seconds Bedevil Knicks Once Again
description: Kurt Thomas had been nearly automatic, sinking jumpers, open or not, for the bulk of the fourth quarter. But with 5.5 seconds to play tonight, the touch that had carried the Knicks to the cusp of a breathtaking victory failed them.

title: Senator Miller, Democratic Maverick, Will Retire
description: Senator Zell Miller, the wild-card Georgia Democrat who has contributed to some of the Bush administration's biggest legislative victories, announced today that he would not seek re-election in 2004.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Panel Urges Judge's Removal
description: A state commission has recommended that a judge be removed from the bench for campaign remarks made four years ago that implied he would favor the police and prosecution in cases that came before him. In 1999, the judge, William Watson, who was then campaigning for the Lockport City Court, promised voters that he would ''work with the police'' on ''cleaning up the streets,'' the Commission on Judicial Conduct said on Tuesday. Also, he urged Police Department employees, by letter, to ''put a real prosecutor on the bench!'' Judge Watson is a former assistant district attorney. His lawyer, Timothy P. Murphy, called the commission's recommendation unwarranted and said he planned to seek a review by the State Court of Appeals. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Bush and the Economy: The Debate Heats Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Hole Caused Collapse, but Who Did the Digging?
description: The cleanup and investigation into the collapse of a wall at a Crown Heights apartment building on Tuesday is becoming a whodunit, with no one sure who dug the hole that officials say caused the collapse.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: 11 Arrested At Defense Contractors
description: Eleven workers at defense contractors that help supply combat helicopters to the Pentagon have been charged in a scheme to get security clearance at the Sikorsky Aircraft Corporation in Stratford, officials said yesterday. Eight of the workers, illegal immigrants, were charged with using fake records; the other three, United States citizens, were charged with lying about their past, officials said. Federal prosecutors identified the workers as employees of subcontractors for Sikorsky. All had access to classified areas, though none have been charged with theft or with involvement in terrorist activities. After their arraignment in Federal District Court here, the illegal immigrants were turned over to immigration authorities. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Some Progress In Talks
description: At peace talks in Thailand, the Sri Lankan government and the rebel Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam agreed that the World Bank would be the custodian of a fund for the rebuilding of the war-ravaged north and east, and made progress toward setting a timetable for the rebuilding. They continue to disagree over the resettlement of Tamil civilians on land taken by the army as high-security zones. The army wants the rebels to disarm in those areas before giving up the land; the rebels say they will not. In Colombo, Sri Lanka's capital, 10,000 people protested, saying the government was conceding too much in the talks. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: MAYOR ADMITS GUILT IN DISCARDING PAPERS Tom Bates, the new mayor of Berkeley, pleaded guilty to petty theft and paid a $100 fine for tossing into the trash 1,000 copies of a newspaper run by students at the University of California that endorsed his opponent in the November election. Mr. Bates, 64, an assemblyman for 20 years, was easily elected on Nov. 5, a day after the paper, The Daily Californian, had endorsed Mayor Shirley Dean for a third four-year term.

title: Jackals Gather Round
description: Two nights ago in Tehran, President Mohammad Khatami, the pretended reformist who fronts for hard-line ayatollahs, held a meeting with leaders of the Iraqi opposition to Saddam Hussein.

title: The Revenge of Trent Lott
description: The nation didn't have to wait long to find out if President Bush's impassioned denunciation of Trent Lott's racial views last month presaged a new approach to the selection of federal judges. It didn't. That became clear on Tuesday evening when the White House decided to renominate Charles Pickering, who failed to win confirmation from the Democratic-controlled Senate last year. Judge Pickering, a Mississippi trial judge and a protg of Mr. Lott, was rejected largely because of his insensitive handling of civil rights cases. The Senate should once again refuse to confirm Judge Pickering, and should carefully scrutinize the 30 other nominees the administration is putting forth.

title: 21 Die in Commuter Plane Crash in North Carolina
description: A fully loaded commuter plane departing here for a short hop to Greer, S.C., veered left this morning and nosedived seconds after taking off, slamming into a maintenance hangar and bursting into flames. All 21 people on board were killed.

title: Smoke in Suffolk, Revisited
description: Leading critics of a proposed ban on smoking in bars and restaurants in Suffolk County now support a revised ban, the measure's sponsor said yesterday. The agreement is expected to clear the way for the ban's adoption by the County Legislature at its next meeting, on Jan. 28.

title: A Comeback on Another Coast
description: The sun had faded after burnishing the San Gabriel Mountains, and after riding 10 horses in morning workouts and posting two victories in four afternoon mounts, Julie Krone was losing her light, too. All 4 feet 11 inches and 105 pounds were balled up on a bench in front of the paddock at Santa Anita Park, making her barely bigger than the stuffed backpack that sat at her side.

title: Frist Points to Racial Inequities in Health Care
description: Bill Frist, the new Senate majority leader, vowed today to reduce racial disparities in health care as a means of repairing his party's standing with minorities.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Visas Now Required For Jamaicans
description: The government announced that Jamaicans must now obtain visas to enter the country, saying that of those who entered as vistors, an unacceptably high number -- 150 a month -- failed to leave as required after six months. The measure was part of a tough new immigration policy that denies support to asylum seekers within Britain who cannot explain how they entered the country. Jamaica is a particular concern to British officials, who estimate that 10 percent of travelers from there are ''mules'' used by smugglers to ferry cocaine into the country. Jamaican officers have been stationed at airports there and at Heathrow outside London to try to screen out drug couriers. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Spencer Signs With the Indians
description: They were the words Shane Spencer never heard from Yankees Manager Joe Torre, and when Eric Wedge said them, Spencer knew where he wanted to play.

title: Bricks Go, but Seminary's Liberal Foundation Stays
description: A FEW decades ago, in the world of theological education, Union Seminary was a titan. The faculty included some of the greatest theologians of the century, including Reinhold Niebuhr, Dietrich Bonhoeffer and Paul Tillich. Harry Emerson Fosdick presided over the congregation at Riverside Church. Across the street, at Jewish Theological, was Abraham Heschel. This little stretch of Broadway, to some, was close to sitting at the feet of the prophets.

title: Now Playing: Reality Without the Downside
description: RUNNING at remarkably steep angles up a grassy hill, Melinda Gann glanced over her shoulder and caught a glimpse of the beach falling far away from her as she recently made her way to the summit. She was alone and exhilarated. The view, she recalled, was almost as stunning as her achievement: leaving behind her body -- disabled with lupus and arthritis that has confined her to a wheelchair -- to enter a newly created, computer-generated world called There.

title: With Helmets, Fashion Is a Slave to Safety
description: There was a time, not long ago, when the only people wearing helmets while riding bicycles were racers. The same was true for people on horseback, people in kayaks, people climbing mountains or people playing ice hockey.

title: White Supremacist Is Held In Ordering Judge's Death
description: A white supremacist was arrested this afternoon on charges that he had solicited someone to kill a federal judge presiding over a copyright case regarding the name of his organization, the World Church of the Creator.

title: Sales Rise 1.7% For Licensed Goods
description: The retail sales of licensed merchandise in North America rose 1.7 percent in 2002, to $71.5 billion, from $70.3 billion in 2001, according to the 26th annual licensing industry survey by The Licensing Letter, published by EPM Communications in New York.

title: A Card With Bargains For Demanding Bearers
description: The holidays may be over, but for some the urge to shop never ends. A discount card for 140 stores, restaurants, museums and theaters in SoHo and TriBeCa is available for a $25 donation to the SoHo Partnership, which provides job training and employment for homeless men and women. The list includes Anthropologie, Pearl Paint, Jan de Luz, a linen shop, and Craft Caravan, which has a selection of African wares, all offering a 10 percent discount. Kate's Paperie gives 15 percent off. The SoHo Partnership is at 114 Greene Street (Houston); (212) 274-0550 or www.sohonyc.org. The card is good for one year. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Hate of the West Finds Fertile Soil in Yemen. But Does Al Qaeda?
description: Investigators know the basic facts: In this poor and isolated nation with no lack of extremists, a young preacher named Ahmed Ali Jarallah assembled a small cell of militants to strike the enemies of Islam in Yemen. Two years ago, he read off a hate list in a speech at a mosque here, singling out specifically a hospital run by American Baptists.

title: Germany Will Not Insist On 2nd Vote, Envoy Says
description: Germany will not insist on a second Security Council resolution if there is a new debate on whether to authorize war in Iraq, Gunter Pleuger, the German ambassador to the United Nations, said today. But it believes that weapons inspectors are making progress, he added, and should be given time to do their work.

title: Power-Saving Stylus Lights Up Hand-Helds
description: Tired of running down the battery on your hand-held organizer every time you need to use the backlight to check a phone number or an appointment? The Belkin penlight stylus offers a simple but elegant solution. A cleverly designed replacement for a standard Palm stylus, this little gizmo shines a bright light onto the screen of your hand-held, often eliminating the need to use the standard backlight.

title: Panel Offers Blueprint to Fix Smithsonian's 'Unfocused and Underfunded' Science Programs
description: The Smithsonian Institution should refocus its vast scientific research on four major areas, and it should receive more federal and private money for that mission, a commission has concluded.

title: Bush and the Economy: The Debate Heats Up
description: To the Editor:

title: A Family's Fortune, a Legacy of Blood and Tears
description: In their hometown, the McWanes are known for quiet generosity. The family pledged $10 million to the science museum, the McWane Center. They have given millions more to Alabama's major cultural institutions, including the Birmingham Civil Rights Institute. College students compete for McWane scholarships.

title: Oakland Comes Out Throwing Barbs
description: Randy Jordan is a sage special teams player for the Oakland Raiders, but he was once a young, impulsive member of the Jacksonville Jaguars.

title: U.S. Lobbies Oil Exporters to Produce More
description: The Bush administration, alarmed by a 38-day strike that has crippled Venezuela's petroleum industry and caused sharp increases in prices, has begun pressing countries that export oil to increase production, administration officials said today.

title: Pataki Backs Wind and Solar Power
description: In a brief, low-key passage in his annual address to the Legislature, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday electrified green-energy supporters and environmentalists who had hoped without much hope for years that New York would become a national leader in sustainable nonpolluting energy.

title: Hong Kong's Leader Cuts His Pay in 'Hard Times'
description: Saying he thought that Hong Kong was facing the worst economic situation in decades, the territory's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, cut his own salary 10 percent today. He said he was reducing his pay, and that of 16 of his ministers and close aides, to ''share the hard times'' and help fight a ballooning budget deficit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANTO, MITZI NEE GOLDREYER
description: DANTO-Mitzi nee Goldreyer. Wife of the late Jules. Mourned by her daughters, Amy (Michael Hundert) and Sally (Michael Clancy), her grandchildren, Julie and Joshua Hundert, and Justis and Jacob Danto-Clancy, her brothers, Harvey Dreyer and Leonard Goldreyer. Companion of Wim de Vrijer. Services on Friday, 10 A.M., at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 26 about a mobile early-warning system that the United States military has deployed to Qatar to protect American and allied troops in the Persian Gulf against Iraqi missiles characterized the system incorrectly. It is a ground station that receives and processes infrared data from satellites, not a radar system.

title: Giuliani Defends Dismissals Of 3 Who Wore Blackface
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani testified yesterday that as New York City mayor, he immediately called for the firing of a police officer and two firefighters for their participation in a racist 1998 Labor Day parade float because he feared the possibility of ''civil unrest leading to violence and riots.''

title: The Symbol Of a Troupe: Joining New To the Old
description: ''Another opening, another show'' is a clich more suited to Broadway than to the New York City Ballet, with its storehouse of 19th- and 20th-century classics. In recent years, however, the company seems to open its winter season three times.

title: Military Says It Can't Make Enough Vaccines for Troops
description: One of the Army's top biodefense officers said today that the Pentagon does not have vaccines to protect troops from some virulent biological agents because it has not been able to offer enough money to commercial pharmaceutical companies to produce them.

title: Raising High the Russian Roof Beams
description: IT'S a long climb up poorly lighted stairs to reach Gillian Bailey's 19th-century apartment high above this city's congested historic center. The effort pays off once inside, though, at the unlikely sight of sunlight bursting through a half-dozen skylights and half-moon windows. With its ceiling sloping almost to the floor, the apartment combines the clean lines of modern architecture with the charm of exposed wood trusses and brick. Its expansive living space and two bedrooms call to mind the SoHo loft district rather than Imperial Russia.

title: Paris Journal; Once Again, the French Storm the Cash Registers
description: The daily Figaro published maps of the most dangerous battle zones. The radio station RTL announced survival strategies. The Ministry of the Interior pledged to maintain an increased police presence deployed during the Christmas season.

title: When a Snowy Landscape Isn't Enough, Accessorize
description: AT last, a winter with enough snow to turn backyards into sports centers -- a private Lake Placid out the backdoor. All that's needed are sleds, igloos and ice rinks. For those who prefer to skate in warmth, an artificial rink can be installed in the basement.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: TV Maker Rescued
description: The Taiwanese consumer electronics group Sampo agreed to take a majority stake in the German television maker Grundig, helping the troubled company avoid liquidation. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed. The companies said Anton Kathrein, Grundig's majority shareholder, would retain a minority stake. Grundig, which is based in Nuremberg, has 2,800 employees and expects a loss of 75 million euros ($77.8 million) on sales of about 1.2 billion euros ($1.25 billion) in 2002. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, MARY BENTLEY
description: BAKER-Mary Bentley. Died on January 7, 2003 in NYC. Wife of the late Robert Lynn Baker. Survived by her daughters, Ellen Baker and Susannah Bell, her granddaughter, Tabor Tompkins Story, her sons-in-law, James Sweeney and James Bell, eight nephews and a niece. Mass on Monday January 13, 10 AM, St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and 50th St, NYC. Contributions may be made to St. Patrick's Home, 66 Van Cortlandt Park South, Bronx, New York 10463.

title: Corrections
description: The introduction to a film review excerpt yesterday about ''The Slaughter Rule,'' which has reopened in New York after showing in a festival last year, misidentified the theater for the current showing. It is the Pioneer, at 155 East Third Street (Avenue A), not the Anthology Film Archives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAPP, JAMES F.
description: MAPP-James F. On January 5, 2003. Born in Melfa, Virginia, May 9, 1909. Was a trial lawyer for Kemper Insurance, New York City, for 30 years. Survived by wife Anna, son George. Burial, Wachapreague Cemetery, Va.

title: Apple Thinks Big, And Small
description: THE number 128 is important in personal computing. Because it's a tidy power of two, it often defines quantities of things like megabytes, megahertz and megawatts. But for Apple at the annual Macworld Expo trade show, 128 was a more important number. It was the number of times the audience interrupted Steve Jobs's keynote speech with applause.

title: Child Abuse Case In Newark Grows As Man Is Charged With Molestation
description: A friend of the woman whose locked basement concealed the body of a 7-year-old boy was arrested today and charged with sexually assaulting the child's brother, law enforcement officials said.

title: Mysteries Made for Partygoing Sleuths
description: ONE day last week, someone -- my daughter Ella, I think it was -- informed me that there were only 49 days to go until her 12th birthday.

title: Corrections

description: The Topps Company, the maker of collectible trading cards and Bazooka bubble gum, said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter profit fell 4 percent on an 8 percent decline in sales, led by its Pokmon products.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Mayor Admits Guilt In Discarding Papers
description: Tom Bates, the new mayor of Berkeley, pleaded guilty to petty theft and paid a $100 fine for tossing into the trash 1,000 copies of a newspaper run by students at the University of California that endorsed his opponent in the November election. Mr. Bates, 64, an assemblyman for 20 years, was easily elected on Nov. 5, a day after the paper, The Daily Californian, endorsed Mayor Shirley Dean for a third four-year term. When he took office last month, Mr. Bates apologized at his first meeting with the City Council. Robert B. Gunnison (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Environment: Rare Turtles Die In Fishing Nets
description: More than 3,000 rare olive ridley sea turtles became entangled and died in fishing nets on their way to lay eggs along India's Bay of Bengal coast, environmental campaigners in Orissa State said. They said the deaths had resulted from poor enforcement of wildlife laws requiring trawlers to stay several miles offshore during the turtle nesting season. The species, which can grow to twice the size of a trash-can lid, is listed as threatened or endangered throughout tropical seas. Its largest nesting ground is thought to be in Orissa. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: TYCO IS LOOKING FOR CHEAPER OFFICE SPACE
description: Tyco International says it is looking in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania for offices so it can save money by leaving the New York City space now used by top officers. The United States headquarters of the company, which is based in Bermuda, will remain in Exeter, N.H., a spokesman said. Tyco's office on the 43rd floor at 9 West 57th St. is among the city's most expensive, said Ruth Colp-Haber, a partner at the real estate firm Wharton Property Advisers. The office is used by about 30 Tyco executives, including the chief executive, Ed Breen, who was hired in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERVONI, PAUL V.
description: CERVONI-Paul V., 64. Husband of Mary K. Birdsall Cervoni of North Haven, CT. English teacher, former Chairman of the English Dept. at Trumbull High School, Trumbull, CT, twice made a National Center of Excellence in English. Paul was Chairman of the CT Council of Teachers of English and was active in the National Council of Teachers of English and the New England Council. Cervoni pioneered programs in the training of student teachers for Central CT State University, University of Bridgeport and Southern CT State University. A Fullbright exchange teacher to England he was a champion of international education programs. A brilliantly innovative educational leader, his classes produced a wide range of high achieving students. He led a golden age of education from 1963 - 98. Funeral service Saturday, January 11, 11AM at St. John Episcopal Church, 3 Trumbull Pl, North Haven, CT. Beecher & Bennett, 2300 Whitney Ave, Hamden, CT for information. title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Fund-Raising Letter Stirs Concern
description: A watchdog group expressed concern about a fund-raising letter that Speaker Rick Johnson, a Republican, sent lobbyists, businesses and special-interest groups last month. The letter, first published by The Detroit News, sought $20,000 donations to the House Republican Campaign committee in exchange for a ''meal or meeting'' with Mr. Johnson to discuss political concerns. Rich Robinson, executive director of the Michigan Campaign Finance Network, said the timing of the letter was troubling because new lawmakers were sworn in this week. ''It appears this is the first priority,'' he said. A spokesman for Mr. Johnson said the letter was meant to announce smaller meetings that would replace an annual $1,000-a-plate fund-raiser. David Enders (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Mendocino, Calif.
description: A QUICK immersion in this Northern California coastal village, the picturesque hub of Mendocino County, is a chance to aerate body and soul. Mendocino is a stage set of pioneer California, a cluster of low white frame Victorian buildings and old water towers nestled in the curve of a cove high above the crashing waves of the cold Pacific. Somewhere between a New England fishing village and an Old West frontier town, little Mendocino (population 1,200) looks much as it did in the 19th century, when it was a thriving logging town, shipping redwoods down to an expanding San Francisco. Today's visitors typically arrive after a drive through Sonoma and Napa Counties, with their vineyards, cheese- and snack-laden tasting rooms and many wines that cannot be found elsewhere. The last part of the drive to Mendocino is an exhilarating hairpin-turn coastal road through what remains of the ancient redwood forest, where huge evergreen trees obliterate the sky before opening suddenly onto a five-mile stretch of ocean road that leads directly into the village. The temperature hovers between 50 and 60 degrees year-round; sunny days are glorious; stormy days, memorably dramatic. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: PATERSON: FOUR PRIESTS UNDER REVIEW A review board for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson has determined that sexual misconduct allegations against four priests, whose cases cannot be pursued by civil authorities, are credible and should be pursued by a church court. The sexual abuse charges against the priests  Msgr. John Derricks, the Revs. James A. D. Smith, Ralph Sodano and Alan Stepien  have been referred to a diocesan official. Some of the allegations date back 50 years and could not be prosecuted because of the statute of limitations, a spokeswoman for the diocese said. A lawyer representing Monsignor Derricks, Father Sodano and Father Stepien did not immediately return a call for comment. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Detainees To Be Freed
description: Rwanda plans to release up to 40,000 detainees who have been held for years for their reported involvement in the mass killings of 1994, according to a decree by President Paul Kagame. The move is aimed at clearing prisons of youths, sick people and elderly prisoners, and some suspects who confessed to their involvement in the ethnic massacres of Tutsi and moderate Hutu. Those released could still face trial in local courts, Attorney General Grard Gahima said. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BUCHANAN: NUCLEAR PLANT REPORT DUE SOON A long-awaited draft report on the effectiveness of evacuation plans for the Indian Point nuclear plant may be released as early as today, officials from Gov. George E. Pataki's administration said yesterday. The state's emergency management office received the report in mid-December but has not yet made it public, upsetting environmentalists and some public officials. Pataki officials said the delay was caused by factual errors in the first draft. The report, by James Lee Witt, a former director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, was commissioned by Mr. Pataki last year to determine whether nearby communities could be evacuated or protected in a terrorist attack or other disaster.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Safir Testifies In Police Lawsuit
description: Howard Safir, the former New York City police commissioner, testified in federal court yesterday that he independently decided to dismiss a police officer who wore blackface on a float in a 1998 Labor Day parade in Queens. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had publicly said the officer, Joseph Locurto, would be fired. Mr. Safir testified, ''There was no doubt in my mind that the mayor, if it was his decision, wanted him fired, but it wasn't his decision.'' Mr. Safir testified in a trial over lawsuits filed against the city by Mr. Locurto and two former firefighters, Jonathan Walters and Robert Steiner, who were also fired for their roles in the float. All three contend they were fired in violation of their rights to free speech. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Navy Confirms Uranium Use
description: The Navy has confirmed that it fires rounds made in part of depleted uranium in its tests of the Phalanx antimissile systems aboard surface ships. The Ground Zero Center for Nonviolent Action, a peace advocacy group, obtained a Navy memo last month that described the firing of depleted uranium rounds by the destroyer Fife in June 2001 off the coast of Washington. Kenneth Chang (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Inflation Tops Target
description: Inflation in Mexico was 5.7 percent in 2002, the Bank of Mexico said today. The target for the year was 4.5 percent, but the removal of most electricity subsidies and a 14 percent weakening of the peso against the dollar pushed the rate higher. Investors expect the central bank to tighten monetary policy today, at its first meeting of the year on that topic, to curb inflation expectations for 2003, when the target is 3 percent. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Youth Permitted To Dress As Female
description: A young man living in a city foster-care home may dress as a woman, a state court ruled. Justice Louise Gans of State Supreme Court ruled, in a decision released yesterday, that the city had violated the youth's rights when the city-run home, the Atlantic Transitional Foster Facility in Brooklyn, prevented him from wearing skirts and dresses. The name of the man, 17, was not released because of his age. He identifies himself as a female and is considered legally disabled; a psychiatrist said the diagnosis was gender identity disorder. The judge ordered the Administration for Children's Services to exempt the youth from male-only dress. Facility officials had argued that the women's clothing he wore was sexually provocative in an all-male environment. A spokeswoman for the children's services agency said yesterday that it had not yet received the decision but had already moved the youth to another facility, where he can dress as he likes. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: The Knicks Go to the Edge, but No Further

The tangled web of keiretsu partnerships, heavy government influence and sheer resistance to change make it one of the most impenetrable industries for newcomers, especially foreigners, to enter.

The measure was the first passed by the new Congress, as it should be, and helps redeem the sour finish of the last.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Construction To Begin
description: The Department of Education plans school construction, the equivalent of 13,495 new seats, to be ready in the fall, officials said at a School Construction Authority meeting yesterday. Most of the space will be built in Queens, the most overcrowded borough. Eight new schools will open in Queens, along with three additions to schools. Two schools are planned for both Brooklyn and the Bronx and one school is scheduled to open in Staten Island. In November, the Independent Budget Office estimated that 7,400 seats would be delayed this year because of budget shortfalls. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Sony Chooses NBC TV Executive to Head Music Division
description: The Sony Corporation has chosen the longtime television executive Andrew Lack to succeed Thomas D. Mottola as the chief executive of its music division, The Times has learned. An official announcement is expected this afternoon.

title: Albert I. Edelman, 86, an International Lawyer in New York
description: Albert I. Edelman, a top international lawyer in New York and a former law partner of Senator Jacob K. Javits and of John J. McCloy, died yesterday at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Bronxville and East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDER, MARGARET SLADE
description: LANDER-Margaret Slade. On Wednesday, January 8, at her home in Manhattan, at the age of 89. Former head of the Personal Shopping Department and the Control Center at Macy's, in her retirement active quiltmaker and member of Empire Quilters. Widow of William Hall Lander of New York City; mother of Louise Lander of Guanajuato, Mexico, Patricia Lander of Nanuet, N.Y. and Slade Lander of Toronto; grandmother of Alison Elizabeth Lander Alpern, Adam Lander Alpern and Bryn Lander. Interment at TrinityChurch Cemetery will be private.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Volkswagen Investment
description: Volkswagen has picked its Puebla, Mexico, plant to make the new Bora model for the European market, said Reinhard Jung, president of Volkswagen Mexico. The company plans to invest $2 billion in the plant in the next five years, including $180 million on the Bora line, and add 1,500 jobs. Mr. Jung said 4,000 to 5,000 jobs would be created among local suppliers. The car's production will begin in 2005 with 100,000 units a year.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Quiet Man Now Coaches the Raiders
description: The man who replaced Jon Gruden as coach of the Oakland Raiders grew up on the South Side of Chicago, where he went to Catholic school in the shadow of a U.S. Steel factory and where the lure of the family business was strong.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

title: 'Session the Bowl'
description: Deitch Projects

title: Fearing Liability, Law Firms Change Partnership Status
description: Two of New York's most prominent law firms have quietly converted to a type of partnership that shields members from personal liability if the firms collapse under devastating lawsuits by clients or investors. Several other large firms are weighing similar steps.

title: Thomas Wyman, Ex-CBS Chief, Dies at 73
description: Thomas H. Wyman, a former chairman and chief executive of CBS who resigned his membership in the Augusta National Golf Club last month to protest its refusal to admit women, died on Wednesday in Boston. He was 73.

title: U.S. Economy Shows Unexpected Weakness as Jobs Decline
description: In a clear sign that the economy is stalling, the Labor Department reported today that the nation's payrolls fell for a second straight month in December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILPATRIC, MIRIAM THORNE
description: GILPATRIC-Miriam Thorne. Died Tuesday, January 7, at her home in New York City. Mrs. Gilpatric was born in Clinton, IN. She led an active and interesting life and traveled widely with her three devoted and prominent husbands. Her first husband and the father of her children, Fulton Cahners, who worked for Cahners Publishing Company, predeceased Mrs. Gilpatric. She subsequently married Landon Thorne, Jr., a banker, newspaper publisher and diplomat, and Roswell Gilpatric, Deputy Secretary of Defense under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson and a former member and presiding partner of the New York City law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. Both Mr. Thorne and Mr. Gilpatric also predeceased Mrs. Gilpatric. Mrs. Gilpatric was an active patron of many institutions. She served as a trustee of the American University in Cairo, the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, and the Wildlife Conservation Society, and was a director of The Thorne Foundation. She was also a member of the Director's Round Table of the Pierpont Morgan Library, a contributor to the Mayo Clinic and a long-time patron of WNET Channel Thirteen and The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mrs Gilpatric is survived by her sister, Bettie Watson, of Louisville, KY, and by her two children, Laura CahnersFord of Charlotte, VT, and John Cahners of Portola Valley, CA, and their children, William and Sarah Ford and Kyle Cahners. She is also survived by three stepchildren, Landon Thorne, III, of Sheldon, SC, David Thorne of Brookline, MA, and Julia Thorne of Bozeman, MT, and their children, Landon, Christopher, Charles, Thomas, David, William, Emma, Vanessa and Alexandra. A memorial service will be held on Friday, January 17, 11:00 A.M., at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to any of the following charitable organizations: National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, New York, NY; Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN; WNET Channel Thirteen, New York, NY; and The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, NY.

title: Riley Eager to Prove That Last Year's Victory Wasn't a Fluke
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii, Jan. 9  Chris Riley and his wife, Michelle Louviere, were married last month on Bourbon Street in New Orleans.

title: Machines, Noir Mood And Mayhem
description: With its microscopic eye for detail, Japanese anime is the ideal film medium for a techno-thriller like ''WXIII (Wasted 13: Patlabor the Movie 3),'' a visually absorbing futuristic fantasy that evokes a paranoid world choking on its own technology. With its murky chiaroscuro and fascination with machines (which it renders with far more precision than it does the faces of its characters) and brooding electronic score, the film, set in Tokyo in the near future, sustains a heady noirish atmosphere that might be called Technomood.

title: Report on Nuclear Quest: 'Clarification' Is Needed
description: Following are excerpts from a United Nations Security Council briefing yesterday by Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei, as provided by the United Nations. The complete text can be found at nytimes.com/international

title: American Furniture On the Block
description: ''It's a literal 10-ring circus,'' said Allan Katz, a veteran dealer in American folk art, commenting on the many Americana-related activities beginning this weekend in Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Muslim Brotherhood Loses A Seat
description: The Muslim Brotherhood lost one of its 17 seats in Parliament in a local election but remains the largest opposition bloc. Dr. Gamal Hishmet, an outspoken moderate member of the Brotherhood who ran as an independent, had served as a legislator for more than a year before being expelled last month when the 2000 election results in his Delta constituency were canceled because ballots were miscounted. During the new election, security forces blockaded the 110 polling stations and turned away about 148,000 voters, Dr. Hishmet said. Samar Aboul-Fotouh (NYT)

title: Pharmacy Benefit Companies Won't Disclose Fees
description: The companies that provide discounts on prescription drugs for about 200 million Americans have refused to tell Congressional investigators how much they are paid by drug makers to promote sales of their favorite drugs.

title: WILLIAMS-SONOMA SAYS DIRECTOR IS TAKING OVER AS CHIEF
description: Williams-Sonoma said yesterday that it had replaced its chief executive, Dale W. Hilpert, after 21 months, saying it needed a different type of leadership as the company grows. A director, Edward A. Mueller, 55, took over as chief executive. The company, which operates the Williams-Sonoma and Pottery Barn chains, said it would have $3.6 million in costs associated with Mr. Hilpert's departure, reducing fourth-quarter earnings by 2 cents a share. Mr. Hilpert, 59, left in a mutual decision with the board, the chairman, W. Howard Lester, said. Mr. Hilpert's leaving had nothing to do with the company's accounting or financial performance, Mr. Lester said. Shares of Williams-Sonoma fell $2.26, or 8 percent, to $25.73.

title: IMMUNE RESPONSE, STRUGGLING DRUG MAKER, NAMES CHIEF
description: The Immune Response Corporation, which is trying to avert bankruptcy while it develops an H.I.V. treatment, said yesterday that it had named John N. Bonfiglio chief executive. Mr. Bonfiglio, 48, previously served as chief operating officer of Cypress Bioscience. The previous chief executive, Dennis Carlo, resigned in September. The company, co-founded by Jonas Salk, the inventor of the polio vaccine, is reorganizing as it seeks more financing. It has enough money to operate for several more months, Mr. Bonfiglio said. Immune Response has no products on the market and has been working for a decade to get its Remune H.I.V. treatment on the market.

title: Woman Dies and 8 Are Hurt As Car Crashes Into Store
description: A speeding car -- engine roaring and tires screeching -- mounted a crowded sidewalk and plowed into a storefront in Lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, striking pedestrians, vendors and shoppers in a blur of violence and shattering glass. A woman was killed, and eight other people, including the driver, were injured, the police said.

title: Orange County School Official Charged in Sex Abuse Case
description: The school superintendent in this growing city flanked by the Catskill Mountains was charged today with sexually molesting a 14-year-old boy in his school district.

title: A Speech by Sharon Is Pulled Off the Air
description: With his re-election campaign in chaos over corruption accusations, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel went on the counterattack, pounding the lectern and calling the allegations ''despicable slander.''

title: NORTH KOREA SAYS IT IS WITHDRAWING FROM ARMS TREATY
description: Stepping up pressure following an American offer to open talks, North Korea said today it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. The announcement means that, in 90 days, North Korea will no longer be bound by the treaty.

title: Agency Challenges Evidence Against Iraq Cited by Bush
description: The key piece of evidence that President Bush has cited as proof that Saddam Hussein has sought to revive his program to make nuclear weapons was challenged today by the International Atomic Energy Agency.

title: Michael Haas, Yves Dana and Not Vital
description: Jan Krugier Gallery

title: Crime, False Confessions and Videotape
description: By the time five teenage suspects gave the videotaped confessions that helped convict them in the 1989 rape of the Central Park jogger, they had been through hours of unrecorded interrogation. What led them to confess to a crime they apparently did not commit will never be known for certain. Far from a neat ending, the exoneration of the young men begs for reforming the way suspects are led to rehearsed statements of guilt.

title: 2 Airline Executives Say Industry Needs More U.S. Aid
description: Two of the nation's biggest airlines told Congress today that they were searching their operations for cost cuts but still needed government help to pay for new security measures and to tackle their single largest expense: labor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, DR. ALBERT L. DDS
description: GORMAN-Dr. Albert L. DDS, of Suffern, NY., and Boca Raton, Fl. Formerly of Bronx, NY. At rest on January 8, 2003. Loving husband of Caroline (nee Giuliano). Beloved father of Louis M. Gorman, Mona E. Gorman, Renee L. Press, and Jackie Gorman. Dear brother of Edward J. Gorman and Susan Ruland. Grandfather of seven. Funeral services Friday, January 10, 12:00 pm at the SJ Priola Parsippany Funeral Service, 60 North Beverwyck Road, Lake Hiawatha, NJ. Interment Beth-El Cemetery, Washington Township, NJ. For further information please call 973-335-4700 or see www.parsippanyfuneral.com
