description: To the Editor:

title: An Unusual Band That Specializes in the Familiar
description: Paul Motian's Electric Bebop Band seemed like an eccentric idea when it was started 11 years ago. A small jazz group with two tenor saxophonists is rare enough; a small group with two guitarists is rare enough. But this band has two of each, all front-line instrumentalists, soloing in pairs, and it covers a lot of piano-dominated bebop material from the 1940's and 50's, despite the absence of a piano.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, MAUREEN
description: LYONS-Maureen. Beloved wife of George V, mother of Anne Sengebush Gerard and Foster Lyons. Memorials may be made to the Sherburne Memorial Library Gardens, Killington, VT 05751

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 25 about federal appeals courts' rules against citing one-time rulings as precedent misstated the date for the end of such a restriction in the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the policy of the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The District of Columbia restriction ended on Jan. 1, 2002, not 2003. The First Circuit eased its restriction on Dec. 16; the change was not still pending.

title: Race and the Party of Lincoln
description: To the Editor:

title: An Italian Invasion, Rippling Muscles and All
description: Salander-O'Reilly Galleries makes a pretty sweeping claim when it calls its ''Italian Sculpture: From the Gothic to the Baroque'' show ''the largest and most comprehensive exhibition of Italian sculpture ever held in New York City.'' Still, go prove that it isn't.

title: Bush Says His Tax Proposal Will Be Fair for All Incomes
description: President Bush promoted his tax cut proposal today as fair to all Americans and accused opponents of the package of engaging in class warfare.

title: John Cole, 79, Conservationist And Maine Times Co-Founder
description: John Cole, an author, conservationist and co-founder of Maine Times, a spirited weekly newspaper that championed the environment and doggedly kept tabs on state and local government, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home in Brunswick, Me. He was 79.

title: British Chain Plans to Buy Rival Grocer
description: In Europe's biggest supermarket merger since a wave of consolidation three years ago, William Morrison Supermarkets, a regional low-price chain strong in the north of England, said today that it had agreed to buy its bigger and higher-priced southern rival, Safeway P.L.C., for 2.92 billion ($4.7 billion) in stock. Morrison will also assume 1.12 billion ($1.8 billion) in debt.

title: North Korea Says It Is Withdrawing From Arms Treaty
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Jan. 10  Stepping up pressure following an American offer to open talks, North Korea said today it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. The announcement means that, in 90 days, North Korea will no longer be bound by the treaty.

title: LEHMAN BROTHERS TO TAKE $56 MILLION CHARGE
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings said yesterday that it would take a fourth-quarter after-tax charge of $56 million, or 21 cents a share, to pay for a settlement of charges that it misled investors with biased research. Lehman, which announced fourth-quarter earnings in December, said profit would be 23 percent less than originally reported. It will post a profit of $187 million, or 69 cents a share, down from $243 million, or 91 cents. Regulators announced last month a $1.4 billion settlement with 10 of the largest securities firms to resolve conflict-of-interest allegations. The agreement includes a $50 million fine against Lehman, plus a requirement that it spend $25 million to buy independent research for customers and $5 million on investor education.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: John Bradford
description: 55 Mercer Street Gallery

title: Philippine President Signs Economic Reform Bills
description: DAVAO CITY, Philippines, Jan. 10  President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo announced today a set of economic reforms that she said would guide her administration's mission to improve the Philippine economy in the next 18 months. Most of these measures require approval by Congress and they range from raising more revenues to combating corruption.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Driver's License Scheme Alleged
description: Federal prosecutors broadened allegations yesterday against three people charged with fraudulently obtaining driver's licenses for more than 900 illegal immigrants. Prosecutors say two defendants, Rafet Ozoglu of Brooklyn and Mustafa Ozsusamlar of Manhattan, charged clients about $1,500 each for the licenses. They bribed the third person, Gwendolynn Dean, a window clerk in the Department of Motor Vehicles in Washington, D.C., the authorities say. About 75 immigrants, the indictment says, then exchanged their illegally obtained licenses for New York licenses. All three defendants pleaded not guilty in federal court when first charged last year. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Another Kind of Grace Under Pressure
description: ''The Son'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 28, 2002; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Asks Judge to Deny Terror Suspect Access to Lawyer, Saying It Could Harm Interrogation
description: The Bush administration asked a federal judge in New York last night to reverse his decision allowing a Jose Padilla, the man suspected in a plot to detonate a radioactive bomb, access to a lawyer to challenge his detention as an enemy combatant.

title: Sri Lankan Talks End Round Without Major Breakthroughs
description: The Sri Lankan government and the rebel Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam concluded another round of peace talks today in Thailand with an announcement of incremental progress but without the dramatic breakthroughs of previous rounds.

title: Bush Offers a Break if Companies Pay Taxes
description: ONCE upon a time, the corporate income tax produced nearly a quarter of the federal government's revenue. Over the years it was whittled away. Rates came down and companies found a host of ways, some authorized by Congress and some involving clever ways around the law, to avoid the tax.

title: Schools' Internet Subsidies Are Called Fraud-Riddled
description: The $2.25 billion E-Rate program has helped connect thousands of schools and libraries to the Internet, but it may also be enriching unscrupulous contractors, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Carpets That Transcend The Arts-Crafts Border
description: If Islamic knotted-pile carpets rank among the world's great visual furnaces for burning intensity of color, pattern, iconography and texture -- and they do -- then the Textile Museum here should expect a visit from the local fire marshal. Housed in the former mansion of its founder, George Hewitt Myers, this small institution is ablaze with a ravishing and important exhibition of 52 carpets produced over the course of four centuries in Anatolia, the Asian portion of Turkey.

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend last Friday about the folk-art collector Electra Havemeyer Webb misidentified her husband and her father-in-law. Her husband was James Watson Webb Sr.; her father-in-law was William Seward Webb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, THOMAS W.
description: CARR-Thomas W. It is with great sadness that we mourn our dear friend and neighbor, Tom. Our families shared life's joys and sorrows for over 40 years, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to Agnes, John and Louise, Jimmy and Robin, and Pete. We will miss his witty and stimulating discussions and remember him always with great love and affection. Doris O'Connell, Children and Grandchildren

title: For Better and for Worse, Worse, Worse, as the European Honeymoon Gets Hairy
description: ''Just Married,'' which opens today nationwide, could most obviously be described as a romantic comedy. But that's not really a very helpful designation. Ernst Lubitsch's films fit within that category, but so do Freddie Prinze Jr.'s. It may be better to think of this fluffy little doodad as a January movie, as a work, in other words, that is meant to last -- at least until early February, when it will cheerfully fade into oblivion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUREN, CHARLES B.
description: LAUREN-Charles B., 95. Of North Branford, CT, Dorset, VT and formerly of Bronxville, NY, died peacefully on December 31st in North Branford. Beloved husband of the late Priscilla Lauren, father of Cynthia Zellmer of Golden, CO and Clark Lauren of Sarasota, FL, and grandfather of Matthew Zelmer and Wendy Bellas of Denver, CO and Alexandra Lauren of Sarasota, FL. He is also survived by three great - grandchildren. Memorial service will be held at 3 PM, January 11th, at Zion Episcopal Church, Manchester, VT. Donations in his name may be made to Hartwick College, 1 Hartwick Dr., Oneonta, NY 13820.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: MERCK RAISES STAKE Merck & Company won approval to buy the remaining 49 percent of the Banyu Pharmaceutical Company, Japan's eighth-largest drug maker. Merck already holds 51 percent of Banyu, which will become a subsidiary. The MSD (Japan) Company, Merck's Japanese subsidiary, will pay 181.5 billion yen ($1.5 billion) for the outstanding shares, a 30.3 percent premium over Banyu's average share price during the last three months. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: When An Apple Loves A Worm
description: THE look of love beams like a laser from Brian Bedford's eyes in the handsome, absorbing new production of Molire's ''Tartuffe'' that opened last night at the American Airlines Theater. It's that glazed, honeyed gaze found among men who, having surprised themselves by falling in love in their autumn years, have also fallen into a dream. Mr. Bedford's character, a bourgeois gentilhomme named Orgon, looks so happily enchanted that it seems almost a shame that he has to be awakened.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Catholic Group's Frustration
description: The leader of Voice of the Faithful, a Roman Catholic lay group formed in response to the clergy sexual abuse scandal, expressed frustration that after nearly a month as head of the Boston archdiocese, Bishop Richard G. Lennon, has had no contact with the group. James E. Post, president of Voice of the Faithful, said that the organization had repeatedly asked for a meeting and that Bishop Lennon's lack of response raised questions about his stated commitment to reach out to Catholics. A spokeswoman for the diocese, Donna M. Morrissey, said that the bishop had been very busy making the transition to his new job, but that he was ''committed to improving communication and rebuilding trust.'' Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, ISIDORE
description: FALK-Isidore. With love and great sadness, we mourn the passing of Isidore (''Issie'') Falk on January 6, 2003 at age 99. Beloved husband of the late Anne Falk. Cherished father of Serafina (Melvyn), Rebecca (John), Maurice (Judi) and the late Michael (Barbara). Adored grandfather of Nathaniel (Esther), Monica (Ira), Cindy (David), Jessica (Chaim), James, Jeremy, Michelle (William), Leslie, Annie, Harry (Claudia) and Eve. Treasured great grandfather of Elizabeth, David, Emily, Joshua, Harry, Alexander, Sarah, Abigail, Abraham, Simon, Michael and Benjamin. We remember him with love, laughter and admiration. Funeral serviceswere held at at Park East Synagogue on January 8 at 9:30 AM. Shiva will be observed at 188 East 70th Street.

title: After Three Decades, A Noir Classic Opens
description: ''Le Cercle Rouge,'' released in France in 1970, was the 12th of Jean-Pierre Melville's 13 films and, at least in his native land, his biggest popular success. Until now, American audiences have known this doleful, elegant exercise in underworld existentialism mainly through its legend, its influence and the brief circulation of a drastically edited, dubbed version a few years ago. The film's belated arrival, in uncut form, at Film Forum in Manhattan today is thus an exciting and unusual event -- exciting because it provides a chance for total immersion in Melville's stylish, moody noir world, and unusual because, even though the movie has not been seen here before, it offers a curious experience of dj vu.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHANAM, LUCIE (NEE TRINCELLITA)
description: BUCHANAM - Lucie (nee Trincellita), January 8, 2003. 92. Widow of Douglas Charles Buchanan, beloved mother of Douglas, Jane, and the late Charles, grandmother of Nicholas. Formerly of North Bergen, NJ, she resided in Manhattan. Appreciated for her fine and lively mind, and creative spirit, she will be deeply missed. Visiting from 7-9PM on Friday, January 10 and from 10-11AM on Saturday, January 11, Reddens Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZACHER, ISRAEL
description: ZACHER-Israel. Happy 80th in Heaven. So absent, so present. Fly high. Sonia and Family

title: First Europeans Bring a Mystery to New York
description: The first human ancestors to leave Africa, more than 1.7 million years ago, turned east and headed across Asia. For them Europe seemed to hold no attraction for the longest time. Scientists once doubted there were any Europeans at all until about 500,000 years ago.

title: As Trail Leads Back to Newark, Suspect in Boys' Abuse Is Caught
description: A search that went as far as North Carolina ended today when the police found Sherry L. Murphy, suspected in the abuse of three children here, sleeping in the basement apartment of a man she had met three days ago.

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Lawmakers Name New Governor
description: James Douglas, a Republican, was chosen governor after a vote in the Legislature resolved the inconclusive results of the election two months ago. In November, Mr. Douglas received 45 percent of the vote, while Doug Racine, a Democrat, received 42 percent. In Vermont, when no candidate receives more than 50 percent of the vote, the Legislature must choose a winner, and yesterday the Democrat-dominated Senate and the House, narrowly controlled by Republicans, picked Mr. Douglas by a vote of 159 to 16. Pam Belluck (NYT)

The MSD (Japan) Company, Merck's Japanese subsidiary, will pay 181.5 billion yen ($1.5 billion) for the outstanding shares, a 30.3 percent premium over Banyu's average share price during the last three months.   Ken Belson (NYT)

description: Sheldon S. Leffler, the former city councilman who represented northeastern Queens for 24 years, has been indicted on charges of using illegal fund-raising tactics during his failed 2001 campaign for Queens borough president, prosecutors said yesterday.

description: Fredericks Freiser

title: The Roots of Afrikaner Rage
description: These were places black people were forbidden to go,'' my mother says as we near the restaurant in an upmarket Cape Town shopping mall. ''And now we can come to the same places as whites, walk into a cafe, and pay the same money -- just like that.''

description: It's easy to see why Natalie hasn't spoken to her brother, Roy, for 10 years. He's a monster.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: A RETIREMENT AT BP BP said its deputy chief executive, Rodney Chase, left, would retire on April 23, ending 38 years at the company. Mr. Chase, 59, will give up his duties as deputy chief executive immediately, BP said, though he will remain on the board and as an adviser to Lord Browne, the chief executive, until his departure in April. Richard Olver, 56, will succeed Mr. Chase as deputy chief executive. He most recently ran the exploration and production division.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, ALYSSA AMELIA
description: ROBBINS-Alyssa Amelia. Of New York City. Born September 10, 1975 in Atlanta, GA, passed away January 2, 2003. She was a contemporary folksinger/songwriter, a writer, an artist, and a teacher. She was loved by many friends and relations in particular her partner, Jeffrey Akers, her mother Carolyn A. Ristau, her father Donald Robbins, her older brother, Christopher W. Robbins and her younger brother Daniel J. Robbins. Memorial services will be held at the Little Neck Community Church, 46-16 Little Neck Parkway, Queens, NYC on Saturday, January 11, 2003 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, the family's preference is that donations be made in her memory to Farm and Wilderness, Plymouth, VT 05056. Website: www.fandw.org. She will always be in our hearts.

title: Jets' Special Teams, Among the Elite, Fuel Up for Raiders
description: The phone rang early in Mike Westhoff's office this morning. It was Dolphins linebacker Zach Thomas, calling to tell the coach who scouted him as a potential special-teams player that he was rooting for the Jets.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about plans by AT&T to eliminate 3,500 jobs referred incorrectly to the company's plans to use systems from Covad Communications Group Inc. to provide high-speed Internet access. Limited areas of California, New York and Texas are the sole places where the systems will not be used -- not where they will be.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: The Round Table That Wasn't
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's campaign team declined to participate in a round-table discussion of the 2002 governor's race at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University, causing the school to cancel the Jan. 24 event, its organizers said yesterday. The round table was intended to be a candid discussion among campaign strategists, top advisers and journalists. Campaign managers for H. Carl McCall, the Democratic nominee; Andrew M. Cuomo, his challenger in the primary, who later dropped out of the race; and Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate, had agreed to attend the event, the brainchild of Fred P. Hochberg, a former member of the Clinton administration who serves on the school's advisory council. Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, said, ''The elections are over and our focus is on moving forward.'' Mr. Hochberg said he did not see any way to proceed without the victors. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: A Bad Joke, Resembling A Bad Penny
description: JOSEPH LOCURTO is a former New York City police officer who fancied himself a splendid wit. The Police Department agreed, but only if ''wit'' came with a prefix like ''half,'' ''dim'' or ''nit.'' It decided that Mr. Locurto was a man of demonstrably defective judgment and should not be running around the streets of New York with a badge, a gun and a license to shoot. And so it fired him.

title: One Boy's Golden Age of Radio
description: WHO knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men? Until a few months ago I would have been pretty sure that the answer was either Tony Soprano's psychiatrist, Dr. Melfi, or the editorial staff of the magazine Maxim. In fact, the correct response is the Shadow, according to those old enough to have tuned in during the golden age of radio drama (Hey there, Aunt Dorothy), and to my 11-year-old son, Matthew, an impassioned fan of 30's and 40's ear candy.

title: SIX MONTHS LATER, NEW AUDIT BOARD HOLDS FIRST TALK
description: Six months after it was created by Congress, the new board overseeing the accounting profession -- the centerpiece of reform legislation after a year of corporate scandal -- held its first formal meeting today without a permanent chairman, a senior staff or a final budget.

title: Panel Suggests Splitting Roles At Companies
description: Executives must give corporate boards more independence if they are to regain the trust of investors, a panel of financial leaders said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Ban On Torture Rejected
description: The Guardian Council rejected for a third time a bill approved by the reformist Parliament that would ban torture of prisoners. Legislators will have to make further amendments to satisfy the watchdog panel or the bill will be sent to the Expediency Council for arbitration. Many prisoners have complained that confessions were extracted from them under duress. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Merck Raises Stake
description: Merck & Company won approval to buy the remaining 49 percent of the Banyu Pharmaceutical Company, Japan's eighth-largest drug maker. Merck already holds 51 percent of Banyu, which will become a subsidiary. The MSD (Japan) Company, Merck's Japanese subsidiary, will pay 181.5 billion yen ($1.5 billion) for the outstanding shares, a 30.3 percent premium over Banyu's average share price during the last three months. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Danny Kaye Hit Becomes a Russian Music Survey
description: It takes a comic spark plug touched with brilliance to pull off the kind of tour de force that the maniacally exuberant singer, pianist and cutup Mark Nadler has brought (through Jan. 25) to the Firebird Upstairs Supper Club, the opulent new cabaret atop the Firebird restaurant at 365 West 46th Street. In keeping with the club's jewel-box dcor and rich Russian cuisine, Mr. Nadler is performing his one-man show, ''Tchaikowsky (and Other Russians),'' a zany tutorial in modern Russian music spun off from one of the greatest patter songs ever written.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: COMPUWARE LOWERS EARNINGS ESTIMATE Shares of the Compuware Corporation fell about 8 percent yesterday after Compuware, a software products and services concern, said its third-quarter earnings would be below Wall Street expectations. Compuware now expects to earn 6 to 7 cents a share for the fiscal third quarter; analysts were expecting a profit of 9 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter, ended Dec. 31, will be $318 million to $327 million, the company said. Compuware will announce its final results for the quarter on Jan. 22. The company said it expected new software license revenue to range from $70 million to $73 million and maintenance revenue from about $98 million to $100 million. Compuware said it experienced strong operating cash flow of about $70 million in the quarter.   (AP)

title: The Right Tax Plan for Today and Tomorrow
description: President Bush has proposed a set of tax reforms that will give a quick lift to the economy and make for long-term improvements in our tax system. Critics argue that the plan is merely an effort by the president to exhibit concern about the economy (and to avoid the fate of his father). Such charges are baseless. The president's bold plan reflects the ideas that have long been central to his tax policy.

title: The President Of the L.I.R.R. To Step Down
description: Kenneth Bauer, the president of the Long Island Rail Road, who was known for taking groups of commuters to dinner to hear their concerns, announced yesterday that he would retire after a 30-year career with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the railroad, a spokesman for the railroad said. Mr. Bauer was the railroad's president for nearly three years.

description: The Chinese often say students are the conscience of the nation. If so, the nation must be unusually concerned about traffic safety these days.

description: BERMAN - Lois. Beloved bride of David Berman for 56 years, passed January 9, 2003. Born in Peabody, MA, she graduated from Salem State Teachers College. She served in the Red Cross in the Pacific during W.W. II. After the war, she moved and married in New York and started a successful literary agency. She retired in 1994. She shall be missed.

Popular will buy the stake from a Portuguese investor, Amrico Amorim, in exchange for a 4.5 percent stake in Popular, Spain's third-biggest bank, Popular said.

The industrial explosion that killed him, they agreed, was the result of reckless criminal conduct by his employer, McWane Inc., the Alabama conglomerate that owns a cast-iron foundry here in upstate New York.

Thousands of his countrymen lined the docks of the Viaduct Basin that day, roaring for their skipper and his triumphant crew.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Four Priests Under Review
description: A review board for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson has determined that sexual misconduct allegations against four priests, whose cases cannot be pursued by civil authorities, are credible and should be pursued by a church court. The sexual abuse charges against the priests -- Msgr. John Derricks, the Revs. James A. D. Smith, Ralph Sodano and Alan Stepien -- have been referred to a diocesan official. Some of the allegations date back 50 years and could not be prosecuted because of the statute of limitations, a spokeswoman for the diocese said. A lawyer representing Monsignor Derricks, Father Sodano and Father Stepien did not immediately return a call for comment. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Aid Worker Freed In Chechnya
description: The director of a Russian aid organization who was kidnapped in July in Chechnya was freed in a raid by security officers. Nina Davidovich, 57, head of Druzhba (Friendship), was kidnapped in Gorogorsky, prompting the United Nations to suspend relief operations there for several weeks. She said at a news conference in Chechnya that she had been held captive in a pit, with one leg shackled. Her captors demanded $1 million for her release, but the regional chief of the Federal Security Services, Oleg Dukanov, said no ransom was paid. He did not say if her kidnappers were captured. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: U.S. Holds Man Identified as False Tipster

description: The Police Department will flood crime-ridden neighborhoods, subway stops and housing projects with 1,400 police officers fresh from the Police Academy later this month, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday.

description: The White House announced today that President Bush will nominate Roger F. Noriega, the United States representative to the Organization of American States, to be assistant secretary of state for Western Hemisphere affairs, the most senior diplomat for Latin America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, GERSHON
description: STERN-Gershon. The Yeshiva University family and Canadian Friends of Yeshiva University are deeply grieved by the passing of our beloved, longtime friend and distinguished leader who for more than 25 years was a member of the YU Board of Trustees. He also served as National President of Canadian Friends of Yeshiva University and was currently Honorary National President. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Sy Syms School of Business (SSSB) where he and his wife, Merle, YU Benefactors, established the Gershon and Merle Stern Chair in Banking and Finance. He served as a past member of the Board of Trustees of YU's affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS). An alumnus of Yeshiva College, he also received an honorary degree from YU in 1984. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Merle and their children: Sharon (and William) Hyman, Judy (and David) Lobel, Jonathan (and Kris) Stern, brother Zalman (and Barbara) Stern, and grandchildren: Caroline, Alexandra, Andrew, and Zachary. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees Bernard L. Madoff, Chairman SSSB Board of Directors

title: Hispanic Treasures, Awaiting Discovery
description: THE Hispanic Society of America, lonely up at 155th Street and Broadway in Washington Heights and tired of having a world-class art collection that almost nobody sees, has found one solution: send the work where the audience is. So in March the museum is lending seven prize paintings, including two El Grecos and a Velzquez, to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for a show examining the effect of Spanish painting on French artists. In September the society plans to exhibit prints and drawings based on the Don Quixote story at the Prado in Madrid.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BULGARIA: COURT DELAYS CLOSING OF REACTORS A top court overruled a government accord with the European Union that would have closed two Soviet-era nuclear reactors by 2006. Bulgaria agreed to a European Union demand to shut the No. 3 and No. 4 reactors at the Kozlodui power plant to avoid derailing accession talks last year. Ruling on an appeal brought by the opposition Socialist Party, the Supreme Administrative Court said the agreement ignored a vote in Parliament that the reactors should be kept on line until Bulgaria's entry into the European Union, planned for 2007. Brussels wants the reactors shut in 2006 for safety reasons, despite the fact that the plant produces half of Bulgaria's electricity. The government is likely to appeal the decision. The No. 1 and No. 2 reactors were closed in late December. (Reuters)

title: The Iraq Dossier
description: International arms inspectors told the Security Council yesterday that they had not yet found any ''smoking gun'' proving Saddam Hussein's continued manufacture of unconventional weapons. That increases pressure on the Bush administration to share more of what it knows about the state of Iraq's biological, chemical, nuclear and missile programs. Less than three weeks remain until Jan. 27, when the inspectors are to provide a more comprehensive report. If Washington hopes to persuade the world and the American people that Baghdad has forfeited its chance for a peaceful solution, it will need compelling evidence to support its case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHURCHWELL, GORDON LEE
description: CHURCHWELL - Gordon Lee, 44. In Cold Spring, NY, on January 8. Beloved husband of Julie Metz and adoring father of daughter Olivia Ella. Son of Gordon and CC. Churchwell, brother of John, Soonhi, Bong-Eui and YongEui. Uncle of Hyun Joo, nieces and nephews. Author of Harper Collins' ''Expecting'' and the work in progress ''The Umami Trail'' for Bloomsbury. Close and loyal friend to many, creator of magnificent meals, generous, life loving and always exuberant. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. A wake will be held Saturday, January 11th, 2-5PM, at the Clinton Funeral Home in Cold Spring, NY. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, January 12th at the First Presbyterian Church, 10 Academy Street in Cold Spring from 2-4PM. The family requests that in lieu of flowers a donation be madeto The Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Ave., NYC 10017.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Nuclear Plant Report Due Soon
description: A long-awaited draft report on the effectiveness of evacuation plans for the Indian Point nuclear plant may be released as early as today, officials from Gov. George E. Pataki's administration said yesterday. The state's emergency management office received the report in mid-December but has not yet made it public, upsetting environmentalists and some public officials. Pataki officials said the delay was caused by factual errors in the first draft. The report, by James Lee Witt, a former director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, was commissioned by Mr. Pataki last year to determine whether nearby communities could be evacuated or protected in a terrorist attack or other disaster. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Moscow Journal; Minus 4 on Mean Streets: Nonpersons Are Dying

title: American Nurse Released From Indonesian Prison
description: Banda Aceh, Indonesia, Jan. 10 — Joy Lee Sadler, an American nurse who came to this tropical strife-torn territory as a sort of freelance Florence Nightingale, was released from prison today after being convicted by the Indonesian authorities for contacting separatist rebels.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Charges In Rape And Robbery Spree
description: A salesman for an advertising company was charged yesterday in a three-month crime spree in which he is accused of robbing nine stores in Bergen County at gunpoint, tying up and raping three clerks, groping one clerk and beating two others, the authorities said. The crimes occurred between Oct. 10 and Jan. 6. The Bergen County prosecutor, John L. Molinelli, said the arrest had ended an extensive manhunt. The salesman, Charles A. Rawlings, 43, of Lodi, was arrested on Wednesday as he left a bank in Garfield, shortly after the state police lab matched his DNA with DNA from a semen sample from a rape, Mr. Molinelli said. Mr. Rawlings was ordered held in bail of $2 million. He is scheduled to appear in State Superior Court today. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Sidecars: Family Transport And More
description: THREE years ago, Steve Diaz, now 44, knew things had to change. Mr. Diaz, who lives in Orange Grove, Calif., and restores Jaguars for a living, was a lifelong motorcyclist -- and so was his wife, Annette, now 34, whom he had met at a motorcycle rally. They wanted to continue riding on weekends, but they had young children and didn't like leaving them behind. So Mr. Diaz did what quite a few aging Easy Riders are doing these days -- he piled everyone onto a motorcycle with a sidecar.

title: National Briefing: New England

In November, Mr. Douglas received 45 percent of the vote, while Doug Racine, a Democrat, received 42 percent. description: Magazine advertising in 2002 ended on a high note as ad pages showed their largest gain of the year in December, the second consecutive month of growth, the Publishers Information Bureau said yesterday.

title: 2 Decades After Stabbing, Man Dies From Wounds
description: In 1981, Charles Boccaleri was stabbed in the West Village.

title: EASTMAN CHEMICAL WILL HAVE LOSS IN 4TH QUARTER
description: Eastman Chemical, a producer of plastics used in soda bottles, said yesterday that it had a fourth-quarter loss because sales declined while it reorganized operations. The loss was 10 to 20 cents a share, compared with a loss of $1.20 a year earlier, the company said. The loss included 7 to 9 cents a share for reorganization costs and write-downs. The loss widened after operations were slowed to fix broken equipment at a plant in Columbia, S.C. Higher costs for a long-term disability plan and for writing down assets and equipment costs also added to the loss. Shares of Eastman fell $1.07, or 2.8 percent, to $37.10.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Retirement At BP
description: BP said its deputy chief executive, Rodney Chase, left, would retire on April 23, ending 38 years at the company. Mr. Chase, 59, will give up his duties as deputy chief executive immediately, BP said, though he will remain on the board and as an adviser to Lord Browne, the chief executive, until his departure in April. Richard Olver, 56, will succeed Mr. Chase as deputy chief executive. He most recently ran the exploration and production division. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Art Listings
description: Aselective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: VOLKSWAGEN INVESTMENT Volkswagen has picked its Puebla, Mexico, plant to make the new Bora model for the European market, said Reinhard Jung, president of Volkswagen Mexico. The company plans to invest $2 billion in the plant in the next five years, including $180 million on the Bora line, and add 1,500 jobs. Mr. Jung said 4,000 to 5,000 jobs would be created among local suppliers. The car's production will begin in 2005 with 100,000 units a year.

title: Why City Transit Workers Should Reject the Contract
description: Most New Yorkers, including most transit workers, were relieved on Dec. 16 at word that a tentative agreement had been reached between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union. None of us, whether we work on the buses and subways or simply ride them, were eager for the hardships that a strike would cause.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: There are a couple of ways to think of the new cafe at Pico, John Villa's romantic, Portuguese-inspired restaurant in TriBeCa. Depending on your interests, it's either a discounted ticket to Mr. Villa's kitchen or a sly excuse to gain access to his wine list and his desserts, especially the famous little doughnuts, called sonhos, that come with fruit dipping sauces.

title: Residential Real Estate; Hope Rises on a Desolate Bronx Lot
description: A Z-shaped lot in East Tremont that had been vacant and weed-strewn for the last dozen years is undergoing a transformation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 25 about federal appeals courts' rules against citing one-time rulings as precedent misstated the date for the end of such a restriction in the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the policy of the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The District of Columbia restriction ended on Jan. 1, 2002, not 2003. The First Circuit eased its restriction on Dec. 16; the change was not still pending.

title: North Korea Assailed for Withdrawing From Arms Treaty
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 10  North Korea announced today that it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, a decision that set off a flurry of diplomatic activity and condemnation.

title: Into the Wilderness, With Skis and a Diaper Bag
description: BACKCOUNTRY skiing, the do-it-yourself approach to ascending and descending snow-covered mountains, isn't for amateurs. The ski patrol isn't there to bail you out of trouble if you get lost or hurt, and the threat of an avalanche, like the one that killed a wilderness skier on Crystal Mountain, Wash., late last month, is omnipresent.

title: F.D.A. DELAYS RULING ON ASTRAZENECA CANCER TREATMENT
description: AstraZeneca said yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration had delayed a decision on the cancer treatment Iressa while it reviewed the safety of the product. The treatment, which is intended to have fewer side effects than traditional chemotherapy, has been linked to more than 80 deaths in Japan. The F.D.A. said it expected to complete the review by May 5, instead of Feb. 5, as originally planned, a company spokeswoman said. AstraZeneca once hoped to introduce the medicine in the United States in 2002.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Trespassing Complaint In Tree Case
description: Life got tougher for John Quigley, a protester who has spent 70 days in a 400-year-old oak tree near Santa Clarita. A developer who wants to move the tree to make way for a road served him with a trespassing complaint and closed off a wider area around the tree. The move isolates Mr. Quigley from volunteers providing him with food and supplies. The developer, John Laing Homes, said he wanted to make the situation safer while allowing the issue to be handled in the courts. Mr. Quigley was to have been replaced by a new tree sitter on Thursday, but has now resolved to stay longer. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: U.S. Transportation Leader Acts To Stop Screeners' Union Effort
description: The leader of the Transportation Security Administration took action today to block an effort to unionize 56,000 federal screeners at airports, saying collective bargaining for them was ''not compatible'' with the fight against terrorism.

title: The Veil Lifts on a Classic
description: An uncut version of the 1970 French heist movie ''Le Cercle Rouge,'' written and directed by Jean-Pierre Melville, is getting its first American showing, starting today at Film Forum in Manhattan. Yves Montand plays an alcoholic former policeman, recruited to help rob a jewelry store. Alain Delon (above right, with Jean-Pierre Janic) is a doleful hoodlum, one of the accomplices. But the greatest risk, in this existential shadow-world, is to form a connection with someone else.

title: Jewish Experience, Lived and Recalled
description: ''Why does a Jew always answer a question with a question?'' my Jewish grandfather (and not only mine, I'm sure), liked to ask. The response, of course, was ''Why not?'' The 12th Annual New York Jewish Film Festival, which starts on Sunday and runs through Jan. 23, suggests a similar exchange. What exactly is a Jewish film? The best response might be: What isn't?

title: Two City Assembly Seats Open Up, but Successors Seem All Set
description: The recent resignations of two members of the State Assembly have left two Democratic seats open, and in both cases the successors have been all but selected, according to politicians in the two boroughs.

title: Israel's High Court Reinstates Candidacy of 2 Israeli Arabs
description: Israel's Supreme Court restored the candidacy of two Israeli Arab legislators today, overturning a ban that had stirred resentment among the country's Arab minority and prompted a debate about the country's identity.

title: Detaining 'Enemy Combatants'
description: A federal appeals court in Virginia ruled this week that Americans who are labeled ''enemy combatants'' can be held indefinitely without access to a lawyer. The court is correct that soldiers on the battlefield do not have the same rights as ordinary criminal suspects. But this ruling, in the case of a man held on American soil for months, gives the government too much power to imprison citizens, and offers too few protections. The Supreme Court should develop a better set of standards.

title: Skipping Ads? TV Gets Ready To Fight Back
description: A leading television producer and two major advertisers have joined forces to present a live variety show with no commercial interruptions. Instead, the advertising messages will be incorporated into the show.

description: A Box Office Like an Icebox

title: Memoir Deal Reported for Justice Thomas
description: Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas has agreed to sell HarperCollins the rights to publish the memoir of his rise from poverty for an advance of $1.5 million, people involved in the auction said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELDER, BARBARA JEAN (HAWKINS)
description: ELDER-Barbara Jean (Hawkins). January 4, 2003. 73 years of age, of Manhattan. Originally from Portland, OR. A veteran of the Korean War, US Army Nurse Corps. She is survived by her husband of 45 years George, her children Scott, Janet and John and two grandchildren, William and Sierra. There will be a memorial service Sunday, January 12, 4 PM at First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at 12th St, NYC.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 10 — North Korea set off a flurry of diplomatic activity and condemnation Friday when it announced it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

title: Sharon Snubs Blair's Request to Let Palestinians Go to London
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel has rebuffed Prime Minister Tony Blair's personal appeal to reconsider Israel's decision to keep Palestinian negotiators from attending a British-sponsored conference in London next week, officials said today.

title: McNair Hurts, Reflects, Wins
description: It was the middle of the 1999 season and Steve McNair did not know it, but he would eventually land in the Super Bowl in what was his fifth pro year. McNair settled in at his Tennessee Titans locker to prepare for the day and saw a package. Must be important, he thought. After all, someone had taken the time to send it overnight.

title: Authorities Say L.I. Psychiatrist Told Patient Of Plot to Kill 6
description: It started unfolding inside a psychiatrist's office in a small brick office building here: one man confided to another that he wanted to kill as many as six people, then drop their dismembered bodies in the Atlantic Ocean, the authorities said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, GEORGINE
description: CHASE-Georgine. Died January 8th, 2003. Beloved mother of Bari Chase and Daniel Kalin. Devoted grandmother of Skylar. Loving wife of the late Joseph Chase. Cherished sister of Marian and Martin Abbey. Wonderful aunt of Mark Abbey. Services Friday, 11:15, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: G.M. Warns of $2 Billion in Added Expenses From Pensions
description: General Motors said today that expenses related to its pension plan would triple from $1 billion to nearly $3 billion this year. As a result, the company said, its operating earnings would fall about 25 percent from last year, to $5 a share.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAN: BAN ON TORTURE REJECTED The Guardian Council rejected for a third time a bill approved by the reformist Parliament that would ban torture of prisoners. Legislators will have to make further amendments to satisfy the watchdog panel or the bill will be sent to the Expediency Council for arbitration. Many prisoners have complained that confessions were extracted from them under duress. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: The Secret War on Condoms
description: Three thousand years ago an amorous Egyptian couple (probably libidinous liberals) experimented with a linen pouch, producing the world's first known condom. Some right-wingers still haven't gotten over it.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurance Merger Is Abandoned
description: Asahi Mutual Life Insurance, one of Japan's weakest life insurers, will abandon its plan to join Millea Holdings, The Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported. Asahi was due to join Millea, which includes the Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company and the Nichido Fire and Marine Insurance Company, by 2004, but it was unlikely to gain the needed approval of its policyholders to convert into a joint stock company. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Loss At Water Company
description: The world's secondlargest water company, Suez, posted its first loss ever in 2002 and said that it would introduce new measures to reduce debt by one-third. Suez, a French utility, said its net loss was about 900 million euros ($944.6 million) in 2002, in contrast with a profit of 2.1 billion euros the year before. The company wrote off 1.3 billion euros to cover losses in places like Argentina and a drop in the value of its shares in AXA and TotalFinaElf. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A television review last Friday about ''The Crooked E: The Unshredded Truth About Enron'' misattributed an error in the hiring date given for Brian Cruver, the former Enron employee on whose book the film was based. The error originated with the filmmakers, not in his book.

title: A Family Collection, Flavored by a Taste for Drawing
description: It was no surprise to anyone that Robert Lehman (1891-1969) became a world-class collector of world-class art. He learned the sport at his father's knee. The elder Lehman, Philip, a partner in the investment banking house of Lehman Brothers, which his father helped to establish, assembled a renowned collection of Western European masterpieces, of which his son became the unofficial curator.

title: North Korea Opens Unofficial Channel for U.S. Talks
description: Two North Korean diplomats met here tonight with the governor of New Mexico, Bill Richardson, in an unexpected initiative by North Korea to open communications with Washington about its nuclear confrontation with the United States.

title: Full Text: North Korea's Statement of Withdrawal
description: Following is the text of the North Korean government's statement yesterday on its withdrawal from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, as provided by the official Korean Central News Agency.

title: SCHERING SAYS '02 EARNINGS ARE SHORT OF FORECAST
description: Schering-Plough said yesterday that 2002 profit was $1.40 to $1.42 a share, below estimates, because of declining sales for its Claritin allergy medication. The company said earlier that it expected to earn $1.58 a share. It had profit of 27 to 29 cents in the fourth quarter, below the 44-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Schering-Plough won approval in November to begin selling a version of Claritin without a doctor's prescription after losing a battle to prevent generic versions from reaching the market. Shares of Schering-Plough rose 19 cents, to $23.06.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, THOMAS HUNT
description: WYMAN-Thomas Hunt. Of Cambridge, after a brief illness January 8, 2003. Beloved husband of Deborah (Little) Wyman. Loving father of Peter Wyman of CT, Michael Wyman of IL, Thomas H. Wyman Jr. of CA, and Elizabeth Cordle of NH. Cherished brother of Betty Caspari and Mary Hunt, both of MO, and Sally Slack of NC. Also survived by eight dear grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. Funeral from the J.S. Waterman & SonsEastman - Waring Funeral Home, 495 Commonwealth Ave. (at Kenmore Sq.), Boston on Monday, January 13 at 9am, followed by a funeral service to be held in The Emmanuel Church of Boston, 15 Newbury St., at 10AM. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend and may call at the funeral home on Sunday, January 12, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Interment in Mt. Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge. Late President and CEO for CBS Television and late member of the Country Club of Brookline and The Charles River Yacht Club of Cambridge. Memorial donations may be made to the Ecclesia Ministries, 35 Bowden St., Boston, MA 02114. Visit www.mem.com for pictorial memorial.

description: THOMAS-George M. You are always in our thoughts and greatly missed. Our love, Bernice, Joan, Edward, Philip and families.

title: Radical Islamists a Threat to Southeast Asia Even if Al Qaeda Is Eliminated, Singapore Says
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 9  Even if the United States is successful in dismantling Al Qaeda, radical Islamic groups in Southeast Asia will be capable of further terrorist acts like the recent one in Bali, the Singaporean government said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAPORTA, HY
description: SAPORTA-Hy. January 10th, 2000. Your family is growing. Joining David, Evan and Ethan we welcome Cole, Amanda and Harrison Scott named in your beloved memory. We think of you daily and miss you so much. Your Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLICK, PHILIP
description: CLICK-Philip. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Queens Borough Public Library mourn the passing of a dear friend and colleague. He was a tireless advocate for literacy and strengthened Queens Library with his wisdom and leadership. He served as a library Trustee from 1973 until his death and was Board President in 1983 and 1984. He will be deeply missed. Our deepest condolences to his family. George Stamatiades, Pres. Queens Library Board Gary E. Strong, Library Dir. and the Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITCHEL, RUTH. (NEE GOODMAN)
description: Witchel-Ruth. (nee Goodman) on January 4, 2003. Ruth has left us to join her beloved Jess. A dedicated elementary school teacher, Ruth was as well an exlemplary mother and mother-inlaw, an excellent cook, a fine knitter and superb grandmother. She will be cherished and missed by her son Carl, her daughter-in-law Lucie Rodrigue, her two grandsons Alexandre and Simon Rodrigue-Witchel, her loving sister Hannah Stern as well as family and many friends. Services Sunday 11:15 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment to follow at Mt. Judah Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: Top Official In Cicero, Ill., Gets 8 Years In Fund Theft
description: Nearly two years after federal officials declared the Cicero ''candy store'' officially closed, Betty Loren-Maltese, the former town president, was sentenced today to eight years and one month in prison for helping steal $12 million from a municipal insurance fund.

description: With that $300,000 Maybach from Mercedes-Benz on order, you might want to consider a $5,000 wax job to keep it looking tiptop.

description: VOUTSAS-George, 91. On January 2, 2003, in Carmel, CA. Director and producer for NBC Monitor, Toscanini's NBC Symphony Orchestra, and Glen Miller's Band during W.W. II. Survived by his wife Margery Mayer Voutsas, brother Diamond Cooper, sons Christopher and Gregory, daughter Alexandra Kornriech, and six grandchildren.

description: Five Massachusetts students filed a lawsuit in federal court today challenging the constitutionality of military registration because it requires that only men register, and not women.

description: In 1981, when Georgina Forlano discovered that her boyfriend was using heroin, they split up. She did not want him in her house or around her three children.

title: TENET HEALTHCARE REFINANCES $500 MILLION IN LOANS
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that it had refinanced $500 million in loans with three banks at a lower interest rate. The agreement to replace a $500 million revolving credit line due Feb. 28 will be used to reduce debt from a $1.5 billion revolving credit line due in 2006, the company said. Banc of America Securities, Citigroup and SunTrust Banks arranged the three-year loan.

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: New Move In Range War
description: A 30-year range war between the federal government and two elderly Western Shoshone Indian sisters reached a new stage when Bureau of Land Management officials said they were planning to round up more than 800 non-branded horses that belong to the women, Mary and Carrie Dann. The women are grazing their livestock on public lands without a permit, but they contend they do not need one since their ancestors never signed papers ceding the territory to the government. Late last year, bureau agents confiscated 227 cattle belonging to the sisters and fined them $3 million for willful trespass. Carrie Dann, above, said she and her sister were weary of the fight. ''We're old,'' she said. ''If we were young men, we'd show them a trick or two.'' Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

title: U.S. Official to Discuss Trade; Africa Hopes to Discuss AIDS
description: When Ambassador Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, travels to southern Africa next week, new free trade agreements will take up most of his agenda.

title: In McNabb And Vick, Quarterbacks Who Do It All
description: They have known each other for years, ever since Michael Vick showed up for a recruiting visit at Syracuse and was chaperoned by Donovan McNabb to a basketball game and dinner. Vick chose Virginia Tech, but the two quarterbacks stayed in touch.

title: NBC President To Take Over At Sony Music
description: The Sony Corporation of America announced today that it had appointed an outsider, Andrew Lack, the executive who rebuilt the NBC News division, to help save its faltering music operation.

title: Cowboys Hire Giants' Payton As the Quarterbacks Coach
description: Under normal circumstances, Giants General Manager Ernie Accorsi would not allow an assistant coach under contract to join a rival team. But as Sean Payton, the Giants' offensive coordinator, took a job as quarterbacks coach with the Dallas Cowboys yesterday, Accorsi said it was fair and equitable to let it happen.

Former Adelphia Executive Enters a Guilty Plea
description: The former director of accounting at Adelphia Communications pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal charges stemming from the $2.5 billion accounting scandal that pushed the company into bankruptcy.

title: Supreme Court to Review Nike Case in Major Look at Free Speech Rights of Companies
description: The Supreme Court, accepting its most important case in years on the free speech rights of companies, agreed today to review a California decision holding Nike potentially liable for damages for any false or misleading statements it makes in defense of its overseas business practices.

title: Venezuela Crisis Complicates Iraq Situation, Experts Say
description: The crisis in Venezuela is creating major new complications for the Bush administration's campaign to oust President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, causing oil shortages that would probably make a Persian Gulf war more costly to the economy than once anticipated, American officials and industry experts said.

title: STATE BUDGET GAP PUT AT $10 BILLION
description: With December tax collections more dismal than anticipated and the state falling short in attempts to reduce its work force, New York now has a budget gap far larger than the Pataki administration had forecast, a high-ranking administration official said today.

title: Korea Crisis: Same Song, Second Verse
description: If everything about the North Korean nuclear crisis has a familiar ring to it, it's because the North Koreans have followed a script they wrote in 1993 and 1994. But this time, they are reading the lines a lot faster.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cable And Wireless Executive
description: Cable and Wireless said it had named Richard D. Lapthorne, a medical diagnostics executive, as its nonexecutive chairman. Mr. Lapthorne, who said he planned to retire as the chairman of the medical diagnostics company Amersham in May, will assume his new duties at Cable and Wireless immediately. Cable and Wireless has been searching for a new chairman since November, when its chairman-elect, David Nash, said he would not succeed its departing chairman, Sir Ralph Robins. Analysts said the appointment of Mr. Lapthorne could place new pressure on Graham Wallace, the chief executive, who has been trying to salvage a costly expansion into data services. In November, Cable and Wireless acknowledged that overhauling its data services division would cost more than anticipated. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Religion Journal; Asking Whether God Has a Rooting Interest
description: In the first moments after victory, many professional athletes stand at center court, or under stadium lighting or in the middle of the boxing ring and thank God. Sometimes, before the game is over, they point to the heavens to acknowledge a particularly good play.

title: Double-Dealing, 1930's Style, From a Historic Match
description: It is not a misprint. For the first time in the history of this department, there is, literally, double-dealing. West was the designated dealer, but North dealt out of turn.

description: Following are excerpts from the North Korean government's statement yesterday, as provided by the official Korean Central News Agency. The full text can be found online at nytimes.com/international.

title: Dispute on Drug Testing Is Settled
description: The American and world governing bodies of track and field have argued bitterly over the Americans' refusal to disclose the names of a handful of athletes who failed at least parts of drug tests between 1996 and 2000. Yesterday, the dispute ended in more or less a draw.

title: Wanted: Right Buyer for a Japanese Bank
description: Few areas of Japan's notoriously opaque business world are murkier than banking. Tangled webs of corporate partnerships, heavy government influence and sheer resistance to change make it one of the country's most impenetrable industries, especially for foreigners.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 16 about the economy in the Southeast included an erroneous reference to a study of the economic impact of a BMW auto plant in South Carolina. The study, by the Moore School of Business at the University of South Carolina in 2002, showed that BMW's investment supported 16,691 jobs and produced $691 million in annual wages and salaries in South Carolina. The study did not examine the benefits to North Carolina and did not show that North Carolina received more jobs and contracts for auto suppliers than South Carolina received.

title: Police Layoffs Are Possible, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged yesterday that for the first time in nearly 30 years the city might have to lay off police officers to help balance the budget.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Tracking Down Fugitives
description: The Detroit Police Department will begin a 60-day sweep of the city to hunt down some of an estimated 20,000 fugitives, Deputy Chief Harold Cureton said. The effort, which follows accusations that the city had ignored the problem, is a partnership between the department and the sheriff's office in Wayne County. Thirty-three officers will scour the city for criminal suspects, parole violators and escapees who were arraigned and released and later failed to show up for trial. Anand Giridharadas (NYT)

title: Els Isn't Taking It Easy, Surging to a 36-Hole Record
description: Ernie Els may be in a great vacation spot, but he is taking care of business on the golf course.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Trial Set For Terror Suspects
description: Judicial officials said the trial of 19 suspected members of the November 17 terrorist group would start on March 3. Most of the accused, who include a 40-year-old banker arrested on Thursday, face multiple counts of murder and other charges linked to the organization's campaign of bombings, drive-by shootings and bank robberies dating to 1975, including the killing of a C.I.A. Athens station chief. Most of the accused have confessed to their involvement, facing life sentences if found guilty for more than one murder. Greece has abolished the death penalty. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Greece Enters Europe's Spotlight Under Skeptical Eyes
description: In 1983, when Greece first held the presidency of what was then simply the European Community, it riled other member nations by blocking the group from condemning the Soviet Union for shooting down a South Korean airliner.

title: Upper East Side Journal; A Test That Gives the Jitters Even to the Best and Brightest
description: Gladys Cruz crossed her left leg over her right. A moment later, the right one went over the left. The foot on the ground tapped; the one in the air jiggled. Her eyes stared at a blank wall, and she nibbled at her lip. On the auditorium seat next to her sat a chaste romance novel in a plastic bag, its pages unruffled, though she had bought it precisely to help her endure this agonizing wait.

title: College Leaders' Spouses Gain Salaries as Partners
description: When the University of Toronto recruited Robert Birgeneau to become its president two years ago, leaving behind his dean's post at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, board members approached his wife as well. Like most other boards, they hoped she would work alongside her husband promoting the university. But departing from tradition, they were willing to pay her.

title: Retail Consultant Says Kmart Will Seek to Close 312 Stores
description: The Kmart Corporation is expected to file a plan with the United States Bankruptcy Court next week seeking to close at least 312 stores, a retail consultant said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The dollar fell to its lowest level since November 1999 against the euro after United States payrolls unexpectedly declined in December. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0547, up from $1.0487 on Thursday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Rating Cut At Telecom Concern
description: Moody's Investors Service has cut Deutsche Telekom's credit rating to the lowest investment grade because of concern that the company is spending too much on its wireless unit in the United States to reduce its 64 billion euros ($68 billion) of debt. Bonds sold by Deutsche Telekom fell sharply after Moody's lowered ratings on the debt by two levels, to Baa3. Analysts expected a one-level reduction. Moody's cut the rating on a Deutsche Telekom unit, T-Mobile USA, the former VoiceStream, in the United States to Ba3, or below investment grade.

title: Number of Inmates on Death Row Declines as Challenges to Justice System Rise
description: For the first time in a generation, the number of inmates on death row has dropped. And the number of new death row inmates in 2001, the most recent year for which comprehensive data is available, was the lowest since 1973.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLAT, DR. BERNARD
description: GREENBLAT-Dr. Bernard, 90. In Carson City, NV on January 5th. Formerly of Great Neck, NY. Specialized as OBGYN on Long Island. Predeceased by his beloved wife, Gertrude Greenblat. Survived by daughter, Deborah Miller (Paul) and son, David Greenblat (Mary), grandchildren, Dylan Greenblat and Luke Miller. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, WILLIAM
description: BERLINER-William. In Boston, MA. Formerly of East Meadow, NY. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Dear father of Jeffrey and Leonard. title: Aides Say Political Pressure Forced Medicare Fraud Settlement
description: Aides to Janet Rehnquist, inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services, said today that she had responded to political pressure by ordering a quick settlement of federal charges against a Pennsylvania hospital accused of filing false claims with Medicare.

title: U.S. Plan Could Ease Limits on Wetlands Development
description: The Bush administration opened the way today for a redefinition of federal rules that could remove obstacles to development on millions of acres of isolated wetlands historically protected under the Clean Water Act.

title: State Cannot Find Victims In 110 Child Abuse Inquiries
description: Two days after New Jersey officials ordered child welfare workers to visit 280 children who are the subject of abuse investigations, caseworkers have been unable to locate 110 of them, officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Software Profit Increases 24%
description: One of India's largest software exporters, Infosys Technologies, said its quarterly profit rose 24 percent, to 2.56 billion rupees ($53 million) but fell short of market expectations. Infosys, which is based in Bangalore, said its profit in the period, which ended Dec. 31 and was the third quarter of its fiscal year, was up from 2.06 billion rupees ($42 million) a year earlier. The chief executive, Nandan Nilekani, above, said a broader spectrum of clients was farming work out to his company. ''For the near future, at least, we think volume growth will be the key driver of revenue,'' he said at a news conference. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Gold in Them Thar Tin Cans?; Recycler Sees Money to Be Made From City's Containers
description: Recycling, as conceived in the flower-power 1970's, was never about making pots of money, and mostly it hasn't. In recent years, hopes began to fade in many cities around the nation that it could ever even pay its own way.

title: No Defects Are Found on Planes Like the One That Crashed
description: Inspections of other Beech 1900 commuter planes serviced at the same West Virginia shop as the one that crashed here on Wednesday have not turned up any defects in their tails, safety officials said today, as investigators continued to look into what caused the plane here to pitch up sharply on takeoff and then fall back to earth, killing all 21 people aboard.

title: Following the Path of a Medieval Arab Wanderer
description: The mildly hypnotic effects of his daily khat chew had barely kicked in before Tim Mackintosh-Smith made an odd admission for a travel writer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVING, MICHAEL H.
description: IRVING-Michael H. Of Westport, CT., and Martha's Vineyard, MA, died January 7, at age 79 of complications of Parkinson's Disease. A Navy veteran of W.W. II, and designer of many residential and commercial properties in New England and elsewhere, he was consulting architect of The Whitney Museum in New York City and an honorary member of its Board of Trustees. He was an avid watercolorist and served with much joy as a Docent with The Maritime Aquarium at Norwalk, Connecticut. A son of the late Evelyn DuPont and Carolyn Mann Irving, he is survived by his beloved wife, Patricia, his children; Michelle Evans of San Raphael, CA, Duncan Irving, of Darien, CT, Cully Irving, of Larchmont, NY and Fiona Donovan of New York City; his step-children; Sabrina Rainford Goldberg, of Park Slope, Brooklyn and Nancy Rainford Meinelschmidt of Los Angeles, CA and their spouses. Also, nine grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and three stepgrandchildren, and a brother, Alex of Southampton, NY. He was predeceased by another brother, John. A funeral service will be held on the Vineyard at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Edgartown, MA, Monday, January 13, 2003, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family would deeply appreciate any contributions to the Vineyard Nursing Association, P.O. Box 2568, Oak Bluffs, MA 02557. For additional information, please call Chapman, Cole and Gleason at 508-693-1495. Everyone who knew Michael loved him deeply.

title: MASTERCARD TO MOVE BACKUP DATA CENTER TO MISSOURI
description: MasterCard International Inc. said yesterday that it would move its backup data center to Kansas City, Mo., from an undisclosed site on Long Island, to be closer to its processing operations in St. Louis. The new center will cost as much as $50 million and will be in operation around June, the company said. About 30 people will work in the center. The backup center will duplicate functions from its primary data center, said MasterCard, which is based in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Owners Hope to Link Home Field in Series To All-Star Game
description: Commissioner Bud Selig and baseball's club owners are poised to embellish the All-Star Game by linking it to home-field advantage for the World Series, but the players association is not ready to endorse the idea.

title: Owner of A.&P. Chain Narrows Its Loss
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the operator of the A.& P. and Waldbaum's supermarket chains, said today that its third-quarter loss narrowed as it sold stores.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Big Jump In Crimes With Guns
description: Gun crime in England and Wales soared by 35 percent last year, with 9,974 crimes involving firearms reported in the 12 months to last April, up from 7,362 the year before and 4,903 in 1997, the year the Labor government took office promising reductions in crime. Anticipating the statistics, the government said this week that it would seek a five-year minimum jail sentence for gun possession, announced a ban on carrying imitation pistols in public and restricted the ownership of air guns by teen-agers. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Rumsfeld Orders 35,000 More Troops Deployed Near Iraq
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld signed a mammoth deployment order today sending about 35,000 new troops, half of them marines, to the Persian Gulf region, Pentagon and military officials said.

title: FORD IS ADDING TO UNDERFUNDED PENSION PLAN
description: The Ford Motor Company contributed $500 million to its underfunded United States pension plan this month and said it planned to add another $500 million by June. Ford cut the assumed rate of return on its pension funds in the United States, Canada and Britain to 8.75 percent from 9.5 percent, the chief financial officer, Allan Gilmour, told investors on a conference call yesterday. The lower rate of return on the pension assets in the United States will result in an estimated 2003 pretax pension cost of $270 million after a gain of $190 million last year. Mr. Gilmour said Ford had identified $992 million of $1 billion more in cost savings to help offset pension expenses.

title: Westchester Hit by Quake
description: A slight earthquake hit Westchester County last night, but did not cause any serious injuries or property damage, said Won-Young Kim, a research scientist at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, situated in Rockland County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARLES, BERNICE

Loving wife of Ray for 62 years; devoted mother of Michael, Jon and Wendy; doting grandmother of Claire, Annalily, Clover and Jonathan; best friend to daughters-in-law Lake and Maureen, and brother Bob Rosengarden, sister Joan Meyer and sisters-in-law Audrey Newman and Sharon Rosengarden; left us January 8, in Los Angeles. She was beloved by all.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: U.N. Wants Action On Killings
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission is demanding that the government find and arrest the killers of two of the country's foremost advocates for indigenous people's rights. Antonio Pop, a priest-turned-lawyer, was shot and killed after being kidnapped in December. Diego Velsquez Brito, a former legislator, was found dead days later. The country's various Maya communities were caught in the middle of a civil war that ended in 1996 with peace accords that have yet to be fulfilled, especially regarding indigenous rights. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Teenage Relative Is Charged In Death of Boy in Newark
description: A teenage cousin of the boy found dead here last weekend in a gruesome child-abuse case has been charged with aggravated assault in the child's death, law enforcement officials said last night.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Large Strike Averted
description: The government averted a strike by the country's largest labor union, agreeing to a wage increase this year and two smaller increases next year. The Verdi union, whose 2.8 million members include garbage collectors, firefighters and kindergarten teachers, had threatened to strike later this month. Local officials criticized the agreement as being too costly and said it would place a burden on Germany's cities, many of which are desperately short of funds. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: A Worldwide Economic Stimulus Plan
description: The Bush administration is leaving no doubt that it intends to use the United States' enormous military power to make the world a safer place. But to succeed, Washington must develop a more robust global economic policy as well. Unless our military confrontations lead to something much better for the millions of people who will be hurt, we will have won the wars and lost the peace.

Beckerman. He is a professor at the University of California, Santa Barbara. (At New York University he is a visiting professor.)

title: New Jersey Lawmakers Set to Approve Embryonic Stem Cell Research
description: New Jersey legislators are poised to give official approval for research on embryonic stem cells, a measure that, while largely symbolic, would be a powerful statement against federal funding restrictions on such research.

title: National Briefing: West
description: NEVADA: NEW MOVE IN INDIAN RANGE WAR A 30-year range war between the federal government and two elderly Western Shoshone Indian sisters reached a new stage when Bureau of Land Management officials said they were planning to round up more than 800 non-branded horses that belong to the women, Mary and Carrie Dann. The agency says the women are grazing their livestock on public lands without a permit, but the sisters contend they do not need one since their ancestors never signed papers ceding the territory to the government. Late last year, bureau agents confiscated 227 cattle belonging to the sisters and fined them $3 million for willful trespass. Carrie Dann said she and her sister were weary of the fight. "We're old," she said. "If we were young men, we'd show them a trick or two." The state has contacted horse adoption agencies in the hope they can place the animals. Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

title: Meditating On War And Guilt, Zen Says It's Sorry
description: To many Americans, Zen Buddhists primarily devote themselves to discovering inner serenity and social peace. But Zen has had strong ties to militarism -- indeed so strong, that the leaders of one of the largest denominations in Japan have remorsefully compared their former religious fanaticism during Japan's brutal expansionism in the 1930's and 40's to today's murderously militant Islamists.

description: What had been a lackluster campaign leading to the almost certain re-election of Israel's hard-line prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has suddenly been thrown into confusion, with doubt cast on the continued rule of his coalition of right-wing and religious parties.

title: Dismissal of Charges Against Lawyer Is Sought
description: Lawyers for Lynne F. Stewart, a New York lawyer charged with supporting terrorism, asked a federal judge yesterday to dismiss the indictment against her, saying the acts she is accused of are ''pure speech'' protected by the First Amendment.

description: Britain will use a telephone conference hookup to include Palestinian negotiators in Middle East peace talks scheduled on Tuesday in London, and thus get around an Israeli ban on their attendance.

title: Garden Remains a Draw for Crowds, and for Redevelopment Rumors
description: Madison Square Garden has been selected for a starring role next year in the Republican National Convention. There will also be a worldwide broadcast of the Rolling Stones concert at the Garden next week, and it will be home to the Grammy Awards Feb. 23.
