description: Accepting its most important commercial-speech case in years, the Supreme Court agreed to review a decision holding Nike, the sportswear company, potentially liable for damages for any false or misleading statements it makes in defense of its overseas business practices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSKIND, IDA LEVINE
description: SUSKIND-Ida Levine. It is with great sadness that the Suskind family marks the death of their Matriarch, Ida Suskind. Ida died quietly on January 9 in Bridgehampton, NY, where she moved permanently a few years ago. Ida grew up on Staten Island, where she lived with her late husband, Morris Suskind. She is celebrated by her surviving family: her son, Dennis Suskind, and daughter-in-law, Cynthia, her grandchildren, Jay, Debra, Brian, John, Pamela and Audrey, as well as four great-grandchildren. Her daughter, Lorraine Gootenberg, passed away late last year. Services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., on Monday, January 13, at 11:30 AM. Contributions in her name may be made to the Bridgehampton Food Pantry, Bridgehampton, NY 11932, or the Arthur Ashe Institute for Urban Health, 450 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11203.

title: U.S. ASSAILS MOVE BY NORTH KOREANS TO REJECT TREATY
description: The United States today condemned North Korea's decision to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, but privately -- through diplomacy in New Mexico and a phone call by President Bush to the Chinese leader, Jiang Zemin -- sought ways of defusing the confrontation.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: PARAMILITARY LEADER JAILED The British province's most notorious Protestant paramilitary leader, Johnny Adair, was arrested and jailed for breaching the terms of his release from prison. Mr. Adair, 39, left, a former West Belfast leader of the Ulster Defense Association who has been linked to at least a dozen killings, was expelled from the organization last fall along with several close associates. That move split hard-line Protestant paramilitaries and led to a feud that has resulted in two killings since Christmas and many attempted killings. The Belfast peace accord, signed by Catholic and Protestant political parties and paramilitary groups in 1998, included an amnesty for prisoners provided they do not continue any paramilitary activity.    Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Veteran Soloist Bows Out in an Impromptu Farewell
description: Kipling Houston, a soloist with New York City Ballet, gave what was called his last performance with the company on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Putting On the Dance Style of New Orleans
description: Jazz, basically, is musicians firing intelligence tests at seated audiences, communicating wordlessly among themselves. And that's O.K: this has been the language of serious jazz performance for more than 50 years. So it's amazing to get a glimpse of jazz serving, or at least referring to, a social function.

title: SOTHEBY'S INCREASES ITS COMMISSIONS ON SALES
description: Sotheby's Holdings Inc. increased commissions on sales in New York, London and Geneva to as much as 20 percent, the company said yesterday. The premium charged to buyers on amounts of more than $100,000 was raised two percentage points, to 12 percent, Sotheby's said. The commission on the first $100,000 rose to 20 percent from 19.5 percent. The increases take effect immediately. ''We've been going through significant cost-cutting to strengthen our balance sheet and increase our earnings, and adjusting our prices was one way to do that,'' the chief financial officer, William Sheridan, said.

title: Shinjo and the Mets Almost Have a Deal
description: The Mets were completing the details of a contract last night to bring outfielder Tsuyoshi Shinjo back to the team. Shinjo, negotiating from Japan through his New Jersey-based agents, has all but agreed to a one-year contract for about $600,000. He could also choose an option for a second year with a similar salary, although he may decide to forego that and re-enter the free-agent market next off-season.

title: Washington's Disunity Complicates Dialogue
description: As the confrontation between the United States and North Korea deepened today, two North Korean diplomats spent the day here trying -- through an old intermediary, Gov. Bill Richardson -- to explain what their country seeks from Washington in return for de-escalating its nuclear ambitions.

title: Advocates Paint a Dismal Picture of a Child Welfare Agency
description: Many accusations of child abuse reportedly go entirely uninvestigated in New Jersey's poorest and most dangerous neighborhoods. More than half of the children in foster care in the state are not checked on with the regularity that federal guidelines demand. And caseworkers investigating abuse reports often fail to conduct the kind of basic interviews with neighbors or doctors that might improve the state's record for removing children from troubled households.

title: Madison Square Mayhem
description: It's sort of good news that the Republican Convention is coming to New York in 2004. It's nice to see support from the Red country for the Blue city. It's a pity, though, that we will have to fork over some $50 million to defray G.O.P. expenses. I hope predictions based on Philadelphia's experience in 2000 will prove true and the event will bring in three times that amount, helping revive our battered tourist trade.

title: Mexican Foreign Minister Quits; Critic of Nafta Replaces Him
description: President Vicente Fox today formally accepted the resignation of his foreign minister, Jorge G. Castaeda, and named Luis Ernesto Derbz, his economy secretary, to the post.

title: Cheers for Three Halls at Once on London Stages
description: Sir Peter Hall, a perennial of the British theater for 50 years, is onstage this particular afternoon in a different role: as the concerned and proud paterfamilias.

title: Disaster Plan for Indian Point Is Called Inadequate
description: Emergency plans are inadequate to protect the public from a disastrous leak of radiation at the Indian Point nuclear plant in Westchester County and do not fully take into account the possibility of a terrorist attack, according to a report commissioned by Gov. George E. Pataki and released yesterday.

title: Paris Frees Airport Worker Who Was Framed as Terror Suspect
description: An airport baggage handler found with weapons and explosives in his car was released today after France's antiterrorism police determined that he had been framed by a former Foreign Legionnaire and in-laws who blamed him for the death of his wife.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Job Cuts At Shoemaker
description: The German shoemaker Salamander said it would cut 1,330 jobs, a quarter of its work force, in its shoe division, which is losing money, and close 20 branches. About 900 of the jobs to be cut will be outside Germany. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: U.C.L.A. Doesn't Intrigue St. John's
description: It might as well be the Acropolis or any other ancient tourist site. Pauley Pavilion, home of U.C.L.A. basketball, holds 11 national-championship banners. But for the Red Storm players, who visit Pauley today to meet the Bruins, their attitude is: what mystique?

title: Russia and Japan Sign Accord to Seek End to Dispute Over Islands
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan signed an agreement today calling for an accelerated effort to resolve the long-standing territorial dispute over the Kurile Islands that has left Russia and Japan technically in a state of war for six decades.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: PERU: SEARCH FOR MISSING PLANE Steady rain and cloudy skies hampered the search for a plane carrying 42 passengers and 4 crew members that is believed to have crashed in the Amazon jungle. The search resumed after being suspended late Thursday because of the poor weather. The Fokker-28 disappeared from radar screens on Thursday morning as it flew from Lima to Chachapoyas, a northern city in mountainous jungle. Contact was lost with the plane a few minutes before it was due to land.

title: Taiwan Lawmaker's Skill May Be Hereditary
description: THE first hint that life might not be just what it seemed came when John Chang was in grade school. The other children teased him and his identical twin brother, Winston, about their eerie resemblance to one of Taiwan's most powerful public figures, the head of its secret police, Chiang Ching-kuo. Some whispered that they were his sons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADER, MORTIMER E.
description: BADER-Mortimer E., 80. Healer of thousands. Brilliant doctor, research scientist, teacher; beloved father and grandfather. Passed away Thursday night after braving Parkinson's disease for over three decades. Mortimer Eugene Bader, M.D., worked his way from humble roots to lead a distinguished life and career. First in his class at both Stuyvesant High School and Columbia College, he was graduated with honors from Harvard Medical School. Sent to the Arctic by the United States Armed forces during the Second World War, he co-authored three landmark papers on the effects of cold environment on human metabolism. Following his return to civilization, he worked in the laboratories of Nobel Laureates Cournand and Richards, producing significant papers on the work of breathing. At 24, he began his career at Mount Sinai hospital, co-founding the hospital's first pulmonary function laboratory and continuing research and publication relating to collagen - vascular diseases, basic pulmonary physiology, and occupational lung disease. Renowned as a superb clinician and lecturer, he saved countless lives in his private practice with his twin brother Richard. Associate Editor of the American Journal of Medicine, Clinical Professor of Medicine at Mount Sinai, and lecturer at the University of Bologna medical school, he was awarded the Jacobi Medallion for distinguished achievement in the field of medicine and extraordinary service to Mount Sinai Hospital in 1983. Not just a legendary diagnostician, he was a charismatic man with a generous heart and sweet soul who was deeply dedicated to his family. A devoted chess player, he once defeated a Russian grandmaster in a simultaneous exhibition; a lover of puzzles and games from backgammon to bridge, he regularly completed the Sunday Times of London Crossword in addition to other less challenging puzzles. Possessed of an exceptional memory, he was a lifelong student of languages, history, philosophy, and mathematics. He held fast to his ideals and always valued honor and wisdom. Selfless and committed always to doing the right thing, he was a dear friend to many, loving father to John and Jenny Lyn, grandfather of William and George, brother of Richard, husband of Pauline. Services on Sunday at 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station, P.O. Box 4777, New York, New York 10163

title: Danger to the Wetlands
description: The Bush administration has opened the possibility that up to 20 percent of the nation's wetlands -- 20 million acres in all -- could lose protections they currently enjoy under the Clean Water Act. This is a door that should have remained closed.

title: Not Just Going Along for Ride, Testaverde Stays Ready in Wings
description: As he has on thousands of other days as an N.F.L. quarterback, Vinny Testaverde took the snap today, backpedaled, surveyed the field and cocked his arm in his classic quarterback's stance. And then he cradled the ball.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sharp Predicts Doubling Of TV Sales
description: The Sharp Corporation, which makes most of the televisions that use liquid crystal displays, will double its sales of those televisions in the next business year, its president, Katsuhiko Machida, told reporters in Tokyo. Sharp also expects sales of liquid crystal display televisions industrywide to increase to 3 million units from 1.5 million. Sharp will make most of the components in Japan and assemble the televisions in China, Spain and Mexico.

title: MIRANT TO FREE UP CASH IN EFFORT TO AVOID BANKRUPTCY
description: The Mirant Corporation, an electricity producer and natural gas trader, said it would pay $270 million to cancel orders for power plant turbines and would cut gas sales by half, as it sought to free up cash and avoid bankruptcy. Mirant also plans to sell at least $300 million of assets. Mirant, which is based in Atlanta, has said it may declare bankruptcy if it cannot refinance more than $5 billion in debt coming due over the next three years, including a $1.13 billion bank loan in July.

title: Russia Announces Chechen Vote on New Constitution in March
description: Russia announced today that it would hold a constitutional referendum in Chechnya on March 23, advancing an effort by Moscow to demonstrate to Russians and the world that the war in the breakaway republic is over.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Fewer Asylum Seekers
description: The number of asylum seekers dropped by nearly 20 percent last year to 71,127, the interior ministry said. The leading countries of origin were Iraq, with 10,242 people from there seeking asylum, along with Turkey (9,575 applicants). The sharpest drop was in asylum requests from Afghans; they fell by 52 percent to 2,772. Interior Minister Otto Schily credited the drop to the proposed new immigration law which, he said, ''made it clear that abuse of asylum in Germany can in future be ended more easily and quickly.'' The law was rejected last month by the Supreme Court because of irregularities in a parliamentary vote, but will be resubmitted in the next few weeks. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Critics of Plant Cheer Report's Findings
description: Lawmakers and critics of the Indian Point nuclear plant renewed calls today for the plant's immediate shutdown after the release of a report that called evacuation plans for the plant unworkable.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Trade Gap Widens
description: Australia's trade deficit grew in November to its widest in more than two years, as imports of consumer goods rose and a drought reduced the earnings from wheat, cotton and meat exports. The shortfall widened to 1.14 billion Australian dollars ($656 million) from a revised 957 million Australian dollars in October, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said. The trade gap was the widest since August 2000, when it reached 1.15 billion Australian dollars.

Bush both took office two years ago promising to forge a new partnership bridging the Rio Grande, one marked by a once-unimaginable level of cooperation on a number of fronts. It hasn't happened, and as a result Mexico's enlightened foreign minister, Jorge Castaeda, has resigned.

description: ZAINO-Costantino, M.D., 96, of Tuckahoe, died on January 9, 2003. He was a graduate of NYU Medical School. For information regarding visitation, Mass time and place, interment and contributions call Westchester Funeral Home, Inc., 914-337-4585

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer Takes A Charge
description: The Belgian-Dutch banking and insurance concern Fortis said that it lost 1.7 billion euros ($1.8 billion) last year in the stock market, causing its annual earnings to decline more than 80 percent. Fortis predicted that its earnings for 2002 would fall to 400 million euros ($420 million), in contrast to 2.27 billion euros ($2.38 billion) in 2001. The company said the value of some of its investments had fallen 1.7 billion euros below the price it paid for them. Fortis holds about 140 billion euros ($147 billion) worth of stocks, bonds and real estate. The largest share of its portfolio, about 87 percent, is in bonds. Fortis said its after-tax operating profit for the year, excluding the equity charge, would decline 8 percent, to about 2.39 billion ($2.51 billion) euros, compared with the period a year earlier. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: STATE STREET SAYS 4TH-QUARTER EARNINGS TRIPLED
description: The State Street Corporation, which provides custodial services for financial assets, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings almost tripled, helped by the sale of a corporate trust business. Net income rose to $477 million, or $1.46 a share, from $171 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue at State Street, which provides investment services for pension funds, rose 46 percent, to $1.5 billion. State Street sold its corporate trust business, a provider of administrative services to issuers of municipal and corporate debt, to U.S. Bancorp last week. It will use the proceeds to pay for the purchase of record-keeping and securities lending operations from Deutsche Bank. The company also cut jobs and compensation, after being hurt by dwindling mutual fund assets and three years of falling stock prices.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CABLE AND WIRELESS EXECUTIVE Cable and Wireless said it had named Richard D. Lapthorne, a medical diagnostics executive, as its nonexecutive chairman. Mr. Lapthorne, who said he planned to retire as the chairman of the medical diagnostics company Amersham in May, will assume his new duties at Cable and Wireless immediately. Cable and Wireless has been searching for a new chairman since November, when its chairman-elect, David Nash, said he would not succeed its departing chairman, Sir Ralph Robins. Analysts said the appointment of Mr. Lapthorne could place new pressure on Graham Wallace, the chief executive, who has been trying to salvage a costly expansion into data services. In November, Cable and Wireless acknowledged that overhauling its data services division would cost more than anticipated.

title: The Quarterback Who Got Away
description: When Jeff Garcia tried out for Coach Jon Gruden's Oakland Raiders before the 1999 season, there was no two-minute offense, no 24-point deficit to come back from, no Terrell Owens to find streaking across the middle. There was just a father in the stands and his son on the field, a Canadian Football League quarterback who needed an N.F.L. job

title: Long-Range Shooting Is Difference for Knicks
description: They just kept falling from beyond the top of the key, from the wings, from the corners, from 27 feet out, 25 feet away, with hands in faces, with opponents charging out, wide open.

title: FILINGS SHOW DETAILS OF LUCENT EQUIPMENT BUYBACK
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. paid about $48 million to buy back unsold fiber optic equipment from the Solectron Corporation after the two companies canceled a $2 billion manufacturing contract. Lucent hired Solectron last May to build optical equipment over the next three years. Lucent ended the agreement in October because of slumping demand, the companies said in recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Lucent is based in Murray Hill, N.J., and Solectron is based in Milpitas, Calif.

title: Fannie Mae Head to Quit
description: Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of home mortgages, said its vice chairwoman, Jamie Gorelick, will step down July 1 and would be succeeded by the chief financial officer, Timothy Howard.

title: Education Dept. May Change Report Cards for Principals
description: The Department of Education may modify a new report card that rates city principals, after superintendents complained that the current rating relies too heavily on test scores.

title: White House Adds a Crisis
description: North Korea's abrupt decision to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty has taken an issue that the Bush administration had hoped to shift to the back burner and forced it to the top of the world's foreign policy agenda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, BEATRICE
description: LEVY - Beatrice. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Mother of Ronald and Peter, mother-in-law of Fran and Wendy. Sister of Elaine Harris and Anne Green. Loving grandmother of Benjamin and Jacob. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. Services Sunday, 1:00 PM at Central Synagogue, 430 DeMott Ave, Rockville Centre.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Paramilitary Leader Jailed
description: The British province's most notorious Protestant paramilitary leader, Johnny Adair, was arrested and jailed for breaching the terms of his release from prison. Mr. Adair, 39, left, a former West Belfast leader of the Ulster Defense Association who has been linked to at least a dozen killings, was expelled from the organization last fall along with several close associates. That move split hard-line Protestant paramilitaries and led to a feud that has resulted in two killings since Christmas and many attempted killings. The Belfast peace accord, signed by Catholic and Protestant political parties and paramilitary groups in 1998, included an amnesty for prisoners provided they do not continue any paramilitary activity. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Rooting out truffle fraud:French use genetic coding tools
description: PARIS:  A French research laboratory has unraveled the genetic code of the famed black truffles from the Perigord region, finally giving anti-fraud inspectors a tool to distinguish between the pricey French fungus and a Chinese competitor that looks identical but tastes insipid.

title: Bridgeport Mayor Took What He Could, Ex-Adviser Says
description: Describing a routine of $600 dinners, cash-stuffed envelopes and $7,000 shopping sprees, a star government witness in the federal corruption trial of Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport portrayed him today as a shakedown artist who was willing to sell his official powers to whichever city contractor kicked back the most money.

title: Californians Hear Grim News on Budget
description: Gov. Gray Davis offered a grim $62.8 billion budget today that would bring pain to virtually every Californian through tax increases and cuts in almost every state program.

title: Accused Member of Terror Cell Near Buffalo Agrees to Guilty Plea
description: One of six men accused of belonging to a terrorist cell in western New York pleaded guilty yesterday to attending a training camp in April 2001 run by Al Qaeda in Afghanistan. He also pleaded guilty to contributing money, goods and services to the terrorist group.

title: The Black Hole: For Raiders Fans, So Good It's Scary
description: The first cars begin peeling off Hegenberger Road at 6 a.m., black sports utility vehicles rolling through a black mist toward this concrete house of worship. The parking lot gates open at 8:30 a.m. at Network Associates Coliseum, and the first match is thrown on the grill at 8:31, sending a billow of smoke above the home of the Oakland Raiders, smoke that will soon cover the skies above one of the loudest football stadiums in the National Football League.

title: 4 Death Row Inmates Are Pardoned
description: Robyn Hobley's long red fingernails were quivering, tears making rivers on her cheeks, this morning as she held the advance text of Gov. George Ryan's speech on the death penalty.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Futures declined on expectations OPEC will increase crude oil production, helping ease concerns over shortages. The February contract settled at $31.68 a barrel, down 31 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MYER
description: COHEN - Myer. A distin guished United Nations official died, January 8, 2003 in Newtown, PA. at the age of 95. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Elson Cohen. Cherished father of Arthur E. Cohen of Worcester, MA. and Judith C. Kretzmann of Washington, D.C. Devoted grandfather of three and great grandfather of three. Contributions may be made to a United Nations lecture series being established being established in his memory C/O Pennswood Village Residents Association, Pennswood Village, 1382 Newtown-Langhorne Road, Newtown, PA. 18940.

title: Linen Service Reaches Deal With Union Over Firings
description: A linen service in the South Bronx that was accused of firing two immigrant workers for backing a union agreed yesterday to rehire them; in exchange the union agreed to end its pressure campaign against the company.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Water Concern Acquired
description: RWE, one of the world's largest water companies, said its Thames Water subsidiary had completed the $4.6 billion acquisition of the American Water Works Company. The acquisition, which includes the assumption by Thames of $4 billion in debt, was completed after the company received approval from regulatory agencies and the shareholders of American Water Works, which is based in Voorhees, N.J. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Death in the Workplace
description: Politicians score easy points by railing against big government and excessive federal regulations. But a three-part series in The Times this week by David Barstow and Lowell Bergman showed that workplace safety rules are in fact far too weak, and dramatically underenforced.

title: NBC's Loss of One Executive Clears the Way for Another
description: NBC said yesterday that it would not replace its departing president and chief operating officer, Andrew Lack. But one thing is certain: his exit leaves a much clearer path for Jeff Zucker, the president of NBC Entertainment, to ascend eventually to the top position in the company.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 30 about new services being offered by cellphone companies misstated a prediction by Seamus McAteer, principal market analyst at the Zelos Group in San Francisco, about the concentration of young cellphone users in the United States by the end of 2003. He estimates that half of 14- to 20-year-olds will have cellphones, not that half of all cellphone customers will be 14 to 20.

title: Police Investigate the Death Of a 'Matriarch' in the Bronx
description: A 91-year-old woman considered the matriarch of her neighborhood was found dead yesterday, tied to a chair in her home in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, where she had lived for almost 50 years, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLECK, STEPHEN
description: FLECK-Stephen. The Western New England Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the death of our beloved colleague, teacher, and friend, Dr. Stephen Fleck. Lawrence Levenson, M.D., President, WNEPS Robert King, M.D., President, WNEIP

title: Political Memo; Weapon in Health Wars: Frist's Role as a Doctor
description: Critics of the Republican health care agenda say they are getting a little tired of hearing about the heroic-healer image of the new Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, a former transplant surgeon. They say that he may be a wonderful heart surgeon but that he is peddling the same old Republican free-market ideology on Medicare.

title: Jets Head for West Coast In a Rare Festive Mood
description: There have been few festive departures like this in the Jets' history: smiling players loading up three buses, spouses and children saying goodbye, camera crews, photographers and reporters milling about.

title: Car-Rental Talks
description: Avis Europe, the region's largest car-rental agency, is in talks to acquire assets of Budget International, whose United States parent company filed for protection from creditors last year.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: SOFTWARE PROFIT INCREASES 24% One of India's largest software exporters, Infosys Technologies , said its quarterly profit rose 24 percent, to 2.56 billion rupees ($53 million) but fell short of market expectations. Infosys, which is based in Bangalore, said its profit in the period, which ended Dec. 31 and was the third quarter of its fiscal year, was up from 2.06 billion rupees ($42 million) a year earlier. The chief executive, Nandan Nilekani, above, said a broader spectrum of clients was farming work out to his company. "For the near future, at least, we think volume growth will be the key driver of revenue," he said at a news conference. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Richard Mohr, a producer of opera records and Metropolitan Opera intermission broadcasts, misspelled the surname of an artist who recorded for him. It was the pianist Arthur Rubinstein, not Rubenstein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUKAT, SCOTT
description: SHUKAT-Scott. Beloved husband of Evelyn Shukat, M.D. Devoted father of Jonathan. Dear son of Harry and Florence Shukat. Loving brother of Peter and Yvette Shukat and Susan Kasten. Adoring uncle. Service 10am Sunday at ''The Riverside'', 76th St & Amsterdam Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Lincoln Hospital Auxiliary Fund Child Advocacy Center, c/o Lincoln Hospital, 234 E. 149th St, Bronx, NY 10451.

title: Top Debt Rating Agencies Take a Look at Accounting
description: The largest rating agencies, which received their share of criticism for failing to foresee the collapse of Enron more than a year ago or the accounting debacles last year, are planning to include evaluations of accounting policies in credit reports.

title: The Son of a Famous Father, Best Known for His Name
description: The makers of the latest exploitative television movie about the Kennedy family seem to have realized that the genre is close to exhausted, so they have taken a brash new approach: they have made a film whose main objective is to get you to turn it off.

title: God at Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: Senators and Sabres Feeling Economic Pinch
description: Like two wet skate boots, the financially troubled Ottawa Senators and the Buffalo Sabres keep clop-clopping across the National Hockey League's front hallway, leaving messy money puddles. Commissioner Gary Bettman wields the mop to keep things clean and dry. But the words bankruptcy and debt seep like cold air from a drafty door. The money woes worsen the wind-chill factor as this sport shivers in a difficult winter.

title: Hard Hits and Hard Feelings for Steelers and Titans
description: Before both teams find their way into the end zones and determine the eventual playoff winner, there is a physical score to settle between Pittsburgh (11-5-1) and Tennessee (11-5) at The Coliseum here on Saturday.

title: With Companies Still Gloomy, Payrolls Shrink by Thousands
description: The nation continued to bleed tens of thousands of jobs in December, the Labor Department reported yesterday, jolting forecasters who had expected a modest upturn in employment and suggesting that American business remains highly pessimistic about the economic future.

title: George Van Brunt Cochran, 70, a Surgeon, Mountaineer and Arctic Explorer, Is Dead
description: Dr. George Van Brunt Cochran, an orthopedic surgeon, mountaineer and former president of the Explorers Club in New York, whose specialty was climbing uncharted Arctic mountains, died on Monday in Ossining, N.Y. He was 70.

title: INSIDE
description: Guilty Plea in Terror Case

title: In Ryan's Words: 'I Must Act'
description: Following is the prepared text of Gov. George Ryan's speech at Northwestern University College of Law.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 13 about Singapore's economic uncertainty and China's growing economic power misidentified the post held by Tan Khee Giap, who commented on Singapore's role as a financial center. He heads the central banking policies research unit at Nanyang Technological University's business school in Singapore and is an adjunct senior fellow at the Institute of Policy Studies there. He does not head the government's central banking policy research unit.

title: The Neediest Cases; Illness and Hard Floors Challenge Family's Grit
description: After a breakfast of Indian pancakes, Bhavna Gupta, 2, giggled as she jumped up and down on two single beds pushed together in the corner of a studio apartment in Flushing, Queens. She lives there with her older sister, Sonia, 7, and their father and mother, Vinod and Saroj. And those beds, they are an exciting new luxury for a family that has been far more accustomed to hardships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, ISIDORE
description: FALK-Isidore. With love and great sadness, we mourn the passing of Isidore (''Issie'') Falk on January 6, 2003 at age 99. Beloved husband of the late Anne Falk. Cherished father of Serafina (Melvyn), Rebecca (John), Maurice (Judi) and the late Michael (Barbara). Adored grandfather of Nathaniel (Esther), Monica (Ira), Cindy (David), Jessica (Chaim), James, Jeremy, Michelle (William), Leslie, Annie, Harry (Claudia) and Eve. Treasured great grandfather of Elizabeth, David, Emily, Joshua, Harry, Alexander, Sarah, Abigail, Abraham, Simon, Michael and Benjamin. We remember him with love, laughter and admiration. Funeral serviceswere held at at Park East Synagogue on January 8 at 9:30 AM. Shiva will be observed at 188 East 70th Street.

title: Case Against A Psychiatrist Is Unfolding, Gradually
description: At the Seven Seas diner here, Dr. Richard J. Karpf was known simply as ''Doc,'' the quiet man and generous tipper with the predictable order: veal or lamb chops with an extra-large grapefruit juice for lunch, and a banana split at night.

title: A-Arms Treaty: Goals and Signers
description: The Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons is an international accord that took effect on March 5, 1970. Its goal is to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and arms technology and to promote disarmament and cooperation on the peaceful uses of nuclear energy.

title: More North Korean Brinkmanship
description: North Korea's decision to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty represents a sharp turn for the worse in an already dangerous crisis. It may be a particularly reckless bargaining tactic meant to extort a nonaggression pact from America or, worse, part of a crash drive by Pyongyang to build a stockpile of nuclear weapons. Either way, the move complicates the search for a diplomatic solution and adds to North Korea's dangerous isolation. The North claims to have no quarrel with the international community, only with Washington. By targeting an important global treaty, it belies its own argument.

title: At the Other End of the Axis: Some F.A.Q.'s
description: Everybody seems to be asking which is the bigger threat, North Korea or Iraq. What do you think?

title: National Briefing | West: California: Tree Sitter Is Ordered Down
description: A judge ordered a tree sitter, John Quigley, to leave a 400-year-old oak tree near Santa Clarita, where he has been living for more than 70 days to prevent its removal. Mr. Quigley, 42, plans to tie or chain himself to the tree rather than leave. His lawyer sought an emergency appeal to stay the ruling. The developer, John Laing Homes, has agreed to move the tree rather than cut it down, but environmentalists oppose the move, saying the tree could not survive. A deadline for removing Mr. Quigley was not set. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOFFER, PAUL E., M.D.
description: SOFFER-Paul E., M.D., 78. Of Lake Worth, Florida and North Shore Towers, Long Island. With love and sadness we mourn the passing of Paul Soffer on January 7, 2003. Beloved husband of Babette Weil Soffer for 55 years. Cherished father of Dr. Robin Soffer Sternberg and Debra Ornan, adored grandfather of Hannah Sternberg and Joseph Sternberg. Brother of the late Jessica Fleishman and Dr. Milton D. Soffer. He was a graduate of NYU College of Medicine. He practiced Obstetrics and Gynecology on Long Island. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, January 12, in Florida.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Trade Surplus Widens
description: Germany's trade surplus in the first 11 months of 2002 widened to $119 billion, compared with $91.5 billion in the period in 2001. In the month of November alone, the surplus rose to a record of $12.6 billion, from $11.7 billion in October, amid a strong increase in exports and a further drop in imports, the Federal Statistics Office said. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Gardens of California
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Rejects Tax Strategy Merrill Sold To Companies
description: A federal appeals court yesterday rejected a $226 million tax refund for the drug company Wyeth, reversing a lower court's ruling concerning a tax-avoidance strategy promoted by Merrill Lynch & Company in the early 1990's.

title: Judge Orders Pay Cut for Machinists at United
description: The machinists' union at United Airlines must accept short-term pay cuts that executives say are necessary to keep crucial financing in place, a bankruptcy court judge ruled yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corning Considers Additional Job Cuts
description: CORNING , N.Y., Jan. 10 (Bloomberg News)  Corning Inc., which is a leading maker of optical fiber for carrying phone calls and data, said today that it might cut more jobs this year and was considering options like partnerships for its fiber optic parts business.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Dec. 31 with an article about possible adjustments to Einstein's theory of relativity misstated the value of Planck energy, which some theorists think should represent the maximum energy of an elementary particle. It is 1019 billion electron volts, not 1019 electron volts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISER, CHARLOTTE
description: EISER - Charlotte. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Cherished mother of Henry. She was a devoted wife and a wonderful mother. A dedicated teacher and a lover of life. Graveside services, Sunday, 1PM at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ELSIE
description: SHAPIRO-Elsie. On January 10, 2003. Beloved wife of Nathan for 45 years. Adored mother of Janet, Robert and Ellen. Dear grandmother of Cooper, Keeton & Benjamin. Funeral services to be held on Monday, January 13th at 1:30 PM, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81st St. and Madison. Donations in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Anti-Israel Remark Draws More Protest
description: Gretta Duisenberg, wife of the European Central Bank president, Wim Duisenberg, generated more controversy and accusations of anti-Semitism today when she compared Israeli policies to the World War II Nazi occupation of the Netherlands. Ms. Duisenberg met this week with Yasir Arafat and toured the West Bank and Gaza as chairwoman of a pro-Palestinian Dutch group, Stop the Occupation.

title: Cheney Returns Fire In Battle On Tax Cuts
description: Vice President Dick Cheney struck back today at critics of President Bush's $674 billion economic plan, saying the proposal was not geared to the rich, would not hurt state budgets and would not increase the federal deficit over time.

title: Coming to a Showroom Near You
Cell vs. Soul? Shelter Island Mulls Tower
description: THE local medical center does not have an X-ray machine. The only traffic light was removed in 1994. There are no traffic lights. The library closes at four o'clock every day but Thursday. Welcome to Shelter Island, where 2,500 permanent residents pride themselves on resisting change.

title: Tropical Drama On Kauai
description: IT was pouring in paradise. Sitting in the dining alcove of the Jungle Cabana, a secluded cottage down a dirt road on Kauai's verdant north shore, my husband, John, and I listened to the roar of the stream just 15 feet from our doorway, the splash of water sluicing off the eaves and the PLAT! PLAT! PLAT! of raindrops pelting the leaves of the banana trees.

title: British Storm? Try This Port
description: Two sips of Fonseca Bin No. 27 defeat winter. Some Britons view this ambrosial port as central heating. Unlike other ports roughened by 20 percent alcohol, it is velvety and caressing. With walnuts and cheese, it's a banquet; alone, it's a dessert redolent of black currants. Finish it within two weeks of uncorking. McCabe's, 1347 Third Avenue (77th Street), charges $13.

title: A Flickering Flame
description: LAST Wednesday, Trista Rehn, 29, a physical therapist whose rsum includes a stint dancing for the Miami Heat as well as a master's degree in exercise science, began a nationally televised search for a husband on ''The Bachelorette,'' the new reality series. Each week she will eliminate prospective mates from a pool of 25, and with each program it is likely that remaining supplicants will continue to include the words ''Alex was crazy'' in their pitch for her affections.

title: Sharon Sees Political Motives in Arafat's Appeal
description: JERUSALEM, Jan 12 — Israel's embattled prime minister, Ariel Sharon, dismissed today Yasir Arafat's appeal for a pre-election halt to attacks on Israeli civilians, clearly implying that the Palestinian leader was trying to help his dovish opponent.

title: India Harvests Fruits of a Diaspora
description: Sir Shridath Ramphal's grandmother left India in rebellion 150 years ago, after refusing to throw herself on her dead husband's funeral pyre. She ended up in indentured servitude in South America, in what was then the British colony of Guiana. When it became a nation, her grandson, Sir Shridath, became its first foreign minister.

title: A.F.C. DIVISIONAL PLAYOFF
description: 1. Pressure Pennington -- The defense must lay some helmets on Pennington, especially early. In the Jets last two victories -- over Green Bay and Indianapolis -- Pennington was able to lead the offense on quick scores early, helping to put the games away in the first half. If the Raiders allow Pennington to get into a rhythm in the first quarter, there might be no stopping him. When the teams met on Monday night in December, the Raiders sacked Pennington twice and held him to a 95.8 quarterback rating -- still a high mark but the second-lowest from Pennington in his last eight starts. By comparison, Pennington had a 142.0 rating against the Colts and 134.7 against the Packers.

title: January 5-11: NATIONAL; JUDICIAL BATTLE REVISITED
description: President Bush renominated Judge Charles W. Pickering Sr. of Mississippi to a federal appeals court, all but guaranteeing that the recent debate about the racial politics of the Republican Party will continue. Judge Pickering, a protg of Senator Trent Lott, was turned back in his confirmation bid last year and it was unclear if Mr. Bush would renominate him and risk a reprise of the issues that cost Mr. Lott his post as majority leader. With the news, Democrats began preparing for a filibuster to block Judge Pickering's confirmation again. Neil A. Lewis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, GERSHON
description: STERN-Gershon. The family of Edith Agus and the late Dr. Haim Agus joins its lifelong friends, the family of Merle Stern, in mourning the passing of Gershon, a beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend. For 50 years, the lives of the Agus and Stern families were entwined. Our hearts reach out to Merle, his beloved wife, to his beloved children, Sharon and William Hyman, Jonathan and Kris Stern, Judith and David Lobel, to his beloved grandchildren, Caroline, Alexandra, Andrew, and Zachary and to his brother, Zalman, and his wife, Barbara. In addition to all the great occasions we shared with the Stern family, we shared its pride in Gershon's deep devotion to charitable causes and in his many philanthropic achievements in Canada, in the U.S. and Israel. A graduate of Yeshiva University, he and his beloved wife, Merle, ultimately endowed a chair at its business school. He was a great man with a great spirit, full of generosity, devotion and gratitude, widely admired and loved, who will be missed by the many he impressed so deeply in his lifetime. May his name be remembered always as a blessing. Mrs. Edith Agus Dr. Bert and Shoshana Agus Dr. Saul and Marcelle Agus Stephen and Linda Agus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHER, JOHN R.
description: MATHER - John R. The American Geographical Society family mourns the death on January 3rd of Russ Mather, whose friendship, sound judgement, and devoted service to the Society have been invaluable. As a Councilor from 1981 through 2000 and Secretary from 1983 through 2000, he earned the gratitude, respect, and affection of colleagues and staff. In 1999 the Society awarded him the Charles P. Daly Medal, established in 1902 for ''valuable and distinguished geographical labors.'' He will be long remembered as one of the stalwarts who loyally supported the Society in difficult days and rejoiced in its growing strength. We will sorely miss him. John E. Gould, Chair Jerome E. Dobson, President Mary Lynne Bird, Exec Dir

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: City Sidewalks, Packed in Holiday Style, Hint at End to a Lingering Slump in Tourism
description: People lined up for hours on the sidewalk in front of the Empire State Building during the holiday season just past. Ground zero was packed. Crowds spilled out the entrance of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and even if the guy holding a yellow cobra had not been standing in front of the Virgin Megastore in Times Square on the Monday afternoon before New Year's Eve, the sidewalks would have been as congested as, well, Times Square on New Year's Eve.

title: Schools Ending Year Early Among Efforts to Cut Costs
description: Linda Pattison, a fourth-grade teacher here, uses her fingers to check off the lessons that she usually teaches but will skip this spring. Her pupils will not study the metric system in arithmetic, nor electricity in science. Nor will they read Oregon history in social studies.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Prosaic Buildings Are Honored for Inventive Designs
description: A CARWASH won a medal, and so did a university parking garage. Another medal went to a furniture showroom storefront redone on a budget.

title: Driving Out An Unneeded Store
description: To the Editor:

title: Data-Storage Stocks Face Barriers
description: THINK of all the stuff that is routinely crammed into a computer. E-mail. Word processing. Presentation slides. Databases. Images, video and audio files. It's a wonder that the machines can contain it all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRYER, DR. KATHARINE HOMER
description: FRYER-Dr. Katharine Homer, passed away on January 5, after a long ordeal with ovarian cancer. Dr. Fryer obtained her doctorate from NYU and taught at that institution and at C.W. Post. Since 1995 she has been Director of the Fryer Research Center, a healthcare organization that offers a biochemical-nutrional treatment for mental disorders. Her serious avocation was singing. She performed in a series of concerts at The National Arts Club in New York, the Amato Opera and in the Opera in Central Park. In her teenage years, Dr. Fryer was afflicted by a severe thryoid deficiency that went undiagnosed and nearly led to an early demise. After encountering little success in New York, a simple country doctor in Florida finally identified the problem and prescribed medication that saved her life. This ordeal became the subject of a book authored by her mother, and simply titled ''Kathy.'' Dr. Fryer is survived by her three sisters, Dr. Judy Shedden, a financial planner in New York City, her twin sister, Anne Eddis, a violinist with the New York City Opera, and Dr. Sarah Fryer Leibowitz, a Professor of Neurobiology at The Rockefeller University. Dr. Fryer's life was dedicated to giving to others through her professional work and her artistry. Her strength, courage, warmth and graciousness will be sorely missed by many well beyond her immediate family and friends. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Fryer Research Center, 30 East 40th Street, Suite 608, New York, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHANAN, LUCIE (NEE TRINCELLITA)
description: BUCHANAN - Lucie (nee Trincellita), January 8, 2003. 92. Widow of Douglas Charles Buchanan, beloved mother of Douglas, Jane, and the late Charles, grandmother of Nicholas. Formerly of North Bergen, NJ, she resided in Manhattan. Appreciated for her fine and lively mind, and creative spirit, she will be deeply missed.

title: Postgrads; Break a Leg
description: ESTELLE PARSONS, winner of an Obie and Oscar, received her training almost entirely on the job. She played child roles in community theater until having to kiss a boy in ''Junior Miss'' became too embarrassing to bear. Her father offered to buy her a car for high school graduation. She asked for cash instead and blew all $300 to be a paying apprentice at a nearby summer theater. There, she got to play Kay Francis's maid (''a small part, a very small part,'' she recalls) and watch the pros up close.

title: No Vow of Poverty For Bishop Murphy
description: I agree wholeheartedly with the letter [Dec. 29] criticizing Bishop William Murphy over the cost of building his official residence. However, the writer is misinformed about Bishop Murphy's vows. Chastity and obedience, yes; poverty, no. He could win the lottery and keep it all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEEKIN, JOHN R.
description: MEEKIN-John R. Died on January 8, 2003 at the age of 77. A retired vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, he was a warden emeritus of the Church of the Ascension, a trustee of the Church Club of New York, and a member of the University Club and the Grolier Club. title: Blake Is Ready for Australian Open
description: James Blake, who first came to prominence at Fairfield High School, got his tennis year off to an eye-opening start last weekend in Perth, Australia, when he defeated the top-ranked men's player in the world, Lleyton Hewitt of Australia, 6-3, 6-4, in the final of the Hopman Cup.

This month Jefferson's home in Charlottesville, Va., will commemorate the bicentennial of that expedition, which was headed by Meriwether Lewis and William Clark.

title: Soft on Students Means Hard on Us, Teachers Say
description: As the dean of discipline at Middle School 202 in Ozone Park, Queens, Donna Solomon has faced her share of frightening incidents. In the last semester alone, she said, she took reports on a student who threw two punches at a security guard, a student who discharged a fire extinguisher, a student who took a box cutter to gym class and a student who knocked down a teacher and stepped on her back as he ran away. She said she herself became a victim of unruliness when a student pushed her against a wall, bruising her shoulder.

title: A Vampire With Soul, and Cheekbones
description: LOVE hurts. Just ask Spike, the formerly evil peroxide-blond punk vampire of UPN's ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer.'' Last season, Spike's desperate passion for Buffy culminated in an extraordinarily mature story line, in which the emotionally frozen slayer used the masochistic vampire for violent, all-consuming sex. Their affair walked the line between love and hate; it ended in rejection and attempted rape. Sick with remorse, Spike tried to win Buffy back with a typically brash gesture, traveling into the underworld to regain his soul. But now that soul burns with guilt and self-loathing.

title: 3 Lives, In Theater And Now On Stage
description: REMEMBERING her first big role on the stage, the dancer and actress Valda Setterfield says, ''I was pleased, as I still am today, whenever I'm lucky enough to get a job.'' The line seems to resonate with memories of auditions dared, rejections endured and acceptances celebrated. In other words, it describes a life in the theater, and it is voiced toward the beginning of ''Art, Life & Show-Biz,'' a nonfiction play that is at P.S. 122 in the East Village through Jan. 26.

The star of the show was not a car at all but a motorcycle with 10 cylinders and 500 horsepower.

description: COCHRAN - George Van Brunt, MD. Died January 6 at home in Ossining NY. Born in Brooklyn, he attended Poly Prep, Dartmouth and College of P&S, Columbia University. Donations in his memory may be made to the Conservation Fund of the Campfire Club, or Exploration Fund of the Explorers Club.

description: Witchel-Ruth. (nee Goodman) on January 4, 2003. Ruth has left us to join her beloved Jess. A dedicated elementary school teacher, Ruth was as well an exlemplary mother and mother-inlaw, an excellent cook, a fine knitter and superb grandmother. She will be cherished and missed by her son Carl, her daughter-in-law Lucie Rodrigue, her two grandsons Alexandre and Simon Rodrigue-Witchel, her loving sister Hannah Stern as well as family and many friends. Services Sunday 11:15 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment to follow at Mt. Judah Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

description: Even some of Governor McGreevey's most loyal allies have been a bit surprised by the vehemence of his reaction to the horrifying case of child abuse that has unfolded in Newark.

description: D. J. Enright, a British poet, novelist and critic whose ironic, self-deprecatory, minimalist verse was admired by writers but never won much of a public following, died last Tuesday in London. He was 82.

title: The New E.U.
description: FOR a college founded in 1614, the University of Groningen in the northern Netherlands is surprisingly open to change. This fall, it divided its five-year undergraduate program into separate bachelor's and master's degrees. It will soon adopt a new European credits system. And its recruiters are busy wooing young Asians and Eastern Europeans to do their postgraduate studies -- in English, naturally -- in this friendly medieval city.

description: To the Editor:

title: Venus Wants a Place in the Universe
description: Venus Williams stands in a torn-up condominium in Palm Beach, Fla., assessing a man's shower curtain. The condo has the mausoleum feel of a work in progress, with unpainted walls, freshly marbled floors and furniture draped in drop cloths. Contractors mill about expectantly. Against this stark monochrome, Williams is an arresting, 6-foot-1 presence, dressed in a denim skirt and a leopard-print Versace top that fits like a second skin, the striated muscles of her back rippling and rearranging themselves as she lifts a swatch of shower curtain to the light. The curtain itself is a notch above ordinary -- a scrap of fawn-colored linen -- but the way the 22-year-old Williams studies it, you'd think it was the key to some faraway kingdom, a piece of a large and scintillating puzzle. The question at hand is whether this fabric matches the yachty style of the recently divorced, retired manufacturing exec who hired the tennis star to decorate his place.

title: If Chickens Are So Smart, Why Aren't They Eating Us?
description: THE wrath of PETA, the animal rights group, has now been turned on KFC, the fried-chicken chain. After two years of failed negotiations aimed at forcing KFC to introduce more humane practices into the raising and slaughtering of chickens, PETA announced last week that it would start a worldwide ''Kentucky Fried Cruelty'' campaign, distributing posters, stickers and leaflets that feature a cartoon Colonel Sanders grinning wickedly as he slices open a live bird.

title: Central Park Zoo Workers Stalk the Elusive Snowfall
description: When a snowstorm graces Central Park with a layer of wintry icing, most New Yorkers smile at the glistening spectacle. Many of them probably even start humming ''Winter Wonderland.''

title: All Eyes on the Stage
description: SEE me. Feel me. Touch me,'' implored the singer from a stage festooned with American flags. It was an unnerving proposition -- even here in touchy-feely Los Angeles. He was 6-foot-5 and nude, save for a carefully placed acoustic guitar, red socks and battered work boots. Welcome to the Naked Trucker show at Largo, a bijou of a club where the patrons are as passionate about live entertainment as they are about their Guinness beer.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for PETER HAKIM; How Free Trade Will Alter a Hemisphere
description: LAST week, the Bush administration opened negotiations to create a free-trade agreement similar to Nafta with five Central American countries, a large step in the administration's plans for a free-trade zone throughout the Western Hemisphere. An agreement with those countries -- El Salvador, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua -- could be completed within a year and cause a rush of American investment to Central America, which only a few years ago was still reeling from effects of protracted civil wars. Peter Hakim, the president of Inter-American Dialogue, a research group in Washington, spoke last Thursday about an agreement's effects. ELIZABETH BECKER

title: Afghan Editors Test Freedom's Boundaries With Cartoons
description: It looks like a typical Afghan party, with music and dancing and dollars being thrown at the dancers. But the cartoon in a recent issue of a Kabul weekly that showed President Hamid Karzai leading a song and dance number, sent the magazine's editor to jail for two nights last month.

title: Corrections

There have been three, not two: in addition to Don Shula and Dan Reeves, Dick Vermeil accomplished the feat, with Philadelphia and St. Louis.

title: Editorial Observer; Two Things Linger in Cuba: Fidel and a Pointless Embargo
description: Cuba's oddest tourist attraction may well be the Rincn de los Cretinos, or Corner of Cretins. Tucked into a dim hallway of the Museum of the Revolution, it features life-size caricatures of Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush. The plaque beside Mr. Reagan reads, ''Thanks you cretin for helping us to strengthen the revolution.'' The first President Bush is thanked for helping to ''consolidate'' the revolution.

title: Advocacy Invigorates Human Rights Topics
description: SLAVERY, violence in Latin America, oppression in China all these are compelling topics to local undergraduates. Interest in human rights issues isn't new at colleges, of course. But a blend of advocacy and academic study has recently invigorated human rights offerings on local campuses.

description: Reactions to Sept. 11 and complications of young love were nominated for the top Grammy awards. Bruce Springsteen, the Dixie Chicks, the gentle pop-jazz singer Norah Jones and two rappers, Eminem and Nelly, vie for album of the year. Ms. Jones is one of four women nominated as best new artist, along with Ashanti, Michelle Branch, Avril Lavigne and one man, John Mayer. The awards are to be broadcast on Feb. 23 on CBS. Jon Pareles

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THIS COLD HEAVEN: Seven Seasons in Greenland, by Gretel Ehrlich. (Vintage, $14.) The author's extended travels among the Greenland natives took place during a period of transition in the 1990's, when a 5,000-year-old subsistence culture was threatened by global warming and the temptations of the modern world. ''Ehrlich has written a stunning portrait of a people and the landscape that shaped them,'' Elizabeth Royte said here in 2001. ''Her story has great emotional and physical sweep, and one shares her loss at leaving this peculiarly fascinating place.''

title: Els Sets Blistering Pace, But Others Are Near
description: On a day when scoring records were not safe at the Mercedes Championships, Ernie Els continued to set the pace.

title: Sarah Kirshbaum, Daniel Levy
description: Sarah Beth Kirshbaum, the daughter of Barbara and Laurence J. Kirshbaum of New York, was married last evening to Daniel Walter Levy, a son of Evelyne H. Levy of Fair Lawn, N.J., and the late Irwin G. Levy. Rabbi Judith S. Lewis officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Planning for the Future As a United Island
description: Recently, Governor Pataki's task force on local government reform took testimony on a variety of topics, one of which was ''what can the state government do to help us on Long Island?'' Help with regional planning would be welcome. Parochialism has reared its head recently with inter-town posturing and chest thumping between Riverhead and Southampton, while East Hampton is doing everything it can to torpedo a regional transportation planning mechanism supported by the four other East End towns. Seems that new interstate ferries will have no place to land if East Hampton has its way. And Long Islanders, especially those out east, are more than ever concerned about overdevelopment, loss of farms and open space, water-quality protection and, on the East End, the total inability to make a left turn between July 4th and Labor Day.

title: Taking Apart Politics (While Playing all the Parts)
description: MAN, you still good!'' chortles James Carville. He is listening to Bill Clinton juggle telephone calls from an achingly clueless Al Gore and a desperate Tom Daschle, admiring the silk-smooth Clinton's effortless evasions. Help the party? Clinton's gone solo: he's jetting to England to see his pal Tony Blair and renew an acquaintance with an actress who auditioned to play Xena. ''I have to be out there where the game is played,'' Clinton tells his former political consultant. ''Mark of a pro.''

title: In Ballet World, America Is Still a Distant Shore
description: ON Oct. 16, 1942, cowboys rode bucking broncos across the stage of the old Metropolitan Opera House. The cowboys were really dancers of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, and the broncos were invisible. But their buckings could be sensed in Agnes de Mille's choreography for ''Rodeo,'' and the ballet, to a score by Aaron Copland, created a sensation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVING, MICHAEL H.
description: IRVING-Michael H. Of Westport, CT., and Martha's Vineyard, MA, died January 7, at age 79 of complications of Parkinson's Disease. A Navy veteran of W.W. II, and designer of many residential and commercial properties in New England and elsewhere, he was consulting architect of The Whitney Museum in New York City and an honorary member of its Board of Trustees. He was an avid watercolorist and served with much joy as a Docent with The Maritime Aquarium at Norwalk, Connecticut. A son of the late Evelyn DuPont and Carolyn Mann Irving, he is survived by his beloved wife, Patricia, his children; Michelle Evans of San Raphael, CA, Duncan Irving, of Darien, CT, Cully Irving, of Larchmont, NY and Fiona Donovan of New York City; his step-children; Sabrina Rainford Goldberg, of Park Slope, Brooklyn and Nancy Rainford Meinelschmidt of Los Angeles, CA and their spouses. Also, nine grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and three stepgrandchildren, and a brother, Alex of Southampton, NY. He was predeceased by another brother, John. A funeral service will be held on the Vineyard at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Edgartown, MA, Monday, January 13, 2003, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family would deeply appreciate any contributions to the Vineyard Nursing Association, P.O. Box 2568, Oak Bluffs, MA 02557. For additional information, please call Chapman, Cole and Gleason at 508-693-1495. Everyone who knew Michael loved him deeply.

title: The Adventurous Side of a Chinese Menu
description: COLUMN A and column B are history at most Chinese restaurants. They went the way of so-called Chinese-American eating places and moo goo gai pan. Today, Chinese spots serve the food of Sichuan, Hunan, Singapore, Shanghai and Guangzhou. Many throw in some Japanese dishes and call themselves Asian or, as is the case at the six-month-old East Wok in Glen Cove, Asian gourmet.

title: Corrections

The photographer was Catherine Lutz; Aspen/Snowmass supplied the picture. This correction was delayed because a reader's e-mail message reached a vacationing staff member.

title: Prison Is a Member of Their Family
description: Since Nina was born, Lolli has been dressing her for prison. Nina wore new baby clothes for visits to her 16-year-old father, Toney, in a juvenile detention facility not too far from their Bronx neighborhood. As Nina grew, Lolli dressed her daughter for the rarer afternoons in faraway New York State maximum-security visiting rooms. The gaps between visits gave Lolli time to save and shop for the brand-new outfits on layaway. In the inner city, being ''dressed'' has always been important: it means you are provided for, a part of bigger things. Sloppiness and stains were physical evidence of failure, of poverty winning its battle against you. The night before visits, Lolli would spend hours doing Nina's hair in her father's favorite style -- Shirley Temple curls. Nina groaned and grimaced. Lolli tugged and yanked. Nina winced whenever Lolli cleaned her ears (Toney sometimes checked). In prison, as on the street, a well-dressed family enhanced Toney's stature. Interactions were public, and appearances mattered.

title: When Stars Direct: Vanity? Maybe Not
description: IT may not feel like it at the moment, with three highly visible stars making their highly visible directorial debuts, but actors have been turning into directors for decades. Ida Lupino did it in the 50's, Warren Beatty did it in the 70's, Sean Penn did it in the 90's. Still, it feels like a major event when an A-list movie star like George Clooney or Denzel Washington or Nicolas Cage tries his hand at making a movie instead of just starring in one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, GEORGE A.
description: DEAN-George A. The Women's Campaign Fund notes with great sadness the death of George Dean, on January 10, 2003. He was an outstanding Board member and we will miss him every day. Women's Campaign Fund

title: RUTGERS SUED
description: The InterVarsity Multiethnic Christian Fellowship is suing Rutgers University for reinstatement of about $1,200 and the right to meet on campus. A Rutgers spokeswoman confirmed that funds had been withheld but said the group was free to meet on university property. Rutgers says the fellowship is subject to the university's anti-discrimination policy. But the group, which requires its leaders to declare that they are Christians, deleted from its charter language that is required to meet that policy. Jeremy Pearce

title: When Cameras Roll, So Do Dollars
description: AT Ward Pound Ridge Reservation here, no coyotes or wild turkeys can be spotted, but beneath the trees, on the fields and atop rocks, grips, gaffers, thick-neck wrestlers and baby-faced production assistants are running wild. Battle cries suddenly go up as opposing Revolutionary War armies, the red coats and the blue, charge at each other across an open field. They meet in the middle where, instead of bayoneting one another, the soldiers enter a wrestling ring for headlocks and body slams. Just how did it come to pass that King George's army and Minutemen are charging at each other in the middle of this reservation's 4,700 acres of wilderness.

title: A Sign Might Be More Than a Sign, But Frank's Lounge Stays the Same
description: The forest of white plaster icicles still hangs over the bar. Strings of miniature Christmas lights still cascade down the wall in back. But something happened last month at Frank's Cocktail Lounge in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, that struck the fear of gentrification into Micaela Birmingham's heart.

title: Milton Berle
description: I remember what Uncle Miltie said when Bishop Fulton Sheen's TV sermons on another channel cut into his Texaco Star Theater TV ratings: ''We both have the same sponsor -- Sky Chief.''

title: A Journeyman Actor Never Far From a House
description: DANIEL GERROLL, for many years a ubiquitous and uncommonly dependable presence on New York stages, has a reason for regularly contracting to do two or three plays a season: he's indolent.

title: Need a Minister? How About Your Brother?
description: LAST August in the Southern California desert, Blithe Smith, a lawyer, and David Bock, a children's television writer, exchanged wedding vows.

title: Paul Klingenstein, 88, Seller Of Photographic Equipment
description: Paul Klingenstein, who turned a childhood picture-taking hobby into a company that sold cameras and photographic equipment, died last Sunday at his winter home in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 88, and lived in Longboat Key and Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: After Ground Zero: The Idea, Again, Is to Look Up
description: ''TRIBUTE IN LIGHT,'' the twin high-intensity beams that pierced the night sky near ground zero in Lower Manhattan for a month last spring, was partly the work of the New York-based sculptor and conceptual artist Julian LaVerdiere. The light shafts were seen both as ghostly replications of the fallen towers and as votives for the victims. For Mr. LaVerdiere, the temporary memorial was also a tough act to follow.

title: Just a Regular Guy Who Likes to Go To the Movies
description: As a prototypically opinionated New Yorker, Edward I. Koch landed the perfect job after he stepped down as mayor: writing movie reviews for several neighborhood newspapers.

title: The Baby Ivies
description: To enter the 92nd Street Y Nursery School, parent and child pass through a large granite and marble lobby. Beyond the Felix M. Warburg Lounge, beneath an exquisitely stenciled ceiling, they wait in a long line behind a red velvet rope for the special elevator that carries them to the sixth floor. When the shiny brass door opens, an impressive display case filled with ribbon designs and candleholders made by the children greets them.

title: The Mean Season
description: This is the time of year when people still emanate a glow of goodness, fueled by a thoughtful holiday season and New Year's resolutions. But this year, why bother with any of that? You can't expect me to resolve to be a more sober person when a recent Harvard study made it clear that moderate drinking helps prevent heart disease. And forget about swearing off chocolate. Life-preserving antioxidants have been discovered in cocoa. title: January 5-11: INTERNATIONAL; BRITAIN, READYING FOR COMBAT
description: Britain took its much anticipated first step at mobilizing for combat in Iraq, but the numbers were less than had been expected. The government tried to assure the skeptical British public that war was not inevitable and that support for the United States-led campaign against Iraq was, in the words of Prime Minister Tony Blair, ''massively in our self-interest.'' Mr. Blair acknowledged to a gathering of British diplomats that anti-Americanism was on the rise, but said it was a ''foolish indulgence.'' Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon told Parliament that Britain was calling up 1,500 reserves and augmenting a naval task force now training in the Mediterranean -- far short of informed predictions that he would summon 7,000 reserves to active duty and begin the dispatch of the first of Britain's 20,000-man ground force. title: Where the Girls Aren't

Computer science, the mathematics-based study of programming, is so unpopular among girls that even the most rigorous girls' schools rarely find enough students to fill a class. Tech-minded teachers worry that programming is to this generation what math was to their mothers -- a boys' club preventing girls from getting a foothold in the technological world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELZER, JOAN G. (NEE STRAUSS)
description: MELZER - Joan G. (nee Strauss). Of Stamford, CT, formerly of Riverdale, NY, died peacefully, at age 86, on January 11. Beloved wife for 52 years of the late Dr. Hyman Melzer and loving sister of Sydnee Gordon. Devoted mother of Jane Appel and Robert Melzer, mother-in-law of Fred Appel and Judith Melzer, grandmother of Jonathan, Eric and the late Michael Dorf and Meredith and Craig Melzer, and grandmother-inlaw of Anne Schlesinger. She was a lifelong volunteer, helping those in need. While in high school she served at the Hospital for Joint Diseases and Grand St. Settlement, both in New York. She had been actively involved with the Veterans Hospital Radio and Television Guild (The Bedside Network), working with veterans at the Kingsbridge Veterans Hospital and other hospitals in the northeast. She then volunteered for 21 years at Montefiore Medical Center. For the last three years she resided at Edgehill in Stamford where she made many friends. During that time she volunteered at Stamford Hospital. She will be missed by all who knew her. Services will be today at 11 AM at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT.

title: Madame Nhu Almost Slept Here
description: Wherever Madame Nhu lives today, it can't be half as glamorous as the place she left behind. Ousted by a 1963 coup that resulted in the assassinations of her husband and his bachelor brother, President Ngo Dinh Diem, the first lady of South Vietnam -- now reportedly living in Paris -- sacrificed a 100-room palace that Diem commissioned but never used. Still standing in the middle of Ho Chi Minh City, Reunification Palace is the sexiest building in Southeast Asia. And yet, despite the fame of its French-trained architect, Ngo Viet Thu; the dragon-lady reputation of Madame Nhu (Life called her the most ''devious'' beauty ''anywhere east of Suez''); and the breathtaking folly of its wartime construction, the White House of South Vietnam remains an edifice obscure.

title: Parkingless in Hoboken
description: I'd been on the sidewalk barely a minute when I was stopped by a passing driver. ''Please tell me you're moving your car,'' he asked, his voice full of the frustration known to anyone who has looked for parking in Hoboken on a Saturday night. Relief may be coming. A new ordinance sets aside about 2,500 spots that are reserved 24 hours a day, seven days a week, for holders of residency permits in this town of 38,000 people. But desperate parking-hunters are choosing to ignore the telltale green signs. Since enforcement began on Oct. 21, the town says, 800 cars have been booted, costing the owners $100 each. Not everyone agrees that the new ordinance is tough enough. ''People who come here to go out in the evening shouldn't get street parking,'' said Cregan Cooke, a resident since 1991. ''They should have to use a garage.'' In fact, a 744-car garage is scheduled to open later this month at Fourth and Clinton Streets. Gretchen Kurtz

While some teachers have always used eyewitness accounts to conjure the sights, smells and sounds of past events, D.B.Q.'s now show up on tests that are mandatory for public school students, including the 10th and 11th grade social studies Regents exams required for graduation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBMAN, THEODORE, M.D.
description: LEIBMAN-Theodore, M.D., FACOG, died in Englewood at age 64. Dr. Leibman, an obstetrician/gynecologist, will be missed by family and friends. A man larger than life itself, Dr. Leibman was dedicated to humankind and was instilled with empathy for all who touched his life. A native of South Africa, he emigrated after completing medical school at the University of Pretoria where he was an avid squash player. He saw an ad in the Lancet medical journal and took a oneyear position in New Jersey's Englewood Hospital. He met and fell in love with Felicia Lipchez of New York City. They were married that summer in Englewood. Theodore and Felicia Leibman returned to South Africa and settled in Klerksdorp where he maintained a general practice. The United States beckoned and they returned to New York City a few years later. His three brothers soon followed and settled in the Houston area. Dr. Leibman completed a residency in OBGYN at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He practiced on the faculty at that institution, but gravitated back to Englewood Hospital, where he practiced for many years. Dr. Leibman's son Michael joined his practice in 1999 and they worked together until his retirement in February of 2002. Dr. Leibman delivered thousands of children, and in many instances, the children of those children. One of his most gratifying experiences was volunteering his medical skills through the Indian Health Services. He served the Native American populations in Arizona and New Mexico. His interests included fishing and boating as well as collecting decoys, sculpture and Native American art. He was a longtime subscriber to the ballet and opera and enjoyed Broadway theater. His second home was Chamberlain, Maine, which always reminded him of the shores of Capetown, South Africa. A world traveler, he had recently completed trips to Antarctica, Portugal, fishing in Guatemala as well as the game reserves of his native South Africa. He is survived by his wife Felicia, three sons, Dr. Michael, Peter and Marc, three brothers, and daughters-in-law, and nine nieces and nephews. For more information contact Wien & Wien Memorial Chapel 201-489-6125

title: Lugging the Dummy
description: Never mind the pornographic passages that appear every few pages in 69 THINGS TO DO WITH A DEAD PRINCESS (Canongate, paper, $13); the British writer Stewart Home, champion of ''proletarian'' postmodernism (which means forget about character and plot), is a surprisingly easy read. The graphically described couplings are among the novel's many sendups, as Home sets out to undermine the role of books as commodity (another of his obsessions) with the sort of goings-on you can't describe without sounding foolish. For instance: the efforts of the main characters, Alan and Anna, to test the ''credibility'' (ha!) of an obscure text called ''69 Things to Do With a Dead Princess,'' whose author claims to have taken Princess Diana's corpse on a tour of the local Neolithic stone circles ''as a means of luring tourists to the prehistoric delights of ancient Aberdeenshire.'' The pair retrace the journey, lugging a ventriloquist's dummy as a princess stand-in. Between sex scenes, Alan sounds off on a range of authors, with charming disregard for their relative prominence or obscurity. Home makes an agreeably deadpan ventriloquist himself, venting intellectual spleen through his transparently thin characters. It's only when he points out the illusion -- having Alan disappear into Anna, or letting the dummy narrate a chapter -- that the joke falters, and his absurd picaresque reveals itself as that tamer thing, a novel of ideas. Matthew Flamm
