description: ROBINSON-Joan A. Butler, 69, in Manhattan, on January 7, 2003, of lung cancer and pneumonia. We wish to thank her friends for their support and friendship to our mom. We will all remember her wisdom, compassion and zest for life. Her sons, Adam, Matthew and Noah

title: In a Nutshell, Beauty Marks
description: ''Pretty City New York'' by Kim Weinstein ($11.95 at Saks Fifth Avenue) is a comprehensive Zagat-style guide to beauty-related products and services in New York.

title: Barkhagen (Who?) Blazes Through a Tournament
description: Upsets are far from unknown in chess. The game involves imagination, instinct and inspiration, and on a given day, a lesser player can rally magnificently. But when a player rallies through the whole nine-round Swiss System of the Rilton Cup in Stockholm, that's something else. Jonas Barkhagen of Sweden, an international master, won first place with a hot 7 1/2-1 1/2 score. In this tourney, Dec. 27 to Jan. 5, Barkhagen beat three grandmasters: Joseph Gallagher of Switzerland and Sergey Ivanov and Mikhail Ulibin of Russia.

title: Visions of Peril Dance in Her Head (but It's a Secret)
description: She used to be known as Raven-Symone, the tiny child actress who played the spirited Olivia on ''The Cosby Show.'' That gig ended almost 11 years ago. Now she is simply Raven, and at 17, with a couple of pop music CD's and several television and movie appearances behind her, she is the star of a new half-hour sitcom. ''That's So Raven,'' created for a 6- to 14-year-old audience, will have its premiere on Disney Channel in four back-to-back episodes on Friday at 7 p.m.

Daughter of the late Jacob and Anna, sister of the late Marcia Balsam and the late Shirley Gimple, aunt to Nina, Freda, Vivian, Alan and his wife Christina and great-aunt to Marcie, died at her home. She lived with grace, aged with grace and died with grace. Funeral Monday, January 13, 10 AM, at Gramercy Park Chapel, 152 Second Avenue.

Inspired by the success of Juicy Couture's belly-baring women's sports pants -- the company has also started offering a version for men ($60 at Barneys New York) -- designers are embracing the concept of hip-hugging leisure wear. Bella Dahl's pink velour sweats, far left, have star appliqus on the back ($118 at Saks Fifth Avenue) and Troo's black sweat pants, second from left, tie with a pink satin drawstring ($80 at Olive & Bette's).

title: Wings Beneath the Waves
description: I AM on the bottom of the ocean, at night. It is a peaceful place to be. A large flapping creature flies toward me. Its wings are 10 feet across. It has a tail, about 4 feet long, skinny, like the devil's. Its open mouth is wide enough that it could swallow me. My hindbrain kicks in, the thrill of anxiety, but best not to hyperventilate, in scuba gear, on the bottom of the ocean in Hawaii.

title: Crackdown on Drinking Targets Adults
description: ASK Jeanine Pirro if teenage drinking is a rite of passage, a stage that many passed through and many others will, and Ms. Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney, answers with the names of those who died young in accidents where a driver was drunk.

title: Technology; Beyond the Blackboard
description: IN its day, which lasted for centuries, the blackboard was as emblematic of education as textbooks and three-ring binders are today. Besides a little chalk dust and, yes, that unnerving screech the chalk occasionally makes, the blackboard was environmentally friendly -- made from natural material (slate), certainly energy efficient and, with enough erasers and chalk on hand, inexhaustibly interactive. Best of all, it was ideal for teaching large groups of students.

title: County Water Board Sues U.S. in Dispute Over Colorado River
description: Farmers in Southern California who use most of the state's disputed supply of Colorado River water have struck back at the federal government for taking some of it away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIASBERG, HAROLD
description: ELIASBERG-Harold. 88, a longtime resident of Sands Point, died in Phoenix, AZ, on January 10, 2003. He is survived by his wife Svea (Singer), his daughter Peggy (Cochran), his grandson Christopher (Cochran) and his brother Jay. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Cornell University in 1934, was a member of the New York Stock Exchange for 65 years and served as a Lieutenant - Commander in the US Navy in World War II.

title: The Back Seat Riders
description: MOST children want to ride in the front seat of the car because it is the cool thing to do. It makes them feel grown up and in charge In most cases, they are in charge. Despite all evidence that indicates the front seat is dangerous for those under 5 feet and 100 pounds, this is the place that children go to when they graduate from a booster seat. Never mind the impact of a crash; if the air bag deploys, the results can be disastrous. Air bags inflate at 200 miles per hour and can cause death, head injury and spinal cord damage. Factor in the number of children who are also allowed not to use seat belts, and the statistics become even more alarming.

title: Teamsters Take Control Of Elmsford Local
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters took direct emergency control of Local 456, based in Elmsford, last Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with a front-page article about the comeback of Bill Parcells misstated the number of football coaches besides him who have taken two different teams apiece to the Super Bowl. There have been three, not two: in addition to Don Shula and Dan Reeves, Dick Vermeil accomplished the feat, with Philadelphia and St. Louis.

description: BILLY COLLINS, the poet laureate of the United States, who lives in an antique farmhouse in Somers, likes to say that if you sat on the steps of the Katonah library for the last 35 years without moving ''nearly every notable American poet would walk by you.''

title: Judge Orders Group to Stop Promoting Income Tax Evasion
description: The widely promoted claim that Americans are not required to pay income taxes on their wages is false, a federal judge ruled Friday in ordering one of its leading proponents to stop inciting tax evasion.

title: January 5-11: NATIONAL; SONY SURPRISES
description: The Sony Corp. of America announced that Andrew Lack, the president and chief operating officer of NBC, would replace Thomas D. Mottola, who was forced out as chairman and chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment. Many in the music industry were shocked by the news because Mr. Lack, a seasoned television network executive, has no background in the music business. Instead, Mr. Lack is a close friend of Sir Howard Stringer, the chief executive of Sony Corp., since they worked together at CBS two decades ago. Laura M. Holson

title: Private Sector; Which Kind of Merger Is Harder: The Corporate or the Marital?
description: Gerald M. Levin, the beleaguered former chief executive of AOL Time Warner, may be about to start over. No, not with a new executive position. Mr. Levin, 63, who has been married to his wife, Barbara, for 32 years, has told several people that he is involved with a woman named Laurie Perlman, a former agent at the Creative Artists Agency who is now a psychologist. Mr. Levin, who did not return phone calls, has told his wife he intends to divorce, according to a person who knows him. Dr. Perlman did not return a phone call seeking comment.

He said that Arnold was a traitor and should have been hanged. Furthermore, he doesn't believe in rewriting history. ''I want to see the truth, no matter where the chips fall,'' he said.

description: WHENEVER Ira W. David hears about yet another big class-action lawsuit, he is overcome with mixed emotions.

description: As much as the Tampa Bay Buccaneers would like to tone down Warren Sapp's pronouncements, which the opposition can use as bulletin board motivation, sometimes he cannot stop himself.

title: The Cost of Winning at Science
description: I AM appalled whenever I hear about high school students trying to do research instead of concentrating on their fundamental education. Long Island school officials are spending millions of tax dollars to have their students win prizes in the Intel and Siemens science contests. That money would be better utilized if channeled to underachieving students or applied to the science training of high school teachers.

title: In Albuquerque, A Flea Market of Archaeology
description: FLYING into Albuquerque is a thrill: The Sandia Mountains, rosy at dusk, pop up like a gigantic dome from the sandy landscape. Perhaps that's why conquistadors who explored the area gave the range the name Sandia, ''watermelon'' in Spanish. Once we hopped over the peaks, we descended into a bowl of desert rimmed by distant blue mesas.

title: Lifeboat Long Island
description: LONG ISLAND governments have plenty of emergency plans and protocols for dealing with disasters like hurricanes, toxic spills, explosions and fire. Emergency officials say these same plans would make for a swift response to a terrorist incident.

title: Over-the-Counter Headache
description: Three years ago a strange cycle of headaches started to grip Linda Norton. In July 1999, after her husband received a promotion, she moved from a cozy house in the woods of New Hampshire to an upscale development in Hackettstown, N.J. A few days after the move, while unpacking boxes, she felt a mild throbbing in her head. Norton, a 42-year-old mother of three with glossy blond hair and a winsome smile, didn't make much of it; she hadn't had a headache since she was a teenager. She took some Tylenol, and the headache went away. But a few days later the pain came back -- it felt like a vise clamped around the back of her head -- and returned again a few days after that. It had to be the stress of moving, Norton concluded, figuring that her headaches would disappear once her family settled into their new home.

title: January 5-11: NATIONAL; BENEFITS FOR JOBLESS
description: Congress went back to work, and Republican leaders of the House and Senate, eager to take a political weapon away from Democrats, moved quickly to help Americans who have lost their jobs. The first bill enacted by the new Republican-controlled Congress extended federal jobless benefits for those who have used up their state assistance. Democrats complained that Republicans ignored about 1 million people who have already exhausted their federal and state aid but are still unemployed. Carl Hulse

title: Adolph Green
description: Adam Green's heartbreaking record of his father's last words, ''I want to go home,'' triggered a memory in me, one that a few minutes of research confirmed. The words ''I want to go home'' were also the title of one of the handful of feature films in which Adolph Green appeared as an actor. The French-produced picture, practically unheard of in the United States, was scripted by Jules Feiffer and directed by Alain Resnais.

Rabbi James Scott Glazier officiated at the Edson Hill Manor in Stowe, Vt.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Derelict Sites Developed, With History Given Its Due
description: WITH raw land scarce and the demand for new houses strong, builders are putting high-end homes on derelict sites in historically prime locations and incorporating aspects of their past in the designs.

title: Bush Proposes Big Increase in Securities Commission's Budget
description: President Bush made good today on a promise to seek a big increase in spending for the beleaguered Securities and Exchange Commission, saying that his budget for next year will propose a 73 percent increase from last year's level to help the commission fight corporate fraud.

title: A Loss of Support
description: FOR more than 20 years, social workers employed by the White Plains division of the New York Presbyterian Hospital have visited mentally ill patients regularly at their homes, checking on their health, taking them shopping for groceries, filing benefit applications for them, putting them into psychiatric treatment at times of crises and most often just chatting with them.

title: DETECTORS REQUIRED
description: Starting in mid-February, single-family and two-family homes that are built, sold or renovated must be equipped with carbon-monoxide detectors under new regulations by the state Department of Consumer Affairs. All multifamily buildings, hotels and boarding homes are now required to have the detectors. The new rules extend the requirement to all single-family and two-family homes. Karen DeMasters

title: BAYONNE SITE PREFERRED
description: A coalition of 11 New York television stations that want to build a 2,000-foot TV tower in Hudson County said last week in a letter to New Jersey's environmental commissioner, Bradley M. Campbell, that it considered a Bayonne site far superior to one in Jersey City in terms of size, security, environmental concerns, cost and construction timetables. Mr. Campbell had asked the group, the Metropolitan Television Alliance, on Dec. 12 to explain why it favored Bayonne. He also raised broader issues, saying the alliance had not shown that the tower would provide a ''substantial public benefit'' to the state. The tower, which the alliance says would be the world's tallest free-standing structure, would replace antennas that stood atop the World Trade Center. The alliance says it would restore quality TV reception for about 700,000 people in the metropolitan area, including many poor and elderly, who do not have cable television, and would be a boon to construction workers in the region. Robert Hanley

title: The Triumph Of Hope Over Self-Interest
description: Why don't people vote their own self-interest? Every few years the Republicans propose a tax cut, and every few years the Democrats pull out their income distribution charts to show that much of the benefits of the Republican plan go to the richest 1 percent of Americans or thereabouts. And yet every few years a Republican plan wends its way through the legislative process and, with some trims and amendments, passes.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IT wasn't Sinclair Lewis's finest novel, and it certainly wasn't Spencer Tracy's finest film (the original review in The New York Times called it ''as slick and as pat and as implausible as Mr. Lewis's yarn'') but CASS TIMBERLANE (1947) is definitely worth a look -- for the performances and for the theme. Tracy plays the title character, a sober, respectable Midwestern bachelor judge who marries a sexy, not entirely virtuous young blonde (Lana Turner) from the wrong side of town. Unfortunately, Timberlane's stuffy middle-aged friends have never heard of the trophy-wife concept (or just don't think it applies to a man's first marriage) and do not welcome her into their circle with open arms. What else can the Timberlanes do? They move to New York. George Sidney directed -- Tuesday at 6 p.m. on TCM.

title: The Landmarking Is Easy, But the Enforcing Is Hard
description: New York landmarks are born at 1 Centre Street, home to the Landmarks Preservation Commission. But preservation itself, staving off the effects of time and ignorance, falls to a grass-roots army of watchful neighbors and civic groups. The process may be cheap, but some suggest it is flawed.

title: Mediator Urges Direct Dialogue In Korea Crisis
description: Gov. Bill Richardson said today that his three days of unofficial talks with two North Korean envoys here had ''eased tensions a bit'' between North Korea and the United States. Speaking just hours after a North Korean diplomat in China had warned that his country might resume long-range ballistic missile tests, Mr. Richardson called on the Bush administration to engage in its own direct talks with the North.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, ALBERT I.
description: EDELMAN-Albert I. Our family mourns, with my sisterin-law Eleanor Edelman and her children Gwen, Thomas, Jennifer and Cornelia, and grandchildren Elizabeth and Eleanor, the loss of my dear brother Albie. A star has fallen but it will live forever in our minds' eyes as we recall his quick response and steady and wise hand in any family crisis and life-long contributions in the legal profession, to his country and to scientific and educational institutions. His great intelligence, high spirits, good cheer and wit and his brilliant and humorous verses composed for many occasions will never be forgotten. A memorial service will be held at 11AM Monday, January 13th, Temple Emanu - El, 65th Street and 5th Avenue. Contributions may be made to the RU Council of Rockefeller University. Ruth and Dan Edelman Richard and Roz Edelman and children Margot, Tory and Amanda Edelman Renee Edelman John Edelman

title: PATROL CARS GROUNDED
description: The Bergen County Police Department grounded its Crown Victoria patrol cars last week to install shields to prevent their gas tanks from being punctured and exploding in high-impact rear-end collisions. Officers were using other cars to make their rounds; the retrofitting of all 39 Crown Victorias is to be completed next week. Several county and municipal departments in New Jersey have stepped up efforts to have the shields installed, citing concerns after the death last month of a New York State trooper whose parked cruiser burst into flames after being rear-ended. The Bergen County Sheriff's Department reported that nearly 40 of its 49 Crown Victorias had been fitted with the shields. George James

title: POSTINGS: White Plains Site Sells for $39.9 Million; Shopping Mall Changes Hands
description: Urstadt Biddle Properties has acquired the 185,000-square-foot Westchester Pavilion shopping mall in White Plains, site of an Alexander's department store from the 1950's to 1994, for $39.9 million.

Morty's diplomacy and wonderful sense of humor will live on in our memories. The Trustees and staff extend their condolences to his family and loved ones.

title: Gibb, Bassist for Bee Gees, Dies
description: Maurice Gibb, who wrote songs and sang high harmonies in the Bee Gees through decades of hits and more than 120 million albums sold worldwide, died shortly after midnight on Sunday morning at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami, where he had lived. He was 53 years old.

title: AOL Chairman Quits His Post Amid Criticism
description: Stephen M. Case, the former chief executive of America Online who engineered its acquisition of Time Warner, resigned tonight as chairman of the combined company, AOL Time Warner, bowing to shareholder anger over the disappointing results of the merger. He will remain as a board member.

title: UPDATE/Newark; What's Going On at Maize?
description: When Maize opened in May 2000 -- a luxury restaurant opposite the New Jersey Performing Arts Center -- critics greeted it as an inspired piece of urban renewal. The food and wine and service struck me as pretty terrific too. But in recent months the restaurant has hit some deep potholes. Maize is now on its fourth executive chef: Terrence Soto, a 29-year-old Newark native who was a member of the original team. Even without knowing about these shufflings, a diner could have sensed that something was amiss. On recent visits, dishes were correctly presented, but they didn't soar -- or even leave the plate (in the case of mushy stuffed calamari). The wine list was largely intact, but the staff didn't seem to know much about it. Even on a Saturday night, more than half the tables were empty.

description: Melinda Williams's sons always seemed to end up in the basement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSKIND, IDA LEVINE
description: SUSKIND-Ida Levine. It is with great sadness that the Suskind family marks the death of their Matriarch, Ida Suskind. Ida died quietly on January 9 in Bridgehampton, NY, where she moved permanently a few years ago. Ida grew up on Staten Island, where she lived with her late husband, Morris Suskind. She is celebrated by her surviving family: her son, Dennis Suskind, and daughter-in-law, Cynthia, her grandchildren, Jay, Debra, Brian, John, Pamela and Audrey, as well as four great-grandchildren. Her daughter, Lorraine Gootenberg, passed away late last year. She is also survived by her sister, Libby and her dear friend, Angie. Services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., on Monday, January 13, at 11:30 AM. Contributions in her name may be made to the Bridgehampton Food Pantry, Bridgehampton, NY 11932, or the Arthur Ashe Institute for Urban Health, 450 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11203.

title: Private Sector; Take the Award. Hold the Haggis.
description: What do Robert Burns, the 18th-century Scottish poet, and Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, have in common? Both will be honored tomorrow at the annual Burns night supper sponsored by ScottishPower, a British energy company that owns PacifiCorp in the United States. Ian M. Russell, ScottishPower's chief executive, said the company was giving Mr. Grasso its first ''values'' award, for his strong stance on corporate governance, his leadership after the Sept. 11 attacks and his effort to attract more foreign companies.

title: Gabriel Almond, Influential Political Scientist and Author, Dies at 91

title: A Cup Runneth Over
description: IT'S hard to remember now, but in the distant Middle Earthian time before the dark empire of Starbucks came to rule the suburbs, there were places called teahouses. My Cup of Tea began life that way, in Fair Lawn, several towns (and income-tax brackets) south of Allendale.

title: Drunken Driving Deaths Take a Disturbing Turn
description: NOVEMBER, 2001: A drunk freshman slams his car into a University of Connecticut pharmacy student as she is walking across North Eagleville Road. The pharmacy student dies from her injuries.

title: UConn's Okafor Soars in Overtime
description: Emeka Okafor scored 5 straight points in overtime today to lift third-ranked Connecticut to an 83-80 victory over Miami in the Huskies' Big East opener.

title: Investing; Many May Not Feel Dividend Plan's Impact for Years
description: MARK BROOK, 43, the owner of a home-building supply company in Oceanside, N.Y., is ecstatic about the possibility that most taxes on dividends will be eliminated.

title: Islanders Continue Hat Trick Habit
description: Hundreds of pairs of blue boxer shorts sailed onto the ice. With Islanders fans already running low on hats, they saluted Jason Blake by hurling the underwear they had been given as a promotion.

title: Lox, Stock and Barrels
description: When I walk the mile or so from my apartment in SoHo to Russ & Daughters on East Houston Street near Orchard, on Manhattan's suddenly stylish Lower East Side, I experience that enlargement of the soul felt by ancient worshipers as they blissfully approached the temples of their gods.

title: Cyrus Vance
description: Douglas Brinkley's charge that I should have informed Secretary of State Cyrus Vance, who was on a weekend vacation, about a meeting of the National Security Council regarding the 1980 hostage-rescue mission ignores fundamental facts. I was informed that a meeting would take place on Friday, April 11, 1980, but Zbigniew Brzezinski, the national security adviser, instructed his office not to reveal what the subject matter of the meeting would be. Therefore, it would have been impossible for me to alert Vance that a meeting on the rescue mission would take place.

title: So Nice, You Apply Twice
description: LAST fall, Ezekiel Pfeifer of Catonsville, Md., and more than 67,000 other high school seniors applied to college under an early decision plan, which is binding -- if accepted, you are obligated to go. Zeke's No. 1 choice was Pomona College in Claremont, Calif.

title: California Waves; Los Angeles Becomes A Base for Cutting-Edge Performance
description: IN the beginning, there were mountains and beaches and deserts and American Indians and, a little later, some scattered Spanish villages and orange groves. Then urbanity and suburbanity connected the villages, turning Los Angeles into a sprawling metropolis dominated artistically by the entertainment industry.

title: Experts Doubt Repeal Can Hold
description: AFTER a legislative vote Monday night, Las Vegas Nights no longer are legal in Connecticut. But legal scholars and gaming authorities said the state's latest move to limit casino gambling may be difficult to hold up in court.

title: January 5-11: NATIONAL; A CANDIDATE NO MORE
description: Everything seemed to be in place. Tom Daschle, the Senate minority leader, had scheduled a trip home to Aberdeen, S.D., to announce that he was seeking the Democratic nomination for president. His aides had charted a trip that would take him to Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina, important primary states. He had nailed down a campaign manager and top campaign staff. He had called Democratic officials saying that he was getting in the race.

title: Lynbrook Company Testing Fat Buster
description: LIKE countless other Long Islanders, Vicki O'Keefe of Babylon made a New Year's resolution to lose weight. The fact that Ms. O'Keefe, 49, has made the same resolution every year since she was 14 should not suggest that she is not serious: in years past she has gone to great lengths, from liquid diets to liposuction. But every year she falls off the wagon.

title: I Love Not Woman the Less, but Man More
description: BYRON

title: Perspectives Heard From Two Points of View
description: Mitsuko Uchida, who recently turned 54, is one of the most interesting pianists around, as the Cleveland Orchestra has already acknowledged and Carnegie Hall is about to. On Feb. 3, Ms. Uchida opens a two-season Perspectives series at Carnegie, performing and conducting two Mozart concertos with the Cleveland Orchestra.

title: Executive Life; On the Inside Track in Venture Capital
description: FROM her desk at Mayfield, a venture capital firm in Menlo Park, Calif., Julie Hanna Farris founded her first company in June. But she did so from within one of the most coveted yet loosely defined relationships possible with those who put up the money -- as an entrepreneur in residence.

title: Be Ready for a Long Line. Once.
description: FOR decades, New Jersey drivers have been able to avoid that dreaded trip to the office of the Division of Motor Vehicles by filling out and mailing in a form to renew their licenses. But starting in July, those drivers, more than one million of them, will have to get in line.

title: In Search of Mother's Molecules
description: WHEN the new $36.5 million science building opens on Jan. 23 at Agnes Scott, the liberal arts college in Decatur, Ga., a three-story-tall mural in the atrium will serve as an appropriate tribute: it depicts the DNA double helix, the most important molecule of the recent era in science. It also replicates the DNA of its namesake, an Irish immigrant whose industrialist son was the college's chief financial backer.

title: Private Sector; Marshaling Troops and Money
description: Lehman Brothers' chief executive, Richard S. Fuld Jr., seems to think about his staff as an army on Wall Street's bloodied battleground. On Thursday in London, he gave a military-like acceptance speech for winning the award for bank of the year at banking's version of the Oscars, held by the International Financing Review. With cigar smoke wafting from Lehman's tables and at least one reveler drinking Champagne from the bottle, Mr. Fuld directed his employees to take a bow. ''Lehman stand! Let the troops be recognized!'' he ordered, as some in the audience chuckled. And even as layoffs rise on Wall Street, Mr. Fuld made sure his ''troops'' were not beaten in the charitable-giving battle by Citigroup. At the last minute, he pledged 230,000 ($368,000) to Save the Children. ''My original bid was 10,000,'' he acknowledged. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: These Gold Diggers Are Having a Ball
description: MIKE RACE doesn't like to be called a treasure hunter, though that's exactly what he is.

title: Opponents of Indian Pt. Are Quick to Add Report's Criticisms to Their Arsenal
description: Richard L. Brodsky was working frantically yesterday, making phone calls and sending e-mail, capitalizing on an independent report echoing some of his longtime criticism of the Indian Point nuclear plant.

title: Life, and Death, at a Foundry
description: To the Editor:

title: DataBank; Tax Proposal Brightens the Mood in Stocks
description: Stock prices added to their 2003 advance last week, helped by President Bush's $674 billion tax-cut proposal. The plan included as its centerpiece the elimination of the double taxation of dividends.

title: Corrections
description: An author identification on Dec. 22 with the Choice Tables column, about restaurants in the Piedmont region of Italy, misstated the title of a book written by the columnist, Maureen B. Fant, with Howard M. Isaacs. It is Dictionary of Italian Cuisine, not simply Cuisine.

title: Corrections
description: Credits last Sunday for two editorial cartoons last were reversed. The top one, about President Bush and North Korea, was by Jimmy Margulies of The Record. The bottom one, about Republicans in Congress, was by Ed Gamble of The Florida Times-Union.

title: Delivery Denied
description: My aunt lives in a public housing project in the Bronx. While visiting her, I tried to order Chinese food, but I was told by the employee taking orders that the restaurant did not deliver to the projects because it was not safe for their deliverers. The restaurant did place the menu under our door, and it advertises ''free delivery.'' Is it right for them to deny me delivery? Jos Ferrer, New York

title: Coming to the Rescue of Run-Down Libraries
description: MY team and I have built or restored more than 75 libraries since I joined the Hillier Group 24 years ago. My first job was developing the Ocean County Library in Toms River, N.J. There was an old library near an abandoned Methodist church in the center of town. The church was so neglected that there were pigeon droppings 10 feet deep in the steeple. We renovated the library and created a park to link it to the church and to a new library behind the church. The abandoned church became the meeting room of the new library. Now, a quarter-century later, the library board has brought me back to build an addition to the library.

title: Streetscapes/Fulton Street Between Nassau and Williams Streets; A Vibrant and Noisy Block With Varied Architecture
description: THERE'S a sad empty gap at the western end of Fulton Street, where the World Trade Center once stood, but two blocks east, traffic noise and storefront hullabaloo enliven the vibrant and architecturally varied section between Nassau and William Streets. The block was built up over a century and a half, and its architectural evolution continues, with several renovation projects under way.

title: Chasing The Threads In the Life Of Ralph Lauren
description: IN nearly every rags-to-riches story, particularly ones involving the rag trade, the protagonist learns about life from the movies. Norman Norell, who was born Norman Levinson in Noblesville, Ind., owed much of his big-city panache to a star-struck youth. Manolo Blahnik, the son of banana growers, escaped the isolation of the Canary Islands by going to the cinema. John Weitz, whose bold life could have been a movie, married a Hollywood ingnue and fathered a pair of directors.

title: Harmonious Choice
description: To the Editor:

description: YOUMAN-William H. It has been a year since we celebrated your life at your memorial. This year has been extremely challanging and difficult without you. You are missed more with each passing day. We love you. Donald, Sonya, Eddie, Veronica, Monique, JaVaughn, Quintae, Keyana, Aaron, Bryce, Your Friends at SONY Music Entertainment & Production Control and your loving wife Mercede

description: GOLMAN-Reine. Memorial service at Workmen's Circle, 45 E. 33rd St., New York City on Tuesday, January 14th at 12:30PM.

description: THE Rhodes is just one of a number of international fellowships coveted for their prestige and opportunity. The programs, which pay tuition and a stipend, seek postgraduates who have demonstrated academic excellence and leadership potential in their fields. SARA IVRY

description: Lewis and Clark, and Jefferson

description: To the Editor:

title: Confessions of a Macabre Tourist
description: I WASN'T, my parents assure me, an especially morbid child. Family legend records no bedtime pleading for Edgar Allan Poe stories, no infantile forays into taxidermy: I was never caught stuffing and mounting the corpse of my pet iguana. Then why do I now find myself so drawn to all the dank and musty places from which tour groups shrink?

title: Dance Listings
description: ALTOGETHER DIFFERENT  Today, 2: Keely Garfield presents "My Mother Was a Four Alarm Fire" and "Free Drinks for Ladies . . . " Today, 7:30; Tue., 8: Peter Boal will dance to three new works by Wendy Perron, Albert Evans and Molissa Fenley. Wed., 8: ZviDance will perform two new works by Zvi Gotheiner to original sound scores by the composer Scott Killian. Thur., Sat., 8; next Sun., 2: Donna Uchizono Company will offer a premiere and perform "Low." Fri., Sat., 8; next Sun., 7:30: Sara Pearson/Patrik Widrig and Company gives the premiere of its dance-theater epic "The Ballad of Lot's Wife." Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Ave., at 19th St. (212-242-0800) Through next Sun.

title: The Nation; Reform? Republicans Reconsider
description: ONE of the first things Republicans did in 1995 after they took control of the House was to adopt tighter ethics rules for House members, in response to what they saw as decades of Democratic arrogance and abuse.

title: January 5-11
description: BRITAIN, READYING FOR COMBAT — Britain took its much anticipated first step at mobilizing for combat in Iraq, but the numbers were less than had been expected. The government tried to assure the skeptical British public that war was not inevitable and that support for the United States-led campaign against Iraq was, in the words of Prime Minister Tony Blair, "massively in our self-interest." Mr. Blair acknowledged to a gathering of British diplomats that anti-Americanism was on the rise, but said it was a "foolish indulgence." Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon told Parliament that Britain was calling up 1,500 reserves and augmenting a naval task force now training in the Mediterranean — far short of informed predictions that he would summon 7,000 reserves to active duty and begin the dispatch of the first of Britain's 20,000-man ground force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISKIN, MARY C.
description: DISKIN-Mary C. 88, of Westhampton Beach, NY, and Havertown, PA, on January 10, 2003. Predeceased by her husbnd of 59 years, Thomas A. Diskin, and is survived by four children, Thomas Diskin, Dover, NH, Mary Freeman, San Diego, CA, Anne Smalley, McLean, VA, and Peter Diskin, Havertown, PA; eight grandchildren, two greatgrandchildren. Visitation Monday, January 13, 2003, 2-4 and 7-9, at Follett and Werner Funeral Home, Westhampton Beach, NY. Mass will be celebrated at 11 on Tuesday morning at the the Immaculate Conception Church, Westhampton Beach.

title: Stephen Abrams, Douglas Harrison Jr.
description: Stephen James Abrams, a son of Diane and Stephen S. Abrams of Oradell, N.J., and Dr. Douglas James Harrison Jr., a son of Dr. Joan T. Harrison and Mr. Harrison of Falmouth, Mass., celebrated their partnership on Friday in New York. The Rev. Mary Foulke led the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Luke in the Fields.

title: Private Sector; A New Kind of Tabloid Tycoon
description: WHEN Sly Bailey officially starts her new job next month as the chief executive of Trinity Mirror, the largest newspaper publisher in Britain, she will face the kind of drama worthy of a backbiting tabloid story.

title: Monique Wittig, 67, Feminist Writer, Dies
description: Monique Wittig, a French writer and literary theorist whose imaginative, fiercely innovative books tried to create a new mythology for the feminist movement, died Jan. 3 in Tucson. She was 67 and lived in Tucson.

title: Inge Morath
description: In a few short lines, Arthur Miller tells it all regarding his love for his late wife, Inge Morath, and the stark reality of her losing a personal battle with cancer: ''We thought she was licking it, she was beating it. That is what we were told'' (What They Were Thinking).

title: Is Parking The Cure For Traffic Headache?
description: RELIEVE congestion; park your car. That's the message from the state as it starts rolling on a plan to add 20,000 parking spaces in the next five years at train stations and bus stops around the state.

title: Upward Mobility And Downright Lies
description: YOU want to end up back in the projects? Keep dreaming dreams that'll never happen,'' warns the heroine's mother in ''Maid in Manhattan,'' when it looks like her daughter the chambermaid has lost the rich, handsome politician she loves. Gee, thanks, Mom.

title: The World; Infectious Chaos In West Africa
description: KOFI ANNAN, the United Nations secretary general, warned last week that the Ivory Coast's civil war threatened the recently restored stability of Sierra Leone. It was an indication that West Africa's pockets of chaos could spread.

title: For Oracle's Dickson, Second Place Is Nowhere
description: After a lifetime of sailing, months of hard work with his Oracle-BMW team and dozens of kidney-jolting sailboat races on the frothy waters of the Hauraki Gulf, Chris Dickson is where every aspiring America's Cup skipper hopes to be: in the finals of the Cup Challenger series. He is racing against a childhood rival in his fellow New Zealander Russell Coutts.

title: Putting All the Eggs in a One-Stop Basket Can Be Messy
description: TO the architects who build them, integrated financial services empires have the allure of immense profits. But for the customers of these one-stop financial entities, perils often result.

title: Pop Quiz; If You Mean Business
description: The appeal of an M.B.A. shows no signs of abating: almost 245,000 Graduate Management Admissions Tests were given in 2001-02, up 15 percent from the previous year and 180 percent from 1970-71. Theorists point to the sour economy, which traditionally sends people into hiding -- or into a new career. The degree would not be enjoying this kind of historic popularity if it didn't deliver results, in jobs and salaries, notes Daphne Atkinson, a vice president at the Graduate Management Admissions Council. Below, a sample from G.M.A.T. reasoning sections.

title: Milton Berle
description: Your year-end issue filled me with nostalgia for those who checked out in 2002. I enjoyed Frank Rich's article on Milton Berle. The anecdote about his being stranded with Berle in Joe Franklin's greenroom put it all in perspective.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: HESSEL-Miriam. Beloved wife of the late Alexander. Mother of Judy and Nomi, mother-in-law of Stephen and Andrew, loving grandmother of Samantha, Jeremy and Jonathan. Sister of Estelle Berger. She will be missed by all who knew her and loved her.

title: The Nation: Top Drawer; Defining the Rich in the World's Wealthiest Nation
description: THEY have become the most discussed social group in the United States. Yet few people acknowledge being a member, and there is little agreement about what qualifies one for inclusion.

title: 'Motown'
description: Berry Gordy Jr. was the seventh of eight children, born in Detroit on Thanksgiving Day, November 28, 1929, just at the onset of the Great Depression. His father was the son of freed Georgia slaves who had become sharecroppers of a 168-acre patch of barren farmland that had yielded barely enough to keep the family going. Twenty-three children were born there, but fourteen died at or shortly after birth. Those who survived were tough. The mulatto Berry Gordy Sr.-his own father was the child of a slave and her white plantation owner-was a short, wiry man who did not get to high school until he was twenty-two because his family could not spare him from the backbreaking farming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURZWEIL, MILBURN SIDNEY
description: KURZWEIL-Milburn Sidney. Loving father to Brett and father-in-law to Audrey, and grandpa Mel to Danielle, died peacefully January 10. Your life will be remembered like a joyful song.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOILO, A. MARC
description: ZOILO-A. Marc. Of Weston, CT, passed on January 9, 2003. Retired Brooks Brothers executive, he made many outstanding contributions to the development and growth of Brooks Brothers during his 31 years with the company. Since retirement Marc was active with many civic and volunteer organizations, among them 15 years with SCORE-Service Corps of Retired Executives. A 1944 alumnus of the University of Notre Dame, he loved his Norte Dame football. Survivors include daughter Daphne Rich, sons Marc Jr. and John, and granddaughter Stephanie. Calling hours are from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM, January 13, at Bouton Funeral Home, Georgetown, CT.

title: Resignations and Turmoil at the Atheneum
description: THE turmoil at the Wadsworth Atheneum -- where six board members have resigned while the museum is in the middle of a $120 million capital campaign and expansion, and also searching for a new director, because the current one has resigned as well -- might make a worthy subject for an Old Master's canvas.

description: HERE'S some bad news for students who put off studying: procrastinators get more cold and flu symptoms and have more digestive problems than their punctual classmates.

description: THE National Football League needs to bite the bullet and make its officials full-time employees. The officials do a good job, but good is no longer good enough.

description: POLITICAL antagonists of President Bush attacked what they described as his lack of sufficient action on global warming last week, but his administration held firm, saying cautious measures were best while the science surrounding climate change and the human factors contributing to it remained uncertain.

We extend our deepest sympathy and heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Claire Schussler, and family. description: Eliza Ridlon Culbertson, a daughter of Deborah Culbertson and the Rev. Dr. Thomas Culbertson of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Arryn Wayne Milne, the son of Gail Duggan of Auckland, New Zealand, and Neville Milne of Baltimore. The bride's father, who is the rector of the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Baltimore, performed the ceremony there.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bittersweet Memories Of a Fight for Change
description: WHEN Calvin Spann was growing up in Rutherford in the 1930's and 1940's, he watched the planes at Teterboro take off and land. He read the comic strip ''Smilin' Jack,'' about a pilot, and dreamed of becoming one. In May 1943, before he graduated from high school, he took a college equivalency test, which qualified him for the Army Air Corps.

title: FAILING GRADES ON TOBACCO
description: New Jersey received mostly failing grades in a survey by the American Lung Association comparing states' uses of tobacco settlement money and cigarette taxes. The state got an A for imposing a cigarette tax of $1.50 a pack, the highest in the nation after Massachusetts. But it received an F for both its laws to protect people from secondhand smoke and its measures to stop children from smoking. And it was given a D for spending on efforts to discourage smoking. It will spend $31 million this year on such efforts, including the use of money from the 1998 settlement with tobacco companies. Nicole Zamerovsky, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey chapter of the lung association, said that amount is expected to grow in the next four years, to give New Jersey an A in that category. Karen DeMasters

description: Gloom and Doom

title: Balanced Scoring by Red Storm Only Adds to the Bruins' Misery
description: There is a new tradition at U.C.L.A., far different from the one maintained year after year during the John Wooden era. This one is about losing, and it is becoming more familiar with each game.

title: Nuclear Mediators Resort To Political Mind Reading
description: An Asian diplomat emerged from one of the many meetings on defusing the North Korean nuclear crisis saying that no one could know what Kim Jong Il wants: a nuclear arsenal or new relationship with the West.

title: The War Against Women
description: Running for the White House in the fall of 2000, George W. Bush did not talk about ending the right to abortion. To avoid scaring off moderate voters, he promoted a larger ''reverence for life'' agenda that also included adoption and tougher drunken driving laws. Voters were encouraged to believe that while Mr. Bush was anti-choice, he was not out to reverse Roe v. Wade.

description: MOGER-Madeleine. On January 8, 2003. Services on January 12, 3 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations to Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, NYC 10022.

description: IT was only a few years ago that Chinese leaders fretted about what might happen if their citizens gained access to the Internet.

title: Earth's Beautiful Fury, Up Close
description: ''AIR quality is GOOD!'' exclaimed the handwritten sign at the edge of the lava field. ''Yes, red lava from this trail tonight!''
