description: Featuring the 20th-Century

title: Chasing Stardom In the New Hollywood
description: FOLLOWING the lead of its kitschy cousin Times Square, Hollywood has been getting a long-awaited makeover. Some of the best-known thoroughfares, like Hollywood Boulevard, have exchanged sleaze for shopping with touristy extravaganzas like the new Hollywood and Highland mall, the colossal, open-air bazaar modeled after the stage set of D.W. Griffith's 1916 historical allegory, ''Intolerance'' -- including elephant sculptures on 100-foot-high columns.

title: Connecticut Delays Cross-Sound Cable
description: The Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection has told the company that owns the power cable strung along the bottom of Long Island Sound between Shoreham and New Haven that unless the cable is properly buried, it will be a violation of its construction permit to operate it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, C. DOUGLAS
description: DILLON-C. Douglas. 93 of Hobe Sound, FL. Beloved husband of Susan, father of Phyllis D. Collins and Joan Duchesse de Mouchy, grandfather of Joan Frost, Ambika Collins, Mark Collins, Douglas Collins, Charlotte Cunningham, Robert Luxembourg and 15 great-grandchildren, died on January 10, after a long illness. He was precedeased by his first wife Phyllis Ellsworth in 1982. He had been Secretary of the Treasury, Ambassador to France, Under Secretary of State, Chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Chairman of the Brookings Institution, and President of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University among many other positions of distinction and high public honor. Funeral services will be private. The family has indicated that any memorial gifts should be sent to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, NY, NY 10028.

title: Leaping Into Brooklyn Saying, 'Let's Be Neighbors'
description: THE choreographer Elizabeth Streb's new dance center in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is intended to beckon the curious passerby. The one-story brick building, once occupied by the Dutch Mustard Company, has 5,000 square feet of unobstructed space, a 27-foot ceiling and a large sliding door on the front.

title: Easy Rider
description: THE ride board -- ''Seeking ride to New York! Will pay for gas!'' ''Anybody going to Philly?'' -- has been a campus essential for generations. But like so many things, the Internet has given the board an electronic spin.

title: Habitats/Bleecker Street, West Village; A Tiny Town House Gets A Feeling of Openness
description: SOME town houses in Manhattan are almost too grand, with cavernous rooms and staircases that are forbiddingly high. At the other extreme is the tiny house on Bleecker Street that Laura Bilyeu and Joel Leib bought two and a half years ago.

title: Breast Cancer Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Trail of Pain in Church Crisis Leads to Nearly Every Diocese
description: The sexual abuse crisis that engulfed the Roman Catholic Church in the last 12 months has now spread to nearly every American diocese and involves more than 1,200 priests, most of whose careers straddle a sharp divide in church history and seminary training.

title: In Virtual Museums, an Archive of the World
description: On a simple table, under a bright light, the fossilized skull of a protoceratops is waiting for its close-up. Once the portrait is made by a high-resolution digital camera, it will take its place online with 8,000 other fossil images and more than 200,000 catalog entries of vertebrate and invertebrate fossils in the collection of the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Oms at High Temperatures In a New Chappaqua Studio
description: Hot yoga has come to Chappaqua. Yoga Mania, a new yoga studio, is offering classes in a studio heated to 105 degrees. Known as Bikram yoga after its creator, Bikram Choudhury, the practice involves a sequence of 26 hatha yoga positions and incorporates meditation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUKAT, SCOTT
description: SHUKAT-Scott. Beloved husband of Evelyn Shukat, M.D. Devoted father of Jonathan. Dear son of Harry and Florence Shukat. Loving brother of Peter and Yvette Shukat and Susan Kasten. Adoring uncle. Service 10am Sunday at ''The Riverside'', 76th St & Amsterdam Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Lincoln Hospital Auxiliary Fund Child Advocacy Center, c/o Lincoln Hospital, 234 E. 149th St, Bronx, NY 10451.

title: January 5-11: NATIONAL; NEW LABELS FOR ESTROGEN
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced that all estrogen drugs and drugs combining estrogen and progestin that are used to relieve symptoms of menopause must warn, in a black-rimmed box, of their health risks. A large federal study indicated that one drug, Prempro, increases the chance a woman will develop heart disease, stroke, blood clots and breast cancer. But the agency said that unless other drugs are proved to be safer, doctors and women must assume that they carry the same risks. Gina Kolata

title: Jordan Draws Fans, but Oakley Lifts Wizards Over Knicks
description: For one of the few times this season, Madison Square Garden was packed at tip-off last night, and the Knicks' improved play had nothing to do with it. Michael Jordan was in the house, 39 years old but still capable of brilliance, and Knicks fans wanted to see him for one of the last times.

title: How the Study of Sexual Abuse by Priests Was Conducted
description: As the scandal of sexual abuse by priests roiled the Roman Catholic Church and the country, the true dimension of the problem remained elusive. Was it a crisis that was overblown by lawyers and the news media, as some church defenders say? Or was it a growing malignancy deep in the culture of the church?

title: New Philanthropists Find Drudgery
description: Among a certain slice of society in the booming days of the late 1990's, starting a private foundation was every bit as de rigueur as taking a company public or commuting to the office on a private helicopter. For many, it was an easy way to flaunt success, ensure legacies and put their wealth to charitable use.

title: Adolph Green
description: Adolph Green was a hero of mine. His work with Betty Comden was the soundtrack of my childhood and the beacon of hope and possibilities in dismal times.

title: Shockey and Owens
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTONE, JEANNETTE
description: GLADSTONE - Jeannette. The Samuel and Sara Gladstone Family Circle notes with sorrow the death of our Aunt Jeannette, wife of Murray. She is the last of the original twelve & their spouses.

title: View; Speaking in Tongues
description: AT the start of the Nixon administration, Attorney General John N. Mitchell advised reporters: ''Watch what we do, not what we say.'' In the world of educational politics, however, watching what people say reveals a lot -- about what they know and what they don't, and what they believe. Parsing the language may help us understand what education leaders are really up to.

title: A Disturbing Vision Of the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Laughing Through the Pain In the Holy Land
description: IN the Palestinian filmmaker Elia Suleiman's vision of the Holy Land, motorboats pull water-skiers across the lake where Jesus walked. Souvenir bottles of ''sacred water'' are filled at the tap. Soldiers go haywire and begin folk dancing at checkpoints. And Santa is stabbed by a bunch of street kids from Nazareth.

title: Small Trattoria That Delivers a Big Punch
description: IN the heart of Cross River, at the busy junction of Routes 35 and 121, sits Bacio, the little trattoria that could. Where bigger, more boastful restaurants fail to deliver, the determined Bacio brings simple food full of flavor to the lucky residents of Katonah, Lewisboro and beyond.

title: Multiplying Scents
description: Like double-caffeinated espressos that give extra punch, perfume makers are stirring up concentrated versions of their fragrances. Este Lauder offers a scent-saturated version of its original Pleasures with Pleasures Intense ($45 at Bloomingdale's), and spicy top notes of ginger and pepper make Lancme's Miracle Intense more pungent ($55 at Bergdorf Goodman). L'Artisan Parfumeur's Ambre Extrme contains four times the amber and sandalwood of its regular Ambre scent ($85 at Bergdorf Goodman), and Origins has pumped up notes of ginger, bergamot, lemon and lime to give its Ginger Essence Intensified scent a greater kick ($39.50). A higher concentration of fragrance in Clinique's Happier Perfume Concentrate is intended to give a longer-lasting scent experience than just plain Happy ($42.50 at Saks Fifth Avenue).

title: Don't Let the Healing Begin
description: Faxes sent by the Oakland Raiders come with a cover page. On that page is a photograph of Charles Woodson, a Raiders cornerback, about to strip the ball from Tom Brady, quarterback of the New England Patriots. In the final minutes of last year's snowy American Football Conference playoff game in New England, the Patriots were trailing the Raiders, 13-10, when Woodson knocked the ball loose, and the Raiders recovered. One official called a fumble. But then another called for a replay and, minutes later, it was determined that Brady hadn't fumbled. The official said that Brady was in the process of tucking the ball under his arm, which by rule made it an incomplete pass.

title: When Rents Exceed Legal Limits
description: IN the various interactions between tenants and landlords, few are as vexing as disputes over overcharges in rent-regulated apartments.

title: Enter the Dragon Coach
description: AS savvy New Yorkers will tell you, the streets of Chinatown are rife with bargains: Prada bags for mere peanuts, CD players at eight-track prices. But Chrissy Piper, a 30-year-old photographer from Red Hook, Brooklyn, has found a deal that beats them all.

title: Hardcover Highlights
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: Sling Low, Swing High
description: Now the truly fashion-boundcan wriggle out of their low-rise jeans at day's end and slip into a pair of low-rise sweat pants. Inspired by the success of Juicy Couture's belly-baring women's sports pants  the company has also started offering a version for men ($60 at Barneys New York )  designers are embracing the concept of hip-hugging leisure wear. Bella Dahl's pink velour sweats have star appliques on the back ($118 at Saks Fifth Avenue) and Troo's black sweat pants tie with a pink satin drawstring ($80 at Olive & Bette's).

title: How to Win a Rhodes
description: When Keri Steffes, a senior with a 4.0 average at the University of Arkansas's honors college, is asked exactly when she began the application process for a Rhodes Scholarship, she says: ''Freshman year really, that's when they start talking to you about it. They're like, 'You can be a Rhodes, you can be a Marshall Scholar' -- and you've been on campus two months!''

title: A Neo-Modernist Is Having His Moment
description: ON a recent Tuesday morning in this city's booming Pearl District, the Allied Works Architecture office was in flux. The firm had moved to a historic two-story brick building over the weekend, and renovations were not yet complete. While young architects conversed over drawings and computer screens, a construction worker fastened a final swatch of carpeting to the floor. Scaffolding clogged the exterior. And Brad Cloepfil, the founder of Allied Works and a rising star of American architecture, was running late -- he had driven to the old office by mistake.

title: Alinghi Tops Oracle in Opener
description: It took all of 10 minutes today to find out who had the faster boat in the first race of the America's Cup challenger series.

title: The Underground Men
description: ON a slate-gray afternoon at a Midtown construction site, seven men in hard hats and yellow rain gear stepped into a steel cage suspended over a dark hole nearly 60 stories deep. The last man on board latched the door shut, and the cage sank away from daylight and toward a sonorous, mechanical roar far below. The men inserted earplugs and then bowed their heads and folded their hands, as though observing a somber ceremony.

title: Nuclear
description: President George W. Bush pronounced malfeasance without its s in July 2002, adding to the growing collection of his verbal gaffes, dubbed Bushisms. Web sites listing Bushisms are legion. Bush has a well-documented habit of tripping over words, especially when, as with subliminal and malfeasance, they're somewhat bookish.

title: Polish Pride, American Profits
description: WHEN Aleksander Kwasniewski, the president of Poland, visits with President Bush at the White House on Tuesday, talk will inevitably turn to the F-16 fighter jet. Over the Christmas season, almost unnoticed, Poland announced it was accepting a $3.8 billion loan from Congress, the largest military loan in memory, to buy 48 of those Fighting Falcons.

title: BEST SELLERS: January 12, 2003
description: Weeks

title: Miami
description: For many vacationers, Miami means Miami Beach -- a separate and sizable city (population almost 88,000) across Biscayne Bay from mainland Miami. But while Miami Beach's lure is undeniable as well as historic (its early developer, Carl Fisher, planned the place to be a ''city like magic''), some of South Florida's most interesting attractions are elsewhere in the countywide area referred to as Greater Miami.

title: Honors for a Southampton Composer With a Distinctive Voice
description: MOST contemporary composers of classical music toil in near obscurity. But despite the indifference of the mainstream public, they have established ways to preserve their art and introduce it to audiences. One of these ways is through a support network of foundation grants and academic affiliations. Another is by decorating each other with prizes, both honorary and monetary.

title: Roberta Gausas, Allen Model
description: Dr. Roberta Elisabeth Gausas and Allen John Model were married yesterday at the College of Physicians of Philadelphia. The Rev. Joseph P. Watkins, a Lutheran pastor, performed a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADER, MORTIMER, M.D.
description: BADER-Mortimer, M.D. It is with profound sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Dr. Mortimer Bader, whose remarkable career at Mount Sinai covered almost half a century. Upon arriving at Mount Sinai in 1946, Dr. Bader, along with his brother Richard, became living legends-the epitome of the ''right stuff'' upon which great academic medical centers are erected. A role model to young physicians and peers alike, he exemplified the very best personally and professionally. In 1983, The Mount Sinai Alumni presented its most coveted award, the Jacobi Medallion, to Dr. Bader in acknowledgment of his profound professional achievements and his extraordinary service to the Medical Center and The Alumni. His didactic lectures and bedside teaching rounds have always been cited as the teaching highpoints by generations of medical students and housestaff. More than a great investigator, teacher and physician, his remarkable brillance, humor and humane relations with all, has earned him the esteem and affection of his students, peers and patients. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D.-Pres. William G. Stein, M.D.-V.P. Maria L. Padilla, M.D.-Secy. George Raptis, M.D.-Treas.

title: Watching the Waistline, Online
description: More than 3.5 million people logged on to Internet sites that focus on health, fitness and nutrition in the final days of 2002, Nielsen NetRatings said last week.

title: Edith Bouvier Beale
description: We, members of the surviving family of Edith Bouvier Beale, were surprised to find her on your cover but gratified that the picture you used was one from her gorgeous youth. We have many such pictures, which show a beautiful, poised and promising young woman. Indeed, David Rakoff captured the central theme of Edie's life: why did this woman of such potential become a recluse? Of course, if it were not for the film ''Grey Gardens,'' the public would not have known about Big and Little Edie at all. They were not ''crazy cat ladies'' or ''camp'' figures but simply ladies of a certain upbringing who were abandoned and neglected, mostly by male members of their families.

title: January 5-11: NATIONAL; NEW JERSEY ABUSE CASE
description: A horrifying discovery in a Newark basement has set off a firestorm of accusations and questions. In the home of Sherry L. Murphy, police discovered two young brothers starving and imprisoned in the basement, and the corpse of their 7-year-old brother, Faheem Williams, in a plastic storage bin. Ms. Murphy, a relative of the boys, evaded arrest for several days before she was found and arraigned Thursday, but it remained unclear whether she or the children's mother, in a Bronx hospital, was behind the abuse.

title: A Political Limbo Tests Arafat's Fortitude
description: Around and around, hour after hour, Yasir Arafat circles the desk in his office, waiting for the world to come back to him.

title: Film Openings and Film Series Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: Lawmakers Seek a Routine in the Capitol Maze
description: As snow dusted the Capitol last Sunday afternoon, Candice Miller, no longer Michigan's secretary of state but not quite an official member of the House of Representatives, arrived at her new suite in the Cannon Building to meet her staff and do a little unpacking. Dressed casually in sweatshirt and khakis, Mrs. Miller strode through the door, stopping as she spotted her new nameplate.

title: Barring a Buyer After an Auction
description: Q. I live in an eight-unit owner-occupied co-op. One shareholder moved out about two years ago without leaving any forwarding address. His girlfriend remained in his apartment and paid the maintenance fees, and now has a new boyfriend living in the apartment with her. When the bank notified us that the apartment would be auctioned, we learned that the original shareholder had defaulted on his mortgage. The buyer at the auction was the new boyfriend. When he submitted his financial package to the board he was rejected. Now he is threatening to sue us on charges that we cannot reject anyone who buys at an auction. Is this true? . . . Mary Hobart, Manhattan.

title: New Flight Paths? Maybe. New Fears? Certainly.
description: At first, Marcus Edward thought the noise was in his head, not in the sky. But as the months wore on, Mr. Edward, who lives in a brownstone on West 142nd Street, reached a different conclusion.

title: Filmed on Location: The Gangs of Rio de Janeiro
description: A CAST composed almost entirely of unknown actors, a setting that is none too attractive, a lot of violence and no sex scenes. If ever a studio wanted a formula for a film to fail, that would be it,'' said the Brazilian director Fernando Meirelles.

title: Always Avoid Boredom
description: WHEN I was 5, Mom and Dad bought a grocery store in Wisconsin and put me to work unpacking boxes of thimbles. After we moved back to St. Louis, where I was born, I worked with my parents in a hearing-aid business, a gas station and a bowling alley. By the time I was 16, they had bought a shoe store. I sold shoes for a long time. In fact, I'm still a fanatic about shoes; I probably own 75 pairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ANNE
description: BERNSTEIN-Anne. Beloved wife of Harry Bernstein, devoted sister of Sam Drachman, loving mother of Toby Bernstein. Died Jan. 4, 2003.

title: Reading, From Branch to Branch
description: THE suburban library of my childhood, with its glass atrium, pristine bathrooms, deep easy chairs and smorgasbord of new fiction, spoiled me forever. This, I thought, is what all libraries are like. College did nothing to dispel this notion. I loved the library at Brown University as much as I'd loved the one in Syosset.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-8

title: Anthrax Island
description: In one of the most remote spots on earth, a desiccated island in the Aral Sea, lie the remains of the world's largest biological-warfare testing ground. Since Russia abandoned Vozrozhdeniye Island in 1992 to its new owners, Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan, it has remained uninhabited, its laboratory complex deserted by all but the Kazakh scavengers who pilfer its parts.

title: Senescent Prejudices
description: How should we read Tom Paulin's new book of poetry, ''The Invasion Handbook''? Paulin is the Irish poet and Oxford professor whose invitation to speak at Harvard was rescinded after he said in an interview that ''Brooklyn-born'' settlers on the West Bank ''should be shot dead.'' (He has since been reinvited.) Paulin is also famous for having led the attack on T. S. Eliot for his anti-Semitism -- he argued in a passionate review of a book on the subject that you can't separate the poetry from the poet's malignity. So do we read Paulin as he has read Eliot, scouring his poems for evidence of his hatred of Jews? Or do we disdain the journalistic trick of turning a writer's statements against his own work and entertain the possibility that Paulin is a misunderstood philo-Semite, as he says he is, whose poetry is on the whole sympathetic to Jews?

title: Two Tough Cookies
description: He sets the fashion in politics. She sets the politics in fashion.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with a report in the Postings column about the refurbishing of a Brooklyn building for use by arts groups misstated the street number and misspelled the surname of the president of the BAM Local Development Corporation. As the column noted, the address is 80 Hanson Place, not 8. The developer is Jeanne Lutfy, not Lufty.

title: Free to Be
description: IT was a typical exercise to promote orderly response. The teacher called on each student, who was to shout out his name. ''Here! Yuuki Tamori, I am fine.'' But Yuuki, 10, was shy.

title: The Goliath of Medical and Dental Supplies
description: CLEAR evidence that dentistry is changing can be found in the ''dancing banana'' card in the current Henry Schein dental merchandise catalog. One of about 50 easygoing cards offered for sale to dentists to mail out to remind patients to come in for scheduled visits, the cartoon features four bananas performing a line dance and the message, ''The bunch of us wants to see you soon!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, ISIDOR
description: SCHNEIDER - Isidor. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Isidor Schneider, associated with The Times from 1955 until retiring in 1990.

title: Wearing Socks to Bed? Blame Oil Prices
description: SUBURBAN life has its charms, but I miss Manhattan in the winter. Outside of the tropics, Manhattan apartments can be the steamiest habitats on earth. Without control of their own heat, city dwellers crack their windows to bring temperatures down. December, January, February, in snowstorms, frost and sleet: city residents often leave their windows open through it all.

title: Iraqi Dissidents Reassured in a Talk With Bush About the Post-Hussein Era
description: President Bush told Iraqi opposition figures on Friday that he favored a sweeping transition to democracy in Iraq and a short military occupation after Saddam Hussein is out of power, according to Iraqis and others who attended the meeting.

title: Peggy Lee
description: Rob Hoerburger's article on Peggy Lee was great. It gave me fever. I loved being there with him.

title: Teach Them Well
description: According to America's ''certified financial planners'' (whom the public should be skeptical of, perhaps, for adopting such a smooth, disarming title), it's never too early to start saving for retirement. But while poring over my year-end I.R.A. statements just the other day, I found myself wishing that I had waited a bit. Thanks to the prudent advice of the professionals who told me to buy immediately, buy big, hold on tight and never, ever look back, a great deal of money that once belonged to me -- and money that might still belong to me, at least in the form of a plasma television or a 12-man hot tub, if I'd spent it rather than invested it -- now belongs to someone else, apparently, or maybe to no one. The experts misled me. They forgot to mention that, in certain markets (the only sort of market I've known since I began providing for my golden years), aggressively investing for a rainy day can actually bring about a rainy day.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: You have probably received lots of fan letters, but I still want you to know that I really liked your annual issue (Dec. 29) on people who died during the past year. I send appropriate items to my daughter for her to enjoy.

title: Sandbox Shock: Indoor Playground to Close Soon
description: Once upon a time, enchanted play areas with glistening sandboxes and Crayola-colored houses sprouted across the city. They offered parents and toddlers, cubbyholed in tiny apartments, an indoor haven to let loose.

title: Virtual Property
description: Elizabeth Lapple, the seller: ''Bridgeville is the perfect thing. You can have control of the town, everyone who lives there, and you can have your own little paradise away from Los Angeles. My mother bought it in 1972. I inherited it. I decided to sell it because I realized that I could throw $5,000 or $10,000 at it here and there but I was never gonna have the money to fix it up. I sell a lot of stuff on eBay. The bidding started at $5,000. When it hit a million and a half I was like, is this real? Someone needs to pinch me! It worked its way up to $1,777,877. I have to admit: I enjoyed it. But then it got to a point where people were coming up to my children saying: 'Oh, your mother sold Bridgeville. Can you loan me 10 bucks?' I've had nine marriage proposals since the sale. They're like: 'You're really beautiful. Let's go somewhere and get married.' ''

title: Big Dreams Cause Big Eyes: From Concept to Production
description: CONCEPT cars are the dream machines of auto shows, unattainable flashes of show-biz glamour among vehicles that come with easy-payment plans, extended warranties and Scotchgard fabric protection. Concept cars are not for sale, and they may say more about the state of mind of the industry than about the state of the art of engineering.

title: Of Milk and Cookies, or How Orthodox Jews Saved an Italian Recipe
description: Stella D'Oro, the Bronx-based baker of cookies and breadsticks, was founded in 1932 by an Italian immigrant couple, but in one of those lyrical convergences of ethnicities that gives New York City its special flavor, Stella D'Oro's cookies have for 45 years held a special place in the hearts of many Orthodox Jews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURMAN, DOROTHY
description: FURMAN - Dorothy. Born June 12, 1917, died January 10, 2003, in Sarasota, FL. A former resident of Lake Mohegan, NY, she was the beloved wife of the late Abraham Furman and sister of the late Rhoda Zak and Burton Loesberg. Her loving children Andrea, Kim and Daniel, and grandchildren Erika, Sean, Jon, Kelly, Rachel, Jeffrey and Brian survive her. For information contact Hellman's Funeral Home, Spring Valley, NY.

title: Commercial Property/Garment District; Amid Offices and Factories, Space for Arts Groups
description: UNTIL about three years ago, all 25 floors of the 750,000-square-foot building at 520 Eighth Avenue, between West 36th and 37th Streets in the garment district, were filled with manufacturers, almost all of them involved in the garment trade. Since then, 500,000 square feet have been converted to offices and rented to such tenants as the Mason Tenders Welfare Fund, with 50,000 square feet; several real estate agencies; and a number of nonprofit organizations, including Chess in the Schools, a program that uses chess to teach learning skills to pupils from kindergarten through high school.

title: Atop Shinerwe Mountain
description: In the valley beneath Shinerwe Mountain, in northern Iraq, there is a sense that this small war is soon to grow.

title: Mom Still Pays Attention (But She May Be Dead)
description: Maud hasn't spoken to her husband, Darren, in six months. Unfortunately he hasn't noticed.

title: Roger W. Martin, 70, Restaurant Consultant
description: Roger W. Martin, a restaurant consultant and a longtime associate of Joseph H. Baum at both Restaurant Associates and Windows on the World, the restaurant atop the World Trade Center, died on Jan. 4 at New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. He was 70.

title: Battle at the Breakfast Table; Claire Tomalin and Michael Frayn, Wife and Husband, Compete for British Book Prize
description: Over the years the biographer Claire Tomalin and her husband, the novelist and playwright Michael Frayn, have developed various strategies to cope with the inevitable irritations of life in a two-writer household.

title: Music Industry Braces for a Shift
description: The resignation last week of one of the music industry's most powerful figures, Thomas D. Mottola, the chairman and chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment, and his subsequent replacement by an outsider, Andrew Lack, a top NBC executive, has brought to the surface a growing sense of fear within the industry. The record business is bracing for a seismic shift and is increasingly reconciled to the fact that the current priorities of senior executives are outmoded.

title: 2 Plan Counteroffers for Safeway of Britain
description: Wal-Mart Stores and J. Sainsbury of Britain are each drawing up plans to make a counteroffer for Safeway, Britain's fourth-largest supermarket chain, which last week agreed to be bought by William Morrison Supermarkets, a smaller rival, for 2.7 billion, or $4.3 billion, in stock.

title: Knight Silences Rutgers, and No. 6 Pitt Hangs On
description: It was not a good idea to motivate Brandin Knight. Maybe Rutgers has learned its lesson, though too late.

title: Nine Years After Cobain's Death, Big Sales for All Things Nirvana
description: To call what has happened in the last several months a Nirvana revival would imply that the band had fallen off the cultural radar. While that was hardly the case, Nirvana's singer-guitarist leader, Kurt Cobain, and other former members of the grunge rock band are having more success now than at any point since Mr. Cobain's suicide in 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, CELIA
description: STEIN-Celia. Founder, with her husband David, of The Riverdale Press, and the newspaper's guiding spirit from 1950 to the present, died on January 11, at her home in Riverdale. Her efforts helped win new schools and protect a special neighborhood. In turn, she was honored by virtually every community organization in Riverdale. The only thing she loved more than her community was her family, her sons Bernard and Richard; her daughters-in-law Marguerite Adams and Hilary Baum; her grandchildren Anna Stein, Alex Baum-Stein and Annie Baum-Stein and her husband Mauro; and her great-granddaughter Anaia Daigle. Services on Wednesday, January 15, at 1:30 PM, at Riverdale Temple, 246th St and Independence Ave. Contributions may be made to Riverdale Mental Health Association, 5676 Riverdale Ave; or Riverdale Neighborhood House, 5521 Mosholu Ave, Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 20 about the approval of an environmental impact report for the Ahmanson Ranch, a major development near Los Angeles, misstated its proximity to a contaminated site of rocket testing and nuclear research. Some property owned by the developers adjacent to the site has been deeded to the State of California. The development does not abut the site.

title: Equity Offerings Planned
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: POLICE LAYOFFS OPPOSED Two members of the City Council who are former police officers warned yesterday that the city should not lay off police officers to balance its budget. The council members, Hiram Monserrate of Queens and James E. Davis of Brooklyn, both cautioned that laying off officers could imperil public safety. The Police Department, along with all other city agencies, is set to submit a proposal today to cut its budget, and city officials and police officials have said that layoffs may be needed.

title: Those S.U.V. Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Whistle-Blower Changes Sides To Aid Hewlett, Once a Target
description: Personal computer makers shuddered in 1999 when Toshiba agreed to a $2.1 billion settlement in a class-action suit for shipping computers with an arcane flaw. The mammoth settlement opened the door to potentially lucrative follow-on suits against other PC makers, and the first companies in the sights of the Texas class-action lawyers behind the Toshiba case were Compaq and Hewlett-Packard.

title: Glendale Journal; Good Fences, Uneasy Neighbors, a Frosty Dispute
description: The virtue of a sturdy fence is held in no higher esteem than in Southern California, where the gated community was perfected and people barricade themselves in until it seems as if the doghouse merits its own ZIP code.

title: Raiders Flipped Jets By Flipping Script
description: Wherever Charlie Garner moved, the Jets followed, covering his tracks at the line of scrimmage as the Oakland Raiders spent the first 30 minutes of today's American Football Conference divisional playoff game on unsteady feet.

title: U.S. Envoy Starts Discussions in Seoul on North Korea
description: Assistant Secretary of State James A. Kelly began consultations with South Korea's president-elect and other officials today about the nuclear threat from North Korea, as the North Korean government maintained a barrage of bellicose statements.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman Killed In Fire
description: A 54-year-old Queens woman was killed yesterday in a fire that broke out in her apartment above a store in Bellerose. The police said the woman, whose identity was not disclosed, lived alone in the apartment at 84-04 266th Street. Firefighters, responding to a report of the fire about 3:20 p.m., found her body on a couch inside the second-floor apartment. One firefighter sustained minor injuries, and was listed in stable condition last night at North Shore University Hospital. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: MacArthur Foundation Gives $42 Million, Despite Economy
description: At a time when foundations are cutting grants and paring budgets, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation plans to announce a $42 million package of special grants today.

title: New Issues As Hearings Address Rebuilding
description: Having enticed New Yorkers to let their thoughts about the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan soar to new heights, rebuilding officials now face the far more difficult task of bringing the public discussion back down to earth.

title: U.S. and Britain Assert No Deadline on Iraq Inspections
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  The White House said today that the United States was "not putting any artificial timetable" on United Nations arms inspectors in Iraq, and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said that the United Nations' work there should not be bound by any "arbitrary time scale."

title: Can a Television Official Make Music for Sony?
description: How on earth can a television executive save a music company?

title: Metro Matters; Author's Life, Made of Twists And Turns
description: AMONG the many improbable things to know about Julia Glass is that she never even wanted to come to the city that is at the center of her novel. Just out of Yale and working at a Harvard museum, ''I was determined not to be one more artist in New York,'' she said.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Austin Kelley Advertising , Atlanta, promoted two employees to executive vice presidents. They are Margaret Gearing , director for client services, and Jim Spruell , chief creative officer. Austin Kelley is part of the McCann-Erickson World Groupdivision of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEITELBAUM, LEW
description: TEITELBAUM - Lew. My sweetheart. On your 64th birthday all is the same. You are still my excellent strongman and I will miss you and love you forever. Your Sooky

title: Victim Looks for Meaning In Random Subway Slashing
description: A few days after being slashed on her head and left hand by a man wielding a blade on a Lower Manhattan subway platform, Yael Leopold vowed to return to New York and realize her dream of becoming a sixth-grade teacher.

title: Lack of Preparation Shows In Venus Williams's Opener
description: Venus Williams had not played a match in two months, and it showed as she walked into Rod Laver Arena today with her hair and asymmetrical earrings in place but her tennis in a less organized state.

title: Winter in Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon Says Arafat's Truce Call Aims at Influencing Israeli Voters
description: Israel's embattled prime minister, Ariel Sharon, spoke dismissively today about Yasir Arafat's appeal for a pre-election halt to attacks on Israeli civilians, clearly implying that the Palestinian leader was trying to help his dovish opponent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUKAT, SCOTT
description: SHUKAT - Scott. Cherished friend and personal manager for over twenty years. I am forever grateful for his strength, honesty, loyalty, intelligence and perseverance. My family and I will always honor his memory. Our love and deepest sympathies to his wife Evelyn and his son Jonathan. Alan, Janis, Anna Nora Menken

title: Wacky Works That Get Everybody Into the Pool
description: Keely Garfield Sinister Slapstick offers just that. The three works this dance company presented on Wednesday night in the Altogether Different series at the Joyce Theater could have benefited from trimming. Yet all three showed that Ms. Garfield's choreography can be both amusing and peculiar.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page news analysis article on Dec. 14 about challenges to the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church as a result of the sexual abuse scandals included one state erroneously among those in which grand juries are investigating the church. Last April a grand jury in York County, S.C., indicted one priest, the Rev. Juan Carlos Castano, on a charge of performing a lewd act on a minor, but the church itself is not under investigation by a grand jury in South Carolina.

title: At a Reunion in Moscow, Tales of Economic Change
description: In the first year of the new Russia, a group of students enrolled in a new Western-style graduate school to learn a long-forbidden academic discipline -- market economics.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VERNICK, GLORIA
description: VERNICK-Gloria. And I shall sleep in peace until you come to me. I will always love you. Irving

title: Patents; A molecular biologist hopes that an antibody will thwart heart disease, and help treat cancer.
description: EVEN though heart disease is not the death sentence it once was, it remains a major threat, especially to women.

title: A Job for Mary Donohue
description: The bottom line in New York's State Capitol these days is so grim that every state worker needs to pull a full load. There is no room for make-work or political sinecures. That is particularly true for Lt. Gov. Mary Donohue, whose only real job is waiting around for Gov. George Pataki to vacate his office abruptly.

title: Reviews Begin On 2 Big Accounts
description: Two big advertisers, America Online and Nextel Communications, have started reviews on their accounts, with combined billings estimated at $300 million to $400 million.

title: Sharon Under Fire
description: Sailing serenely toward re-election at the end of this month, Israel's Ariel Sharon was jolted by two political torpedoes.

title: Bucs Get the 49ers Down, and Keep Them There
description: Once Tampa Bay gained a 22-point halftime lead over San Francisco, the witty Warren Sapp began to joke with his Buccaneers defensive teammates. He knew the 49ers were in today's game because they had created a magical 25-point second-half comeback last week to beat the Giants.

title: As waistlines expand, so does advertising for a range of weight loss programs and products.
description: DR. title: Is That You, Mr. W., or a Dream Sequence from 'Frasier'?
description: Hasn't Benedict Arnold suffered enough? His duplicity earned him the hatred of his countrymen. He ended his days in misery and pain. His name is synonymous with traitor. But now, more than 200 years after his death, here comes another kick in the head. His life has become fodder for an overwrought melodrama, a television movie that turns a fascinating figure into a ranting head case. And that's nothing compared with the injury to Arnold's onetime mentor, George Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSKIND, IDA LEVINE
description: SUSKIND-Ida Levine. It is with great sadness that the Suskind family marks the death of their Matriarch, Ida Suskind. Ida died quietly on January 9 in Bridgehampton, NY, where she moved permanently a few years ago. Ida grew up on Staten Island, where she lived with her late husband, Morris Suskind. She is celebrated by her surviving family: her son, Dennis Suskind, and daughter-in-law, Cynthia, her grandchildren, Jay, Debra, Brian, John, Pamela and Audrey, as well as four great-grandchildren. Her daughter, Lorraine Gootenberg, passed away late last year. She is also survived by her sister, Libby and her dear friend, Angie. Services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., on Monday, January 13, at 11:30 AM. Contributions in her name may be made to the Bridgehampton Food Pantry, Bridgehampton, NY 11932, or the Arthur Ashe Institute for Urban Health, 450 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11203.

title: Comcast and Radio One in TV Joint Venture

title: Let It Be Said Beatles Tapes Are a Trove, If Familiar
description: To read the statements made by British and Dutch officials after the arrest of a group of bootleggers in suburbs of London and Amsterdam on Friday, one would think that the police had apprehended a band of thieves who for the last three decades had been sitting on a vast trove of long-lost master tapes from Beatles recording sessions. There is an element of truth in what they say, but also a good measure of exaggeration. Whether the seizure of these tapes should be regarded as good news -- and for that matter whether it will have any effect on the thriving trade in Beatles bootlegs -- is another matter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, C. DOUGLAS
description: DILLON-C. Douglas. 93 of Hobe Sound, FL. Beloved husband of Susan, father of Phyllis D. Collins and Joan Duchesse de Mouchy, grandfather of Joan Frost, Ambika Collins, Mark Collins, Douglas Collins, Charlotte Cunningham, Robert Luxembourg and 15 great-grandchildren, died on January 10, after a long illness. He was precedeased by his first wife Phyllis Ellsworth in 1982. He had been Secretary of the Treasury, Ambassador to France, Under Secretary of State, Chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Chairman of the Brookings Institution, and President of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University among many other positions of distinction and high public honor. Funeral services will be private. The family has indicated that any memorial gifts should be sent to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, NY, NY 10028.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, GEORGE ALDEN
description: DEAN-George Alden. With love and sadness we mourn the passing of George Dean of Southport, CT. Beloved husband of Jane Kentnor Dean, father of Jay Dean, Diane Dean Stocks, Jeffrey Pratt and Susan Pratt. Princeton graduate, Korea veteran, and advertising executive for over 30 years. In retirement he dedicated himself to the encouragement and support of women running for public office, as a tireless champion, mentor and unifying force. His patient and reasoned words moved minds and inspired others to action. Generous with his time, he enthusiastically served on numerous charitable boards. Equally generous with his affection, his treasured friendships cross physical, political and ideological boundaries. A courageous man, wonderful friend, and true patriot, his family and many friends will deeply miss him. His family suggests a donation to the Women's Campaign School at Yale University, the United VNA of Trumbull, CT, or any of the charities he loved and supported.

The council members, Hiram Monserrate of Queens and James E. Davis of Brooklyn, both cautioned that laying off officers could imperil public safety. The Police Department, along with all other city agencies, is set to submit a proposal today to cut its budget, and city officials and police officials have said that layoffs may be needed. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Franklin Square: Armed Standoff Ends Peacefully
description: A man with two handguns and a sawed-off rifle who opened fire on Nassau County police officers from his home was arrested early yesterday, after a standoff with the authorities that lasted nearly five hours. Between 10:30 p.m. Saturday and 3:15 a.m. yesterday, the police said, the man, Harry Blasich, 61, fired more than 50 rounds from the second floor of a house where he rented a room. Mr. Blasich's motive was unclear, they said. The police said that they evacuated neighbors and that no one was hurt. About 3 a.m., the authorities said, hostage negotiators talked Mr. Blasich into leaving the house. He was expected to be arraigned on five counts of first-degree attempted murder and weapons charges. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Remember The Fear
description: Early one morning in January 1990 the actress Viveca Lindfors was attacked by a stranger in Greenwich Village and slashed in the face. ''It happened so unbearably fast,'' she said at the time. ''One minute we were coming out of the building, talking about Gorbachev and Lithuania, and suddenly a guy was right in front of me, holding my face. And the next second I was lying on the street. I heard screams, 'Get him!' And I felt the blood.''

title: Editorial Observer; In South Africa, a Hero Measured by the Advance of a Deadly Disease
description: South Africa, cursed with a history of causes worth dying for, is blessed with men and women willing to die for them. To that list now add Zackie Achmat. Mr. Achmat, 40, is South Africa's most prominent AIDS activist, and chairman of the Treatment Action Campaign. He found out that he was H.I.V. positive in 1990, and has had AIDS since 1997. He can afford antiretroviral drugs, but in 1998 he vowed not to take them until everyone in South Africa could. That day is inching closer, largely due to the work of the campaign. For Mr. Achmat it may not arrive soon enough.

description: DILLON-C. Douglas. The Trustees, Physicians and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend C. Douglas Dillon. As a statesman, a diplomat, an international business leader and a philanthropist, Mr. Dillon made unique contributions that have left a lasting impact on art, science, industry and world affairs. Mr. Dillon joined the Board of Governors of The New York Hospital in 1947, and was elected a Life Trustee of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital in 1998. He brought his sharp intellect and uncommon skills to bear in support of the Hospital's commitment to providing the highest quality patient care. He leaves an outstanding legacy of stewardship and benevolence. We will miss his wisdom and his friendship, and we join with all those who knew him in mourning his loss. Our deepest condolences are extended to his wife, Susan, and to the entire Dillon family. John Mack, Chairman, Herbert Pardes, M.D. President & CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

A trip to the Philippines early this year, for example, was considered but dropped. The visit to Croatia would be his third. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Synopsys To Buy Numerical Technologies
description: Synopsys Inc. has agreed to buy Numerical Technologies Inc. for $250 million, or $7 a share, the companies announced yesterday. The acquisition price represents an 89.2 percent premium, based on Numerical's closing price of $3.70 a share on Friday. Shares of Numerical, which is based in San Jose, Calif., closed yesterday at $6.91, up $3.21, or about 87 percent. Chip-making companies use Numerical's software and other applications to produce integrated circuits with patterns that are smaller than the wavelength of light. Numerical's applications are based on phase-shifting and optical correction technologies that compensate for distortions caused by working in such reduced dimensions. Synopsys, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., makes electronic design automation software. The company expects the deal to speed production of sub-wavelength chips as well as reduce costs and manufacturing risk for customers developing power-efficient integrated circuits. The acquisition requires regulatory approval and other closing conditions. The deal is expected to close in the first quarter.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Lawyer Pleads Guilty To Embezzlement
description: Robert Burrick, a lawyer in Short Hills, pleaded guilty yesterday to two counts of embezzlement, crimes that could bring a penalty of 10 years in prison. The plea came a week before Mr. Burrick was to go on trial in federal court on a 15-count indictment. He was charged with embezzling $120,000 from clients and the Millburn Youth Soccer Club, where he served as treasurer. Mr. Burrick, a former partner in the Morristown law firm of Pitney, Hardin, Kipp & Szuch, used the money to support a lavish lifestyle and pay personal bills, according to the indictment. During the scheme, in which he engaged between 1997 and 1999, he funneled money from various accounts he controlled to a dummy corporation operated by a co-conspirator who in turn wrote checks to him, according to court papers. Mr. Burrick will be sentenced on April 14. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIDY, GRACE A.
description: LEIDY-Grace A. Age 92, of Kennett Square, PA, died on Thursday, January 9, 2003, at Crosslands in Kennett Square, PA. Born in Baltimore, MD, she was the daughter of the late Charles and Katherine Hart Leidy. She was a 1932 graduate of Hunter College where she received her B.S. majoring in Biology. She received her M.A. degree from Columbia University. She was a well respected scientist, when she worked in the Department of Clinical Pathology at Babies Hospital of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. While working with Dr. Hattie Alexander, she developed a therapeutically successful specific anti-serum against Hemophilus type B meningitis, a relatively common and virtually always fatal disease in infants. Subsequently, she and Dr. Alexander became known internationally in the field of bacterial transformation, conveying the genetic characteristics of one strain of Hemophilus influenza to another by using RNA derived from the first strain. other by using RNA derived from the first strain. She was the second person to demonstrate such transformation and the first to do it with Hemophilus influenza. She then developed strains of H. Influ with characteristics of two antigen types in a single particle. In the late 1970s and early 80s, she worked with Dr. Katherine Sprunt to exploit the naturally occurring protective value of interbacterial interactions to prevent bacterial infection in the neonate. Dr. Sprunt remembers that work with respect and affection, and says that their work lowered the Nursery infection rate thereby, putting them out of a job. Grace enjoyed reading, politics, classical music, and helping the Leonia school children with their microbiology projects. Services and burial will be private. For information Kuzo & Gofus Funeral Home Ltd, Kennett Square, PA, ''A Life Celebration Home''.

title: HALLIBURTON EXPECTS DECLINE IN 4TH-QUARTER EARNINGS
description: The Halliburton Company, the world's second-largest provider of oil field services, predicted a decline in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday because of a slowdown in oil and natural gas drilling. Profit fell to 22 cents a share, excluding expenses of 1 cent or 2 cents related to the strike in Venezuela, Halliburton's second-largest area of operations outside the United States, said the company's chief executive, David Lesar. Halliburton, which is based in Houston, earned 32 cents a share a year earlier. The company is scheduled to report fourth-quarter earnings on Feb. 20.

title: City for Rent

While we were in New York waiting out the dot-com boom, San Francisco had been transformed into an unrecognizably frenzied place where jobs were plentiful but apartments were not. From friends who stayed behind, we heard stories about open houses in which apartment hunters showed up early, dressed well and clutched leather-bound folders holding their credit reports, checkbooks, pay stubs -- even renters' rsums, listing their references and touting their monk-like living habits.

title: Corrections

The zones, one in the north and one in the south, were imposed by the United States, Britain and France after the Persian Gulf war; they cited United Nations resolutions calling for Iraq's Kurds and Shiites to be protected from Saddam Hussein; the zones were not created by the United Nations.

title: Soft Money, Hard Revenge
description: The high price of independence has been driven home to Republicans in the new Congress. In a vivid bit of leadership payback, Representative Christopher Shays, the Connecticut Republican, has been punished for his role as champion of last year's campaign finance reform bill. Mr. Shays had infuriated his party leaders by working with Democrats to foil Republican attempts at bottling up the bill. Now these same leaders have denied him the chairmanship of the House Government Reform Committee, a high-profile post for which his ranking seniority and legislative talents fully qualify him. Instead, the new chairman will be Tom Davis of Virginia, a key party fund-raiser last November.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline Loss Expected

The airline cited intensified domestic competition, especially on long-haul routes. Air Canada's domestic flights were an average of 67.4 percent full in December, down from 74.5 percent a year earlier. Air Canada said that the fourth-quarter operating loss would be lower than the 308 million Canadian dollar deficit posted in the period in 2001.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Possible Shift In Drug Agent Case
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that a Drug Enforcement Administration agent charged with manslaughter after shooting a suspect can have his case moved from state to federal court. The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, had fought the effort by lawyers for the agent, Jude Tanella. A federal trial could give Mr. Tanella access to a jury drawn from a wider pool that might be more sympathetic to law enforcement officers than a jury drawn only from Brooklyn. The judge, Nicholas G. Garaufis, said in an opinion yesterday that if Mr. Tanella eventually proved that the killing was a legitimate law enforcement response to threatening actions by the suspect, Egbert David Dewgard, the judge could dismiss the indictment and declare Mr. Tanella immune from the state charges. William Glaberson (NYT)

Lember, disclosed yesterday. No motive was offered and no arrests had been made in the slaying of the builder, Michael Parisi, Mr. Lember said. Mr. Parisi, 52, was shot either Saturday night or Sunday morning, the police said. He had built hundreds of homes in Hunterdon County, and was also a partner in two restaurants. The police said his silver Corvette had been found outside the county and was in police custody. Iver Peterson (NYT)

description: CANADA: AIRLINE LOSS EXPECTED Reversing two profitable quarters in a row, Air Canada said that it expected to report operating losses in the fourth quarter and for 2002 as a whole. The airline cited intensified domestic competition, especially on long-haul routes. Air Canada's domestic flights were an average of 67.4 percent full in December, down from 74.5 percent a year earlier. Air Canada said that the fourth-quarter operating loss would be lower than the 308 million Canadian dollar deficit posted in the period in 2001.

title: The U.S. plans to see if there is misleading marketing of movies.
description: IN a little-noticed move, the Federal Trade Commission announced last week that it would review its guidelines on endorsements and testimonials this year. The process promises to illuminate one of advertising's foggier areas: the blurbs of movie reviews that studios use to publicize their films.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, ELIAS BERNARD
description: BLOCK-Elias Bernard. Beloved son of the late Helen and Nathan Block. Truly loved by wife Beatrice (Bea). Loving father of Kenneth and Leslie. Devoted stepfather of Robin, Scott and Andrea. Grandfather of Colin and Cameron. Brother of Lorraine Machiz. Funeral services January 14, 1 PM Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY, 718-445-0300. Donations may be sent to the National Council of Jewish Women, 53 W 23rd St., NY 10010.

title: Mobster Turned Informant Testifies in a Shooting Trial
description: One November night in 1994, a card game in a Brooklyn social club was interrupted by gunfire. A budding Brooklyn mobster named Michael D'Urso ended up with a bullet in his head. A cousin who was as close to him as a brother was also shot and died next to him.

title: The Collections / Milan : A flicker of glitter among futuristic, military sportswear
description: MILAN  When a sparkling suit winked from under a multi-colored fur coat at Roberto Cavalli's show on Monday, it was the first glitz and glitter of the Milan menswear season  unless you count a few icicles of embroidery on a Valentino scarf or the candy-wrapper metallic parkas in Burberry's fresh and colorful show.

title: As British Antiwar Sentiment Rises, Blair Defends Iraq Stand
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair today took on domestic opponents of his hard-line stance on Iraq, saying that while he accepted that they might feel the problem was far away and not urgent, he was convinced it was a direct and imminent threat to Britain.

title: Chief of CNN Is Departing After 2 Years
description: Walter Isaacson, the chairman of CNN since the summer of 2001, said yesterday that he would leave the network in the spring to become chief executive of the Aspen Institute, a nonprofit research center specializing in public policy issues.

title: A Decade Later, as Modest And Obstinate as Ever
description: ''I've got some funny ideas about what sounds good,'' David Lowery proclaimed in ''Shut Us Down,'' a song from 1986 that a reunited Camper Van Beethoven played at Irving Plaza on Friday night. Camper Van Beethoven was an odd band during the 1980's, and it hasn't gotten any more fashionable lately.

title: Caseworkers Are the Target Of Rage Over a Boy's Death
description: After three frantic days of knocking on doors, facing threats and in some cases dodging bricks, child welfare workers have been able to find only 30 of the 110 children who have been named in abuse investigations but not yet seen by caseworkers, state officials said today.

title: Her Name Is Sharky? Sounds Like Trouble
description: In Marlane Meyer's dark comedy ''The Mystery of Attraction,'' two brothers, Ray and Warren, have had their lives ruined by the same woman. She married both of them (Ray first; Warren stole her away) and the mystery of the title is why people (men and women, but mostly men) are so inscrutably drawn to those who would undo them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWICK, BARUCH, 79. BENNO
description: ZWICK-Baruch, 79. Benno, beloved brother, brother-inlaw, uncle and great-uncle died in Kfar Saba on January 11, 2003. Benno was a warm, funny and loving man who came to Israel on Youth Aliyah, a founding member of the Golani Brigade who served his country as a soldier and as an ambulance driver. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife Shoshana, his sons Udi & Yoram, and their families. The Picker Family.

title: No Need to Ignore Jeers; Nedved Is Amassing Goals
description: Behind Petr Nedved's seventh career three-goal game last night, the Rangers turned in one of their most impressive victories of the season, a 5-1 drubbing of the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden.

title: G.O.P. Pledges an Effort on Race
description: In an effort to improve the Republican Party's image among African-Americans, party leaders agreed today to set benchmarks for the party to gauge how well it is doing in grooming black candidates, hiring black staff members and acting on issues of concern to black voters.

description: To the Editor:

title: Carriers Pull Back On Fuel Surcharges
description: As if the airlines don't already have enough trouble, the price of oil has been going up, but travelers' resistance to any price increases in the form of new fuel surcharges evidently remains steady.

title: New Ideas Energize Alzheimer's Battle
description: The clinical signs of Alzheimer's disease are all too familiar -- the erosion of memory for recent, then distant events, the declining ability to reason or to think.

title: Ashcroft Says Church Groups Suffer Bigotry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  The Bush administration escalated its campaign today to loosen restrictions on religious charity-providers, with Attorney General John Ashcroft delivering an aggressive attack on the "bigotry" that he said religious groups had faced for decades in the United States.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Threat To End Russian Peacekeeping
description: President Eduard A. Shevardnadze threatened not to renew the mandate of 3,000 Russian peacekeepers in the breakaway Georgian republic of Abkhazia, a sign of growing tensions over the Russian presence. Mr. Shevardnadze cited the opening of a railroad link last month between the Russian Black Sea port at Sochi and Sukhumi, the capital of Abkhazia, as evidence of Russia's support for Abkhazia's government. The peacekeepers' mandate, which expired on Dec. 31, is renewed every six months. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: The Choreography of Misery, Amid Sharp Shadows and Sounds
description: Zvi Gotheiner is a beloved New York dance teacher and choreographer. His work gives dancers a chance at movement that is physically demanding but lyrical, a rarity these days. He has created entire worlds with one or two performers, a prop and a few strong gestures in the excerpted pieces seen frequently on gala programs. But Mr. Gotheiner's dances may be best savored in small doses.

title: I.R.S. Offers Amnesty for Offshore Credit Card Accounts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 — The Internal Revenue Service, seeking to crack down on the use of credit cards linked to undeclared offshore financial accounts, announced a one-time amnesty today for people who declare such hidden income.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURSO, MICHAEL J.
description: DURSO-Michael J. Beloved husband of Rosemary. Devoted father of Judi Dolgow and Michael. Loving grandfather of Michelle. Dear brother of Frank. Cherished cousin of The Hon. Anita Florio. Reposing at Farenga Bros. Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Ave. until Thursday 9 AM. Mass of Christian burial at Fordham University, Rosehill Campus, Bronx, NY 10458. Church 10 AM. The family would appreciate contributions to the Michael J. Durso scholarship fund C/O Fordham Prep., Rosehill Campus, Bronx, New York 10458.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ADRIA, PH.D.
description: SCHWARTZ-Adria, Ph.D. Esteemed colleague, devoted therapist and beloved friend, died on January 11th. Adria participated in founding the Relational Orientation of the NYU Postdoctoral Program, where she was a supervisor. Her work on gender, sexuality, and social forces was a significant contribution to contemporary psychoanalysis. She is survived by her son, Alex, and her companion Rima Shore. Lewis Aron, Ph.D, Director, NYU Postdoctoral Program in Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKEL, NORMA
description: MARKEL-Norma. On January 11, 2003. Beloved daughter of the late Rachel and Joseph Markel, adored sister of Barbara Hart and her husband Stanley W. Hart, dear aunt of Charles and the late Simon.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Internet Users Beware
description: Following the creation of an electronic crimes department by the Interior Ministry, the police have arrested a schoolteacher for sending an e-mail message ''full of lies and rumors to the F.B.I.'' and a 30-year-old gay man who arranged a date over the Internet with a man who turned out to be a police officer posing as another gay man. Despite criticism from human rights' advocates, the ministry is continuing to monitor Web sites and has warned Internet users against viewing ''porno Web sites'' and ''harmful'' chat rooms.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Radisys Will Cut 17% Of Work Force
description: The RadiSys Corporation, a computer equipment maker that has reported losses for the last seven quarters, will cut 17 percent of its jobs by selling a business and hiring another company to do more manufacturing. RadiSys will eliminate 108 jobs this quarter, Brian Bronson, the treasurer of the company, said in an interview yesterday. The step, intended to shave $2 million from its expenses every three months, will cut first-quarter profit up to $2.5 million because of severance payouts and other expenses. RadiSys, which is based in Hillsboro, Ore., makes equipment used in telecommunications switches and other products by companies including Cisco Systems, Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M. The company has not made a profit since the fourth quarter of 2000, when sales were $82.5 million, compared with $47.9 million in the third quarter of last year. The company said 58 of the jobs will be eliminated because it is shifting more production to an outside manufacturer. The remainder will come as it scales back other parts of its business.

title: Front Row
description: Uncertainty in the Meat District

title: A Skeptic About Wars Intended to Stamp Out Evil
description: DR. ROBERT JAY LIFTON has spent his life studying people in extreme situations. He has written about Japanese survivors in Hiroshima, Vietnam veterans, Nazi doctors and members of terrorist cults. But he has also spent a lifetime as an activist, involved in the Vietnam antiwar movement and the antinuclear movement. The two activities, scholarship and activism, are for him intertwined. All of his work is infused with the struggle to live the moral life.

title: When Death Row Is Emptied
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Airline Buys Jets
description: The parent of Malaysia Airlines has agreed to buy six A380 superjumbo jets from Airbus, a purchase that industry analysts said was worth about $1.5 billion before discounts. Penerbangan Malaysia, which owns 69 percent of Malaysia's flag carrier, plans to take delivery of the planes in 2007 and then lease them to Malaysia Airlines. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: College Student Stabbed To Death
description: A college student has been charged with first-degree murder in the fatal stabbing of another college student in what may have been a gang-related brawl involving the gang known as the Crips. The accused, Marquise S. Howard, 18, of Roselle, N.J., and a student at Norfolk State University in Virginia, discarded what may have been gang colors at a friend's house after the stabbing, the authorities said. Mr. Howard is being held in $350,000 bail. The victim, Olayiwola Esan, died on Thursday after attending a high school basketball game at St. Mary of the Assumption, his alma mater. A student at Emmanuel College in Boston, Mr. Esan may have been caught in the middle of a brawl between two groups outside the school, said Robert O'Leary, an assistant prosecutor for Union County, who also said that Mr. Esan was not in a gang. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The dollar rose against the euro on expectations that a government report today will show that retail sales increased in December. In New York, the euro settled at $1.05470, down from $1.05720 on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROPHET, WILSON B. JR.
description: PROPHET-Wilson B. Jr. Peacefully died in Hospice 08 January 2003, survived by his wife Harriet, daughter Kathleen, sons Douglas and Thomas, and grandchildren Trevor and Juliana.

title: New Trade Center Site Plans Draw Some Old Complaints
description: Since the attack on the World Trade Center 16 months ago, the public has responded to calls for comment on rebuilding the World Trade Center with a host of new ideas, innovative thinking and considered debate.

title: ON THE GROUND In Hamilton, Bermuda; Resort Spot and Corporate Home Away From Home
description: Long before New York City had a mayor with a house in Bermuda, many American businesses -- especially in insurance and international banking -- were attracted to Bermuda because of its favorable tax laws, stable government and proximity. But these days, companies treating Bermuda as a tax haven are coming under increased scrutiny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, A. JOHN
description: ALLEN-A. John, of Sarasota, FL, formerly of Smoke Rise, Kinnelon, NJ, died December 20, 2002. Survived by his wife Virginia Starke Bruns, daughter Joan Greene, son Wesley Allen, three grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Combining the Scattered Data From Violent Deaths
description: What proportion of murders are related to drug trafficking? How often do suicide victims act immediately after a marital split, loss of a job or some other personal crisis? Where are teenagers who shoot others most likely to obtain the weapons they use?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUSTAFSON, RUSSELL
description: GUSTAFSON-Russell. Age 55. Died January 11, 2003 in NYC. B.A., Lynchburg College, 1969; M.A., University of Virginia, 1972. A former actor, his credits included many plays and musicals at The Albemarle Playhouse in Charlottesville, VA, and the New York premiere of Mustapha Matura's ''Play Mas'' at The Urban Arts Corps. He had worked as assistant to the late Vinnette Carroll at The Urban Arts Corps; as a press agent for Pat Dale Associates and for Henry Luhrmann Associates; and as a senior copywriter for Pace Advertising. He is survived by his nieces and nephews, Andy Gustafson, Kristen Gustafson O'Mahony, Meredith Ray, and Allen Gustafson.

title: British Child-Pornography Investigation Is Broadening
description: LONDON, Jan. 14 — The list includes police officers and dentists, judges and politicians, lawyers, teachers and social workers and, as of Monday, the guitarist Pete Townshend of the Who. In all, more than 1,300 people have been arrested in Britain in the last 10 months as part of Operation Ore, a nationwide hunt for users of child Internet pornography.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Shipbuilding Dispute
description: The South Korean government is preparing to file a trade complaint against the European Union over subsidies to shipbuilders, trade officials in Seoul said. Yonhap, the country's semiofficial news agency, said the preliminary step taken yesterday would be followed by a formal filing to the World Trade Organization in February. The sides have squabbled for years over the legality of each other's shipyard support. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICKER, DORIS SILBERMAN
description: PICKER - Doris Silberman. On January 12, 2003 at age 81. Veteran of World War II and the Women's Army Corps. Survived by children Susan (Burt), Barry (Robin) and David (Grace) and grandchildren Jason, Rori, Marshall, Craig and Jeremy. She will be deeply missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, MATILDA B.
description: FINKELSTEIN-Matilda B. On January 12, 2003. Beloved wife of Isador for over 70 years, devoted mother of Herbert and Lois and daughter-in-law Iris and son-in-law Morton, cherished grandmother of Amy, Stacy and Sarah and their husbands Jeffrey, Michael & Mark. Loving great-grandmother of David, Daniel and Brian. Devoted and loving sister of Mae Norins and Eleanor Clark. Lifelong member of Ima Group of Hadassah. Her kindness and caring nature will be sorely missed. Services on Wednesday, January 15, 12PM Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: WAL-MART REPORTS RISE IN SALES AND MAINTAINS FORECAST
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that sales last week at stores open at least a year rose and the company maintained its forecast for a January gain of 2 percent to 4 percent. Sales of products, including electronics and prescription drugs, increased, with the largest gains in the Northeast and West, Wal-Mart said. Wal-Mart's discount-store sales in the week ended Jan. 10 rose within expectations for a 3 percent to 5 percent monthly increase, the company said. The J. C. Penney Company said same-store sales last week were putting the retailer below its January forecast for no increase or a gain of as much as 3 percent.

title: LeBron James's S.U.V. Prompts an Investigation
description: LeBron James, a 6-foot-8 high school senior who is expected to be the No. 1 choice in the N.B.A. draft in June, is driving a new $50,000 sport utility vehicle. The Ohio High School Athletic Association says it wants to be sure the vehicle was a legitimate gift from his mother and not from an outsider.

title: When Death Row Is Emptied
description: To the Editor:

title: Widely Used Crop Herbicide Is Losing Weed Resistance
description: The world's most widely grown genetically engineered crops -- soybeans, cotton and corn developed to be impervious to a popular herbicide -- are facing a new challenge to their continued long-term use. The herbicide, known as Roundup, is beginning to lose its effectiveness in controlling weeds.

title: Protesters Invade British Nuclear Plant
description: Using ropes, ladders, climbing hooks and wire cutters estimated to cost a total of less than $50, more than 30 Greenpeace protesters broke into a nuclear power station in eastern England today in an effort to demonstrate poor security at nuclear plants.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: New Accusations Against Ex-Priest
description: A former Roman Catholic priest cooperating with the authorities investigating pedophile priests in the Diocese of Rockville Centre was arrested and jailed yesterday on new allegations of criminal activity. The former priest, Michael Hands, 36, is already awaiting trial on charges of sexually abusing a teenage boy. He was returned to jail yesterday in $1 million bail and placed on a suicide watch. The Suffolk County district attorney, Thomas J. Spota III, did not detail the new accusations against the former priest but said prosecutors had received a credible tip last weekend accusing Mr. Hands, who later surrendered a computer to the authorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVERY, SALLY MICHEL
description: AVERY-Sally Michel. The Board of Trustees of the Skowhegan School of Painting & Sculpture expresses their sincere condolences to the family on their loss. A respected Trustee for 20 years, Sally's generosity has helped innumerable young artists. We honor her life and cherish her memory. Ann Gund, Chair Judson Reis, President

title: House Campaign Appointment Upsets Blacks
description: The decision by Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader, to pass over a popular black lawmaker for a top campaign job has produced fresh tension between blacks and whites in the Democratic caucus.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: OFFICIALS MEET U.S. TRADE ENVOY Officials from several southern African nations met in South Africa with the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, to discuss setting up a free trade agreement with the United States. Formal negotiations between the Southern African Customs Union and American officials are expected to start next month and officials hope an agreement will be signed in 2004.

title: Blantyre Journal; Not Your Usual Vampires, but Scary Nonetheless
description: They wear dark clothing, it is said, and carry syringes to draw blood from their drugged victims, who sicken or die. The creatures have magical powers and a fondness for vanishing in graveyards, but no one has ever heard of them changing into bats.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Wednesday about tighter temporary restrictions on motor vehicles in Prospect Park misstated the hours that driving will be permitted on weekdays from Jan. 21 to April 4. They will be 7 to 9 a.m. and 4 to 7 p.m. The morning hours will not start at 6.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: NEW EDITOR The editor of The Sun, Brit- ain's largest tabloid, said that he would resign to take an unspecified management job in New York with the News Corporation , the paper's publisher. The editor, David Yelland, 39, will be replaced by Rebekah Wade, left, 34, currently editor of News of the World, another News Corporation publication. Analysts said that Mr. Yelland was leaving on a high note, after expanding The Sun's circulation to 3.5 million and widening its lead over The Daily Mirror, a Trinity Mirror publication. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Poor Mr. Case? Financially, Think Again
description: Stephen M. Case may be out of work, but he is unlikely to run out of money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROMHOLZ, HELEN
description: KROMHOLZ-Helen. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Helen Kromholz. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Gary Miller, Chairman of the Board

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Editor
description: The editor of The Sun, Britain's largest tabloid, said that he would resign to take an unspecified management job in New York with the News Corporation, the paper's publisher. The editor, David Yelland, 39, will be replaced by Rebekah Wade, left, 34, currently editor of News of the World, another News Corporation publication. Analysts said that Mr. Yelland was leaving on a high note, after expanding The Sun's circulation to 3.5 million and widening its lead over The Daily Mirror, a Trinity Mirror publication.
