title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILD, ALICE
description: SCHILD-Alice. On Jan. 13, 2003. It is with great sadness that our family marks the death of Alice Schild, sister of Marge and Bob LeVine and Lore and Mel Mallin, loving aunt of many nieces and nephews. She was a world traveler and a business woman who lived and died her way. She will remain in our hearts forever. Donations to Make a Wish Foundation.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Court Strikes Down Ban On Unmarried Sex
description: The State Supreme Court struck down a 19th-century law that made it a crime for unmarried people to have sexual intercourse. The case arose from the prosecution of a 16-year-old boy for having sex with his girlfriend, also 16, in her bedroom. The court held that ''the government may not reach into the bedroom of a private residence and criminalize the private, noncommercial, consensual sexual acts of two persons capable of consenting to those acts.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Wins Legal Case
description: The Microsoft Corporation yesterday won a legal fight to bar two computer trade associations from appealing a judge's approval of its antitrust settlement with the U.S. government and nine states. U.S. District Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly rejected arguments by the Software & Information Industry Association and the Computer & Communications Industry Association that an appeal is required to protect their interests in a competitive market. ''Nothing prevents (the groups) from pursuing their own antitrust suits against Microsoft,'' Judge Kollar-Kotelly said, citing Sun Microsystems Inc.'s private lawsuit seeking billions of dollars in antitrust damages. The settlement that Judge Kollar-Kotelly approved requires Microsoft to give computer makers freedom to promote rival products on personal computers.

title: Post-Mortem Of a Death So Puzzling
description: The conference took place at Bellevue, in a large room where the hardest cases have been discussed for years. A senior doctor stood and described the symptoms.

title: Russians Ponder 2 Competing Oil Routes in East Asia
description: A debate is raging in Russia over how to get the bountiful supplies of crude oil out of the wilds of Siberia into world markets.

title: Restoring Churches, Rekindling His Faith
description: As the one who brushes the blush on the Virgin Mary's cheeks and gilds the lilies on St. Joseph's staff, Eduardo Esparza is catching his breath between busy seasons. ''Christmas and Easter are when the priests really want them looking their best,'' he said of the brightly painted wooden statues dating back to 1876 that decorate SS. Cyril and Methodius Roman Catholic Church here. A former hairdresser, Mr. Esparza has recaptured his faith, he said, through restoring the exuberantly painted decorations and murals of churches in central and south Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUKAT, SCOTT
description: SHUKAT - Scott. Cherished friend and personal manager for over twenty years. I am forever grateful for his strength, honesty, loyalty, intelligence and perseverance. My family and I will always honor his memory. Our love and deepest sympathies to his wife Evelyn and his son Jonathan. Alan, Janis, Anna Nora Menken

title: Friend Arrested in Murder, Then Charge Is Dropped
description: Mystery surrounding the weekend killing of a newly arrived young banker on the Lower East Side deepened yesterday after the police filed a murder charge against a college acquaintance who was with the victim when he was shot, but then dropped the charge and released the man at the request of the Manhattan district attorney.

title: Oil Prices Rise Despite OPEC Output Pledge
description: Crude oil prices rose yesterday on expectations that additional oil from an OPEC production increase will not reach refineries in the United States until March at the earliest.

title: Insurer's Officers Broke Laws, Australian Inquiry Concludes
description: Australian law was apparently broken hundreds of times by executives of HIH Insurance and by its auditors, the Australian branch of Arthur Andersen, before the company collapsed early in 2001, investigators said today.

title: Pope Voices Opposition, His Strongest, To Iraq War
description: Pope John Paul II today expressed his strongest opposition yet to a potential war in Iraq, describing it as a ''defeat for humanity'' and urging world leaders to try to resolve disputes with Iraq through diplomatic means.

title: Footlights
description: Winter Harvest

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Shot To Death At Midtown Hotel
description: A woman was shot to death in a Times Square hotel room early this morning, and the police arrested the man with whom she was staying, the police said. Both were from Oregon, said an officer outside the hotel where the shooting occurred, the DoubleTree Guest Suites at 1568 Broadway near West 47th Street. The man and the woman, whose names were not released, had been staying on the 43rd floor and the room was in the man's name, with the woman on the register as his guest, the police said. The police were called just past midnight, after the man, in his 50's, presented the hotel desk clerk with a gun and sat down in a chair in lobby, said Det. Robert Price. Officers went to his room and discovered the woman on the floor, shot four or five times in the head, an officer at the scene said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARST, SUSAN MCGINNIS
description: DARST-Susan McGinnis, 89. Died peacefully on January 11. A 43-year resident of Nashville. Widow of Guy B. Darst. Beloved mother of Guy B. Jr., David M., Charles L., Daniel S. and the late James M. Darst. Dear grandmother of Elizabeth, David Jr., Devin, Winnie, Owen, Jim and Kathryn. She will be fondly remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAI, VISHVA ROOP
description: RAI-Vishva Roop. Of Parsippany, N.J. Beloved husband of Roopa, father of Ajay, brother of Kanti, Savitri, Shanta and Veena. Devoted uncle and friend. Died suddenly November 19, 2002 while on a business trip in Singapore. Funeral was held in Jaipur, India on November 23rd. Memorial service 11AM Saturday, January 18, 2003, in the United Nations Chapel, 777 U.N. Plaza (44 St between 1-2nd Avenues), N.Y., N.Y. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Center for Independence of the Disabled in New York, 841 Broadway, N.Y., N.Y. 10003, or Disha Foundation (for the Disha School) in Jaipur, C/O Ajay Rai, 2166 Broadway, New York, New York 10024.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Shift In Judge For Supremacist's Case
description: A federal judge from outside Chicago will handle the case of a white supremacist charged last week with soliciting the murder of a federal district judge. Judge Elaine E. Bucklo of the Northern District of Illinois, who was temporarily assigned to the case, gave no reason for the decision, but the defendant, Matt Hale, 31, left, the head of the World Church of the Creator, is charged with trying to arrange the death of her colleague, Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow. Judge Lefkow was presiding in a trademark infringement case filed against Mr. Hale's group. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Bush Shows Impatience With Iraq but Optimism on North Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  President Bush reiterated his pessimism and impatience over Iraq today, but in a significant shift, he expressed a new level of optimism and a measure of conciliation in addressing his other big foreign policy problem, North Korea.

title: U.N. Chief Says It Is Too Early to Consider War With Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 14  Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that it was too early for the Security Council to consider whether to authorize military action against Iraq, and he said he remained "both optimistic and hopeful" that war could be avoided.

title: Chicago Exchange Starts Campaign
description: Chicago Exchange Starts Campaign

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 6 about a New York State law requiring drivers to yield for pedestrians anywhere in a crosswalk included erroneous numbers from the State Department of Transportation for pedestrian deaths in 2000 in the city and state. The number in the city was 181, not 335. In the state it was 335 (17,000 was the number of pedestrians injured statewide in 2000).

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lebanon Township: Builder Killed In Home
description: A major home builder was shot and killed in his bed at his Lebanon Township home over the weekend, the acting Hunterdon County prosecutor, Steven C. Lember, disclosed yesterday. No motive was offered and no arrests had been made in the slaying of the builder, Michael Parisi, Mr. Lember said. Mr. Parisi, 52, was shot either Saturday night or Sunday morning, the police said. He had built hundreds of homes in Hunterdon County, and was also a partner in two restaurants. The police said his silver Corvette had been found outside the county and was in police custody. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: N.F.L. Desperate to Curb Officials' Crucial Gaffes
description: No one would talk about game officials if they were perfect, and over the last eight days, there has been a lot of conversation about them in the National Football League. One of those discussions yesterday was between Art Modell, the owner of the Baltimore Ravens, and the Giants co-owner Wellington Mara.

title: Fight Over Committee Power Delays Ridge Confirmation
description: A partisan fight over reorganization of the Senate spilled tonight onto the Senate floor, with Republican leaders demanding control over committee assignments, financing and office space, and Democrats insisting that they retain their chairmanships until they get what they view as an equitable power-sharing arrangement.

title: City to Resume Recycling Of Plastics
description: New York City is poised to resume recycling plastic this summer and save a significant amount of money thanks to a New Jersey company's bid to pay the city for its crumpled water bottles and deli containers, city officials said yesterday.

title: Now Playing In a Suite Near You
description: You have read the critics' top 10 movies lists for 2002. Now here are the 10 most-watched films in hotel rooms in 2002, in order of popularity, according to the On Command Corporation, the leading supplier of in-room movies for hotels:

title: Joint Service for Exit Polls Shuts Down; Networks Say They Plan New System for 2004
description: The vote analysis service at the center of the confusion over the 2000 presidential balloting officially went out of business yesterday. Its demise leaves in doubt the news media's plans for projecting the outcomes of the 2004 election.

title: Masters of Suicide Bombing: Tamil Guerrillas of Sri Lanka

title: Finns Prove the Adage: You Get What You Pay For
description: The excellence of the Finnish Radio Symphony Orchestra's New York debut concert on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall was a testimony to the budget priorities of the Finnish government. Put some real money into music institutions and music education, as Finland has for decades, and this is what you get: a fine orchestra (one of several there) with skilled, enthusiastic and noticeably young players, and a dynamic, technically formidable conductor, Jukka-Pekka Saraste, who has been the orchestra's music director for 12 high-growth years. Not to mention, back in Finland, a nation of musically informed concertgoers.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: WOMAN SHOT TO DEATH AT MIDTOWN HOTEL A woman was shot to death in a Times Square hotel room early this morning, and the police arrested the man with whom she was staying, the police said. Both were from Oregon, said an officer outside the hotel where the shooting occurred, the DoubleTree Guest Suites at 1568 Broadway near West 47th Street. The man and the woman, whose names were not released, had been staying on the 43rd floor and the room was in the man's name, with the woman on the register as his guest, the police said. The police were called just past midnight, after the man, in his 50's, presented the hotel desk clerk with a gun and sat down in a chair in lobby, said Det. Robert Price. Officers went to his room and discovered the woman on the floor, shot four or five times in the head, an officer at the scene said.

description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan 14  The Indonesian police said today that they had arrested two more suspects in the Bali terrorist attack, including a man they believed drove the van packed with the explosives for the blast that killed 192 people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCHALE, DR. THOMAS RILEY
description: McHALE-Dr. Thomas Riley. An economist and Southeast Asia expert who also advised the Saudi government in the 1970's, died December 10, 2002 at age 77. Dr. McHale was born on March 20, 1925, in Waterbury, Connecticut. He won a scholarship to attend Yale University, which he entered in 1941. In 1943, his studies were interrupted by World War II. Mr. McHale enlisted in the Naval Air Corps and served in the Pacific Theater, including the Philippines. Thus began a connection to the Philippines which lasted more than fifty years. After demobilization in 1946, he returned to Yale and finished his B.A. He was later awarded a doctorate from Harvard University in political economy in 1959. Dr. McHale's life and work spanned disparate worlds. He was a businessman (specializing in developing economies) who had a long connection to academia. He was an expert on Southeast Asia who also worked in the Middle East. He published books on rubber in Malaysia and (with his spouse) on Nathaniel Bowditch, who served on the first American vessel, the Astrea, to engage in trade with the Philippines. He authored articles on a wide variety of topics, including Malaysian and Philippine economic development, the world oil market, and the future of Saudi Arabia. He served as a visiting professor at the SAIS/ Johns Hopkins as well as at the University of Malaya. Most of Dr. McHale's career involved work as an economist for businesses, foundations and investment banking firms. He served on the World Bank's Rueff Mission, led by the French Inspector General of Finance in 1962, to chart the economic integration of the Federation of Malaya, Borneo, and Singapore to form Malaysia. In 1965 he became the Executive Vice President of Victorias Milling Company in the Philippines, the largest integrated sugar mill and refinery in the world. He left Victorias Milling Company in 1969 to take a writing and research sabbatical. In 1971, he joined Stanford Research Institute (SRI) to advise the government of Saudi Arabia on economic planning, and then later became a special adviser to Harold Geneen, President of ITT. He also served with three investment banking firms as a senior economist: Morgan Stanley, Drexel Burnham Lambert, and Goldman Sachs. Mr. McHale was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and a longtime member of the Association for Asian Studies. He is survived by his wife, Mary Coughlin McHale, and six children. He will be buried in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Los Angeles's playful side
description: LOS ANGELES  What do Bob Dylan, Jimmy Page, Robert Plant, Lenny Kravitz, Dave Navarro and Steven Tyler all have in common except music? All of these gents have been known to strut about in the rock 'n' roll couture made by Henry Duarte in his Los Angeles studio. But anyone can feel like a rock star now that Duarte is selling his hip-hugging, low-riding, lace-up pants and leather and denim jeans off the rack in his new store on Melrose Avenue.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Agreement On Mentally Ill Inmates
description: Los Angeles County has agreed to significant changes in the way it handles more than 2,500 mentally ill jail inmates, avoiding a potentially costly civil rights lawsuit by the United States Justice Department. The agreement followed a six-year federal investigation into mistreatment of inmates, who in many cases were subjected to beatings, excessive use of restraints and overprescription of drugs. The county, which runs the largest municipal jail system in the country, agreed to adhere to new rules covering virtually every aspect of the custody of the inmates. John M. Broder (NYT)

Levin, who was resigning.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a manufacturer's decision to retain the traditional nondairy recipe and kosher labeling for Stella D'Oro cookies misstated the symbol used by the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations for products that are pareve -- that is, made with neither meat nor dairy ingredients. It is ''OU Pareve,'' or simply ''OU.'' (''OU-P'' signifies a food that is kosher for Passover -- free of contact with leavened dough.) The cookies, favored in Orthodox Jewish communities as a dessert after meat, are pareve but not kosher for Passover.

title: CONGOLEUM, MAKER OF FLOORING, TO FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Congoleum Corporation, a maker of sheet and tile flooring, said it would file for bankruptcy protection to erase its current and future asbestos liability. Officials of the company said that it hoped to emerge from Chapter 11 protection within six months after setting up a trust to compensate people who assert they have health problems linked to asbestos in some Congoleum products. Congoleum's operations ''have been overshadowed by the cloud of asbestos litigation hanging over this company,'' the chairman, Roger Marcus, said. The company, which is based in Mercerville, N.J., laid off 150 workers, or 13 percent of its work force, last year.

description: It is perhaps a measure of his ambition as much as his political skill that when the man they call Joe finally announced today that he was running for president, friends and supporters admitted feeling a thrill but no surprise.

title: D&B PLANS TO CUT 550 JOBS, OR 7% OF WORK FORCE
description: D&B, the provider of business information once known as Dun & Bradstreet, said yesterday that it planned to cut 550 jobs, or about 7.1 percent of its work force, by July to reduce costs. The company, which is based in Short Hills, N.J., said it expected additional expenses of about $16 million before taxes, or 14 cents a share, in connection with the cuts. D&B had 7,800 employees as of Dec. 31, 2001, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company also said it was in talks to sell its European headquarters in Britain and expected to have noncash pretax costs of about $13 million, or 17 cents a share, for that transaction. Bruno de la Riviere, president of the company's European unit, resigned.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: SHIFT IN JUDGE FOR SUPREMACIST'S CASE A federal judge from outside Chicago will handle the case of a white supremacist charged last week with soliciting the murder of a federal district judge. Judge Elaine E. Bucklo of the Northern District of Illinois, who was temporarily assigned to the case, gave no reason for the decision, but the defendant, Matt Hale, 31, left, the head of the World Church of the Creator, is charged with trying to arrange the death of her colleague, Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow. Judge Lefkow was presiding in a trademark infringement case filed against Mr. Hale's group. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

A standing ovation at the historic Palazzo Corsini greeted the retrospective show of Cardin's silver overalls, space-age minis, spinning satellite sleeves and hula-hoop dresses tracing the geometric lines of his half-century career.

title: As Cases of Induced Labor Rise, So Do Experts' Concerns
description: A number of obstetrical experts are becoming increasingly concerned about the growing number of pregnant women whose labors are induced for no apparent medical reason. Since 1990, the proportion of births resulting from an induced labor has doubled: one baby in five is now born after the birth process has been started by a drug.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NEPAL: NEW CLASHES WITH REBELS At least 15 people have been killed in renewed fighting in two parts of western Nepal, Agence France-Presse reported. Army officials reported continuing clashes in Accham, about 120 miles west of Katmandu, where Maoists and security forces have been fighting since Sunday, but did not give a casualty figure. The Nepalese press reported that 15 rebels were killed yesterday in a separate clash in Bhojpur, about 135 miles west of Katmandu.    David Rohde (NYT)

title: APACHE SAYS IT IS BUYING OIL AND GAS RESERVES FROM BP
description: The Apache Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy oil and natural gas reserves in the North Sea and the Gulf of Mexico from BP for $1.3 billion in cash. Apache, which is based in Houston, will issue 6.2 million shares and take on long-term debt to pay for the BP holdings, a spokesman, Tony Lentini, said. Apache said the acquisition would lead to a 29 percent increase in production and that it had already found buyers for the oil and gas. The purchase includes a 96.14 percent stake in the Forties oil field in the North Sea, the companies said. The Gulf of Mexico will become Apache's biggest producing region after the acquisition of the BP properties off the coast of Texas and Louisiana, the company said.

description: When red deer stand up and honeybees dance, they are not simply stretching their legs or indicating where the nectar is, according to a new study. As bizarre as it may seem, they are voting on whether to move to greener pastures or richer flowers.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Executives Appointed
description: France's third-largest bank, Socit Gnrale, announced four appointments to its general management committee, naming Jean-Pierre Musiter the head of its corporate and investment banking unit, succeeding Xavier Debonneuil, who was killed in a car crash in December. Socit Gnrale named Frdric Ouda as chief financial officer, succeeding Herve Saint-Saveur, who will become special adviser to the chairman, Daniel Bouton. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burberry's Sales Rise
description: The Burberry Group said that third-quarter sales rose by a third, bolstered by new stores and brisk sales of cashmere scarves and coats. Rose Marie Bravo, who has led the charge to revitalize Burberry, is opening stores in large cities like New York. Total retail stores now stand at 129, after seven stores were added in the last three months. Burberry has been one of the few bright spots in a retail industry suffering from economic malaise and a downturn in tourism. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Governor Wants New Death Row

The new unit would house about 1,000 inmates at San Quentin prison, accommodating a growing death row population. There are 604 inmates awaiting execution. The state averages more than 20 death sentences a year but only about one execution. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

Vladimir Putin's plan to hold a referendum on a proposed new constitution in March, followed by new presidential and parliamentary elections, is superficially appealing, but falls short of the steps needed to bring the conflict to a democratic resolution.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot In Attempted Robbery

The robber, who was shot in the face, neck and torso, was one of three men who tried to rob the shop, on Mother Gaston Boulevard in Brownsville, just before noon, Detective Kevin Czartoryski said. The other two suspects took the wounded man to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center and drove off, the police said. The security guard was shot in the buttocks and was in stable condition at Brookdale, the police said. Andy Newman (NYT)

Some figures show that 61 percent of Michigan residents are overweight. The program, which will lose more than half of its $1 million budget and 13 of its 19 paid staff members, focused on teaching children the value of exercise. David Enders (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 5 about the role that Iraqi tribes might play in an American military campaign against Saddam Hussein misstated the history of a British defeat during World War I. As many as 30,000 British and Indian soldiers were killed or wounded at the hands of Turkish Ottoman forces joined by Iraqi tribesmen besieging the town of Kut, about 170 miles south of Baghdad. (That figure includes thousands who were not killed during combat, but perished either during a forced march across northern Iraq after the British and Indian troops surrendered or during their imprisonment in Anatolia.) The casualties were not solely at the hands of tribesmen.

description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it would combine its Minute Maid North America business with its North American unit. Don Knauss, the president of Minute Maid North America, was appointed to lead the merger of the two divisions. The new unit will report to Jeffrey T. Dunn, the president of Coca-Cola North America. The company also appointed Sandy Douglas, who is the president of Coke's North American division, to the new post of chief customer officer. Mr. Douglas will report to Steven J. Heyer, Coke's president and chief operating officer, and will be responsible for working with other Coke units to revamp the company's customer service strategy. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rebels Accused Of Killing Civilians
description: Russian officials accused guerrillas in Chechnya of abducting and then blowing up 10 civilians outside Grozny, the capital of the separatist republic, the Interfax news agency reported. The chief prosecutor of the pro-Russian Chechen administration, Vladimir Kravchenko, said that the civilians' dismembered remains were recently discovered scattered over an area of two and a half acres and that the killings appeared to have taken place sometime last month. He offered no evidence to support the assertion that the victims, who were not publicly identified, had been killed by guerrillas. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFFER, PHILIP
description: SCHIFFER-Philip. Formerly of Brooklyn and Delray Beach. Beloved husband of Ronnie, dear father of Daniel (Sheila) and Robert (Mary Ann Holohean) Schiffer, five grandchildren, one great granddaughter. Services and interment Wednesday in Michigan. For further information call the Ira Kaufman Chapel, 800-325-7105.

title: First Joint Appearance Set By 6 Presidential Hopefuls
description: The six Democratic candidates for president have agreed to appear on the same stage for the first time in the campaign to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision removing restrictions on abortion.

title: Shadows on a Wall in Portugal's Long Nightmare
description: THE INQUISITORS' MANUAL

title: Dayne Says He Didn't Request a Trade
description: Giants General Manager Ernie Accorsi has received a letter from Ron Dayne's agent suggesting that it might be a good time for the team to trade Dayne. But Dayne told a club spokesman yesterday that he did not want to be traded, and that he did not authorize the letter.

title: Lost in Afghanistan (Maybe): Bin Laden (Still) and 2 Others
description: Three leftover enemies from the war here remain at large and, American and Afghan officials say, still pose a potentially lethal threat to peace in this region even as the United States turns its attention toward Iraq.

title: Downtown Visions: Who Decides?
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Police Scholars
description: New Jersey has found a new way to recruit state troopers. In the only program of its kind in the country, the State Police department provides stipends of $5,000 a year, an annual paid state police internship, and mentoring by a state trooper to selected students at Rutgers University's Newark campus who intend to join the force. The program began last year with five New Jersey State Police Scholars, and it recently named 10 new scholars. They are Alicja Chrzanowska, Matthew Durak, Moya Hodges, Wojciech Jastrzab, Jason Jorgenson, Jackson Liautaud, Thomas Manco, April Reichelmann, Kelly Rieder and Jose Velez Jr.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mendham: Toddler Dies From Injuries
description: A 3-year-old girl who was pulled from her blazing home Sunday has died from her injuries. Firefighters had found the girl, Julia Metzler, underneath a bed. Her mother, Margaret Metzler, and two siblings had escaped. Suffering from smoke inhalation, Julia was brought to Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, where she died at 6:45 p.m. Monday. A candle might have started the fire, said Lt. Jeffrey Paul of the Morris County prosecutor's office. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: New Players on Global Warming
description: Given the Bush administration's inert approach to global warming, the best hope for getting a start on the problem this year lies with the Senate. The prospect that something will actually happen there improved greatly this week with the introduction of a bipartisan bill bearing the signatures of two marquee sponsors, Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut and John McCain of Arizona.

title: The Glow and the Glare
description: ON a dim street in the East Village, a warm, buttery glow spills forth from the restaurant Prune. For approaching diners, the light may spur hunger or a sense of relaxation or put a spring in the step. But they might not realize what has happened until they're well into the main course.

title: Britain's Hunt for Child Pornography Users Nets Hundreds Besides Pete Townshend
description: The list includes police officers and dentists, judges and politicians, lawyers, teachers and social workers and, as of Monday, the guitarist Pete Townshend from the Who. In all, more than 1,300 people have been arrested in Britain in the past 10 months as part of Operation Ore, a nationwide hunt for users of child Internet pornography.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: THREATS MADE AGAINST DEPUTY MAYOR Deputy Mayor Marc V. Shaw received several threatening phone calls last month and police officers were temporarily assigned to guard his house, administration officials said yesterday. The calls followed Mr. Shaw's public criticism of the Fire Department. Mr. Shaw said firefighters fight fires only 5 percent of the time and "are hanging around doing nothing the other 95 percent of the time." Mr. Shaw's office at City Hall received at least two calls from unidentified men who commented on Mr. Shaw's remarks and made references to his family. Mr. Shaw, who is in charge of the city's operations and oversees the budget process, would not comment last night.   Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Black District Attorney Takes Office
description: Eddie Jordan, who in 1994 became the first African-American United States attorney for eastern Louisiana, took office as the first elected black district attorney of New Orleans. Mr. Jordan, 50, was elected on Nov. 5 to replace the retiring Harry Connick Sr., who held the office for 29 years. Mr. Jordan, who successfully prosecuted former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards in 2000 for racketeering and fraud, has pledged to reduce New Orleans's rising violent crime rate.

title: Company News
description: HEINZ CREATES CONSUMER AND BUSINESS UNITS

title: Pentagon Official Wants to Speed Rebuilding of Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 15  Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy defense secretary, called today for accelerating the reconstruction of Afghanistan, and he outlined a new plan for using American, Afghan and possibly European forces to improve security in more than half a dozen cities racked by banditry and factional fighting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTER, FRANCES
description: KANTER-Frances. Of N. Miami Beach and NYC, after a long illness on January 13. Wife of the late Harold (as of June 22, '02). Beloved mother of Carolyn and Michael Kanter and Sue and Steven Kanter. Grandmother of Drew. Loving sister of Kiki. Generous aunt, and animal lover. Services today at Schwartz Brothers, Forest Hills.

title: President of Zimbabwe Insists That He Won't Step Down Early
description: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe denied today that he had agreed to retire as part of a power-sharing deal with the leading opposition party.

title: Calendar
description: Cupid in the Kitchen

title: Microsoft to Give Governments Access to Code
description: To try to slow the acceptance of the Linux operating system by governments abroad, Microsoft is announcing today that it will allow most governments to study the programming code of its Windows systems. Under the program, governments will also be allowed to plug their security features instead of Microsoft's technology into Windows.

title: Heady Coffee Brews From Vienna
description: The richly aromatic coffee served with or without whipped cream at Cafe Sabarsky in the Neue Galerie, above, is now available in New York stores. It is made by Julius Meinl (pronounced MY-nil), a Viennese coffee company that has been in business since 1862. Most of the coffees are blends notable for rounded flavor and low acidity, with names like Wiener Melange, Imperial Melange and Vienna Night. They are roasted medium-dark, typical in Vienna, and are sold both whole bean and ground. Some decaffeinated varieties are available. I especially liked the mellow Wiener Melange with steamed milk and the more robust King Hadhramaut, black. The coffees are $8.50 to $10 for about 17 ounces at Zabar's and Grace's Marketplace in Manhattan and at Chef Central in North Paramus, N.J. Dean & DeLuca carries special assortments for $16 and $28. The coffees are also sold, mostly for $6.80 to $8.50, from www.meinl.com. There is a shipping charge of $18.99 for up to 10 pounds.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Domestic Partner Benefits
description: A group of City Council members called on New York City Transit to extend domestic partnership benefits to all employees yesterday. Their call came in support of a lawsuit brought by James Reilly, a gay subway motorman who wants the agency, which operates the city's buses and subways, to extend his benefits to his partner of 20 years. Although the city extends domestic partnership benefits to its employees, New York City Transit has argued that as an independent agency it is not bound to do so, city officials said. The tentative contract recently negotiated by the Transport Workers Union would extend some benefits to domestic partners. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Chimay Journal; Monks' Brew Showers Blessings on Belgian Town
description: With his billowing white beard and black and white hooded habit, Dom Armand Veilleux, a Canadian-born monk in his mid-60's, more resembles a figure from Umberto Eco's novel of monastic mystery, ''The Name of the Rose,'' than your average brewery executive.

title: As You Like It (Sandwich Division)
description: Lunch Boxes Etc., a food shop decorated with new and old lunchboxes, is the kind of storefront you would expect to see in the East Village, not at 21 West 100th Street, just steps from Central Park.

title: Holik Challenges the Rangers' History of Complacency
description: Bobby Holik cannot remember the last time he went this far into the season without his team's having won three consecutive games, which is exactly what the Rangers will be trying to do for the first time this season tonight when they play the Capitals in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISIG, MINNA M. (NEE MAX)
description: FLEISIG-Minna M. (nee Max), of Bayonne, New Jersey, on January 14. Beloved wife of the late Morris, devoted mother of Richard and Martin Fleisig, loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services will be held at Mokom Shalom Cemetery, Ozone Park, N.Y. on Thursday, January 15, at 10AM. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to Franciscan Home, Jersey City, N.J. Call for information Wien & Wien 1-800-322-0533

title: Slow on Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Panamsat Posts Higher Profit
description: The PanAmSat Corporation yesterday posted a higher fourth-quarter profit, beating the average Wall Street forecast, but revenue declined as demand for video services weakened. The satellite communications company, which includes broadcasters among its customers, also said that its growth strategy was aimed at taking advantage of consolidation in the industry. PanAmSat said its profit rose to $23.5 million, or 16 cents a share, from $3.2 million, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier. Shares were up 32 cents, to $15.50.

title: A Crucial Decision on Race
description: With the government's briefs due tomorrow, President Bush has become personally involved in deciding the administration's position on the two big affirmative action cases scheduled for argument in the Supreme Court in April.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Debating the Future

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Vetoes Cellphone Limits
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed a bill yesterday that would ban the use of mobile phones during public performances. In his veto message, Mr. Bloomberg conceded that such use was ''in most cases'' rude and disrespectful. Nonetheless, he wrote, the law would be unenforceable because it could apply in so many locations. He added that existing solutions, like the ''reproof of other members of the audience,'' were more effective. The bill passed the City Council by a vote of 40 to 9, with two abstentions, more than the 34 votes needed to override a veto. But last night a Council spokesman would say only that the veto was ''under review.'' Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: $70 Million in Fines Paid In Illegal Stock Trading

title: Evaluating a Brooklyn Principal, Measure for Questionable Measure
description: NEW YORK CITY's schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, has been quietly grading principals from A to F, based almost solely on how their students perform on state tests.

title: Annan Says Talk of War With Iraq Is Premature, but Warns Baghdad It Must Disarm
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 14  Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that it was too early for the Security Council to consider military action against Iraq and said he remained "both optimistic and hopeful" that war could be avoided.

title: Steve Case, Genius
description: The morning after announcing he would resign as chairman of AOL Time Warner, Steve Case was asked to feel his shareholders' pain. ''In a personal sense, how badly do you feel about the almost $200 billion worth of shareholder value that has been wiped out?'' asked an interviewer on CNN. Not too bad, apparently. His face expressionless, Mr. Case said: ''I recognize a lot of people have bet on this company and are disappointed by the results. But it's never over till it's over.''

title: Doctors Are Ironing Out Details For Giving the Smallpox Vaccine
description: With smallpox vaccinations for half a million health and emergency workers scheduled to begin later this month, doctors advising the government were still ironing out details yesterday of who should avoid the vaccine and how it should be given.

title: The Nuclear Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, HARRIS
description: SILVER-Harris. Beloved husband of Laura and cherished son of Stephen and Adrienne. Dearest brother of Jill Eisenberg and Susan Bernstein. Services Thursday, January 16, at 11:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Handful of Indictments Over Technology
description: In three separate cases since October, natives of China have been accused of obtaining technology from Silicon Valley companies with the intent of exporting it to China.

title: Sniper Suspect in Court
description: Prosecutors seeking to have Lee Malvo tried as an adult on capital murder charges told a juvenile court judge that fingerprints, notes and phone calls linked him to the Washington-area sniper shootings.

title: Another Gotti Case Opens, This Time With 2 Marquee Names
description: Federal prosecutors evoked the history of Mafia domination of the New York waterfront and repeated their claim of a movie-star extortion as they opened their case yesterday against Peter Gotti, who the government says is the boss of the Gambino crime family.

title: WebEx to Begin $8 Million Campaign
description: WebEx Communications, the online-meetings company in San Jose, Calif., will begin an $8 million national television, radio and print campaign on Monday that again features a celebrity in humorous situations.

title: Alinghi Increases Lead in Series
description: The most exciting race so far in the Louis Vuitton Cup had it all: tacking and jibing duels, brilliant crew work, penalties and contact between 70-foot-long carbon fiber yachts. The Swiss team Alinghi, helmed by Russell Coutts, crossed the line one second ahead of its American rival, Oracle-BMW of San Francisco, which was penalized a minute to make the official margin 61 seconds.

title: Wall St. Analyst and Husband Under Scrutiny
description: Holly B. Becker, one of Wall Street's most powerful Internet stock analysts, and her husband have been notified by securities regulators that they may face enforcement action over possible insider trading based on her firm's research.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Pope Adds Three Trips
description: Pope John Paul II, will make at least four foreign trips this year, beginning with a short visit to Spain in May, said the Vatican spokesman, Joaqun Navarro-Valls. The announcement came a day after a Vatican official outlined plans for the pope to visit Croatia in early June. Dr. Navarro-Valls said that after Croatia, the pope would go to Bosnia later that month, followed by Slovakia in September. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Think Rich, Vote Rich, Get Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Weighing Brief Opposing College on Race
description: President Bush has asked administration lawyers to present him with a brief arguing that the University of Michigan's programs for using race in admission decisions go too far, officials said today.

title: Matsui Draws His First Crowd for the Yankees
description: There was music pulsating from overhead speakers, enough lights to bathe Yankee Stadium in yellow, and more than 400 people inside a ballroom yesterday at the Marriott Marquis Hotel in Times Square, a raucous setting that would have been appropriate for a fancy wedding. Actually, it was a marriage, but not in the formal sense. It was a baseball marriage between outfielder Hideki Matsui and the Yankees.

title: Roddick Struggles at Start of His Slam Quest
description: Andy Roddick still looks the way he did last season on a tennis court: with his eternally rumpled hair, visor and respect-demanding serve and forehand. But he intends for this year to be significantly different than the last, and even though he is seeded a lofty ninth in this Australian Open, there is a restless air to Roddick.

title: With Land Deal, Town Aims to Bulldoze a Scandal
description: When Elizabeth S. Grubman backed an S.U.V. into a crowd of clubgoers here two summers ago, she put the Conscience Point Inn on the map for people who had never set foot in the Hamptons. But to the nightclub's neighbors, the crash -- and the crush of curiosity seekers it drew -- was only the latest annoyance from an establishment they have complained about for years.

title: McGreevey To Legislators: Fight Sprawl
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey today issued a fervent call to legislators in New Jersey, the most congested state in the nation, to curb the development and sprawl that he said were devouring 50 acres a day.

title: Borrowing Seems Inevitable To Close State Budget Gap
description: With 10 weeks left until the end of the fiscal year, Gov. George E. Pataki is running out of time to close a budget gap projected at $2.5 billion, and it appeared certain today that the state would have to borrow money to balance the books.

title: Recipe: Spiced Pecans
description: Time: About 15 minutes

title: Sit Tight. Turbulence Ahead.
description: Jeanine Durning is a paradoxical creature. She looks like a timid, sweet-natured wren and moves with a wonderful practicality. But the two premieres she presented on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop filled the stage with monumental gale-wind forces made of subtly paced movement alone, in dances that embodied inner and outward turbulence.

title: Indonesian Province Enjoying First Signs of Peace
description: Children are playing outside again, street vendors are selling soda and couples are strolling on the rutted walkways, simple pleasures that perhaps spell some return of normalcy to Aceh, the northern Indonesian province torn apart by conflict for nearly 30 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESMERIAN, VIRGINIA SIEG MAN
description: ESMERIAN - Virginia Sieg man. Died peacefully at home on Sunday, January 12th in her 100th year. Beloved mother of Jacqueline, Edward and Ralph. Cherished grandmother of Eric, Pierre, Anne, Cynthia, Philip, Edward and Frederic. Loving greatgrandmother of 14.

title: Stormy Raiders See a Silver Lining
description: Tom Flores, the last man to coach the Raiders to a Super Bowl, is a radio broadcaster for the team, a strange job for someone who admittedly used to loathe talking about anything. As a coach, Flores would avoid telephone calls from his coordinators during the game because ''everybody was always yelling,'' he said in a telephone interview yesterday from Indian Wells, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVICK, JANIS
description: NOVICK-Janis. A teacher who taught us to cherish friends and family, to work hard, and to never give up. Beloved wife of Mitch. Loving mother of Jeffrey and Melissa Chwast and wife of the late Michael Chwast. Cherished daughter of Thelma and the late Sanford Finkelstein. Dear sister of Amy and Jeff Feibusch and adored aunt of Eric and Michelle. Services: ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 1:30 PM Wednesday.

title: Regulator Reaffirms Focus on S.U.V.'s
description: The Bush administration's chief traffic safety regulator reaffirmed today that regulating sport utility vehicles would be a top priority.

title: Bush Opposes University of Michigan on Race
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  President Bush offered a sweeping denunciation of direct preferences for racial minorities in university admissions today and said his administration would file a brief with the Supreme Court urging that the affirmative action admissions policies at the University of Michigan be declared unconstitutional.

title: Last Suspect in Financier's Kidnapping Is Named
description: Agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation were searching today for a 23-year-old man recently discharged from the United States Marine Corps who they believe is the fourth suspect in last weekend's kidnapping of a wealthy Greenwich financier, federal law enforcement officials said.

title: New Creative Heads at Two Agencies
description: Two agencies have hired creative chiefs.

title: Bush Urges Congress to Extend Welfare Law, With Changes
description: President Bush called on the new Congress today to move quickly to extend the 1996 welfare law for five years and to revise it by imposing stricter work requirements on welfare recipients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIRONE, PASCAL P.
description: PIRONE-Pascal P. Died on January 11 in Lexington, KY, at the age of 95. Dr. Pirone received B.S. and Ph.D. degrees from Cornell University and was a faculty member at Cornell and Rutgers Universities prior to joining the New York Botanical Garden as plant pathologist in 1974. He lectured and consulted widely, and wrote hundreds of scientific and popular articles on plant care. Two of his books, ''Diseases and Pests of Ornamental Plants'' and ''Tree Maintenance'', were the leading sources of information in these areas for several decades. He was the recipient of numerous awards from professional societies. His wife, Loretta, and son, John, predeceased him. A daughter, Mary Pirone of Sotogrande, Spain, sons, Joseph of Hancock, NY, and Thomas, of Lexington, KY, and five grandchildren survive him. Services at Ralph Giordano Funeral Home, Bronx, New York., Contributions may be made to Camp Venture, Nanuet, NY 10954.

title: MAGELLAN HEALTH CONSIDERS FILING FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Magellan Health Services is talking to its lenders about the possibility of filing for bankruptcy protection, the company said yesterday. Magellan, one of the nation's largest managed care companies in mental health, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was circulating a proposal with those lenders outlining a plan to restructure its debt. The company, which has about $1 billion in debt, said any bankruptcy filing would not affect its regular payments to hospitals, doctors, its employees or its customers. Under the proposal, $625 million of senior subordinated notes would be exchanged for ''substantially all of the equity of the company,'' according to the financial statements. The company's stock, which traded as high as $8.93 in April 2002, closed yesterday at 17 cents. Reed Abelson (NYT)

title: A Rarely Played Bruckner And a Testimony to His Faith
description: The American Symphony; the Concert Chorale of New York; Meagan Miller, soprano; Elizabeth Batton, mezzo-soprano; and Richard Clement, tenor

title: Airbus Says It Is on Course To Lead Market in Aircraft
description: Airbus said today that it was raising the price of its aircraft by an average of 2.5 percent and forecast that it would deliver about 300 aircraft this year, setting it on course to be the market leader in terms of orders and deliveries over the Boeing Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSLER, ARTHUR N., M.D.
description: TESSLER-Arthur N., M.D. The faculty, staff and students of NYU Medical Center mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Arthur N. Tessler, M.D. An outstanding clinician, Dr. Tessler was one of the Medical Center's most accomplished urologists. Throughout his long career as a physician, Dr. Tessler embodied the finest traditions of the medical profession. He will be deeply missed by all who had the privilege to know and work with him. Our sincere condolences to his family. Robert M. Glickman, M.D., Dean, NYU School of Medicine CEO, NYU Hospitals Center Theresa A. Bischoff, President NYU Hospitals Center Herbert Lepor, M.D., Chairman, Dept. of Urology, NYU School of Medicine

title: Missed Dunk Helps St. Raymond's Win
description: Shagari Alleyne, Rice High School's 7-foot-2 senior center, made 11 of 14 shots from the floor, all but two of them dunks, in last night's game against St. Raymond's at the Gauchos Gym in the Bronx. He missed only two shots in the second half, but it was his last miss, on a dunk attempt, that he will remember after a 68-62 loss.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: SUIT DEFENDS RELIGIOUS SPEECH A group of Springfield high school students who were suspended after defying a principal's order not to hand out candy canes affixed with religious notes have filed a federal lawsuit against school officials, asserting that their right to free speech was violated. Six of seven students, all of whom received one-day suspensions for violating a school rule that forbids students from handing out material unrelated to the school curriculum, joined the lawsuit. The candy canes had notes attached that said their "J" shape stood for Jesus.

title: Producer From U.S. Shelves Oil Sands Project in Canada
description: An ambitious project to extract oil from tar sands at Fort Hills in northern Alberta has been shelved, a Canadian unit of Koch Industries of Kansas said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLTA, JACQUES
description: SOLTA-Jacques, 85. Died January 13, 2003. Loving companion of the late Ruth Shapiro and son of the late Deborah Soltanitzsky. He is survived by his daughters, Nadya and Dana, grandson, Leland, sons-in-law, Dr. Barton Hoexter and Owen Wild. For over fifty years he was a member of the American Stock Exchange. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Services will be held Sunday, January 19th, 2003 at 11:30 AM at Riverside Memorial, Amsterdam and West 76th Street. Dad, forever rest in peace.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about lore and local eccentricities in the wine-growing country of the Anderson Valley in California misstated the cause of death of a local environmental advocate, Judi Bari. It was not a bomb; although permanently disabled by a pipe bomb in her car in 1990, Ms. Bari died of cancer in 1997.

title: Justices Reject a Double-Jeopardy Claim
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution's bar against double jeopardy does not protect a murder defendant from being sentenced to death in a new trial after the first jury had deadlocked over the sentence.

title: Poverty in Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Going Green Is Called a Matter of Economics
description: The tools for constructing environmentally conscious, energy-efficient office buildings have existed for decades, but commercial developers have not adopted the principles of what is commonly called green or sustainable building because a compelling case demonstrating the economic rewards has not been made, according to specialists in real estate, finance, design, construction and environmental health and safety.

title: Annan Says Talk of War With Iraq Is Premature, but Warns Baghdad It Must Disarm
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that it was too early for the Security Council to consider military action against Iraq and said he remained ''both optimistic and hopeful'' that war could be avoided.

title: Hearing Starts for Teenager in Virginia Sniper Case
description: Prosecutors seeking to have Lee Malvo tried as an adult on capital murder charges told a juvenile-court judge today that fingerprints, as well as notes and phone calls to investigators all linked him to the sniper shootings in the Washington area that left 10 dead.

title: FOOD DISTRIBUTOR CUTS OUTLOOK FOR 4TH QUARTER
description: The Fleming Companies, one of the country's top wholesale food distributors, cut its fourth-quarter earnings outlook yesterday, citing soft sales and higher meat prices and employee costs. The company, which is based in Lewisville, Tex., also announced a charge of about $116 million for discontinued operations relating to the pending sale of some retail operations. Fleming said it had signed agreements to sell 32 discount warehouse grocery stores to Save Mart Supermarkets. Fleming now expects to report earnings from continuing operations of $5 million to $6 million, or 10 cents to 12 cents a share, on sales of about $4.08 billion. Analysts expected fourth-quarter earnings of 31 cents a share, on revenue of $3.98 billion, according to Thomson First Call. Fleming stock fell $1.48, or 23 percent, to $5.04 a share.

title: Transition in Senate Leads to Impasse and Accusations
description: Republicans won control of the Senate on Nov. 5, but Democrats are not stepping aside easily.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ACCPAC INTERNATIONAL, Pleasanton, Calif., a unit of Computer Associates International, Islandia, N.Y., acquired AGS Software, Toronto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODE, ANN PRYOR
description: RODE-Ann Pryor, 96. Of Yorkville, Manhattan died on January 12. Mrs. Rode, an Eastside District Leader for more than fifty years, represented the Yorkville neighborhood with passion and courage her entire life. Mrs. Rode was one of the first women elected District Leader in New York County. She also served on the New York County Democratic Party's Executive Committee. Mrs. Rode mentored and guided countless public servants, elected officials and neighborhood advocates through their early development and deep into their careers. Her tireless generous commitment to helping all in need will be missed. Two grandsons, Robert and Thomas R. Pryor, a daughter-in-law, Rose Pryor, granddaughterin-law, Michele Pryor and a great-granddaughter, Alison L. Pryor, survive Mrs. Rode. Visiting on Thursday and Friday from 5-9 PM at Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th St. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30 AM at St. Stephen of Hungary Church, 408 East 82nd St. NYC

title: Van Horn Puts Up Numbers and Puts Up With Doubters
description: When the Philadelphia 76ers finished a long practice session today, Keith Van Horn walked to the sideline and plopped himself into a chair, feeling his teeth after taking a blow to the face in the spirited scrimmage. Coach Larry Brown went over, inquired about the injury and, assured that the damage was not serious, moved on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ''MICKEY''
description: GOLDMAN - ''Mickey''. On January 14 in Queens NY. Loving brother of Belle, devoted uncle of Roberta, Penny, Joan, Audrey, Barbara and Martin. A lifelong and true patriot. Member of the military and World War II veteran, he served in the army for 59 years and was awarded a Purple Heart. Funeral service on Thursday at 10 AM at Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York.

description: To the Editor:
