title: Opposing Views, but Shared Agonies in Occupied Territories
description: Two documentaries from the Israeli left, Ruth Walk's ''Settlers'' and Ram Loevy's ''Close, Closed, Closure,'' open today at the Film Forum in the South Village, both dealing with the agonies of the occupied territories, but from very different points of view. ''The Settlers'' examines life in the West Bank from the perspective of Israeli settlers, while ''Close, Closed, Closure'' depicts the lives of Palestinians living in the Gaza Strip.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Refiner's Profit Falls
description: BP said its oil-refining division was less profitable in the fourth quarter than it was in the third as seasonal shifts and a strike in Venezuela sent prices for crude oil soaring. Higher oil prices can dampen demand and make crude more costly to process. Slimmer margins at the oil-refining unit, which accounted for about two-thirds of BP's revenue last year, will be partly offset by wider margins at BP's drilling unit, which gains when prices rise, because it can charge more for the oil it pumps from the ground. BP's warning opens the door to the possibility that other large oil companies may see lower profits. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Samsung Profit Surges
description: Samsung Heavy Industries reported net income last year of $93 million, nearly twice the year-earlier figure. The company, Korea's second-largest shipbuilder after Hyundai Heavy Industries, said sales in 2002 had increased 3.7 percent, according to preliminary figures, enabling it to pay its first dividends since the period before the economic crisis of 1997 and 1998. The company said it had $3 billion in new orders last year, 36 percent higher than the year before. At the same time, Samsung Electronics, the world's leading manufacturer of memory chips and the flagship company of the Samsung Group, Korea's largest business group, announced plans to invest $911 million in new plants. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUKAT, SCOTT
description: SHUKAT - Scott. Cherished friend and personal manager for over twenty years. I am forever grateful for his strength, honesty, loyalty, intelligence and perseverance. My family and I will always honor his memory. Our love and deepest sympathies to his wife Evelyn and his son Jonathan. Alan, Janis, Anna Nora Menken

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a decision by Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas to sell his memoir to HarperCollins misstated the citizenship of Rupert Murdoch, whose company, the News Corporation, owns the publishing house. He is a naturalized American; he gave up Australian citizenship in 1985.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Suit Defends Religious Speech
description: A group of Springfield high school students who were suspended after defying a principal's order not to hand out candy canes affixed with religious notes have filed a federal lawsuit against school officials, asserting that their right to free speech was violated. Six of seven students, all of whom received one-day suspensions for violating a school rule that forbids students from handing out material unrelated to the school curriculum, joined the lawsuit. The candy canes had notes attached that said their ''J'' shape stood for Jesus. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Take One Chicken, Add Mint and Rose Petals
description: Spice rubs don't have to be saved for barbecues. Elements of Spice makes eight rubs that can be used to create sauces for pasta, savory roasts, stir-fries and more. Bed of Roses, a mix of ginger, garlic, sesame, cumin, turmeric, mint, nutmeg, saffron and rose petals, can be rubbed onto chicken thighs for a tagine. Thaiphoon -- basil, galangal, coriander leaves, Thai chilies, lime zest and lime leaves -- is good as a seasoning for stir-fried sliced chicken. (Add coconut milk and cilantro to the pan to make a sauce and serve over jasmine rice.) Rub Holey Smoke (brown sugar, wood-smoked sea salt, mustard and coriander seeds) onto wedges of pumpkin, squash or potatoes, drizzle with olive oil and roast until browned and tender. More ideas on the company's Web site: www.elements-of-spice.com. The rubs are $5.29 each at Fairway Markets and $7.95 at Broadway Panhandler. DENISE LANDIS

title: China Offers to Be Host of Direct U.S.-North Korea Talks
description: China stepped up an effort today to defuse the North Korea nuclear crisis, offering to act as host to direct talks between the United States and North Korea should both sides agree.

title: 2 Germans Go on Trial In Arms Sales To Baghdad
description: In a case likely to revive uncomfortable questions about Germany's past role in supplying Saddam Hussein's war machine, two German businessmen went on trial here today on charges of illegally selling Iraq components to build a long-range cannon.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Food Concern Cuts Outlook
description: Royal Wessanen, the world's largest marketer of specialty foods, cut its 2002 and 2003 profit forecasts late Monday and agreed to the departure of its chief executive, Mac Zondervan, after disappointing results at the company's Tree of Life distributor in the United States. Shares of Wessanen fell to a 10-year low. Supermarket chains and discounters like Wal-Mart have cut into Tree of Life's business, which includes the brands Harmony Farms and Peanut Wonder. Wessanen readjusted its 2002 earnings outlook -- before good will and one-time costs -- to 35 million to 40 million euros, down from an earlier estimate of 50 million euros. The chief executive and chief financial officer of Tree of Life North America have been replaced by a Wessanen executive, the company said. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Our Towns; Little Boys, Already Fading In Big Picture
description: ALREADY, the headlines have shrunk. CNN has moved on.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged With Posing As Fire Official
description: A 25-year-old Queens man was charged yesterday with impersonating a fire lieutenant and stealing $21,000 from eight people, the authorities said. The man, Maurice Knight, told at least 8 and possibly as many as 46 people that he could buy discounted cars for them from the city pound, said David Billig, a spokesman for the Fire Department. Mr. Knight then took money from the people without delivering cars, the authorities said. Mr. Knight's s home was searched and officers discovered military uniforms, ID badges for police officers and firefighters, pellet guns and a bulletproof vest. Mr. Knight was charged with forgery, grand and petty larceny, scheming to defraud, and possession of stolen property. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Synagogue Burglaries
description: A man who dressed as an Orthodox Jew and burglarized nine synagogues in Sheepshead Bay and Midwood in recent weeks has been arrested, the authorities said yesterday. From Dec. 28 until about Saturday, the man, Mark Cukierwar, 31, dressed in yarmulke and black suit, broke into the synagogues after hours and stole money from the collection boxes, said Carl Kruger, the local state senator, who announced the arrest. Senator Kruger said Mr. Cukierwar was Jewish but not Orthodox. In late December, Mr. Cukierwar fled a drug treatment center, where he was serving part of his sentence for a prior synagogue burglary, Senator Kruger said. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; The Later, The Colder, The Sillier
description: WITH the National Football League scheduling its playoff games later and later, the Weather Channel should be televising them.

title: Pass the Nuts, Pass Up the Guilt
description: AFTER you've been told for years that fatty foods like nuts are bad, it's pretty hard to switch gears and start eating them because -- surprise! -- now they're good.

title: Recipe: Cashew and Chicken Salad Sandwiches
description: Time: 10 minutes

title: U.S. Urges Hussein to Abdicate, as Inspectors Check Palace
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  As United Nations inspectors pressed their search for illegal weapons into a presidential palace in Baghdad, the United States again suggested today that the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein could save the world much trouble by leaving his country.

title: George Waters, 87, Innovator In Expanding Credit Card Use
description: George W. Waters, an executive who turned the American Express card into a global brand, died Saturday at his home in Fair Haven, N.J. He was 87.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The offering of Time Warner Cable has bankers salivating.
description: IT may not be the deal of the century, but the planned stock offering in Time Warner Cable has investment and commercial bankers scrambling for business in what is an otherwise arid market.

title: Jets' To-Do List Starts With Thomas and Coles
description: The lights were out at the Jets' complex Monday night, the first time this season there was no need for anyone to work late. But that will not last long. General Manager Terry Bradway is scouting college players at the Senior Bowl in Mobile, Ala., and the coaching staff will meet next week to evaluate the roster. Then, a few days after the Super Bowl, the salary-cap experts will gather to evaluate the team's financial situation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, EILEEN
description: MILLER - Eileen. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, Pres. Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Graying, And Playing With Trains; 2 Midtown Hobby Shops Struggle as Customers Dwindle and Grow Older
description: Go past the railroad crossing sign, descend a flight of stairs and there, in a grimy basement store crammed with as many as 100,000 items, Allan J. Spitz can usually be found behind the counter. Often his cat, Kibri, is draped over his shoulders as he briskly dispenses advice to a stream of customers, most of them middle-aged and male.

title: Some Names, But Little Detail On WorldCom
description: In his first extensive public comments since becoming WorldCom's new chairman and chief executive last month, Michael D. Capellas identified some crucial members of his executive team yesterday and said that they would help cut costs and maintain high ethical standards at the company. But he offered few specifics about how many jobs he intends to cut or other steps the company will take as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy protection.

title: Report Says U.S. Human Rights Abuses Have Eroded Support for Efforts Against Terrorism
description: International support for the campaign against terrorism is weakening because of human rights abuses by the United States, Human Rights Watch charged in a report published today.

title: New Creative Heads At Two Agencies
description: Two agencies have hired creative chiefs.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Threats Made Against Deputy Mayor
description: Deputy Mayor Marc V. Shaw received several threatening phone calls last month and police officers were temporarily assigned to guard his house, administration officials said yesterday. The calls followed Mr. Shaw's public criticism of the Fire Department. Mr. Shaw said firefighters fight fires only 5 percent of the time and ''are hanging around doing nothing the other 95 percent of the time.'' Mr. Shaw's office at City Hall received at least two calls from unidentified men who commented on Mr. Shaw's remarks and made references to his family. Mr. Shaw, who is in charge of the city's operations and oversees the budget process, would not comment last night. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: All Schools Doing Poorly Would Get One Curriculum
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will propose today that every low-performing school in the city use a single uniform curriculum, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMPAGNE, LORRAINE A.
description: CHAMPAGNE-Lorraine A. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York mourns the passing of Lorraine A. Champagne, its long-time secretary/administrator, and extends its deepest sympathy to her family. May she rest in peace. John H. FitzSimons, Pres Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: The Ones That Didn't Get Away; A Photographer Who Portrayed Cuba's Revolution With Complex Wit
description: The fishermen in this little village near Havana ''are a lot of liars,'' said Ral Corrales, who has lived here for more than half a century. ''Each one has a catch, the biggest, but he loses it.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: G.M. To Offer Satellite Radio On Most Models
description: General Motors, trying to increase market share by attracting consumers with new technology, said yesterday that it would offer satellite radio on 75 percent of its United States models starting with the 2004 model year. XM Satellite Radio Holdings, which has asked bondholders to let it delay interest payments, will provide the service in 44 of the automaker's 57 models, up from 25 models this year. The basic service costs $9.99 a month, excluding the price of the radio. G.M. first offered the XM service in Cadillac sedans, starting with the 2002 model year.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: TEST OF NEW FUEL FOR SHUTTLE In a development that could lead to new booster rockets for the space shuttle, scientists at Stanford and NASA have successfully tested a new fuel, consisting mainly of paraffin, that is cheaper, safer, and less environmentally damaging than the current solid booster fuel. The new fuel could also be used in emerging rocket designs that could be throttled up or down, shut off or restarted, cutting some launching risks. The existing paired shuttle boosters, once ignited, cannot be controlled.

title: Chapter 11 in Toy Land, But Shhh! The Children!
description: There was no sign of a wolf -- not even a stuffed one -- yesterday at the door of F. A. O. Schwarz on Fifth Avenue.

title: HONEYWELL SELLS ENGINEERING PLASTICS DIVISION TO BASF
description: BASF of Germany, one of Europe's biggest chemical makers, will buy Honeywell International's engineering plastics unit for $170 million and sell a nylon fiber business to Honeywell for $80 million. BASF will become one of the world's largest makers of engineering plastics, with about $2 billion in annual sales, a spokesman, Tim Fitzpatrick, said. The Honeywell unit reported sales of $350 million in 2001 and was profitable, he said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Foreign Investment Grows
description: China attracted a record amount of foreign direct investment last year, as companies shifted production to to take advantage of a growing domestic market and cheap labor in China, the world's most populous country. Foreign investment in factories, supermarket chains and apartment buildings rose 12.5 percent, to $52.7 billion, in 2002, the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation said. Contracted foreign investment, a sign of future investment flows, rose 19.6 percent, to $82.8 billion.

title: Think Rich, Vote Rich, Get Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Objections to Math Instruction
description: Mathematics department chairmen at five branches of City University have asked the New York City public school system to abandon a new kind of math instruction and seek input from CUNY, which educates many of the city's teachers.

title: Describing a Near-Rub-Out Experience
description: What does a rub-out feel like?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMOUR, ALEXANDRA LESTER
description: ARMOUR-Alexandra Lester. Beloved daughter of Julia Henry Armour of Coconut Grove, FL died in Honolulu, HI. on January 4, 2003, aged 56 after a long illness. She is also survived by her brother Philip D. Armour III of Kaneohe, HI, her sister Julia Armour Walker of Washington, CT, four nephews, one niece, two great nephews and one great niece. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Muscular Dystrophy Association, P.O. Box 78342, Phoenix, AZ 85062-8342 or on line at www.mdausa.org

title: French Officials and Muslims Celebrate New Islamic Council
description: It is an ambitious task, nothing less than the creation of an official Islam for France.

title: From Abalone To Ziti, The Language Of Food
description: Do you know the difference between rmoulade and ravigote, borage and lovage or longan and loquat? The International Dictionary of Gastronomy by Guido Gmez de Silva (Hippocrene Books, $14.95), a paperback, can help, though some might find it a bit limited. Despite more than 6,000 entries, there is nothing for galangal, used in Southeast Asian cooking, for the Japanese seaweeds hijiki and wakame, nor for the French mix of diced vegetables called brunoise. But there are handy indexes of gastronomic terms in English, Spanish, French, German and Italian.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, STANLEY
description: MELTZER-Stanley, 76. Of Somers, NY and Boynton Beach, FL. Devoted husband of Roslyn, loving father of Beth, Anne, Clifford and Stacy. Cherished father-in-law of Philip, Frederick, Michael and Rose. Adored grandfather of Brett, Rachel, Andrew, Lauren, Keith, Gregory, Allison, Arielle, Jordan, and Carly. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: Swiss Has Peak to Scale, but It's Not an Alp
description: When the crew of the Swiss team Alinghi crosses the finish line to win races, its custom is to keep the congratulatory hoopla to a minimum. No high-fives, just a few been-there, done-that nods and maybe a handshake or two.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: PROSECUTOR VOWS TO GET BOSNIAN SERBS The chief United Nations war crimes prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, said that the United Nations tribunal in The Hague would not shut down until it had tried Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb wartime leader, and his military commander, Ratko Mladic. The tribunal "cannot close its doors before bringing them to justice," Ms. Del Ponte said in an interview with the Swiss daily Tages-Anzeiger. She said she told President Jacques Chirac of France in Paris last week that the failure of the NATO-led peacekeeping force in Bosnia to arrest Dr. Karadzic, who lives there, was "scandalous." She also said General Mladic's hiding places in Belgrade were well known.(Agence France-Presse)

title: Corrections
description: The illustration on Monday's Op-Ed page carried an incorrect credit. The artist's name is Warren Linn, not Walter Linn.

title: 2nd Quake in Westchester
description: The second minor earthquake in five days hit Westchester County last night, with a magnitude of 1.4 on the Richter scale.

title: Victory Is Shot in Arm For the Ailing Pirates
description: Seton Hall has not been cured. The problems run too deep and the record is too poor. But there is no doubt that a game like tonight's can have some healing effects.

title: Philanthropist Gives A.C.L.U. $8 Million
description: Peter B. Lewis, the feisty philanthropist who has forced several beneficiaries of his largess to practice greater financial discipline, is giving $8 million to the American Civil Liberties Union. But Mr. Lewis said there were no strings attached to his gift.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, ALLAN, M.D.
description: SCHNEIDER - Allan, M.D. Cherished husband of Susan. Loving father of Jack, Michele and Todd. Devoted son of Stella, and son-in-law of Muriel. Beloved brother of Lawrence and Arlene. Dear uncle. He lead his life with a quiet generosity and sweetness that will always be remembered and treasured. Services Thursday, January 16, 11:30 AM at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY.

title: Tony Blair's Keen Instincts
description: Europeans sometimes ridicule Tony Blair for his supposed poodle-like obeisance to President Bush, but on closer inspection it's clear that the British prime minister is less docile than he might seem. In recent days he has subtly signaled Washington that he is in no rush to go to war against Iraq. It is a message Mr. Bush should heed.

title: Big American Food Is Just the Half of It
description: I HAVE seen the past, and it works. It's a place where square-shouldered men in black carve at tableside and at least half the dishes arrive on fire. This is the world of Terrance Brennan's Seafood and Chophouse, a one-way ticket back to the early years of the Kennedy administration, when fine dining meant big, juicy steaks and four-pound lobsters, followed by baked Alaska and crpes suzette.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Officer Dies In Station House
description: A 25-year-old police officer died yesterday at his Greenwich Village precinct house from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the authorities said. The officer, whose identity was not released early this morning, finished a routine shift, signed out at 4:35 p.m., walked to a downstairs locker room and shot himself once in the head with his pistol, according to another officer assigned to the Sixth Precinct station house. He left no note, and it was not known if it was an accidental shooting or a suicide, the police said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: More Infants Are Sleeping With Their Parents, and a Debate Ensues
description: Many more American parents are letting their babies share their beds, a new federal study has found.

title: Protest Groups Using Updated Tactics to Spread Antiwar Message
description: As the threat of war with Iraq heightens, leaders of the antiwar movement are feeling an urgency to mobilize the masses. But in contrast to the tactics of the 1960's, many organizers are trying to sound a note of patriotism and distance themselves from the stereotypical images of angry flag burners or scruffy anarchists.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about C. Douglas Dillon, the Wall Street financier who served as Treasury secretary from 1961 to 1965, misstated the role of his father in the early history of the investment banking house Dillon, Read & Company. Clarence Dillon joined William A. Read & Company in 1913 and later changed its name. He was not its founder.

title: Think Rich, Vote Rich, Get Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Witness Bolsters Robbery Theory in Lower East Side Murder
description: As the police sorted through two competing theories about who killed a 25-year-old man on the Lower East Side on Sunday, a third witness emerged whose account suggested that the victim, Burke O'Brien, was killed by robbers, the police said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Call For Reorganization
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee asked the General Assembly to enact a sweeping reorganization of the public school system and the executive branch, and said higher taxes were unavoidable if the state was to meet its financial and social obligations. Mr. Huckabee proposed reducing by almost two-thirds the state's 310 public school districts through consolidation and transferring control of curriculum, staff and faculty to the state level. He also sought authority to align more than 50 state agencies into 10 cabinet-style departments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMANUEL, LOUIS
description: EMANUEL - Louis. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Myron Fenster, Int. Sr. Rabbi Steven Markowitz, President

title: Dance Time For Oscar (But Don't Admit It)
description: Running on a breakfast of pt, gazpacho and Champagne, not long off a flight from London, Stephen Daldry managed to keep himself upright as his film ''The Hours'' received a standing ovation from the largely blue-haired crowd at the Palm Springs International Film Festival.

title: After Surgery, McGahee Opts for the N.F.L. Draft
description: Miami running back Willis McGahee, announcing he will enter the N.F.L. draft in April, has probably gone from a top-five pick to someone hoping to be taken in the third round as a result of the severe knee injury he sustained in the Hurricanes' Fiesta Bowl loss to Ohio State. But McGahee's father, Willis Jr., said his son's recuperative ability should not be underestimated.

title: Officer's Death in Antiterror Raid Stirs Debate in Britain
description: LONDON, Jan. 15  The police interrogated three North African men in the wake of an antiterror raid on Tuesday that led to the killing of an officer in Manchester. Politicians and law enforcement authorities debated what had gone wrong and what could be learned from it.

title: Think Rich, Vote Rich, Get Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWORKEN, RABBI STEVEN M.
description: DWORKEN - Rabbi Steven M. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) express profound sorrow over the untimely passing of an esteemed and devoted leader of the Jewish community. Executive vice president of the Rabbinical Council of America, Rabbi Dworken was formerly assistant director of RIETS' Max Stern Division of Communal Services. He also served as its director of rabbinic services and past president of RIETS' Rabbinic Alumni. A doctor of theology, he was ordained at RIETS and earned degrees from Yeshiva College and YU's Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology. As a communal leader he served with distinction as rabbi at Cong. Anshe Chesed, Linden, NJ, for 22 years, past president of the Rabbinical Council of New Jersey and the Union County Board of Rabbis, and vice president, treasurer, and secretary of the Rabbinical Council of America. Rabbi Dworken was possessed of wisdom, grace, and humility, a man who embraced and embodied the ideals of Torah Umadda. He will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Susan, children Naomi (and Yechiel) Rotblat, Aliza (and Jonathan) Frohlich, and Arye, and grandchildren. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for a chamber concert tomorrow night at Weill Recital Hall misspelled the surname of the cellist. He is David Geber, not Gober.

title: G.O.P.'s Race Record
description: To the Editor:

title: McCann-Erickson Loses British Chief
description: The chairwoman of McCann-Erickson United Kingdom in London, Tamara Ingram, is leaving, 14 months after taking the job, the agency said.

title: Labor Says It Won't Join A Sharon 'Unity' Cabinet
description: The left-of-center Labor Party today ruled out joining any government led by Ariel Sharon, increasing the chances that after the elections on Jan. 28, Israel will be governed by a shaky rightist coalition.

title: Move to Close Indian Point Gathers Steam After Report
description: The drive to close the Indian Point nuclear power plant intensified today as a coalition of groups urged Gov. George E. Pataki not to certify disaster plans that a consultant hired by the state has called inadequate to protect the public.

title: National Briefing: South
description: LOUISIANA: BLACK DISTRICT ATTORNEY TAKES OFFICE Eddie Jordan, who in 1994 became the first African-American United States attorney for eastern Louisiana, took office as the first elected black district attorney of New Orleans. Mr. Jordan, 50, was elected on Nov. 5 to replace the retiring Harry Connick Sr., who held the office for 29 years. Mr. Jordan, who successfully prosecuted former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards in 2000 for racketeering and fraud, has pledged to reduce New Orleans's rising violent crime rate.  (NYT)

title: Spotlight on N.F.L. Playoffs Exposes Rift Over Officiating
description: The National Football League commissioner was angry because game officials missed a crucial call on the final play of the Giants-San Francisco 49ers playoff game 10 days ago. The Pittsburgh coach was angry because he thought the officials made an unwarranted call at the end of the Steelers' playoff loss to Tennessee last Saturday.

title: Kmart Will Lay Off Up to 35,000 and Close 326 Stores
description: Faced with fierce competition and sales that continue to decline, Kmart will lay off as many as 35,000 workers and close 326 stores around the country over the next three months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEAKER, ADELE
description: YEAKER - Adele. Beloved wife of the late Meyer J. Loving mother of Ed and Barbara Yeaker and Madeline and Thomas J. Kraner. Devoted grandmother of Marc and Shannon, Glenn, Merri, Michael and Lisa. Services today 9:30 A.M. at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, between Ave I and Ave J.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: MACHINERY ORDERS DIP Orders for new machinery, a crucial indicator of corporate capital spending, fell 0.2 percent in November from October, suggesting that companies are scaling back investment plans. The results were worse than the small increase economists expected. Corporate capital spending makes up 15 percent of Japan's economy and has been at the center of past recoveries. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BODINE, RAYMOND C.
description: BODINE-Raymond C. December 19, 1933 to January 15, 1993. With Love, Mario

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Ex-Premier Blames Army
description: The former British Prime Minister Edward Heath told the ''Bloody Sunday'' inquiry that the killings of 14 civil rights marchers in Londonderry in 1972 was the fault of army officers and not, as has been charged, a result of any shoot-to-kill policy under his government. ''It was for officers on the ground to judge in any given situation what force should be used and how an intended operation should be run,'' said Sir Edward, 86, on the first day of what is expected to be three weeks of testimony. The inquiry, which began five years ago and is expected to run until 2004, moved to London from Londonderry late last year out of safety concerns for the 350 British political and military officials scheduled to be witnesses. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: State Argues for Broadening of Managed Care
description: Kentucky told the Supreme Court today that it should be allowed to guarantee patients a broader choice of doctors through a state law regulating managed care companies.

description: King-Size Pizzeria

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, BIRDYE
description: NADLER-Birdye. Beloved mother of Richard and Joan, loving grandmother of Amy. Services Wednesday 12 noon ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: White House Projects Federal Deficit of More Than $200 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The White House said today that the federal deficit was likely to exceed $200 billion this fiscal year and probably hit $300 billion next year.

title: Public Speaks Out About Tappan Zee Bridge
description: While traffic choked the Tappan Zee Bridge this evening, dozens of commuters, local residents and others called for a solution to their traffic headaches, at the first public hearing on the future of the congested link across the Hudson River between Westchester and Rockland Counties.

title: Salmon Brings Its Own Caviar to the Table
description: ''YOU know, salmon caviar isn't real caviar,'' said the counterman at Petrossian.

title: Emerson and Beethoven Portrayed as Kindred Spirits
description: 'American Roots'

title: Has Fox's Own Reality Imp Reached the Limit? Get Real!
description: Like the furies of hell, an unleashed Michael H. Darnell is spreading his mischief across the television world.

title: Bush Warns Hussein Again but Sidesteps Any 'Deadline'
description: President Bush said yesterday that "time is running out on Saddam Hussein" to avert an American-led attack by disarming voluntarily. But the president issued no specific deadline, while Washington's allies reinforced demands that any military action must be approved by the United Nations.

title: Buffalo President Is Leaving
description: WILLIAM R. GREINER will step down as president of the University at Buffalo on June 30, he announced Monday. Mr. Greiner, 68, joined the university's law school faculty in 1967 and became president in 1991.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Wal-Mart Joins Safeway Bidding
description: Wal-Mart Stores confirmed that it was considering making an all-cash offer for Safeway, though it did not specify a price. Wal-Mart, which owns Asda in Britain, said it would make a submission to the Office of Fair Trading, a British regulator, to begin the process of seeking antitrust clearance should it decide to make a formal bid. Wal-Mart's interest in Safeway, which is not part of the Safeway supermarket chain in the United States, follows that of two other suitors. J. Sainsbury has said it was also considering a formal offer using a mixture of cash and stock, while William Morrison Supermarkets said last week that it had reached an agreement to buy Safeway using all stock. Wal-Mart and Sainsbury are refraining from making formal offers until they hold further discussions with regulators. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Former Justice Dies In Snowy Woods
description: A former state Supreme Court justice, Maurice Bois, was found dead after wandering out into the snowy woods behind his nursing home on a night when temperatures hovered in the single digits. The body of Justice Bois, 85, who has Alzheimer's disease, was found the next morning. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISULIA, MARY
description: MISULIA-Mary, 85 years. On January 6, 2003, the Epiphany. Beloved wife of the late John. Loving aunt of Richard and Ronald. Loved by many at the Chai Adult Home. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Dean Amadon, an Authority On Birds of Prey, Dies at 90
description: Dean Amadon, a renowned authority on birds of prey and former Lamont curator of birds at the American Museum of Natural History, died Sunday at his home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 90.

title: 17,000 G.E. Workers Strike Over Higher Health Costs
description: Angry about General Electric's decision to force employees to pay more for their health coverage, 17,000 workers at 48 locations in 23 states began a two-day nationwide strike today.

title: Technology Briefings
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZER, DR. STANLEY Z.
description: MAZER-Dr. Stanley Z. On January 13, 2003. Beloved husband of Marianne Githens. Devoted father of Jeffrey Mazer, Sharon Mazer Nealon, Julie Mazer Lee and Jonathan Githens - Mazer. Loving grandfather of Rachel Lee and uncle of Brenda Hoffman and Meryl Zeigler. Friends may call at the Ruck Towson Funeral Home, Towson, MD. Wednesday, 7-9PM. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at Saint Ignatius Church, Baltimore, MD. Thursday, 11 AM. Interment Saint Mary's Cemetery, Lawrence, N.Y., Friday, 1 PM.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Demonstrators Want Peace Deal
description: Tens of thousands of Turkish Cypriots took to the streets in Nicosia to persuade their leader, Rauf Denktash, to agree to a peace deal with Greek Cypriots. A new round of talks is to start today and United Nations negotiators are urging Cyprus's Greek and Turkish leaders to accept a plan to reunite the island ahead of Cyprus's entry into the European Union next year. Cyprus has been divided since Turkish forces invaded and occupied the island's north in 1974. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, PEARL
description: GINSBERG-Pearl. Sincerest condolences to Liane, Larry and Hilary on the loss of their beloved mother, a woman of dignity and grace. A Diamond Founder of the Medical Center, her outstretched hand of kindness in support of the Department of Emergency Medicine, made a lifesaving difference to the people of Israel. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

title: Teenager Pleads Not Guilty in Boy's Death
description: The teenager who the authorities say has admitted to killing a 7-year-old boy unintentionally with a punch to the stomach and then helping hide the body pleaded not guilty today to charges of aggravated assault.

description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Calls Its Conference on Palestinian Reform a Success
description: Foreign Secretary Jack Straw pronounced a British-sponsored meeting on Palestinian reform a success tonight despite the absence from London of Palestinian representatives barred by the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, from coming here.

title: Modern Infusions to Celtic and Country
description: Traditions were happily stretched when Solas and the Wayfaring Strangers shared a double bill at the Bottom Line on Sunday night. Solas, led by Seamus Egan (who played guitar, flute, whistle and banjo), is an Irish-American and Irish band that applies Celtic-style virtuosity to material well outside typical jigs and reels.

title: In Public Input, a Hint Of Rebuilding Fatigue
description: Since the new designs for the World Trade Center site were unveiled to great fanfare last month, there has been no shortage of public discussion and debate about the plans, their expected impact on the downtown skyline or the future of Lower Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORIN, DEBORAH (NEE BABUS)
description: GORIN-Deborah (nee Babus). Beloved wife of the late Alvin. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Gail and David Furman, and William and Jody Gorin. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Allie, Alexander, Matthew and Gabrielle. Devoted to her friends and extended family who will miss her warmth and laughter. Service Wednesday, 9:30AM at ''Gutterman's'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: The Burger Takes Center Stage
description: I HAVE eaten hamburgers every day for the last two months. I have traveled the five boroughs of New York City to do so. And in the city's lowliest corner diners and loftiest expense account restaurants, I have found satisfaction. New York, my research has documented again and again, is a hamburger heaven.

description: ''In the beginning, I did not react,'' said Karina Britto as she recalled Sept. 11, 2001.

title: F.D.A. Halts 27 Gene Therapy Trials After Illness
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday suspended 27 gene therapy trials involving several hundred patients after learning that a second child treated in France had developed a condition resembling leukemia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, ESTELLE (SIS)
description: NELSON-Estelle (Sis). Wife of the late Martin. Mother of Michael and Joan Nelson, Barbara Nelson Wright and Stephen Wright. Grandmother of Dan, Sarah, Jenny, Emily, Chris and Laura. Sister of Ruth Zucker, Morty Shapiro and Joan Glaser. Adored by nieces and nephews. We will miss her spirit and her love. Private services were held. Donations may be sent to United Cerebral Palsy Association of Nassau County, 380 Washington Ave., Roosevelt, New York 11575.

title: Bush Warns Hussein Again But Sidesteps Any 'Deadline'
description: President Bush said yesterday that ''time is running out on Saddam Hussein'' to avert an American-led attack by disarming voluntarily. But the president issued no specific deadline, while Washington's allies reinforced demands that any military action must be approved by the United Nations.

title: N.F.L. Just Says No To a Super Bowl Ad Promoting Las Vegas
description: Ninety percent of ABC's commercial time for the Super Bowl has been sold, but one advertiser viewers will not see is the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority.

title: Chief Counsel to Pataki Is Resigning Post
description: The exodus of old hands from the Pataki administration continued today as James M. McGuire, the chief counsel and a critical player in the governor's inner circle for the last eight years, said he would leave government service at the end of the month.

title: Getting Onto the Internet at 30,000 Feet or So
description: For many air travelers, flying has become an escape from the modern-day cyclone of phone calls, e-mail and instant text messages.

title: So That Catfish Doesn't Have to Wait
description: Cast iron, that old-fashioned kitchen workhorse, has always needed seasoning; that is, a light oiling and heating to seal the porous metal surface. Or, as Lodge Manufacturing in South Pittsburg, Tenn., the country's top maker of cast-iron cookware, put it, ''until cooking countless batches of fried chicken, catfish and crispy crusted corn bread burnished it to a treasured black patina.''

title: Odd Buddies For Winter
description: HERE are three words you have probably not seen in one sentence: anchovies, turnips and pork. Yet put them in the same pot, and you have a midwinter dish that is delicious and intensely flavorful.

title: Grant Supports Transit Study
description: The CUNY Institute for Urban Systems at City College has received a $135,000 grant from the J. M. Kaplan Fund to study ways to reduce traffic congestion in the metropolitan area by improving mass transit and by imposing higher tolls during rush hour, a concept called value pricing.

title: Builder's Fast Rise to Success Ends in Murder
description: Michael Parisi was the kind of builder who could make money when others were failing. He got started by selling his car and buying a single lot, and he was still meeting with bankers in his jeans and sweatshirt in the weeks before someone killed him last weekend with a single bullet to the head.

title: Virginia Moves to Control Actions of Bounty Hunters
description: Things were looking up for Roberto Martnez. Last fall, Mr. Martnez, his wife and their six children had been displaced when their tiny home in the mountains south of Acapulco burned, but then he came to the United States and in just two months of construction work he had amassed nearly $1,000 to send home.

title: Heinrichs Picks Roster for Trip to China
description: Two players from the New York Power of the Women's United Soccer Association and a high school player from New Jersey were among the 20 players selected yesterday by United States Coach April Heinrichs to play in the Four Nations tournament beginning next week in China. It will be the team's first of two visits to the Far East this year.

title: New Economic Data May Decide Fate of Bush Tax Plan
description: The debate over whether President Bush's tax plan would provide too little or too much economic stimulus could be sharpened over the next several weeks as investors get data on how well the economy is doing right now and how America's top corporate executives expect it  and their companies  to be doing in the months ahead.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged In Hotel Killing
description: An Oregon man was charged yesterday with killing a woman he traveled to New York to see after a yearlong long-distance relationship that grew out of their shared fascination with a television show, the police said. The man, Richard G. Jenkins, 48, who lives with his parents in Portland, Ore., shot and killed the woman, identified as Linda Foreman, 45, of Pennsylvania, in the room they shared at the Doubletree Hotel in Times Square, the authorities said. The couple met last year at a New York convention for the cult television show ''Dark Shadows.'' Mr. Jenkins, who had asked the woman to marry him, had been sending her money because she said she was indigent, the police said. Mr. Jenkins became suspicious when she kept postponing the wedding, and learned she had at least $80,000 in a bank account. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Test Of New Fuel For Shuttle
description: In a development that could lead to new booster rockets for the space shuttle, scientists at Stanford and NASA have successfully tested a new fuel, consisting mainly of paraffin, that is cheaper, safer, and less environmentally damaging than the current solid booster fuel. The new fuel could also be used in emerging rocket designs that could be throttled up or down, shut off or restarted, cutting some launching risks. The existing paired shuttle boosters, once ignited, cannot be controlled. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Atlas move over; skinny is now the chic silhouette
description: PARIS  It's January and a man's thoughts turn to the bathroom scale. Is it possible that bigger (as in chest and bicep diameter), isn't better anymore? Dieting, that once thoroughly feminine occupation, undertaken to slip into a smaller, slimmer, sexier silhouette, is no longer just for the girls.

title: Solving the North Korean Puzzle: Once Again, the U.S. Will Try Persuasion
description: President Bush's new approach to North Korea, involving an offer to consider food and fuel aid upon an agreement to dismantle the North's nuclear program, reflects a determination on the part of the administration to see the Korean crisis resolved peacefully and the focus kept on Iraq.

title: FLORIDA PETROLEUM TERMINALS SOLD TO DENVER COMPANY
description: The El Paso Corporation has agreed to sell its Florida petroleum terminals and tug-and-barge operations to TransMontaigne for about $155 million. The terminals sold an average of 29,000 barrels of fuel a day last year to cruise-ship operators, TransMontaigne said. The terminals, in Jacksonville, Cape Canaveral, Port Manatee, Port Everglades and Fisher Island, can collectively store as much as five million barrels of fuel. TransMontaigne, which transports and stores petroleum products and chemicals, already owns three Florida terminals capable of storing a total of 1.2 million barrels, the company said. Transmontaigne is based in Denver. El Paso is based in Houston.

title: NEW PRESIDENT OF BURGER KING TO COME FROM YUM BRANDS
description: The Burger King Corporation has named Robert Nilsen its president, effective Feb. 3. He was chief operating officer of the Taco Bell unit of Yum Brands. Mr. Nilsen, 43, will report to the chief executive, Bradley Blum, and will be responsible for all systemwide operations, Burger King said. Burger King, which Diageo sold last month to the Texas Pacific Group and partners including Goldman Sachs Capital Partners and Bain Capital, had sales of $11.3 billion in fiscal 2002, which ended June 30.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: REFINER'S PROFIT FALLS BP said its oil-refining division was less profitable in the fourth quarter than it was in the third as seasonal shifts and a strike in Venezuela sent prices for crude oil soaring. Higher oil prices can dampen demand and make crude more costly to process. Slimmer margins at the oil-refining unit, which accounted for about two-thirds of BP's revenue last year, will be partly offset by wider margins at BP's drilling unit, which gains when prices rise, because it can charge more for the oil it pumps from the ground. BP's warning opens the door to the possibility that other large oil companies may see lower profits. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Hearing Starts in Bombing Error That Killed 4
description: As two Air Force pilots looked on silently, their careers and their freedom on the line, the Canadian soldiers who survived their errant bombing run in Afghanistan began taking the stand today to describe how a friendly fire mistake from 20,000 feet up translated into carnage on the ground.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about the National Book Critics Circle Awards misstated the name of the publisher of ''Piano Notes'' by Charles Rosen, which was nominated for criticism. It is the Free Press, not Scribners/Free Press.

title: Yankees Close to Deal to Send Hernndez to Expos
description: The Yankees inched closer to trading Orlando Hernndez to the Montreal Expos as part of a three-way deal involving Bartolo Coln last night. But they would not be receiving the prized Coln in return.

title: A Salute to the Founder, Seated at the Harpsichord
description: The pianist Charles Wadsworth can't say that the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, which he founded in 1969 and directed for 20 years, takes him for granted. Every season since his retirement the society has brought Mr. Wadsworth back for a special concert.

title: Don't Compromise on Abortion
description: The National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League announced recently that it was changing its name to Naral Pro Choice America. Kate Michelman, its president, called it ''the right name for this moment in history.'' She couldn't be more wrong.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Arrow Will Buy Pioneer-Standard
description: Arrow Electronics, the largest distributor of electronic components to commercial and industrial users, will buy the rival components distribution operations of Pioneer-Standard Electronics for $285 million, the two companies said. Arrow Electronics, based in Melville, N.Y., said that the Pioneer unit, which has revenue of about $700 million, would add up to 20 cents a year to Arrow's per-share earnings after its operations are integrated. Pioneer-Standard, based in Cleveland, said it would focus on the sales of computer systems and related products. Arrow's shares traded as high as $14.11 after the announcement before settling to close at $13.89, up 4 cents; Pioneer-Standard's shares jumped $1.93, to $10.86. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: The New Math
description: You can understand everything you need to know about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict today through a simple math equation offered by Danny Rubinstein, the Haaretz newspaper's Palestinian affairs expert. The equation goes like this: Suppose Israel discovers that 10 Palestinians from Nablus are planning suicide attacks. Israel says: If we can kill at least two, that will be progress, because only eight will be left. The Palestinians, by contrast, say: If you kill two, four more will volunteer to take their places, and you will be left with 12. So for Israel 10 minus 2 is 8, and for the Palestinians 10 minus 2 is 12.

description: The major recording companies said yesterday that they would not seek government intervention to prevent digital piracy, in a compromise with computer companies that may hurt the movie industry's efforts to win support for its own anti-piracy plan.

title: An Eight-Year-Old Marriage Begins
description: In eight years of marriage, Madison and Kim Hobley had never hugged without handcuffs. Their kisses were chaperoned by prison guards and cut off when they got too intense. Illinois does not allow conjugal visits on death row, where they had met and wed.

description: MOORE-William Musgrave III, age 82, on January 6, 2003. A writer and a gentleman who enjoyed his life and lived it to the fullest. He will be remembered with joy by his wife, Marion, his son, Christopher, and everyone who knew him.

title: Knicks Turn Tables On Bulls
description: Last night at Madison Square Garden, Tyson Chandler was not the dynamo he was on Monday, when he grabbed 19 rebounds, a career high. Instead, Chandler, the Chicago Bulls' 20-year-old center, did everything but take notes and raise his hand to ask questions as Kurt Thomas demonstrated how to hit midrange jumpers, box out in the paint and excel without the benefit of great athleticism.

title: A Stroll Through the '21' List, Circa 1945
description: THE restaurant consultant Roger Martin began a long career in New York restaurants by checking coats at the ''21'' Club in the early 1950's while still a New York University student. Mr. Martin, who died on Dec. 4, went on to work for Restaurant Associates and Windows on the World, and for a time he ran his own place in the Hamptons.

Stepfather of Steven and Todd Kingsbury and Elizabeth van Dusen. Grandfather of nine. Brother of Christina DeVoe Johnson. Visitation Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at The Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad St, Red Bank, NJ. Funeral service Friday, 10:30 AM, from St. Georges by the River, Lincoln Ave, Rumson, NJ. Interment to follow NJ Veterans Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Georges Church are preferred.

title: Union Plans To Prohibit Minicamps
description: Unhappy that the Mets and other teams have assembled players this winter for what were billed as optional minicamps, the players association plans to enforce the basic agreement and essentially prohibit teams from such off-season workouts.

title: Cardinal Egan Upsets Members Of Review Board Studying Abuse
description: Cardinal Edward M. Egan has given a cold reception to the national review board of prominent Roman Catholics who were appointed by the bishops to study the priest sexual abuse scandal and who are to meet in New York on Friday, according to board members.

title: Study Faults U.S. on Assessing Altered Fish
description: A new study maintains that the government is poorly structured to assess possible environmental hazards posed by genetically modified fish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, C. DOUGLAS
description: DILLON-C. Douglas. The members of the Board of Directors of the French-American Foundation are greatly saddened at the passing of their venerable colleague and friend. His lifelong contributions to the French-American relationship and his steadfast and most generous support of the French-American Foundation, of which he was a founding member and its first Chairman, will always be remembered and will continue to influence its efforts for the cause he considered so imporrtant. We extend our deepest sympathy to Susan and to all of his family. Michael E. Patterson, Chairman Anthony A. Smith, President

title: South Korea Leader Visits U.S. Military Base
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 15  President-elect Roh Moo Hyun moved strongly today to ease concerns about anti-Americanism in South Korea and over his own ambivalence toward his country's alliance with the United States.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Dip
description: Orders for new machinery, a crucial indicator of corporate capital spending, fell 0.2 percent in November from October, suggesting that companies are scaling back investment plans. The results were worse than the small increase economists expected. Corporate capital spending makes up 15 percent of Japan's economy and has been at the center of past recoveries. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 5 about the role that Iraqi tribes might play in an American military campaign against Saddam Hussein misstated the history of a British defeat during World War I. As many as 30,000 British and Indian soldiers were killed or wounded at the hands of Turkish Ottoman forces joined by Iraqi tribesmen besieging the town of Kut, about 170 miles south of Baghdad. (That figure includes thousands who were not killed during combat, but perished either during a forced march across northern Iraq after the British and Indian troops surrendered or during their imprisonment in Anatolia.) The casualties were not solely at the hands of tribesmen.

title: BUSH SAYS SHIFT BY NORTH KOREA COULD BRING AID
description: President Bush signaled a major shift in approach to North Korea today, saying for the first time that if North Korea abandoned its nuclear weapons program he would consider offering a ''bold initiative'' that could bring aid, energy and eventually even diplomatic and security agreements to the politically and economically isolated country.

title: As You Like It (Sandwich Division)
description: Lunch Boxes Etc., a food shop decorated with new and old lunchboxes, is the kind of storefront you would expect to see in the East Village, not at 21 West 100th Street, just steps from Central Park.

title: Hughes, Cohen and Kwan: No Stars Missing Nationals
description: Since the magical night 11 months ago when Sarah Hughes captured the Olympic gold medal in Salt Lake City, sending her off to see the world on a swell of celebrity, she feels she has aged five years.

title: Positive Test for Anthrax
description: Postal officials evacuated a sorting center today after routine tests for anthrax in mail destined for the Federal Reserve showed a preliminary positive result. The officials said they would run further tests into the night at the sorting center.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent In Labor Accord
description: The Communications Workers of America and Lucent Technologies have reached a tentative agreement on a new 20-month contract to take effect when the current five-year agreement expires on May 31. Lucent said it sought early negotiations on a short-term pact to get a clearer idea of its future labor costs as it struggles to restructure debts that are coming due in the next few years. The union represents 5,400 of Lucent's 5,700 unionized workers. The agreement would give the workers a 2 percent raise in June and another 2 percent raise a year later, but would require them to pay more for most health benefits. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEDDENS, CORNELIA VANDERBILT (NEE DAVIS)
description: HEDDENS-Cornelia Vanderbilt (nee Davis). Passed into Divine Embrace at 6:20AM on Wednesday, January 9, 2003. She is survived by her three children, Claudia V. McCain (Ketchum, ID.), Henry D. McCain (Seattle, WA.) and Charles S. McCain III. (Nashville, TN.), and her half sister Grace Vanderbilt Sutton (New York City). Born in New York City on April 13, 1929 to Grace Vanderbilt and Henry Gassaway Davis. Married Charles S. McCain, Jr. 1949, divorced 1965. Married Kimber J. Heddens 1965, divorced 1976. Connie's energy and vivacity were apparent to all who knew her. Her generosity and passion were never hidden. She will be sorely missed by all of us who knew and loved her.

title: F.C.C. Chief Dismisses Talk Of Extensive Rule Changes
description: Michael K. Powell, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, reassured Congress today that there would not be radical changes in rules governing local phone service, high-speed Internet access and ownership of media outlets, but Democratic and Republican senators said they were worried that anticipated changes could hurt consumers.

title: Online Brokers Fined Millions In Fraud Case
description: Seven former traders and executives of Datek Online, a pioneer in online stock trading, agreed yesterday to pay $70 million in fines for what regulators called illegal trading and fraudulent bookkeeping during the market boom of the 1990's.

title: The Not-So-Garden State
description: As Gov. James McGreevey of New Jersey noted in his State of the State address yesterday, his first year in office had plenty of missteps beyond the one that broke his leg early in his term. But in treading ever so cautiously in his speech, the governor inexplicably skipped right over offering solutions to the biggest problem facing his state, its formidable $5 billion budget gap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVERY, SALLY MICHEL
description: AVERY-Sally Michel. The MacDowell Colony honors the life of Sally Avery, colony fellow and director emerita. The Milton and Sally Avery Fellowships at MacDowell support the residencies of outstanding painters and carry on her creative spirit.

title: Between a Rock and a Hard Stepmother
description: Viewed one way, Janacek's remarkable opera ''Jenufa'' is a story of how a winsome young woman in a remote rural village of Moravian Slovakia in the late 19th century is nearly crushed by the oppressive, small-minded morality of her severe stepmother and judgmental neighbors. That certainly seems the sole concept of Olivier Tambosi's new production of ''Jenufa'' that arrived at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night.

Perhaps. But at least a change of location. In the musical arts bad thoughts have found a less threatening theater of operations.

title: Steinbrenner Won't Just Give Mondesi Away
description: Once the Yankees officially added outfielder Hideki Matsui, it was obvious that General Manager Brian Cashman would intensify his efforts to trade Raul Mondesi or Rondell White, or both. Cashman could have traded Mondesi and cash to the Pittsburgh Pirates recently, but, for the second time this off-season, George Steinbrenner scuttled a deal involving Mondesi.

title: Buffalo President Is Leaving
description: WILLIAM R. GREINER will step down as president of the University at Buffalo on June 30, he announced Monday. Mr. Greiner, 68, joined the university's law school faculty in 1967 and became president in 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHLIS, JAMES JOSEPH
description: ROCHLIS-James Joseph. On January 14, 2003. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Money Promised For Fiat
description: The Agnelli family is willing to invest more money in Fiat to help rescue the company, Italy's largest manufacturer, said Umberto Agnelli, whose family owns 30 percent of Fiat. ''Our commitment to provide the company with the funds it needs isn't in doubt,'' said Mr. Agnelli, grandson of the company's founder, in a newspaper interview with MF. A spokesman for Ifil, one of the holding companies through which the family controls Fiat, confirmed the remarks.

The talks between Glafcos Clerides and Rauf Denktash, left, come a month after an earlier United Nations initiative failed to produce an agreement on the sidelines of a summit meeting of the European Union, which agreed to admit Cyprus, divided or not, next year. The United Nations wants the sides to sign a deal by Feb. 28, but Mr. Denktash warned that the plan contained many ''traps.'' Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MURRAY
description: KAUFMAN-Murray. On January 15th. Lifelong resident of NYC, executive director of R.A.I.N. Home Health Care Services. Loved art, photography, travel, theater and many friendships around the world. Devoted friend and beloved son, brother, uncle and great uncle. Survived by nephew Erwin, niece Stacey and their families. Service is at 12:45 P.M., Friday at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Merrill Lynch Loses Ruling in Tax Court
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has lost a $32.7 million court fight with the Internal Revenue Service over the tax treatment of the sale of two subsidiaries in the 1980's.

title: AOL's Top Job Goes to Veteran of Time Warner
description: Richard D. Parsons, the chief executive of AOL Time Warner , was named yesterday to succeed Stephen M. Case as the company's chairman, the culmination of a surprising consolidation of Mr. Parson's power in the two years since AOL acquired Time Warner.

title: A Picture Organizer That Imports, Edits and Jogs the Memory
description: If your digital photos are in files scattered around your hard drive like so many virtual shoe boxes, Adobe has software to help: Photoshop Album, a tool for organizing, editing, sharing and printing digital images.

title: Guess Who's Coming for a Mortgage?
description: In 1979, I bought a dilapidated five-bedroom Queen Anne Victorian house in Oakland's inner city. The house was in such bad shape that it rained in the living room. The house would have remained that way had I not obtained a low-interest rehabilitation loan from the city. I got some free paint along with the deal. With the loan and other improvements, I have come close to restoring the house to its 1906 state. It's a sturdy old thing, having survived two major earthquakes and hundreds of small ones. The 1989 earthquake left only some cracks in the plaster.

title: O.K., Chief, It's Time to Get Down to Business
description: They are not just fire chiefs -- they are public sector executives. They must not only lead their firefighters into harm's way then safely back out again. They must also ''operationalize the values of their organization'' while they are at it.

title: Bush Aide Sees Deficit in 2003 Of $200 Billion
description: The White House said today that the federal deficit was likely to exceed $200 billion this fiscal year and probably hit $300 billion next year.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Indictment For Alderman
description: A Milwaukee alderman was indicted on Tuesday on extortion and mail fraud charges, the second council member charged in four months in an F.B.I. investigation into corruption at City Hall. Alderman Paul Henningsen, 56, the chairman of the Zoning, Neighborhoods and Development Committee, is accused of soliciting campaign donations from developers in exchange for approval of their projects. Rosa Cameron, a former alderwoman, pleaded guilty to misusing grant money. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: BANK'S PROFIT RISES The country's second-largest bank, Woori Bank, said its net income reached $1 billion last year, an increase of 79 percent over 2001. The bank, part of Woori Finance Holdings, attributed the increase to consumer loans, notably for mortgages and credit cards. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Harvard Aims to Stimulate Public Service With Scholarships
description: In a new program to encourage graduate students to enter public service, Harvard University plans to give $14 million in ''presidential scholarships'' over the next three years to 200 to 300 graduate students interested in public service or research careers.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Planting Of Modified Crops Rose In 2002
description: The planting of genetically modified crops increased in 2002 despite lingering concern in some countries about their safety and environmental effects, a group that conducts an annual survey said yesterday. Land devoted to such crops grew 12 percent worldwide last year, to 145 million acres, an area two and a half times the size of Britain. The survey was done by the International Service for the Acquisition of Agri-Biotech Applications, a nonprofit group backed partly by biotechnology companies that introduces biotechnology to developing countries. The crops were grown in 16 countries last year, up from 13 in 2001, with India, Colombia and Honduras being the new ones. But four countries -- the United States, Argentina, Canada and China -- accounted for 99 percent of the total. The United States, where planting rose 9 percent, accounted for two-thirds of the world's total. The types of crops were also concentrated, with herbicide-resistant soybeans accounting for 62 percent of the global total and insect-resistant corn for 13 percent. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: A Shady Ex-Official
description: The former finance minister, Katele Kalumba, was arrested and charged with theft after the police found him hiding in a tree near his rural home. Mr. Kalumba, who had been on the run for four months, is being charged in connection with some $33 million that vanished while he was in office. He is the latest former official to be arrested in the country's corruption inquiry; investigators have indicated that they also hope to arrest former President Frederick Chiluba. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Parsons Seen Topping List To Be New AOL Chairman
description: As the directors of AOL Time Warner prepare for the full meeting of the company's board today, Richard D. Parsons, the chief executive, is emerging as the most likely successor to the chairman, Stephen M. Case, who is stepping down in May.

title: Scientist Offers New Hints to the Evolution of Flight
description: The behavior of chukhar partridge chicks, which can run straight up the side of a hay bale or a tree while flapping their wings, may offer a new window on the origin of flight in birds.

title: For Berlin and Paris, a facade
description: PARIS:  Jacques Chirac says that France and Germany's approach and vision concerning Iraq are "identical and of the same nature"  an elastic, credulity-stretching description of unity across the Rhine. It turns a wish into a single will, a country that describes its armed forces as ready for action into the supposed psychic mirror of a neighbor that rules out any role in a military strike against Saddam Hussein.

title: President Faults Race Preferences as Admission Tool
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  President Bush offered a sweeping denunciation of direct preferences for racial minorities in university admissions today and said his administration would file a brief with the Supreme Court urging that the affirmative action admissions policies at the University of Michigan be declared unconstitutional.

title: Defending France's Jews
description: Over the past two years France has been the site of hundreds of anti-Semitic incidents -- synagogues defaced, sacred texts burned, individuals menaced -- nearly all of them perpetrated by disaffected North African youths. The official reaction consisted of a Gallic shrug, as if to ask, What can you expect from poor Arabs when they watch brutal scenes of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict on television? As accusatory reminders of France's Nazi collaboration flowed in from the United States and Israel, the French establishment went from dismissive to defensive. President Jacques Chirac asserted indignantly, after his re-election last May, that France was not an anti-Semitic country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, C. DOUGLAS
description: DILLON-C. Douglas. The Trustees and Staff of The New-York Historical Society mourn the passing of their friend and supporter. The Society expresses its heartfelt sympathy to the Dillon family for their loss of this great history-making New Yorker. Nancy Newcomb, Chair Kenneth T. Jackson, Pres.

title: Lights Cloud the Night Sky
description: DR. STEPHEN PAULEY, a powerfully built man with ruddy cheeks, drove his Chevy Tahoe down Main Street here, past Atkinson's Market, Ozzie's Shoes and Country Cousins, one evening this month. He stopped in the parking lot of Cox Cable and gestured toward a high-intensity floodlight that radiated a sickly-looking yellow cloud into the night sky.

title: With a Frantic Finish, Sixers End Their Slump
description: The Philadelphia 76ers needed a victory, while Keith Van Horn wanted some revenge against the Nets.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Plea In Fatal Beating
description: Jemeral Andrews, one of several youths charged in a beating that killed a Milwaukee man, Charles Young Jr., pleaded no contest Monday to aggravated battery. Mr. Andrews, 17, will be sentenced on Feb. 28. Originally charged with first degree reckless homicide, he made the plea after agreeing to testify against others. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's remarks yesterday at the White House on affirmative action, as recorded by The New York Times:

description: Steven A. Cohen may be the most successful -- and wealthiest -- hedge fund manager that no one outside Wall Street knows.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Reinstatement Of Crime Program Urged
description: A group of state and local officials called yesterday for reinstatement of an ambitious crime-reduction program that was financed in part by an income-tax surcharge on city residents. The proposal, which is being formulated by Councilman Hiram Monserrate, left, and Assemblyman Ivan C. Lafayette, both of Queens, would call for a temporary one-half-percent tax increase, which would require approval by the State Legislature. But council leaders and Bloomberg officials expressed little interest in the revival of the program, called Safe Streets, Safe City. Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr., chairman of the Council's Public Safety Committee, called the proposal premature. (His father was an architect of the original program.) ''We can provide for Safe Streets, Safe City levels of police staffing within the current budget,'' he said. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Even as Foundation Is Set, a New 7 World Trade Center Faces Barriers
description: Construction workers are laboring busily these days beneath the arc of a crane and the pipes pouring concrete at Vesey and Washington Streets, where the developer Larry A. Silverstein wants to rebuild 7 World Trade Center, one of the skyscrapers destroyed in the terrorist attack 16 months ago.

title: Federal Worker Sentenced For Passing On Information
description: A federal judge in Atlanta has sentenced a former Drug Enforcement Agency analyst to a year in prison for taking unclassified information from agency databases and files and giving it to a British reporter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWORKEN, RABBI STEVEN
description: DWORKEN-Rabbi Steven. We mourn the untimely death of our colleague and friend, devoted Executive Vice President of the Rabbinical Council of America, whose energies and skills were dedicated to bringing benefit and caring to rabbis and their families, whose passion was teaching Torah and who labored for klal Yisrael. We extend our condolences to his loving wife, Susan, to his family, and to all who were touched by his caring and friendship. The memory of his life is a blessing for his life was a blessing. Rabbi Reuven Hammer, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Executive Vice President The Rabbinical Assembly

title: G.E. to Spend $100 Million Promoting Itself As Innovative
description: After almost a quarter-century, General Electric will no longer ''bring good things to life.'' It is taking the risky step of replacing the familiar corporate slogan with one meant to laud its innovations in areas far afield from prosaic products like refrigerators and night lights.

title: In a Game of Serenity, Therapy Trumps Thrills
description: COMPUTER game designers do not need graduate degrees in business to figure out that profits tend to be highly correlated with crashes, explosions, combat, high-risk gambles, sex or just about anything else that is arousing.

title: WPP Acquires HHCL in London
description: The WPP Group in London is again expanding Red Cell, its newest worldwide agency network, by acquiring management control of Howell Henry Chaldecott Lury, a London agency known as HHCL, from Chime Communications in London, the agency companies said yesterday.

title: Bush Says He Will Ask Congress To Extend Africa Trade Benefits
description: President Bush said today that he would ask Congress to postpone the expiration of a trade law that gives 35 African nations duty-free access to American markets, an announcement he had planned to make as a centerpiece of a trip to Africa that was put off because of the confrontation with Iraq.

title: Medical Leave Act Is Debated in Major Federalism Case
description: Listening to the Supreme Court argument in the term's major federalism case today resembled nothing so much as eavesdropping on one hour of a yearlong conversation. People spoke in a shorthand that rendered complex constitutional concepts into a kind of code. Shared history was taken as a given. Premises were assumed, not stated.

title: MAYOR SETS PLAN FOR TIGHT CONTROL OVER CITY SCHOOLS
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced an ambitious plan yesterday to impose rigorously centralized control over the New York City school system and its teachers, wiping out local districts and requiring a single curriculum for reading, writing and mathematics for all but the top-performing schools.

title: Wells's Attacker Gets 45 Days
description: Rocco Graziosa was sentenced to 45 days in jail yesterday for punching David Wells in a diner last September, Wells's lawyer said.

title: 500 Songs, One Disc: A Player That Can Navigate
description: As digital audio players grow in storage capacity, a trade-off is emerging. Less time spent switching storage media could mean more time poring over which songs will make the cut.

title: PC's Aside, Digital Ideas Aplenty
description: IF you had awakened on the floor of the Las Vegas Convention Center and tried to figure out where you were, you might have first guessed the Conclave of American Optimists. You would have seen 115,000 people buzzing with confidence and excitement. On the other hand, noting how many passers-by were loudly talking to themselves, you might have concluded that you had wandered into the International Expo of Eccentrics.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Catastrophe Training For Firefighters
description: The New York Fire Department will receive training from the United States Forest Service on how to deal with large-scale catastrophes. The Department of Agriculture announced yesterday that the service, which has long experience in dealing with fires that last for weeks and burn thousands of acres, will train 64 New York firefighters, using as a model the service's Incident Management Teams. The training begins in March. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Plea Of Not Guilty
description: The former secretary to a top American investment banker at the London office of Goldman Sachs pleaded not guilty to 21 counts of embezzling $7 million from her boss and two other bankers. The not guilty plea from Joyti De-Laurey, the former secretary to E. Scott Mead, appeared to infuriate the judge, who said that Ms. De-Laurey's lawyers had indicated to him earlier that she would plead guilty. Ms. De-Laurey's lawyer said, however, said that he had just been hired and that she had fired her previous lawyer. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Teradyne Shares Drop On Wider Loss
description: The stock of Teradyne Inc. skidded yesterday after company, which makes of semiconductor testing equipment, posted a wider-than-expected net loss for the fourth quarter, despite a surge in sales. Shares of Teradyne fell $2.49, or 16 percent, to $12.99. Teradyne reported a net loss of $423.8 million, or $2.31 a share, compared with a net loss of $112.6 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding restructuring charges and other items, the company, based in Boston, said it would have posted a loss of $36.5 million, or 20 cents a share. The mean estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 22 cents a share, excluding items. Revenue increased 51 percent, to $333.6 million, from $220.2 million a year before.

title: INTERPUBLIC EXPLORES THE SALE OF MARKET RESEARCH UNIT
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies, New York, said yesterday that it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to ''explore strategic alternatives'' for the NFO WorldGroup, a large market research company that it acquired in spring 2000 for about $600 million. Advertising Age reported last month that Interpublic, which is struggling with financial problems, was considering a sale of NFO WorldGroup to help reduce debt. In a related step, Interpublic, which owns agencies like McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, said it had reached agreement with its lenders to extend a due date for amending its major credit agreements to Feb. 10 from yesterday. Stuart Elliott (NYT)

title: Hernndez and Coln Traded in Three-Team Deal
description: For months, the Yankees collected pitchers, their rotation bulging and their payroll steadily rising. But one prominent hurler remained on the market who somehow eluded their grasp -- Bartolo Coln, the Montreal Expos' ace right-hander. Yesterday, he was finally traded, but not to the Yankees, who instead helped move Coln to the Chicago White Sox by sending Orlando Hernndez to the Expos.

title: Titans Hope George Can Still Run It

description: KATZ-Ada Weiner, 96. Matriarch. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Katz. Survived by daughters: Selma and Irving Krasner, Enid and Sheldon Smookler. Grandmother and great-grandmother.
