title: This Mr. Fix-It Can Tell A Network From a Portal
description: If you have ever wrestled with a wad of wires trying to set up stereo equipment or a home office, you may be ready for Audio Video Solutions, which sells and installs flat-screen televisions, surround-sound home theaters and other electronics. David Slavitt, the owner, can set up multiroom audio-video systems and connect a computer network inside a home. He will even design and install lighting. Mr. Slavitt works in New York, Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey. His equipment prices are below retail. A home consultation is free; after that, it's $95 an hour for installation. Information from www.avsolutionsinc.net or (866) 335-2412 toll-free. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

description: FOUR shows this week are featuring American antiques and decorative arts. For those who covet Americana but can't afford the originals at the shows, skilled craftsmen sell fine reproductions from their workshops at a fraction of the cost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, OTTO L.
description: WALTER-Otto L., 95. Of New York City, died January 12 after a brief illness. Driven from his native land by Nazi hatred, he became a powerful voice for German-American reconciliation in the decades following World War II. Disbarred by Hitler's antiJewish decrees from practicing as an attorney in Germany after earning his law degree there, he studied law again in the United States and became a renowned international jurist. Confronted with ugliness, he became a patron of the arts. Persecuted, he responded with charity. Deeply mourned by his loving wife, Frances; sister-in-law, Marga; nephews, Michael and Robert, and untold colleagues and friends. In accordance with his wish there will be no funeral ceremonies. Gifts in his memory may be made to City Harvest, 575 Eighth Avenue, 4th floor, NYC 10018; Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue, NYC 10027-4698; or New York Law School, 57 Worth Street, New York City 10013-2960.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: STATEN ISLAND: EMPLOYEES ACCUSED IN FATAL FIRE A fire that killed the owner of a thrift shop was set by employees, investigators said yesterday. Sandra Sharma, 43, and her daughter, Maria Sharma, 27, were charged with second-degree murder, arson and conspiracy in the death of Christopher Fabanwo on Tuesday. Mr. Fabanwo, 49, the owner of the Second Hand store on Broadway in Stapleton, died of injuries suffered when he went back to fight the fire after steering his employees out of the store, investigators said. Ms. Sharma's son, Thomas Therrien, 21, was charged with conspiracy, said the Staten Island district attorney, William L. Murphy. The workers told fire marshals and the police that they set fire to a clothing bin in the back of the store because they were tired of folding clothes, investigators said. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: Anthony Havelock-Allan, 98, Producer
description: Sir Anthony Havelock-Allan, a British film producer and scriptwriter who worked on major British films of the 1940's like ''Brief Encounter'' and ''Great Expectations,'' died on Jan. 11 in London. He was 98 and had made his home in London.

description: Doctors in New Jersey are planning a work stoppage on Feb. 3 to protest rising malpractice insurance costs and to highlight their nearly yearlong demand for legislative relief.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 16  In a determined defense of engagement with North Korea, President-elect Roh Moo Hyun all but ruled out the use of force against his isolated neighbor today and vowed to continue to press for dialogue, come what may.

description: Slovakia was chosen as the site for a new car plant by Peugeot Citron of France, as the company seeks to increase sales in Central Europe. description: The Israeli Army shut down two Palestinian universities in the West Bank city of Hebron today, stepping up military pressure on Palestinian institutions and individuals it said were linked to terrorism.

description: Times are always tough in the indie world, and by all accounts they are particularly tough on the eve of this year's Sundance Film Festival, which opens Thursday night with a gala in Salt Lake City before moving up to Park City, Utah, for its remaining nine days.

title: Strike's Effects Tear at Social Fabric in Venezuela
description: The sign on the door says ''closed.'' The lights are dim. The staff is not in uniform. Customers are only allowed in through the out door. But in the seventh week of a national strike aimed at shutting down the economy and toppling President Hugo Chvez, Blockbuster Video began covert operations in at least two popular stores in the capital.

title: Seoul's Choice: The U.S. or the North
description: It seems almost heretical to question the merit and durability of the United States alliance with South Korea. Yet recent events in Seoul -- huge anti-American protests, a reluctance to join with the United States in facing down the North Korean nuclear threat -- should prompt just such a reconsideration. South Korea may soon have to decide whether it stands with the United States, which is responsible for much of Seoul's present security and prosperity, or whether it will take another path.

title: U.S.O.C. Member Resigns
description: A member of the United States Olympic Committee has resigned to protest its refusal to discipline the chief executive officer, Lloyd Ward, for using a staff member to assist his brother's business venture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, EILEEN (NEE ESKOW)
description: MILLER-Eileen (nee Eskow). After her courageous battle against brain cancer, died peacefully on January 14, 2003, at age 47. Precious and beloved sister of Valerie and husband, Jim O'Halpin, sister, Karen Seader and sister, Laurie, and husband, Michael Getlan. Her good humor and passion for life affected everyone who knew her. Services Friday, January 17, 11 AM, at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Rd.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Lawsuits Increase
description: The German pharmaceuticals company Bayer said that the number of lawsuits it faced after the recall of its anticholesterol drug Baycol had risen to 7,400 from 5,700 in November. Baycol was withdrawn in August 2001 after it was linked to more than 50 deaths worldwide. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: South Korea's Next Leader Reassures U.S.
description: President-elect Roh Moo Hyun moved today to ease concerns about anti-Americanism in South Korea and his own ambivalence toward the alliance with the United States, visiting its military headquarters in Seoul and invoking American sacrifices in the Korean War.

title: Laptop Sends Network Cruisers Into 802.11a Overdrive
description: Laptop speedsters on corporate Wi-Fi networks can surf even faster with a new notebook computer from Toshiba. The top model in the company's new Satellite Pro 6100 series comes not only with built-in wireless 802.11b networking for data transfer at a fast 11 megabits per second, but also with 802.11a networking capability.

title: In 1908, Gaud Had a Vision Of a Skyscraper
description: The world contracted skyscraper fever long before 1930, when the Chrysler Building smacked its glossy kiss on the Manhattan skyline. Look into the files of any great architect -- at least those with Y chromosomes -- and there's bound to be a skyscraper sketch in there. One is from 1908 and by Antoni Gaud, whose vaulted peaks are best displayed in the Sagrada Familia church in Barcelona. Two American businessmen commissioned a Manhattan skyscraper from Gaud, who proposed a 984-foot hotel tower with elaborate halls dedicated to all the continents. Marc Mascort i Boix, the author of a CD-ROM about the design, will give a free lecture on it next Thursday at 6 p.m. at the CUNY Graduate Center, 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street; (212) 817-8410. JULIE V. IOVINE

description: PERHAPS recognizing the handwriting on the wall, Palm Inc. is changing the handwriting input component of its Palm operating system for hand-held organizers.

description: The Supreme Court's decision to uphold a 20-year extension on the copyright term handed a major victory to the entertainment and publishing industries, which stand to make billions of dollars by keeping control over lucrative properties for up to 95 years.

title: Protests Against Fuel Price Hike Continue in Indonesia
description: Indonesia's government proposed delaying increased prices on fuel and power as popular protests continued Thursday against the plan. Any postponement would be certain to complicate scheduled talks with international lenders next week.

title: Workers Say Child Agency Turnover Slows Abuse Inquiries
description: The unceasing turnover of caseworkers at New Jersey's child welfare agency has caused hundreds of open investigations of abuse to go unattended for weeks and sometimes months at a time, caseworkers and supervisors with the agency said in interviews this week.

title: Boy, 3, Is Killed As Mitten String Gets Caught In a Bus Door
description: A 3-year-old Rockland County boy was dragged to his death on Tuesday after the long string connecting his mittens became caught in the bus's closing door as he was getting off in front of his home, the authorities said yesterday. The bus continued to move, and the boy, Chaim U. Horovitz, was dragged more than 100 feet, officials said. He was pronounced dead at the scene.

Fujitsu's unsecured debt rating was cut to Baa2, the second-lowest investment grade, from A3. The company's outlook is stable, it said. Fujitsu, based in Tokyo, makes computers and communications equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ''BILLIE'' (FRANCES)
description: ROSENBERG-''Billie'' (Frances). Deceased at age 89 of a lengthy illness in Mt. Vernon, New York, January 14, 2003. Loving mother of Merri. Cherished mother-in-law of Kenneth Hupart. Adored grandmother of Jacob and Ruth Hupart. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Jacob, and daughters Marian and Helen. A native and 70-year resident of Brooklyn, she had recently lived in Boca Raton, Florida before returning to New York. A graduate of Brooklyn College, where she served as her class president, she earned her Master's Degree from Teachers College, Columbia University and taught for many years in the New York City public school system. After retiring, she became an active and dedicated volunteer for the Brooklyn Museum. Donations may be made to the Brooklyn College Alumni Federation, 2900 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11210; the Brooklyn Museum Community Committee, 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, New York 11238 or the Brooklyn Botanical Garden, 1000 Washington Ave, Brooklyn, New York 11225.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Employees Accused In Fatal Fire
description: A fire that killed the owner of a thrift shop was set by employees, investigators said yesterday. Sandra Sharma, 43, and her daughter, Maria Sharma, 27, were charged with second-degree murder, arson and conspiracy in the death of Christopher Fabanwo on Tuesday. Mr. Fabanwo, 49, the owner of the Second Hand store on Broadway in Stapleton, died of injuries suffered when he went back to fight the fire after steering his employees out of the store, investigators said. Ms. Sharma's son, Thomas Therrien, 21, was charged with conspiracy, said the Staten Island district attorney, William L. Murphy. The workers told fire marshals and the police that they set fire to a clothing bin in the back of the store because they were tired of folding clothes, investigators said. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: Villanova Wins It At the Line
description: When St. John's forward Anthony Glover was asked what made the Red Storm's free throws look like shot-puts last night, Coach Mike Jarvis whispered in his ear. Jarvis may have been advising Glover to take the diplomatic high road in assessing his teammates' foul shooting, but to everyone in the crowd of 10,684 at Madison Square Garden, the display was obviously hideous.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: TERADYNE SHARES DROP ON WIDER LOSS The stock of Teradyne Inc. skidded yesterday after company, which makes of semiconductor testing equipment, posted a wider-than-expected net loss for the fourth quarter, despite a big surge in sales. Shares of Teradyne fell $2.49, or 16 percent, to $12.99. Teradyne reported a net loss of $423.8 million, or $2.31 a share, compared with a net loss of $112.6 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding restructuring charges and other items, the Boston-based company said it would have posted a loss of $36.5 million, or 20 cents a share. The mean estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 22 cents a share, excluding items. Revenue, however, increased 51 percent, to $333.6 million, from $220.2 million a year before. "The combination of a weak economy, weak demand for technology products and the uncertain world situation overwhelmed the recovery we had begun to see in the first half of 2002," said George Chamillard, Teradyne's chairman and chief executive.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 16  Samsung Electronics posted higher profits and sales last year, but it turned in such a disappointing fourth quarter that its stock declined for several hours today after the figures were released in the morning.

description: Rockland County yesterday joined an effort by two neighboring county governments to shut the Indian Point nuclear plant by refusing to sign off on plans for a possible radioactivity emergency.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEWARK: RETAILER SETTLES SEX HARASSMENT SUIT The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission announced yesterday that Babies "R" Us had agreed to pay $205,000 to a former employee in a federal employment discrimination lawsuit brought after the employee asserted that other workers mocked him because he was homosexual. The employee, Andres Vasquez, who worked at a Babies "R" Us store in Paterson, said that other employees whistled at him, called him names and pulled his pants down because, he said, he did not conform to male stereotypes. Babies "R" Us is a division of Toys "R" Us , which is based in Paramus. The company also agreed to give antidiscrimination training to its employees. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Slower Growth Expected
description: Jeon Yun Churl, the finance minister, forecast that South Korea's economic growth would slow and its trade surplus would decline this year. Mr. Jeon predicted the economy would grow by about 5 percent in 2003 after climbing 6.2 percent in 2002. He said the trade surplus would probably fall short of last year's $10 billion because exports would increase at a slower rate. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Baby Dies In a House Fire
description: A 1-year-old boy was killed and two women were critically injured yesterday in a house fire in Morris Heights that sent five other people to the hospital, the authorities said. The fire broke out at 12:20 p.m. in the rear of an apartment near the top of 1571 Undercliff Avenue, a seven-story building. The baby, whose name was not released, was taken to Lincoln Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, the authorities said. Two other children and three firefighters were taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where they were treated and released. The two women, about 40 years old, were in critical condition in the hospital's burn unit last night, a hospital spokesman said. The fire was accidental, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Those Giant Poppies From Marimekko Are Back

The brightest new light on the Upper East Side is the Marimekko shop, which opened on Third Avenue last month, tickling the eye with bursts of color in bold-patterned 100 percent cotton fabric, home furnishings and clothing. Everything in the store is made by Marimekko in Finland. ''A whole new generation has discovered Marimekko,'' said Joe Dance, who worked for the original Marimekko New York store in the 1970's and 80's. Mr. Dance, who is now a spokesman for Crate & Barrel in New York, described the new enthusiasts: ''It's a young, hip group, furnishing first apartments. They think it's fresh and different -- not their grandmother's old stuff.'' But, of course, it could be.

Wares as varied as beds and bud vases can be found in the tranquil 5,000-square-foot space, designed by Studio Lanzi in Milan. There are handblown carafes ($100) and wenge wood breakfast trays ($216). Egyptian cotton sheet sets, in vivid Baroque patterns, include a duvet cover ($330 to $750.) Flou beds come with clever storage features. The Nathalie, designed 25 years ago by Vico Magistretti, has an upholstered headboard in a choice of 300 fabrics ($2,500 for queen size; mattress additional). ''New Yorkers are mattress-obsessed,'' said Richard Garofalo, president of Flou, N.Y., fascinated with ''how mattresses are constructed and what they are made of.'' He proposed smaller classes in middle schools, the place where so many students lose their footing. And he vowed to bring parents into the mix, making schools ''parent friendly'' while challenging parents to do their part.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NEPAL: CONFLICT'S TOLL ON CHILDREN Two thousand Nepalese children have been orphaned, 4,000 displaced and 168 killed in the Maoist insurrection that began in 1996, a Katmandu-based human rights group reported. The group, the Child Workers in Nepal Concerned Center, said more than 10,000 children had been denied access to education because of the insurgency. The center's president, Gauri Pradhan, expressed concern about reports that children have been recruited into the Maoists' army.    Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: SOLDIERS ACCUSED OF SHOOTING AT BUS A Chechen emissary to the Kremlin accused drunken Russian soldiers of firing on a bus outside Chechnya's second-largest city, Gudermes, killing its driver and wounding four others. Vatya Baibatyrov said the soldiers had fired on the bus at a military checkpoint on the road from Gudermes to Chechnya's capital, Grozny. A Chechen spokesman said the servicemen had been detained and that an inquiry was under way. But the chief administrator in Gudermes, Akhmed Abastov, told Moscow's Ekho Moskvy newsradio that "there has been nothing of the sort here."

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Wireless Services Bill Introduced
description: Senators George Allen, Republican of Virginia, and Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, have introduced legislation to promote wireless broadband deployment. The bill, the Jumpstart Broadband Act, calls for the Federal Communications Commission to allocate at least 255 megahertz of spectrum in the 5-gigahertz band for unlicensed use by wireless broadband services. The measure seeks to support the expansion of wireless technology known as WiFi, which allows users of personal and hand-held computers to connect to the Internet at high speed without cables. Mr. Allen said the legislation would create an environment that embraces innovation and encourages the adoption of next-generation wireless Internet devices. In addition, he said, such action would build confidence among consumers, investors and those in the telecommunications and technology industries. ''It's going to make it easier to get your information,'' Ms. Boxer said, ''make it quicker, make it less hassle.''

The director of Fallingwater, Lynda Waggoner, said that she knew she ''would do something with it,'' but she didn't know what until she met Cara Markowitz, a New York jewelry designer. description: Head-to-head matches between teams representing clubs take place in Britain and other parts of Europe but are rare on this side of the Atlantic. A first effort was made last week as part of Bridge Week, and others may follow.

title: Jury Behavior Raises Issues In Terror Case
description: Lawyers for four terrorists convicted in the 2001 embassy bombings trial in Manhattan said in court papers yesterday that jury irregularities might have affected the verdicts and could be the basis for granting a new trial.

title: Bouncing Signals Push the Limits of Bandwidth
description: IT is a phenomenon well known to people who drive through urban high-rise canyons. Just as you stop at a traffic light, the car radio loses its signal. Once the light turns green, the car only has to creep forward a few feet to restore the radio reception.

title: G.O.P. Proposes Widespread Spending Cuts
description: Senate Republicans, trying to untangle a financial mess from 2002, tonight unveiled a $386 billion measure that would cut proposed spending for most federal agencies by 1.6 percent and eliminate $9.8 billion approved by senators last year for domestic security, education and other programs.

title: Phillies Sign Houston; Yanks Agree to Terms With Flaherty
description: The Phillies signed infielder Tyler Houston yesterday to a one-year, $1 million contract, eliminating another option at third base for the Mets. Houston hit .281 with 7 home runs and 40 runs batted in for the Brewers and Dodgers last season, playing mostly at third base. The Mets, who had not pursued Houston aggressively, need to replace Edgardo Alfonzo, who signed as a free agent with the Giants in December. They have the rookie Ty Wigginton as their current third baseman.

title: G.M. Earnings Surge as Heavy Incentives Fuel Sales
description: DETROIT, Jan. 16  General Motors nearly doubled its profits last year and beat Wall Street's expectations in the fourth quarter, bringing employee bonuses back to the world's largest automaker.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERGENFELD, ANITA S.
description: BERGENFELD-Anita S. The puzzles are no longer done and other things are undone. Miss you. Love, Howar

title: Wolfowitz, in Kabul, Calls for Rebuilding
description: Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy defense secretary, called today for accelerating the reconstruction of Afghanistan, and he outlined a new plan for using American, Afghan and possibly European forces to improve security in more than half a dozen cities racked by banditry and factional fighting.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Supreme Court Upholds Extension of Copyright

title: Fair, Isaac Buys A Super Bowl Spot
description: Another advertiser is joining the handful of dot-coms that are buying commercials during the Super Bowl.

title: Looming Trade Penalties Could Sever a North Korean Link to Japan
description: With the red star of North Korea emblazoned on its funnel, a 300-passenger ferry from North Korea eased into the port of Niigata today, dropping anchor in the midst of Japan's debate over imposing economic sanctions on North Korea.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank's Profit Rises
description: The country's second-largest bank, Woori Bank, said its net income reached $1 billion last year, an increase of 79 percent over 2001. The bank, part of Woori Finance Holdings, attributed the increase to consumer loans, notably for mortgages and credit cards. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: David C. Morton II, Architect, 61, Dies
description: David Cummins Morton II, an architect who did the first residential loft conversion in the Fulton Ferry area in Brooklyn, died on Tuesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 61 and a former resident of Brooklyn Heights.

title: The Supreme Court Docket; States' Rights vs. Civil Rights
description: William Hibbs was fired by the Nevada Department of Human Resources for going on leave to care for his ailing wife. When he sued under the Family and Medical Leave Act, his employer responded that Congress had no power to impose the law on Nevada's state government. The Supreme Court heard arguments yesterday in Mr. Hibbs's case. If it rules against him, and holds that the Family and Medical Leave Act does not apply to state employers, it will radically diminish the power of Congress -- with no constitutional justification -- and strip millions of state workers of their rights.

title: The Cars Drove Away And Left A Challenge
description: AS young designers eager to get hands-on experience, John Jennings and Sasha Tarnopolsky wanted to find a true fixer-upper. They found one just over their fence in the Mar Vista neighborhood here, east of Venice.

title: Philippines Decides It's Time to Collect Taxes
description: Officials in the Philippines are trying to restore business confidence and attract investment by doing a better job at something many people wish they did not do at all: collecting taxes.

title: The Invisible Jobless
description: To the Editor:

title: Bold Move By Red Sox May Work
description: So the Boston Red Sox didn't get Bartolo Coln and they didn't get Jos Contreras. They didn't even get Edgardo Alfonzo or Jeff Kent. But they may wind up getting Kevin Millar, and if they do, they will have executed one of the cleverest initiatives of the off-season.

title: Third in a Row Is a Rangers First
description: It took the Rangers more than half the season, but tonight they finally won their third consecutive game.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Jan. 7 about the ways animals survive in winter included an erroneous statistic from the book ''Winter World: The Ingenuity of Animal Survival,'' by Bernd Heinrich, for the northern limit of a type of woolly caterpillar. It is 450 miles from the North Pole, not 100 miles.

title: Seles Exits Australian Open With Loss to Koukalova
description: Melbourne, Jan. 16 -- Four-time champion Monica Seles lost to world No. 113 Klara Koukalova in the Australian Open second round, removing a top seed from Serena Williams's route to the final.

title: British Police Review 'Poison' Raid That Left Officer Dead
description: The British police interrogated three North African men today over an antiterror raid that led to the killing of a policeman in Manchester on Tuesday, while politicians and law enforcement authorities debated what went wrong in the operation and what could be learned from it.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: In-Law Confesses In Fake Terror Case
description: The mother-in-law of an airport baggage handler has confessed to trying to help frame him by arranging for weapons and explosives to be placed in the trunk of his car. Fatia Bechiri blamed her son-in-law, Abderazak Besseghir, for her daughter's death in a household fire and intended to seek vengeance by having him jailed as an Islamic terrorist. Mr. Besseghir, 27, was arrested in late December after the police, acting on a tip from a former French Foreign Legionnaire, found the weapons in his car. The former soldier and another man, Patrick Pouchoulin, later confessed to putting the weapons there and Mr. Besseghir was released last week. Mrs. Bechiri and her husband, Ahmed Bechiri, have been placed under investigation. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Enchanted Across a Crowded (and Compact) Room
description: ''Bigger is better'' has been the mantra of more than one theater impresario. What you don't hear too often is ''smaller might be cool,'' and this is especially so if you're talking about musical revivals. But if the production of ''South Pacific'' by the Arena Stage here has any influence -- and it should -- the musical in miniature could well become a theatrical trend.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture yesterday with an article about conflicts in northern Iraq misidentified a tribal fighter who was seen unbuckling his cartridge belt. He was unidentified; Gilda Drozna was a town's name, not his.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMBLER, ANNE BERSHAD
description: STAMBLER-Anne Bershad. 91. Died January 13, 2003 at home. Beloved widow of Sigmund, loving mother of Helen Lynne of NYC, devoted aunt and great aunt. A lifelong resident of Philadelphia, she will be greatly missed by her family and friends. Donations may be made to National Dance Institute, 594 Broadway, New York, NY 10012.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWSON, CAROL W.
description: DAWSON-Carol W. Age 85, of Bridgeport, CT, formerly of Staten Island, died Jan. 6, 2003. He was an Army veteran of WWII, and Ret. Secretary of the Board for American Maritime Insurance Company. His funeral was held on Jan. 10th in CT. Memorial gifts can be directed to: The New York Public Library. For more information, visit www.leskofuneralhome.com

title: Small Nations Criticize Plan For 2 Chiefs Over Europe
description: Deep divisions emerged in the European Union today over a joint proposal by the French and Germans to install two presidents at the helm of the expanding bloc.

title: Teenage Prostitution Ring Broken in Detroit
description: The police said today that they had broken up a Midwestern sex ring that plucked teenage girls from the streets, kept them captive and coerced them to peddle jewelry and sex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOROWSKI, ELIE
description: BOROWSKI-Elie. A giant of a man-who lived a life of scholarship, heroism, philanthropy, and family. Elie Borowswki is a world-renowned collector and scholar of monotheism's shared values, texts, and artifacts. The Borowski Collections' are world known; with the most important works housed in his Bible Lands Museum, Jerusalem. Elie Borowski was a humanitarian, a Holocaust survivor, a classical scholar focused on the future. On behalf of the values of good, Elie Borowski battled the 'angel of death' for 90 years. With prayers of love and support to Batya and the entire family. Alan & Naomi Bayer

title: Globalstar, Bankrupt Satellite Company, to Be Sold for $55 Million
description: Globalstar, the bankrupt satellite phone company, agreed yesterday to sell control of itself to an investment firm run by Bennett S. LeBow for $55 million.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: WIRELESS SERVICES BILL INTRODUCED Senators George Allen, Republican of Virginia, and Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, have introduced legislation to promote wireless broadband deployment. The bill, the Jumpstart Broadband Act, calls for the Federal Communications Commission to allocate at least 255 megahertz of spectrum in the 5-gigahertz band for unlicensed use by wireless broadband services. The measure seeks to support the expansion of wireless technology known as WiFi, which allows users of personal and hand-held computers to connect to the Internet at high speed without cables. Mr. Allen said the legislation would create an environment that embraces innovation and encourages the adoption of next-generation wireless broadband Internet devices. In addition, he said, such action would build confidence among consumers, investors and those in the telecommunications and technology industries. "This is really the next revolution in the whole communications area," Ms. Boxer said. "It's going to make it easier to get your information, make it quicker, make it less hassle." (NYT)

title: Economic Scene; What would be the long-run impact of tax-free dividends on markets?
description: PAUL H. O'NEILL, the former Treasury secretary, was known for saying ''the right thing at the wrong time.'' The phrase is a fitting description of President Bush's recent proposal to eliminate taxes on stock dividends.

title: Columbia Takes Off Under Tight Security
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 16 — The space shuttle Columbia roared off into a picture-perfect sky today to begin a 16-day research mission with a crew that includes the first astronaut from Israel.

title: Airliners Are Vulnerable, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  Airliners remain vulnerable to terrorist bombs hidden in air cargo, the General Accounting Office said in a report released today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Green Light For U.S. Missile Shield
description: The government signaled its approval of President Bush's proposed missile shield, saying it was prepared to agree to an American request to upgrade the Royal Air Force early warning station at Fylingdales in North Yorkshire and make it available for the defensive system. Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon made the announcement to the House of Commons where many Labor members, already concerned about possible British involvement in an American-led attack on Iraq, denounced the decision. A former defense minister, Peter Kilfoyle, accused the government of rushing to embrace every ''crackpot notion'' put forward by ''ideologues in Washington.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: There Goes The Nabe: Up, Up, Up
description: WHEN Alyssa Shelasky, 26, was apartment-hunting earlier this month on West 78th Street near West End Avenue, the owner of a property she didn't find especially captivating shared some news he thought would help seal the deal.

title: Serena Williams Is Returning to Form
description: While Round 1 brought ample and audible cause for concern, Round 2 brought nothing but the usual for the Williams sisters: straight-set victories, seen-a-ghost testimony from the opposition, and light and breezy chatter in the interview room.

title: Adventures In Driving, Via Web Map
description: FIGURING out how to drive to an unfamiliar destination is not what it used to be. Passenger seats across the United States are strewn with evidence that verbal directions and folding maps are yesterday's tools.

title: Bush Urges Nationwide Limits on Medical-Malpractice Awards
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  With doctors across the country protesting the cost of malpractice insurance, President Bush is making a renewed push for strict limits on the jury awards he blames for skyrocketing premiums.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METRINKO, MICHAEL
description: METRINKO-Michael. NYSE trader and Wall Street legend Michael J. Metrinko missed the opening bell Monday. Michael J. was the oldest New York Stock Exchange Trader who also held the record as being the longest standing member of the NYSE. He passed away at the age of 93. ''Mike was a beloved member of the Exchange community and will be missed'', Dick Grasso, Chairman of the New York Stock Exchange said on Monday. The Exchange flew their three American Flags that adorn the facade of its building, 11 Wall Street, at half staff Monday in honor of Metrinko. Married for 62 years to Elizabeth Sedor of Alden Station, PA, they have three daughters, Marsha, Michele and Monika; and four grandchildren, Michele, Monique, Michael and Marc Rollins. Also survived by sister, Olga, brothers, Pat and Will, and numerous nieces and nephews. Donations may be made to: Oblates of Saint Francis de Sales, for The Msgr. Martin Canavan's Ukrainian Project, C/O Father William Gore, 1600 Brinkle Avenue Wilmington, DE. 19806.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIAK, JOSEPH MICHAEL
description: SPIAK-Joseph Michael, 46, of Acton, MA, by airplane accident in Charlotte, NC. January 8. Husband of Jill (Langston). Father of Michael and Kristin Spiak, both of Acton. Son of Anthony and Palavia (Kawola) Spiak of Latham, New York. Brother of Marybeth Panock and her husband Richard of Lexington, Matthew and his wife Stephanie, and Thomas, all of Latham, New York. Also survived by father-in-law, Reuel Langston and his wife Madeline of Latham, NY, sister-in-law Barbara Langston and her husband Paul Rowe of Lexington and his nieces and nephews, Megan Spiak, Joel and Craig Panock, and Matthew Spiak. A memorial service at Our Lady of the Assumption Church, 498 Watervliet-Shaker Road, Latham, New York Will be Saturday, January 18, 12 Noon, immediately followed by a reception. In lieu of flowers, an educational trust fund has been established at Hudson River Bank & Trust Co., 767 New Loudon Road, Latham, NY Attention: John Delory. Donations will be made to ''The Children of Joseph Spiak.''

title: For Good or Ill, Districts That Defined Neighborhoods Will Disappear
description: Savvy New York City parents know that if they want good schools, they should move to District 2, which stretches from TriBeCa to the Upper East Side, or District 26, in Bayside, Queens. These are islands within the city school system that have dozens of top-performing schools, where nearly every child reads above grade level.

title: Czech Deputies Fail to Pick Successor to Havel
description: The Czech Parliament failed today to elect a successor to the departing President Vaclav Havel. A second balloting is expected after Mr. Havel steps down on Feb. 2.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Conflict's Toll On Children
description: Two thousand Nepalese children have been orphaned, 4,000 displaced and 168 killed in the Maoist insurrection that began in 1996, a Katmandu-based human rights group reported. The group, the Child Workers in Nepal Concerned Center, said more than 10,000 children had been denied access to education because of the insurgency. The center's president, Gauri Pradhan, expressed concern about reports that children have been recruited into the Maoists' army. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Ferris State Gains Prominence
description: Up in Big Rapids, Mich., these days, Coach BOB DANIELS is dealing with a new emotion as his Ferris State University Bulldogs sit stubbornly in first place in the Central Collegiate Hockey Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, ROBERT
description: COOK-Robert. On January 14, 2003. Beloved son of Anne (nee Gallagher) and the late Robert. Loving father of Patrice and Robert. Fond brother of Barbara West and Bernadette O'Donnell. Adored uncle of several nieces and nephews. Reposing Riverdale On Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue (West 261st Street), Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10AM, St. Margaret of Cortona RC Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, MILTON AARON
description: EPSTEIN-Milton Aaron. On January 14, 2003. Beloved father of Ethan, Deborah Lara and Diana Collins; loving brother of David; cherished grandfather of Eliza, Adam, Ross, Isabella, Thomas, Eleanor and Jessica. Services Friday 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: State to Give 2 Wrongly Convicted Men $1.65 Million Each
description: Two men wrongfully convicted and imprisoned for 14 years in the 1987 shooting death of a livery cab driver in Brooklyn will receive $1.65 million apiece from the state of New York, the second-highest such settlement.

title: An Appeal To Uncle Sam
description: Felix Rohatyn, the civic-minded financier who helped guide New York City through the perilous waters of its 1970's fiscal crisis, is going to Washington next week to talk to the nation's mayors about possible solutions to the current fiscal crisis that is threatening to overwhelm budgets in states and cities across the country.

title: CHARGES IN GERMANY
description: Prosecutors charged a Turkish man and his American fiance with planning a bomb attack on a United States military base last year. Astrid Eyzaguirre, 23, an American, who worked on an American military base in Heidelberg, and her German-born Turkish boyfriend, Osman Petmezci, 25, were arrested a few days before the first anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. The couple deny they planned an attack. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Hot Brodeur Leaves Islanders Cold
description: The Islanders finally nudged the puck through the Devils' zone, always a feat in itself. Center Aleksei Yashin found himself with the puck, alone, in front of goaltender Martin Brodeur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZISSU, LILLIAN (NEE SCHEPS)
description: ZISSU-Lillian (nee Scheps) of North Caldwell, N.J., formerly of Kings Point, Long Island, wife of the late Frederick Zissu, mother of Barbara Kushnick, Jeffrey Zissu, Sandra Rosenbaum & the late Karen Zissu Magidson, grandmother of 14, great grandmother of eight. Funeral services at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, N.J. on Thursday, January 16 at 11:30AM. Interment Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, New Jersey.

title: Carmakers Design For Generation Y
description: The Honda Element looks like a sport utility vehicle that married a Brink's truck, with as much headroom as a Greyhound bus. Inside, Honda calls it a dormitory room on wheels, with seats that can be turned around, pulled out, folded flat, stacked with gear and hosed off.

title: The Neediest Cases; Defying the Odds to Keep Her Children in School
description: At night, the stairwells of the Brooklyn apartment building where Sandra Campbell lives echo with loud music and ceaseless activity. A woman sprays an old armoire with paint and varnish, filling the halls with acrid fumes. Children in heavy coats sit by the main stairwell, where they have spread their homework, trying to ignore the constant foot traffic that tramples their papers.

title: Pilots Ignored Rules on Attacks, Commander Testifies
description: An Air Force commander who supervised air combat in Afghanistan testified today that two F-16 pilots had ignored a series of standing orders intended to prevent innocent deaths when they dropped a 500-pound bomb on a squad of Canadian soldiers, killing four and wounding eight.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Fishing Deadline Extension
description: Fishermen won a reprieve from tough new catch restrictions that were to begin next year after the National Marine Fisheries Service extended the deadline for replenishing depleted populations of cod, haddock and other species to 2014 from 2009. The extra time will allow scientists to review the health of the fish and to further assess a count botched two years ago. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: 'Dance of the Vampires,' a $12 Million Broadway Failure, Is Closing
description: In one of the costliest failures in Broadway history, the producers of ''Dance of the Vampires,'' a $12 million camp musical at the Minskoff Theater, will close the show on Jan. 25, having lost their entire investment.

title: Accounting Rules Changed to Bar Tactics Used by Enron
description: The nation's accounting rule makers took steps yesterday intended to make it harder for companies to hide debts and assets from their shareholders. At the same time, the Securities and Exchange Commission adopted rules aimed at changing other practices thrown into a harsh light by recent financial scandals.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: NASA Sets Shuttle Launching
description: NASA cleared the space shuttle Columbia for launching today on a 16-day science mission with a crew that includes the first Israeli astronaut. NASA managers issued the order after determining that an oxygen line crack in another shuttle was not a threat to Columbia. Stefano S. Coledan (NYT)

title: Nine Bullets That Ended Baptists' Work in Yemen
description: The last note on the medical chart was made on Dec. 26 when Abed Abdel Razzak Kamel called the hospital to say that he and his wife could not make an appointment that day. ''One to two months pregnant,'' the note reads. ''Will be here on the 30th.''

title: Study Finds North Atlantic Shark Populations in Decline
description: Shark populations in the northwest Atlantic have plunged by more than half since scientists began closely tracking them in 1986, with marquee species like the hammerhead and the great white falling more than 75 percent, researchers say.

title: Football's Looniest Stadium Has Its Last Rowdy Hurrah
description: For a decade, Daniel Flagg has regularly attended Philadelphia Eagles games at Veterans Stadium. He always wanted to meet his heroes, and last Saturday night he did -- right in the middle of a playoff game against the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Rash Of Statue Vandalism
description: Law enforcement officials are investigating the defacement of more than a dozen statues two weeks after the head was removed from a limestone eagle on a federal courthouse facade. The police said that around 9:30 p.m. on Tuesday they received a report that someone had defaced a dozen statues outside St. Lucy's Church in Newark's North Ward. Reports of similar incidents involved statues outside St. Patrick's Pro-Cathedral in Washington Park and outside St. Michael's Medical Center. Because the vandalism occurred outside churches, the police are investigating the incidents as possible hate crimes, but they do not yet know if the incidents are related. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the debate between President Bush and Democrats in Congress over education policy referred incorrectly to spending provisions in legislation signed by Mr. Bush last year. While it called for specific increases for a number of educational programs, it did not authorize an overall increase this year to $29.2 billion from $22.2 billion.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Perjury Conviction In Asylum Case
description: A woman from Ghana in West Africa whose plea for political asylum drew national attention after she said she feared genital mutilation, was convicted yesterday in Brooklyn federal court of perjury, passport fraud and making false statements to immigration officials. Federal prosecutors said the woman, Regina Norman Danson, 32, ''made a mockery of the immigration system and real victims of genital mutilation'' by inventing her story so she could remain in this country. Dawn M. Cardi, a lawyer for Ms. Danson, said that Ms. Danson would appeal. She faces prison and deportation at a sentencing on March 26. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Mainstream Ahead In Black Publishing
description: Not too long ago, as these things go, book publishing had the epiphany that there were a large number of black readers with a thirst for relevance. From that revelatory discovery grew a burst of imprints devoted to books by and for African-Americans and more interest in adding such fiction and nonfiction to mainstream lists. It's a bit early to evaluate.

title: G.M. Critical Of Regulator Questioning S.U.V. Safety
description: General Motors sharply criticized the Bush administration's top automobile regulator today for questioning the safety of some sport utility vehicles, signaling a surprising rift between the auto industry and the administration.

title: These Bowls From Italy Say Oranges and Lemons
description: The pattern looks retro. The colors also look period. Laura Cassell, a senior buyer for Williams-Sonoma, said she found these bowls and 100 percent cotton tablecloths in Italy. The tablecloth was available only in blue. She ordered it done over in citrusy colors. ''I think the really large-scale print makes it more casual and fun for breakfast,'' she said. Depending on size, the cloth is $62 to $89; four napkins, $36.

title: Lack of Witnesses Hinders Inquiry Into Police Shooting
description: An investigation of a fatal shooting by a police officer in Brooklyn on Jan. 2 has been stymied by a lack of witnesses with a clear view of the officer at the instant of the shooting, according to several law enforcement officials.

title: Hingis Says She Might Call It Quits
description: Martina Hingis cast further doubt on her tennis future, telling a Swiss news service that she had no plans to resume playing.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Eyewear Acquisition
description: The Luxottica Group, the world's No. 2 eyewear maker, said it bought IC Optics from Gianni Versace and would increase revenue with a 10-year contract to make glasses using the IC Optics brand name.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Soldiers Accused Of Shooting At Bus
description: A Chechen emissary to the Kremlin accused drunken Russian soldiers of firing on a bus outside Chechnya's second-largest city, Gudermes, killing its driver and wounding four others. Vatya Baibatyrov said the soldiers had fired on the bus at a military checkpoint on the road from Gudermes to Chechnya's capital, Grozny. A Chechen spokesman said the servicemen had been detained and that an inquiry was under way. But the chief administrator in Gudermes, Akhmed Abastov, told Moscow's Ekho Moskvy newsradio that ''there has been nothing of the sort here.'' Michael Wines (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: In Gotham, for Gotham And, Yes, by Gotham

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LILIENFIELD, ROBERT
description: LILIENFIELD-Robert. Died peacefully at his home after a brave battle with cancer. He is survived by his beloved wife Barbara, his devoted children Tracy, Todd and Terry, his son-in-law Barrett Heins, his grandchildren Benjamin, Kelsey, Rebecca, and his father Walter. His family, friends, and all who knew him will remember him with joy. Services will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, Sunday, January 19, 2003 at 2PM.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the killing of a British police officer during the arrest of suspected terrorists from North Africa referred incorrectly to events in 1992 that prompted some Algerians to settle in Britain. Military officers canceled elections that were expected to bring a militant Islamic party to power. They did not take power from an elected Islamic government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, HANNI
description: KRAUS-Hanni, 83. Of New York City. On January 14, 2003 after a brief illness. Loving wife of the late Hans P. Kraus. Beloved mother of Mary Ann Folter, Barbara Gstalder, Eveline Rauber, Susan Nakamura and Hans P. Kraus, Jr. She is also survived by her sister Dorit Cohn, twelve grandchildren and two great-grancchildren. She was an active member of the International Association of Bibliophiles. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Friday, January 17 at 1:30PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Kraus Fund at the Beinecke Rare Book Library at Yale University, New Haven, CT.

title: Europe Scrutinizing Deals Studios Make With Pay TV
description: Antitrust officials at the European Commission are investigating broadcast-rights deals between Hollywood film studios and some European subscription TV companies, a spokeswoman for the commission said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Ariba To Restate More Results
description: Ariba said yesterday that it would restate 10 quarters of results, the second such announcement in less than three weeks, after failing to record as costs some stock options and $1.2 million in chartered-airplane services provided by the chairman, Keith Krach, to an executive. The money-losing software maker also said it expected the Nasdaq to say it might be delisted because it had not filed its annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Krach, Ariba's top shareholder, paid for flights by the former chief executive, Larry Mueller, from September 2000 to July 2001, the company said. Ariba said on Dec. 31 that it failed to book a $10 million payment from Mr. Krach to Mr. Mueller in 2001 as an expense and would restate its fiscal 2001 loss. The company, which makes business-procurement software, did not record the payments or chartered flight services as expenses, James Frankola, the chief financial officer, said. He declined to provide details on the flights. The restatements are unusual because the chairman -- not the company -- covered the expense.

title: Hussein's Foes Put Off Talks In North Iraq; Safety Is Issue
description: The Iraqi opposition yesterday postponed for at least two weeks what was supposed to be the first meeting of dissidents on Iraqi territory in a decade after Bush administration officials said the United States could not guarantee security, according to Iraqi dissidents and administration officials.

title: A Week When Punk Rules On MTV; A Network Gambit In Hope of Igniting Another New Wave
description: On Monday afternoon at the MTV studios, the Donnas were strutting through a sharp make-out song called, ''Take It Off.'' About a hundred fans -- all young, mainly white, largely female -- bobbed and clapped as Brett Anderson (who is Donna A.) told a reticent lover to quit dillydallying. ''Stop staring at my D cup,'' she snarled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSNER, JOHN W.
description: RESSNER-John W. January 9, 2003. Husband of Laura Bemben Ressner. Son of Natalie G. Ressner. Memorial service Saturday, January 18. 2 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers or gifts, donations may be made in his name to the American Heart Association (800-AHAUSA1), or to Princeton University through the John Ressner 84 Memorial Fund (send donations C/O Nancy Kalmikoff, Princeton University, P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, N.J. 08543-5357 and include the name of the fund).

title: Random House Merger Ousts a Top Publisher
description: Ann Godoff, the president of the Random House Trade Group and one of the most respected figures in book publishing, has resigned, after her job was eliminated in a corporate reorganization.

title: U.S. Asks U.N. To Speed Pace Of Inspections
description: The United States, eager to press the pace of arms inspections in Iraq, called today for a Security Council session on Thursday to air a dispute over the inspectors' schedule.

title: Riley Housewright, Microbiologist, Dies at 89
description: Riley D. Housewright, a microbiologist who helped direct United States research in biological warfare from World War II until 1970, died on Saturday at an assisted living center in Frederick, Md. He was 89.

title: $4 Billion Community Is Planned at Pilgrim Psychiatric Site
description: A new approach to suburban life is being planned for Long Island: a pedestrian-oriented, self-contained community that would be composed of 9,000 apartments, a shopping mall, an office tower, industrial space, a hotel and an aquarium. Some 20,000 people would work there. The $4 billion project would be on the site of the state's Pilgrim Psychiatric Center in Suffolk County.

title: Union Opposes Linking All-Star Game to Series
description: The people who operate the All-Star Game think it would be a smashing idea to link its outcome to home-field advantage in the World Series, but the people who play the game think otherwise.

title: Medical Panel Has Doubts About Plan For Smallpox
description: The government's plan for smallpox vaccinations is too rushed and lacks adequate safeguards, according to a draft report by a panel of independent medical experts convened to advise federal health officials.

title: Planned Databank on Citizens Spurs Opposition in Congress
description: Opposition is growing in Congress and among public interest groups to a domestic antiterrorism surveillance program being developed in the Defense Department.

title: Council Members Push Hard To Fill Coffers, Records Show
description: Several City Council members are already well on their way to raising as much as they would be legally allowed to spend on their re-election primaries this fall, according to campaign finance records released yesterday.

title: Oil Prices Hit 2-Year High, as Iraq Tensions Grow
description: LONDON, Jan. 16  Oil prices rose today to a two-year high, building on a weeklong surge after OPEC's decision to raise output failed to ease concerns about a supply disruption stemming from the escalating moves toward war in Iraq.

title: North Korea And the U.S. Must Talk, Carter Says
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, who helped defuse a nuclear crisis with North Korea in 1994, has urged the Bush administration to open direct talks with North Korea to resolve the latest showdown. He said any settlement should require North Korea to go beyond its earlier promises and verify that it had shut down all research aimed at the production of nuclear weapons.

title: German Economy Stagnates, and Revival Seems Far Off
description: BERLIN, Jan. 16  As Germans woke up to yet another dismal economic report today, a single question echoed from the nation's finance ministry to its fashion industry: Can anything revive Germany?

title: Inspectors Find Empty Warheads Able to Carry Chemical Agents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  United Nations weapons inspectors in Iraq reported today that they had found empty warheads designed to carry chemical agents, but the Iraqi government asserted that the weapons were not banned and were disclosed in its report to the United Nations last month.

title: 20-Year Extension of Existing Copyrights Is Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The Supreme Court today upheld the 20-year extension that Congress granted to all existing copyrights in 1998, declaring that while the extension might have been bad policy, it fell clearly within Congress's constitutional authority.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING CUTS EARNINGS FORECAST
description: Automatic Data Processing Inc., a processor of stock trades and payrolls, cut its 2003 earnings forecast because of slumping demand, and said profit fell last quarter for the first time since it went public in 1961. The shares fell 8 percent. The company, the world's biggest paycheck issuer, expects less profit and sales growth in the year ending in June than its July forecast of gains below 10 percent. Sales of brokerage services like settling share sales, mailing reports to shareholders and distributing proxies fell 14 percent in the second quarter, which ended Dec. 31, Automatic Data said. Second-quarter net income fell 1.1 percent, to $261.7 million, or 43 cents a share, from $264.6 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, ALLAN, M.D.
description: SCHNEIDER - Allan, M.D. Cherished husband of Susan. Loving father of Jack, Michele and Todd. Devoted son of Stella, and son-in-law of Muriel. Beloved brother of Lawrence and Arlene. Dear uncle. He lead his life with a quiet generosity and sweetness that will always be remembered and treasured. Services Thursday, January 16, 11:30 AM at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY.

title: McDONALD'S NAMES VICE PRESIDENT FOR U.S. OPERATIONS
description: The McDonald's Corporation named Ralph Alvarez to the new position of executive vice president and chief operations officer for United States restaurants. Mr. Alvarez will oversee more than 13,000 restaurants, the company said. He joined McDonald's in 1994 and was most recently president of McDonald's central division, with responsibility for about 4,300 restaurants. The chief executive, James Cantalupo, has created several posts since succeeding Jack Greenberg on Jan. 1. Last week, he named Mats Lederhausen as president of McDonald's business development group and Russ Smyth as president of the company's European unit.

title: Judge Is Angered by U.S. Stance In Case of 'Dirty Bomb' Suspect
description: A federal district judge in Manhattan showed anger and impatience yesterday at the Bush administration's new arguments as to why a terror suspect in military custody since June should not be able to meet with his lawyers, who are challenging his detention as an enemy combatant.

title: Apple Posts Loss on Weaker-Than-Expected Revenue
description: Apple Computer reported yesterday that it lost money in its fiscal first quarter, ended in December, on revenues that were slightly weaker than analysts' expectations.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Retailer Settles Sex Harassment Suit
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission announced yesterday that Babies ''R'' Us had agreed to pay $205,000 to a former employee in a federal employment discrimination lawsuit brought after the employee asserted that other workers mocked him because he was homosexual. The employee, Andres Vasquez, who worked at a Babies ''R'' Us store in Paterson, said that other employees whistled at him, called him names and pulled his pants down because, he said, he did not conform to male stereotypes. Babies ''R'' Us is a division of Toys ''R'' Us, which is based in Paramus. The company also agreed to give antidiscrimination training to its employees. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: F.D.A. PANEL VOTES TO SUPPORT LUNG PROTECTION DRUG
description: The Genzyme Corporation and BioMarin Pharmaceutical Inc. won the support of a federal panel for Aldurazyme, a drug that treats a rare and often fatal disorder that can damage organs and deform bones. A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee twice voted 12 to 0 to tell the agency that the companies' research showed Aldurazyme offers benefits, like protecting lungs, in patients with a condition called MPS-1. People with the disorder lack an enzyme needed to prevent a kind of sugar from building up in cells. Aldurazyme, which replaces the enzyme, may generate peak annual sales of $400 million worldwide, an analyst from CIBC World Markets, Matthew Geller, said. The votes move Aldurazyme closer to approval, since the F.D.A. usually takes the advice of its panels.

title: Rule Your Own Realm: The Ultimate E-Mail Address
description: IN this mobile age, an e-mail address can offer stability. People may move across town or halfway around the world, but they can always be found online. So even when faced with better or cheaper options for Internet service, they are often reluctant to switch because they will lose those precious e-mail addresses.

title: Fannie Mae's Profit Fell in 4th Quarter
description: Fannie Mae, the mortgage buyer, said today that its fourth-quarter net profit fell by more than half, hurt by low interest rates that cut into the value of its derivatives.

title: The Black Sea Yields a Ship From Greece in Its Glory Days
description: Scientists said yesterday that they had discovered the remains of a 2,400-year-old ship at the bottom of the Black Sea -- the oldest shipwreck ever found in the sea and a testament to its role as a vibrant crossroads of ancient commerce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTHMAN, MARTIN
description: WORTHMAN-Martin. Died January 9, 2003, age 85, of New York and Ft. Lauderdale. Beloved husband of Ruth (Isaac) Worthman, devoted father of Roy and wife Laurie, and Douglas and wife Patricia. Loving brother of Della Weinberger & brotherin-law Oscar, dear grandfather of Michael, Caleb, Alana and Nikki. Private graveside services: at New Montefiore Cemetery, Friday 1 P.M.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELPHI CORP., Troy, Mich., the maker of auto parts, said it won a $135 million order from Volkswagen, Wolfsburg, Germany, for electronic control units for windshield wipers and other components.

title: Seeking Power, 49ers' Coach Loses His Job
description: Steve Mariucci was part of the San Francisco 49ers family for six seasons, but he was more like an in-law than an embraced member of the clan. After Mariucci asked for more power within that family, he was fired yesterday.

title: French Risking Prestige as Talks Open in Ivory Coast Civil War
description: France initiated peace talks here today between rival factions fighting for control of Ivory Coast, hoping to end that country's four-month civil war and extricate itself from a dangerous and expensive military intervention.

title: Footlights
description: Attention, Muggles!

title: A Church in Crisis: Sunlight Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: DISCOUNTS HURT RETAILER The British retailer Marks & Spencer reported a 7 percent rise in third-quarter sales in stores open at least a year, but said disappointing clothing sales in November required it to take greater markdowns during its post-Christmas clearance sale. As a result, the company said, full-year markdown costs will be 5 percent higher than last year. Same-store sales of general merchandise, including clothing and home furnishings, rose 8 percent in the period. Same-store food sales grew 4 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Oh, for a Pizza: A Cry in the Wilderness
description: WHEN people ask me about the culture shock of moving from New York to Northern California, I answer that for the most part I have been charmed by the Left Coast.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Air Delays Expected
description: Lufthansa expects delays at several German airports today because of warning strikes in the morning that could last up to three hours. Ver.di, Europe's largest union, which represents Lufthansa's 52,000 flight attendants and ground employees, announced the strike after monthlong pay talks with the airline broke down this week. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: First Israeli in Space Sees Mission as a Symbolic Journey
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 16 — He is a soft-spoken man who is conscious of the importance of symbols and history, and the role he plays in both.

title: From Worm Genes, Human Obesity Clues
description: Biologists have laid a new basis for studying human obesity by identifying almost all the genes that regulate fat storage and metabolism in a small animal, the laboratory roundworm.

title: Briefly Noted
description: STRASBOURG SUSPECTS German prosecutors narrowed their case against four Algerian men suspected of planning a bomb attack in the French city of Strasbourg, dropping a charge that the suspects belong to a terrorist group. The prosecutors said they still intended to convict the four men of conspiracy to murder, and that dropping the charge of membership in a terrorist organization would speed up the trial.

title: Corrections
description: A Cabaret review on Friday about Mark Nadler's one-man show at the Firebird Upstairs Supper Club, in which he uses the Danny Kaye hit ''Tchaikovsky (and Other Russians)'' misspelled the name of one of the 49 composers mentioned in the song. It is Gretchaninoff, not Gretchnaninoff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, PEARL
description: GINSBERG - Pearl. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a most cherished friend of its extended family. Together with her late husband, Al, an esteemed member of our Board of Directors and its Executive Committee, Pearl identified with Boys Town's mission of helping disadvantaged Israeli youth receive a quality education enabling them to emerge as the builders and leaders of Israel. The Ginsbergs understood the importance of a combined Torah/Technology curriculum built on a foundation of values and care and concern for their fellow human beings. They expressed their commitment to these lofty ideals through their establishment and continued support of the Al and Pearl Ginsberg Scholarship Endowment Fund. The individual and collective achievements of Boys Town's students past, present and future will endure as a most meaningful legacy. We extend heartfelt condolences to Liane, Larry, Hilary, and the entire family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Josh S. Weston, Honorary Chairman Raphael Benaroya, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Executive V.P.

title: National Briefing | Washington: More Money Possible For Food Program
description: The Bush administration will ask for a $43 million increase in the program that provides food to poor women, infants and children, Ann M. Veneman, the secretary of agriculture, said. Known as WIC, the program helps feed 7.8 million people at a cost of $4.7 billion. Part of the new money would be used to create programs on breast-feeding and childhood obesity. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: PRESIDENT FAULTS RACE PREFERENCES AS ADMISSION TOOL
description: President Bush offered a sweeping denunciation of direct preferences for racial minorities in university admissions today and said his administration would file a brief with the Supreme Court urging that the affirmative action admissions policies at the University of Michigan be declared unconstitutional.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Discounts Hurt Retailer
description: The British retailer Marks & Spencer reported a 7 percent rise in third-quarter sales in stores open at least a year, but said disappointing clothing sales in November required it to take greater markdowns during its post-Christmas clearance sale. As a result, the company said, full-year markdown costs will be 5 percent higher than last year. Same-store sales of general merchandise, including clothing and home furnishings, rose 8 percent in the period. Same-store food sales grew 4 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: The Supreme Court Docket; The Coming of Copyright Perpetuity
description: In 1998 Congress was the scene of a battle over public domain, the public right of common, free and unrestricted use of artistic works whose copyright has expired. Corporations like Disney, organizations like the Motion Picture Association of America, and dead artists' families wanted to extend copyright. Advocates of public domain wanted to leave copyright protection as it was, which would have allowed many early 20th-century works, including corporate creations like Mickey Mouse, to slip into the public domain. The copyright owners won, and yesterday they won again when the Supreme Court, by a vote of 7 to 2, decided that Congress was within its constitutional rights when it extended copyright. The court's decision may make constitutional sense, but it does not serve the public well.

title: McGreevey Hopes Sprawl Is His Salvation Issue
description: By turning his first State of the State address into a rallying cry against suburban sprawl, Gov. James E. McGreevey put the most valiant possible face Tuesday on the limited political options now at his disposal.

title: New York Police Send an Investigator to London to Focus on a Poison Threat
description: The New York Police Department has sent a senior counterterrorism official to London because of concerns about the threat posed by a group of North African men accused of plotting terrorist attacks there using the lethal toxin ricin, and the department may send additional investigators, according to New York and British police officials.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: PLAGUE, LOST AND FOUND About 30 vials of plague were reported missing at Texas Tech University on Tuesday, but were accounted for the next day. A bureau official in Washington, speaking on condition of anonymity, said investigators believe that the samples were simply destroyed without proper paperwork, rather than stolen or misplaced. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Heineken Sells Stake
description: The world's third-largest brewer, Heineken, will sell its 15 percent stake in the Argentine brewer Quilmes International Bermuda, leading to a 73 million euro ($77 million) gain in 2003 earnings. Heineken is selling the stake in the venture with Quilmes Industrial, or Quinsa, after a Brazilian rival, Cia de Bebidas das Americas, known as Ambev, won approval from an Argentine regulator to buy a stake in Quinsa, a spokesman, Albert Holtzappel, said.

title: Bootleg Bytes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Making Art Together
National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Quicker Psychiatric Evaluations
description: The state has agreed to evaluate prisoners sent to its psychiatric hospital by judges more quickly, resolving a lawsuit filed two years ago by the American Civil Liberties Union. The state conceded that some inmates waited a year or longer before psychiatrists examined them. The settlement, approved by a federal district judge, requires preliminary evaluations of prisoners to be conducted within 30 days of their transfer to the hospital.

title: I.B.M. Beats Earnings Expectations Again
description: For the second consecutive quarter, I.B.M. reported earnings and revenues yesterday that were better than most analysts expected. But the computer giant urged Wall Street to interpret the report as an indication of its strength, not a general rebound in technology spending.

title: New Scoring System in Early Stages
description: DALLAS, Jan. 16  The figure skating judging scandal at last year's Winter Olympics led to calls for an overhaul of the selection of judges and scoring, but a new points system aimed at eliminating bias is still in its developmental stage.

title: Judge Rules Mob Turncoat Can't Testify Against Gotti
description: A federal judge dealt prosecutors a major blow in their racketeering case against Peter Gotti yesterday by barring the testimony of a Mafia turncoat who was prepared to testify that Mr. Gotti is now the head of the Gambino crime family once led by his brother John.

title: WAR DISSENT IN CHICAGO
description: By a vote of 46 to 1, the Chicago City Council adopted a resolution opposing a unilateral, pre-emptive strike on Iraq, joining more than two dozen cities nationwide that have taken similar action. Saying that there was no evidence that Iraq posed an imminent threat or that an attack would result in an Iraqi democracy, the Council urged President Bush to resolve the situation through the United Nations. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: G.E. Posts 21% Drop in Profits, Matching Its Forecast
description: General Electric reported today that its profits fell 21 percent in the fourth quarter, matching the reduced forecast it made to investors in November, and the company reaffirmed its outlook for 2003.

title: Diocese Is Said to Depose Abuse Therapists
description: Victims of sexual abuse by priests and advocates for the victims complained today that lawyers for the Archdiocese of Boston had begun to depose therapists who are treating the victims and had subpoenaed records of the therapy sessions.

title: Wide Inquiry Into Lobbyists' Gifts and Payments to Legislators
description: After a Bronx assemblywoman's recent admission of taking bribes, prosecutors in Manhattan are looking into whether some lobbyists have failed to follow state laws in their efforts to curry favor with legislators, a senior law enforcement official said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Scaffolding Rules Reviewed
description: A City Council committee began deliberations yesterday over a measure that would require new training, certification and inspection standards for erecting and using certain scaffolds and sidewalk sheds at construction sites. The proposal comes after several poorly made and improperly used scaffolds have caused workers' injuries and deaths, officials said. The buildings commissioner, Patricia J. Lancaster, along with union and industry representatives, agreed with the intent of the proposal, but objected to some details. Councilwoman Madeline Provenzano, chairwoman of the Housing and Buildings Committee, was optimistic that the Council could fashion a compromise. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: 2 From Europe Make Brazil Phone Deal
description: Two major European phone companies, Telefnica of Spain and Portugal Telecom, said today that they would acquire the Brazilian mobile phone operator Tele Centro Oeste Celular Participaes for just over $1 billion, raising their share in one of the world's fastest-growing wireless markets above 50 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERIN, SALLY (NEE BARRIS)
description: HALPERIN-Sally (nee Barris). Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Ali Sanders and Elinor Sands, mother-in-law of Lewis Sanders and Ben Sands. Dear sister of Sylvia Loew, Molly Schoenbrun and George Barris. Loving grandmother of Steven, Justin, Alan and Caryn, Jay and Meredith, and great-grandmother of Joshua, Alec, Jack and Taylor Claire. Services were held Thursday, January 16, 2003.

title: Constellation to Buy Australian Winemaker
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 17  Constellation Brands of the U.S. and Australian winemaker BRL Hardy announced a merger agreement today to create the world's largest wine company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, SCHIRLEY B.
description: LEVY-Schirley B. Beloved wife of Marvin, devoted mother of Ilene and Steven. Services Sunday, January 19th, at 9:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Hangover Is the Least of His Problems
description: Most of the meager charms of the chaotic romantic farce ''A Guy Thing'' spring from the deft comic contortions of Hollywood's ultimate nerdy sidekick, Jason Lee. As Paul Morse, a Seattle ad salesman about to marry his boss's daughter, Karen (Selma Blair), this 32-year-old actor expands from the blandly goofy Keanu-manqu he often plays into a variation on the comic leading man Ben Stiller has made into a specialty.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Security Tapes Examined In Defacement Inquiry
description: A police task force investigating a rash of recent desecrations of religious statues is examining videotapes from security cameras at some of the sites, a police spokesman said yesterday. The desecrations occurred at two Catholic churches and a hospital here. Security cameras are also being checked for clues to recent vandalism of statues in civic areas. Meanwhile, the Anti-Defamation League offered a $20,000 reward for information leading to an arrest and conviction in the case of the religious statues. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Despite the Finery, This Babe's a Brute
description: A lot of gloriously bad dialogue is devoted to defining the charms of Lady Sylvia Allington, the heroine of ''Shanghai Moon,'' Charles Busch's happy, cockeyed new melodrama. Much is made of her beauty, her scandalous past, her opalescent skin, the mystery in her eyes. But what makes Sylvia so immensely appealing can really be summed up quite simply. The lady, you see, is a broad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETTERSEN, ELEANORE KENDALL
description: PETTERSEN-Eleanore Kendall. Beloved friend, mentor, renowned architect, founder of the architectural firm Design Collaborative and protege of Frank Lloyd Wright died at her home in Saddle River, NJ on January 15, 2003 at the age of 86. She was the first woman to open her own architectural practice in NJ and the first female president of the NJ State Board of Architects. A memorial service will be held in early February. Contributions in memory of Eleanore Pettersen should be sent to Altrusa Club of Bergen County, 246 Woodfield Road, Township of Washington, NJ 07676. For information, contact Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc, 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, New Jersey.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Of Course, It Might Bomb

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Archdiocese Reports On Abuse By Priests
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago released a report saying that in the last 40 years, 36 archdiocesan priests have been responsible for 55 instances of sexual abuse of minors. Of the 36 priests, 19 were removed, 9 have resigned and 8 are dead. Abusive priests cost the diocese $16.8 million in legal fees, victim assistance and settlements and therapy for victims and priests. Victims' advocates praised the release of information, but criticized the archdiocese for failing to name all the priests. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSNER, JOHN W.
description: RESSNER-John W. A native New Yorker and passionate patron of the arts, died on January 9 in the city he loved from complications following a stroke. He was 41. After graduating Princeton University Cum Laude in 1984 with a double major in Computer Sciences and Electrical Engineering, John received his MBA in Finance from the Columbia Business School in 1988. By day, John worked as Executive Vice President, Director of Research, and Portfolio Manager in the Fixed Income Division of the Capital Group Companies, an L.A.based group with offices in New York. He divided his time between the two cities and most enjoyed mentoring younger employees to preserve the Company's institutional memory. He served on the Boards of Capital Research Company and Capital International Research, Inc.
