Those who knew and loved John also felt his gentle but powerful passion for life in his pursuits outside of work. He served as Chairman of the Princeton Alumni Schools Committee in Manhattan for the five years prior to his death and graduated from the French Culinary Institute in 1994, where he trained in the art of pastry and chocolate-making under the direction of Jacques Torres. He was a devotee of amateur astronomy, physical training, the Mets and the Jets, and wine collecting and was an enthusiastic member of the WIGWAM Wine Group of Los Angeles. He generously supported many arts organizations and non-profit institutions including Princeton University, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Metropolitan Opera, American Museum of Natural History, Los Angeles Opera, Central Park Conservancy and Wildlife Conservation Society. John loved most dearly his wife Laura Bemben Ressner, his corgi Ollie, his mother Natalie G. Ressner, the Island of Nantucket and New York City. He is survived by all of them. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 18 at 2PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers or gifts, donations may be made in his name to the American Heart Association (800 - AHA - USA1), or to Princeton University through the John Ressner '84 Memorial Fund (send donations C/O Nancy Kalmikoff, Princeton University, P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, N.J. 08543-5357 and include the name of the fund.)

title: South Korea's President-Elect Rejects Use of Force Against North Korea
description: In a determined defense of engagement with North Korea, President-elect Roh Moo Hyun today all but ruled out the use of force against his isolated neighbor, which he said was seeking a way to open up to the world.

title: First, Unveil Schools Idea; Now, Turn It Into Reality
description: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg tries to bring a business model to government and reorganize the $12 billion New York City school system on a large scale, he is facing a huge logistical challenge.

title: Baby Ivy Blues (Maybe)
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TAKES $278 MILLION CHARGE
description: International Paper, the world's largest forest products company, said yesterday that it took an after-tax charge of $278 million in the fourth quarter to increase reserves used to settle claims that it made defective siding and roofing. The charge erased a profit of 58 cents a share, a spokeswoman said. International Paper has raised the reserve at least three times to pay customers who say the company's former Masonite unit made building products that swelled and fell apart when wet. The company now has $507 million to pay claims from three-class action lawsuits, which were settled in 1998 and 1999. The charge equals $450 million before taxes.

title: Excerpts From Administration Briefs on Michigan Affirmative Action
description: Following are excerpts from two briefs filed to the Supreme Court by the Justice Department yesterday in two Michigan affirmative action cases, Graz and Hamacher v. Bollinger and Grutter v. Bollinger:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Europe: Ban On Animal Tests For Cosmetics
description: The European Parliament passed a law this week that will ban the use of most animal tests to develop cosmetic products in the European Union by 2009. The vote marked the end of years of fierce debate over how strict to make rules on cosmetics testing. The ban will cover animal tests in Europe, and the law also calls for a ban on imports of cosmetics that have been tested on animals. As a concession to the cosmetics industry, though, the import ban will be delayed until 2013 for products for which no alternative to animal tests has yet been found. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Mayor Says No Layoffs For Police Now
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he did not expect to lay off police officers in the current round of budget cuts, but he held open the possibility of future layoffs if the police union did not agree to money-saving changes in work rules.

title: JONES APPAREL SAYS IT WILL LAY OFF 2,100 WORKERS
description: The Jones Apparel Group, maker of Jones New York clothing and Nine West shoes, said yesterday that it would lay off 2,100 people, or about 14 percent of its work force. The company will also convert some stores to a lower-price brand. It said costs from the layoffs and remodelings would reduce fourth-quarter profit by $15.9 million, or 11 cents a share. Excluding the expenses, profit rose to 48 to 50 cents a share, from 36 cents a year earlier, the treasurer, Thimio Sotos, said. Jones said 1,500 of the job cuts would be made in Mexico, where it is closing three plants. It is also closing warehouses in El Paso.

title: The Growing Clamor Over Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: News Corporation Concessions
description: The News Corporation has given new concessions to the European Commission in a bid for regulatory approval for its planned acquisition of the Italian pay TV channel Telepi, a spokeswoman for the company said. The European competition regulator will make a preliminary decision in the coming weeks on whether the concessions are enough to allay its concerns about the deal. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Pentagon Draws Up a 20-to-30-Year Antiterror Plan
description: The nation's top military officer has approved and sent to the armed services and the Pentagon's worldwide commands a comprehensive plan to combat terror that includes confronting countries that sponsor terrorism, senior defense officials say.

title: Is a Dividend Taxable? Investors Can't Tell
description: SHORT selling will become harder, and perhaps more expensive. Companies will no longer be able to use losses in one year to get refunds of taxes paid in prior years. Mutual funds may split into two camps -- those marketed to retirement accounts like 401(k)'s and those sold to investors who must pay taxes.

title: Japan's Monarchy, Once Godlike, Shows Its Frailty
description: The declaration was as refreshing as it was startling. Late last month, as Japan was working its way through year-end parties and holiday preparations, the Imperial Household Agency told the nation that the emperor, Akihito, had prostate cancer. Although the emperor, 69, is in no grave danger, he will undergo surgery this Saturday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ruling In Diamond Pact
description: The European Commission said it believed that a supply agreement between the South African diamond group De Beers and Alrosa, a rough-diamond producer owned by the Russian government, breaches European Union competition laws. Under the agreement, Alrosa sells half its output, worth 800 million euros annually, to De Beers. The companies informed the commission of the agreement last March. Europe's competition regulator said the arrangement amounts to an abuse of De Beers dominant position in the market for rough diamonds. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Phillies Sign Tyler Houston
description: The Phillies signed infielder Tyler Houston yesterday to a one-year, $1 million contract, eliminating another option at third base for the Mets. Houston hit .281 with 7 home runs and 40 runs batted in for the Brewers and Dodgers last season, playing mostly at third base. The Mets, who had not pursued Houston aggressively, need to replace Edgardo Alfonzo, who signed as a free agent with the Giants in December. They have the rookie Ty Wigginton as their current third baseman. Rafael Hermoso

title: I.M.F. Gives Argentina a Reprieve From Its Debt
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Argentina won a reprieve from the International Monetary Fund, postponing payment of a $1 billion debt payment due today in an agreement that improves the country's chances of pulling out of its depression.

title: Washington Post In Dow Jones Deal
description: The Wall Street Journal's editions in Europe and Asia will shortly begin daily publication of a small selection of news and opinion articles from The Washington Post as part of a deal announced yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WHIRLPOOL, Benton Harbor, Mich., the home appliance maker, said it would take a fourth-quarter after-tax charge of $43 million, or 62 cents a share, to reflect the reduced value of its aircraft lease assets after a bankruptcy filing by the UAL Corporation.

title: 2 Archaeologists, Robert Braidwood, 95, And His Wife, Linda Braidwood, 93, Die
description: Robert J. Braidwood, a University of Chicago archaeologist who uncovered evidence of the beginnings of agriculture and the subsequent rise of civilization in the Middle East, died on Wednesday in Chicago. He was 95.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for performances last Saturday night only.

title: He's Tightly Wrapped, She's About to Unravel
description: ''Kira's Reason: A Love Story'' was shown as part of last year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 6; full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The film, in Danish with English subtitles, opens today in Manhattan.

title: Your Wishes At a Fingertip
description: Audi's new A8 sedan responds to a light touch -- literally. The console on certain models of this aluminum-bodied luxury car incorporates a device that recognizes the driver's fingerprints. It then responds with an individual adjustment of several controls, like radio presets or the position of the seat, steering column and mirror. It can even adjust the automatic transmission -- to stay in low gears longer for high performance driving, for example, or to shift faster for fuel economy.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Las Vegas

title: San Francisco Journal; For Penguins, a New Will to Swim
description: This is a place with a weakness for social trends. So it is probably not surprising that the week's most riveting celebrities are 52 Magellanic penguins at the San Francisco Zoo, who have spent the last three and a half weeks swimming round and round a shallow pool in a mysterious marathon.

title: Republicans Wield New Control as Debate Begins on $390 Billion Spending Measure
description: Senate Republicans, seeking to push through a $390 billion appropriations bill that sticks closely to President Bush's demands to limit spending, defeated attempts today by Democrats to add as much as $5 billion for domestic security and $6 billion for education.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Europe: Chechen Rights Complaints In Court
description: The European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France, agreed to consider complaints by six former residents of Russia's Chechen Republic that Russian troops tortured them, killed family members or bombed civilians at the height of the Chechen conflict in 1999 and 2000. Another 114 similar complaints have been filed with the court, an arm of the Council of Europe, whose parliament has frequently criticized human-rights conditions in Chechnya. The chief human-rights official in Russia, which is a member of the council, dismissed the court's action as a political move aimed at showing ''how bad everything is in Russia.'' Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Off the Wagon
description: Picture a recovering alcoholic falling off the wagon. First he says he can handle a few drinks. Then, when his inebriation can't be denied, he insists it's only a temporary lapse. But eventually he turns mean. ''What's so great about being sober?'' he growls, reaching for another bottle.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: The Neediest Cases; Single Mother Sets Goals And Tries to Meet Them
description: For much of her childhood, Joanne Carpenter had to take care of herself -- she lived in public housing in the Bronx with four siblings, a mother who was addicted to drugs, and a father, she says, who wasn't often around.

title: Sun Posts Its Largest Quarterly Loss Ever
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., still reeling from the collapse of the Internet bubble and facing steep competitive pressures, posted its largest quarterly loss ever today.

title: Merrill Lynch brings back the bull for its latest campaign.
description: MERRILL LYNCH is trying to reinvigorate an old bull with some new tricks.

title: McDONALD'S PLANS TO CLOSE MORE RESTAURANTS
description: McDonald's said yesterday that it would close more underperforming restaurants in the United States and Japan. It did not say how many. The company also said it would retain its $1 Value Menu, which has increased business but decreased profit margins. James J. Cantalupo, the new chief executive, said that drastic changes at the company were not necessary but that small modifications like keeping restrooms cleaner and providing customer service were. Mr. Cantalupo also said that McDonald's would not provide quarterly earnings forecasts in 2003, but would focus on the long-term goal of rebuilding its business. In December, the company warned that it would not meet earnings expectations and would close 175 lagging restaurants. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: EBay Profits Rose Sharply In 4th Quarter
description: Benefiting from an aggressive campaign to position itself as a place to buy Christmas gifts, eBay posted sharply higher sales and profits in the fourth quarter of last year.

title: Shopping List | Winter-Proofing the Car
description: WHEN the weekend rolls around and you are ready to head for ski country, the last thing you want to hear on the radio is a winter storm advisory. This year, be prepared before you get stuck in icy weather. Pick up the newest crop of smartly designed emergency supplies; you'll wonder how you ever survived the cold without them. NANCY M. BETTER

title: Restoring Peace to Ivory Coast
description: West Africa is facing another disastrous civil war. Ivory Coast, once a beacon of relative stability and wealth, is split across the middle, convulsed by mercenary gang killings reminiscent of recent conflicts in neighboring Liberia and Sierra Leone. If the situation deteriorates further, the entire region could be imperiled. As the world's biggest cocoa producer, Ivory Coast remains central to West Africa's economy.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about a hostile bid by the Simon Property Group for the Taubman Centers shopping mall company misstated the age and size of a Taubman mall, the Beverly Center in Los Angeles. It opened in 1982, not 2001. It has 876,000 square feet of gross leasable area, not 1,341,000, and has about 160 stores, not 150.

title: STATES CAN LIMIT EMERGENCY ACCESS IN MEDICAID CASES
description: In a reversal, the Bush administration has ruled that managed care organizations can limit and restrict coverage of emergency services for poor people on Medicaid.

title: Houses Near Mountains: The Views Are What Matter
description: WHO -- Mark Conklin, 42, a former actor, and Noelle Strong, 40, a former speech pathologist.

title: The Islanders Meet Again, And Atone for Poor Effort
description: The Islanders were furious with themselves Wednesday night. They had talked about what they needed to do to beat the Devils, but the Devils shredded and embarrassed them. So the team met again today and decided to concentrate on defense tonight.

title: AOL's Top Job Goes to Veteran Of Time Warner
description: Richard D. Parsons, the chief executive of AOL Time Warner, was named yesterday to succeed Stephen M. Case as the company's chairman, the culmination of a surprising consolidation of Mr. Parson's power in the two years since AOL acquired Time Warner.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Martin Luther King's Birthday will be legally observed.

title: Congress's Messy Leftovers
description: The pain of Congress's budget inaction last year is about to strike home as the start of a long national hangover. The divided houses had opted for gridlock over compromise as revenues dwindled and the election loomed. Now the new G.O.P. majorities are belatedly rushing through a bill that slashes vital domestic spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIZLISH, NATHAN
description: MEIZLISH-Nathan, age 83, of Trumbull, CT., on January 16, 2003. Survived by his loving wife, Beatrice Reich Meizlish of Trumbull, CT.; his devoted son and daughter, Dr. Jay Meizlish of Weston, CT., Diane Reichlin of Jericho, NY.; cherished sister, Sara Reich of Queens, NY; also five grandchildren and one great - grandchild. Services Friday, January 17th, at 12:00 Noon, from The Abraham L. Green & Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Rd., Fairfield, CT.

title: Atlantic Sharks Found in Rapid Decline
description: Shark populations in the northwest Atlantic Ocean have plunged by more than half since scientists began keeping careful track in 1986, with marquee species like the hammerhead and the great white falling more than 75 percent, researchers are reporting.

title: Prusek Denies The Ducks
description: Martin Prusek came within 5 minutes 41 seconds of recording Ottawa's fourth straight shutout and Marian Hossa scored his 29th and 30th goals to lead the host Senators to a 3-1 victory over Anaheim last night.

title: Linebacker As Outlaw, Destined For Raiders
description: In the back of Al Davis's mind there always must have been been a picture of Bill Romanowski: a spitting, trash-talking madman -- to use Jerry Rice's words -- complete with a whiff of a drug scandal, craggy lines around the eyes and Clint Eastwood in his voice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHLIS, JAMES JOSEPH
description: ROCHLIS-James Joseph. On January 14, 2003. Beloved father of Susan and Jeffrey, proud grandfather of Jennifer, beloved brother of Theda Sannit, father by affection of Ellen Koerner, adoring and loving friend of Muriel Goldblatt. To the family and friends fortunate enough to have known him, a man of distinguished accomplish ment, character, integrity, generosity and honor. Service at 11:30 A.M. on Sunday, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to the charity of one's choice would be appreciated.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: POWER CABLE OPERATOR SEEKS APPROVAL Despite a legislative moratorium on projects in Long Island Sound, the owners of the disputed Cross-Sound Cable between Long Island and New Haven have made another attempt to activate the 24-mile underwater line. On Wednesday, the Cross-Sound Cable Company filed a request with Connecticut's Department of Environmental Protection asking for permission to turn on the cable. Charles H. Evans, a department director, said the agency had 45 days to respond to the request. A decision is not expected before next week, Mr. Evans said. (AP)

title: Assets Off Sharply At Magellan Fund
description: The Magellan Fund of Fidelity Investments ended last year with $56.8 billion in assets, the smallest total in five and a half years as declining stock prices shrank what was once the nation's largest mutual fund.

title: Poor Token, We Hardly Need Ye
description: IF you check out the letters NYC perched atop this column, you will notice that the N and the C serve as bookends to a larger Y. This is a typographical flourish devised long ago as a playful hommage to the old New York subway token, with its oversized cutout Y. (Hommage is French for rip-off, but it sounds much more pleasant, non?)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Price Plan Falters
description: The Indonesian government said that it would consider scrapping increases imposed Jan. 1 on prices for fuel and power in response to more than a week of protests around the country, less than a day after canceling similar price increases for telephone calls. The moves could complicate talks next week with international lenders. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: F.T.C. Inquiry On Fake Driving Permits
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it was seeking to shut six Internet operations that sold fraudulent international driving permits, many to immigrants who were looking for legitimate identification documents. The commission filed complaints in federal courts in California, Maryland, Massachusetts, New York and Washington, D.C. Officials said the operations used unsolicited e-mail messages and Web sites to promote the permits. An international driving permit translates a government-issued driver's license into different languages; it is not a substitute for an American license, or any other identification document issued in the United States. J. Howard Beales, director of consumer protection at the commission, said the fraudulent permits misled people with limited English proficiency. He said the permits were sold on the Internet for as much as $375, while the AAA and the American Automobile Touring Alliance charge $10.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDONESIA: PRICE PLAN FALTERS The Indonesian government said that it would consider scrapping increases imposed Jan. 1 on prices for fuel and power in response to more than a week of protests around the country, less than a day after canceling similar price increases for telephone calls. title: The Malpractice Insurance Crisis
description: President Bush called for a cap on medical malpractice awards yesterday as a way to control soaring premiums for medical liability insurance that have sparked protests from doctors in several states. But the president's plan seemed far too narrow to solve a multifaceted crisis, and the limit he suggested -- $250,000 for pain and suffering -- is too low. While changing some parts of the nation's tort system may be a good idea, it has to be part of larger, more fundamental reforms that will benefit -- and be fair to -- both doctors and patients.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about clues to obesity found by biologists in the genes of roundworms misstated the affiliation of the scientists in some copies. They were from Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard, not the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Boys Soldiering in an Army of Crime
description: In ''City of God,'' Fernando Meirelles's scorching anecdotal history of violence in the slums of Rio de Janeiro, a fretful boy with the cute nickname Steak & Fries (Darlan Cunha), begs for a gun that would certify his membership in one of two rival gangs. ''I smoke, I snort, I've killed and robbed,'' he pleads none too convincingly. ''I'm a man.''

description: The State of the Art column in Circuits yesterday, about innovative products on display at the 2003 Consumer Electronics Show, misstated the model number of a cellphone-camera due this year from Samsung. It is the v205, not the i205.

It would be March 1. (May 31 is the expiration date of the current contract.)

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  President Bush's nominee to head the new Homeland Security Department won quick approval from the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee today and was on his way to speedy confirmation by the full Senate, possibly by this evening.

description: For movie collectors there is fresh concern, especially among those clinging to their VCR's. As studios release more of their libraries on DVD, they are abandoning VHS.

title: In Berkeley, Strollers Find Art With Curb Appeal
description: ''WESTWARD the course of empire takes its way,'' wrote the 18th-century Irish philosopher Bishop George Berkeley, so the 19th-century founders of a little city directly across the bay from San Francisco, almost at the western extremity of the American Empire, chose to name it after him.

title: Relatives of Victims Of Snipers File Suit
description: Relatives of two people killed in the Washington-region sniper case filed a suit today against the manufacturer of the Bushmaster XM-15 rifle used in the shootings and the store where it was bought or stolen.

title: South Korea's President-Elect Seeks Peace Structure With U.S.
description: SEOUL  South Koreas President-elect Roh Moo Hyun proposed Friday the United States and South Korea establish "a peace structure on the Korean peninsula" that would "induce Pyongyang to reform and open up" to overtures to "resolve the North Korean nuclear issue through dialogue."

title: A Faltering German Economy Worsens
description: As Germans woke up to yet another dismal economic report today, a question echoed from the nation's finance ministry to its fashion industry: Can anything revive the German economy?

title: A Top Publisher Out in Random House Merger
description: Ann Godoff, one of the most influential publishers in the book industry, was forced out yesterday as president of the Random House Trade Group. Her division, home to authors like Salman Rushdie, E. L. Doctorow and William Styron, was merged with an imprint better known for mass market paperback editions of thrillers, romances and science fiction.

title: Champion Mortgage Seeks New Agency
description: The Champion Mortgage Company is placing its $20 million account in review after parting ways with the Martin Agency, which has handled the assignment since January 2001. In a related move, Martin is laying off 19 of the 332 employees at its headquarters in Richmond, Va., and its office in New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teenager Critically Injured By Gun
description: A 14-year-old Astoria boy was shot in the head and critically injured in his home, the authorities said yesterday. The police said they believed that he accidentally shot himself with his uncle's pistol at 12:10 p.m. Wednesday as he played with a friend. The boy, Santiago Echezervi, was taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center, where a spokeswoman said he was on life support yesterday. The gun, a .25-caliber pistol, was recovered, and his uncle, Kevin Chavez, 41, was charged with weapons violations, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Check Your Engine! And Never Mind Why
description: IT'S a tiny rectangle hidden among the gauges clustered on the dashboard near the steering wheel. When all is well, it is blank and quiescent. But then one day, unaccountably, it glows yellow and commands, ''Check engine.''

title: Government Strengthens Threat of Denying Water to California Farmers
description: The Bush administration said today that it might invoke a fundamental principle of Western water law to further reduce water from the Colorado River going to farmers in Southern California. Invoking that principle would allow the administration to contend that water is being wasted in the irrigation of farmland.

title: Miscellany
description: * Hasbro, Pawtucket, R.I., named Creative Artists Agency, Beverly Hills, Calif., to develop marketing tie-ins for the company in entertainment areas like movies, music and television. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Retailer To Focus On Luxury
description: The French retailer that controls the Gucci Group, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, said that it would sell noncore assets to continue with its strategy to focus on luxury goods, including Gucci. The company also said that revenue in 2002 fell 1.5 percent compared with a year earlier, to 27.4 billion euros. Since August, Pinault has raised more than 4 billion euros for the group by selling assets. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Israeli Gadfly Hopes to Separate Religion and State
description: Tommy Lapid, bare-knuckled commentator and crusader against state-subsidized Judaism, has emerged, grinning, as the biggest surprise of this most surprising campaign season -- the man who would be kingmaker in Israel.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: CITY COUNCIL URGED TO OPPOSE NUCLEAR PLANT City and state lawmakers, environmentalists and others opposed to the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan said yesterday that they would push for the City Council to join the movement to close the plant. About 30 local governments around the plant have passed resolutions calling for its closure because of safety concerns, but so far New York City has not joined the drive. Opponents of the plant said emergency plans failed to consider the jeopardy that city residents could face from a large release of radiation from the plant, 35 miles north of Midtown. The plant operator, the Entergy Corporation , says that it is safe and that such a large release is highly unlikely. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Media Coalition On AIDS Prevention
description: A coalition of media companies is introducing a public-awareness campaign meant to help slow the spread of H.I.V. and AIDS among African-Americans through testing and prevention. The campaign is called the Drumbeat Project and will employ advertising and articles. It will begin in February, which is Black History Month.

title: Now Berkeley Lets Words Of Anarchist Stay in Letter
description: Reversing a decision that had ignited a debate over freedom of expression, University of California officials have given the university's Emma Goldman Papers Project permission to send a fund-raising letter that includes quotations from Goldman about war and the suppression of free speech.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAVALLERO, CATHERINE
description: CAVALLERO-Catherine. Mom, ten years have passed and your loving ways are with me as strongly as if you were still here. You are forever in my heart.

title: Head of New York Fed Says He'll Retire
description: William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the second most important person in the Federal Reserve System, after the chairman, said today that he would retire in July.

title: Briefly Noted
description: GERMAN MISSILE LEASE TO ISRAEL Germany leased a pair of Patriot antimissile batteries to Israel yesterday as part of Israeli military preparations for a possible American-led war against Iraq. Israel plans to use the Patriot batteries to reinforce its own Arrow antimissile system because it is concerned that Iraq might attack it with biological or chemical warheads in response to an American-led invasion. The Patriot batteries will be shipped to Israel "as soon as possible," the ministry added. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Gangs of Rio de Janeiro
description: Youthful gang members wield their weapons in ''City of God,'' Fernando Meirelles's searing anecdotal history of violence in the slums of Rio de Janeiro. The movie takes its name from Cidade de Deus, a sprawling housing project built in the 1960's on the outskirts of Rio and left to fester in a poisonous stew of poverty, drugs and crime. The film, which depicts a shadowy slum teeming with armed adolescent posses, reminds us that the civilized society we take for granted is a luxury.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: SENATE PANEL APPROVES CHANGES AT D.M.V. Democrats and Republicans in the State Senate have resolved differences over Gov. James E. McGreevey's plan to overhaul the State Division of Motor Vehicles. The Senate Budget Committee approved the initiative yesterday after agreeing to raise vehicle registration fees by $7 instead of $8. Governor McGreevey had wanted an $8 increase to strengthen security and improve service at the D.M.V.'s 45 offices. Planned improvements include new computer software that can verify immigration status and other information about driver's license applicants. (AP)

title: Yanks Consider Japan Opener

title: In New York Taxis, Must-See TV
description: Television, having moved into every other facet of life, is taking over New York City taxicabs. In a yearlong pilot project undertaken by the Taxi and Limousine Commission, riders are being asked to evaluate several types of monitors with different kinds of programming in the back seats of thousands of cabs. One such monitor will allow passengers to look up information on city sights, while ignoring the real thing just outside the window. Others will carry entertainment, courtesy of the same folks who created those recordings of Elmo or a wrestling announcer reminding you to ask for a receipt.

title: PUBLIC APPROVAL OF BLOOMBERG JOB TAKES SHARP DROP
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's job approval rating dropped sharply in recent months as he moved to address the city's looming fiscal crisis, according to a New York Times Poll that found that for the first time since Mr. Bloomberg took office more than half of New Yorkers now disapprove of his handling of the job.

description: Three vastly different designs for the rebuilding of the World Trade Center, one emphasizing tall towers, another an excavated memorial site and a third a large public garden, appear to be receiving the greatest support in public discussions about the future of the site and of Lower Manhattan.

title: Greetings from ... Wyotana ''Home of the Second Home''
description: JAGGED mountain peaks pierce the clouds as their nine-million-year-old spires loom above a patch of delicate blue harebells still wet with morning dew. The lake below reflects the shifting colors of the rocks -- green at the bottom, gray melding to white at the top -- as they stretch toward the infinite blue sky. Off in the distance, a moose slowly makes its way to the water's edge. A bald eagle soars above, talons ready, looking for breakfast.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Hamrlik Is Only Islander Headed to All-Star Game
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 16  Islanders defenseman Roman Hamrlik was selected today to play in his third All-Star Game. Hamrlik was flattered, but was not sure why he was the only Islander picked.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There are periods of time when premiums stop going up, and then nobody's interested, then again we get a crisis and everybody says juries are terrible.''

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Methuselah Of Mice Dies
description: A dwarf mouse that was said to have surpassed all known records for mouse longevity died on Jan. 8 at a laboratory in Carbondale, Ill., Southern Illinois University said. The mouse, from a genetically engineered line, was 4 years, 11 months and 3 weeks old, and weighed 8 grams. Dr. Andrzej Bartke, a physiologist, said a normal life span for a mouse is 2 to 2 1/2 years, Dr. Bartke said the mouse probably owed his longevity to his lack of a gene that allows the body to respond to a growth hormone. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: President Asks Congress for Measures Against Frivolous Suits
description: Saying rapid increases in malpractice premiums are driving doctors out of some states and pushing up the cost of health care, President Bush said today that a big part of the solution was to curb what he called frivolous suits and put a $250,000 limit on pain and suffering awards by juries in cases that go to trial.

title: Lockheed Shift On Its Reporting
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation will begin reporting pension income and expenses separately to highlight the performance of its operating segments.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Hard-Liners Win More Seats
description: Pakistan's pro-military political party and a coalition of hard-line religious parties each won at least three additional parliamentary seats in by-elections held Wednesday, Pakistan's official news agency reported. The Pakistan People's Party, led by Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister, fared poorly and did not win any of the nine national assembly seats contested. The results appeared to mean a stronger hand in government for the religious parties, which won more seats than expected. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about large shortfalls in corporate pension plans misstated the amount that General Motors contributed to its United States plans in 2002. It was $4.8 billion; $2.6 billion was the amount in the fourth quarter.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Tuesday about the National Book Critics Circle Awards misidentified the publisher of ''Sleeping With the Dictionary'' by Harryette Mullen, which was nominated for poetry. It is the University of California Press, not Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: U.S. Says Michigan System Is Equivalent to a Quota
description: Lawyers for President Bush filed a pair of briefs with the Supreme Court tonight, saying the University of Michigan's admissions programs in both the undergraduate and law schools designed to increase minority enrollment were quota systems in disguise and were unconstitutional.

title: Profits at Samsung Electronics Rise but Disappoint Investors
description: Samsung Electronics reported today that its profits and sales rose last year, but it turned in such a disappointing fourth quarter that its stock declined for several hours after the figures were released in the morning.

title: INSPECTORS FIND EMPTY WARHEADS IN AN IRAQI DEPOT
description: United Nations weapons inspectors discovered 11 empty chemical warheads today at an ammunition storage depot in southern Iraq, while another team entered the homes of two Iraqi scientists unannounced, carting away documents.

title: Alinghi Demoralizes Oracle And Needs Just One Victory
description: When Larry Ellison's Oracle-BMW team won its America's Cup challenge series race on Thursday, the syndicate sent its fleet of 10 BMW 7 Series to the end of a wharf near Viaduct Harbor and had chauffeurs flash headlights and blow horns as its yacht came into port. Today those cars stayed in the garage.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Mobster Testifies On Former Premier
description: Giulio Andreotti, the former Italian prime minister whose conviction last year for ordering a mob assassination stunned the country, faced more charges involving alleged Mafia connections. A leading Mafia turncoat testified yesterday from a Milan prison that the seven-time prime minister protected the mob during his years at the helm of Italian government. Mr. Andreotti, 83, who was acquitted of the same charges nearly 10 years ago, called the day's proceedings ''squalid and useless'' and maintains that the Mafia is seeking revenge for crackdowns he made against them. In November, a Perugia appeals court sentenced Mr. Andreotti to 24 years in prison for his role in a 1974 murder, but he remains free while he appeals that case. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Challenge On U.S. Death Penalty
description: The International Court of Justice in The Hague will hold a hearing on Tuesday on Mexico's request that the United States commute the sentences of 51 Mexicans on death row. Mexico asserts that American officials failed to tell the condemned men of their right to consular assistance at the time of their arrests, which is guaranteed under international law. Three other Mexicans on death row were spared this week by the governor of Illinois. The court, an arm of the United Nations, has no way to enforce its decisions. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Alarms Without the Burglars Put Strain on Police Budgets
description: For police chiefs all over the nation these days, the biggest concern is often not drugs, not gangs, not burglars, but burglar alarms.

title: Owners Vote to Link All-Star Game to Series
description: Despite players' views to the contrary, baseball's club owners acted today on their conviction that linking the outcome of the All-Star Game to home-field advantage in the World Series would rejuvenate the All-Star Game.

title: Radio Ad Revenue Jumped in November
description: Advertising revenue for radio rose strongly again in November, posting a double-digit percentage gain for the third consecutive month, the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York reported yesterday. .

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Juniper Networks Posts Profit As Sales Rise
description: Juniper Networks, the No. 2 maker of equipment to direct Internet traffic, had a fourth-quarter profit of $8.45 million as expenses fell. Sales climbed 2.8 percent. Net income was 2 cents a diluted share, in contrast to a net loss of $5.13 million, or 2 cents a diluted share, in the year-earlier period, the company said yesterday. Revenue rose to $155.3 million from $151 million. First-quarter sales and profit, excluding certain items, will be unchanged from the preceding period, beating analysts' forecasts, the chief financial officer, Marcel Gani, said. Juniper, which trails Cisco Systems in sales of data-traffic routers, had losses in five of the six preceding quarters as customers slashed spending after overbuilding fiber optic networks. Shares of Juniper dropped 33 cents, to $8.90, in after-hours trading. Earlier, shares fell 46 cents, to $9.23, in regular trading.

title: Striving to Blend Mammon and Art
description: Ask Peter Olson, the chairman and chief executive of Random House, about Gina Centrello, the beneficiary of yesterday's corporate shake-up at the world's largest book publisher, and his enthusiasm is clear.

title: Why Your Waitron Can Serve Brunch but Not Linner
description: PREDICTING NEW WORDS

title: Utility Shareholders Demand Liability Disclosure
description: A group of shareholders that includes the Connecticut treasurer's office and several religious organizations have begun a campaign to compel the largest electric utilities in the nation to publish information about liabilities they might face because of their emission of gases that contribute to global warming.

title: When Drug Lords, not Trendoids, Reigned
description: Josh Pais's casual and engaging ''7th Street'' is, quite literally, a home movie -- a documentary about the East Village block where Mr. Pais, now an actor who has appeared in films as diverse as ''Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' (he was Raphael) and ''A Beautiful Mind,'' has lived since his childhood in the late 1960's.

title: Royal Philips Moves Account
description: In another large account shift after the decision by the Publicis Groupe to close D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Royal Philips Electronics in Amsterdam is moving accounts with billings estimated at $250 million from D'Arcy to a sibling, Leo Burnett Worldwide. The move, which had been expected, includes brands like the Sonicare toothbrush line, with billings estimated at $20 million to $30 million, and Norelco razors and shavers. Burnett will handle the accounts from its Chicago, London and Hong Kong offices.

title: Close to Perfection
description: When Geno Auriemma arrived 18 seasons ago to coach women's basketball at the University of Connecticut, his team played in the campus fieldhouse. Attendance at games topped out at 50 -- that is, if enough janitors could be coaxed inside to sit with families and friends of the players.

title: Convicted of Arranging His Wife's Murder, Rabbi Gets a Life Sentence
description: After two of his children and three of his in-laws denounced him as evil, cowardly and arrogant, a South Jersey rabbi was sentenced to life in prison today for hiring a friend to kill his wife.

title: Big Puerto Rico Bank Settles U.S. Money Laundering Case
description: The Justice Department said today that Banco Popular de Puerto Rico, the island's largest bank and a company with a major presence in the continental United States, would pay $21.6 million in penalties to settle accusations that it laundered millions of dollars in drug money. Under the agreement, the bank will avoid criminal prosecution.

title: Whistle-Blower Accuses Wyeth Of Tax Dodges
description: A former international executive for Wyeth, the big drug company, uncovered a worldwide practice of cheating foreign governments out of taxes, only to be demoted after notifying senior executives, according to documents in a state lawsuit he filed against the company.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Wednesday with an article about the hunt for three major figures from the war in Afghanistan was published in error. The picture -- between those of Osama bin Laden and Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, a former Afghan prime minister -- showed Mullah Malang, a former Afghan rebel commander, not the Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, KAY
description: BRODSKY-Kay. Died January 16, 2003. My beautiful beloved wife, a great mother and grandmother to our two children and four grandchildren. She was my best friend and the love of my life. I will miss her and love her 'til the day I die. Irv.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Plague Patient Slowly Recovering
description: A man with the bubonic plague is showing signs of improvement but remains hospitalized in New York City, officials said yesterday. The man, John Tull, is in critical but stable condition at Beth Israel Medical Center, where he was admitted Nov. 5. Mr. Tull and his wife, Lucinda Marker, apparently contracted the plague from infected fleas on their ranch in New Mexico, the authorities have said, but became ill during a trip to the city. Ms. Marker was released from the hospital in November. Mr. Tull, who has had both feet amputated because of the infection, was taken off a ventilator earlier this week, according to www.johnandlucinda.com, a Web site maintained by the couple's friends. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, ESTHER
description: FARBER-Esther. We mourn the untimely passing of our Vice President and beloved friend, Esther Farber. A founding Board member, Esther was a woman of great strength and courage, dignity and elegance. She was a skilled writer, editor and publicist and a committed Orthodox feminist for over three decades. We shall miss her sound judgment and wise counsel, her thoughtfulness and kindness. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband, Charles Gold, and sons, David, Steven and Rabbi Seth Farber. Blu Greenberg, President Robin Bodner, Exec. Dir. Board of Directors Jewish Orthodox Feminist Alliance

description: Jim Phelan of Mount St. Mary's in Emmitsburg, Md., who has coached more games than anyone in college basketball history, will retire in March after completing his 49th season at the university.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ClearOne Falls On S.E.C. Complaint
description: Shares of ClearOne Communications fell about 43 percent after the Securities and Exchange Commission said that the company, the maker of videoconferencing products, inflated revenue by selling more products to distributors than could be sold to customers. Shares of the company, which is based in Salt Lake City, dropped $1.16, to $1.54. ClearOne's audit committee was already investigating the complaint when the S.E.C. filed suit, and the company says that many of the charges are based on the testimony of a ''disgruntled employee'' and require ''substantial verification.'' The complaint accuses the company and some executives of inflating revenue, net income and accounts receivable through improper revenue recognition in 2001 through Sept. 30, 2002.

title: Drive, They Said, and We Did
description: MY 14-year-old twin girls have become incredibly facile with a map, as long as I promise not to yell at them while they are staring at one.

title: Pedigreed Feast of Winter Is Back at the Armory
description: The Winter Antiques Show, an enticing consumerama whose goods range from massive pedigreed furniture to petite pocket tchotchkes, is back in its element at the Seventh Regiment Armory after last year's switch to the Hilton Hotel. And its officials and organizers seem much, much happier.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Just when the last Ralph Lauren Navajo blanket has been mothballed, along comes Agave, a heartfelt if wayward tribute to the colors, textures and food of the American Southwest. It's a handsome restaurant, with smooth adobe walls, American Indian artifacts on those walls and a subdued, flickering light provided by white votive candles.

title: A Racehorse Remembered In Pottery
description: In 1839 an English racehorse named Dunstan won the Champagne Stakes at the Pottery Racecourse in Staffordshire, England. The following year, the dappled gray colt won the Wolverhampton St. Leger, a race for 3-year-olds, along with three other races. Dunstan, owned by Mr. T. Critchley, was a local champion and was soon celebrated in clay, along with his jockey, G. Whitehouse. He became a popular Staffordshire figure.

description: President-elect Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea today hailed the ''pivotal'' role of foreign investment in building ''the hub economy of Northeast Asia,'' in a speech intended to ease fears abroad about anti-Americanism in his country, which is Asia's third-largest economy.

description: The Vatican issued guidelines for Roman Catholic politicians today that underlined the church's opposition to abortion, euthanasia and same-sex marriage and told Catholics not to promote laws that favor those practices.

title: In This Mind's Dcor, Sex Is No Love Seat
description: The dcor has changed a bit since this time last year. There are playing cards on the walls now and an army of dolls with long golden curls on the ceiling. But in many ways, the old place looks the same -- creepy, disorienting and astonishingly familiar.

title: White House Intensifies Criticism of Iraq Over Warheads
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  The White House today called the discovery of 11 empty chemical-weapon warheads in an Iraqi ammunition storage depot "troubling and serious" and said it was another indication that President Saddam Hussein was ignoring his "obligation to disarm."

title: The Makeover
description: Wearing a gold robe and matching cap, Muammar el-Qaddafi -- ''the Leader,'' as he is universally referred to in Libya -- paces a well-worn strip of land beside his tent. He stares down at the bare earth as he walks, stopping occasionally to gaze up into the surrounding trees. His is the preoccupied walk of a philosopher thinking deep thoughts, or of an actor memorizing his lines.

description: These may be lean times for investment banks, but at least one has found itself in the embarrassing position of having more business than it can properly handle.

title: Muted Call in Race Case
description: As an example of political stage-management, the Bush administration's handling of its Supreme Court brief in the Michigan affirmative action case was masterly, impressive even by the standards of a White House unusually skilled at spin control.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Compensation For Tortured Man
description: A court ordered the Interior Ministry to pay more than $26,000 in compensation to an Egyptian merchant who was held and tortured for nine days in 1996, and it ordered a disciplinary trial for the Alexandria police officers who were involved. The court found that the officers failed to submit a detention order or a legal reason for the man's detention. In 2001, 12,478 people were held in prolonged detention in Egypt without trial, the Egyptian Organization for Human Rights' latest report said. Samar Aboul-Fotouh (NYT)

description: With doctors across the country protesting the cost of malpractice insurance, President Bush is making a renewed push for strict limits on the jury awards he blames for skyrocketing premiums.

title: 1,800 Connecticut Workers Today Face Another Round of Layoffs
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 16  Friday will be the last day on the job for 1,800 state employees, a sweeping layoff that Gov. John G. Rowland had hoped could be averted through union concessions when he proposed it last month to help Connecticut close its huge budget gap.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Harry Potter And The Clergy's Ire
description: Leading Orthodox prelates in Cyprus have called for a ban on the blockbuster film ''Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets,'' saying it casts a demonic spell on children and promotes sorcery and witchcraft. The campaign, led by Bishop Chrysostomos of Paphos, eastern Cyprus, is expected to dominate a meeting of the church's highest body, the Holy Synod, in February. The film has drawn full houses in Cyprus theaters and sold more than 10,000 tickets in its first weekend. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

description: The behavior of chukar partridge chicks, which can run straight up the side of a hay bale or a tree while flapping their wings, may offer a new window on the origin of flight in birds.

description: To the Editor:

title: W.N.B.A. and Casino In Talks for a Team
description: The Mohegan tribe needs entertainment to fill its arena and lure customers to its casino in southeastern Connecticut, and the struggling Women's National Basketball Association needs to find areas that might support a team. The two objectives appear ready to unite in the unlikely marriage of a casino and a professional sports league.

title: Increase in Electronic Attacks Leads to Warning on Iraqi Hackers and U.S. Safety
description: Intelligence officials are concerned that a recent rise in electronic attacks against government and military computer networks in the United States may be the work of pro-Iraqi hackers and could signal a ''potential crisis'' in national security, according to a classified F.B.I. assessment.

title: Court Bars Mexican Trucks Pending a Study on Impact
description: A federal appeals court yesterday blocked President Bush's plans to open all American highways to Mexican trucks, ruling that the administration could not open the roads until it conducted a study of how the trucks would affect the environment.

title: Russian TV Network Fires American Executive
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17  The American financier who runs Russia's often-embattled NTV television network said today that he had been dismissed by the network's state-controlled owner, the latest chapter in a media drama sometimes seen as an indicator of this nation's press freedom.

description: FAMILY life, at least in my house, often requires a voice-over to add a sense of drama or comedy, as the case may be, to the exploits of children and dogs.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: STOCK TRADE INVESTIGATION Prosecutors in Kiel, Germany, are investigating Gerhard Schmid, the founder of the troubled wireless company MobilCom for illegal stock transactions, they said. Mr. Schmid, left, who was ousted in June as MobilCom's chairman and was forced five months later to hand over his stake in the company to a trustee, is being investigated for paying $75 million to his wife as part of a stock option plan in 2001, said a prosecutor, Uwe Wick.  (AP)

title: Residential Real Estate; Real Estate Brokerage Firms Now Have to Share New Listings
description: In a significant shift toward opening the Manhattan marketplace, residential brokerage firms belonging to the Real Estate Board of New York are being required to share new listings with all other members within three days.

title: What a Well-Dressed Marsupial Wears
description: ''Kangaroo Jack'' concerns a pair of hapless fellows from Brooklyn who set off for Australia with $50,000 of a Mafioso's money, which is promptly snatched by a marsupial, setting in motion all manner of tiresome high jinks. Actually, the hectic, pointless motion of this interracial buddy action kiddie comedy -- a kind of eager younger brother to the cruder, more violent ''National Security,'' which also opens today nationwide (review, Page 13) -- begins well before the kangaroo arrives on the scene. Early on, there is a squealing car chase through someplace supposed to be Brooklyn, during which many pounds of fish and several television sets fall from trucks.

title: M.T.A. Faces Bigger Woes Linked to Debt, Study Says
description: The financial problems of the city's subway and bus system over the next two years do not appear nearly as dire as transit officials have portrayed them, according to an analysis released yesterday by the city's Independent Budget Office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, HANNI
description: KRAUS-Hanni, 83. Of New York City. On January 14, 2003 after a brief illness. Loving wife of the late Hans P. Kraus. Beloved mother of Mary Ann Folter, Barbara Gstalder, Eveline Rauber, Susan Nakamura and Hans P. Kraus, Jr. She is also survived by her sister Dorit Cohn, twelve grandchildren and two great-grancchildren. She was an active member of the International Association of Bibliophiles. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Friday, January 17 at 1:30PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Kraus Fund at the Beinecke Rare Book Library at Yale University, New Haven, CT.

title: Reflections of Byzantium, Where East Meets West
description: I went to Mount Athos -- Hagion Oros, the Holy Mountain -- in Greece in 1982, and I went the way everyone does: very slowly. From New York I wrote to the Greek Foreign Ministry asking permission to visit this great monastic center, isolated on a squared-off peninsula in the northern Aegean. In Athens, I picked up my pass for a four-day stay, then took a long bus ride to Thessalonika, and another to the port town of Ouranopolis.

title: A Second U.S.O.C. Officer Resigns
description: The ethics compliance officer of the United States Olympic Committee has resigned, raising new questions about how Lloyd D. Ward, the committee's chief executive, avoided punishment this week for attempting to help his brother's business venture involving the Pan American Games this year in the Dominican Republic.

title: Some Parents Fear Weaker Role in Centralized Schools
description: Some New York City parents lashed out yesterday at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan for involving them in school decision-making under a newly centralized system, saying they wanted more than an advisory role.

title: New Jersey Officials Present Map Showing Battlefields in New Fight on Sprawl
description: State officials, beginning the anti-sprawl campaign that Gov. James E. McGreevey announced this week, today presented a map of the state that sketches out preliminary plans for controlling development.

title: Thomas May Earn Star Status
description: Knicks Coach Don Chaney has not had a lot to brag about this season, but he would like to lay claim to this: Kurt Thomas became an All-Star under his watch. Now he need only convince his fellow coaches.

title: Plan to Offer Free Electronic Tax Filing
description: Seventeen tax preparation companies will offer free electronic tax filing under an agreement announced today that would keep the government out of the software business.

title: Pollution Linked to Low Birth Weights in African-Americans
description: Pollutants in the air in Upper Manhattan and the South Bronx have been linked to lower birth weights and smaller skulls in African-American babies, according to a long-term study on the unusually high rate of childhood asthma in those areas.

title: Lottery Numbers
36 Hours | Fort Myers, Fla.
description: WITHIN 24 hours of arriving in Fort Myers in March 1885, Thomas Edison bought 13 acres on the Caloosahatchee River, and before long he was planting palm trees along the dirt road between downtown and his spread. The road is now McGregor Boulevard, lined with thousands of royal palms (not all courtesy of Edison) and congested in tourist season, and Fort Myers is still seducing Northerners. Now a mally, sprawly city of 48,000, spawning suburban housing developments, it offers not only warmth and sunshine, but boating, beaches, spring-training Minnesota Twins and Boston Red Sox games, and a pedestrian-friendly downtown historic district with restored buildings and diet-busting restaurants. There are frequent downtown festivals, where retirees can impress their visiting families with their new outdoor lifestyle and rub shoulders with tourists and longtime Floridians. The largest is the Festival of Light, celebrating Edison's bulb, which began last week and runs through Feb. 15. For its big parade (Feb. 15 this year), people reserve viewing spots a week in advance along Cleveland Avenue by positioning their folding chairs, which no one disturbs. LINDA SALISBURY

Beloved youngest daughter of Joon Young and In Ok of the Bronx. One and only sister, in spirit and blood, always of Chisun. Cherished niece and cousin of many in Seoul, Beijing, New York, and New Jersey. Respected and celebrated friend of many. A fiercely principled, compassionate, loyal, and loving young woman. Umma, Apba, and Unnie look forward to reuniting with her soon and love her always. title: ABBOTT LABS SAYS PROMOTION COSTS TO CUT INTO '03 PROFIT
description: Abbott Laboratories expects the cost of promoting a new rheumatoid arthritis treatment to reduce profit growth this year, after a 2.2 percent gain in the fourth quarter. Net income in the quarter rose to $627.1 million, or 40 cents a share, from $613.6 million, or 39 cents, a year earlier. Sales increased 8.9 percent, to $4.8 billion. Fourth-quarter pharmaceutical sales in the United States rose 14 percent. The company said it expected to earn 50 to 52 cents a share in the first quarter, lower than the 57 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The company expects to earn $2.20 to $2.25 a share this year, compared with the $2.26 First Call estimate.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Last Day Of Work For 1,800
description: Today will be the last day on the job for 1,800 state employees, a sweeping layoff that Gov. John G. Rowland had hoped could be averted through union concessions when he proposed it last month to help Connecticut close its huge budget gap. But the labor talks have stalled, as have budget negotiations between Mr. Rowland and the General Assembly. And the governor now says that as many as 1,000 more state workers could face layoffs if the unions do not accept his package of concessions. Today's layoffs -- the last of the 2,800 that Mr. Rowland ordered in December -- mean that about 5 percent of the staff members of each state agency and department have been let go. The layoffs will save $120 million, said Christopher Cooper, the governor's spokesman, far short of the $550 million in concessions over three years Mr. Rowland has requested.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: December Sales Fall
description: Department store sales in the Tokyo area, a crucial indicator of private spending, fell 5.3 percent in December from the month a year ago. The decline suggests that consumer demand, which makes up 55 percent of the economy, will detract from growth. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Stewart Signs With D.C. United
description: The United States national team midfielder Earnie Stewart, who has played in the last three World Cups, has signed with Major League Soccer and will play for D.C. United after 14 years in Dutch professional leagues, D.C. United announced. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIAK, JOSEPH MICHAEL
description: SPIAK-Joseph Michael, 46, of Acton, MA, by airplane accident in Charlotte, NC. January 8. Husband of Jill (Langston). Father of Michael and Kristin Spiak, both of Acton. Son of Anthony and Palavia (Kawola) Spiak of Latham, New York. Brother of Marybeth Panock and her husband Richard of Lexington, Matthew and his wife Stephanie, and Thomas, all of Latham, New York. Also survived by father-in-law, Reuel Langston and his wife Madeline of Latham, NY, sister-in-law Barbara Langston and her husband Paul Rowe of Lexington and his nieces and nephews, Megan Spiak, Joel and Craig Panock, and Matthew Spiak. In lieu of flowers, an educational trust fund has been established at Hudson River Bank & Trust Co., 767 New Loudon Road, Latham, NY Attention: John Delory. Donations will be made to ''The Children of Joseph Spiak.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Broadband Purchase Scrapped
description: Hanaro Telecom no longer plans to take over Korea Thrunet. Korea's second-biggest broadband provider after Korea Telecom, Hanaro withdrew from a deal to buy 72 percent of the company for $160 million, saying Thrunet's short-term financial burden was too significant in relation to the benefits of a deal. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Scowls and Rants Facing Mugs and Riffs
description: Steve Zahn and Martin Lawrence play a mismatched pair of security guards in ''National Security,'' an interracial buddy action comedy opening nationwide today. As such relationships go, theirs is admirably egalitarian. They take turns driving, shooting guns and punching each other in the face.

title: Michigan's Means to Campus Diversity Are Among Many in Effect From Coast to Coast
description: The extra points that the University of Michigan awards to black, Hispanic and American Indian applicants for undergraduate admission are but one of many ways that selective public and private universities give preference to minority high school students.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Loss For Chip Maker
description: One of the world's largest makers of semiconductor equipment, ASML Holding, reported a second-half loss of 110 million euros, considerably less than the 383 million euros the company lost a year earlier. Net sales in the second half of 2002 nearly doubled, to 1.17 billion euros, but orders have fallen by 30 percent since June. ASML said it was able to pare its losses through cost-cutting measures, recently announcing plans to cut 20 percent of its work force. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: In Training War Leaders, the Lessons From Poetry
description: THE cadets at West Point, bundled up against the wind that whips across the snowy campus, talk of war. They discuss the news from recent graduates who have been in Afghanistan. They hear from others stationed in the Persian Gulf. And they wait. Soon it may be their turn, perhaps in Iraq, perhaps beyond.

title: Vuillard the Spectator, Poised at Life's Windows
description: THE douard Vuillard show opening Sunday at the National Gallery of Art here, frequently gorgeous, nonetheless almost buries the French painter with love. Lavish, panoramic, poorly edited and finally exhausting, it has the honorable air of an official retrospective put together over many years by a committee, with some fresh information but too many pictures that don't show this erratic, endearing genius at his best. You recognize his greatness in the early works -- how could you not? -- but by the end you may also feel a little sorry for him.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Payments To Black Universities
description: The state Senate voted to release $7.2 million for two historically black universities in connection with a class-action desegregation case settled by the state last February. If signed by the governor, the payment will go to Alcorn State and Mississippi Valley State. The case stemmed from a 1975 lawsuit that contended the state's historically black universities had far worse facilities and financing than the state's white colleges.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Judge Dismisses 'Bumfights' Felony Charges
description: Four men charged with enticing homeless men to batter one another and then selling videos of the fights had all felony charges against them dismissed or reduced to misdemeanors. The video, ''Bumfights,'' which was promoted by Howard Stern on his radio show, has sold about 300,000 copies at $20 each, the authorities said. Judge Larrie Brainard of Superior Court in El Cajon called the filmmakers' actions ''morally repugnant'' but ruled that prosecutors had not produced sufficient evidence of a felony by the men, Daniel Tanner, 21, left, Zachary Bubeck, 25, Ryan McPherson, 19, and Michael Slyman, 21. The four were ordered to stand trial Feb. 5 on one misdemeanor charge of conspiracy to stage an illegal fight; three face a charge of conspiracy to commit a battery, also a misdemeanor. Rick Lyman (NYT)

description: It began with faculty senates at large universities on the West Coast, upset over $80 million expansions of college football stadiums and $2 million coaches' salaries. Then faculties at universities in the Big Ten and other major conferences also started voting to restrain the growth of big-time college sports.

title: Head of Downtown Rebuilding Agency to Leave
description: Louis R. Tomson, the president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, who shepherded the rebuilding process through a sometimes chaotic first year, will resign from the agency effective the end of February, state officials said yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: COURT SAYS APOTEX DRUG WOULDN'T VIOLATE PFIZER PATENT
description: A low-cost Apotex drug for treating epilepsy would not infringe a Pfizer patent on the drug's main ingredient, a federal appeals court said yesterday, upholding a lower court ruling. The patent covers a method of using gabapentin, the main ingredient in the Pfizer epilepsy drug Neurontin, to treat other diseases like Alzheimer's. The ruling was issued by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington. Neurontin generated $1.6 billion in sales for Pfizer for the first nine months of 2002. Pfizer has another patent in dispute with Apotex and other generic drug makers involving a composition that Pfizer says makes the drug safer. Analysts say that patent dispute, in district court in New Jersey, is the crucial case for Pfizer.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rock and Jazz Intertwine In a Hot-and-Cool Concert
description: Rock 'n' roll and jazz share so many of the same artistic bloodlines that it's remarkable the two don't fuse more often into the kind of inspired marriage of visceral clout and intellectual savvy conjured by the singer, songwriter and saxophonist Curtis Stigers.

title: Political Fervor of Iranian Clerics Begins to Ebb
description: While recent pro-democracy demonstrations on Iranian campuses have attracted widespread attention, a potentially more explosive movement has quietly been taking shape here in one of the leading religious centers of the Islamic world. The Shiite clergy who a generation ago called for the establishment of a fundamentalist, religious government are having second thoughts. Religion, many are now saying, belongs in the mosque.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, OTTO L.
description: WALTER - Otto L. The Trustees and Staff of the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies (AICGS) are deeply saddened by the death of its longtime supporter and friend, Dr. Otto L. Walter. Dr. Walter joined the Institute in 1994 as a Trustee to continue his lifelong support of the GermanAmerican relationship. Through his personal engagement and experience in the field of German-American relations, his contribution to the Institute and its mission has been invaluable. He will be greatly missed. Our deepest sympathies go out to his wife and family. The AICGS Board of Trustees

title: Losing Job and Girlfriend But Gaining Burglar Buddy
description: James Kirkwood Jr., who died in 1989, will probably be best remembered for the book of ''A Chorus Line,'' but he also wrote several other novels and plays about the agonies of a show business life -- a subject he knew from childhood on, being the son of the silent film stars James Kirkwood and Lila Lee.

title: U.N. Report Shows Growing Poverty Among European Gypsies
description: Poverty has worsened for millions of Gypsies across Central and Eastern Europe since Communism collapsed a decade ago, and many now live in conditions resembling those of poor sub-Saharan Africa, the United Nations said in a report published today.

title: Asian allies reluctant to push North Korea to the brink of war : Envoy sees long slog to a deal with Pyongyang
description: SEOUL:  The United States and its allies appeared resigned Thursday to a prolonged struggle to come to terms with North Korea after Pyongyang rejected the enticement by President George W. Bush of aid in return for abandonment of its nuclear weapons program.

description: The Justice Department yesterday expanded a registration program for visitors, most of them from Muslim and Arab nations, to include men from Bangladesh, Egypt, Indonesia, Jordan and Kuwait.

title: ICAP AGREES TO PAY $290 MILLION FOR BROKERTEC GLOBAL
description: ICAP P.L.C., the world's largest interbank securities brokerage firm, said yesterday that it was buying BrokerTec Global for about 181 million ($290 million) in stock to gain a foothold in electronic bond trading. ICAP, which acts as a wholesaler for banks in buying and selling derivatives, bonds and currencies, is expanding as demand for such products grows. BrokerTec is owned by 14 securities firms, including Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank.

title: Sports of The Times; Not Being Bill Walsh Is a Burden
description: SOME of the San Francisco 49ers' players never quite got used to the scene, squirming in their seats whenever it occurred. It would begin with Coach Steve Mariucci's delivering one of his riveting, often emotional speeches on a Friday, hours before their Sunday game. That was the part players liked -- Mariucci could carry a room. This was the part some of them did not understand: Following his speech sometimes, Mariucci would then turn the meeting over to another man, Bill Walsh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, CORNELIA M.
description: ROBERTS-Cornelia M. On January 14, 2003 at age 100. Wife of the late William Bryce Roberts, born in Vienna, Austria 1902. Dear friend, excellent equestrian and American patriot. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 18 at 10AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Red Cross.

title: Clemency Without Clarity
description: Before he left office on Monday, Gov. George Ryan of Illinois, a longtime supporter of capital punishment, emptied the state's death row by pardoning four condemned men and commuting the sentences of the remaining 167 prisoners. Some are calling this an act of tremendous bravery, while prosecutors and the families of victims claim justice was thwarted. Many others believe he should have acted in the most questionable cases without providing leniency to some of the state's most brutal and unrepentant murderers.

description: Frustration rose like steam from the crowd of commuters, huddled impotently together at Waterloo Station. They were there; their trains were not.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Decline In Auto Sales Forecast
description: Isuzu Motors, the struggling maker of trucks and cars, said it expected global sales to fall by 20 percent this year as the company phased out production of its pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles. The company expects a 31 percent slide in exports and a 13 percent rise in domestic sales. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: For Debuts, A Charge Of Emotion
description: There is nothing like a gifted newcomer to add spark, even a competitive edge, to a dance season. Sofiane Sylve, the New York City Ballet's French guest, continues to light up her surroundings with energy and projection. Catalyst or not, she joined a cascade of lively debuts at the New York State Theater on Tuesday.

title: Venezuela's President Reasserts Hard Line Against Strikers
description: Brushing aside proposals to end the seven-week-old strike that has crippled his country's economy, President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela said tonight that he was fully confident he would vanquish the opponents demanding his resignation.
