title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELOCK, JAMES T.S.
description: WHEELOCK - James T.S. Died on December 28 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York of complications from leukemia, for which he had undergone a bone-marrow transplant in March. Born in Wilmington, Delaware, in 1943, Mr. Wheelock attended the Tower Hill School and the Canterbury School, New Milford. He graduated Magna Cum Laude from Yale University in 1965, receiving a B.A. in Italian Studies. Fluent in three languages, he had a passionate interest in Italian medieval and humanist literature, in particular Dante and Boccaccio, which inspired an impressive career as a scholar. In 1971 he received a Ph.D. from Columbia University, where he received the Woodbridge Distinguished Fellowship and a Fulbright Fellowship. After living in Milan, Mr. Wheelock joined the faculty of the University of Colorado, Boulder, and became the youngest department chair in the university's history. In 1980 he made a significant shift in his career, leaving academia to focus on real estate development, in particular historic preservation in the Capitol Hill section of Denver where he lived. Mr. Wheelock was also a founding board member of Opera Colorado and co-founder and board member of the Colorado Wagner Society. Mr. Wheelock returned to New York in 1986. After years of full-time volunteer work at the GMHC, he became Assistant Director of the Legal Department and then director of both Intake and Client Services. In 1996 he began JTSW Consulting, specializing in data management for not-for-profit medical organizations. Among his clients was the AIDS Institute of the New York State Department of Health, for which he developed, under the federal Ryan White CARE Act, an electronic records system to improve medical care and treatment for children with AIDS. The system is currently being used throughout New York State and Kenya. His clients also included The League for the Hard of Hearing and the Medicare Rights Center. In addition to Thomas Padon, his partner of eighteen years, Mr. Wheelock is survived by his son, James T.S. Wheelock, Jr. (from his former marriage to Susan Pettibone), and granddaughter, Madeleine James Wheelock, of Brooklyn. He is also survived by his sister, Catharine Johnstone of Greenville, DE, and three brothers: C. Webster Wheelock of New York; Joseph A. Wheelock, Jr., of Williamstown; and Thomas Wheelock of St. Louis. A memorial service will be held in New York on February 8. Donations to further bonemarrow transplant research may be made in his name to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: The Cost Of Wireless
description: Japan's largest wireless service provider, NTT DoCoMo, will share half of the cost of developing handsets for its high-speed third-generation phones. The service, which has attracted less than half the subscribers anticipated, has proved a burden to handset makers like the NEC Corporation and others who expected to sell more phones. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: As Worries Over Iraq War Rise, So Does the Price of Crude Oil
description: Oil prices rose to two-year highs today, building on a weeklong surge after an emergency OPEC decision to raise output failed to assuage growing fears over a possible war in Iraq.

title: Champion Mortgage Seeks New Agency
description: The Champion Mortgage Company is placing its $20 million account in review after parting ways with the Martin Agency, which has handled the assignment since January 2001. In a related move, Martin is laying off 19 of the 332 employees at its headquarters in Richmond, Va., and its office in New York.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about meetings between James A. Kelly, the United States envoy, and South Korea's president-elect, Roh Moo Hyun, misstated the location. It was Mr. Roh's office, not at the Blue House, the presidential mansion.

description: ALTEMUS-Gertrude Mercer ''Gipsey'', on January 8, 2003. Residence: 1276 Green End Ave, Middletown, R.I. Ms Altemus is survived by her five children: Michael HuttenCzapski, Lowie Crisp, Bondi Macomber, Sarah Vanderveer and Stuyvie Vanderveer. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to the Whitehall Committee, Altemus Orchard Fund, 21 Bull St., Newport, R.I. 02840. Information and directions: www.memorialfuneralhome.com

description: The space shuttle Columbia roared off into a picture-perfect sky today to begin a 16-day research mission with a crew that includes the first astronaut from Israel.

title: A Fearless Dawkins Is the Eagles' Heavy Hitter
description: There must be fear somewhere inside Eagles safety Brian Dawkins. He says there is not. But fear dwells within the National Football League. Fear is why wide receivers pull their arms closer to their bodies when running pass routes over the middle. Fear is what causes tacklers to slow just before collisions.

description: For movie collectors there is fresh concern, especially among those clinging to their VCR's. As studios release more of their libraries on DVD, they are abandoning VHS.

description: Barton Biggs, for nearly three decades the leading investment strategist at Morgan Stanley, said yesterday that he would retire from the firm and start a hedge fund.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Union Audit Finds Diversion Of $5 Million
description: An audit by the American Federation of Teachers has found that more than $5 million was diverted from an affiliate, the Washington Teachers' Union, over the last seven years. A suit by the national union says three former officials defrauded the union and seeks to recover the money. The three, the president, Barbara A. Bullock; her assistant, Gwendolyn M. Hemphill; and the treasurer, James O. Baxter II, were asked to resign in October.

title: New York Reaches Deal to End 20-Year Legal Fight on Homeless
description: New York City and lawyers representing the homeless said they took an extraordinary first step yesterday toward ending a 20-year-old lawsuit over the rights of homeless families. In the deal, they agreed to create an independent panel with broad powers to help the city shape its long-range policy for such families.

title: Fresh Eyes See the Light
description: For 20 years, the city and lawyers for homeless families locked horns in court, bitterly at times, in a tussle to shape city policy. Yesterday, not long after a brutal summer when homeless advocates sued to cite the city's homeless commissioner for contempt, the two sides announced an unlikely truce.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: PHONE STAKE SOLD The French construction and communications group Bouygues said it would buy E.ON's 16 percent stake in Bouygues Telecom for about 1.1 billion euros ($1.17 billion). The company said the sale would be subject to approval by the French telecommunications regulator. Bouygues owns 67.1 percent of Bouygues Telecom, and will own about 72 percent once the sale is complete. Shares in Bouygues rose 2.9 percent, to 26.07 euros, after the announcement. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: After Rucker Park, Alston's Chance Arrives
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 17  It took a convergence of his struggles and those of the Toronto Raptors to provide Rafer Alston with the stage to perform the magic that had been confined primarily to the asphalt courts of Rucker Park in Harlem.

title: Indictment in Hotel Killing
description: A state grand jury in Manhattan indicted an Oregon man yesterday in the murder of a woman he had traveled to New York to see after a long-distance relationship that had grown out of their shared fascination with the television show ''Dark Shadows.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELL, ANN E.
description: ZELL-Ann E. Loving wife of the late William. Beloved sister of Helen. Loving aunt of Steven, Dianne, Kenneth, Lawrence and Carolyn, and loving great aunt of Andrew, Michael, Lindsay, Leslie, Tracy, Sean and Kathleen. Interment shall be at Beth Yeshuran Cemetery, Allen Parkway, Houston, TX, Sunday, January 19th at 1 PM. Memorial services for New York friends will be scheduled.

title: Senate Panel Quickly Backs Ridge for New Antiterror Post
description: A Senate committee today unanimously approved the nomination of Tom Ridge to be the nation's first secretary of homeland security, although some lawmakers expressed skepticism about Mr. Ridge's assertion that the nation was ''far safer'' than it was before the terror attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, SYLVAN

title: Nets Win, but Challenging Trip Awaits
description: Although Continental Arena was nearly filled with 17,107 fans tonight, there was little electricity in the building. And that was because of the one seat that was empty.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Power To Cut Aid
description: Gov. Mitt Romney has signed into law a bill giving him expanded powers to cut aid to municipalities as a way to deal with a state budget shortfall. The law lets Mr. Romney unilaterally reduce aid if the cuts amount to less then one-third of the total deficit, which could reach $600 billion by the end of this fiscal year. Mr. Romney, a Republican, has warned that he might need to reduce local aid by $200 million. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: The Germans Are Breaking An Old Taboo
description: My earliest memories are of endless journeys in overcrowded trains that made sudden halts in open country. Then we would hear the droning of dive bombers that dropped their loads and veered up again only to return and drop more bombs. Once, we were told to get off the train and seek shelter in a nearby pine wood. As we ran toward the wood, we heard, I heard -- it is impossible to distinguish now between what one experienced oneself and what was told afterward -- that there were 300 charred bodies lying in the wood, making it not a good place to seek shelter.

title: Graziosa Released, Pending New Trial
description: Rocco Graziosa, who was sentenced Wednesday to 45 days in jail for punching Yankees pitcher David Wells, was released from Rikers Island on $10,000 bail yesterday, pending an appeal for a new trial.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Army Raids Drug Agents' Office
description: The army raided the offices of drug enforcement officers in 11 states, officials said. Attorney General Rafael Macedo said the investigation was intended to rid Mexican law enforcement of ''malefactors who have betrayed the trust of our society.'' The raids were intended to seize evidence, and although no one has been arrested yet, hundreds of officers are under scrutiny, officials said. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Catholic Review Board Begins Its Interviews on Abuse Crisis
description: A review board of Roman Catholic laypeople appointed by the nation's bishops to investigate the sexual abuse scandal in the church has begun the first of 100 interviews it plans to conduct with bishops, abuse victims and experts to measure the crisis.

title: 3 QUITTING PANEL ON OLYMPIC ETHICS
description: In a widening rift within the United States Olympic Committee over conflict of interest charges against its chief executive, Lloyd D. Ward, three members of the organization's ethics committee resigned yesterday. Their action brings to five the number of officials who have stepped down since Monday, when Mr. Ward was cleared of committing ethical violations.

title: Genteel Changes To Hardscrabble In Publishing
description: Sherlock Holmes, the detective who was the mainstay of the publishing industry in his day, famously found significance in a dog's not barking. On Thursday, when Ann Godoff, the publisher of the highly regarded Random House Trade Group, was dismissed, the ritual growling over the future of literature was somewhat muted.

description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Takes Case On Black Voting Districts
description: The Supreme Court accepted a politically charged redistricting case from Georgia today that could help determine the future of districts with overwhelming black majorities that have helped Republicans and hurt Democrats across the South and elsewhere in the country.

title: Lottery Numbers
Company That Owns Indian Point Defends Emergency Plan
description: Despite the findings of a consultant's report released Jan. 10, emergency plans for the Indian Point nuclear power plant could protect the public from a large release of radiation, even from a terrorist attack, an official with Entergy, the company that runs the plant, said today.

title: A Million-Dollar Dream for the Neediest
description: ''If I had a million dollars'' is a musing usually followed by a wish list of luxuries, like a house, car, vacations and jewels. But a million dollars can go further than that. A million dollars could provide nearly 400,000 meals for poor children or hungry elderly people. A million dollars could save 800 families from being evicted for one month, feed them and provide job training for their breadwinners.

title: In Purring Retrospect
description: Nancy Wilson spoke about her career in the past tense on Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall. ''I wanted to sing songs,'' she said in her tragic purr. ''I wanted to interpret. It was about the material. It was about telling you some stories. And I've been doing that for a long time.''

title: Briefly Noted
description: BUSH VISITS WOUNDED SOLDIERS President Bush visited five soldiers who had been wounded in Afghanistan, thanking them for their service and pledging to provide the military with the best possible care. Mr. Bush traveled to Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington for a 40-minute visit with the soldiers, all of whom suffered blast or shrapnel wounds. Afterward, he described the five, who were not identified, as "incredibly brave soldiers, five of America's finest citizens."

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday about a Massachusetts high school where students were suspended for handing out candy attached to religious notes misstated its location. It is in Westfield, not Springfield.

title: A Knick Draws the Line After Another Road Loss
description: Allan Houston does not fume, yell or go on tirades in the locker room. But after yet another Knicks debacle tonight, Houston, the team captain, calmly aimed powerful words at himself and his teammates.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Sluggish Growth For Software

Wipro earned 2.31 billion rupees ($48 million) in the quarter, up from 2.24 billion rupees a year earlier, but short of analysts' expectations. Sales in the period, which ended Dec. 31, increased 27 percent, to 11.08 billion rupees. Azim Premji, above, the chairman and majority shareholder, said the company was looking for acquisitions. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: When Eagles Blitz, Madness Has Method
description: The Eagles' defensive scheme has roots that can be traced far back, to another time and another land, before football was invented. It is this simple: the quarterback is the fox, the Eagles' defenders are the hounds.

title: Officials Press Ahead With Smallpox Shots
description: The government's smallpox vaccination program will proceed as planned, federal health officials said yesterday, despite concerns raised by an expert advisory group and calls for delay by unions representing health care workers.

title: Cougars Tackle Declares for Draft
description: Defensive tackle Rien Long of Washington State, the Outland Trophy winner as college football's best interior lineman, intends to skip his senior season and enter the N.F.L. draft, his coach, Bill Doba, told The Spokesman-Review yesterday.

title: VALUE OF POLAROID ASSETS WILL BE RE-EXAMINED
description: A Delaware bankruptcy judge has appointed an independent examiner to determine whether One Equity Partners, the venture capital arm of the Bank One Corporation, got too much of a bargain last July when it bought the assets of the bankrupt Polaroid Corporation for $255 million. Ulysses Yannas, an analyst with Buckman, Buckman & Reid, said that he and some other Polaroid specialists had mounted a letter-writing campaign to have the sale price re-examined. He said Polaroid had ''salted away money'' in its overseas operations by selling them film at very low prices, and then buying back instant cameras at very high prices. Mr. Yannas also complained that the profitable and debt-free overseas plants were assigned no value in the bankruptcy proceedings and that Polaroid had played down the value of its Massachusetts real estate. ''Their cash and receivables alone were worth more than $255 million,'' Mr. Yannas said. A Polaroid spokesman said the re-examination was a routine move as part of the bankruptcy. Claudia H. Deutsch (NYT)

title: Charles Sternberg, 91; Led Refugee Aid Group
description: Charles Sternberg, a refugee from Nazi persecution in Czechoslovakia and France who went on to head the International Rescue Committee, the largest private American organization helping international refugees, died on Thursday in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 91.

title: Boston's Effort to Pry Millar From Japan Club Hits Snag
description: About an hour after he awoke yesterday at his home in Beaumont, Tex., Kevin Millar figured he might as well still be sleeping.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Iceland: Sharpening The Harpoons
description: On a visit to Japan, Prime Minister David Oddsson said he wanted his country to follow Japan's lead and start hunting whales for scientific research. Most whaling stopped after 1986 under an international moratorium. But the moratorium allows some whales to be killed to gather data on populations and biology. Japan has been harshly criticized for killing hundreds of whales, ostensibly for research, while selling the meat. Iceland has said it plans to resume commercial whaling in 2006. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Two Palestinians Attack Jewish Settlement, Killing One Israeli
description: Two Palestinian gunmen attacked an isolated Jewish settlement near the embattled city of Hebron tonight, killing one Israeli and wounding three others. One of the attackers was killed while the other escaped.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Escapes yesterday about the architect Bernard Maybeck and other famous residents of Berkeley, Calif., misspelled the surname of the leader of the Free Speech Movement of the 1960's. He was Mario Savio, not Savo.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Class Action Against Cable Company
description: A state judge has granted class-action status to a suit against a cable company, Charter Communications, clearing the way for hearings on the damages that Judge Donald Beatty will award its 250,000 customers in the state. Geraldine Barber and Nikki Nicholls of Spartanburg won the suit, which said Charter forced customers to pay for unnecessary equipment and services when Judge Beatty found procedural errors by Charter lawyers.

title: Senator Lugar's Moment
description: The shift of the Senate to Republican control has brought one of the G.O.P.'s most seasoned and sensible foreign policy hands, Richard Lugar of Indiana, to the chairmanship of the Foreign Relations Committee. With an unusually challenging array of international crises now commanding the nation's attention, Senator Lugar has an opportunity to restore some of the prominence and influence that committee once had.

title: Turkey Calls a Regional Meeting To Try to Head Off an Iraq War
description: The Turkish prime minister, Abdullah Gul, said today that he had embarked on a major diplomatic effort to head off an American-led war with Iraq, calling regional foreign ministers to a meeting next week.

title: City Seeks to Recoup Tax Money From Internet Cigarette Vendors
description: Seeking to recoup millions of dollars in uncollected tax revenues, the city filed suit yesterday against several companies that sell cigarettes over the Internet but, the suit alleges, do not properly report the sales to the authorities.

title: VERITAS SOFTWARE RESTATES LOSSES FOR 2000 AND 2001
description: The Veritas Software Corporation restated its 2000 and 2001 losses to correct how it had accounted for a swap of software and advertising with AOL Time Warner Inc. The 2000 net loss of $620 million widened by $7 million, and a 2001 net loss of $651 million narrowed by $8 million, Veritas said. Sales and profit in the first nine months of 2002 were reduced by less than 1 percent. The company, a maker of data-storage programs, said on Nov. 15 that it had been subpoenaed for a federal inquiry on how an AOL Time Warner unit recorded advertising sales. Federal regulators are examining whether companies including AOL Time Warner and Global Crossing Ltd. improperly bartered services to inflate sales and cash flow.

title: Funds Aid Ex-Workers of Enron and WorldCom
description: Rebekah Rushing considered herself blessed. She received two job offers the day after she was laid off from Enron in December 2001, while thousands of other ex-employees were having trouble finding work.

title: Does Class Count in Today's Land of Opportunity?
description: As the maid Marisa Ventura in the new film ''Maid in Manhattan,'' Jennifer Lopez uses charm and hard work to vault the growing chasms between the rich, the poor and the getting-by (managing to snag the cute, rich guy along the way).

title: Voigt's Aida Is Assured
description: As opera fans everywhere know by now, Deborah Voigt's voice is gloriously suited to the German dramatic soprano repertory, especially Wagner and Strauss. But as she increasingly takes on weightier German roles, like Isolde, which she sings for the first time at the Vienna State Opera in May, she wants to keep the kind of lightness in her sound and smoothness in her legato that singing Italian repertory can provide. Though not an ideal match for Ms. Voigt's voice, the role of Verdi's Aida has been especially important to her.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Advertising Company Faces Formal S.E.C. Investigation

title: SUNY Trustees Seek 41% Tuition Increase
description: State University of New York trustees recommended raising undergraduate tuition for state residents by 41 percent, or $1,400, the largest increase in SUNY history. With the proposal, SUNY joins a flood of public universities that are trying to cover rising costs by raising tuition.

title: Decline in Market Leads to Fewer Arbitration Cases
description: The owners' off-season signing strategy was vividly on display yesterday. Only 35 players exchanged figures with their clubs for salary arbitration, demonstrating the high number of arbitration-eligible players who had already agreed to 2003 salaries.

title: City to Support Suit Seeking More State Aid For Schools
description: Lawyers for the city plan to offer their support to a lawsuit seeking more state money for New York City's public schools, officials said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: More Interest In Safeway
description: The buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company may make an offer for Safeway, creating a four-way contest for the British supermarket chain. Wal-Mart Stores and J Sainsbury have said they may bid for Safeway. Safeway has already agreed to be bought for about 2.7 billion ($4.3 billion) in stock by William Morrison Supermarkets. Kohlberg Kravis told Safeway it might bid without specifying a price, a Safeway spokesman, Kevin Hawkins, said. Kohlberg Kravis would not face the antitrust hurdles of Wal-Mart or Sainsbury, two of Britain's top food retailers, investors said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISSMAN, MILTON L.
description: WEISSMAN-Milton L. Five long years have passed. You are thought of and deeply loved every second of every day. Helen, Steve, Stephanie and Seren

title: American Financier Is Fired as Head of Russian TV Network
description: The American financier who runs the often-embattled NTV television network in Russia said today that he had been fired by the network's state-controlled owner, the latest chapter in a struggle that is seen as an indicator of this nation's press freedom.

title: Militants Use British Policy On Asylum To Plot Terror
description: To his neighbors up and down the street, the 23-year-old Algerian who rented a second-floor apartment at No. 4 Crumpsall Lane, posing as a student, was just another anonymous tenant of the hotels and short-stay rentals that dot the area.

title: A Threat to Women
description: To the Editor:

title: A Campus Mourns Three Young Men
description: Most of them were athletes, or had been. The driver, Sean R. Fenton, had quit the football team and plunged into computers and a campus job that involved fixing the kinds of hardware headaches that can confound students with papers to finish.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Switzerland's security plans for the World Economic Forum next week misstated the type of force Liechtenstein will be sending to join some 2,000 Swiss soldiers. The members are police officers, not soldiers.

title: Republicans Fight Off More Amendments to Spending Bill
description: For the second day in a row, Senate Republicans stuck together today to sweep aside Democratic efforts to add more money for domestic security and education to a $390 billion appropriations bill. But a final vote on the measure, which is left over from last year, was delayed yet again, until next week.

title: Race and the Admissions Puzzle
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. and the Wetlands
description: To the Editor:

title: Tapping Toes, Rapping Stilts
description: The program called ''Kdanse'' a ''new work in progress.'' Whatever form it may eventually take, the dance was exciting when Tamango's Urban Tap presented it last Saturday afternoon at the Kitchen.

title: Fight Heats Up to Redevelop Arena Site in Meadowlands
description: The effort to redevelop the Continental Arena site, as its sports teams anticipate a move to Newark, began four months ago as an orderly competition among six major developers. They quietly showed their traffic studies, economic projections and colorful site plans to the professional staff of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which will decide the fate of the Meadowlands site.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Martin Luther King's Birthday will be legally observed.

title: Like Sniper Case, Hearing for Youth Is Out of the Ordinary
description: If this had been an ordinary murder case, legal experts say, the preliminary hearings would have probably gone on for two hours instead of two days.

title: Kvasha Has Hit the On Switch Again
description: Oleg Kvasha, the Islanders' talented yet confounding left wing, has had flashes of brilliance before. Then the flashes end. His inner fire seems more like a flickering hearth than a blast furnace.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: DOSSIER ON BERIA Prosecutors displayed a criminal dossier on the Soviet secret police chief Lavrenti Beria, including a list of hundreds of women he was accused of stalking and raping. The military prosecutor's office presented Mr. Beria's 47-volume criminal case, which ended with a death sentence and quick execution in 1953. The dossier will be opened to the public after 25 years, according to Russian television stations, which said the prosecutors had presented the files to disprove press reports they had been stolen. Mr. Beria, appointed head of the secret police in 1938, played a major role in the terror of the Stalin era. He was convicted of treason after Stalin's death.    (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Delay For Debt Agency
description: The Industrial Revitalization Corporation, a new government agency charged with overhauling debt-burdened companies, will not begin work until at least May, the group's chief said. The Koizumi administration put the agency together in November to help banks deal with weakened borrowers. But the group, which will probably require guarantees for 10 trillion yen ($85 billion) in financing, must seek approval from lawmakers next week. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Members of New Panel Praised by Both Sides
description: The two sides in the battle over the city's homeless policy do not agree on many things, but they are unified on these three: Gail B. Nayowith, John D. Feerick and Daniel Kronenfeld.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVINE, MARY K.B.
description: DEVINE-Mary K.B. On January 16, 2003. Wife of Robert W. Devine Jr. Sister of J. David Boland of Grand Rapids, MI. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, January 20th, 10:30 AM at St Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th St and Lexington Ave. Interment will take place in Grand Rapids, MI.

title: Race and the Admissions Puzzle
description: To the Editor:

title: Germans Were Tracking Sept. 11 Conspirators as Early as 1998, Documents Disclose
description: Three years before the Sept. 11 attacks, Germany's domestic intelligence service was tracking prominent members of the Hamburg terrorist cell that planned and executed the aircraft hijackings, according to newly obtained documents.

title: Production Falls and Trade Deficit Rises
description: The United States trade deficit swelled in November, industrial production dropped in December and consumer confidence fell this month, according to reports issued today that prompted some economists to cut fourth-quarter growth estimates.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Keith Richards Keeps the Stones Rolling
description: Keith Richards is the formula for the Rolling Stones as well as its claim to spontaneity. The best moments of the Stones' show at Madison Square Garden on Thursday were introduced by his riffs, which appeared suddenly, bright and cutting and emphasizing the weak beats of a rhythm. They sliced through the music's laggardly atmosphere.

title: Who Moved My Arugula?
description: After graduating from college in the late 1960's, unclear about my future, I drifted into the family supermarket business in New Jersey. From Day One, I bugged my father and uncle about all the things they were doing wrong. In response, they sent me to an old-fashioned supermarket training program.

title: New Details Offered on Webber Charges
description: Federal prosecutors filed a more detailed indictment today against Chris Webber and two relatives, in a case that involves payments that a booster says he made to Webber and other University of Michigan basketball players in the 1990's.

title: Rising War Fears Bring Economic Turmoil to Kurdish-Ruled Zone
description: Signs of worry over the possibility of war have begun to affect the tenuous economy in northern Iraq, destabilizing the local currency and creating confusion in the market for gasoline and food, commodities that would be essential if the area is besieged.

title: ARMS INSPECTORS WANT MORE TIME FOR WORK IN IRAQ
description: The Bush administration and the United Nations weapons inspectors differed sharply today on the effort to disarm Saddam Hussein, with the inspectors saying they needed more time, possibly months, while the White House said evidence was rapidly accumulating to justify military action.

title: The Law And The River
description: On New Year's Day, Californians woke up to a new reality as painful as any hangover. The secretary of the interior cut the delivery of Colorado River water to Southern California by nearly one-fourth of what urban areas there consume in a year.

title: 9/11 Program Finally Gets Flood of Requests for Help
description: A flood of last-minute requests to the biggest program aiding small businesses and nonprofit groups in Lower Manhattan in the wake of the World Trade Center attack has pushed the amount of aid approved to more than the $481 million allotted for the program, according to the state agency that runs the program. Beyond that, 1,700 applications remain to be processed.

title: The Owners of Culture vs. the Free Agents
description: The Stanford Law School professor Lawrence Lessig called it the ''Mickey Mouse Protection Act.'' And even though Mickey himself does not figure in the law or in the Supreme Court's 7-to-2 decision to uphold the 1998 Copyright Term Extension Act on Wednesday, the smiling rodent still has a starring role in discussions of the case.

title: U.S. Approves Code Sharing By 3 Airlines, With Limits
description: The government approved a marketing partnership today among three airlines -- Delta, Northwest and Continental -- but only on strict conditions intended to limit anticompetitive behavior.

title: Swiss Company in Accord Over Asbestos-Related Suits
description: ABB, the Swiss maker of industrial equipment, said today that it had reached a settlement with lawyers representing more than 110,000 people who had sued the company over asbestos-related claims, potentially dispelling the biggest cloud hanging over the company.

title: Venezuelan Soldiers Try to Reopen Beverage Plants
description: Venezuela's national guard today seized warehouses full of beer, soft drinks and bottled water, which had been closed since the start of a seven-week strike that has crippled business and industry and caused food shortages.

title: Ex-Music Director of Church Admits Raping Girl
description: The former music director of a Long Island church admitted in court today that he repeatedly raped an 11-year-old girl who had been his music student and a baby sitter to his two small children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHLIS, JAMES JOSEPH
description: ROCHLIS-James Joseph. On January 14, 2003. Beloved father of Susan and Jeffrey, proud grandfather of Jennifer, beloved brother of Theda Sannit, father by affection of Ellen Koerner, adoring and loving friend of Muriel Goldblatt. To the family and friends fortunate enough to have known him, a man of distinguished accomplish ment, character, integrity, generosity and honor. Service at 11:30 A.M. on Sunday, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to the charity of one's choice would be appreciated.

title: As an American Armada Leaves San Diego, Tears Are the Rule of the Day
description: The ships shoved off this morning at half-hour intervals. The Comstock was the first at 7 a.m. Then the Dubuque, the Cleveland, the Boxer, the Bonhomme Richard, the Anchorage and, finally, the Pearl Harbor.

title: KMART WANTS REPAYMENT OF EXECUTIVE RETENTION LOANS
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it had demanded the repayment of all executive retention loans made before it filed for bankruptcy protection and that it had fired the five remaining bonus recipients still with the company. An internal investigation found that management under the former chairman, Charles Conaway, did not properly disclose information to the board when it set up the loan program in 2001, Kmart said. The retailer lent more than $30 million to dozens of executives in the year before its bankruptcy filing in January 2001. Kmart is based in Troy, Mich.

title: M.T.A. Executive Clarifies Budget Deficit
description: The executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that the agency's projected budget deficit of $2.8 billion over the next two years -- which transit officials are widely reporting now in advertisements and on subway posters -- does not take into account several cost-cutting measures that will almost certainly narrow the gap to $951 million to slightly more than $1 billion.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; BUSH VISITS WOUNDED SOLDIERS
description: President Bush visited five soldiers who had been wounded in Afghanistan, thanking them for their service and pledging to provide the military with the best possible care. Mr. Bush traveled to Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington for a 40-minute visit with the soldiers, all of whom suffered blast or shrapnel wounds. Afterward, he described the five, who were not identified, as ''incredibly brave soldiers, five of America's finest citizens.'' Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: SLUGGISH GROWTH FOR SOFTWARE The Indian software company Wipro posted a 3 percent increase in third-quarter revenue and warned of slow sales and declining profit margins. Wipro earned 2.31 billion rupees ($48 million) in the quarter, up from 2.24 billion rupees a year earlier, but short of analysts' expectations. Sales in the period, which ended Dec. 31, increased 27 percent, to 11.08 billion rupees. Azim Premji, above, the chairman and majority shareholder, said the company was looking for acquisitions. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Yao Proving A Bigger Man Than O'Neal
description: WHAT does an aerial view reveal about the landscape?

title: U.S. Plan to Monitor Muslims Meets With Widespread Protest
description: American plans to fingerprint and register visitors from a number of predominantly Muslim countries met with widespread protest and indignation yesterday. The foreign minister of Pakistan made plans to fly to the United States this weekend to protest in person, and the government of Indonesia advised its citizens to avoid traveling to the United States.

title: Corrections
description: Anurse quoted in an article on Thursday about the impact of a national strike on day-to-day life in Venezuela says the article misstated the context of her comments. The nurse, Nicolasa Veita, who works at the Centro Medico Caracas, said, "The doctors are looking for an excuse to close the hospitals and blame it on the government." Later, in the presence of Centro Medico administrators, Ms. Veita said her comments had referred to Vargas Hospital, a public facility, where she also works, not to the Centro Medico.

description: FISHER - Michael T. We mourn the passing of Michael T. Fisher, beloved son of Steven and Elissa Fisher. We extend our deepest sympathy to his mother and father, and to his sisters, Jamie Rose and Natalia Lyn, and his brother Kyle Robert, during this painful time. Bill White Col. Tom Tyrrell David Winters Kristen Kelly

title: Getting the Courts Out of the Shelters
description: New York City's mayor, Michael Bloomberg, has made a habit of taking a fresh and aggressive approach to problems that have tied his predecessors in knots. The latest and most striking example came yesterday when his administration reached a landmark agreement with the Legal Aid Society, which has been waging courtroom war against the city for 20 years over the way homeless families and individuals should be housed and cared for.

title: Banana Workers Get Day in Court
description: Manuel Guido Montoya never had the children he once hoped would ease his workload and bring home a few extra dollars. Years ago, he tried to start a family, he said, but the woman left him once she realized he was sterile.

title: Eased Rule May Benefit House G.O.P. Leader
description: The House majority leader, Representative Tom DeLay, may be one of the first to take advantage of a recent relaxation of rules that let charities pay the expenses of lawmakers who travel to special fund-raising events.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the sentencing of a Drug Enforcement Agency analyst who gave internal documents to a British freelance reporter referred incorrectly to the newspaper that first reported the sentencing. It was a daily, not a weekly -- The Fulton County Daily Report, not The Fulton Daily Times.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about two leukemia-like cases in a gene therapy test misstated its sponsorship. It was a French test, not an F.D.A. test.

title: Success Formula: Hip-Hop in Force
description: How do you put on a successful hip-hop show? On Thursday night at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., the radio station Power 105 found an obvious answer: overkill. The station sponsored a four-hour concert that featured more than two dozen performers, with a supporting cast of D.J.'s, radio personalities and -- inevitably -- hangers-on.

title: Unusual Allies Succeed in Halting Princeton Deer Shoot
description: An odd teaming of animal rights advocates and sports hunters have at least temporarily derailed Princeton Township's ambitious program to thin its deer population by using professional sharpshooters.

description: First, in October 2001, Caryll Adderley was told she had cervical cancer. Then, last year brought more frightening news: breast cancer and lymphoma.

description: STANLEY-Lila Jean of Plymouth January 1st, age 75. She is survived by a nephew Hamilton S. White of Syracuse, New York. Nieces Laura McSweeney of West Granby, Connecticut and Sarah Chadwick of Schnectady, New York and cousins Frank Stanley of Canton, Connecticut and Courtney Stanley Brady of Edgartown, Massachussets. There are no visiting hours. A private family service will be held at a later date in Great Barrington, Massachussets. Donations in her memory may be made to the Order of St. Anne, 25 Hillside Ave, Arlington, Massachussets, 02476-5816. For information the Richard Davis Funeral Homes of Plymouth and Manomet.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Builder Cuts Jobs
description: One of Japan's largest construction companies, the Hazama Corporation, will lay off 40 percent of its workers and close money-losing subsidiaries as it tries to get more debt relief from its main banks. The company will eliminate 1,140 jobs and ask the Mizuho Corporate Bank to exchange 10 billion yen ($85 million) in debt for new shares. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, MICHAEL TYLER
description: FISHER-Michael Tyler. Born August 31, 1990, passed away Friday, January 17, 2003. Beloved son of Steven and Elissa Fisher and brother of Jamie-Rose, Kyle Robert and Natalia Lyn. A student at Horace Mann Academy, Michael was a scholar who truly excelled in all forms of creative expression. He was a loving young man who brought such immense joy and happiness into the lives of his parents and siblings. Michael had many dreams and did so much in his time here. At the early age of 12, he was already a master of four languages. Michael dreamed of being the best at all he attempted and always succeeded. His brothers and sisters loved him deeply, and he was the life of every party. Michael's intellect was surpassed only by his kindness. He changed this world for the better and will be greatly missed. In addition to his immediate family, Michael is survived by a loving extended family: his paternal grandparents, Arnold and Audrey Fisher of Pine Plains, NY, and Lyn and Jack Schwartz of Manhattan; his maternal grandparents, Vincent and Assunta Gerard of Marco Island, FL, formerly of Rutherford, NJ. Michael is also survived by his uncle Kenneth Fisher, his wife Tammy, and their children Crystal, Brittany and Joshua; his aunt Karen and Thomas Misisco and their children Jonathan, Nicholas and Dylan; his aunt Helene and Ted Brois and their son Brandon; his aunt Tina and Douglas Cuveron and their sons Douglas, James and Evan; his aunt Pamela and Terek ElGammal and their sons Omar and Adam. A memorial service will be held Monday, January 20, 11AM at Temple Israel, 112 E. 75th St, Manhattan.

title: Being in Position for a Title Is Nothing New to Kwan
description: Michelle Kwan heard the melody in her head today as she practiced her long program, blocking out the other skaters on the ice and their music on the speakers.

title: War Uncertainty Weighs on Economy
description: As Washington decides whether to invade Iraq, uncertainty about a war is already weighing on the economy.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; TERROR PENALTIES
description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously voted in favor of a resolution strengthening the enforcement of penalties -- including the freezing of funds, an arms embargo and travel prohibitions -- against Osama bin Laden, Al Qaeda, the Taliban and their associates. It also called on governments to submit updated reports on their efforts.

title: Constellation Brands Agrees To Buy Australian Winery
description: Constellation Brands, the American wine, beer and spirits company, said today that it had agreed to acquire the winemaker BRL Hardy of Adelaide, Australia, for 1.9 billion Australian dollars ($1.1 billion) in cash or stock. The combined company would be the world's largest wine producer.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Futures prices rose after Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said the U.S. had proof that Iraq was hindering weapons inspectors. In New York, oil for February delivery rose 25 cents, to $33.91 a barrel.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The dollar fell against the euro as lower consumer confidence, a wider trade deficit and a drop in stocks fueled fears that the economy will slow. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0666, up from $1.0617 on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASSER, STELLA
description: STRASSER-Stella. Born September 9, 1910; died December 28, 2002. An electronics engineer, nationally recognized as an expert in the field of signal analysis, she became the top salaried woman scientist at US Army Engineering Laboratories at Ft. Monmouth and was one of the first women recipients of the Old Crows' certificate of merit. She was president of Ft. Monmouth's Toastmistress Club and among the first to be named to Hunter College's Hall of Fame. She was deeply devoted to family and friends; we mourn her passing and miss her enthusiasm for life, her humor, and her generous spirit.

title: Living on Dividends
description: To the Editor:

title: Asleep in the Crib, or in the Parents' Bed?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Anti-Quota Smoke Screen
description: The Bush administration sacrificed truth for political gain this week when it filed legal briefs urging the Supreme Court to overturn the University of Michigan's use of racial ''quotas'' in admissions. Michigan's admissions system does not use racial quotas. But the administration has clearly decided the best way to appease its right-wing supporters without alienating the rest of the country is to disguise its anti-affirmative-action agenda as an anti-quota crusade. The administration should start leveling with the American people about race, and it should stop trying to turn back the clock.

title: JUDGE ORDERS LIQUIDATION OF WADE COOK FINANCIAL
description: The Wade Cook Financial Corporation was ordered liquidated by a federal bankruptcy judge yesterday after its chief executive failed to provide testimony requested by creditors. The company, which advertised itself widely on popular radio programs, provided training seminars for stock trading. Creditors asked the court last month to force the company and its subsidiary, Stock Market Institute of Learning Inc., into bankruptcy, saying that employees had not been paid back wages and that their health insurance was canceled after the company collected and pocketed premiums. A bankruptcy judge in Seattle ordered the company into Chapter 7 bankruptcy proceedings, which call for liquidation of the company's assets. Wade Cook, the chief executive and founder of the company, predicted that the company would earn $6 million in 2002. The company lost $6.2 million in the first nine months of the year, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Jurevicius May Miss The Bucs' Big Game
description: Joe Jurevicius, the former Giants wide receiver, has been a quiet contributor in the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' offensive resurgence this season. But his availability for Tampa Bay's N.F.C. title game against the Eagles on Sunday became a bigger question mark today when he did not practice for the third straight day.

title: Freud Meets Buddha: Therapy for Immigrants; Disorders From the East Emerge Here
description: The patients may suffer from classic mental ailments: depression, anxiety, schizophrenia.

title: Eleanore Pettersen, 86, Pioneering Architect
description: Eleanore Pettersen, a New Jersey architect who helped lead the way for women in her profession, died on Wednesday at her home in Saddle River, N.J. She was 86.

title: Will Cloney, 91, Dies; Put Boston Marathon on the Map
description: Will Cloney, a former sportswriter and journalism professor who transformed the Boston Marathon from an all-amateur rite of spring to a world-class prize-money production and lost his job as race director doing it, died Thursday in a hospital in Weymouth, Mass. He was 91 and lived in Duxbury, Mass.

title: The Weight Of Evidence
description: The discovery of 11 empty chemical warheads by United Nations weapons inspectors has brought to the fore a simmering debate about how much evidence must be amassed before the United States uses military force to oust Saddam Hussein from power.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NATIONAL-OILWELL ACQUIRES HALLIBURTON PUMPING UNIT
description: National-Oilwell Inc., a maker of equipment for oil and natural gas drilling, said it had bought the Halliburton Company's pumping-equipment business for about $89.2 million in stock and cash to expand its product range. The company paid $22.7 million in cash and 3.2 million in newly issued shares for the unit, known as Monoflo Inc. in the United States and the Mono Group in Britain. The acquisition will increase operating profit by $18 million and add 5 cents a share to 2003 earnings, the company said. Both National-Oilwell and Halliburton are based in Houston.

title: S.E.C. UPGRADES E.D.S. INQUIRY TO FORMAL INVESTIGATION

title: Joe Millionaire for President
description: Watching that noble doctor Bill Frist make his TV rounds last weekend -- I know he's a saint because he keeps telling us so -- I began to think I was going under general anesthesia. Here's a guy who dispenses bromides and palliatives for every troublesome topic, dishing out the spin so smoothly that you have to question your own grasp on reality. A spoonful of sugar makes the medicine go down? Dr. Frist, as he insists that we call him, gives us the whole bowl. ''He's perfected that earnest, focused look that people want when they go to the doctor,'' one of his former medical colleagues told me this week. ''It's as if you are the only person in the world.''

The increase would push annual tuition at SUNY's four-year campuses to $4,800 next year from $3,400, and to nearly $5,700 on average, if required campus fees were included.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Workers Spread Chernobyl Poison
description: Workers cleaning up the radioactive remains of the Chernobyl nuclear power station have hauled 315 tons of contaminated metal into radiation-free areas, threatening untold numbers of people with a new wave of radioactive poisoning, Ukraine's prosecutor general charged in a statement. The prosecutor, Svyatoslav Pyskun, said workers had improperly dumped the debris in part because Ukraine lacked money to provide safe disposal sites for the continuing cleanup of the world's worst nuclear accident, which occurred in April 1986. He also accused workers of laziness and disregard for rules. Michael Wines (NYT)

The group's political representative, the Progressive Unionist Party, said members were angered over Britain's snubbing them and devoting its attention to Sinn Fein, the party of the Irish Republican Army, in talks intended to revive the suspended Northern Ireland Assembly. Under the plan, which requires approval by Parliament, the government would be able to seize assets legally held by drug traffickers and to deport illegal immigrants sentenced to fewer than six years in prison. People convicted of more than four petty offenses would be sentenced for a serious crime. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Gone Ape
description: Anyone who has watched much nature television knows that orangutans are by far the handsomest and smartest-looking of the great apes. They're literal highbrows, with wide, soulful eyes and broad expressive foreheads. They're covered not with bathmat fur, like so many apes, but with what amounts to a couture pelt -- red hair so long and fine it seems blow-dried. It's true that orangutans drag their knuckles when they walk, but how else are you going to get around if your arms are longer than your legs? For creatures so large, they are uncommonly graceful, not to mention sweet-natured, so it's gratifying to learn that a team of scientists, writing in the journal Science, has recently certified them as ''cultured'' as well. Metaphorically at least, the news makes you want to extend a cheerful hand to your fellow primate and pump him by his auburn, hirsute paw (it would feel sort of like angora, I'm guessing).

title: 'Craze'
description: ON 27 OCTOBER 1688, William of Orange, stadtholder of the United Provinces of the Netherlands and husband of Mary, daughter of James II of England, was stranded in the small Dutch port of Hellevoetsluys. His old enemy, Louis XIV of France, was once again on the move, and French troops were poised to invade the Netherlands. A few miles away, in the stormy waters of the North Sea, William had at great cost and even greater risk assembled an armada of 225 ships, ostensibly to come to the rescue of his fellow Protestants in England. Winter was fast approaching, and with it the prospect that William would not only have to call off his invasion of England, but also leave his own country vulnerable to being invaded by the French. The following day, however, the storms that had been buffeting the Dutch fleet lifted; two days later William set sail; and four months later, with James II now in ignominious exile in France, William was crowned along with his wife Mary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, CHARLES (CAREL)
description: STERNBERG-Charles (Carel). The Board of Directors, the staff and the worldwide family of the International Rescue Committee (IRC) are deeply saddened by the death on January 16, 2003, of our former Executive Director, who devoted his life to the cause of refugees and human rights. As a refugee himself from his native Czechoslovakia, Carel carried out his first humanitarian assignment in 1941 in Marseille, where he helped hundreds of targets of the Nazi Gestapo make their way out of occupied France. After reaching the United States and serving three years in the U.S. Army, he rejoined the International Rescue Committee in 1946. Thereafter, he assumed increasing responsibilities as the IRC responded to refugee crises worldwide and resettled tens of thousands of refugees in the United States. From 1965 to 1985, he served with distinction as Executive Director. Until his final illness, he was an active volunteer, Secretary of the IRC and member of our Board and Executive Committee. We express our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Irma Kadmon Sternberg; his sister, Ella Rosenheck of Bayside, N.Y.; his niece, Michelle Eisner of Hollis Hills, N.Y., and his nephew, Doron Rosenheck of Plainview, N.Y. Winston Lord James C. Strickler Co-Chairmen John C. Whitehead Chairman Emeritus George Rupp President

title: Why We Kindle the Dreams of the Young

title: Take Another Madeleine
description: ''Around 7:30 a pale young man with doelike eyes would arrive at Weber's. . . . Pretty soon his lips would let fall, pronounced in a hesitant, hard-pressed tone, exceptionally refreshing remarks and diabolically accurate perceptions. . . . It was Marcel Proust.'' These observations come from the writer and bon vivant Lon Daudet, who, with other decadently ornamented figures, stares out at us from THE WORLD OF PROUST: As Seen by Paul Nadar (MIT, $34.95), a collection of photographs by Nadar, who in his fashionable portrait studio recorded the same aristocratic figures that Proust drew upon for his exquisitely etched characters in ''Remembrance of Things Past.'' The book was edited by Anne-Marie Bernard, who provides extended captions detailing each sitter's relationship to Proust and his prose. We meet, for instance, the possible model for the Duchesse de Guermantes in the several pictures taken between 1883 and 1900 of the Comtesse Greffulhe, whose beauty intoxicated Proust as it did the Comtesse herself, who wrote: ''I don't believe there is in the world a pleasure comparable to that of a woman who is aware she is the center of everyone's attention.'' There is also a shot of the resigned face of Proust's grandmother, recalling a description in the novel: ''Her cheeks . . . unconsciously assumed an expression of their own, livid, haggard, like the expression of an animal that feels that it has been marked down for slaughter.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELD, DR. JULIUS
description: HELD-Dr. Julius. Renowned art historian and collection advisor to the Ponce Museum of Art, passed away on December 22, 2002, at the age of 97. The Museum and especially its President and founder, Hon. Luis A. Ferre, lament the loss of this great collaborator and friend. He contributed to the creation and development of the Ponce Museum of Art for more than forty years, with his expertise and connoisseurship. Dr. Held shared with Hon. Luis A. Ferre, Puerto Rico's former Governor and philanthropist, the dream of establishing the first fine arts museum in Puerto Rico that would present to the public fine samples of European art. In 1962, Dr. Held's initiative made possible a donation to the Ponce Museum of early renaissance paintings from the Kress Foundation in New York. That same year he collaborated with the planning of the new building designed by renowned architect Edward Durell Stone that opened to the public in 1965. In 1967 he published the Museum's first catalogue, followed by the second in 1984, with the collaboration of Dr. Rene Taylor. His dedication to the Ponce Museum of Art was uninterrupted. Over the years he advised the Museum on the acquisition of the finest examples of European paintings, such as Rubens, Van Dyck, Teniers, Joos van Cleve, Luca Giordano, Murillo, Rivera, Claude Lorrain, Gerome, Vigee-Le Brun, Gainsborough, among others. He also was the reason for the Museum's fine collection of 18th and 19th century sculptures as well as an excellent Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood collection, renowned among the American collections. He was instrumental in achieving the Museum's 1987 AAM accreditation, making it the first museum accredited in Puerto Rico. In his last letter sent to the Hon. Luis A. Ferre, he expressed: ''tell me more about our museum,'' showing his undying devotion for this museum. We will never forget his love, passion, and hard work for the Ponce Museum of Art. Hiromi Shiba Director & Chief Curator Ponce Museum of Art Puerto Rico

title: The Spa Owner
description: Ji Baek dresses more like a spa guest than a spa owner, even when she is working overtime. Next month, Ms. Baek, a 32-year-old manicurist who owns the Rescue Nail Spa as well as two Rescue Beauty Lounges in New York City, will come out with her own line of nail polishes. (They will become available next month at Fred Segal in Los Angeles.) Her packed schedule does not cramp her style. "Comfort is not an issue for me," Ms. Baek said. "I wear heels every day. I've been known to wear cocktail dresses at 10 in the morning." High heels may be the only constant element in Ms. Baek's personal style catalog. "I love changing my look," Ms. Baek said. "I'll be brushing my teeth and think: `It's a preppy day. I'm going to wear a kilt and look like a schoolgirl.' " This winter, Ms. Baek has been rotating creamy whites and ladylike yellows, as well as the pink ensemble shown here, which consists of a Smashing Grandpa tank top ($30 at rescuebeauty.com ); Marc Jacobs cargo pants ($550 at Marc Jacobs, New York; 212-924-6126); and hot pink cashmere socks nestled into Prada pumps ($510 at Prada stores). A Chanel jacket ($2,080 at Chanel stores) and a hard-to-find Hermes Birkin bag add weight to the whimsy. "Color intrigues me because that's my work," Ms. Baek said. "I rarely wear all black."

title: New Music, and Older Music That May Sound Newer Still
description: POUL RUDERS -- The Danish composer Poul Ruders, 53, is hard to categorize, and that's the way he likes it. He once sang in a boys' choir, and vestiges of spirituality, even direct quotes from medieval scores and old German Christmas carols, turn up in his works, sometimes devoutly, sometimes impishly. He has been inspired by sources as disparate as Minimalism and the cha-cha. Yet his pluralistic musical language abounds with authenticity and freshness. His audacious opera ''The Handmaid's Tale,'' based on Margaret Atwood's futuristic novel, received its premiere in 2000 at the Royal Danish Opera. On May 10, it arrives in America, at the Minnesota Opera. I'll be there, grateful that Mr. Ruders, a major figure in Europe, is finally attracting real attention in America.

title: PILLS AND CHILDREN
description: Two to three times as many children and adolescents were taking some type of psychiatric drug in 1996 as in 1987, researchers at the University of Maryland reported. Stimulants, like Ritalin, and antidepressants topped the list of the most frequently prescribed medications. But the use of anti-psychotics, so-called mood stabilizers and other potent drugs also jumped sharply. Some experts said the increase might reflect greater awareness of mental illness and advances in treatment. Others suggested the drugs -- whose long-term effects on the developing brain are not known -- are being overprescribed. Erica Goode

title: D. H. Lawrence Frees the Slaves
description: ''Listen to the States asserting: 'The hour has struck! . . . The U.S.A. is now grown up artistically. It is time we ceased to hang on to the skirts of Europe, or to behave like schoolboys let loose from European schoolmasters.' '' That's D. H. Lawrence in his 1923 ''Studies in Classic American Literature.'' ''We like to think of the old-fashioned American classics as children's books. Just childishness, on our part. . . . It is hard to hear a new voice, as hard as it is to listen to an unknown language.'' He was writing about Poe, Hawthorne and Melville -- canonical now, but radical then. And ''studies'' is too mild: these are blasts, rants, taunts and thunderbolt revelations hurled every which way. The old American artists were ''hopeless liars. But they were artists, in spite of themselves.'' Then comes the line that could be the password to all postmodern literary theory: ''Never trust the artist. Trust the tale.''

title: Hey, Character and Ability!
description: Whether chronicling the lives of leaders, inventors, artists or athletes, Russell Freedman presents his subjects both in the context of their extraordinary accomplishments and as individuals whose vision and values ran counter to the prevailing wisdom and prejudices of their time. The moral might be that the truly great are true to themselves, no matter what. Certainly this was so for Confucius, who was born around 551 B.C. Living in a time of corruption and unrest, when feudal lords fought among themselves, taxes were high and peasants often starved, he believed ''the right to govern . . . should depend on a person's character and ability, not on his birth.'' A revolutionary idea. He also believed that if education were open to rich and poor alike, class distinctions would soon disappear and governments would be run by the most able people.

title: HOPE SEEN ON CANCER RATES

The study stopped short of blaming environmental pollutants in the towns, Toms River and Dover Township, but officials said they now had further clues to explore such a link. The study found 25 cases of childhood leukemia and cancers of the brain and nervous system in Dover Township from 1996 to 2000 and 87 such cases since 1979. Researchers for the state Department of Health said a drop in the number of younger cases in Toms River could suggest a trend toward declining cancer rates. Jeremy Pearce

title: The Power and the Silence In the Vatican
description: WHAT did Pope Pius XII know about the Holocaust? The question is not new. Since the mid-1990's, when the Vatican began considering the wartime pontiff's beatification, a flurry of books have charged that he ignored strong evidence of the continuing extermination of Jews for fear of German reprisals. Now, with ''Amen,'' the latest in a long line of powerful political movies by the Greek-born director Constantin Costa-Gavras, the case against Pius XII has been brought to the screen.

title: PAC Man
description: BOY GENIUS

title: Personal Business; Faraway Relatives Turning to Geriatrics Experts
description: TWO years ago, when her widowed mother in Sun City, Ariz., lost consciousness, fell and cracked some bones, Merle J. Wexler, who lives in Virginia, could not run over to help. Nor could her brothers, who live in California and North Carolina. Her mother had delayed seeking medical treatment.

title: Investing; Save for Retirement and Get Wisdom, Too
description: SINCE the beginning of 2000, Dr. James L. McCoy has watched his 401(k) account lose half its value. But he hasn't altered his investment strategy.

title: Blazers' Wallace Suspended
description: Portland Trail Blazers forward Rasheed Wallace was suspended yesterday for seven games without pay for confronting and threatening a referee after a game Wednesday night outside the Rose Garden in Portland, Ore.

title: GENE THERAPY SETBACK
description: The Food and Drug Administration suspended 27 gene therapy clinical trials after a second child receiving such treatment in France developed a disease resembling leukemia. Nine children in France had been virtually cured of a fatal immune disease, in the first unequivocal success for gene therapy. But two of them subsequently developed leukemia because, scientists determined, the curative gene put into their blood cells landed on or near a cancer-promoting gene and activated it. Andrew Pollack

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 5 about living in Shrub Oak, N.Y., misstated the name of a new independent living facility for the elderly there, as did a correction last Sunday. It is Wynwood Oaks -- not Windwood and not Windward.

title: Sara Horwitz, Adam Meier
description: Sara Ellen Horwitz, a daughter of Marjorie and Albert A. Horwitz of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Weston Meier, the son of Emily and Robert C. Meier of St. Paul. Rabbi Richard H. Berman officiated at Bridgewaters, a caterer in Manhattan.

title: Next U.N. Vote on Iraq Could Put Schrder on the Spot
description: BERLIN, Jan. 17  Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany used his opposition to a war against Iraq to save his political career last fall, picking up crucial anti-war votes for a come-from-behind election victory.

title: Metamucil Ad Featuring Old Faithful Causes a Stir
description: Suzanne Lewis was in for a shock when she sat down at home one recent night to watch television.

title: Thousands Converge in Capital to Protest Plans for War
description: In a show of dissent that organizers said ''shattered the false myth of consensus,'' for a war with Iraq, tens of thousands of protesters representing a diverse coalition for peace converged here today for a rally and march against the Bush administration's threatened use of military force against Saddam Hussein's regime.

title: Going South, the Knicks Go to Weatherspoon
description: It was the type of play that could send a player into a shell. Darvin Ham of the Hawks dunked viciously over Clarence Weatherspoon while drawing a foul. The play came with six minutes left and, after Ham made the free throw, gave Atlanta a 3-point lead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMANN, WILMA
description: BAUMANN-Wilma. September 29, 1910 to January 14, 2003. She was a keen birder and a lovely human being. Her friends will miss her. Lore J. Schore

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHRMAN, SAMUEL ALLEN, MD
description: LEHRMAN - Samuel Allen, MD, 51, died January 16, 2003. Survived by wife Ellen, children Beth and Michael, in-laws Fred and Evelyn Phillips, family members Ruth, Gwen, Malcolm and Rebecca. He was Chief of Radiology at St. Mary's Hospital-SVCMC.

title: With Kidnapping of Executive, Security Has Become an Issue
description: ON Friday night, Jan. 10, the nightmare began. Edward S. Lampert, a prominent hedge fund manager, was nabbed in an underground parking garage in downtown Greenwich and forced into a rented Ford Expedition. Mr. Lampert, who runs ESL Investments in the town, was then taken to a Day's Inn in Hamden.

title: Titans Will Be Trying To Disrupt Gannon
description: At least the Tennessee Titans could act a little worried. Defensive end Jevon Kearse led a contingent of players from Florida to the door to gaze out at the eight-inch snowfall here Thursday. A few moments later, a snowball fight broke out in the locker room. Some of the Titans talked about building a snowman after their late afternoon meetings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNHEIMER, MARTHA
description: MANNHEIMER - Martha. Born October 9, 1905. Died January 17, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Adolf. She is survived by her son David Fried and daughter Elaine Block, and five grandchildren.

title: A Talent To Annoy
description: In the middle of our row, in autumn-bronze Milan, watching Italy's stake in the spring collections come down the runway, one skirt shorter than the next, I thought I felt a rumble underfoot. Raging drums seemed to come from as far away as -- well, as far away as Larchmont and Laguna, where ladies, I am told, gather every season in cozy groups and head toward the malls, wondering what to wear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIERING, LAURETTE
description: ZIERING-Laurette. Loving wife of Jesse. Mother of Susan and Gerald (Judy). Loving grandmother and greatgrandmother. Longtime teacher and bridge player. We will miss you dearly.

title: Late Run Secures Victory For Cabral
description: Jeremy Bloom, the crowd favorite, stumbled, then skied off the course and out of the competition. Travis Mayer, the Olympic silver medalist in moguls a year ago, skied fast but sloppy and did not make the finals. Toby Dawson, another young moguls phenom from the United States, was well back, in 17th place.

description: MAX BEERBOHM

title: Plantation on the Hudson
description: MOST visitors reach for their cameras when they first glimpse the cluster of historic buildings at Philipsburg Manor in Sleepy Hollow. A narrow bridge crosses over a pond, leading to a whitewashed fieldstone manor house. With its large wheel in the water, a weathered wooden mill sits at the foot of the bridge, and a rustic barn is off to the side.

title: So Many Bills to Consider, So Little Money
description: WITH attention at the Capitol focused squarely on state budget talks and union negotiations, it might be easy to forget that more than 100 new bills have been proposed since the General Assembly convened Jan. 8.

title: A Grizzly Task
description: For the Memphis Grizzlies, the bad-news bears of the National Basketball Association, November was the cruelest month. They lost their first eight games of the season, and then they lost their head coach, Sidney Lowe, an admirable man who at the end had the look of someone watching a car crash: shocked and appalled and powerless to change the fates.

title: Pride Was Behind Lawsuit, Woman at Heart of It Says
description: At first they called it McCain v. Koch. Over the next 20 years, the legal name of the lawsuit filed on behalf of the city's homeless families was changed three times as mayors came and mayors went. Through it all, McCain, their silent steadfast accuser, remained the same.

title: Devils Speed Hurricanes' Fall
description: If the Carolina Hurricanes continue their nose dive in the Eastern Conference, there is a good chance they will miss the playoffs in the spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, EDWARD
description: LIEBERMAN-Edward. Died at his home in Miami Beach, FL. He was 95 years old. Eldest son of Mary Duberstein. He was the beloved husband of the late Celia Kamenson. He is survived by a daughter, Linda Kramer of Westport, CT. and a son, Allan Lieberman of Roslyn, N.Y. and two grandsons, Shepard Kramer and Brian Lieberman. A graveside service was held at Temple Israel Cemetery, Norwalk, CT.

description: A new family has moved into the tan corner house on a well-kept street in the suburb of Kendall, southwest of Miami. Still, neighbors who pass by are more interested in remembering the girl who once lived there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBRE, KERRY X.
description: LeBre-Kerry X. Of Greenville, S.C., died of lung cancer on Dec. 30, at the age of 54. He was dearly loved by his niece, Yvette, & her husband, Michael Davis, and by his many friends in New York City, Florida, California, Arizona, Ecuador & South Carolina. His devoted friend, David Maizer, will miss him most of all.

Her collages were recognized as masterpieces after her death in 1987, but she was never part of the established art world. She taught herself to paint and draw, shunned gallery openings and signed her works on the back.

title: Roh or No?
description: In print, the name of the new president of South Korea is spelled Roh Moo Hyun. But in transcripts of broadcasts, the family name as spoken by American newscasters is spelled not Roh but Noh, reflecting the way it is pronounced. Which is it -- Roh, as in ''row your boat,'' or Noh, as in ''a thousand times, no''?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, OTTO L.
description: WALTER-Otto L. The Board of Directors of the German American Chamber of Commerce is deeply saddened by the apssing of its long-time friend and supporter, Otto L. Walter. He joined the Board of Directors of the Chamber in 1961 and continued to work tirelessly on German-American relations. He was an authority on international and tax law, a writer, a lecturer and philanthropist. His personal engagement combined with his experience and knowledge has been invaluable to the Chamber. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife and family. The Board of Directors, German American Chamber of Commerce E.A. Sekulow, Chairman W. Walbroel, President

title: Rebecca Felsen, William Sherman
description: Rebecca Ann Felsen is to be married today to William Alan Sherman. Rabbi Eli Fishman is to officiate at the Valley Regency, a caterer in Clifton, N.J.

title: To a Watchmaker, It's Fashion First
description: FOSSIL INC., along with competitors like Swatch, made a mark in the 1980's by ''fashionizing'' watches -- turning them into fashion accessories. But Fossil says its recently announced partnership with Microsoft to produce watches that can receive short text messages does not mean that it is now in the business of fashionizing geekware.

title: Cyclones Offer Season Tickets To the Public
description: The Brooklyn Cyclones will put full-season ticket packages on sale to the public tomorrow. The Cyclones, the Mets' Class A minor league affiliate, have already sold 3,000 season ticket renewals.

title: Risky Turn on Madison Avenue
description: THE printed advertisement showed water gushing through an opening in a dam. ''It could feel like this again,'' the accompanying text said. Puzzled? You probably wouldn't be if you knew where the ad appeared: in the men's restrooms of 100 or so restaurants in Minneapolis and St. Paul last year. The ads, sponsored by Medtronic, the medical device manufacturer, promoted a minimally invasive procedure that can be administered by a urologist to help relieve urinary discomfort from an enlarged prostate.

title: A Cheese Slice and a Dose of South Shore
description: PAPPALARDO'S PIZZA COVE is a shrine to the actor Steve Guttenberg. Signed, framed posters of his movies, from ''Three Men and a Baby'' to ''Cocoon'' and ''Police Academy 3,'' line the walls of the Italian restaurant in North Massapequa.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Martin Luther King's Birthday will be legally observed.

title: Tantalizing Visitors
description: FARRUQUITO -- There are flamenco dancers and then there is Juan Manuel Fernndez, the brooding, noble Gypsy known as Farruquito, who was the sensation of the first New York Flamenco Festival two years ago. Pure flamenco is a solo dance, and yet it is also a community affair. One looks forward to Farruquito's heartthrob appeal and virtuosity when he joins his younger brother Farruco and an array of other dancers at the new festival's opening night gala on Jan. 30 at City Center. On Feb. 2 he appears with Juana Amaya, a distinctive stylist on her own.

title: Young Tar Heels Manage to Fend Off Pressure by Huskies
description: The game had a minute and a handful of seconds to go, but it seemed as if the script had already been written. North Carolina had lost its huge lead, and the young Tar Heels and their tempestuous coach were sure to complete what was turning into a painful meltdown against the more established squad from Connecticut. The pressure was unmistakable. In the end, so was North Carolina's composure.
