title: The Apartment
description: John Dillinger saved my life, 68 years after his death by firing squad in a federal ambush outside the Biograph Theater in Chicago. J. Edgar Hoover had designated Dillinger public enemy No. 1 and ordered him shot on sight after the gangster humiliated the pug-faced Hoover by calmly machine-gunning his way past the Feds outside Apartment 303 of Lincoln Court in St. Paul, Minn. These days, I'm living in that hideout.

title: A Closer Look at the Mystery of College Admissions
description: ON a warm spring morning several years ago, the admissions committee at Wesleyan University took up the case of a candidate with seemingly impeccable credentials.

title: Questions for Frank Gehry
description: I really liked that Gehry turned down an offer to submit designs for a memorial at ground zero simply because he wouldn't be paid enough. Maybe his refusal to work for inadequate pay is a sign that we're now moving beyond the sensationalized sentiment surrounding Sept. 11.

title: 'Sweet Violence'
description: To the Editor:

title: Atop Mast, a Whole New World
description: Atop the mast of Oracle-BMW's USA-76, sea gulls fly by at eye level. Rangitoto, the volcanic island that towers over the Hauraki Gulf, looks a little smaller, a little less indomitable. Crew members down on deck look as tiny as pedestrians look from a 10-story window. And the ride is stomach-churning: a 5-degree wiggle on deck results in a swing of 10 feet up high. Let go of the mast and you're flying around like a tetherball.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the poet and critic D. J. Enright last Sunday omitted attribution for a phrase he used in a speech on Robert Graves at the University of Singapore in 1960 -- that all art begins ''in the foul rag and bone shop of the heart.'' It is the last line of a poem by Yeats, ''The Circus Animals' Desertion.''

title: Rio Grande Choice: Take City's Water Or Let Minnow Die
description: A three-inch-long endangered fish is standing between this city and its plans for a well-watered future.

title: So, Let the Rat Races Begin!
description: I HAVE developed a craving for the corporate cafeteria, the corporate desk, the water cooler and the copy machine. I want to wake up each day, deck myself in Armani and join the throngs of workers with a defined purpose, or at least have a place to go in the mornings besides Starbucks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSH, LOUIS, M.D.
description: BUSH-Louis, M.D. 92, peacefully on January 8, 2003. Practiced Family Medicine in Baldwin, L.I., and Pompano Beach, FL, for 45 years. Beloved husband of Selma Klein Bush for 64 years. Treasured father of Janet and Irwin Light, Joy and Thomas Gilmore, Donald and Chantal Bush. Adored grandfather of Alan and Sharon Light, Suzanne McElfresh, Alix-Anne, Maxence and Chloe Bush, and great-grandfather of Adam Light. Beloved son of the late Ralph and Jenny Bush. Cherished brother of the late Helen Spellens. Memorials may be made to The American Red Magen David for Israel, 888 7th Avenue, NY, NY 10106; or to a charity of one's choice.

title: LIEBERMAN SAYS 'I'M IN'
description: At a time when so many Democrats have been announcing that they might announce for president sometime later this year, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut skipped the preliminaries, declaring that he was absolutely and unequivocally running. As the party's candidate for vice president in 2000, Mr. Lieberman has the advantage of name recognition. As arguably the most conservative Democratic candidate, though, he has his work cut out for him. Adam Nagourney

title: Puzzling Out a Restaurant and Its Quirks
description: THE Rosewood Inn, a Melville newcomer in the quaint half-timbered building that last housed Nickles North, is a maze of contradictions. Just when a diner thinks he has a read on the place, it veers in another direction. Like its predecessor, it is a pub at heart. But its kitchen is capable of much more ambitious fare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, CORNELIA M.
description: ROBERTS-Cornelia M. On January 14, 2003 at age 100. Wife of the late William Bryce Roberts, born in Vienna, Austria 1902. Dear friend, excellent equestrian and American patriot. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 18 at 10AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Red Cross.

title: Maryam Sepahbodi, Christopher Barrett
description: Maryam Fatemeh Sepahbodi, the daughter of Shirin Sepahbodi of London and Parviz Sepahbodi of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Christopher Harold Barrett, a son of Sara and William J. Barrett of Rumson, N.J. In a civil ceremony on Bald Mountain in Sun Valley, Idaho, Robert J. Elgee, the Blaine County magistrate, officiated. The couple plan to have a religious ceremony on Feb. 1 at St. Bartholomew's Anglican Church in Gustavia on the island of St. Barts. The Right Rev. A. Theodore Eastman, the former Episcopal bishop of Maryland, is to lead the service.

title: Up the Down Slope on Skis
description: The most important parts of cross-country skiing are ''falling down and getting up,'' according to ''The Wimp's Guide to Cross-Country Skiing'' (1stBooks Library, October 2002), a new book by James B. Kobak Jr. of Jersey City.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Jan. 5 in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 3 of this section, with an article about bullish investors' modest expectations for the stock market, mislabeled returns for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, including reinvested dividends, over 10-year periods. The returns were annualized, not cumulative.

title: Snow Proves Itself A Friend to Plants
description: A SPRING-LIKE DAY more than a week ago melted all but a few patches of snow in my garden. And the stream that runs through our woods, so alarmingly low this summer, is now brimming with water. From Maine to Maryland, all that melted snow has helped bring reservoirs back up to normal, despite a drought that started last spring and didn't let up until those glorious fall rains.

title: COPYRIGHT LAW UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court does not often defer to Congress these days. But in copyright law, almost anything that Congress says goes. That was the message of a decision upholding the 1998 extension of existing copyrights by 20 years: perhaps it is an unwise law but clearly within Congress's prerogative, the majority said. Internet publishers and others had complained that Congress ignored the basic bargain of copyright law: creators (even of Mickey Mouse) enjoy a monopoly for a limited time and in return must share their work with the public. Linda Greenhouse

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWYER, ANDREW KNOX
description: DWYER - Andrew Knox. Born June 21, 1982, passed away suddenly on Friday, January 17, 2003. Beloved and adored son of Andrew and Cindy Dwyer of Hobe Sound, FL, and Bedford, NY, and brother of Nancy and Elly. A sophomore at Yale University, Andrew was a graduate of Rippowam Cisqua School and The Hotchkiss School. Grandson of the late Martin Dwyer and Mary Dwyer of Hobe Sound, FL, and the late Alex Kroll and Nancy and Red Gordon of Williamstown, MA. In addition to the immediate family, he is survived by many loving aunts, uncles and cousins. A Memorial Service will be held Tuesday, January 21, 11 AM, at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, NY. In lieu of flowers, please direct contriubtions to The Hotchkiss School, Lakeville, CT.

title: For a Kiss of Freshness
description: Those who swapped lowly Tic Tacs for curiously strong Altoids may enjoy the current wave of upscale, super-potent mouthwashes. Too concentrated for unceremonious Scope-style swigging, the new breath fresheners are meant to be mixed (a few drops in a cup of warm water) and swished. Floris, the English perfumer to the Queen, has just introduced Rose Mouthwash ($25 at Floris London in New York, 212-935-9100), a pink potion that leaves one's mouth tasting oddly like a minty flower bed. Eau de Botot ($10.99) takes a less genteel approach with a howitzer blast of cinnamon and ginger, while Archipelago Botanicals mixes mint with citrus in its Morning Mint Mouthwash ($10, both at Scrips Elixers in New York, 212-941-4600). Aveda's Breath Elixir comes in a portable vial for on-site touch-ups ($5 at Aveda stores). And D. R. Harris's magenta mouthwash was recently reintroduced ($25 at www.bigelow chemists.com), although the formula has been around since 1790. Apparently, halitosis is a problem with real history.

title: Private Sector; A Dodge Ram in the Tip Jar
description: Remember DaimlerChrysler's party at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit? It is always among the most lavish, in part because of its setting -- a 1929 firehouse near the Cobo convention center, where the show is held.

title: Boston Bungles Coln; Yankees Are Blamed
description: The ownership troika of the Boston Red Sox believes that the Yankees became the third wheel in the Bartolo Coln trade from the Montreal Expos to the Chicago White Sox to keep the Red Sox from getting him. The Yankees deny harboring an ulterior motive, but it does not matter who is right.

description: PARIS, Jan. 19  Francoise Giroud, a widely admired French journalist who co-founded the political weekly L'Express and later served as France's first minister of women's affairs, died on Sunday in the American Hospital of Paris. She was 86.

But to a group of determined 11- to 18-year-olds whose life mantra is ''practice, practice, practice,'' a summer with the violinist Itzhak Perlman is a dream come true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLMANN, MARTHA
description: HILLMANN - Martha, 94. Passed away in Naples, FL on January 3rd, 2003. Formerly of Brooklyn and Mattituck NY. She was born January 16th, 1908 in Bardonia to Alfred and Martha Kimpel. Martha is survived by her daughter Doris Guggliatta of Long Island, NY, sons Niles Hunold of Marco Island, FL and Dr. William Hillmann of Nokesville, VA, seven grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband, William, in 1972. He was a NYC Parks Department Foreman of Mechanics at five borough shops on Randalls Island. Burial will be at Pinelawn National Cemetery at a later date.

title: Raiders and Titans Revel in the Moment
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 18  One team has fallen inches short of a Super Bowl title. The other had its ride to the title game swiped by Cinderella two years in a row. The many layers to Sunday's American Football Conference championship game between the Tennessee Titans and the Oakland Raiders boil down to which team can seize a rare opportunity for greatness.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Fairfield Office Park Plan Progresses
description: FOR nearly seven years, a massive mixed-use project proposed for a 35-acre brownfield site in the Black Rock section of the town of Fairfield has been punted back and forth by three critical parties: the developers, Kurt Wittek and Arnold D. Stauber; the town; and the Connecticut Department of Transportation. The estimated cost of the project is now about $200 million.

title: 11 KILLED IN ISRAEL
description: Nine Palestinians and two Israelis were killed in a single day of violence last Sunday, as the conflict in Israel became entangled in the run-up to the Israeli elections scheduled for later this month. The violence followed an appeal by Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, for Palestinians to refrain from attacks on Israeli civilians. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon accused Mr. Arafat of trying to swing the election in favor of his more dovish opponents. Dexter Filkins

description: An answer in the Q&A column last Sunday about finding resources for history-related travel misstated an A&E Network Web address. It is www.aetntravel.com/tours/tours.asp.

title: Houston Gloomy About His All-Star Prospects
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 18  Allan Houston believes he is having his best season yet. His scoring is at a career high. He is atop the National Basketball Association in free-throw shooting at 91.9 percent, and though still not a stopper, he has improved his play on the defensive end.

title: The Return of 'Angels,' and Essays on the Blues
description: ANGELS IN AMERICA -- A decade after Tony Kushner's groundbreaking play about the politics and emotions of the AIDS crisis arrived on Broadway, it returns to a different social landscape. Mr. Kushner has adapted the two parts of his play, ''The Millennium Approaches'' and ''Perestroika,'' for HBO's six-hour production, scheduled for fall or winter and by far the most artistically promising and starry television event of the year. Directed by Mike Nichols, the cast includes Al Pacino as the homophobic homosexual Roy Cohn, Meryl Streep as a pill-popping Mormon housewife with a closeted husband and Emma Thompson as the Angel who serenely comments on it all. Film may suit Mr. Kushner's blend of the real and the feverishly imagined even better than theater.

title: After 3 Years, Wait for Answers on Seton Hall Fire Is Not Over
description: Three years have passed since a predawn fire ravaged a dormitory lounge at Seton Hall University, killing three freshmen. The mysteries about the fire are as deep and dark now as they were on Jan. 19, 2000.

title: The Way We Are
description: Who is John Galt? What's new, pussycat? Is that all there is? Who shot J. R.? Who are those guys? Quo vadis? To be or not to be? Dude, where's my car? Seriously, dude, where's my car?

title: A Place for Artists to Shoot the Breeze
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV announced last month that he would open an arts center, called the Baryshnikov Center for Dance, in 2004. It will occupy three floors in a new performing arts complex at 450 West 37th Street, with rehearsal studios, offices and access to a 300-seat theater. The center's board of advisers and participants includes Pedro Almodvar, the filmmaker, and Susan Sontag, the writer. Mr. Baryshnikov, who also announced the closing of his company, the White Oak Dance Project, talked about the plans with Ms. Sontag recently in a conversation taped at Mr. Baryshnikov's Manhattan apartment. Here are excerpts.

title: A Devil of a Marriage, Scarier Than Ever
description: When ''Rosemary's Baby'' came out in 1968, starring a coltish Mia Farrow as a young Upper West Side wife who suspects she's carrying Satan's spawn, it ushered in a decade of hugely popular films about children who were either demonically possessed (''The Exorcist'') or the Antichrist himself (the ''Omen'' series). The angry Vietnam-era generation gap those movies spoke to has become a distant memory, but a restored print of ''Rosemary's Baby,'' opening Friday at Film Forum in Manhattan, remains as fresh and scary as ever. Only now audiences may see it as a horror movie about marrying badly and discovering that there's hell to pay.

title: State 2-Mile Record For Sayville Senior
description: Brian Dalpiaz posted the fastest time in the nation this year for the second straight week when he won the two-mile run yesterday in 9 minutes 1.2 seconds in the Stanner Games at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan. Last week, Dalpiaz, a senior from Sayville High School on Long Island, ran 4:14.52 in winning the one-mile race at the Hispanic Games.

description: TESTED -- 2003 Yukon XL 2500 SLT

title: How Schools Are Trying To Avoid the 'Senior Slide'
description: THREE afternoons a week, Lindsey Tibbott leaves Phillipsburg High School and crosses over the Delaware River into Pennsylvania to take a class at Lafayette College in Easton.

title: On the Vaccine Scene
description: As an infectious-disease specialist, I will be called on to be vaccinated early to counter any terrorist smallpox attack. I believe the chances of this are vanishingly small and that the policy is primarily an effort to spread fear and build support for a war with Iraq. If I am vaccinated, I will be complicit with a policy I morally oppose and unnecessarily endanger my own health. (The vaccine is one of the most dangerous available.) Yet I feel dutybound to be available to those suffering adverse effects from the vaccine. Should I be vaccinated? Hal Martin, M.D., M.P.H., Minneapolis

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Office Vacancy Rates Continued to Rise in 2002
description: RECENT reports about New Jersey's office market all sound pretty much the same sour note: the situation is dismal, and not getting better fast.

title: 'Confucius' and Other Children's Books
description: CONFUCIUS

title: QUICK BITE/Summit; Comfort Food, to Go
description: Tired of tuna carpaccio with shaved fennel or yet another mediocre dish of pad thai? Cold weather means solid, comforting food like the macaroni and cheese at Towne Deli in Summit. This dish ($4.95 a pound) is made by the deli's chef, Rita Stravaskus, who says her secret is ''a lot of cheese.'' The crusty, buttery casserole is my madeleine, transporting me back to the meatless Fridays of childhood.

title: Fires in Canberra Kill 3 and Burn Many Homes
description: Wildfires erupting from forested hills killed three people and destroyed 388 houses here in Australia's capital on Saturday.

title: JOUSTING OVER KOREA
description: President Bush said he still wouldn't negotiate with North Korea, but suggested, for the first time, that if the nation gave up its nuclear weapons program he would consider offering a ''bold initiative'' of aid, trade openings and security guarantees. North Korea was unimpressed: they called the offer ''pie in the sky.'' But Washington seemed to be edging toward negotiations, and the North will soon face the choice of making bombs or making a deal. David E. Sanger

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 19, 2003
description: Weeks

title: Slopes So Snowy, So Close
description: IT may not have the prestige of Gstaad, or the 3,430-foot vertical drop of Whiteface Mountain in the Adirondacks, but Thunder Ridge Ski Area in Putnam County has one key advantage: it is less than an hour from anywhere in Westchester.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: FAYE DUNAWAY'S ''She's my daughter -- she's my sister -- she's my daughter and my sister'' speech may be camp, but it deserves more respect. It's easy to forget just how good Roman Polanski's CHINATOWN (1974) is. Robert Towne's screenplay is as smart as the picture is stylish, and the stars are in fine form. Jack Nicholson plays a 1930's Los Angeles private eye and Ms. Dunaway would be the quintessential classy dame who walks into his office, but someone pretending to be her walks in first. When they do meet, she likes him, even with his recent nose injury. The film's unlikely surface topic is city irrigation, but its real theme is corruption, and John Huston, as Ms. Dunaway's powerful father, makes a thrilling, sickening villain -- Sunday at 8 p.m., Sunday/Early Monday at 2 a.m. and Monday at 5:35 p.m. on AMC.

title: In a Small And Dark Art, A World of Grief
description: THE artist Hannelore Baron often remarked that she was afraid of large things, so she practiced small art, making delicate collages of fabric and spidery drawing, and strange, dark wooden boxes tied up with rags, wire and string. But within that small art, she managed to confront the largest things -- personal tragedy, the nightmare of history, the body's frailty and the origin of art in human spirituality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATIMS, RUTH, NEE OHSIE
description: KATIMS-Ruth, nee Ohsie. New Yorker, died January 13th, in Santa Monica, CA, a stroke victim. She is survived by three children, four grandchildren and her husband of 48 years. Funeral at Catskill New York, January 22. Memorial service: Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street, NYC scheduled, 4PM on January 23 so that her family, many friends, co-workers, and co-activists may gather, mourn her passing and rejoice in her life.

description: GORDON-Edward S., 65, founded the real estate firmbearing his name, and he died September 21, 2000. I want you to know how much you inspire and motivate me everyday. Everything I read about your life clearly demonstrates to me that I will always have tremendous respect and admiration for you. My goal in life is to be successful like yourself as a deal maker. NJY

title: Israel Waits For Godot
description: Maybe the most telling fact in this coming Israeli election is that at this moment of intense crisis, a tiny Israeli party, Green Leaf, which advocates the legalization of marijuana, could win one or two seats in the new parliament. Green Leaf's motto might as well be: since every other solution has been tried and failed, why not just get high?

title: Arts and Yuks In Snowtime
description: EVENING HOURS Correction: January 26, 2003, Sunday A picture caption with the Evening Hours column last Sunday about the International Women's Health Coalition dinner at the American Museum of Natural History on Jan. 16 misidentified the woman shown with George Soros. She was Maureen White, finance chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, not Ellen Chesler.

title: The Picture Man
description: EVERY photographer is a photographer of transition. The shutter blinks, confines history to a moment or a mood, but elsewhere, life moves on. The image left behind is part of a world that is already receding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, KIM
description: WILSON-Kim. Dear Kimmie, you will always be one of my sweetest, dearest friends. Bill and I and especially Harry will miss you. Love, Elizabeth Wright Kahane

title: The World; Nuclear War Strategists Rethink the Unthinkable
description: TO a world conditioned by the cold war to think of a nuclear exchange as Armageddon, it may appear somewhat comforting that the minor powers that have acquired (or may have acquired) the Bomb -- India, Pakistan, North Korea, Israel -- at least don't have enough Bombs to wipe out the world.

title: Misery Finds Company, Even Among The Rich
description: On Feb. 14, if all goes as planned, Bob Guccione's 17,000-square-foot town house on East 67th Street will be auctioned off downtown in the gilt rotunda of the New York Supreme Court, under the watchful, albeit painted, gazes of Hammurabi and Moses.

title: An East End Bordeaux
description: Readers often ask, what's the finest Long Island red or white you have tasted? Sometimes the wine springs instantly to mind; other times I check the records and phone back.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel's Fine Political Shades

title: In the East Village, an Unusual Bid to Fix Up a Firehouse . . .
description: A tiny white firehouse for Engine 28 and Ladder 11 sits on East Second Street between Avenues B and C. The firehouse's backyard is actually a lot at 222 East Third Street, a site formerly used as a paper refuse depot and later as a lumberyard.

title: Douglas Herrick, 82, Dies; Father of West's Jackalope
description: Douglas Herrick, who gets both the credit and the blame for perhaps the tackiest totem of the American West, the jackalope -- half bunny, half antelope and 100 percent tourist trap -- died on Jan. 6 in Casper, Wyo. He was 82.

title: Portraits, Fair and Square
description: Museum boxing, a photograph-mounting technique that was popular in the 1960's, is now being revived at Kate Burton Photography in New York, just in time for Valentine's Day. The museum boxes -- enlarged photographs mounted on wooden squares or rectangles -- provide a substantial and permanent way to display pictures that deserve more than being rotated in and out of a frame, and without the sittings and expense of a painted portrait. Ms. Burton's photography clients can choose among various sizes, from 5 by 7 inches all the way up to a 20-by-24-inch box ($120 to $190 at Kate Burton Photography, 212-717-9958).

title: New Interview Uniform: Gray Means Business
description: WHEN Jeff Wilcox, a Manhattan interior designer, was going to job interviews last fall, he fortified his arsenal of selling points by adding a novel counterpart to his carefully prepared rsum, design portfolio and firm handshake: a new custom-made gray suit.

title: A See-Through Library of Shifting Shapes and Colors
description: TIRED of special effects? How about special causes? That's what unbuilt architectural designs represent. Models and drawings need not be poor substitutes for completed buildings. They possess their own intrinsic interest. They are links in the chain of causality that produces, sustains and transforms major cities over time. And if a design is special enough, a city can take up the cause of getting it built.

title: Cozy Warmth and Pasta. Must Be Italian.
description: SET back from busy Post Road in Larchmont is a building that has been occupied by a string of restaurants. Diners may remember La Cote d'Argent, here for many years. Cocconatos and Pastore's followed, but were never quite able to catch diners' fancy. Now Savini has moved into the spot, in a village already densely populated with an embarrassment of dining choices. Can Larchmont use another Italian restaurant? Maybe.

title: Private Sector; Up for Auction at 92nd St. Y: Everything but a Nursery Spot
description: The 92nd Street Y collected $1.4 million through its black-tie corporate dinner and live auction on Wednesday at the Grand Hyatt in Manhattan. And, no, coveted spaces in its preschool were not on offer.

title: Of Seasons Long Past, And Stars of the Game
description: IT is 1946. The two young men gaze confidently at the camera. They are stars of the Newark Eagles, part of the Negro leagues, and it is the season when their team beats the Kansas City Monarchs to become the champions of those leagues.

title: Villanova Defeats Rutgers, And How
description: Less than two minutes into tonight's game, Rutgers trailed Villanova by 10-0, and the Scarlet Knights had already committed 4 turnovers. It was the beginning of a long game for Rutgers, one that got worse before it got better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSH, AL
description: RUSH-Al. Television industry leader for over 45 years peacefully passed away at home on January 14, 2003, in Beverly Hills, CA, age 76. He most recently served as Executive of Special Projects for Paramount Television Group and previously held a long career with MCA, becoming Chairman of MCA Television Group from 1986 to 1991. Also held Executive VP positions at NBC and NBC Sports. He will be fondly remembered for his communications expertise, strong personal ethics and the value he placed on the camaraderie of his colleagues. Al is survived by his three beloved sons Bruce (Lynn), Robert (Deirdre) and Jeffrey (Mary Ann), his seven treasured grandchildren, and cherished sister Rita Grobisen. For the last six years he was the devoted partner to Dale Engelson. He was a graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Law School. Funeral Services will be held on Tuesday, January 21, at First United Methodist Church, 1008 11th Street, Santa Monica, CA, at 12:30 PM.

title: Rivals Rally in Ivory Coast as Peace Talks Enter 4th Day
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 18 (Reuters)  Demonstrators on both sides of Ivory Coast's conflict held marches today, in shows of support for the government and rebels, as peace talks near Paris to end the civil war moved into a fourth day.

title: Somalia Talks Are Stormy, But They Still Inch Ahead
description: The peace talks unfolding here aimed at ending Somalia's long civil war have turned as chaotic as the country itself. Warlords are trying to oust the mediator. Hotels are threatening to evict delegates over unpaid bills. The police were recently ordered to expel the many Somalis who arrived without invitations.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Developers Are Building Numerous Rental Projects
description: IN the last three years, Long Island has built more rental housing than in any other such period since the 1970's. According to those in the industry, there is demand at both ends of the age spectrum: older people are selling their homes and looking to downsize and young professionals are attracted to a growing number of high-technology companies in the region.

title: New Suffolk Fights to Save Tiny School
description: AT the picturesque little red schoolhouse up on the hill in this tiny hamlet of 337 in the Town of Southold, it's all about the numbers. Not multiplication tables and long division, but enrollment numbers, tax levies and student-teacher ratios.

description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Airlines Experiment With Selling Food
description: Two airlines have begun trial programs to gauge whether passengers are interested in buying meals on flights.

title: The Dreaded Season
description: THESE cold January days mark the start of a dreaded season: College Limbo of the High School Senior. From January through April, high school seniors like me suffer from a common ailment, which causes confusion, anxiety and frustration. It is a malady called College Decision Disorder, which a majority of American high school seniors will go through this winter -- nearly three million of us, according to the National Center for Education Statistics. We will endure three interminable months, waiting for the letters that will decide our fate.

title: Woolly And Wild
description: New Yorkers were snug in their copies of the chullo, the Peruvian and Bolivian knitted stocking cap with ear flaps and a pointed crown. The originals were made from llama wool, known for its extra warmth. The design dates back 1,000 years and can be seen on ancient Inca pottery. Today, street vendors sell versions produced all over the world. John Galliano, designing for Dior, took the hat, added a rainbow Mohawk crest (right) and trimmed the ear flaps with tassels, creating a chullo that sells for $400 and up. Timid knockoffs (below) are already sprouting, crest and all.

title: Runaway, 14, Is Found Fatally Stabbed at L.I.R.R. Station
description: A 14-year-old runaway died early Friday morning after he was found unconscious and bleeding on the steps of the Long Island Rail Road station in Hempstead, the police said yesterday.

title: Absolutely, Positively For Capital Punishment
description: NO one was surprised when prosecutors and families of crime victims denounced Gov. George Ryan of Illinois for commuting the death sentences of 167 prisoners last weekend. But some of the loudest voices condemning the Republican's decision came from a less-expected quarter: Democratic politicians, including several candidates running for the party's presidential nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAWYER, CARL
description: SAWYER-Carl. Died Thursday, January 9, 2003 in San Francisco. New York born, he was an engineering graduate from Columbia University, his first marriage being to Barbara Bel Geddes with one issue, Mrs. Susan McLellan. Two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren survive as do two sisters, Doris Weever and Vilma Potterton and one brother, Robert Schreuer. A second spouse, Helen Rhinelander-Sawyer of St. Lunaire, France also survives. Turning to the theater in the 1950's he co-produced ''Thirteen Daughters'' on Broadway. The idea of a dinner theater was his and bore fruit with the Meadowbrook Dinner Theater in New Jersey. In Sacramento he managed Music Circus in the Round and the musicals at the California State Fair in collaboration with Howard and Young. He then managed the touring company of ''Camelot'', with Richard Burton and went on for many years to undertake the same role for Marcel Marceau in his American tours. With San Francisco as his base, he worked as manager of the Curran Theater and helped in the revival and managing of the Orpheum Theater. He will always be fondly remembered by friends and theaterfolk worldwide for his professionalism and for his joie de vivre and bon vivant charm.

title: Questions for Frank Gehry
description: I wonder how many of the secretaries and other office workers who died in the World Trade Center even made $40,000 a year. For their families, I think Gehry has redefined the word ''demeaning.''

title: Executive Life; No, I Insist: You Pick Up the Check
description: EVERYBODY knows that companies have cut their employees' expense accounts in this sputtering economy. But it took a lunch with four other business travelers during a trade show last fall in Los Angeles for Hal Bringman, a public relations executive, to witness close up the new tightfistedness of his fellow executives.

title: The Secrets, And Lies, Of Families
description: 'LONG DAY'S JOURNEY INTO NIGHT' -- Eugene O'Neill's masterwork is the ''King Lear'' of the American theater -- a play of such intensity, gravity, unwieldiness and, yes, greatness that if a production hits even half of its depth-charging dramatic notes, it's a big deal. The odds are automatically improved in this spring's Broadway production, however, by the participation of Vanessa Redgrave, who is portraying the morphine-sneaking mother and who is famous for fearlessly burrowing into darkness to bring a character to light. The promising cast is rounded out by Philip Seymour Hoffman and Robert Sean Leonard as the unhappy brothers and, as their swashbuckling, penny-pinching dad, Brian Dennehy, who collaborated to stunning effect with this production's director, Robert Falls, on ''Death of a Salesman.''

title: Time for Decision on Iraq Is Nearing, White House Says
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Top officials of the Bush administration today rejected calls for a prolonged inspections process in Iraq, asserting that the moment of decision was fast approaching on whether Saddam Hussein's regime had complied with the disarmament demands from United Nations Security Council.

title: No Hard Time for Prison Budgets
description: Gov. Gray Davis's proposed budget for the coming fiscal year left virtually no state program immune from the pain. State subsidies for homeless shelters will be slashed. Artificial limbs will no longer be provided for impoverished amputees. Welfare payments to the blind will be cut. College students will pay higher fees.

title: EMPTY WARHEADS FOUND
description: Less than two weeks before they are to report on what they have found in their first 60 days in Iraq, United Nations weapons inspectors found 11 empty chemical warheads at an ammunition storage depot. White House officials called the discovery ''serious and troubling,'' and said time was running out for Saddam Hussein. But the inspectors, at a news conference, said that their goal was to avoid war and that they would ask the Security Council for more time to do their job.

title: Concern Tempers Tappan Zee Plans
description: CAROLYN SWENSON, who has two small children, bought her house 10 years ago in Landing, a waterfront neighborhood in Tarrytown where the Tappan Zee Bridge ends on the east bank of the Hudson. She wishes she hadn't.

title: Two Months After Oil Spill, Spain Is Still Struggling to Clean Up
description: Two months after the tanker Prestige sank 133 miles off the Spanish coast, more than 5,000 soldiers and civilians continue the backbreaking task of scraping gluey fuel oil from sand and rocks stained by ''black tides.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, MURIEL
description: SHAPIRO-Muriel. Memorial to celebrate her life at Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St., Saturday, January 25th at 1:30 PM.

title: Police Officer Is Suspended After Escape
description: A police officer was suspended early yesterday after a prisoner he was guarding at North Central Bronx Hospital walked away from the area where he was being treated, the authorities said.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Under the River

title: How to Beat Nike
description: High-tech research and hip advertising mean little when your product is made in sweatshops (Seth Stevenson, Jan. 5). The success of New Balance might be only about comfort and simplicity, or it could be partly a result of consumers making conscious decisions about what they buy and where it was made. Nike would do well to listen up.

title: Breast Cancer Service Finds Few to Serve
description: HEWLETT HOUSE faced a steady stream of obstacles as Nassau County transformed it into a breast cancer resource center. The old landmark, a 1720's farmhouse built by the area's original white settlers, was more dilapidated than it looked, and the renovations that began in 1998 wound up costing $1.5 million, triple the estimate.

title: Its Bankruptcy Incomplete, Kmart Changes Chiefs
description: With its bankruptcy reorganization still incomplete, Kmart's chief executive, hired to lead the company out of its financial distress, is stepping down, Kmart said today.

title: Broadway Comes to Moscow, and Takes on the Risks
description: IT sounded like a great idea. Importing an American musical to a Moscow hungry for Western culture and maybe rich enough to pay top ticket prices.

title: Foul Weather Brings a Cargo of Ice to a Latvian Port
description: Wind lashed the standing ships, held in place by a strange new invader that has taken this Latvian port -- quite literally -- by storm.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Fifth Wheel

title: Alinghi Victory Sets Up America's Cup Showdown With New Zealand
description: In a thrilling finish, the Swiss team Alinghi defeated the American syndicate Oracle-BMW Racing today to win the Louis Vuitton Cup, the challenger series to the America's Cup.

title: U.S.O.C. Chief Is Still Troubled
description: The chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee, Lloyd D. Ward, emerged from an ethics investigation last week with his job intact, but he is faced with senators who want answers, working relationships that need mending and an NYC2012 bid that could be threatened by the organization's tainted image.

title: Memo to the Democrats: Quit Being Losers!
description: This fall, for the second time in a row, the Democratic Party lost an election it should have won. Democrats offered no rationale for why they should be running the country and no vision for how they would run it. The party got the drubbing it deserved. I enjoyed watching.

title: ... and Making a Precinct True Blue for the Viewers
description: For 10 seasons, Anne Johnson has made an avid habit of watching ABC's cop drama ''N.Y.P.D. Blue,'' which is filmed mostly in California. But Ms. Johnson catches herself smiling whenever she sees an exterior of its gritty 15th Police Precinct station house, with its sunburst windows and steel double doors. Like many members of Community Board 3, she knows that the six-story building is actually in the Ninth Police Precinct at 321 East Fifth Street, between First and Second Avenues.

title: Oscar's New Home Is Offering Tours
description: The Kodak Theater in Hollywood, which became the new home of the Academy Award presentations last year, has started offering 30-minute guided behind-the-scenes tours.

title: The Fire Alarm Box: Rich Past, but What Future?
description: Earlier this month, Mayor Bloomberg spoke of removing all 15,077 fire alarm boxes from city streets, on the grounds that more often than not they were used to transmit false alarms.

title: New Link Opens (at Last) to Boston's Airport
description: Its construction snarled traffic and infuriated drivers and pedestrians here for more than a decade. But this afternoon, traffic finally started flowing through a new connector linking the Massachusetts Turnpike, Interstate 90, with Logan Airport.

title: Private Funds Lag, Report Says
description: The annualized returns of private equity funds over the last 20 years have slipped below the 15 percent minimum expected by most venture capital investors, according to Jesse Reyes, vice president of Thomson Venture Economics.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Critic's Notebook article last week about two new books on the career of Ralph Lauren misidentified the one that discussed a critical review by the Times article's writer, Cathy Horyn, dealing with Mr. Lauren's fall 2000 collection. That book was ''Genuine Authentic'' by Michael Gross, not a 1988 biography of Mr. Lauren by Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg.

title: It's O.K. to Reach for Unreachable Star Managers
description: INVESTORS are behaving rationally when they engage in apparently pointless searches for mutual fund managers who can beat the market over the long run, according to a new study.

title: Where Composers Still Held Sway, From Underground
description: THE festival ''Masterpieces of the Russian Underground,'' presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center beginning on Friday, explores a Russian phenomenon unknown in the West: music by proscribed composers. The flip side of this peculiarity is a paradox: the same composers enjoyed a national influence and prestige seldom attained by composers in other lands.

title: Making Art Around the Hearth While Warding Off the Chill
description: EVERY Wednesday night in his hometown, Winnipeg, Manitoba, Marcel Dzama packs up his supplies -- pencil crayons, acrylic paints and whatever else he can grab -- and walks the half-dozen blocks to his friend Michael Dumontier's house.

title: BERGEN COUNTY THREATENS TO SUE
description: Bergen County Executive Dennis McNerney last week joined a chorus of officials calling for the closing of the Indian Point nuclear plant in Buchanan, N.Y., until improvements are made to disaster plans that a consultant's report called ''inadequate'' in case of an accident or a terrorist attack. Mr. McNerney threatened a lawsuit if the two reactors were not shut down voluntarily. He directed his emergency management team to evaluate dangers to Bergen County residents, who live within 50 miles of the plant, and told emergency management and public safety officials to report within 30 days on the county's ability to respond to an emergency there. George James

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIST, VERA G.
description: LIST-Vera G. A memorial service for New School University trustee Vera List will be held on February 4, 2003 at 10:30 AM in the John L. Tishman Auditorium at New School University, 66 W 12 St. If you are able to join President Bob Kerrey, Board Chairman Philip Scaturro and the University Community in celebrating Vera's life, please RSVP to Katherine Fields at 212-229-5878

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HEIFERMAN, CELIA, (NEE FRIEDMAN)
description: HEIFERMAN-Celia, (nee Friedman). It has been one sad and lonely year since the death of our beloved Mother, Grandmother and Great-Grandmother. She was a gentle and gallant lady who was admired by all who knew her and deeply loved by those lucky enough to have known her well. She left us a legacy of love and a lifetime of treasured memories of her warmth, wisdom and laughter. She is deeply missed by us, her family, and always will be.

title: Commission to Urge Freezing Some Medicare Payments
description: To slow the growth of Medicare, an influential federal advisory panel will soon recommend that Congress freeze payments to nursing homes and home care agencies and reduce the cost-of-living allowance that hospitals are scheduled to receive next year.

title: Pragmatic Ladies, New York Rockers
description: INDEPENDENT WOMEN -- Call them rhythm-and-blues women, call them neo-soul or call them the voices of sanity and pragmatism. Under any label, the ladies have consistently provided innovative music and hard-headed responses to the tough-guy and Casanova fantasies of hip-hop. They're the hedonists and the working moms, the bohemians and the teachers; they're self-invented but not self-absorbed. And they can sing. In a coincidence of career rhythms, many were silent in 2002 and have albums due this year. Among them are the solo debut of Beyonc Knowles, the ''independent woman'' leader of Destiny's Child, along with new albums from Macy Gray, Erykah Badu, Mary J. Blige, Lauryn Hill, Kelis, Monica and Kelly Price -- a cornucopia of possibilities.

title: And Bear in Mind
description: FAT LAND: How Americans Became the Fattest People in the World, by Greg Critser. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) Americans have increased their daily average intake by 200 calories in two decades, Critser says. Elementary! And the food industry has helped them by discovering ways to get people to eat more and feel good about it.

title: Communing With Nature on the 8:15
description: LATELY I have been a more aggressive commuter. Every morning, at the Cortlandt train station on the Metro-North line, I will leave the waiting room a full five minutes before the train is due.

title: He Said, She Said: When Insiders Share a Pillow
description: HOLLY loves Michael. Holly marries Michael. Holly researches stocks. Michael trades stocks. Maybe they share secrets. Maybe they cash in. Federal authorities investigate them.

title: Where Hospitality Is an Oasis
description: ''FORGET about the problems between America and the Muslim world -- tonight you are a Mauritanian,'' Alyen Ould Nolkhayatt said, motioning for me to eat my dinner.

title: DataBank; Markets Slide on Flat Economic Prospects
description: It was the first losing week of the year for the three major stock indexes, as indifferent prospects for technology bellwethers and worries about the economy rattled the markets.

title: Introduction
description: There was a compelling blueprint in Michael Ignatieff's article, many said, for the conversation we all should be having about America's new role in the world. The hot-button issue, though, was Frank Gehry's refusal to put out a ground zero plan for what he said was a paltry $40,000.

title: CRACKDOWN ON ILLEGAL DOCKS
description: State environmental officials are moving against the owners of 93 docks placed on state-owned tidelands without permits and licenses. They could face orders for removal or have to pay back rent. Most of the docks are in Monmouth and Ocean counties, where biologists have warned about damages to clam beds and fish habitat from dredging and from oil and gas leaked by boats using the docks. Officials of the state Department of Environmental Protection said that some violation notices dated back to 1991 and that the origins of 80 more docks were being investigated as part of a renewed enforcement effort. Jeremy Pearce

title: Inside and Out in Suffolk County Politics
description: LAUREN FORTMILLER, the first woman to be elected mayor of Sag Harbor, said she received telephoned death threats in September 2001 after she did not jump to reappoint the village's police chief. Picketers marched in front of her office, and insults were shouted at her from passing pickup trucks, she recalled.

title: It's Back to Competition For Jenny Thompson
description: KAREN GATELY had been told what to expect before the meet between her swim club, the Boston-area Gators, and the Badger Swim Club of Larchmont in early November. While there was nothing unusual about the meet, there was the matter of the swimmer on the next starting block. It was Jenny Thompson.

title: Hughes and Cohen No Match For Kwan's Grace and Style
description: Michelle Kwan came to a soft stop, smiled and raised her arms with the effortlessness of a breath. The audience, hypnotized by her elegance, rose and erupted in response.

title: Excelling in Science Doesn't Hurt Students
description: In ''The Cost of Winning at Science'' [opinion, Jan. 12] the author states that he is appalled when he hears about high school students entering science contests like Intel and Siemens. Frankly, I find the author's opinion appalling, in addition to being filled with inappropriate allegations of elitism.

Schlesinger Jr., the 70's pop duo Ashford and Simpson and a bedraggled man in overalls who sat surrounded by a brood of plastic shopping bags. The East Side matrons swathed in mink, the graying ponytailed musicians and even the sprinkling of children at St. Peter's Church on East 54th Street last Sunday would have made Daphne Hellman smirk with quiet satisfaction.

title: Which Clothes Make Which Man?
description: LONG ISLAND men are not famous for their sense of fashion. A few stylish ones may be spotted in the Hamptons during the season. But, in general, men's clothes stopped evolving here when Archie Bunker was the best-dressed man on television.

description: Richard Crenna, the prolific actor who went from being a child performer in radio and eventually progressed to roles of complexity and nuance in serious films, died Friday morning in Los Angeles. He was 76.

description: ONE year ago, a 50-inch Hitachi television cost $1,400 at Circuit City. It costs $1,000 today.

title: BUSH FAULTS PREFERENCES
description: President Bush had no legal obligation to insert himself into the most important affirmative action case in 25 years, but in the end he decided he could not stay away from such an important issue. His lawyers told the Supreme Court that the affirmative action programs for admissions to the undergraduate and law schools at the University of Michigan were unconstitutional because they relied too heavily and directly on race and unfairly penalized white applicants. The Supreme Court will have the final say this spring. Neil A. Lewis

title: One-Vehicle Gridlock: Hummer Arrives In the City
description: There are certain disadvantages to being an urban Hummer dealer.

title: From Ground Zero To Gehry's Disney
description: ROLAND BETTS -- From ancient Egypt to corporate America, great art and architecture are the only decent forms of propaganda the status quo has ever come up with. That is why many New Yorkers are looking to Roland Betts as the pivotal figure in determining the future of Ground Zero. A board member of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and a co-owner of Chelsea Piers, Mr. Betts was a Yale classmate of George W. Bush. Until Mr. Betts persuaded the development agency to try architecture for a change, city and state officials were taking the low road. That risky instinct paid off with new designs of historical importance. My instinct is to believe that he will deliver on the high level of expectations his agency has raised.

title: Holmes Loses the Hat, and Watson Gets Hip
description: WHAT would you call a ''great, black beast, shaped like a hound, yet larger than any hound that ever mortal eye has rested upon'' that bays its unearthly cries across the lonely moor on nights such as this? How, pray tell, would you greet this ''foul thing'' when it ceased its infernal howling and turned its ''blazing eyes and dripping jaws'' in your direction?

title: Ach du Lieber! Don't You Wish ber Was Over?
description: QUESTION: Does the use of a German prefix meaning ''super'' make you sound hip, or does the use of ''ber'' make you sound like a goober? Either way, you're in plentiful company, as the sampling below, from just the past month, suggests.

title: Keeping Pace With Its Fancier Neighbor
description: REIN has pretzels, caviar and everything in between. The pretzels were in an addictive peanut and cracker mix that came with drinks at the Garden City Hotel's new No. 2 restaurant. The sevruga caviar was stuffed into four tiny fingerling potatoes. The pretzels, nuts and crackers cost nothing. The caviar goes for $24. There were also $12 and $15 entrees and dishes that were alternately earthy and elegant on what is perhaps Long Island's most refined, rarefied bar menu.

title: The Outback, Tamed
description: RIDING in air-conditioned luxury through one of the world's most inhospitable environments can be a tad surreal. Savoring my grilled tenderloin medallion and cabernet in the dining car while crossing Australia by train, I remembered reading that the surrounding countryside was in the grips of a drought so severe that wild camels had resorted to licking dew off train tracks in order to survive. My meal suddenly seemed all the more appealing.

title: SHAKE-UP AT AOL
description: Stephen M. Case, the architect of AOL's acquisition of Time Warner just two years ago, resigned as chairman of AOL Time Warner, bowing to protests from shareholders angry over the merger's dismal performance. Richard D. Parsons, the company's chief executive, was named to succeed Mr. Case, at left, who will step down in May. Mr. Parsons, the soft-spoken president of Time Warner at the time of the merger, was largely pushed aside in its aftermath. David D. Kirkpatrick

title: Deals and Discounts
description: AMTRAK ROLLBACK -- A reduction of up to 25 percent in many coach fares was recently announced by Amtrak. Between New York and Atlanta, for example, the new fare is $84, down from $110; from Miami to New York, it's $66 (previously $88); Seattle to San Francisco is $76 ($101). And as part of Amtrak's Winter Promotion, there is a free companion fare along those same routes, making the New York-Atlanta fare equal to $42 a person, for two passengers. If you can't find a companion, Amtrak will still take another 25 percent off the already-discounted fares as part of the winter special. The Winter Promotion portion of the discounts applies for travel through Aug. 28, with purchase by Feb. 15. None of the price cuts apply to Northeast Corridor trains. Information: (800) 872-7245 or www.amtrak.com. Fares are nonrefundable and other restrictions apply.

title: Trial Date Set for Palestinian Leader
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 19  An Israel court today brushed aside the contention of Marwan Barghouti, a Palestinian leader, that it had no right to try him, setting a trial date of April 6 on charges of involvement in attacks that left 26 people dead and many others wounded.

title: Family Vacations
description: To the Editor: ''The golden age of the Wetherell vacation'' does not have to be ''a thing of the past.'' With careful juggling of music camps, sleep-away camps, wilderness adventure programs, university science programs for high school kids, kids' part-time and full-time summer jobs, high school cross-country training, and marching band camp, the last day of school, the first day of school, spouse's vacation time and your vacation time, it is still possible to find a magical window of opportunity for the beloved family vacation.

title: POSTINGS: Estimating Construction Spending in City; For 2003 and '04, It's 2002 Redux
description: Construction spending in New York City is expected to remain essentially the same this year and next as it was in 2002, at slightly more than $15 billion annually, according to a report by the New York Building Congress, a private coalition of contractors, subcontractors, developers, architects, engineers and skilled workers. The figure, though, is considerably higher than the $10 billion a year in the mid- to late 1990's.

title: Co-op's Ability to Charge for Storage
description: Q -- Our 123-unit co-op has always provided free storage for trunks, luggage and bicycles. Now the board has announced plans to renovate the storage room and install shelving for the trunks and luggage and hooks for bikes. The luggage storage will still be free, but there will be a charge of $120 a year for the bicycles. Our proprietary lease states, ''If the lessor shall furnish to the lessee any storage bins or space . . . the same shall be deemed to have been furnished gratuitously by the lessor and under a revocable license.'' Is the board's decision to charge selectively for storing bicycles legal? . . . Gail B. Kraushar, Manhattan.

title: G.M. Primps for Its Return to the Midsize Ball
description: EAGER to rekindle some of the passenger-car magic it lost long ago, General Motors is conjuring up new automobiles to assault the midsize market it once dominated.

title: The Familiar Face That Nobody Knows

description: FOR almost 30 years, officials at Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford have wanted to make runway safety improvements that would have involved expanding the airport. The issue became particularly heated in 1994 after a crash on a foggy April night resulted in the deaths of eight people aboard a chartered flight from Atlantic City.

title: Squeezing High Style In a Package That's Low
description: ''I THINK of pigs, who are fat but have delicate little feet,'' said Susan Orlean, the author of ''The Orchid Thief,'' which is the focus of the new movie ''Adaptation.'' She was speaking of two stools woven of honey-colored fiber, one round, one square, both of them plump. They stand 17 1/2 inches high and perch on tiny metal legs. The stools not only possess shapes that delight her, but they also satisfy her philosophy of life.

title: The Burden
description: I am uncertain whether you published Ignatieff's article to incite debate or because you believe its hawkish stance. Certainly it is well written and contains some good observations about the beneficial outcomes of past wars. Its moral interpretation of present events (and perhaps past ones) assumes, however, that the Bush administration is acting out of an imagined and noble democratic ethic, rather than for the financial gain of its funders: American energy and military industries.

title: In Milan, Beau Brummell Vs. Dirk Diggler
description: Masculinity is a lot easier to put across when times are fat and money is flowing. Good economies give men a lot more latitude in how they present themselves and fewer jitters about how they are perceived. The fact of having capital is, in itself, considered a nearly Darwinian marker of success and, by inference, virility.

title: 80 CHILDREN MISSING
description: Workers with the state Division of Youth and Family Services were searching late last week for 80 missing children who may have been victims of abuse. The search for a total of 280 children was ordered as Governor McGreevey declared a state of emergency after a Newark child was found dead in a storage bin. Workers said they had found 200 and were checking records in schools and hospitals on 80 children still missing. A spokesman for the state Department of Human Services said that child abuse had been verified in six of the cases, but that all the cases remained under review. Jeremy Pearce

title: Business; Readers, Like Investors, Are Tiring of C.E.O.'s

''For me to be able to sing a great song and not have someone hire a choreographer or have to worry about my image -- it's much purer.''

title: Preventing the Next North Korea

title: The Spa Owner
description: Ji Baek dresses more like a spa guest than a spa owner, even when she is working overtime. Next month, Ms. Baek, a 32-year-old manicurist who owns the Rescue Nail Spa as well as two Rescue Beauty Lounges in New York City, will come out with her own line of nail polishes. (They will become available next month at Fred Segal in Los Angeles.) Her packed schedule does not cramp her style. ''Comfort is not an issue for me,'' Ms. Baek said. ''I wear heels every day. I've been known to wear cocktail dresses at 10 in the morning.'' High heels may be the only constant element in Ms. Baek's personal style catalog. ''I love changing my look,'' Ms. Baek said. ''I'll be brushing my teeth and think: 'It's a preppy day. I'm going to wear a kilt and look like a schoolgirl.' '' This winter, Ms. Baek has been rotating creamy whites and ladylike yellows, as well as the pink ensemble shown here, which consists of a Smashing Grandpa tank top ($30 at www.rescuebeauty.com); Marc Jacobs cargo pants ($550 at Marc Jacobs, New York; 212-924-6126); and hot pink cashmere socks nestled into Prada pumps ($510 at Prada stores). A Chanel jacket ($2,080 at Chanel stores) and a hard-to-find Herms Birkin bag add weight to the whimsy. ''Color intrigues me because that's my work,'' Ms. Baek said. ''I rarely wear all black.'' JENNIFER TUNG

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: COLLECTED POEMS, by James Merrill. Edited by J. D. McClatchy and Stephen Yenser. (Knopf, $27.50.) This gigantic volume reveals the poet's absorption of human experience in all its shapes and sizes, and his delight in reporting it from every conceivable point of view. In 2001 our reviewer, Daniel Mendelsohn, praised both the formal skill and emotional intensity of Merrill's work, saying ''his lyrics . . . have a lapidary smoothness and mosaic fit that recall not his beloved Greeks but, if anyone, the Roman lyricist Horace -- another poet who was haunted by the specter of time and death even as he puckishly pursued the pleasures of life.''

title: Streetscapes/The East Side of Madison Avenue Between 69th and 70th Streets; Remnants of a Wealthy Past, Now Hidden by Retail
description: IN the 1880's, Madison Avenue at the crown of Lenox Hill was the home of the East Side's royalty, with capacious town houses facing one of New York's most exclusive residential streets. The east side of the block between 69th and 70th Streets still bears architectural traces of that past, although the lower floors have been stripped away by storefronts. Now two major changes are under way.

But to the 12,600 people who live within 10530, Hartsdale is very much its own locality.

title: Take Heart. Spring Is in the Bag.
description: As a sunny antidote to the bleak cold of winter, handbag designers have come out with bright yellow pocketbooks in their resort and spring collections. Providing greater visual punch than last year's winter whites and neutrals, these vivid bags are made in a variety of shapes, sizes and skins like calfskin, nubuck and lizard. A buttery shoulder bag by Henry Cuir (top left, $995 at Barneys New York) has natural-leather detailing, while Ferragamo's entry (center, $520 at Ferragamo stores) offers generous shoulder straps and a sweetly fringed top. Coach's lemon lizard clutch (bottom left, $650 at Coach stores) has a slick, lean look that evokes 70's club-hopping. A neatly structured shopping bag by Lambertson Truex is practical yet chic (top right, $795 at Saks Fifth Avenue). Hogan's Shopping Coulisse (bottom right, $645 at Hogan stores) is fitted with a drawstring-closure silk handkerchief lining and has been ordered by Selma Blair and Liv Tyler, which, in the world of fashion, is almost enough to turn yellow to gold.

title: U.S. Accelerates Its Efforts To Build a Case Against Iraq
description: The Bush administration, concerned that a ''smoking gun'' may never be found in Iraq, is urgently assembling an argument that Baghdad's withholding of weapons information, and its refusal to make scientists freely available, should persuade American allies to back the use of force against Saddam Hussein.

Standing there, he knows it will turn pale blue when the sun appears to work its magic.

title: When There Was No Traffic, and No L.I.E.
description: LONG before there was a Long Island Expressway, or a Hampton Jitney, people were traveling around Long Island, and many wrote down their impressions. Natalie Naylor, a retired history professor at Hofstra University and former director of its Long Island Studies Institute, has collected some of these writings in ''Journeys on Old Long Island: Travelers' Accounts, Contemporary Descriptions and Residents' Reminiscences, 1744-1893,'' published by the institute late last year.

title: One Museum, One Not-Museum
description: DIA BEACON -- Opening in May in a former Nabisco factory on the banks of the Hudson River, 60 miles north of New York City, this new museum, housing the Dia Center's collection, enshrines for the first time a generation of artists who came of age in the 1960's and 70's. Large-scale works by Donald Judd, Dan Flavin, Hanne Darboven, Gerhard Richter, Michael Heizer and others will get the room they always needed and rarely, if ever, got. The place has already inspired opportunists in the art world to put down stakes in Beacon, N.Y., anticipating (rightly, probably) that Dia will make this unlikely town a pilgrimage spot for global art lovers.

Even vastly superior forces of invaders are ultimately defeated by the passions and ''territorial imperatives'' of local cultures.

title: TRUCK SPEED LIMIT QUESTIONED
description: State Transportation Commissioner Jack Lettiere applied the brakes last week to a proposal to reduce the speed limit of commercial trucks on New Jerseys highways to 55 m.p.h. from 65. Legislators introduced the bill after truck accidents in November on Interstates 78, 80 and 287 killed three motorists and injured six. But Mr. Lettiere said that reducing truck speeds would probably lead to accidents at highway entrances and exits and to a single lane for truck travel. The bill, which would affect trucks weighing more than 10,000 pounds, follows similar legislation passed in Michigan, Ohio, Illinois, California and Oregon. Jeremy Pearce

title: Blacks Being Themselves, Not Symbols
description: IN the closing weeks of 2002, as in Decembers past, I saw more movies than I can remember, though I'm happy to say that a lot of them turned out to be quite memorable. Some have already gone on to collect critics' prizes and Golden Globe nominations, and will continue to be analyzed, debated and discussed in the fallow weeks leading up to the announcement of the Academy Award nominations next month. In the midst of all this thunder and bombast, however, I retain a special fondness for the lively rhythms of a low-budget picture called ''Drumline,'' made without big stars or grandiose ambitions, which opened on Dec. 13, just before the stampede of designated Oscar contenders.

title: January 12-18
description: EMPTY WARHEADS FOUND — Less than two weeks before they are to report on what they have found in their first 60 days in Iraq, United Nations weapons inspectors found 11 empty chemical warheads at an ammunition storage depot. White House officials called the discovery "serious and troubling," and said time was running out for Saddam Hussein. But the inspectors, at a news conference, said that their goal was to avoid war and that they would ask the Security Council for more time to do their job.

title: DOCTORS PROTEST
description: Doctors around the state plan to stop work on Feb. 3 to protest rising malpractice insurance costs. Elective surgery and other nonemergency procedures will have to wait that day. But Dr. Robert S. Rigolosi, president of the Medical Society of New Jersey, said in a statement last week that doctors would still deliver babies and continue urgent care, such as treatment for cancer. The medical society has not officially endorsed the job action, and it was not clear how many of the state's 24,000 doctors would take part. Physicians around the nation have long sought caps on financial awards in malpractice suits as higher insurance premiums continue to prompt doctors to leave or restrict their practices. Governor McGreevey said in a statement that a work stoppage was not the way to encourage legislators to act. George James

title: Eccentric Italian

title: On Top of the World At Jungfraujoch
description: THE Jungfrau, the Mnch and the Eiger, all in a row on Switzerland's Jungfrau massif, are among the world's mythic peaks, rising above the Bernese Oberland: a mountaineer's dream, a coveted view from an Alpine room, a distant vision from Bern to the Lake of Thun. The Jungfrau, 13,642 feet, is admired for its elegant white beauty. (Jungfrau means virgin.) The 13,449-foot Mnch has a rounded summit. The forbidding north face of the Eiger, one vertical mile of sheer rock and ice, the place where Clint Eastwood swung on a rope, has claimed many lives. The Jungfrau terrain is savage as well as sublime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGNEW, GEORGE BLISS JR.
description: AGNEW-George Bliss Jr. Of Kennebunkport, ME, and Vero Beach, FL, died Monday January 13, 2003, at his home in Vero Beach. He was born in Mt. Kisco, NY on September 9, 1909, son of George Bliss and Emily Dutilh Agnew. He graduated from Haverford in 1928, and Princeton University in 1932, with a degree in psychology. He worked at The Pentagon during World War II. After the war and work on Wall Street, NY, he became Vice President of The Putnam Trust Company in Greenwich, CT. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis Boven Agnew; his children, George Bliss Agnew III, of North Stonington, CT, Thomas Gibb Agnew, of Big Timber, MT, and Emily Dutilh Agnew, of Santa Monica, CA; his sister Madelaine Agnew Dykema; his brother David Paton Agnew; five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Vero Beach Visiting Nurse Association, 1111 36th Street, Vero Beach, FL. 32960, or to The Indian River Memorial Hospital Foundation, 1000 36th St, Vero Beach, FL 32960.

title: My Novel, the Movie: My Baby Reborn; 'About Schmidt' Was Changed, But Not Its Core
description: THE film ''About Schmidt,'' directed by Alexander Payne, is based on my novel of the same title. As is by now well known, the screenplay, by Mr. Payne and Jim Taylor, tells a story quite different from the one I wrote. They obliged my Albert Schmidt, the fancy New York lawyer, to leave his grand house in Bridgehampton, on the South Fork of Long Island, for Omaha, where he had surely never set foot. There, he metamorphosed into Warren Schmidt, an actuary who after 30 years hadn't risen very high at a life insurance company. Yet after Mr. Payne and Mr. Taylor, both quite worried that I would resent the changes, screened the picture for my wife and me, I told them immediately that I would have been proud to have written their book.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, MICHAEL TYLER
description: FISHER-Michael Tyler. Born August 31, 1990, passed away Friday, January 17, 2003. Beloved son of Steven and Elissa Fisher and brother of Jamie-Rose, Kyle Robert and Natalia Lyn. A student at Horace Mann Academy, Michael was a scholar who truly excelled in all forms of creative expression. He was a loving young man who brought such immense joy and happiness into the lives of his parents and siblings. Michael had many dreams and did so much in his time here. At the early age of 12, he was already a master of four languages. Michael dreamed of being the best at all he attempted and always succeeded. His brothers and sisters loved him deeply, and he was the life of every party. Michael's intellect was surpassed only by his kindness. He changed this world for the better and will be greatly missed. In addition to his immediate family, Michael is survived by a loving extended family: his paternal grandparents, Arnold and Audrey Fisher of Pine Plains, NY, and Lyn and Jack Schwartz of Manhattan; his maternal grandparents, Vincent and Assunta Gerard of Marco Island, FL, formerly of Rutherford, NJ. Michael is also survived by his uncle Kenneth Fisher, his wife Tammy, and their children Crystal, Brittany and Joshua; his aunt Karen and Thomas Misisco and their children Jonathan, Nicholas and Dylan; his aunt Helene and Ted Brois and their son Brandon; his aunt Tina and Douglas Cuveron and their sons Douglas, James and Evan; his aunt Pamela and Terek ElGammal and their sons Omar and Adam. A memorial service will be held Monday, January 20, 11AM at Temple Israel, 112 E. 75th St, Manhattan.

On the hit BBC series ''The Office,'' hardly anyone can tell a good joke. Yet British critics have hailed it as a comedy classic on the order of ''Fawlty Towers,'' and it was deemed the No. 1 ''TV treat'' of 2002 in a sort of People's Choice poll in Britain, just ahead of ''The Osbournes'' and five places above David Beckham's penalty kick against Argentina in the World Cup.

title: Oceans in Trouble
description: Last week, a commission of scientists, economists, fishermen and other experts assembled by the Pew Oceans Commission published the last of seven studies based on an exhaustive two-year inquiry into the state of America's ocean waters -- its fisheries, estuaries, wetlands and beaches. It is the first top-to-bottom study of its kind since the Stratton Commission reported to Congress in 1969. While the Pew commission's final recommendations are not due for several months, it has already confirmed what most of us thought: America's coastal waters and fishing grounds are in trouble, and they are greatly in need of far more attention at the federal level than they are getting.

title: 21st-Century Conductor
description: From unorthodox repertory to unruly restroom lines, confronting what others would sooner avoid is one of David Robertson's many talents. At 44, Robertson leads the ranks of a generation of American conductors who -- in a reversal of the tide that brought us Toscanini, Ormandy, Szell and Solti -- have established themselves in Europe. Even in Europe, however, where cultural institutions tend to be state-supported, orchestras are strapped for cash and conductors consumed by the need to draw in new listeners. Robertson, who is erudite and brilliantly musical, is uniquely equipped, by temperament and taste, to reach out to the traditional audience that classical music can't afford to relinquish and the younger one that it dearly needs to attract.

title: A Child Actor Grows Up to Retell a Tale of Poverty and Hope
description: THREE decades have passed since Martin Ritt brought out his film of ''Sounder,'' the beloved children's novel by William G. Armstrong. The story of a black sharecropping family in Mississippi in the Depression, it starred Cicely Tyson and Paul Winfield as the parents and, in the central role of their eldest child, a 13-year-old actor named Kevin Hooks. Mr. Hooks had a gift rare among child performers: a seeming inability to make a false or unnatural move on camera. Though the official emblem of the story is the family's hunting dog, Sounder, Kevin Hooks's open, curious face embodied one of the movie's themes: education as the hope for African-American families mired in poverty and racial oppression.

title: The Freedom of Equality
description: Today marks only the 17th time that America has celebrated an official holiday in remembrance of Martin Luther King Jr. Perhaps in a hundred years, this will be just another holiday, a day commemorating a man who changed the world in ways that will be taken for granted. But there is no taking those changes for granted yet, for civil rights are still a patchwork. If many black Americans are living a version of King's dream, they live it with the perpetual consciousness that that dream still has sharp boundaries, places and situations where it does not yet apply. And, as Trent Lott has notably demonstrated, some white Americans still cling to a version of history that denies even the fundamental premise of King's greatest hopes for his people.

title: China's Relentless Repression
description: China's new generation of Communist leaders seems determined to pick up where its aging mentors left off, by putting peaceful protest leaders on trial for their lives. Court proceedings began last week against Yao Fuxin and Xiao Yunliang, two labor activists from the city of Liaoyang, in northeast China's rust belt, who last year led huge worker protests demanding unpaid wages and benefits. Such demonstrations are perfectly legal under the Chinese Constitution. But the widely covered Liaoyang events embarrassed Beijing, and Mr. Yao and Mr. Xiao were charged with subversion, which carries a potential death penalty.

description: An Israeli court today brushed aside the contention of Marwan Barghouti, a Palestinian leader, that it had no right to try him, setting a trial date of April 6 on charges of involvement in attacks that killed 26 people and wounded many others.

title: No Shortage of Opinions On Salvaging WorldCom
description: Michael D. Capellas, who became chairman and chief executive of WorldCom in December, made his first public comments last week on how he intends to revive the telecommunications company. His ''100-day plan'' included few specifics about how the company hopes to emerge from bankruptcy protection. Instead, Mr. Capellas focused on cutting costs and on initiatives to keep customers who could be rattled by WorldCom's executive turmoil and its $9 billion accounting scandal.

title: The Faithful's Wayward Path

This classic of protest literature is celebrated for its powerful call for immediate and widespread action to end racial segregation through nonviolent marches, sit-in demonstrations and boycotts. But through the fog of history it is often forgotten that Dr. King's letter was not addressed to civil rights advocates. Nor did Dr. King send it to the segregationists who had jailed him. The letter was written to church leaders.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Pistol Misfires Twice
description: A man tried to fire a loaded .45-caliber pistol at two people in a Brooklyn restaurant early yesterday, but the gun misfired and no one was hurt, according to the police. The police said the man, Wayne P. Braga, became enraged when employees at Lily's Public House in Bay Ridge tried to throw him out after he went into the women's bathroom at about 3 a.m. Mr. Braga put his gun to an employee's head and pulled the trigger, but the pistol misfired, the police said, and three unarmed off-duty police officers who were in the restaurant tackled him. Mr. Braga tried to shoot one of them, but the gun misfired again, the police said. Mr. Braga ran out of the restaurant, but was captured shortly afterward and charged with assault, reckless endangerment and criminal possession of a weapon, the authorities said. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: PLATFORM CHANGED AFTER CONDUCTOR'S DEATH New York City Transit officials yesterday changed part of a Queens subway station that apparently led to the death of a subway conductor. On Saturday, the conductor, Janell Bennerson, 39, died when she leaned out of the train as it was leaving the platform and her head apparently hit a fence on the Aqueduct-North Conduit Avenue station in Ozone Park. The outer four-foot length of the fence was cut down to three feet yesterday, said Paul Fleuranges, a spokesman for the transit authority. The fence closed off part of the platform, which was unusually long. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACHETTI, RENATO M.
description: PACHETTI-Renato M. A RAI (Italian Radio & Television) journalist and executive for more than 40 years. He was one of the first dozen journalist to organize RAI's news department, which today has more than 1000 journalists worldwide. He came to the United States for the first time in 1955 to cover the visit of the Italian President to New York. From 1960-1962, he lived in New York as RAI's United Nations correspondent. Upon his return to Rome in 1968, he joined the executive staff of RAI as special consultant to the Chief Executive Officer. He transferred permanently to the United States in 1970 as Executive Vice President of RAI Corporation. He served as Chairman of the Foreign Press Association of the United States of America from 1972-1974; from 1975-1993, he was the Chairman of the International Council of the National Academy of Televison Arts & Sciences of which he remained Chairman Emeritus. From 1977-1993, when he retired, he held the post of President of the Gruppo Esponenti Italiani, the Association of Italian Business Leaders in the United states. Mr. Pachetti was also a member of the Advisory Group of Romance Languages at Princeton University. He was a founding member and later President of ''La Scuola d'Italia'' Guglielmo Marconi in New York. He was an adoring husband and wonderful father and will be terribly missed. He is survived by his wife, Diane; his son Alex and wife Laurie and their daughter Isabella; his son Nick and his wife Barbara; his son Edward and his fiancee Michele. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, Thursday January 23rd, 5-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Friday 11 AM. Interment private.
