title: No News Is Bad News
description: New Yorkers are bred to be skittish. Most have lived through at least one local boom-and-bust cycle, and many can go back through three. They have keen memories of the bad old days when the city seemed to spin out of control, when crime was sky-high, homeless people sat on every corner and nothing seemed to work. It doesn't take much to trigger their fear of regression. Recent warnings that the New York City Police Department might be forced to lay off police officers made crime stories seem more shocking, the subway panhandlers more noticeable. Everyone grew skittish.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Search At Sea For Migrants
description: Rescue workers searched the waters near the southeastern city of Bari for as many as 10 illegal immigrants who were lost at sea after a dangerous journey, apparently from Turkey. Their tiny boat was found off the Italian coast on Sunday with six survivors and six people who were dead from exposure to the cold. The survivors told officials that others aboard the boat had jumped or fallen overboard. The passengers were among hundreds of illegal immigrants who try to slip into Italy by sea every month, often with fatal results. Frank Bruni (NYT)

But the Arctic features -- expanses of stone and soil ordered into rings, islands, labyrinthine ridges and polygons -- have one thing the others do not, a natural explanation.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Reformist Paper Closed Again
description: The hard-line judiciary shut down the newspaper Norouz, which was preparing to resume publishing on Friday after a six-month ban. Its publisher, Mohsen Mirdamadi, a leading reformist member of Parliament, was sentenced to six months in prison. The judiciary has shut down some 90 pro-reform newspapers and journals in the last two years. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

The acquisition will allow G.E. to carry out nondestructive X-ray testing on a wider range of products than just aircraft engines, a G.E. spokesman, Rick Kennedy, said. The Agfa unit made sales worth 220 million euros last year from clients in the power generation and automotive sectors as well as from aerospace companies.

In the intervening months, symposiums, conferences and historical pageants will give the large and growing Lewis-and-Clark-loving public the chance to ponder every conceivable aspect of the expedition, from the whiskey the members of the Corps of Discovery drank, to the wood their pirogues were made of, to whether the captains shaved.

title: Agassi and Venus Williams Advance
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 21  It was clear midway through the second set on Tuesday that Sebastien Grosjean was in dire need of presidential intervention. Andre Agassi was slicing and kicking his serves with conviction; huffing along the baseline and smacking groundstrokes with the sort of been-there-won-that precision that just about always means corner-to-corner disappointment for the foil on the other side of the net. Perhaps only Bill Clinton could have saved the talented Frenchman. Not that Agassi likes that line of reasoning. He has always testily denied that the former American president had the slightest bit to do with Grosjean beating him in the quarterfinals of the French Open in 2001. But anyone who was in the stadium for that schizophrenic match had to view it differently. Agassi was up a set in Paris and cruising until Clinton arrived fashionably late in the front row of the president's box, and Grosjean then won the second set in a hurry. When Clinton stepped out for a few games, Agassi broke the Frenchman and rallied, only to lose his grip for good when Clinton returned. Even Clinton said he felt responsible (not always his specialty), but though the Australian Open is the only Grand Slam event he has yet to attend, he was nowhere to be seen on Tuesday, and though this match was not quite as straightforward as the score looks in newsprint, there was no external or internal force capable of keeping Agassi from his appointed round. That would be the semifinals, but there may be no good reason for him to stop there after his 6-3, 6-2, 6-2 dismissal of the 12th-seeded Grosjean, who did not serve well enough to keep the American at bay. Already in excellent physical condition, Agassi should be fresher than usual after playing precious little tennis over the last 10 days. He has lost just one set in five matches, two of which were mismatches: his 6-1, 6-0, 6-0 victory over Lee Hyung-Taik and his abbreviated encounter with Guillermo Coria, which was stopped because of Coria's sore feet after just 11 games. "Getting through is the first priority," Agassi said. "But getting through with fuel in your tank would be the second. That's where I feel like it's been a good tournament for me up to now: It's not so much that I haven't played at night, but that when I have got out there, I haven't spent any unnecessary energy." It gets better for Agassi. Though it appeared he was on a collision course with No. 4 seed Juan Carlos Ferrero, who has beaten Agassi twice in three matches, Ferrero was surprised 7-6 (7-4), 7-6 (7-5), 6-1 in Tuesday's second quarterfinal by the unseeded veteran Wayne Ferreira of South Africa. Ferreira, just one year younger than the 32-year-old Agassi, has never beaten the American in 10 matches and has won only one set. "He has a certain game that brings out the worst in me," said an otherwise delighted Ferreira, whose only previous Grand Slam semifinal was here in 1992. "I do feel that I have improved my backhand considerably. I'm taking it a lot earlier. I'm more aggressive on it. I'm missing it a lot less, and that's always been a very, very big factor against him: that he has absolutely dominated me on the backhand side and given me no opportunities to hit any forehands." Whoever wins will also have the benefit of two full days of rest before playing the final, while their opponent will have to make do with one. To summarize: tennis is a routinely surprising game, but the omens don't get much better than this for Agassi, and there is another good reason for tennis fans to cheer him on. He said that he and wife Steffi Graf have made a pact: If he wins this tournament, she will play mixed doubles with him at the French Open in May. Graf, the winner of 22 Grand Slam singles titles, has not played competitively since 1999. But then let's not get ahead of ourselves. The other second-seeded American in Melbourne has been nearly as efficient. Venus Williams arrived here with doubts swirling about her form and motivation in the wake of her younger sister Serena's dominant season in 2002. It remains unclear whether Venus has the game to restore family order, but after dropping the first three games of her opening match against Svetlana Kuznetsova she has still not dropped a set. She is still erratic, yet she is playing with enthusiasm, resourcefulness and sometimes startling power. In a sure sign of engagement, she is also externalizing her displeasure with her mistakes: a rare concession for the usually regal and self-contained Venus. On Tuesday, she had just a bit too much of everything for the tall and elegant Slovakian baseliner Daniela Hantuchova, beating the No. 7 seed 6-4, 6-3 and cracking a first serve that was clocked at 201 kilometers per hour: just short of her record of 205 kilometers set in 1998. "I think right now it's all about power," Hantuchova said. "Because I think my tennis is there, but it's just sometimes so fast that I can't do anything about it. I mean, especially the serve." Venus will face No. 5 seed Justine Henin-Hardenne of Belgium in Thursday's semifinals. Henin-Hardenne shrugged off any emotional or physical side effects from her dramatic victory over Lindsay Davenport on Sunday, proving too forceful and complete for unseeded Spaniard Virginia Ruano Pascual and winning 6-2, 6-2. This is Henin-Hardenne's first trip to the semifinals here, and it looked most unlikely at 7-7 in the third set against Davenport when she fell to the ground in agony with leg cramps after a first serve. But after resting on Monday, she practiced lightly on Tuesday morning. "I was a bit nervous this morning, because I was very tired, and I didn't feel the ball very good," she said. "But in the match it was much better." Agassi, seeded second this year, might not have felt the need to grace Melbourne with his presence until fairly late in his career - something he now says is "one of my biggest regrets" - but he has done his best to make up for lost tournaments. Tuesday's romp was his 19th consecutive victory in Melbourne Park, although he missed last year's event with a wrist injury. "It's remarkable," Grosjean said. "Both his physical condition for his age and his motivation, too. He's been on tour for years, and he's won everything and yet he's still finding new challenges. I think that's his real strength." Perhaps Agassi's longevity is giving ideas to some of his contemporaries. If 31-year-old Younes Aynaoui defeats Andy Roddick in the quarterfinals on Wednesday, there will be three players over 30 in the semifinals: quite a statement considering the increasingly physical nature of men's tennis. To make matters even more mature, Aynaoui, Agassi and Ferreira are all fathers of young children and are juggling those responsibilities with the nomadic life of a tennis professional. Agassi's son Jaden Gil is here with him and Graf; Aynaoui's two sons Ewen and Neil are home with his wife in Barcelona; Ferreira's son Marcus is at home with his wife in Berkeley, California. Agassi was winning Grand Slam events long before fatherhood, but both Aynaoui and Ferreira believe the change has helped them play more relaxed and effective tennis. "My son has changed my whole attitude," said Ferreira, who was close to retiring in 1999. "Before it was more of a life-and-death situation, and there was nothing worse than losing a tennis match." He was expected to lose this one, but Ferrero, for all his speed and baseline talent, is still clearly a fragile character: witness his collapse in the final of last year's French Open. Though the Spaniard won the first two games of the first and second set, Ferreira immediately closed the gap and was able to more than hold his own from the backcourt when he wasn't slashing forward to volley away winners at the net. Eleven years later, Ferreira is an Australian Open semifinalist once more. "When I was younger, I went to sports psychologists," he said. "I read these books. I listened to these tapes. I listened to this person and did that and this. None of it ever really seemed to work. I haven't done anything in the last two years, and all of a sudden it's changed."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: France To Be Warned On Deficit
description: The European Union is poised to send a warning to the French government over the size of its budget deficit, finance ministers said. France is forecast to generate a deficit of 2.9 percent of gross domestic product this year -- dangerously close to the 3 percent limit in the stability and growth pact agreed to ensure sound finances in the euro zone. E.U. finance ministers are also likely to support the European Commission's proposal to punish Germany for having already breached the deficit ceiling, at their meeting in Brussels today. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: The Axis of Oil

The move also signals Saudi Arabia's willingness to ensure the flow of affordable crude in the event of war with Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Delays Bond Sale
description: South Korea's largest bank, Kookmin Bank, has delayed the sale of $850 million worth of bonds in foreign markets. The bank had hoped to wrap up the sale by the end of this month but said it would put off the offer for at least another two weeks. The bank said uncertainties about both Iraq and North Korea might result in higher-than-anticipated costs, and analysts questioned whether demand would be weakened while investors worried about the impact of confrontations. Kookmin is raising cash to buy back the government's 9.3 percent stake. The bank anticipates what one official said would be ''a somewhat disappointing'' report on earnings in the fourth quarter of last year as a result of the need to build up loan-loss reserves to cover mounting consumer credit. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Backs Belarus Union
description: Russia's economic alliance with its neighbor Belarus, talked about for years, crept a bit closer to reality as President Vladimir V. Putin said that the Kremlin was committed to the union and that the two countries should speed work toward making the Russian ruble the standard currency in Belarus. Mr. Putin's remarks, during a visit to Belarus's capital, Minsk, were something of a turnabout: in recent months he suggested that poverty-stricken Belarus would be a drag on Russia's economy and that uniting with its autocratic leader, Aleksandr Lukashenko, would be undesirable. Most experts still believe that any alliance will fall well short of the full political union Mr. Lukashenko wants. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; A Prolonged Winter's Sojourn With a Time-Traveling Cat
description: It wasn't my wife saying, ''When are you getting rid of that thing?'' that told me I was in trouble. Nor was it the fact that I'd amassed more gold credits than I knew how to spend -- more, in fact, than the game would let me spend at the stage I'd reached. It didn't even bother me that I could replay whole cityscapes of a video game by memory, lying in bed at night, or that I'd been stuck for a couple of days on a stage I couldn't get out of. The sign that I'd been playing too long was my eyes. They wouldn't stop twitching. Suddenly I knew just how Wile E. Coyote felt.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: SEARCH AT SEA FOR MIGRANTS Rescue workers searched the waters near the southeastern city of Bari for as many as 10 illegal immigrants who were lost at sea after a dangerous journey, apparently from Turkey. Their tiny boat was found off the Italian coast on Sunday with six survivors and six people who were dead from exposure to the cold. The survivors told officials that others aboard the boat had jumped or fallen overboard. The passengers were among hundreds of illegal immigrants who try to slip into Italy by sea every month, often with fatal results.

title: An Acting Lesson, With a Grovel and a Strut, in Two Plays

And their movements, in pursuing courtship and self-advancement, are as different as an abject grovel and a smug strut.

The Democratic Progressive Party is more hostile to close ties with the mainland than the opposition Nationalist Party, and Mr. Chen's trip may contribute to some thawing in relations. title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: PARKING-FINE REVENUE RISES A slight increase in the number of parking tickets issued, combined with the near doubling of some fines and more aggressive collections, has brought in $168 million in revenue in the first five months of the 2002-03 fiscal year, city officials said yesterday, a nearly 15 percent increase from last year. The increase, up from $147 million in the same period last year, was first reported yesterday in The Daily News. The increase shows that the city has been doing a better job of collecting fines from parking summonses, in part by allowing people to pay online or over the telephone, officials said. In October, the Bloomberg administration raised the cost of many parking tickets to $105 from $55.

title: Cake or Prayer, Marching or Running, Holiday Is a Work in Progress
description: At a little after 11 a.m. yesterday, the air getting more Siberian by the moment, Dominic Chianese, also known as Uncle Junior on ''The Sopranos,'' strummed his guitar on West 42nd Street and led 50 freezing children, ages 5 to 25, in singing ''Happy Birthday'' to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. A cake inscribed with the same wishes was propped on a stool in front of Uncle Junior. A scattering of passers-by, including a bike messenger and two police officers, watched.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: JOBLESS RATE RISES The unemployment rate in Hong Kong crept up to 7.2 percent in the fourth quarter, compared with a rate of 7.1 percent for the period from September through November. The number of jobless people dropped very slightly, but the labor force shrank more, pushing up the overall unemployment rate. Joblessness remained below last summer's peak of 7.8 percent, as the Hong Kong economy has begun to show signs of recovery, mainly from handling much of China's ever-rising volume of trade and outbound tourism. Employment fell over the last three months in restaurants and hotels, but rose in stores, construction and tourism.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Port Washington: Tugboat Fatality
description: Co-workers found a tugboat deckhand's body in the icy waters of Hempstead Harbor at 10:31 a.m. Sunday morning, the Nassau County Police said yesterday. They identified the victim as John Carter, 42, of Staten Island. An autopsy was ordered, but the police said there was no evidence of foul play. They theorized that Mr. Carter tried to jump from the bulkhead to a boat late Saturday or early Sunday but fell into the water and died of hypothermia. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACHETTI, RENATO M.
description: PACHETTI-Renato M. A RAI (Italian Radio & Television) journalist and executive for more than 40 years. He was one of the first dozen journalist to organize RAI's news department, which today has more than 1000 journalists worldwide. He came to the United States for the first time in 1955 to cover the visit of the Italian President to New York. From 1960-1962, he lived in New York as RAI's United Nations correspondent. Upon his return to Rome in 1968, he joined the executive staff of RAI as special consultant to the Chief Executive Officer. He transferred permanently to the United States in 1970 as Executive Vice President of RAI Corporation. He served as Chairman of the Foreign Press Association of the United States of America from 1972-1974; from 1975-1993, he was the Chairman of the International Council of the National Academy of Televison Arts & Sciences of which he remained Chairman Emeritus. From 1977-1993, when he retired, he held the post of President of the Gruppo Esponenti Italiani, the Association of Italian Business Leaders in the United states. Mr. Pachetti was also a member of the Advisory Group of Romance Languages at Princeton University. He was a founding member and later President of ''La Scuola d'Italia'' Guglielmo Marconi in New York. He was an adoring husband and wonderful father and will be terribly missed. He is survived by his wife, Diane; his son Alex and wife Laurie and their daughter Isabella; his son Nick and his wife Barbara; his son Edward and his fiancee Michele. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, Thursday January 23rd, 5-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Friday 11 AM. Interment private.

title: Diamonds Tell Tale of Oxygen's Late Arrival

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Uniondale: L.I. Power Wants Higher Surcharge
description: The Long Island Power Authority's trustees recommended yesterday that a 5.8 percent surcharge imposed on electric bills for the past two years be raised to 8.8 percent. But thank goodness the Met decided to stick with this old show for its current revival of Mozart's endearingly silly 1782 comedy about a Spanish lady and her maid abducted by a Turkish pasha. It's a club within a club, a small, windowless room sealed off from the downstairs social swirl and ruled by its own peculiar rituals, meant to suggest a vanished world of privilege and high style. Admittance is gained after a soft knock on the door by the matre d'htel. title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: SUNGARD TO BUY CAMINUS FOR $159 MILLION SunGard Data Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Caminus Corporation , a software provider for the energy industry, for $159 million. Under the agreement, expected to close early this year, SunGard will pay $9 a share in cash for each of Caminus's 17.7 million shares outstanding. The offer represents a 260 percent premium to Caminus' closing stock price on Friday of $2.50 a share. News of the buyout sent shares of Caminus skyrocketing $6.31, or 252 percent, to $8.81. The markets were closed Monday. Shares of Sungard finished at $20.74, down 89 cents, or 4.1 percent. Caminus shareholders representing about 26 percent of the company's outstanding stock have agreed to throw their shares behind Sungard's offer. Caminus, based in New York, makes software that manages trading in commodities like crude oil, natural gas and power. The software simulates conditions in the energy market and potential weather trends to forecast prices. The company had 2002 revenue of $84 million.

title: CHARLES SCHWAB REPORTS A $79 MILLION LOSS IN QUARTER
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the discount brokerage firm, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss widened to $79 million, its largest in a single quarter, as the company spent $165 million to close offices and reduce the number of employees. Schwab said it lost 6 cents a share compared with a loss of $13 million, or 1 cent, a year ago, as it spent $97 million before taxes on severance and $86 million to shut offices. Revenue from customer trading fell 14 percent in the quarter, pushing overall revenue down 6 percent, to $996 million, from $1.1 billion a year ago.

title: The King of Caricature
description: It's best to say it simply. What a life! In a world where the good things seem inevitably to fade away, Al Hirschfeld went on and on until the very last moment, working and drawing as though death were just another deadline. He died in his sleep on Sunday, just short of the century mark. But Hirschfeld already had one century under his belt, for the 20th belonged to him, especially when it came to Broadway. You didn't have to see the whole of a Hirschfeld caricature to know it was Hirschfeld. All you needed to see was one of the sinuous lines that defined his work. It might begin in the margin and swoop toward the center, apparently meaningless in itself. But by the time it converged with the other lines in the drawing, a character had emerged. And not just a character but the quintessence of a character -- the undeniable chin of Kirk Douglas, the irrefutable eyebrows of Groucho Marx, the illogical lip of Liza.

title: Apple Juice With Calvados Has a Low-Key Kick
description: In Normandy, people mix Calvados and apple juice and call it pommeau. Now, Manoir d'Apreval, a producer near Honfleur, France, is bottling a blend of one-third Calvados and two-thirds apple juice that has been aged in oak for five years. The result is a dark amber drink with a rich burnt-caramel-apple flavor. It is relatively low in alcohol (16.5 percent) and is best served chilled as an aperitif or dessert wine. Apreval Pommeau de Normandie is about $32 a bottle in Manhattan at Eli's W.I.N.E., Sherry-Lehmann, Astor Wine and Spirits, McCabe's Wine & Spirits and 67 Wine and Spirits; and in Park Slope, Brooklyn, at Slope Cellars and Red White and Bubbly.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Oil Barge Sinks
description: A barge carrying around 1,100 tons of fuel oil sank in the Bay of Algeciras, in southern Spain, two months after the Prestige oil tanker sank and polluted more than 600 miles of Spain's northern coast. Two crew members were rescued when the Spabunker IV went down before dawn in bad weather, but the body of its captain, Miguel Roig, was later pulled from the sea. A slick apparently formed by the ship's own fuel was washed out to sea, and the Development Ministry said there was no sign that oil was leaking from the hold of the ship. Emma Daly (NYT)

Ms. Loren-Maltese, convicted of racketeering, wire fraud and mail fraud, was to begin serving her sentence on April 1. But after federal prosecutors raised concerns that she might gamble away money that the government hoped to confiscate, Judge John F. Grady of Federal District Court ordered that she turn herself in on Feb. 1. Prosecutors have said that in the last three years Ms. Loren-Maltese bet nearly $19 million at casinos, mostly in Las Vegas. John W. Fountain (NYT)

One can get an idea from the paintings of Anne Vallayer-Coster (1744 to 1818), a court painter and one of only four women elected to the Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture in France before the revolution. An exhibition of 34 of her paintings, mostly still lifes, is at the Frick Collection at 1 East 70th Street through March 23.

description: Joseph DeFede, the acting boss of the Luchese organized crime family in the 1990's who is cooperating with prosecutors, testified in federal court yesterday that Peter Gotti, brother of the late John J. Gotti, was a captain in the Gambino crime family in the 1980's. Mr. DeFede, 68, also testified that Peter Gotti attended meetings in the 1990's that were open only to top Mafia leaders or their representatives. But Mr. DeFede did not provide prosecutors with proof of one of their main contentions: that Peter Gotti became the leader of the Gambino family after the imprisonment in the 1990's of John Gotti and his son, John A. Gotti, who is known as Junior. William Glaberson (NYT)

An investigation determined that a portable heater in the living room either fell or was knocked over, causing the fire.

description: Cable and Wireless said today that Graham M. Wallace, the chief executive and the architect of its transformation from a humdrum telephone carrier into a provider of information services to large businesses, would leave the company.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: WOODBRIDGE: TWO DIE IN HOUSE FIRE A man and his daughter died yesterday in a fire caused by a portable heater in their house in the Colonia section of Woodbridge. The bodies of John Quigley, 77, and his daughter, Cathy, were found in their house by firefighters. Another resident, Howard Wood, 49, escaped the fire by climbing out of a window. An investigation determined that a portable heater in the living room either fell or was knocked over, causing the fire.    (NYT)

title: Kennedy, in Sweeping Attack, Faults Bush on Iraq and Taxes
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy accused the Bush administration today of rushing into war with Iraq at the expense of the struggle against terrorism and the domestic needs of the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, SIDNEY
description: ISAACS-Sidney. On January 20, 2003. Veteran of the U.S. Merchant Marines. Last of the civilian NYC Mayoral chauffeurs for Mayor Wagner to Koch. Beloved husband of the late Ruby. Devoted father of Michael, Jennifer and David. Dear brother of Jack, Cece Sloan, Larry and Marion D'Lugoff. Services Wednesday. 11 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Spirits Soar And Feet Fly At Tribute To Nureyev
description: The first time Rudolf Nureyev danced on the stage of the Palais Garnier here, on May 19, 1961, he had not yet defected from the Soviet Union. The last time he appeared on any stage was at the same theater after the premiere of his final work as a choreographer, ''La Bayadre,'' on Oct. 8, 1992. Now, for the 10th anniversary of his death at 54 on Jan. 5, 1993, the Paris Opera Ballet has celebrated him in a glittering homage at the Palais Garnier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORBES, T. HAROLD JR. (HARRY)
description: FORBES-T. Harold Jr. (Harry). On January 19, 2003 at the age of 89, San Antonio, TX. He was the devoted husband of Margaret;loving father of Maureen, Thom and Jim. Visitation 7-9 PM Thursday at George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Friday at 10AM at the Blessed Sacrament Church. Interment at the Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in New Rochelle.

title: Islands in the Mall: Pushcarts as Revenue Streams
description: The once-humble pushcart, some now equipped with electricity and plumbing, has become a darling of mall operators and other landlords as a way of squeezing rental income from areas formerly occupied by mall rats.

title: When Your Mouth's on Fire, That's the Joy of Sichuan
description: FUNNY things can happen at a Sichuan restaurant. Your lips and cheeks begin to glow with heat. Your tongue starts to tingle until it feels as if it's dancing in your mouth. Your brow sweats, and your nose runs. If you're like me, that's when you shout, ''Yes!'' and reach for more food.

title: Let the Sun Shine
description: Nigella Lawson finds midwinter sunshine in Seville oranges, whose sourness makes them right for tiny tarts, duck or a soothing soup. At My Table, Page 5.

title: Roman Conspirators in Business Suits
description: Like a lot of intelligent people, Shakespeare was amazed at the paradox of political speech -- that it is demonstrably misleading, and that people believe it anyway. This is the bizarre quirk of human nature that ''Julius Caesar'' deals with especially. And because politics is never without purveyors of egregious, self-serving lies, the play is perpetually relevant. Though it doesn't have the psychological depth of ''Hamlet'' and doesn't achieve or even aim for the grievous sadness of ''King Lear,'' it can really make you outraged.

title: Panel Rules New Jersey Must Redraw Its Districts
description: In a decision released yesterday, a State Appellate Court panel ruled that New Jersey's legislative districts needed to be redrawn, plunging the state's political balance into new uncertainty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, SANDY
description: JAMES-Sandy. Born Sandra Lentz. January 20, 2003. Beloved mother, grandmother, aunt, cousin and friend. Leaves behind her companion Jim, four children and eight grandchildren. Successful in family, business and life. You saw the whole picture and you never sweated the small stuff. You will be missed by everyone.

title: Apple Juice With Calvados Has a Low-Key Kick
description: In Normandy, people mix Calvados and apple juice and call it pommeau. Now, Manoir d'Apreval, a producer near Honfleur, France, is bottling a blend of one-third Calvados and two-thirds apple juice that has been aged in oak for five years. The result is a dark amber drink with a rich burnt-caramel-apple flavor. It is relatively low in alcohol (16.5 percent) and is best served chilled as an aperitif or dessert wine. Apreval Pommeau de Normandie is about $32 a bottle in Manhattan at Eli's W.I.N.E., Sherry-Lehmann, Astor Wine and Spirits, McCabe's Wine & Spirits and 67 Wine and Spirits; and in Park Slope, Brooklyn, at Slope Cellars and Red White and Bubbly.

title: A Protest Rooted in Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Curriculum With Roots In Global Competition
description: New York City's latest elementary school mathematics curriculum was inspired by fear -- the nationwide angst 20 years ago that children in places like the Soviet Union, Japan and other countries were learning quicker and more thoroughly than American students, especially in math and science. A blue-ribbon commission warned of the nation's educational deficiencies in a 1983 report to President Ronald Reagan, ''A Nation at Risk,'' complaining that American schools were being ''eroded by a rising tide of mediocrity.''

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits on Thursday, about innovative products at the 2003 Consumer Electronics Show, misstated the Web address for the maker of the KidSmart smoke alarm. It is www.kidsmartdetector.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASSBERG, ESTHER GOLDSTEIN
description: STRASSBERG-Esther Goldstein. A wonderful person, a noble human, a friend to all, a listener and a doer. A true woman of valor-beautiful, intelligent and kind. Born and raised in Monticello, NY. Resided in NYC for the past 20 years. Esther was the first Jewish employee of Sullivan County and former co-owner of the Esther Manor, a Catskill Mountain resort. Esther was the past president of the SC Heart Association, SC Cancer Association and Sisterhood of the Landfield Ave. Synagogue, as well as a lifetime member of Hadassah, Eastern Star and City of Hope. ''Nana'' was always willing to listen, help, do, and give. She fought ''the fight'' gallantly and honestly to the end. Nana leaves behind grieving but proud childrenLeba and Neil Sedaka, Dr. Barbara Strassberg, and Judge Harold Enten, and grandchildren - Dara, Sa mantha, Marc, Louise and Harry, bereft sister Irene Asman and sister-in-law Shirley Goldstein, devoted caregiver-Dominica Sut, and many loving nieces, nephews, and friends. Predeceased by loving husband, Irving, and brothers, Carl, Ralph, Ben, Abe, Nat and Hy Goldstein. Services, Riverside Memorial Chapel, January 23, 11:45AM. Burial following in Monticello. In lieu of flowers please give to charity of your choice or do one giving deed in honor of Esther's lifetime of giving.

title: Our Towns; When Lies Keep Children In Peril
description: PROMISES to whip New Jersey's child welfare system into shape came fast and furious after revelations of government negligence in the recent Newark abuse case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHYTE, GIBONEY GRACE
description: WHYTE - Giboney Grace. Age 63, on January 16, 2003, of ovarian cancer, leaves friend Joshua Shapiro, daughter Abigail Hykin, grandson Theo Hanlon, sister Virginia Wilcox, brother Charles Whyte and the many others whose lives she touched. Memorial is on Sunday, January 26th, 212-683-1798.

title: Court Dismisses Claims of Slave Laborers
description: People forced to work as slave laborers for Japanese and German corporations in World War II may not sue for wages and injuries, the federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, MICHAEL TYLER
description: FISHER-Michael Tyler. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the tragic loss of Michael Tyler Fisher, beloved son of Steven and Elissa Fisher. Our hearts and prayers are with the entire Fisher family who have generously supported the mission of UJA-Federation for countless years. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: French and German Leaders Jointly Oppose Iraqi War Moves
description: PARIS, Jan. 22  In a blunt rejection of American impatience toward Baghdad, the leaders of France and Germany said today that they shared common views on Iraq, and that any Security Council resolution for military action would have to await the report of United Nations weapon inspectors.

title: Mexico Seeks to Halt Executions of 51 in U.S.
description: The government of Mexico, in a direct challenge to the Bush administration, asked the International Court of Justice today to block the executions of 51 Mexicans on death row in the United States.

title: Coaches' Mind Games Have Begun
description: In a Super Bowl whose story line is already established all Gruden, all the time -- the mysterious absence of both head coaches from Monday's news conferences elicited plenty of conspiracy theories. The official version was that Bucs Coach Jon Gruden had received permission from the league to remain behind in Tampa, Fla., with his assistants to work on the game plan. Gruden was expected to arrive here in time for Tuesday's media day. Then Raiders Coach Bill Callahan did not show up, either, and speculation began that the coaches, who are good friends, were engaged in a bit of gamesmanship.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Child-Abuse Bills Advance
description: Two Assembly committees have approved legislation to tighten state oversight of abused and neglected children. The legislation was prompted by the child-abuse case that left a boy dead and his two brothers imprisoned and starving in a basement. The bills passed during a joint session of the Family, Women and Children's Services Committee and the Health and Human Services Committee. The state Division of Youth and Family Services has acknowledged closing cases without visiting children's homes. One bill passed yesterday would require home visits before caseworkers close abuse investigations and another would force the courts and the agency to determine a child's safety when parents or guardians are incarcerated. A third bill would require school districts to notify the agency of all unexcused absences of more than five days. The bills are scheduled for a vote tomorrow by the Assembly. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Got the Interview; Got the Gray Suit?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSS, RICHARD J., DR.
description: CROSS-Richard J., Dr. 87, of Princeton, NJ, died January 20th. Educated at Yale and Columbia Medical School, he served in the medical corps in World War II and on the faculties of Columbia, the University of Pittsburgh and Robert Wood Johnson Medical School from which he retired in 1985. He developed the school's Human Sexuality curriculum in which he taught for 30 years. He served on the Board of SIECUS and HITOPS. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Margaret W. Cross, four children, James, Alan, Anne and Jane, and 10 granchildren. His daughter, Lee Cross, died in 1999. Memorial service will be on Saturday, February 1 at 1 PM at Trinity Church in Princeton. Donations may be made to HI-TOPS Teen Health Center, 21 Wiggins Street, Princeton New Jersey 08542.

title: Blair Sees Iraq Weakening as France Resists Early War
description: LONDON, Jan. 21  Prime Minister Tony Blair told senior members of Parliament today that a "massive amount" of new intelligence suggested that the escalation of armed forces in the Persian Gulf is shaking Saddam Hussein and undermining his rule over Iraq.

title: Columbia U. Sharply Trims Its Financing For Biosphere
description: Columbia University plans to curtail sharply its financial support for Biosphere 2, the ambitious but troubled effort to simulate Earth's ecology under glass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANOWITZ, ADELINE TINTNER
description: JANOWITZ-Adeline Tintner. Of New York City. Born February 2, 1912. Died January 20. Noted Henry James scholar and book collector. She is survived by her husband Henry, her daughters Anne and Mary and grandchildren Andrew and Kita. Services to be held at the Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76 Street Friday, January 24 at 2:15 P.M.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Another Strike By Firefighters
description: Firefighters walked off the job for 24 hours across Britain, the third time in less than three months that the 55,000-member Fire Brigades Union had called a strike in a wage dispute with the government. About 19,000 troops were put on standby to fill in. The firefighters have rejected a proposed 11 percent pay increase over two years because it is tied to changes in work rules that the union says will cost 4,500 jobs. The union said it would hold 48-hour strikes on Jan. 28 and Feb. 11 if the dispute continued. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Citigroup says its quarterly earnings fell 37%, and expresses relief that a difficult year is behind it.
description: CITIGROUP reported a 37 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, closing a turbulent year of weak financial markets and regulatory scrutiny.

title: TAUBMAN REJECTS LATEST BID FROM SIMON
description: Taubman Centers, the shopping mall empire founded by A. Alfred Taubman, rejected a $1.7 billion takeover bid from a rival, the Simon Property Group, as inadequate yesterday. Simon Property had joined last week with Westfield America, which is controlled by the Australian mall owner Westfield Holdings, to make its latest bid of $20 a share, up from its previously rejected offer of $18 a share. Robert S. Taubman, the chief executive of Taubman Centers, reiterated yesterday that the company was not for sale. Simon Property and Westfield responded by saying ''that the Taubman board has offered no credible alternative to their $20 offer.'' Simon Property and Westfield are now counting on shareholder support for their bid in an effort to pressure Taubman Center's board to capitulate. Simon Property has also filed a lawsuit to challenge the way the Taubman family obtained its voting control, giving it the ability to block any deal. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; DOCUMENTS CLASSIFIED
description: Richard C. Reid, the man who admitted trying to sabotage a transatlantic flight by igniting explosives hidden in his shoes, will not be allowed access to classified documents in his case, a federal judge in Boston has ruled. A lawyer for Mr. Reid argued that by allowing him access to the documents and presenting them at his sentencing hearing the public would ''hear the other side of the story.'' Only lawyers and the judge, William Young, have seen the documents, the details of which have not been disclosed. Mr. Reid, who pleaded guilty in October, will be sentenced Jan. 30. The government has recommended that Mr. Reid, who has admitted to being a member of Al Qaeda, receive life in prison. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHFELD, AL
description: HIRSCHFELD-Al. We mourn the very great loss of this dear and distinguished fellow member. As important a figure as the many actors, producers, directors and writers that he immortalized. His passing leaves a large void in the American theatre and in our hearts. Our thoughts and deep affection to his wife Louise and the entire Hirschfeld family. The Players

title: For a Curry, a Chilled Ctes du Rhne Can Be a Cooling Antidote
description: WHEN serving wine with a meal, it's helpful to think of the role you want the wine to play. You might want it to slake your thirst if the dish you're serving is salty. Or you might prefer a cool and crisp sensation to complement a warm dessert.

title: Motorola Posts 2nd Consecutive Profit
description: Motorola's long-awaited rebound appeared to gather momentum in the last three months of 2002 as the company achieved its second straight quarter of profitability and, in contrast to the third quarter, topped Wall Street's expectations for both profit and revenue.

title: Giants Hire Coach
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel drew from his roots in hiring Turk Schonert as the new quarterbacks coach. Schonert, 46, played quarterback at Stanford in 1979, when Fassel worked there as an assistant, and went on to play in the N.F.L.

title: This Winter, Even 'Normal' Is Cold Comfort
description: In weather, it turns out, everything is relative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZSIMONS, JAMES M.
description: FITZSIMONS-James M. Admitted to practice law in New York, California and Connecticut, passed away January 6, 2003. He was the grandson of Chief Justice James M. FitzSimons, who swore in the first Mayor of Greater New York. Members of the family have continuously practiced law in New York for over 100 years. He spent the bulk of his legal career as a Senior Partner at Mendes & Mount specializing in aviation and space litigation. He successfully argued a case before the Supreme Court of the United States. Mr. FitzSimons enlisted in the Navy during World War II. He served as Counsel to the Majority Leader of the City Council of New York and as Chief of the Civil Division of the U.S. Attorney's Office, Eastern District of New York. At the time of his death Mr. FitzSimons was Vice-President and General Counsel of Precision Computer Services. He is survived by his wife Theresa, daughter MaryLynn, and sons John and Michael. In lieu of flowers, donation may be made in the name of James M. FitzSimons to Ozanam Hall, 42-41 201st St, Bayside, NY, 11361. Ozanam Hall is a residence run by the Carmelite Sisters.

title: New Panel to Begin a Quest to Upgrade Teaching
description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., who retired in December as chairman of I.B.M., has assembled a special panel to tackle an educational brainteaser so taxing that even the field's best minds have seemed powerless to solve it.

title: Broome Journal; For the Happy-Go-Lucky, Heaven's Pearly Gate
description: ''Broome time,'' said the owner of Easyrider Backpacker Tours, explaining why her Internet cafe, on the main street here, would be open only until 5 p.m.

title: Negotiations On Land Swap Gain Impetus
description: Negotiations on a proposed land swap involving the World Trade Center site and New York City's two airports, which had been mostly dormant since late summer, have gained new momentum in recent weeks, officials involved in the rebuilding effort in Lower Manhattan said yesterday.

title: American Is Killed in Kuwait
description: At least one gunman opened fire on a car carrying two American civilians in Kuwait, killing one and severely wounding the other. Page A9.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Information Technology Spending Will Rise
description: Gartner DataQuest Inc., a unit of Gartner Inc., predicted yesterday that worldwide information technology spending by corporations will increase 5 percent in 2003 from a year ago. In a news release, the market research firm said sales of technology would reach $2.1 trillion worldwide this year; previously, DataQuest forecast a low single-digit increase on a percentage basis in technology outlays in 2003. According to DataQuest, the industries that will spend the most in 2003 and 2004 on technology are government and health care, although levels will be modest. DataQuest estimates that information technology spending will increase only in the single digits in percentage terms in both industries. ''Key issues that are increasing technology investments will include homeland security, outsourcing, and agency modernization projects,'' an analyst, Rishi Sood, said. In health care, DataQuest said patient safety, the rising costs of delivering and managing health care, and regulatory requirements will drive information technology spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, ELIZABETH H.
description: KANE-Elizabeth H. On January 20, 2003. Wife of the late Josiah M. Mother of Michaela Kane Schaeffer, Ph.D. and her husband Henry A. Schaeffer, M.D. Grandmother of Mary and William and their spouses Brian & Nancy. Great-grandmother of Julia, Benjamin and Beatrice. Services today 9AM, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave (Ave V), Brooklyn. Interment in Toronto.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Board Eliminates Hostile-Bid Plan
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the world's largest personal computer maker, said yesterday that its board had eliminated a defense against hostile takeover because it was no longer needed. The shareholder rights plan expired yesterday rather than in 2011, the company said in a statement. Hewlett-Packard will hold its annual shareholder meeting on April 2. Shareholder rights plans, commonly referred to as poison pills, discourage hostile takeover bids by making an acquisition prohibitively expensive through the issuance of new shares. When shareholders voted last year on Hewlett-Packard's $18.9 billion purchase of Compaq Computer, the company said it intended to scrap the poison pill after completing the purchase. The company may adopt a new poison pill ''based upon changing market conditions and other circumstances,'' Hewlett-Packard said. A company spokesman, Tim Marklein, declined to say why the plan was originally adopted. Hewlett-Packard shares fell 30 cents, to $18.93.

title: Iran Is Said to Jail 2 Lawyers Who Reported Torture Charges
description: Two lawyers have been imprisoned on charges of spreading lies about Iran's Islamic Republic after they asserted that their clients had been tortured in custody.

title: Visions of Polluted Site Made Cargo Hub
description: To many people, the contaminated lands known as brownfields are best forgotten as the refuse of an industrial past. But to at least one group of planners, they are a ''portfolio of hidden economic assets'' that can help solve the growing problem of congestion around seaports and airports, and provide much needed employment for those with limited skills.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: BANK SELLS BONDS Woori Bank, the flagship of the Woori Finance Company and Korea's second-largest bank, completed the sale of $361 million worth of yen-denominated bonds. Woori, largely owned by the government, announced the results after Kookmin Bank , Korea's largest bank, postponed an $850 million bond sale, citing uncertainties about war in Iraq and confrontation with North Korea. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: City Suspends Fluoridation Of Water for Four Months
description: By the time you read this, there may be no fluoride in your New York City drinking water.

title: Lawyers for a Hyatt Heir Seek To Freeze Foundations' Assets
description: Lawyers for Liesel Pritzker filed a motion today trying to freeze the assets of her family's foundations until her lawsuit claiming that her father stole $1 billion from her trust fund is settled.

title: Indian Bureau Rejects Bid For Group's Status as Tribe
description: The Federal Bureau of Indian Affairs dealt a sharp setback today to an American Indian group's ambitions to open a casino here in Connecticut's largest city, rejecting the group's application for federal recognition as a tribe.

description: Witness Criticizes Pilots

description: The Rev. Al Sharpton of New York filed papers today to create a presidential exploratory committee, saying he planned to announce his candidacy for the White House formally this spring.

description: LAST month, Alia Sabur, a college senior, arrived at her final for Applied Math 301 at 7 p.m. The room was nearly empty. ''What were you thinking?'' asked her professor, Alan Tucker. The test was actually scheduled from 5 to 7:30 p.m.

title: Rights Group Retreats on Charges of Threats by Guatemalan Squads
description: Amnesty International has backed off its highly publicized demands that United States and Guatemalan authorities investigate allegations that Guatemalan death squads had threatened and attacked one of its researchers in her hometown of Forks, Wash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEFFER, LOREN BUTLER
description: FEFFER-Loren Butler. 40, of Aberdeen, NJ, died Monday, January 20, 2003 at Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, NJ. She was an independent scholar and musician. She was a graduate of Rumson-Fair Haven Regional High School in Rumson. She received a B.A. degree from Princeton, a Master's from the University of Michigan, and a PhD from The University of Chicago. Dr. Feffer was born in Long Branch and raised in Rumson, NJ. Surviving are her husband, Stuart Feffer; her parents, Elliott and Betty Butler, Rumson; a brother, Edward Butler; and a sister, Pamela Butler, both New York City. Funeral service will be 11 A.M. Thursday, January 23rd at Woolley Funeral Home, 10 Morrell St., Long Branch. Contributions in her memory to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Fdn, 5005 LBJ Freeway, Ste. 250, Dallas, TX. 75244.

title: Checketts Group Wants the Dodgers
description: A group led by Dave Checketts, a former president of Madison Square Garden, has become the front-runner to acquire the Los Angeles Dodgers and the cable-television network that carries many Dodgers games, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Bill Mauldin, Newspaper Cartoonist, Dies at 81
description: Bill Mauldin, the Army sergeant who created Willie and Joe, the cartoon characters who became enduring symbols of the grimy, irrespressible American infantrymen who triumphed over the German army and prevailed over their own rear-echelon officers in World War II, died today in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 81 years old.

title: North Korea Pledges to Hold Off Nuclear Arms Work
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 22  North Korea pledged today that it had no intention of producing nuclear weapons, a declaration made during high-level talks with South Korean officials here in which both sides appeared to be playing to different audiences.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Wheelchair Access For Ferries
description: The city's push to expand commuter ferry service may have run into its first hurdle yesterday, as Councilwoman Margarita Lopez released a study showing that many vessels, piers and terminals are not fully accessible to the disabled. At a hearing, she introduced a bill that would establish uniform guidelines and standards for all ferries, piers, terminals, gangplanks and ramps. ''It is incomprehensible that an alternative transportation system would be expanded and that the needs of disabled are not being considered,'' she said. At Lower Manhattan's Pier 11, for example, the study found that while wheelchairs could navigate the pier, they could not manage many of the ramps and slips. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: Ridge Confirmed as Security Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  The Senate unanimously confirmed Tom Ridge today as the nation's first secretary of homeland security, entrusting him to preside over the biggest reorganization of the government in a half-century.

title: Trottier Focuses On Ice, Not Above
description: In his first visit to Nassau Coliseum as the head coach of the hated Rangers, Bryan Trottier admitted he took a quick glance at his retired No. 19 hanging from the rafters before this morning's skate.

title: Lighting the Fuse on Iraq
description: Last September President Bush made the wise decision to work through the United Nations Security Council as the most desirable way to force Iraq to disarm. While marshaling American military forces in the Persian Gulf region, he has given international weapons inspectors time to gear up their investigations, test Iraqi intentions and satisfy other nations that force remains, as Mr. Bush has repeatedly said, a last resort. Now, with that process still incomplete, he seems increasingly impatient to abandon inspections and go to war, even if other Security Council members are not yet ready to do so. That would be a mistake.

title: Attorney General Will Step Down in New Jersey
description: Attorney General David Samson announced today that he would resign next month and return to private practice. The man likely to replace him, Peter C. Harvey, his chief assistant, would be the first black appointee to lead the office, which has been at the center of the controversy over racial profiling by the state police.

title: Ladies and Gentlemen, It's Show Time
description: THE woks needed adjusting. There was a problem with the four fish tanks. The busboys were struggling to wrap their kung fu pants so they would stay up.

title: Permission Granted
description: The 49ers received permission to interview the Philadelphia Eagles coordinators Jim Johnson and Brad Childress and the New England defensive coordinator, Romeo Crennel, as possible successors to Steve Mariucci, who was dismissed as the team's coach last week.

title: Tax Proposal On Dividends Is Revised
description: The Bush administration yesterday changed its proposal to exempt dividends from taxes in ways that will make life easier both for companies that pay dividends and for those that invest in other companies.

description: Woori Bank, the flagship of the Woori Finance Company and Korea's second-largest bank, completed the sale of $361 million worth of yen-denominated bonds. Woori, largely owned by the government, announced the results after Kookmin Bank, Korea's largest bank, postponed an $850 million bond sale, citing uncertainties about war in Iraq and confrontation with North Korea. title: As Bush Plans 2004 Budget, Parties Haggle Over 2003's
description: As President Bush plans his State of the Union address, set for a week from tonight, details of his proposed budget for 2004 are trickling out of the White House. Congress, though, remains mired in a battle over spending for 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLSTEIN, SYLVIA REGAN
description: ELLSTEIN-Sylvia Regan, on January 18, 2003. Playwright, lifetime member of the Dramatists Guild, widow of musician-composer Abraham Ellstein, with whom she colaborated on the Broadway musical ''Great To Be Alive'', and the opera ''The Golem''. Miss Regan began her theater career as an actress with Paul Muni, and later worked with Orson Welles and his Mercury Theater. ''Morning Star'', her first Broadway play, was produced sixty years ago, and was recently revived, with great success, by Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater. The Chicago Lyric Opera is currently developing it for production. Her play ''The Fifth Season'' was a long-running Broadway hit, and along with ''Morning Star'' continues to enjoy productions abroad. Miss Regan is survived by three brothers, a niece and nephews. She was ninety-four years old, and died of natural causes.

title: A Snap So Cold Dogs Whine Going Out, and Birds Rush In
description: It was so cold in New York Harbor yesterday that the pigeons were riding inside the Staten Island Ferry.

title: Dark Past of Collector's Family Hangs Over Art Show in Berlin
description: When this city agreed to receive on extended loan a museum's worth of modern and contemporary art earlier this month, it made a deal few would refuse. At virtually no cost, the debt-ridden German capital will have the chance to show one of the most distinguished private collections of its kind in the world -- one that, moreover, has never been shown in its entirety to the public.

title: S.E.C. Said to Open Inquiry On Wyeth Tax Allegations
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an informal inquiry into claims by a former international executive at Wyeth, the drug manufacturer, who says the company was involved in cheating foreign governments out of taxes, according to a lawyer for the executive.

title: Banks Encourage Overdrafts, Reaping Profit
description: At least 1,000 banks are encouraging customers with low balances to overdraw their checking accounts, allowing the banks to skirt credit laws and collect billions of dollars in new fees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNDILL, JOAN REED
description: CUNDILL-Joan Reed. Of Aspen, CO and Tucson, AZ on January 14th, after a brief and courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. She is survived by her husband of 30 years, Peter Cundill, son, Roger North Wiewel, daughter, Evelyn Reed Updegrove, and grandson, Charles Holden Updegrove. Raised in New York and graduated from Skidmore College, Joan gravitated to and eventually settled permanenty in the West. She will be remembered for her grace, beauty, wit, vitality and sense of adventure. Joan travelled the world with family and friends and volunteered her time and effort to the Aspen community in which she lived her final years. She will be greatly missed by the many lives she touched and people she inspired. Kindly send any donations to The American Cancer Society Research Fund, 1800-227-2345. Services private.

title: Raiders and Brown Reach Their Goal
description: It was in the final minutes, when Zack Crockett had just scored to give the Raiders a 17-point lead over the Titans last Sunday, that 15 years of memories and disappointment flooded Tim Brown's mind.

title: Footlights
description: The Way West

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; CLERIC MAY FACE CHARGES
description: The Indonesian police said the prominent Muslim cleric Abu Bakar Bashir should be charged with treason and involvement in bombings of churches here in 2000. Indonesia had long been reluctant to act against Mr. Bashir, spiritual leader of Jemaah Islamiyah, an Islamic movement that was declared a terrorist organization by the United States last October. The government feared that any action could cause a backlash among Muslims. It will now be up to the attorney general to decide whether to proceed against Mr. Bashir, who was arrested in October. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Intense Gruden Likes It That Way
description: Jon Gruden pushes emotional buttons like a serial speed-dialer, jabbing his index finger crookedly, arching an eyebrow, cocking his head.

title: Mayor Joins Officials Seeking U.S. Help in City Budget Crisis
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg added his voice, though somewhat quietly, yesterday to the growing chorus of local elected officials who want the federal government to send the city money to help pull it through its budget crisis.

title: Talks Begin On Trade Pact With Morocco
description: The Bush administration began negotiations for a free trade agreement with Morocco today, emphasizing the importance of expanding economic relations with the Muslim world and pledging to try to complete the accord within one year.

title: Charged-Up Rangers Punish the Isles
description: Islanders right wing Jason Blake had edged into Rangers territory. So, Matthew Barnaby, the Rangers' excitable right wing, thumped into him, setting off a brief skirmish. And the game would not begin for another half-hour.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Layoffs At Shipbuilder
description: The shipbuilder BAE Systems said it would eliminate 1,045 jobs at four British shipyards, to help cut costs as it faced a lull in orders. BAE said the job cuts would take place over an unspecified period of time as it negotiated with trade union representatives. BAE is competing for a 3 billion ($4.83 billion) contract to build two Royal Navy aircraft carriers, but construction on those ships would be unlikely to start until 2006. Its shares fell 3.6 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Staff of S.E.C. Is Said to Dilute Rule Changes
description: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission plans to recommend that the agency soften proposed rules that would impose new obligations on lawyers and accountants, government officials said today.

title: For Super Sunday, A Classic Bar Snack To Make at Home
description: Alfred Portale, the chef and an owner of Gotham Bar and Grill, is from Buffalo. That city's famous chicken wings are not on the menu at his restaurant, but for the Super Bowl he makes them for his staff. His recipe is classic. ''I'm addressing my childhood taste memories,'' he said, ''and when people use ginger or honey, they're not Buffalo wings.''

title: 11 Start Trial in Shootings By Miami Police Officers
description: Eleven suspended or fired police officers whose trial on corruption and conspiracy charges began today in federal court here are the worst kind of criminals, as prosecutors say, or the worst kind of victims, as their lawyers say.

title: Virginia Indicts Young Sniper Suspect on Murder Charges
description: A state grand jury in Fairfax County, Va., handed up a capital murder indictment yesterday against 17-year-old Lee Malvo, one of two suspects in a cross-country rampage of serial shootings that culminated in the Washington-area sniper attacks, law enforcement officials said.

title: At Police Graduation, Bloomberg Takes His Boos, Then Bows
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, whose administration recently floated but then abandoned the possibility of laying off police officers, was loudly booed twice yesterday at a graduation ceremony for new police officers in Madison Square Garden.

title: Transit Union to Announce Contract Vote
description: The union representing 34,000 subway and bus workers is to announce results today or tomorrow of a ratification vote on the three-year contract settlement reached last month.

title: From Indonesia, Skinny Peppers That Bite
description: They look like tiny dried cattails and have an intriguingly complex impact. When simmered with other ingredients, and especially when broken, crushed or ground, these Indonesian long peppers release the sharp spiciness of black pepper, a touch of anise and the earthy pungency of dried prickly ash berries, better known as Sichuan pepper. Crush them to season mushrooms or duck, or add them whole to a syrup for poaching pears or clementines. Boxes containing a half-ounce of the peppers are $5 each at the Oliviers & Company stores.

title: Energy Efficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: Borrowing From Many Sources, With an Urge to Teach
description: Barb Jungr

title: For America's Big Retailers, Small Is Beautiful, Sometimes
description: After carpeting the country with stores measuring 150,000 square feet or more, retailers are discovering that people do not always have the time or the inclination to get all the way through them.

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle on Saturday provided an erroneous clue for 57 Down, seeking the answer ''As an.'' It should have read, '' '____ unperfect actor on the stage' (Shakespearean sonnet start),'' not ''uncertain actor.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, JOHN CHARLES
description: McDONALD-John Charles. Of Brooklyn Heights, died of cancer on January 20, 2003. He was 76 years old. Mr. McDonald distinguished himself by virtue of his wit and grace. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and went to Georgetown and Harvard Law School, graduating with the highest honors. Following graduation, he spent several years at the law firm of Mudge-Rose before devoting himself full-time to trademark law in a long career with Sterling Drug. He eventually headed the United States Trademark Association before retiring in 1990. Upon retirement, Mr. McDonald finally had the chance to pursue his greatest interest, the theater. He was passionately committed to The Acting Company in its support and training of young actors in the classical tradition. He was a Vice-President of The Acting Company and an active member of Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights and a member of the Vestry at the time of his death. His presence-and love-will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife, Louanna O. Carlin, and by the children of his late wife, Bettie McDonald, their son, David, their daughter and son-in-law, Martha and Patrick Goupit, and grandson, Max Goupit. He also is survived by the families of his step-children Will Carlin, Mercer Carlin and Alison Carrabba. Contributions in lieu of flowers should be made to Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights or The Acting Company. A memorial service will be held Saturday, January 25th, at 11:00 AM at Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights.

title: The Evolution of a General Strike
description: In Venezuela, groups opposing President Hugo Chávez began a general strike on Dec. 2 with the aim of forcing a referendum on his rule. Mr. Chávez, who was first elected in 1998, won a fresh six-year term in 2000 after the Constitution was amended.

title: Nostalgia and Songs of Love From Swedish Rock Bands
description: Have you heard about the Swedish invasion? Maybe ''invasion'' isn't the right word. A couple of Swedish rock 'n' roll bands came to New York last week, but there were no mob scenes at airports, and the Billboard charts didn't even flinch.

title: Bush Promotes Plan for Small Business Owners
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 22 — President Bush peddled his economic plan in an important political swing state today, saying that it would benefit America's small-business owners and that it was not a giveaway to his richest supporters.

title: An Appreciation; Remembering a French Journalist Known for lan and Grit
description: When Franoise Giroud died on Sunday at 86, France lost more than just a prolific journalist who had served as that country's first minister of women's affairs and (for a few months) as minister of culture during the 1970's presidency of Valry Giscard d'Estaing.

title: The Point of Punk Rock
description: To the Editor:

title: The Right to Agree
description: Today is the 30th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion in the United States. We are two women who were born in the early 1970's and, like other Americans our age, were raised with the divisions the decision has wrought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TODD, HELAINE (NEE FRIEDMAN)
description: TODD-Helaine (nee Friedman). She was the sister we never had. A very special lady whose taste for life touched everyone. We'll truly miss her. Ralph and Bea

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANOFF, MEYER K. (MIKE)
description: SANOFF-Meyer K. (Mike), 88. Of Scarsdale, NY. 64 years at the Bar. Army Captain WWII. Passionately loving husband of Helen, devoted father of Jonathan. Services Thursday, 1 PM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY. 1-800-468-3232.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Front-Runners To Lead W.H.O.
description: Five candidates have been selected as possible replacements for the World Health Organization's departing director general, Gro Harlem Brundtland. They are Dr. Julio Frenk of Mexico, Dr. Jong Wook Lee of South Korea, Dr. Pascoal Manuel Mocumbi of Mozambique, Dr. Peter Piot of Belgium and Ismail Sallam of Egypt, who is a professor. The executive board of the United Nation's main health body will nominate a replacement by Jan. 28. The applicant must be approved this spring by the World Health Assembly. Ms. Brundtland's term expires June 30. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Questions? Where Can We Begin?
description: A YELLOW backhoe with a jagged claw for diggin' deep chugs away on the grounds of America's Olympic headquarters, churning through the layers of dirt beneath the windows of Lloyd Ward's chief executive office.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about protests against the threat of war against Iraq quoted incorrectly from a comment by the actor Martin Sheen, who addressed demonstrators in San Francisco. He said: ''You all know what I do for a living. This is what I do to stay alive'' (not ''You all know what I do for work; this is what I do for a living'').

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Lego Copyright Upheld
description: The Danish toy maker Lego said it won a court case against a Chinese company it accused of copying its building-block products. Lego said that it had filed suit in 1999 against the Chinese company, the Coko Toy Company of Tianjin, and that it had recently won a judgment in the case from the Beijing High People's Court, a ruling it said could have positive implications for other companies in China. Lego said the court ordered Coko Toy to turn over equipment used to copy the Lego building blocks, print an apology in a local paper and pay financial compensation to Lego.

title: Emphasize Disease Prevention, Health Secretary Tells Insurers
description: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said today that the nation's insurance companies were ''wrong-headed'' because they emphasized treating illness rather than preventing disease.

title: M.L.S. Signs Howard to Contract Extension
description: MetroStars goalkeeper Tim Howard signed a three-year contract extension with Major League Soccer. The league, which owns all player contracts, is expected to make an announcement later in the week.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: LAYOFFS AT SHIPBUILDER The shipbuilder BAE Systems said it would eliminate 1,045 jobs at four British shipyards, to help cut costs as it faced a lull in orders. BAE said the job cuts would take place over an unspecified period of time as it negotiated with trade union representatives. BAE is competing for a 3 billion ($4.83 billion) contract to build two Royal Navy aircraft carriers, but construction on those ships would be unlikely to start until 2006. Its shares fell 3.6 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Driver Kills a Bronx Woman, 63, and Flees
description: A 63-year-old Bronx woman was killed yesterday in a hit-and-run accident that left her pinned against a wall of the Morris Heights Post Office, the police said. She was the fourth person to be killed in a rash of hit-and-run accidents in the city since Friday.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Itron To Buy Silicon Energy
description: A maker of electronic meter-reading systems for utilities companies, Itron Inc., agreed yesterday to buy the Silicon Energy Corporation, an energy management software maker for $71.2 million. The purchase, which would be Itron's fourth in the last 12 months, includes about $4.2 million of Silicon Energy debt, Itron said. The transaction is expected to close by the end of next month and will be financed using a $50 million bank loan and cash, Itron said. The acquisition of Silicon Energy is expected to add about $15 million in revenue for the portion of the year that the company is part of Itron, according to Itron. Itron is based in Spokane, Wash., and Silicon Energy is based in Alameda, Calif. Itron said it cut about 40 jobs, representing nearly a third of the work force at its wholesale energy software unit in Raleigh, N.C. Related expenses will reduce 2003 earnings by about $2 million, mostly in the first quarter, the company said.

title: Dow Jones Drops Goodby, Silverstein
description: Dow Jones & Company in New York has parted ways with Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, which has handled the account of The Wall Street Journal since 1999.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; A Conspiracy Nipped Can Still Bring Conviction, Justices Say
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that members of a criminal conspiracy can be convicted regardless of whether the discovery of the plot by the police has made it impossible for the conspiracy to achieve its goal.

title: Then There Are the Poor
description: It may not be class warfare, but it's breathtakingly provocative. One week after President Bush proposed billions in tax breaks for fretful stock owners, he revived a plan to wring an additional 10 hours of work each week from women with small children who are managing to hold a job under the federal welfare reform program. The program was hailed as an early success in reducing the welfare rolls. But it is now being threatened with ideological wrenching under the Bush proposal.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, a front-page article yesterday about disagreement in the United Nations Security Council over the prospect of military action against Iraq quoted incorrectly from a comment by the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, who spoke to reporters after a Council meeting. He said, "Iraq has fully  to comply fully  with all relevant resolutions" (not "Iraq has complied fully with all relevant resolutions").

title: Israel Destroys Arabs' Shops in West Bank
description: The Israeli Army used bulldozers to flatten dozens of shops today in one of the only thriving Palestinian commercial centers near the West Bank boundary, saying that the store owners lacked permits.

title: Avant Wins Contract for Oral Vaccine for Anthrax and Plague
description: A biotechnology company has received a contract to develop an oral vaccine for the military that would work against anthrax and plague. If it works, the combination vaccine could be a major advance from current vaccines, which require multiple injections.

title: Police Buy Suits to Protect Against Chemical Weapons
description: The New York Police Department is buying nearly 40,000 special suits used to protect soldiers against chemical weapons and will begin issuing them next month to 4,600 of the department's 37,000 officers, police officials said yesterday.

title: Sweet, Salt And Crunch
description: THE combination of ham, green beans and pears sounds like a concoction you might come up with only when you were too tired and hungry to do anything except grab whatever was at hand and throw it into a pan.

title: Washington Talk; A Ringing Endorsement, From 700 Miles Away
description: In the politics of abortion, there is no day more fraught with emotion than Jan. 22, the anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision recognizing abortion as a constitutional right. Presidents, as a rule, have to take a stand that day, make a gesture, reaffirm which side they are on.

title: A Rip of Orange in Deepest Winter
description: THERE'S something about this time of year that can take the pep out of your step. It's all right to feel cozy and warm about the advent of winter at the fading fringes of fall, when everything seems to promise crisp nights and warm kitchens, but by now it's too easy to be enveloped in mufflers and despondency. I need something to cheer me up. Thankfully, nature provides it.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Pledging And Studying Ethics
description: In his first official act as governor, Gov. Bob Riley made his cabinet appointees sign ethics pledges and then had them attend a class given by the state Ethics Commission. Mr. Riley, a Republican who asserted during the campaign that the administration of Gov. Donald Siegelman, his Democratic predecessor, lacked ethics, signed the pledge as well. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Far From the Dust, a Persistent Cough; Man With Few Trade Center Ties Traces His Asthma to 9/11
description: Glenn H. Abatemarco got sick two weeks after terrorists attacked the World Trade Center, and he has still not fully recovered his ability to breathe normally.

title: 4-Year-Old Girl in Body Cast Dies in a Fire in Newark
description: A 4-year-old girl, unable to escape a fast-moving fire in her home because she was wrapped in a body cast, died here today in a blaze that left her young brother in critical condition and injured six others, the authorities said. Neighbors tried frantically to save the girl and three other young children, including a toddler who was tossed to safety from a upstairs window.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Class President
description: Once when I was covering the first President Bush, I took one of his top political strategists out to dinner.
