description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Officers of U.S.O.C. Press Its President to Resign
description: Seven officers of the United States Olympic Committee yesterday demanded the resignation of the organization's president, Marty Mankamyer, saying that she had interfered improperly in the investigation into whether Lloyd Ward, the organization's chief executive, had violated its ethics code.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Sungard To Buy Caminus For $159 Million
description: SunGard Data Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Caminus Corporation, a software provider for the energy industry, for $159 million. Under the agreement, expected to close early this year, SunGard will pay $9 a share in cash for each of Caminus's 17.7 million shares outstanding. The offer represents a 260 percent premium to Caminus' closing stock price on Friday of $2.50 a share. News of the buyout sent shares of Caminus skyrocketing $6.31, or 252 percent, to $8.81. The markets were closed Monday. Shares of Sungard finished at $20.74, down 89 cents, or 4.1 percent. Caminus shareholders representing about 26 percent of the company's outstanding stock have agreed to throw their shares behind Sungard's offer. Caminus, based in New York, makes software that manages trading in commodities like crude oil, natural gas and power. The software simulates conditions in the energy market and potential weather trends to forecast prices. The company had 2002 revenue of $84 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES INC., Murray Hill, N.J., the maker of telephone equipment, agreed with Cisco Systems Inc., San Jose, Calif., to sell Cisco's packet-data and media products as part of its mobile network offerings. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLAGSBRUN, DANIEL
description: KLAGSBRUN-Daniel. 1/22/64-1/26/88. Dan, today on your birthday and every day, you are deeply missed, remembered, never forgotten.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Toms River: Staten Island Man Indicted In Deaths
description: A former nurse from Staten Island has been indicted for murder in two dismemberment deaths in the early 1990's, the Ocean County prosecutor announced yesterday. The former nurse, Richard W. Rodgers Jr., is charged with the first-degree murder of Thomas Mulcahy, 57, of Sudbury, Mass., in July 1992 and of Anthony W. Marrero, 44, in May 1993, said Thomas F. Kelaher, the prosecutor. Parts of Mr. Mulcahy's body were found in garbage bags at a Garden State Parkway rest stop and along Route 72. Mr. Marrero's body was found on a dirt road in Manchester Township, Mr. Kelaher said. Mr. Rodgers was a registered nurse at Mount Sinai Medical Center for more than 20 years. He is being held in $1 million bail at the Ocean County Jail.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZALEFSKY, DAVID H.
description: ZALEFSKY-David H. Dear dad, we miss your sage advise and stunning physical appearance. Your greatest legacies are your two grandchildren Allegra and Jeremy. Love, Lois, Ray, Dana, David and James

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBERMAN, HARRY
description: HUBERMAN-Harry. 92, of Hewlett, NY. Peacefully, January 20, 2003. Devoted husband of the late Elizabeth. Cherished brother and brother-in-law of Frances and George J. Greenberg. Beloved father of Roberta (Stuart Schwartz), Laura (Yossie Ben-Shmuel), and Ellen (Chris George). Adored grandfather of Maryam, Juliet, Shaia, Michal, Elisheva, Zack, Benjamin, Alexander and Shira. Loving greatgrandfather of Nico, Eli and Jake. Treasured uncle of Marilyn, Maury and Robert Greenberg. Funeral January 22nd, 11 AM, Lieber Funeral Home, 266 North Central Avenue, Valley Stream. Memorial donations may be made to Greenwood House, Ewing, NJ or UJA.

title: Blair Sees Iraq Weakening As France Resists Early War
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair told senior members of Parliament today that a ''massive amount'' of new intelligence suggested that the escalation of armed forces in the Persian Gulf is shaking Saddam Hussein and undermining his rule over Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 5 about a co-op manager's decision to disconnect the Russian Television Network at a dozen buildings in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to the steps that the manager, Arthur Wiener, said he took to consult residents before acting. He said he did not need the consent of the co-op boards; he did not say he had failed to obtain it. (The board of the building highlighted in the article, 1120 Brighton Beach Avenue, gave its consent. At the others, Mr. Wiener said, he consulted individual members, but not full boards.)

title: Performers Lose a Step, And Find a Second Act
description: When Laine Barton, a clown and mime in her late 40's, began to feel her knees grumbling, she realized that her days as a performer were numbered.

title: Carter Offers Proposals to Resolve Conflict in Venezuela
description: Former President Jimmy Carter dived into this country's tumultuous political crisis today, offering two proposals for ending seven weeks of bitter stalemate between President Hugo Chvez and a broad coalition of opponents that has left the country's economy in shambles and its people poised for violence.

title: The Neediest Cases; Persistent Aunt Travels Extra Mile to Secure Nephew
description: After seven months in a Honduran orphanage, Otto Galindo, now 3, is finally back with his family. In the living room of his aunt's home in Plattekill, N.Y., he eats chocolate and plays with Mia Nikol, his cousin. He laughs when tickled. He cries when frustrated.

title: Giving Cabbage the Royal Treatment
description: NOTHING says winter vegetable like a head of cabbage. I see one just now, heading into a steam bath with a sack of potatoes and a side of pork. Of course, winter has no exclusive rights to cabbage, which finds itself scraped raw on a box grater in July. There is, however, something in a cabbage's gravity, the inscrutability of its smooth, round face, and the jealous grip it keeps on its inner leaves that tells the cook to chop, steam and soften.

description: THEATER

title: Quoting Himself on His Lofty Dream
description: THE SPOOKY ART

description: ''Teachers who are cookie cutters are not what we need. We need teachers who are creative and empowered.''

title: 2004 in Mind, Yanks Talk to Lieber
description: For all of the Yankees' pitching riches, their rotation beyond this season is murky. Mike Mussina, Jeff Weaver and Jos Contreras are signed; Roger Clemens, David Wells, Andy Pettitte and Sterling Hitchcock are not.

title: TEVA SAYS BRITISH COURT INVALIDATES 2 MERCK PATENTS
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, a leading maker of generic drugs, said a British court invalidated two Merck & Company patents for the osteoporosis drug, Fosamax. Merck said it would appeal. Teva said it would not introduce a generic version of Fosamax in Britain until 2004 because of ''regulatory procedures.'' Merck said the ruling by the High Court of Justice for England and Wales also benefits Arrow Generics and Generics UK Ltd., a unit of Merck of Germany. The two Mercks are unrelated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLAND, ELIZABETH (NEE DEVEREAUX)
description: BOLAND - Elizabeth (nee Devereaux). On January 20, 2003. Beloved wife of Laurence, loving mother of Mary and Jim, devoted mother-inlaw of Frances and Michael, and devoted grandmother of James, Caitlin, Matthew and Ryan. Survived by four dear sisters. Reposing at Bay Ridge Funeral Home, 7614 Fourth Ave, Brooklyn, on Wednesday, January 22, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral mass Thursday, January 23, 9:30 AM St. Agatha's RC Church, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Covenant House of New York.

title: Two Surging Belgians Will Test Williamses in Australian Semifinals
description: It will be the United States versus Belgium in the women's semifinals at the Australian Open, and though that matchup is hardly a longstanding rivalry in tennis or any other sport, this just might be the start of something gripping.

title: Lawyers for Indicted Mayor Attack Credibility of Witness
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 21 — Lawyers for Joseph P. Ganim, the Bridgeport mayor on trial on federal corruption charges, continued to attack the credibility of a crucial government witness today, portraying him as seeking leniency for his own crimes by implicating the mayor in a kickback scheme.

title: Jumping at Offer, Czechs Hitch Ride Home From Kuwait
description: When the Czech defense minister paid a visit on Monday to his country's troops engaged in chemical warfare defense in Kuwait, he made an unusual offer. With an American-led invasion of Iraq appearing increasingly possible, the minister, Jaroslav Tvrdik, a former career officer, announced that any Czech soldiers who did not really want to go to war could return home with him that evening.

title: BUSH SAYS IRAQIS ARE STILL RESISTING DEMAND TO DISARM
description: President Bush said today that Iraq was not complying with demands that it disarm and expressed frustration at calls from France and other nations to allow more time for diplomacy and United Nations weapons inspections.

title: Virgin Airways Seeks New Agency
description: A big advertiser is beginning a search for a new agency as other marketers complete reviews.

title: A Series of Solo Piano Works, To the Rhythms of the Psalms
description: Andrew Zolinsky, pianist

title: Podunk, by Way of the Bowery, for Sweets
description: When Elspeth Treadwell worked in an office, she often treated co-workers and friends to her cupcakes and other baked goods. The day she saw a little storefront for rent at 231 East Fifth Street (Bowery), she decided to switch careers. She named her store Podunk, and now sells buttery cookies (75 cents each), scones (75 cents and $1.25), cupcakes ($1.50 each) and cardamom and vanilla Bundt cakes (by the slice or $22 to $24 for the whole cake).

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: COLOMBIA: GROUP HOLDS 3 AMERICANS Far-right paramilitaries said they were holding three journalists in the jungle on the Panamanian border  apparently including Robert Young Pelton, the Canadian-American author of a best-selling book about traveling in danger zones. Panamanian and American officials said Mr. Pelton, a frequent guest on CNN, disappeared on the weekend in the Darien Gap along with Americans Mark Wedeven and Megan Smaker. Carlos Castano, commander of the United Self-Defense Forces, said that the three foreigners were being held "for their own safety" after combat with Marxist rebels, and would be freed soon. Mr. Castano said his militia found them in the northern Colombian province of Choco where his fighters had been under attack from leftist rebels. But Panamanian police said Mr. Castano's fighters had attacked two Indian villages on Panama's side of the border killing five community leaders. (Reuters)

title: Stephen Kates, 59, Teacher And a Prizewinning Cellist
description: Stephen Kates, a cellist and teacher who was a Tchaikovsky International Cello Competition prizewinner, died on Saturday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 59 and lived in Annapolis, Md.

title: Finding a Place for Ridicule In a Tradition of Insensitivity
description: Last week there was horror in the sports pages that the basketball superstar of the Los Angeles Lakers, Shaquille O'Neal, had subjected Yao Ming, the Chinese rookie on the rival Houston Rockets, to ethnic ridicule, a gaffe for which O'Neal has been roundly castigated.

description: The Ribbon Collection, from the Italian architect Pietro Del Vaglio, offers surprisingly comfortable sculptural furniture.

title: Dutch Appear to Re-elect Conservative Leader in Mixed Outcome
description: After a soul-searching electoral campaign, Dutch voters appeared tonight to have returned the incumbent conservative prime minister to office, while at the same time backing a resurgence of the left-of-center Labor Party.

title: Merrill Shows Profit, But Gloom Prevails
description: A continuing campaign of cost-cutting helped Merrill Lynch & Company swing to a profit in the fourth quarter, but the firm's executives sprayed ice water yesterday on any bullish views of Wall Street's future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, HERBERT NOAH
description: COHN-Herbert Noah. Son of late Gabriel and Sarah Cohn, brother of late Gloria Kastner, and survived by his wife, Olive, and their children Nancy and Robert, daughter-inlaw Jayne, and grandchildren Erin, Payton and Evan, died at age 85 on January 21, 2003. He served his country during WWII as a combat engineer and architect in New Guinea with the United States Army. A graduate of Columbia University School of Architecture, he was a partner in CWC Construction Company, and built numerous schools, apartment buildings and other commercial facilities in and around New York City. Memorial services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY on January 24, 2003 at 11:00 a.m. Donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Suite 1100, Chicago, Ill., 60611-8882.

title: Oneida Tribe to Endow $3 Million Chair in Indian Law at Harvard
description: The Oneida Indian Nation of central New York will endow a $3 million chair in Indian law at Harvard Law School, the first such chair at a university east of the Mississippi, Harvard and the Oneidas said yesterday.

title: The Flexible Farmer Lets the Robot Do the Milking
description: FOR most of the last 20 years, the milking at the Cloverdale Farm was an unwelcome ritual for both the cows and the people. Every morning the owner, Wayne Edwards, and an assistant would wake up at 5:30 and spend the next two hours milking. Then every afternoon at 4 the process began again, this time lasting about three hours with cleanup.

description: President Bush told tens of thousands of abortion protesters today that he shared their commitment to ''protect the lives of innocent children waiting to be born,'' and asserted that the anti-abortion movement was gaining steam in Congress and the culture at large.

description: Officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service said yesterday that six detainees had ended the hunger strike they began on Jan. 14 to protest conditions at the Passaic County Jail. An I.N.S. spokesman, Kerry Gill, said no promises had been made to the immigrants, although their demands were being considered. The men, including at least two who were arrested after Sept. 11, are being held on various immigration charges and have asked for visits with their families without the jail's glass wall separating them. Susan Sachs (NYT)

description: LISA HUMMEL is 36 and lives in San Francisco. She found her husband at one of the most frequented spots in the Bay Area: Craigslist.org.

description: At times, football overwhelms Marc Trestman. He loves its details, the levers and the mechanics and the art beneath the savagery, but the game has also driven him away, only to lure him back like a temptress.

description: American Airlines and Southwest Airlines reported results yesterday that painted a stark picture of the floundering airline industry.

description: Sometimes when two old friends get together the stories will flow with particular zest. Thus it was on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall, when the New York Philharmonic played with its namesake from Israel for the first time in more than 20 years, and Lorin Maazel conducted Mahler's First Symphony, with the New York and Tel Aviv musicians sharing desks.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Pressure From U.S. On War Crimes
description: The top American diplomat for war crimes issues, Pierre-Richard Prosper, met senior officials including President Vojislav Kostunica to demand that Yugoslavia hand over people indicted on war crimes charges to the United Nations tribunal. Mr. Prosper warned that unless the two most wanted suspects believed to be hiding in the country were arrested by March 31, the United States could suspend financial aid. Officials in Belgrade say they do not know the whereabouts of Ratko Mladic, accused of genocide in Bosnia, or Veselin Sljivancanin, charged with committing atrocities in Croatia. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

description: ''This is a drill,'' the former chicken farmer said today, pointing to what was undeniably a drill, illuminated in a dark shed by a line of lights atop television cameras. ''This is not a computer.''

title: With Art All the Rage Again, Projects Are Finished
description: IT is not as if Tom Eccles, the director and curator of the Public Art Fund, is without opinions. Mr. Eccles, whose nonprofit group presents attention-getting projects like the Witch Catcher -- a mysterious new installation with a soaring, twisted chimney at City Hall Park and, in 2000, Jeff Koons's flowering 40-foot-tall terrier puppy in Rockefeller Center -- has plenty of them.

title: NATO Secretary General to Leave His Post in December After 4 Years
description: The NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson, announced today that he would leave his job in December, resisting requests from many members to stay on for another year.

title: Chaos, or Democracy, in Iraq Could Be Unsettling to Saudis
description: It is hard to say what the princes here fear more, a war in Iraq that leads to chaos or a war that brings democracy to the Arabian Peninsula.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACKMAN, BARBARA (BOBBI), PSY.D.
description: BACKMAN-Barbara (Bobbi), Psy.D. Defined by style, grace, elegance and beauty, Bobbi attacked everything she did with determination and perfection. As a gifted psychologist, she had an ear for listening and an overwhelming compassion for everyone that came into her life. As a loving and devoted wife, mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, sister and friend, she used those capabalities to make everyone and everything more beautiful. The peace and happiness that she brought to her family and friends will live on for generations to come. After a courageous battle with cancer at 53, she leaves behind her husband, Jerry, son and daughter-in-law, Jon and Dana Kaynes, son, Adam Kaynes, son and daughter-inlaw, Jon and Eileen Backman, son and daughter-inlaw, Ken and Joyce Backman, brother, Michael Fried, loving mother-in-law of Mario Backman and five dear grandchildren. Bobbi will be missed and loved forever. Funeral Services Thursday, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Pain and Palliative Care Dept.

description: Following is a full transcript from a speech yesterday by Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz to the Council for Foreign Relations in New York City, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

title: Big Night Follows An Off Day By Houston
description: Marcus Camby knew the Denver Nuggets were in trouble when he heard Jeff Bzdelik's pregame speech. Bzdelik, the Nuggets' rookie coach, was emphasizing the importance of containing Latrell Sprewell. But Camby knew his coach was shortchanging the Knicks' main offensive weapon, Allan Houston.

title: Corrections
description: A series of profiles on Monday of Pakistanis who were recently deported from the United States for having entered the country illegally or having overstayed visas misspelled the surname of a lawyer for one man. The lawyer, who represents Anser Mehmood, a 42-year-old truck driver and father of four who lived in Bayonne, N.J., is Martin R. Stolar, not Stoller.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Motorola Predicts Rise In Sales
description: Motorola Inc., the world's second-biggest mobile telephone maker, said that consumers worldwide would buy 430 million to 440 million handsets in 2003 as demand increases for the first time in three years. About 400 million cellphones were purchased last year, Mike S. Zafirovski, president of Motorola, said. The forecast is in line with his statement this month that worldwide sales will rise 8 percent to 10 percent this year. Some analysts and investors have said the company's newest models will not be competitive enough to take sales from rivals like Nokia and Samsung. Motorola said that first-quarter profit would miss forecasts as margins lag analysts' estimates. Motorola reported its first consecutive quarters of net income in two years as fourth-quarter sales rose 3.2 percent, beating forecasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAY, DONALD GROFF
description: DAY-Donald Groff. Died on January 16, 2003 in New York City. He worked as a freelance medical writer and editor for more than thirty years. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, January 25, 2003, at 10 A.M. at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, New York 10027.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: City Aid Delayed By Lawsuit
description: A $175 million package of state aid to New Jersey's poorest city has been delayed by a lawsuit that seeks to preserve local control over municipal affairs, state officials said. The suit, filed by a council member and a group of residents, has thwarted an ambitious revitalization plan announced by Gov. James E. McGreevey last summer that would provide the money in exchange for state control over Camden's government. As part of the plan, the state would appoint a chief executive to oversee the city's fiscal affairs and the governor would have veto power over a restructured school board. Melvin R. Primas, above, a former mayor of Camden who was named the city's new chief operating officer, said that the bonds needed to raise the money could not be issued until the lawsuit was dropped or amended. Ali Sloan-El, the council member who is part of the suit, said he was willing to consider a compromise. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Second Child Dies From Fire
description: A second child has died of injuries suffered in a fire that roared through an apartment building here on Tuesday. The authorities said that Eric Bullock, 3, was pronounced dead at University Hospital on Tuesday evening, about nine hours after a fire that claimed the life of his 4-year-old sister, Frances. Firefighters had to rescue the children when smoke and flames trapped them in their second-floor apartment. Frances had been unable to escape because she was wrapped in a body cast from injuries suffered when she was struck by a car. Both children, and six other people, were taken to the hospital suffering from smoke inhalation. The others, including their mother, were treated and released. Officials said early signs were that the fire had begun accidentally, but no definitive cause had been determined. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

description: Burns W. Roper, a leading pollster for four decades and the author of political polling's central question about the state of the nation, died on Monday at his home in Bourne, Mass., on Cape Cod. He was 77.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: PAKISTANI DIPLOMATS ORDERED TO LEAVE The government ordered the expulsion of four Pakistani Embassy officials, a move Pakistan said would further damage relations between the nuclear-armed rivals. The four officials, including the second-ranking diplomat at the mission, were told to leave the country within 48 hours, India's foreign Ministry spokesman, Navtej Sarna, said. Implying that the four were spying, he said they "were found indulging in activities incompatible with their official status."    (AP)

title: Major Family Gift
description: The Hillandale Group of the Sulzberger Foundation, representing the fourth and fifth generations of the Ochs-Sulzberger family, decided yesterday to contribute $250,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. This is the largest single contribution the Hillandale Group has ever made. No previous gift has exceeded $100,000.

title: U.S. SET TO DEMAND THAT ALLIES AGREE IRAQ IS DEFYING U.N.
description: Bush administration officials said today that next week they would confront France, Germany and other skeptics of military action against Iraq by demanding that they agree publicly that Iraq had defied the United Nations Security Council.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: APPEAL TO RULING ON CREDIT STATEMENTS State officials said they would appeal a federal ruling that lets banks ignore a California law requiring them to notify customers in credit card statements how long it would take to pay off debts by making only the minimum monthly payments. "This statute is a legitimate exercise of the state's consumer protection authority," said Tom Dresslar, a spokesman for the state attorney general's office. Last month, Judge Frank Damrell Jr. of Federal District Court sided with banks in ruling that federal regulations superseded the state law. (AP)

title: Outsider Art, In From the Edge And Under the Gavel
description: ROBERT M. GREENBERG doesn't exactly look like Diane Keaton in Woody Allen's ''Annie Hall,'' but stepping into an elevator in Hell's Kitchen last week, dressed in a maxicoat with a beret pulled tight to his wire-rimmed glasses, a long bob of hair hanging out the bottom, he shared some of the same oddball charm.

title: New Group to Oppose Proposals on Digital Piracy
description: Some technology companies and consumer organizations are planning to announce today that they have formed a lobbying alliance to oppose technology regulations that are favored by the motion picture industry.

title: Olympic Aerialist Falls Back to Earth
description: It was Feb. 19, 2002 and Eric Bergoust, the Babe Ruth of freestyle aerials, stood at the crest of a snowy hill making the last preparations for his final jump at the Salt Lake City Olympic Games. As the defending Olympic gold medal winner, a three-time world champion and the recent star of a national campaign of television commercials, Bergoust was, in virtually every way that mattered to him, on top of the world.

Friend to all and loved by everyone. Successful in family, business and life. You deeply touched all of us and you will be missed by all. Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th Street, Friday at 10 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, ALLEN
description: ALLEN-Allen. Famous New York City restaurateur and raconteur died with his family at his side on January 23, 2003. Loving and adoring husband of Fay Allen. Devoted father of Jeffrey and Sheila, Mark and Donna, Bonnie and Ronald Allen. Most cherished grandfather to his ''earth angels'' Gregory, Greer, Meredith, Brett, Carly and Perry. His love, warmth and humor will be deeply missed by all. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Friday, 11:15AM. Interment Abraham and Sarah Cemetery, Paramus, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Friends of Karen or the Friars Club Foundation.

title: Caught in the Cold
description: One thing meteorologists are never short of is ways to measure the way one chunk of weather differs from another. The present chunk, which most of us in the Northeast think of simply as raw, unending cold, is best measured by the number of days in a row the temperature hasn't risen above freezing. We're on the cusp of double digits after a warm December, which means that everyone's inner thermostat has gone haywire. People walk around in the nearly normal cold claiming that it's deeply abnormal. How soon we forget. The record for sub-freezing New York days in a row was set in 1961, but there was a cold snap longer than this one only three years ago.

title: Embracing Mother Russia, Warmly; To migrs in Brooklyn, Furs Are Badge of Success
description: In Russia, there is a cherished expression, says Anatoly Alter, furrier to the women of Brighton Beach: ''We're not so rich that we can buy cheap merchandise.''

title: Random House Expands Into Japan With Joint Venture
description: TOKYO, Jan. 23  Random House, the world's largest publisher of English- and German-language trade books, said today that it would form a joint venture with Kodansha, the largest publisher in Japan, to issue original Japanese-language books and translations of international titles.

title: The Boyz 'N Product Placement
description: It can't be art all the time for today's hip-hop artist. You must put aside quality time to flog the gear. The Source magazine, sort of the Rolling Stone of the hip-hop world, has 10 pages of ads for Air Jordan in its February issue; the rapper JA RULE is on the cover of the magazine; Ja Rule arrives early at the party at Sessa Tuesday night for the photo-op. On his feet the Air Jordan XVIII, the lineage of which, any moment, will exceed that of the kings of France.

title: Calibrating the Smallpox Vaccinations
description: The Bush administration is sending out its first batches of smallpox vaccine this week so that health officials can begin immunizing health care workers against infection should there be a terrorist attack. Despite a small backlash against the vaccination campaign in medical circles, there is good reason to proceed with such immunizations promptly so that a cadre of health workers is available to treat the victims of any terrorist attack without its members falling sick themselves or spreading the disease to others. But medical experts have raised enough cautionary flags that the administration ought to consider modifications that could help the program achieve its goals with greater assurance of safety and effectiveness.

title: Recording Industry Lobbyist Plans to Leave Her Position
description: Hilary Rosen, the music business's prominent Washington lobbyist and a vocal defender of the industry against online piracy and copyright infringement, said today that she was leaving at the end of the year.

title: North Korea Informs South Korea That It Doesn't Plan to Produce Nuclear Weapons
description: North Korea said today that it had no intention of producing nuclear weapons, making the pledge to South Korea in high-level talks here in which both sides appeared to be playing to different audiences.

title: RATINGS AGENCY WARNS INTERPUBLIC ON DEBT
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, the advertising conglomerate struggling with financial and accounting difficulties, was warned yesterday by Standard & Poor's that its credit rating could be lowered to junk status. Standard & Poor's, which downgraded the long-term corporate credit rating of Interpublic in November and again in December, said it would decide soon whether plans by management to address liquidity concerns related to debt coming due ''are enough for the rating to remain at the current level.'' It added, ''There is no remaining cushion in the rating to withstand any negative news or disappointing earnings performance.'' In the meantime, Interpublic remains on the Standard & Poor's CreditWatch with negative implications and its debt is rated one level above junk. Interpublic, which owns agencies like Lowe & Partners Worldwide and McCann-Erickson Worldwide, had $2.9 billion in debt as of Sept. 30. Stuart Elliott (NYT)

title: Electrical Fire Destroys Ballroom at Sharpton Headquarters
description: The Harlem ballroom where the Rev. Al Sharpton has held court for six years, preaching civil rights and excoriating politicians who raised his ire, was destroyed yesterday morning by fire. City officials said last night that the two-alarm fire had been caused by an electrical problem.

The men, including at least two who were arrested after Sept. 11, are being held on various immigration charges.

description: Gov. George E. Pataki took to the road yesterday to sell his philosophy that the state must look beyond its budget crisis and hold down taxes to protect jobs and improve the state's economy. At the same time, he warned that the crisis was so severe that the alternative steps would be extremely difficult, affecting all New Yorkers.

title: Ruling Means Bumpy Year For Elections in New Jersey
description: Just a few months after the bumpy race for the United States Senate, New Jersey is on the verge of another tumultuous election season now that a state appeals court has thrown out the state's map of legislative districts.

title: Suspect Describes Ordeal of Slain Reporter
description: The nursery where they killed him, one year on, is oddly peaceful. Lush mango, palm and pomegranate trees are in bloom, their thick, green leaves whispering in a gentle breeze.

title: Bill Mauldin, Cartoonist Who Showed World War II Through G.I. Eyes, Dies at 81
description: Bill Mauldin, the Army sergeant who created Willie and Joe, the cartoon characters who became enduring symbols of the grimy, irrepressible American infantrymen who triumphed over the German army and prevailed over their own rear-echelon officers in World War II, died yesterday in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TODD, HELAINE (NEE FRIEDMAN)

title: Tyco Posts 47% Decline in First-Quarter Earnings
description: Tyco International, the conglomerate trying to right itself after its top executives were charged with looting the company, said yesterday that its earnings declined nearly 50 percent in its first fiscal quarter and warned that its results for the rest of the year would be near the low end of its previous estimates.

title: Corrections

That boat, in the background, was unidentified; it was not the mysterious ship.

description: Q. I have heard that new DVD's are being developed that can hold more than 20 gigabytes of datA. How is that accomplished, and when will these discs be on the market?

description: Joe Jurevicius' Super Bowl week began today, two days after the rest of his Tampa Bay teammates arrived, and now he has a slightly clearer head.

title: Old-Style Sundance Vs. Starry Premieres; Festival Takes On A Marketing Sheen
description: After last year's Sundance Film Festival, when the crowds were sparse and the films were wanting, this year's installment has been a boisterous, traffic-choked return to the days when Sundance epitomized a certain kind of raw, scruffy cool. At the same time, it also showed signs, troubling to many Sundance veterans, of becoming an increasingly important Hollywood marketing tool.

title: One Design for Trade Center Site Is Crossed Off After Firm Leaves
description: One of the seven architectural teams that submitted new designs for the World Trade Center site has been eliminated from further consideration, rebuilding officials said yesterday. The decision followed the withdrawal of the architecture firm that was the lead partner in the effort, they said.

title: Mouths Wide Open: Sapp and Middleton in Trash-Talk War
description: Warren Sapp is the kind of player who, almost nine years later, remembers an article written when he was a senior at the University of Miami and recalls the headline: ''Lofty Boasts, Lofty Expectations.''

title: Real Chaises Have Curves
description: The Ribbon Collection, the first furniture line from the Italian architect Pietro Del Vaglio, throws a curve at conventionality with eight sinuous chairs and sofas that resemble undulating ribbons. ''Our lives are very frenetic and busy, and my idea was to freeze part of frenetic movement in time,'' he said, ''so people can relax.'' The pieces are not only functional sculpture for the home, they are surprisingly comfortable, their metal frames cushioned in layers of upholstered polyurethane. Mr. Del Vaglio, above, who is also a stage and costume designer, was named one of the five top designers by Italian Architectural Digest last year. He said he wants his work to be an alternative to the traditional ''stuffed chair.''

title: Legislators Try Again on Car Insurance Laws
description: Faced with some of the highest auto insurance rates in the country and deadlocked for two years on how to bring them down, legislative leaders announced today that they would make another attempt at changing New York's insurance laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROMLEY, STEPHEN B.
description: BROMLEY-Stephen B., 79, of East Hampton, on January 16, 2003. Beloved husband of Patricia nee Hamlin. Loving father of Stephen Jr, and Michael H. of Valley Stream, and Leslie T. Kaplan and Bruce D. of Manhattan. Dear brother of Sally Kilvert of Eliot, Maine. Also survived by four grandchildren and nine nephews and nieces. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Profit
description: The telecommunications company SK Telecom said that it earned 164 billion won ($139 million) in the fourth quarter, down from 217 billion won a year earlier and well short of analysts' estimates. The decline was attributed in part to the cost of marketing phones that provide faster access to the Internet. Sales, however, rose 38 percent, to 2.37 trillion won, and its operating profit, which excludes one-time items, rose 23 percent. The revenue gain was led by sales of data services, which nearly tripled. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Ivan Rodriguez Joining Marlins
description: Ivan Rodriguez must not have felt much like a 10-time All-Star, a 10-time Gold Glove winner or a former American League most valuable player while he went more than a month without a job. There was minimal interest in Rodriguez, a 31-year-old, often-injured catcher, who was seeking a lucrative, multiyear contract after the Texas Rangers did not offer him salary arbitration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, JOHN CHARLES
description: McDONALD-John Charles. Of Brooklyn Heights, died of cancer on January 20, 2003. He was 76 years old. Mr. McDonald distinguished himself by virtue of his wit and grace. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and went to Georgetown and Harvard Law School, graduating with the highest honors. Following graduation, he spent several years at the law firm of Mudge-Rose before devoting himself full-time to trademark law in a long career with Sterling Drug. He eventually headed the United States Trademark Association before retiring in 1990. Upon retirement, Mr. McDonald finally had the chance to pursue his greatest interest, the theater. He was passionately committed to The Acting Company in its support and training of young actors in the classical tradition. He was a Vice-President of The Acting Company and an active member of Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights and a member of the Vestry at the time of his death. His presence-and love-will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife, Louanna O. Carlin, and by the children of his late wife, Bettie McDonald, their son, David, their daughter and son-in-law, Martha and Patrick Goupit, and grandson, Max Goupit. He also is survived by the families of his step-children Will Carlin, Mercer Carlin and Alison Carrabba. Contributions in lieu of flowers should be made to Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights or The Acting Company. A memorial service will be held Saturday, January 25th, at 11:00 AM at Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights.

title: Owners of Real Estate Firms Win Immunity to Bias Suits
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that owners of real estate agencies cannot ordinarily be sued for the discriminatory actions of the agents who work for them.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: President To Run
description: President Megawati Sukarnoputri said she would run in next year's election and sternly rebuffed protesters who have called for her to step down. Daily rallies against price increases for fuel and other necessities have developed into demonstrations against the president over the last 10 days. But the protests have failed to attract large numbers of people and seem to have been more an irritant than a threat to the government. Even so, earlier this week, the government backtracked on some increases. The World Bank, which is considering a new loan to Indonesia, said it supported the government's decision to delay some of them. Jane Perlez (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Net Fraud Cases Increase, F.T.C. Report Says
description: Cases of fraud occurring over the Internet have increased about 30 percent in the last two years, according to the annual report on consumer complaints by the Federal Trade Commission. While identity theft topped the list, accounting for 43 percent of the complaints lodged with the commission, about half of the complaints related to other consumer fraud had some connection to the Internet -- through e-mail messages or a Web advertisement, electronic responses to print advertisements or entire transactions over the Web. About 13 percent of all complaints related to Internet auctions and 6 percent involved Internet and computer services. ''As a matter of fact, and this may be a sign of our times,'' said J. Howard Beales, director of consumer protection at the commission, ''among the consumers who complained about fraud, 29 percent were reached through a Web site and 25 percent were first contacted via spam.'' He added: ''Just 23 percent -- a little more than a fifth of the consumers filing complaints -- reported that they were first contacted by telephone.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Insurer To Cut Jobs
description: Italy's largest insurance company, Assicurazioni Generali, said it planned to cut 2,800 jobs, about 5 percent of its work force, after suffering undisclosed losses last year. The company, which is based in Trieste and is Europe's fourth-largest insurer, said that 1,250 of the cuts would take place in Germany, followed by 600 in Italy and 500 in Austria. The company said the layoffs were part of an attempt to whittle away 617 million euros ($662 million) in costs by the end of 2005. The company plans to disclose its 2001 results in March. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Muslim Cleric Goes On Trial
description: The trial of a Muslim cleric accused of spreading racial hatred and urging his followers to kill Hindus, Jews and Americans began in London. Abdullah el-Faisal, of Stratford, has been charged with soliciting to murder in religious meetings held around the country and with distributing material -- including videotapes of his sermons -- for the purpose of inciting racial hatred. In a tape of one sermon, introduced as evidence, he urges Muslims to use nuclear and chemical weapons against non-Muslims and says the bodies of dead nonbelievers could be used to fuel power stations. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions in The Arts yesterday with an article about a tribute by the Paris Opera Ballet misspelled the given name of the dancer-choreographer who was being celebrated on the 10th anniversary of his death. He was Rudolf Nureyev, not Rudolph.

title: U.S. Says Hussein Threatens Scientists Who Assist U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz accused Saddam Hussein today of hampering the efforts of United Nations weapons inspectors by ordering that any Iraqi scientists who cooperated with them be put to death.

title: Islanders Wake Up to Injuries and a Fine
description: The Islanders learned today that goaltender Chris Osgood would be out of the lineup for three to four weeks because of a sprained left ankle. Not only was Osgood playing very well lately, but he was also playing a lot.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit At Yahoo Japan
description: Japan's largest Internet portal, the Yahoo Japan Corporation, said that its profit more than doubled last quarter, helped by strong sales of broadband Internet connections and online auctions. The company, which is half owned by the Softbank Corporation, earned 3.56 billion yen ($30 million), 121 percent above the period last year. Sales in the period, which ended Dec. 31 and was the third quarter of the company's fiscal year, almost doubled to 16.3 billion yen. Though online advertising has slowed, Yahoo Japan started charging for its market-leading auction site and provides high-speed Internet access. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Mayor Backs Universities' Efforts for Racial Diversity of Students
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he supported efforts by universities to achieve racial diversity on their campuses.

title: Fighting Solo If Necessary
description: Even if there is substantial allied resistance to an invasion of Iraq, the United States will be prepared to attack with a force of 150,000 by middle to late February, according to military experts and American officials.

title: Bush Rescinds Plan to Allow Limits on Emergency Care
description: The Bush administration said today that it was rescinding a new policy that allowed managed care organizations to limit and restrict coverage of emergency services for poor people on Medicaid.

title: S.E.C. Backs Rules for Auditors, Revised From Original Plan
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new rules yesterday imposing additional obligations and restrictions on auditors of public companies and requiring additional disclosure by companies of off-balance-sheet transactions.

title: Brrr . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Super Servings Of Pixels And Pretzels
description: IN his 1994 novel ''Fever Pitch,'' Nick Hornby outlined the edifying effects of the male sports obsession. True fans, he wrote, ''become repressed, they fail in their relationships with women, their conversation is trivial and boorish, they find themselves unable to express their emotional needs, they cannot relate to their children, and they die alone and miserable. But, you know, what the hell?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSON, MILTON ''MITCH
description: LIPSON-Milton ''Mitch.'' On January 22, very nearly 90 years old. A man who lived fully in his times serving in the administration of Fiorello LaGuardia, in the U.S. Secret Service, in private legal practice, as Commissioner of Investigation of Nassau County, vice president for security of American Express, Assistant District Attorney of Nassau County and village judge of Sea Cliff. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Broader Horizon Fund of the Sea Cliff Public Library. Clara, Eden and Merek

title: Tale of the Tape
description: \n

title: A Big Bonus Is Scheduled For Ex-Chief Of Kmart
description: Kmart's former chief executive, who stepped down abruptly Sunday, will receive nearly $4 million as a bonus for leading the company during its bankruptcy, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission late Tuesday.

title: Serena Comes Back From Abyss And Sets Up a Final With Venus
description: With one Williams sister already in the final at this Grand Slam event, modern tennis etiquette dictated that the other Williams sister needed to be next. Though Kim Clijsters of Belgium did her best to rewrite the rules at the Australian Open this afternoon, Serena Williams shrugged off two match points and a 1-5 deficit in the final set to keep her now-traditional date with older sister Venus.

title: A Sale Just in Time To Update the Living Room
description: In the market for modern furniture at bargain prices? A floor sample sale at the MoMA Design Store in SoHo begins on Jan. 31 and continues through Feb. 9. Folding chairs by Breuer in chrome and leather, originally $1,285, will be $749.95, and the Fritz stool, made by Rexite in gray plastic, previously $225, will be on sale for $89.95.

title: Some Reshuffling Of Agency Posts
description: Leading executives are taking new jobs.

title: Yankees and Lieber Are Nearing a Deal
description: As soon as a few minor details are completed, the Yankees will announce the signing of Jon Lieber, a former 20-game winner who should have a place in their 2004 rotation.

title: A Friendship Disintegrates As Hitler Triumphs
description: Gabrielle Lansner & Company

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, SHELDON
description: BLUM-Sheldon, August 19, 1916 to January 21, 2003. Beloved husband of Eunice Martin Blum. Loving father of Naomi Fertitta, father-inlaw of George Fertitta and grandfather of Cree and Cameron Fertitta. Sheldon Blum was a graduate of NYU University and NYU Law School, Summa Cum Laude, and a member of Theta Sigma Lamda. He was a member of the New York Bar for 40 years and was a WW II Air Force Veteran serving as an aerial photographer.

title: The Self-Tuning Piano
description: To The Editor:

title: Hartford Integration Plan to Add 8 City Magnet Schools
description: Seven years after Connecticut's highest court ordered the state to end racial disparities in Hartford's overwhelmingly black and Hispanic schools, state officials settled today on a $245 million integration plan. Civil-rights lawyers representing the students called it a historic, if incomplete, step to reforming this city's impoverished education system.

title: Roddick Comes of Age and Wins One for the Ages
description: It is only the middle of January, but Andy Roddick's quarterfinal victory over Younes el-Aynaoui on a Wednesday night that turned into Thursday at the Australian Open could turn out to be the match of the year. Certainly, it will be an exceedingly difficult act to follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENBAUM, JERRY
description: SCHOENBAUM - Jerry. On January 21, 2003. Beloved husband of Barbara, loving father of Mitchell and his wife Liz, and Eric and his wife Marci. Cherished grandfather of Mathew, Jenna, Megan and Max. We will miss you.

title: Agassi Reaches Final of Australian Open
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 23  Was it really just a few days ago that a triumphant Wayne Ferreira described the sight of an opponent losing his cool on court under pressure as one of the most beautiful sights in tennis?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Inflation Policy Unchanged
description: The Bank of Japan's monetary board, resisting growing political pressure to set an inflation target, left its policy unchanged after a two-day meeting. The board voted unanimously to continue pushing short-term interest rates near zero, buying 1.2 trillion yen ($10 billion) a month in Japanese government bonds and keeping as much as 20 trillion yen ($17 billion) in surplus cash in the money market. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHINOFF, LARRY
description: ASHINOFF-Larry. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member Friar Larry Ashinoff. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Random House Expands Into Japan With Publishing Deal
description: TOKYO, Jan. 23  Random House, the world's largest publisher of English- and German-language trade books, said today that it would form a joint venture with Kodansha, the largest publisher in Japan, to issue original Japanese-language books and translations of international titles.

title: Nieuwendyk's Late Goals Save Devils
description: The Devils' defense was surprisingly loose tonight, their goaltending equally suspect. For one game, the Devils had to rely on their offense against the San Jose Sharks at HP Pavilion.

title: In a Single DVD Changer, Hundreds of Movies and MP3's
description: Although it was not Sony's main objective, the company has made its DVP-CX875P DVD-CD changer something of a marathon machine. Among other things, the 301-disc changer can play back DVD's containing music recorded as MP3 files. Anyone who has the patience (and the music collection) to fill 301 discs with MP3 files could sit back and listen to music continuously for just under a year and a half.

title: Iraq Says Scientists Refuse Interviews With U.N. Inspectors
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 23  Iraqi scientists have refused to be interviewed in private by United Nations weapons inspectors, a top Iraqi official said tonight, apparently thwarting for the moment a key demand of the inspectors.

title: Kuwait Says Suspect Confesses to Attack on 2 Americans
description: KUWAIT CITY, Jan. 23  A young Kuwaiti man who had fled to Saudi Arabia "has confessed" to a terrorist shooting on Tuesday here that killed one American and wounded another, the Ministry of Interior said tonight.

title: WATSON PHARMACEUTICALS TO BUY 4 HEADACHE MEDICINES
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc., a maker of generic and brand-name drugs, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy four headache medicines from Novartis for $178 million to add to its line of specialty pain treatments. Watson, based in Corona, Calif., would gain the Fiorinal and Fioricet product lines used to treat tension headaches. Novartis, which is based in Switzerland, will continue to make the products during the transition, Watson said.

title: Graham Says Surgery Will Delay Decision on White House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Senator Bob Graham of Florida, who has been weighing whether to seek the Democratic presidential nomination next year, said today that he would have surgery the week of Feb. 3 to replace a damaged heart valve.

title: Why We Know Iraq Is Lying
description: Eleven weeks after the United Nations Security Council unanimously passed a resolution demanding -- yet again -- that Iraq disclose and disarm all its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs, it is appropriate to ask, ''Has Saddam Hussein finally decided to voluntarily disarm?'' Unfortunately, the answer is a clear and resounding no.

title: Bush Judicial Choices Set to Clear Senate Quickly
description: Senate Republicans are setting in motion what is expected to be a brisk parade of confirmations of President Bush's judicial nominees, starting next week with a scheduled vote on Miguel Estrada, a Washington lawyer who has been named to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

title: Opponents of Circumcision Use the Legal System and Legislatures to Combat It
description: Josiah Flatt, like about 60 percent of other newborn American boys, was circumcised soon after he was born here, in the spring of 1997. Two years later, his parents sued the doctor and the hospital.

title: World Forum, Back at Davos, Faces Tough Economic Skiing
description: The black-tie gala with the poolside bar and the big-band cabaret has been canceled for fear that it would coincide with war in Iraq. Ski time has been curtailed to just a brief morning on the pistes above this Alpine village. The trail to a buffet reception in a five-star hotel tonight began with airport-level security blocking the route to the champagne and canapes.

title: Turkish Court Casts Shadow On Would-Be Premier's Role
description: Turkey's highest court today rejected the claim by Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the victor in elections last fall, that he was the head of the nation's governing political party. The ruling raised the specter of a political crisis in a nation already struggling with recession and the backwash of a potential war in neighboring Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, MELVIN
description: FELDMAN-Melvin. Unexpectedly on January 22, 2003. Remembered with love and affection by his family and friends, daughter, Estey, son, Ronald, sister, Ruth, son-inlaw, Doug, and nephews, Clifford and Bruce, and their families. He was kind, gentle and giving. Melvin and Yetta will be together. God speed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITCHMORE, MYRTLE OLIVE
description: LITCHMORE-Myrtle Olive. Passed on January 20th, 2003. Myrtle was an elegant, generous, loving, kind and private lady whose life achievements will continue to live on in the hearts of all those lives she touched. Myrtle is survived by one brother, Aston, and two sisters, Dasey and Lucibell, and her two children, Barbara and Alvin. Grandchildren include Alycia, Alston and Alleah; great grandchildren include Ajeya and Alakai. Services will be held on Friday, January 24th at Noon at the Greater Allen Cathedral of New York, 11031 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica, NY. The family requests, in lieu of flowers, donations in her memory be made to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: For Lot's Wife, When It Rains It Pours
description: Sara Pearson and Patrik Widrig

title: Two-Week Break to Return
description: Beginning next season, the Super Bowl will return to being played two weeks after the conference championship games.

title: AT&T's Bleak Forecast Rattles Investors and Hurts Stock
description: Shares of AT&T , the biggest long-distance communications carrier in the United States, plunged 20 percent today after the company said that it did not expect the dismal telecommunications market to improve significantly in 2003.

title: Sarah Pettit, 36, a Founder of Out Magazine
description: Sarah Pettit, a founding editor and former editor in chief of Out magazine, one of the first gay and lesbian publications with mainstream status, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. She was 36. The cause was non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, her family said.

title: U.S. to Enact New Shipping Rules for Sea Imports
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 23  The United States plans to start enforcing strict new security rules on Feb. 2 for imports by sea in containers despite complaints from many shippers that they are not yet ready to supply needed information, an American official said here today.

title: It's Never Too Late
description: To the Editor:

title: A Web Map as Road Guide
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: California: Dockworkers Approve Settlement
description: West Coast dockworkers ratified a settlement that will ensure six years of labor peace, the International Longshore and Warehouse Union said. The union said nearly 90 percent of the longshoremen voted for the accord, which calls for large pension increases and lets port operators and shipping lines use far-reaching technologies to speed cargo handling. Last fall, the operators shut 29 ports for 11 days when they locked out 10,500 dockworkers, but President Bush obtained an injunction on Oct. 8 to reopen the ports. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Identity Theft Complaints Double in '02, Continuing Rise
description: The number of identity theft complaints nearly doubled in 2002, continuing to make it the Federal Trade Commission's most widely reported consumer crime since the agency started issuing reports three years ago.

title: Many Locks All Too Easy To Get Past
description: A security researcher has revealed a little-known vulnerability in many locks that lets a person create a copy of the master key for an entire building by starting with any key from that building.

title: Life in Ivory Coast, Once an Oasis, Now Unsettles Immigrants
description: For millions of Africans, this place had long represented something close to hope. A penniless man from Burkina Faso could ride a bush taxi from Ouagadougou to come pick cocoa. People from as far as Mali, Niger and Nigeria could sell cassava on the side of the road here in the country's largest city, drive a taxi, guard the villas of its quiet, leafy suburbs.

title: Corrections
description: A series of profiles on Monday of Pakistanis who were recently deported from the United States for having entered the country illegally or having overstayed visas misspelled the surname of a lawyer for one man. The lawyer, who represents Anser Mehmood, a 42-year-old truck driver and father of four who lived in Bayonne, N.J., is Martin R. Stolar, not Stoller.

title: Economic Scene; Bush wants $670 billion in tax cuts, but where's the bang for the buck?
description: PERHAPS the highly unequal distribution of gains from the Bush administration's $670 billion in proposed tax cuts would be justifiable if the plan offered the prospect of significant economic growth. But this plan, more than half of which is made up of tax cuts on dividends, would have far less stimulative impact than has been promised in both the short run and the long run. What we have here is a huge tax cut for the rich without a commensurate bang for the buck for the economy.

title: Treasury Nominee Says He Will Divest Railroad Holdings
description: John W. Snow, President Bush's nominee for Treasury secretary, said today that he would sell or cash out of at least $80 million in stocks, options and retirement compensation from the CSX Corporation, the Virginia-based railroad operator of which he was chief executive.

title: Public Relations Official to Manage Russian TV Network
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 23  Gazprom, Russia's government-controlled gas monopoly and the largest single owner of the embattled NTV television network, has chosen an obscure public relations employee to manage the network.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Teenage Girl Reported Raped
description: A 14-year-old girl was abducted and raped in Brooklyn as she was walking home from school on Tuesday, the police said yesterday. The girl, whose name was withheld by the police, was attacked at Schole Street and Bushwick Avenue around 3:40 p.m., officials said. A man approached her from behind, forced her into a car and drove her to an unknown area, where he raped her, the police said. She was able to flee at Bushwick Avenue and Stagg Street, the police said. She was treated at Woodhull Hospital and released. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EATON, JOHN MCCURDY
description: EATON-John McCurdy. Died on January 20, after a long illness. Son of Justine Allen Eaton and the late Fredrick M. Eaton. Brother of Frederick A. Eaton and Justine E. Auchincloss. Uncle of ten nephews and nieces. Memorial service at 10:30 AM, Thursday, January 30, St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Ave at 71st Street, New York City.

title: Allies delay decision on U.S, requests : NATO wavering on war with Iraq
description: WASHINGTON:  In a new sign of wavering allied will, NATO postponed a decision Wednesday on a U.S. request for six measures to support a possible war against Iraq.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You look at vast numbers of other countries in Europe. They're not with France and Germany on this. They're with the United States.''

title: Times Appoints Two as Editors In Culture News
description: The appointments of William P. McDonald as deputy cultural news editor of The New York Times and Jodi Kantor as editor of the Arts & Leisure section were announced yesterday by Steven Erlanger, the newspaper's cultural news editor.

title: Video Recorder Snaps Photos And Even Takes Dictation
description: The problem with taking video cameras on the road has always been the size of the machines, even since video has gone digital. But with Aiptek's Pocket DV2, an inexpensive digital video recorder that also functions as a voice recorder, a Webcam and a 1.3-megapixel still camera, travelers need to budget only enough baggage space for a brownie.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: INFLATION POLICY UNCHANGED The Bank of Japan's monetary board, resisting growing political pressure to set an inflation target, left its policy unchanged after a two-day meeting. The board voted unanimously to continue pushing short-term interest rates near zero, buying 1.2 trillion yen ($10 billion) a month in Japanese government bonds and keeping as much as 20 trillion yen ($17 billion) in surplus cash in the money market. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRASS, BARRY J., M.D.
description: BRASS-Barry J., M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague, Barry J. Brass, M.D., an attending physician in the Division of Endocrinology and Metabolism. To his wife Marion, his mother Beatrice, his family and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Thomas Killip, M.D., Interim President and CEO Donald M. Kastenbaum, M.D. President, Medical Board Stephen G. Baum, M.D., Chairman of Medicine Leonid Poretsky, M.D., Chief of Endocrinology and Metabolism Robert L. Salant, M.D., President, Doctors Alumni Association

title: A Land Still Divided on Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Strategist Terms Bush A Populist About Taxes
description: Karl Rove, the White House's senior political strategist, said today that President Bush was a populist whose call for the elimination of taxes on stock dividends was aimed at ''the little guy.''

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Report Chides Flint Police
description: The City of Flint's police force is hobbled by an excess of work and a lack of administration, a review has found. The study, commissioned by the manager named by the state to resuscitate the city's finances, found the police assigned 16,586 cases to 29 detectives in a 10-month period last year; of those, only 153 were closed by arrest. It said the police had a ''dysfunctional relationship'' with emergency dispatchers and that patrol cars went so long without oil changes and other maintenance that 12 engines had to be replaced last year. Anand Giridharadas (NYT)

title: From the East, Teak, Both New and Old
description: Hip & Humble Home, a large furniture store that opened in Chelsea last month, is jam-packed with teak, mainly from Indonesia. Much of the furniture is colonial style and hand hewn. Benches ($895 to $2,295) and dining tables ($1,795 to $2,295) are vintage; armoires ($1,795 to $4,800) are newly made but of old wood, many with shelves for televisions. Wood table lamps with damask shades, above, are made in New York ($195), colorful poufs (inset above) in patterned fabrics come from Morocco ($110), and accessories like wood and metal candlesticks come from India. Hip & Humble Home, 143 West 19th Street, (212) 675-1527. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Archbishop of Newark Bans Eulogies at Funeral Masses
description: One eulogist spoke for 43 minutes. Another ran to the piano for an impromptu performance. Yet another told a joke about Osama bin Laden.

title: Burning a Test Paper, Student Sets House Ablaze
description: Bad marks on a school test can be upsetting, but it's still not a good idea to set the exam papers on fire. A 14-year-old boy learned that lesson the hard way, when flames spread from his test papers destroyed the second floor of his home, the Nassau County police said yesterday.

title: Here's Reality: 'Idol' Feeds Hopefuls to a Shaky Music Business
description: There is a macabre appeal to ''American Idol,'' hovering over its screechy auditions and tearful backstage tableaus. Amid all the dirges about the collapse of the music business comes the second round of ''Idol,'' a digital age talent contest that is as frothily distracting and oblivious as a 1933 Busby Berkeley musical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIOLO, SALLY
description: TRIOLO-Sally. On January 20, 2003, at age 53. Chef extraordinaire. Beloved daughter of Chickie Franke, sister of Debbie Mandelker and aunt of Alison, mother of Shannon Meyers Black. Contributions in her memory may be made to Clinton Presidential Foundation, P.O. Box 1104, Little Rock, AR 72203, or St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, Attn Memorial Dept, 501 St. Jude Pl, Memphis, TN 38105.

title: Taubman Wins One Round in Hostile Takeover Battle
description: Taubman Centers, the shopping mall empire founded by A. Alfred Taubman, won a partial victory in federal court yesterday in its effort to thwart a $1.7 billion takeover from the Simon Property Group.

title: A Personal Organizer Morphs Into a Real Game Pad
description: Attaching a game controller to your Cli personal organizer is a less-than-subtle way of saying, ''Work's over.''

title: Bankers and lawyers see flaws in new pact : Crackdown on tax cheats could backfire on the EU
description: BRUSSELS:  An agreement by European Union countries to crack down on tax cheats will probably encourage some wealthy Europeans to park their money in tax havens in Asia and elsewhere outside the Union, tax lawyers and bankers said Wednesday.

title: Irene Diamond, Philanthropist, Is Dead at 92
description: Irene Diamond, who after a successful career scouting scripts and talent in Hollywood became a major benefactor of the arts and medical research in New York City, died Tuesday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 92.

title: A Land Still Divided on Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: A Waterfront Palace of Produce
description: THE mightiest architecture critic in San Francisco spoke forcefully on Oct. 17, 1989, when the Loma Prieta earthquake shook the unsightly Embarcadero Freeway to its marrow and unwittingly liberated one of this city's most beloved and historic buildings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHFELD, AL
description: HIRSCHFELD-Al. We deeply mourn the loss of Al Hirschfeld, a New York City landmark in his own time, who supported, in wonderfully artistic lines and otherwise, our continuing efforts to preserve the architectural integrity, human scale and quality of life in Carnegie Hill. Our condolences to Louise, who together with her husband, has been a member of our Steering Committee. Citineighbors Coalition of Historic Carnegie Hill Jurate Kazickas Carol McFadden Jane Parshall Co-chairmen

title: Pilot Error Blamed in Basketball Team's Plane Crash
description: The plane crash near Denver two years ago that killed two Oklahoma State University basketball players and six others associated with the team occurred because the pilots lost control of the plane while they were distracted by an electrical failure, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.

title: Wealthy Chinese Businessman Killed
description: BEIJING, Jan. 23  One of China's wealthiest businessmen was shot dead on Tuesday in what investigating police said may have been a vengeful murder.

title: Kennedy Center Approves Dramatic Expansion Plan
description: Thirty-two years after it opened as a white marble memorial on the Potomac, cut off from the rest of Washington's landmarks by a tangle of highways, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has hired the architect Rafael Violy to design two new buildings and a sweeping pedestrian plaza and fountain that would at last link it to the monuments around it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANOWITZ, ADELINE TINTNER
description: JANOWITZ-Adeline Tintner. Of New York City. Born February 2, 1912. Died January 20. Noted Henry James scholar and book collector. She is survived by her husband Henry, her daughters Anne and Mary and grandchildren Andrew and Kita. Services to be held at the Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76 Street Friday, January 24 at 2:15 P.M.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Tariffs On Chicken
description: The Mexican government has placed a 99 percent safeguard tariff on imports of chicken legs and thighs from the United States in an agreement negotiated with Washington and poultry producers in the United States. Under the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mexican tariffs on poultry imports from the United States dropped to zero on Jan 1. But Mexican poultry producers asked the government for extra time to modernize their $2 billion industry, saying the American poultry industry sold its surplus dark meat cheaply in Mexico. Under the agreement, the tariff will drop 20 percent each year until it reaches zero on Jan. 1, 2008. In return, the United States poultry industry will be permitted to export a tariff-free quota of chicken legs and thighs to the border areas. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Venezuelan High Court Suspends Referendum on President Chvez
description: Venezuela's Supreme Court today suspended a referendum scheduled for Feb. 2 on President Hugo Chvez's rule, dealing a blow to the broad coalition of government opponents who had hoped that the vote, though nonbinding, might force him to resign.

title: With Warnings on Needs, Ridge Is Confirmed, 94-0, To Lead New Department
description: The Senate unanimously confirmed Tom Ridge today as the nation's first secretary of homeland security, with Democrats and Republicans alike heaping praise on Mr. Ridge even as they warned that his huge new department faced a daunting responsibility to prevent terrorist attacks on American soil.

title: Getting Your Postcard Kicks on Route 66
description: In ''American Signs: Form and Meaning on Route 66'' (Monacelli Press, $40), the architect Lisa Mahar, whose earlier book was about grain elevators, investigates motel signs. To do so, Ms. Mahar, who has an office (MAP: Mahar Adjmi Partners) in New York with her husband, Morris Adjmi, photographed and analyzed signs from about 500 motels along Route 66 and collected hundreds of postcards. The Palomino, above, in Tucumcari, N.M, used neon, plastic and light bulbs to draw drivers. The Glancy, top, in Clinton, Okla., nicely balanced sans-serif type, blobs, strong colors and the ever-familiar arrow. Ms. Mahar documents how the regional variety of lassos and palm trees, boomerangs and rockets gave way to the standardized green Holiday Inn sign. PHIL PATTON

title: Daring Missions Give Rein To Your Inner James Bond
description: 007: NIGHTFIRE

title: Super Bowl Insiders Watch for Strategy Before Snap of Ball
description: Instead of focusing on the quarterback, or on the ball as it moves around the field, National Football League players, coaches and executives will scan their television screens Sunday for the telltale signs of strategy in the Super Bowl. The insider's game is often out in the open, for all to see.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, IRENE
description: DIAMOND-Irene. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University are deeply saddened by the passing of our cherished friend Irene Diamond, a true visionary in the world of philanthropy. Determined to address the AIDS epidemic, she established the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center and recruited Dr. David Ho to direct it. Mrs. Diamond's encouragement and funding helped the Center emerge as one of the world's leading research facilities. She further strengthened immunology in New York City with her support of post doctoral fellowships and professorships. Her funding of biomedicine has advanced many other areas of research, promising benefits that are profound, lasting, and universal. Mrs. Diamond was also a passionate advocate for human rights and a creative, imaginative patron of education and the arts. New York City has benefited from her extraordinary generosity, and her vision has forever changed our City's intellectual and cultural landscape. We join the citizens of New York in saluating her remarkable accomplishments. She will be greatly missed. Richard B. Fisher, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Thomas P. Sakmar, Acting President Torsten N. Wiesel President Emeritus

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Register.com Gets Bid From 2nd Investor Group
description: A second group of investors said yesterday that it wanted to acquire the Internet address provider Register.com Inc., offering about $227 million, or 12 percent more than a rival group's hostile bid of $202.4 million. IWB Acquisitions, a unit of Zackfoot Investments, offered $5.55 a share in cash, the group said. That is a 4.7 percent premium to the Tuesday closing price of Register.com, which was $5.30. The RCM Acquisition Company, an affiliate of Barington Companies Equity Partners, a Register.com shareholder, earlier this month offered $4.95 a share. Register.com rejected that bid, saying it was too low and contingent on financing. Barington's chief executive, James Mitarotonda, has said RCM Acquisition will continue to pursue a takeover of Register.com and will try to unseat the board. IWB Acquisitions said its offer was also contingent on financing. Zachary Prensky, controlling owner of Zackfoot and a former Register.com director, said that he wanted to ''work with, not against, the current board.'' Shares of Register.com rose 40 cents, or 7.6 percent, to $5.70.

The results included a nonrecurring noncash charge of $307.6 million for writing down certain assets, the company said, which also pushed its full-year net loss to $369.3 million, or $11.58 a share. Once a darling of the Irish stock market, shares of Iona fell 90 percent last year but rose 3 percent, to 3.15 euros ($3.38), on the Dublin exchange yesterday. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Posts 4th-Quarter Loss
description: Texas Instruments Inc., the world's biggest maker of chips for cellphones, said that its fourth-quarter net loss widened to $589 million, or 34 cents a share, as it wrote down an investment in Micron Technology Inc. The loss in the fourth quarter of 2001 was $116 million, or 7 cents. Sales rose 20 percent, to $2.15 billion, from $1.79 billion, and beat a forecast the company raised last month, sending shares up. Sales of chips used in wireless devices increased 13 percent from the third quarter, led by demand in Asia, the chief financial officer, Bill Aylesworth, said. The company said profit would have been 6 cents a share excluding the write-down. On that basis, which does not conform to generally accepted accounting principles, analysts expected profit of 3 cents, the average estimate in a Thomson First Call survey. Sales for the quarter will be about even with the fourth quarter, and profit will be about 6 cents a share, the company said. Analysts expected an average of 3 cents, according to First Call. Shares rose to $15.42 in after-hours trading after the report. They jumped 10 cents, to $14.25, in regular trading.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: FIREHOUSE HEAT PROBLEMS The cold snap has affected firehouses throughout the city and, firefighters' unions say, disrupted heating systems and caused batteries of two-way radios to charge improperly. A spokesman for the Fire Department, Michael Loughran, acknowledged problems yesterday but disagreed on their scale. The unions say heating systems at 18 firehouses have failed, posing a significant risk to the safety of firefighters and the public. In some firehouses, tanks of water stored on fire trucks had to be drained to keep them from freezing, said Philip H. McArdle, the health and safety officer for the Uniformed Firefighters Association. Mr. McArdle said that heating problems dated to 1998 and that the city was not properly maintaining the buildings. Mr. Loughran said that only three direct reports of heating problems had been received and that the department was investigating the problems.   Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

(Barbara) Coates III; Dr. and Mrs. Richard D. (Sharon) Riva; Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey F. (Nancy) Riva; Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. (Nancy) Riva; Mr. William Denning Riva; Mrs. Angela Piela Riva; Mr. and Mrs. Channing J. (Mary Anne) Martin; Dr. Suzanne Riva and Mr. Randy Grisham and the late Dr. John M. Riva and Elizabeth Jane Riva. Dear brother of Victor and Dora Riva. Also survived by 26 grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral mass at St. Rose of Lima Church, 50 Short Hills Ave., Short Hills, NJ on Saturday January 25th at 11:00 AM. Interment Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA. Visitation will be held at The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Ave., Maplewood, NJ on Thursday, 7-9 PM and Friday, 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Memorial donations may be made to the Dr. John M. Riva Scholarship Fund c/o Seton Hall Prepartory School, West Orange, NJ 07052.
