description: George W. Bush may extol the virtues of free trade, but today that did not extend to a Made in America presidential appearance in the heart of the Midwest.

title: Senators Cross Party Lines on Clean Air
description: Voting along regional as much as party lines, the Republican-controlled Senate rejected an effort today to delay the White House's new pollution rules. Many Democrats say the new rules will roll back clean air standards and endanger human health.

description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: With Fronds Like These, Who Needs Anemones?
description: PALM collectors in South Florida sound a lot more like addicts than enthusiasts. ''Collecting is a form of neurosis,'' said Steve Stern, immediate past president of the South Florida Palm Society. ''You have to have it because no one else has it.''

title: Market Place; Dividend Plan Is of Little Use To Margin Buyers
description: Investors who buy stock with borrowed money will find that the dividends they get will be taxable even after other dividends are no longer taxed, according to the Bush administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, HERBERT H.
description: MENDELSON - Herbert H. Age 79, former chairman of the board of Jack X. Wilson, Inc. Died at the Miami Heart Institute on Tuesday, January 21, 2003 following a courageous battle with vasculitis. He was born May 27, 1923 in Chicago, IL to the late Emanuel and Edith Glass Mendelson. He attended Northwestern and Brown Universities and served as a Sargeant in the U.S. Army. A pioneer in the recycling of paper, Herbert and his late wife, Jacquiline Woolf Mendelson resided in Chicago, Philadelphia, New York City and most recently in Aventura, FL where he was an active member of SCORE (Service Corporation of Retired Executives). Herbert is survived by his sons, Emanuel Scott and Anthony Woolf Mendelson, his daughter, Nancy Mendelson and her husband Thomas Scott; his grandson Benjamin Michael Mendelson, and his brother, Donald Charles Mendelson. Funeral services for Herbert H. Mendelson will be held at 12 noon Friday, January 24 at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, NY, NY. A memorial fund has been established in his name for the Johns Hopkins Vasculitis Center, C/O Dr. John Stone, Bayview Medical Center, 5501 Hopkins Bayview Circle, JHAAC, Room 1B. 1A, Baltimore, MD. 21224.

title: Big TV's Without A Fortune
description: WHOEVER said that money can't buy happiness has obviously never bought a high-end home theater system. Once you're snuggled into an $800 recliner among $5,000 surround-sound speakers, watching a great movie on your $10,000 high-definition plasma screen, it's almost impossible not to cheer up at least a little bit.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Monaco: Banker's Killer Captured After Escape
description: An American nurse who in December was convicted of causing the death of the billionaire banker Edmond Safra in a fire in 1999 made a daring escape from jail with a fellow inmate by sawing through the bars of the cell where he was serving a 10-year sentence and lowering himself to a garden using a rope made of plastic bags. But the nurse, Ted Maher, 44, above, was caught in a hotel in the nearby French city of Nice hours after the escape and returned to jail. The police said they learned of Mr. Maher's location from telephone calls he made from the hotel. The other inmate, an Italian jailed for robbery, remained at large. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Among 4 States, a Great Divide in Fortunes
description: Every Wednesday morning in Colorado Springs, dozens of recently laid-off executives gather to share job tips and emotional sustenance.

title: Big Loss Leaves Morgan Cautious About Rebound
description: J. P. Morgan Chase reported a bigger fourth-quarter loss yesterday, mostly because of $1.3 billion in expected charges, and tried to convince investors that the worst of its problems were behind it.

title: Expressing Love in Song, 17th-Century Style
description: Ellen Hargis, soprano, and Paul O'Dette, lutenist

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESHMUKH, MADHUKAR, M., M.D.
description: DESHMUKH-Madhukar, M., M.D. The Montefiore-Einstein Heart Center mourns the death of our colleague and friend Madhukar M. Deshmukh, M.D. Dr. Deshmukh was a distinguished cardiologist and teacher who practiced Cardiology in the Bronx for over 30 years and taught generations of physicians both here and in his native India. He was a member of many national and international medical organizations and was Past President of the Association of American Cardiologists of Indian Origin. He will be deeply missed by his patients, students and colleagues. We extend our condolences to his wife, Sheila M. Deshmukh, M.D., who was also a member of the Montefiore Medical Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, faculty and their son, Ravi Deshmukh, M.D. Mark A. Greenberg, M.D. Interim Chief, Division of Cardiology Jeffrey P. Gold, M.D. Chairman, Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery

title: Howard Signs Contract Extension
description: MetroStars goalkeeper Tim Howard has signed a three-year contract extension with Major League Soccer. The league, which owns all player contracts, is expected to make an announcement later in the week.

title: Season Debut of 'American Idol' Is a Tuesday Triumph for Fox
description: The opening episode of the new season of ''American Idol,'' the amateur talent TV series, drew an audience of almost 27 million and helped give the Fox Network its highest-rated Tuesday night ever and its most-watched night of entertainment.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Clinton Joins A-Plant Critics
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has signed a legal petition calling on the Federal Emergency Management Agency to withdraw its approval of emergency plans for the area around the Indian Point nuclear plant. Mrs. Clinton, now the most prominent signer, said yesterday that she had acted out of concerns raised by a consultant for the state, who said in a report released on Jan. 10 that disaster plans were unworkable. The petition, signed by several lawmakers and organizations, was filed in June by Assemblyman Richard Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat. Unlike Mr. Brodsky, Mrs. Clinton does not advocate shutting down the plant, but she has said that state and federal officials and Entergy, which owns the plant, must take steps to ensure its safety. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Envisioning a Bridge as a Penn Station Foothold
description: A SHORT-LIVED bridge may unlock one of New York City's longest-gestating projects: the transformation of the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue into a new Pennsylvania Station.

title: 'Legacy' Admissions
description: To the Editor:

title: When marketers trip over trademarks, the fun begins.
description: FREEDOM of expression, it turns out, may not be for everyone.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Thursday with an article about measures taken by Ketchum, Idaho, to control excessive levels of outdoor lighting was published in error. It showed the Sun Valley resort; Ketchum is nearby.

title: High Fliers
description: Walking toward his F-14 fighter in a scene from the movie ''Top Gun,'' Tom Cruise yells, ''I feel the need -- the need for speed!'' It's important to note the speed he was referring to had to do with miles per hour, not amphetamines.

title: Personal Data Is Pirated From Russian Phone Files
description: It is a prime nightmare of the digital age: all of your personal information -- credit card numbers, home address, Social Security number -- stolen and passed around, or perhaps even posted on the Internet for anyone to see.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLONNA, ROY
description: COLONNA-Roy. Of Gilbertsville, NY, died January 20, 2003. Fashion illustrator for Elizabeth Arden in NYC, he became a Dada artist, showing at Bodley Gallery. Eighth don in Goju karate, he taught karate and Tai Chi in Cooperstown and Oneonta. Roy is a devotee of Ramana Maharshi. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Nields Colonna, son John Schuyler Colonna, daughter Janine Elder, sonin-law Brian Elder, and grandsons Gareth and Kieran Elder. Funeral: January 25 at United Methodist Church, Mount Upton. Contributions: Emergency Squad, Gilbertsville, NY, 13776 or Arunachala Ashram, 66-12 Clyde Street, Rego Park, New York 11374.

title: City to Let Christo Do Central Park Art Project
description: A work of art featuring 23 miles of billowing saffron-colored fabric by the artist Christo and his wife Jeanne-Claude will be displayed along Central Park's pedestrian paths for two weeks in February 2005, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Judge Rules In Monsterhut Spam Case
description: A company in Niagara Falls, N.Y., has been ordered to stop sending junk e-mail messages, or spam, that claim that the recipient asked for the messages. In a ruling this month, Justice Lottie E. Wilkins of New York Supreme Court in Manhattan ordered Monsterhut Inc. and its executives to stop committing the ''fraudulent, deceptive and illegal acts'' described by Attorney General Eliot Spitzer of New York in a complaint last year. ''It is a victory for consumers, and it shows that standards of honesty and integrity can be applied to and demanded of electronic marketers,'' Mr. Spitzer said yesterday. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Dealing in Universals, Not Specifics, Graham Distilled Human Emotions
description: Martha Graham's dances are more often sensed than comprehended. One understands them through the pores. Her most enigmatic works, also her greatest, can be puzzling, but in the largest sense the viewer knows very well what they are about.

title: Bush Pushes Tax Cut as Small-Business Aid
description: President Bush pushed his economic plan in an important political swing state today, saying that it would benefit America's small-business owners and that it was not a giveaway to the rich.

title: France and Germany Draw a Line, Against Washington
description: In a blunt rejection of American impatience toward Baghdad, the leaders of France and Germany said today during ceremonies marking the 40th anniversary of a French-German cooperation treaty that they shared common views on Iraq, and that any Security Council resolution for military action would have to await the report of weapons inspectors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSS, RICHARD, M.D.
description: CROSS-Richard, M.D. The board and staff of SIECUSthe Sexuality Information and Education Council of the U.S.-wish to express their sadness at the passing of Dr. Richard Cross. Dr. Cross was a pioneer in the field of sexuality. As an early board member of SIECUS, he stepped in as Executive Director to lead the organization during a time of change. He showed the courage to take on the mission of ensuring access to comprehensive, medically accurate information about sexuality. In addition to his unwavering leadership in the field of sexuality, he lent his voice as a well-respected physician and trained other medical professionals to ensure the sexual health of future generations. Dr. Cross was a constant supporter of SIECUS and all we do to work towards a sexually healthy world. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife Peggy and his entire family. The Board of Directors and the Staff of SIECUS

title: Rowland Says 1,000 More Must Be Laid Off
description: With Connecticut's budget gap now estimated at $650 million and growing, Gov. John G. Rowland said yesterday that 1,000 state employees would soon receive layoff notices, in addition to the more than 2,800 who have already gotten pink slips in the last two months.

title: France and Germany Draw a Line, Against Washington
description: PARIS, Jan. 22  In a blunt rejection of American impatience toward Baghdad, the leaders of France and Germany said today during ceremonies marking the 40th anniversary of a French-German cooperation treaty that they shared common views on Iraq, and that any Security Council resolution for military action would have to await the report of weapons inspectors.

title: At Last, Elias Back to 'A' Form
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 22  The mourning period has finally ended for Patrik Elias, the lone survivor of the purge of the Devils' A-line. After months of struggling to adjust to life after the exile of Jason Arnott and Petr Sykora, the long, cold goodbye is over.

title: Large Banks in South Korea Report a Big Jump in Profits
description: The stock market may be sagging and the economy cooling, but South Korea's 19 commercial banks are doing fine -- a sharp contrast to the woes of the banking sectors in neighboring Japan and China.

title: Dorsett Still Looking At the Right Angles
description: This is the second Super Bowl for Oakland safety Anthony Dorsett. His first one, with Tennessee in 2000, ended in the memorable Kevin Dyson catch/Mike Jones tackle at the 1-yard line as time expired.

title: U.S. Businessman Linked To Iraqi Arms Purchases
description: An Iraqi-American businessman recently arrested in Europe was once a key middleman for Saddam Hussein in illegal weapons purchases and last year was trying to organize a last-minute arms-buying spree for Iraq in response to the growing threat of an American invasion, according to American and European law-enforcement officials.

title: Safeway Looks Like the Best Game in Town
description: As new suitors muscle into the bidding for the supermarket chain Safeway -- Tesco became the latest today -- investment bankers are jockeying for advisory roles, bookmakers are taking bets on the outcome, and newspapers are printing the odds on the front of their business sections.

title: Forrest Inspired by Mission Outside the Ring
description: In a culture in which language is often turned upside down so that bad means very good, Vernon Forrest has become one of boxing's good guys.

title: Earthquake Toll in Mexico Now 29; Leader Declares Emergency
description: President Vicente Fox declared a state of emergency today in Colima, a coastal state hit overnight by a powerful earthquake that rolled across central Mexico from the Pacific Ocean, killing at least 29 people and rattling millions of Mexico City residents.

description: Having concluded that international inspectors are unlikely to find tangible and irrefutable evidence that Iraq is hiding weapons of mass destruction, the Bush administration is preparing its own assessment that will rely heavily on evidence from Iraqi defectors, according to senior administration officials.

title: Not a Good Day to Be the Mailman
description: THE weather this week had Shelly Kalmanson seriously second-guessing his career choice.

title: Hits' Quick Trip Into the Home
description: Having rushed big summer movies onto DVD and VHS in time for the holidays, home video isn't letting up on the accelerator with major titles from theater runs in December. Last week Columbia TriStar set a release date of March 25 for "Maid in Manhattan," the Jennifer Lopez vehicle. This week Warner scheduled "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" for April 11.

title: Pilot Error Cited in Crash
description: The plane crash near Denver two years ago that killed two Oklahoma State University basketball players and six others associated with the team occurred because the pilots lost control of the plane while they were distracted by an electrical failure, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column in some copies on Wednesday about a public hearing at Rutgers University on the design for a Sept. 11 memorial misstated the name of a woman who spoke about her son, who died in the attack. She is Krystyna Boryczewski. (The expression ''cq,'' which denotes a verified spelling in the editing process, was reproduced at the end of each name through a computer operating error.)

title: Europeans Try to Stem Anti-U.S. Anger
description: Cool down in Washington and calm down at home was the advice from Europe after continental tempers detonated over Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's dismissal of France and Germany as ''old Europe'' because they are trying to avert a war with Iraq.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Mad Cow Cases
description: Two new cases of mad cow disease have been discovered in the last week, bringing the number of cases in the country to seven. Six of the cows, when calves in 1996, consumed a milk substitute made in Japan with material imported from Western Europe, where mad cow disease had broken out. In June 2001, Japanese agricultural officials suppressed a European Union report warning that Japanese herds were at risk of mad cow contamination. The first mad cow case was reported in Japan in September 2001. James Brooke (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Pilots Apologize to Relatives of Canadians They Bombed
description: Two F-16 pilots who killed four Canadian soldiers in a mistaken air strike in Afghanistan last year apologized to the families of the dead and wounded today, but they took pains to defend their own actions, as a hearing that could lead to their court-martial on homicide charges came to an end.

title: Fattening, Yes, But Blameless
description: To the Editor:

title: Lighting Dark Corners
description: You round a curve at night and a small animal jumps in front of you from the darkness. If you had been able to see it, you might have been able to miss it. What would have helped are headlights that turn when the car turns, called adaptive headlights.

title: Starbucks Earnings Up 17%
description: The Starbucks Corporation, the largest chain of coffee shops, said today that first-quarter earnings rose 17 percent, helped by strong holiday sales. The company also raised its forecast for the year.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Easing Restrictions On Growers
description: As the state prepared for one of its worst freezes in years, Gov. Jeb Bush signed an emergency order to relax road restrictions so citrus and vegetable growers can haul their produce to warehouses and processing plants. The order, in effect for 30 days, waives rules on weight, height, length and width for trucks carrying vulnerable crops. ''Our growers are eager to get the fruit off the trees as soon as possible,'' said Casey Pace, a spokeswoman for Florida Citrus Mutual, a growers association in Lakeland.

title: Whose Mountain Is It Anyway?
description: WITH the Winter X Games only days away, Matt Hammer nailed a couple of tricks on the halfpipe, launching himself several feet into the air and twisting his 23-year-old body like a flat-footed whirlybird amped on Mountain Dew. It was only 12:30 p.m. at Mammoth Mountain, California's premier snow resort, but he was calling it quits.

title: U.S. Record on Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Housing Aid For Jobless
description: New Yorkers who are out of work will receive information on their next unemployment checks about another potential source of aid: emergency housing assistance from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The FEMA program, which was established after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attack, offers assistance to people who are facing eviction or foreclosure. Many people have only recently become aware of the program, said Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, above, a Manhattan Democrat, who urged the State Department of Labor to include the information on all checks. The program expires next Friday. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: How One Clone Leads to Another
description: The failure of the last Congress to enact a ban on human cloning casts grave doubt on our ability to govern the unethical uses of biotechnology, even when it threatens things we hold dear. The new Congress must work to break the legislative impasse.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Magnate Gunned Down
description: One of the country's richest businessmen was shot dead in what the police said might have been a revenge killing. Li Haicang, 47, was shot in the head on Tuesday by a man who burst into his office in the city of Yuncheng, about 120 miles southwest of Beijing. His killer, Feng Yinliang, then shot himself, the police said. Mr. Feng was an old friend of Mr. Li who owned a failed factory and had tried several times to force Mr. Li to buy his factory's land, the New China News Agency reported. Chris Buckley (NYT)

title: Stocks Dive on Worries About Iraq and Corporate Earnings
description: The worsening outlook for corporate earnings and the threat of a war with Iraq weighed heavily on Wall Street today, as the three leading stocks gauges fell 2.9 percent or more, giving the stock market its second straight week of losses and its lowest close so far this year.

description: Outsider Art Fair

title: Novartis's Stake in Roche Fuels Merger Speculation
description: Novartis said today that it had accumulated enough stock in the Roche Group, one of its main rivals, to control 32.7 percent of the voting rights in the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, BEATRICE (NEE OFFIN)
description: KLEIN-Beatrice (nee Offin). Beloved wife of the late Benhard. Devoted mother of Stephanie Krasner and Kenneth Klein. Cherished grandmother of Jill, Sharon, Andrew and Rebecca, and great-grandmother of Austin, Kody, Bradley, Lauren, Luke and Hallie. Past president of Hadassah and B'nai Brith. Funeral services will be held Friday, at 2 PM, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Donations to American Cancer Society.

title: Picking Up the Blues Again at 82 After 20 Years as a Scrub Nurse
description: The blues singer Alberta Hunter, who died in 1984, had been working until her last few months. In a remarkable coda to a remarkable life, she had come out of a self-imposed retirement from the stage -- two decades of working as a hospital scrub nurse on Roosevelt Island -- to perform at the Cookery in Greenwich Village. It was a six-week gig in 1977 when she was 82 that turned into an indefinitely extended one.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If a government is unwilling to disarm itself, it is unreasonable to expect inspectors to do it for them.''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Trade Deficit Falls
description: The Finance Ministry said Mexico's trade deficit in 2002 was $8 billion, an improvement of 19.6 percent over the 2001 deficit. The finance ministry said rising prices for oil exports helped bring the deficit down, along with a slight uptick in economic activity. Total exports for the year reached $160.6 billion, with manufactured goods accounting for 88.4 percent of that.

title: It's Official: British Society Outlasts Tupperware Parties
description: The Tupperware party in Britain is about to go the way of milkmen, drive-in movies and cars with fins.

description: Swiss Institute

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column yesterday, about the balance between literary and nonliterary pursuits at publishing houses, misspelled the surname of a novelist published by Scribner. He is Don DeLillo, not DiLillo.

title: Preserving Democracy in Venezuela
description: The best hope for a peaceful, democratic outcome to Venezuela's political crisis may now rest in the mediation efforts of Jimmy Carter. During his presidency Mr. Carter was a firm champion of democracy throughout Latin America, standing up to the military tyrannies that then predominated in the region. Now he has proposed two principled and plausible solutions to the long-running conflict over President Hugo Chvez, which has divided Venezuela's people, hobbled its economy and raised the specter of a breakdown in constitutional rule.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: SURGERY FOR SENATOR GRAHAM Senator Bob Graham of Florida, who has been weighing whether to seek the Democratic presidential nomination next year, said he would have surgery the week of Feb. 3 to replace a damaged heart valve. Mr. Graham, 66, said he had decided to undergo the operation after recent tests showed that an aortic valve had deteriorated to the point where surgery was advisable. The senator's spokesman, Paul Anderson, said Mr. Graham would defer until early March an announcement on whether he will run for president. Mr. Graham had been expected to make an announcement in early February. David Stout (NYT)

title: Agent Orange And Cancer Are Linked In New Study
description: Exposure to high levels of Agent Orange, the widely used defoliant in the Vietnam War, is associated with a slight increase in the incidence of a form of leukemia, researchers have determined.

title: Renting Cars for A Cleaner World
description: YOU have heard about the new environmentally friendly cars, fueled by electricity or natural gas, or combining electricity and gasoline. But have you ever actually driven one? There is a way. Take one on vacation.

title: Aspiring to Motherhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Madrigals and Vignettes For Ariadne Abandoned
description: The Artek period instrument ensemble has devoted itself to finding fresh ways to present the early music repertory. Often its greatest surprises have been purely musical, functions of the way the familiar and the undeservedly obscure have been juxtaposed in its programs. But the group and its director, Gwendolyn Toth, have also been thinking in increasingly theatrical terms. A production of Monteverdi's ''Orfeo'' moved Artek onto the stage, and a collaboration with the Mark Morris Dance Company in 1997 transformed a group of Monteverdi madrigals into an evening of dance under the title ''I Don't Want to Love.''

title: Democrats to Tackle Insurance Industry
description: Senate Democrats are planning to push for a curb on the insurance industry's longstanding exemption from antitrust laws, in an effort to hold down rising medical malpractice premiums.

title: Indonesian Educators Ponder Lessons After U.S. Visit
description: A treasured souvenir from Muhammad Ishom's trip to America is a color photograph he snapped in an elementary school classroom. It shows, in pastel tones, a poster familiar to many American children: ''We are each unique and special.''

title: 36 Hours | Grafton, Vt.
description: ON a snowy day in Grafton, fires are stoked and soft chairs beckon in a cozy country inn. Nearby, snow enthusiasts strap on snowshoes and cross-country skis. On Main Street, women in pleated wool slacks and men in heavy boots quickly drop their taciturn veneer for a visitor who asks a question or starts a friendly conversation. Grafton is a town of 600, smaller than it was in a long-ago heyday of mills, quarries and sheep farms. But largely thanks to the Windham Foundation, which is based in Grafton and has preserved dozens of its lovely old buildings, the town, set in an alpine valley, still looks like a Currier & Ives print. On a leisurely weekend, it is a pleasant place for discovering winter's quiet side.

title: Gary Hart's Strengths Vie With Embarrassing Past
description: As his plane descended over Iowa's frozen cornfields on Wednesday, Gary Hart analyzed his presidential prospects as cheerily as he did during the 1980's. At 66, he looks the part better than ever now that the boyish good looks have weathered. Gray hair is an asset for a politician whose most famous pictures involved a yacht named Monkey Business.

title: To U.S., Onus Is on Hussein
description: The Bush administration's case against Iraq can be summed up in one sentence: Iraq has not led United Nations inspectors to the weapons Washington insists Baghdad is hiding.

title: Not Even Kidd's Best Effort Can Save Nets
description: Jason Kidd returned to his neighborhood and commandeered the court as he once did his playground.

title: Madden Says Officials Play Team Game, Too
description: For years, John Madden's belief that the best team of officials, not an all-star group, should call playoff games has never wavered. Yet in the postseason, the National Football League sends the highest-ranking officials at each of seven positions, creating a Pro Bowl team of zebras.

title: U.S. Offers Belgrade a Deal for 3 Wanted Men
description: The United States has offered to drop its demand that Yugoslavia send several war crimes suspects to the United Nations tribunal in The Hague if three of the most wanted fugitives are arrested by March 31, a State Department official said today.

title: A Top Inspector Rebukes Iraq for Blocking Reconnaissance Flights
description: Hans Blix, the chief United Nations inspector for chemical and biological weapons, said today that Iraq's cooperation with inspections had been a ''mixed bag'' and criticized Baghdad for blocking U-2 aerial photography flights.

title: Bleak Forecast as City Jobless Rate Climbs
description: New York City's economy ended 2002 in steep decline, with an unemployment rate far above the national average and an accelerating loss of private sector jobs, according to data released today by the state and city governments.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honda Debt In Review
description: Moody's Investors Service has put the debt rating for the Honda Motor Company on review for a possible upgrade. Honda, Japan's second-largest carmaker, has improved its market position and financial flexibility, Moody's said. Honda is one of the few Japanese carmakers with rising sales in Japan, and last year its minicar, the Fit, was the top seller. The company's sales in the United States and Europe have also increased. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Churning Out Votes, Senate Clears Spending Package
description: After more than a week of partisan wrangling, the Senate approved a $390.5 billion spending measure tonight that covers dozens of federal agencies and hundreds of programs, including medical research, early childhood education and the Border Patrol.

title: A Super Sunday for Football and for Madison Avenue
description: As Madison Avenue gears up for Super Bowl Sunday -- the biggest day of the year for both advertising and football -- marketers and agencies are adopting a strategy torn from a gridiron playbook: get big or go home.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: MAYOR OPTIMISTIC DESPITE CITY'S PAIN
description: Plagued by gloomy poll numbers and an intransigent economy, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged in his State of the City address yesterday that his administration's decision to impose an 18.5 percent property tax increase had enraged many New Yorkers, and he expressed sympathy for those forced to sacrifice.

title: Random House Venture To Print Books in Japan
description: Random House, the world's largest publisher of English- and German-language trade books, said today that it would form a joint venture with Kodansha, the largest publisher in Japan, to issue original Japanese-language books and translations of international titles.

title: At World Economic Forum, U.S. Might a Cause for Concern
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 24  Attorney General John Ashcroft came to a snowbound ski resort here today to explain to the world's rich, powerful and just plain pushy the rectitude of his tactics in America's war on terror. In the process, he faced a gantlet of questions, not all of them from the usual suspects.

title: British Safeway Now Urges That Original Suitor Be Jilted
description: Safeway said today that it was no longer recommending that its shareholders approve the deal that it reached two weeks ago to be acquired by William Morrison Supermarkets, a rival chain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENNIS, GERTRUDE WEYHE
description: DENNIS-Gertrude Weyhe. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their colleague, an ADAA member since 1963. Gracious, elegant and knowledgeable, she was for many years an outstanding dealer in American prints and drawings. Our sympathy and condolences to her daughter, Deborah and her brother, Arthur. title: Technology Briefing | Internet: A Gathering On Net Taxes
description: Lawmakers and tax officials from more than 30 states have gathered in Tampa, Fla., in an effort to create a groundwork for setting taxes on Internet sales and services. R. Bruce Johnson, head of the tax commission in Utah, said officials intended to try to define, in legal terms, how digital products like downloadable music, movies and software and other Internet services could be fairly taxed while the Web continued to evolve. States would have to update their tax codes to accommodate e-commerce, and Congress and the White House would have to approve legislation before a plan to tax online sales could be carried out. Internet retailers have opposed such taxation plans. Congress passed a ban on Internet taxes in 1998, and legislation is pending in the House and Senate to extend indefinitely a moratorium on such taxes. Governors and state officials argue, though, that millions of dollars are lost in taxes every year to online shopping.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cable And Wireless Credit Rating Cut To Junk
description: The credit rating of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. was cut four levels by Standard & Poor's to below investment grade yesterday on concern that the company, a British phone and Internet services provider, might spend too much to reorganize its biggest unit. Standard & Poor's lowered the long-term credit rating to BB from BBB+, it said. Moody's Investors Service cut Cable & Wireless's credit rating to junk on Dec. 6, also on concern about reorganization costs at the Global unit, which accounts for almost two-thirds of sales. Standard & Poor's cited concerns about losses at Global and ''significant weakening'' in the cash position after Cable and Wireless said it would spend 800 million orf $1.3 billion this year to exit part of its United States and European operations.

title: Large H.M.O. to Make Treatment Guidelines Public
description: Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest nonprofit health maintenance organization, said yesterday that it would publish on its Web site the guidelines developed and used by Kaiser's doctors for treatment of hundreds of diseases, ''from asthma to visual impairment.'' title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Posts Narrower 4th-Quarter Loss
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, North America's largest maker of telephone equipment, said yesterday that it had a narrower fourth-quarter net loss as costs fell and sales dropped 27 percent. The loss, Nortel's 12th straight, was $248 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with $1.83 billion, or 57 cents, a year earlier, Nortel said. Sales fell to $2.52 billion from $3.46 billion. The results cap five years of annual losses, caused by acquisition expenses in 1998 through 2000 and a plunge in customer spending the last two years. The chief executive, Frank Dunn, the former finance chief who took over in 2001, said in August that he would pare 7,000 more jobs in a bid to restore profitability this year. This year Nortel and rivals like Lucent Technologies ''are all going to be fighting over not a lot of business,'' said Walter Casey, technology analyst at Banc One Investment Advisers. Nortel shares rose 15 cents, to $2.55 in after-hours trading. They rose 5 cents, to $2.40, in regular trading.

title: Bush's Backing, Still Strong, Shows Steady Decline
description: President Bush's public support has eroded steadily over the last 12 months, with a rising number of Americans expressing discontent both with his economic policies and his handling of foreign affairs, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows.

title: UNITED AIRLINES TO LAY OFF 704 MORE FLIGHT ATTENDANTS
description: United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation, said yesterday that it would lay off 704 more flight attendants, about 3 percent of its total, next month because it had reduced flights and amenities like meal service. United, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month, will lay off the workers by Feb. 22, the United Association of Flight Attendants said. The union asked some of the carrier's 23,000 attendants to volunteer for the layoffs or split shifts with co-workers. The carrier has been reducing flights, switching to smaller aircraft on some routes and dropping some food service as it scales back.

title: Holes Found in I.N.S. Checks at Airports

title: MBNA SAYS IT SET ASIDE $1.4 BILLION FOR BAD LOANS
description: The MBNA Corporation said yesterday that it set aside $1.4 billion for bad loans in the fourth quarter. An MBNA spokesman, Brian Dalphon, said the company increased its reserves against losses among customers who took out lines of credit and used so-called convenience checks from MBNA to borrow without using a credit card. The money set aside was 19 percent more than in the period a year earlier and increased reserves by $128 million after write-offs of $1.3 billion, Mr. Dalphon said. MBNA disclosed the set-aside as it reported fourth-quarter results. The company said it earned $540 million, or 41 cents a share, up from $525 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 6.3 percent, to $3.4 billion.

The company had hoped to occupy the site of the defunct Maxim's Restaurant in the Carlton House, a landmark at 680 Madison, by Labor Day. title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Court Rejects Siege Lawsuits
description: A Moscow judge rejected three lawsuits brought by people held hostage during the seizure of a theater by Chechen rebels in October. The judge gave no reason for the dismissal, but under Russian law she must provide a written basis for her ruling by next week. The ruling seemed to indicate the fate of the 58 remaining suits in what has been an almost unheard of initiative by ordinary Russians to fight the government. The lawsuits, with claims totaling $60 million, were brought in December and seek damages over the siege, in which about 120 hostages were killed along with their captors when Russian commandos raided the theater. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chohung Bidder Selected

Shinhan was selected over Cerberus Partners, which includes Korea First Bank, 51 percent owned by Newbridge Capital. She was 54.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit Rises For Steel Maker
description: The Tata Iron and Steel Company, India's largest private steel maker, said it earned 2.8 billion rupees ($58 million) in its most recent quarter, up from 345 million rupees ($7 million) a year earlier, helped by rising domestic steel prices, increased demand for construction and automobile manufacturing and an increase in exports. Sales in the period, which ended Dec. 31 and was the third quarter of Tata's fiscal year, increased 26 percent, to 24 billion rupees. Tata is part of the Tata industrial conglomerate, one of India's largest industrial houses with interests spanning software and truck making.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Otto calls itself an enoteca and pizzeria, which is the truth but not the whole truth. There is a lot of wine, of course, because the owners, Mario Batali and Joseph Bastianich, have carved out a niche as passionate advocates for Italian wines from all regions. There is pizza, too, and lots of it, plate-size individual pies cooked on top of the griddle that come in old-fashioned formats, like the time-honored pizza margherita, and new interpretations, like a pizza topped with thin slices of lardo (or cured salt pork) and strewn with fresh rosemary.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: JDS SALES DROP BUT LOSS NARROWS The JDS Uniphase Corporation said yesterday that sales of its fiber optic equipment dropped for the eighth consecutive period in its second quarter, but its loss shrank as the company continued to squeeze costs. JDS, a supplier of fiber optic parts, reported a loss of $215 million, or 15 cents a share, in its second quarter, which ended Dec. 31. That is an improvement from a net loss of $2.1 billion, or $1.60 a share, in the period last year. Excluding one-time items, JDS posted a loss of $185 million, or 13 cents a share. The results included about $92 million in restructuring charges. On average, analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected an adjusted loss of 5 cents a share. The mean revenue estimate from 13 analysts was $152.5 million. Sales fell to $157 million from $193 million in its first quarter and from $286 million in the quarter a year ago. The company said it would cut its current work force of 7,000 even further.   (Reuters)

description: Continuing a trend that began last year, more New York City schools were removed from the state's list of failing schools this year than were added, the State Education Department said yesterday. title: WILLIAMS SAYS IT CUT DEBT BY $600 MILLION IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The Williams Companies, a United States pipeline owner with $2 billion in debt payments due this year, said yesterday that it had $1.6 billion of cash and unused bank lines after reducing debt by $600 million in the fourth quarter. The company said it had $1.1 billion of cash and almost $500 million in available credit lines from banks. Total debt dropped to $14 billion at the end of December, from $14.6 billion at the end of September. Williams plans to shut its energy-trading business, which had $602 million in losses during the first nine months of 2002.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KLM Narrows Loss
description: The Dutch airline KLM said that it lost 66 million euros ($71 million) in its most recent quarter, an improvement from the 94 million euros it lost a year earlier. It also announced a series of cost-cutting measures. Sales in the period, which ended Dec. 31 and was the third quarter of KLM's fiscal year, increased 7 percent, to 1.6 billion euros. KLM said it imposed a hiring freeze and would reduce the size of its fleet to cut costs. KLM predicted this month that it would post a loss for the fiscal year, which ends March 31. Rising oil prices and political turmoil are aggravating the airline's problems with a weak world economy.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: EASING RESTRICTIONS ON GROWERS As the state prepared for one of its worst freezes in years, Gov. Jeb Bush signed an emergency order to relax road restrictions so citrus and vegetable growers can haul their produce to warehouses and processing plants. The order, in effect for 30 days, waives rules on weight, height, length and width for trucks carrying vulnerable crops. "Our growers are eager to get the fruit off the trees as soon as possible," said Casey Pace, a spokeswoman for Florida Citrus Mutual, a growers association in Lakeland. (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: NORTEL POSTS NARROWER 4TH-QUARTER LOSS The Nortel Networks Corporation , North America's largest maker of telephone equipment, said yesterday that it had a narrower fourth-quarter net loss as costs fell and sales dropped 27 percent. The loss, Nortel's 12th straight, was $248 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with $1.83 billion, or 57 cents, a year earlier, Nortel said. Sales fell to $2.52 billion from $3.46 billion. The results cap five years of annual losses, caused by acquisition expenses in 1998 through 2000 and a plunge in customer spending the last two years. The chief executive, Frank Dunn, the former finance chief who took over in 2001, said in August that he would pare 7,000 more jobs in a bid to restore profitability this year. This year Nortel and rivals like Lucent Technologies "are all going to be fighting over not a lot of business," said Walter Casey, technology analyst at Banc One Investment Advisers. Nortel shares rose 15 cents, to $2.55 in after-hours trading. They rose 5 cents, to $2.40, in regular trading.   (Bloomberg News)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens Profit Slips
description: The electronics and engineering group Siemens posted a quarterly profit of 521 million euros ($560 million), which was down 3 percent from the year-earlier quarter but still better than expected. Sales fell 10 percent and orders were down 21 percent, to 20.1 billion euros, but Siemens said net income was helped by 125 million euros ($134 million) in cancellation fees at its power plant unit. At the annual shareholders meeting in Munich, the chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, reiterated his cautious outlook for 2003, predicting falling sales and orders because of the weak economy. description: Business activity declined for the third straight month in November. The government's all industry index, a proxy for gross domestic product, slipped a worse-than-expected 0.8 percent compared with October. The decline was twice as fast as forecast by economists.

description: Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, left, met at 10 Downing Street and said they had charted a ''work program'' in the coming weeks of intensive meetings for themselves and the leaders of Northern Ireland's political parties to try to get the suspended Catholic-Protestant government of the British-ruled province up and running again. The government created by the 1998 peace agreement was suspended and direct rule from London was restored after the discovery last October of an Irish Republican Army spying operation that was compiling information on prison officers, police officials, Protestant guerrilla groups and community workers. title: The Right to Counsel
description: A federal judge in New York attacked the Bush administration recently for defying his order to allow Jose Padilla, who is accused of being part of a plot to set off a ''dirty bomb,'' to meet with a lawyer. In case after case, the administration has taken the position that if it accuses someone of being a terrorist, he can be prevented from communicating with a lawyer. The right to counsel is a cornerstone of the American legal system, and the administration must realize that it has not been repealed by the war on terrorism.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Surgery For Senator Graham
description: Senator Bob Graham of Florida, who has been weighing whether to seek the Democratic presidential nomination next year, said he would have surgery the week of Feb. 3 to replace a damaged heart valve. Mr. Graham, 66, said he decided to undergo the operation after tests showed that an aortic valve had deteriorated. His spokesman, Paul Anderson, said Mr. Graham would defer announcing whether he will run for president until March. David Stout (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREASSI, CALVIN W.
description: ANDREASSI - Calvin W. Founder of Sandy Lane Partners, a private hedge fund, and owner of CAC MedTech Group, a biotech/healthcare research consulting firm, died on Tuesday, January 21, 2003, at Northern Westchester Hospital. Survived by his beloved wife, Stephanie, mother, Ida; brother, James; sister, Sandra. Cal was born in Bronx, NY, on July 3, 1954. He earned a Bachelor of Fine Arts from New York University and worked as a professional musician for many years. Cal was one of the first dialysis patients in New York City, surviving 22 years on dialysis. In December 1999, he received a kidney transplant from his brother, James, and survived an additional three years during which he expanded his consulting business and hedge fund. Cal was well respected for his unique understanding of the FDA approval process and experimental methodologies for new drugs, as well as an uncanny ability to predict success or failure of a company and its products. Cal loved life and possessed an indomitable spirit which was contagious to all around him. He provided an unforgettable example of stoicism and great courage, and continually exceeded all expectations, achieving so much in such a short time. He will be missed by all who knew him. ''It's all so meaningless we might as well be extraordinary.'' For information Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Inc 914-666-4840

title: Courageous Pilgrims On the Road to Freedom
description: In May 1961 Bruce Davidson, a member of the Magnum photo agency, went to Montgomery, Ala., and joined the Freedom Riders, civil rights workers protesting the racial segregation of interstate travel in the South. A few weeks before he arrived, one bus of Freedom Riders going from Washington to Birmingham, Ala., was firebombed. Another bus traveling the same route was attacked by a mob. Mr. Davidson was there for a third try, traveling with the Freedom Riders on a Trailways bus escorted by National Guard troops from Montgomery to Jackson, Miss. Thus began his off-and-on five-year stint in the South.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 3 Accused In November Killing
description: Detectives have arrested three men who killed a man while stealing from a compact-disc piracy operation, the police said yesterday. The victim, Ablai Diallo, 37, who worked in the bootleg operation on West 29th Street in Manhattan, was killed during the robbery on Nov. 17. Jamel Edwards, 22, and Keith Samuel, 21, both of Brooklyn, were charged Jan. 12 with second-degree murder. Four days later, the third man, Melroy Nembard, 22, was picked up in North Carolina in the killing and is expected to be extradited to New York. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: More Deportations Allowed
description: The Supreme Court ruled that the government could deport people from outside the European Union even if they are parents of children born in Ireland, who receive automatic citizenship. Previously they were allowed to stay on the ground that Irish citizens -- like their children -- had a right to be with their families. The 5-2 decision, which found against a Czech family and a Nigerian man who were due to be deported last year, was attacked by civil rights groups and refugee support agencies. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Weekender | Easton, Pa.
description: PEOPLE looking for a second home in eastern Pennsylvania often drive right through Easton, a faded canal town about 90 minutes from Manhattan. It is hard to miss the boarded-up buildings on one stretch of the main street just minutes from the town square, along with the occasional drifter. But while Easton might lack the quaintness of some other eastern Pennsylvania communities, like the tourist destination of New Hope, an hour away, the town's raw industrial character is precisely its draw for many residents, particularly the young artists who have set up studios in the Victorian brick warehouses, smack in the center of downtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, IRENE
description: DIAMOND-Irene. Jazz at Lincoln Center deeply mourns the death of our great friend and benefactor, Irene Diamond. Since our inception in 1991, she was steadfast in her interest and support of our organization and in her belief that Jazz music must take its rightful place as one of our nation's and the world's great art forms. To this end, the Irene Diamond Education Center, which she helped to make possible, is currently being created in her honor in our new home at Columbus Circle. Irene's extraordinary wisdom, unbending convictions and generous good humor combined with her youthful energy made her a treasure. Her wonderful spirit will live on in the hearts and minds of all of us at Jazz at Lincoln Center and through the work of the many organizations and causes which she supported so generously and passionately. The board, staff and artists of Jazz at Lincoln Center all loved her and will miss her greatly. Lisa Schiff, Chairman Wynton Marsalis, Artistic Director Gordon J. Davis, Founding Chairman Hughlyn F. Fierce, President & CEO

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend last Friday about ''Post-Byzantium: The Greek Renaissance,'' at the Onassis Cultural Center in Manhattan, misstated the policy on the admission of women to Mount Athos, a center of Eastern Orthodox monasticism and Byzantine art. All women are excluded; there is no exception for theology students.

description: Cisco Systems, which makes computer networking equipment, said today that it had sued Huawei Technologies of China, accusing the company of copying software and infringing patents.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Sued Over Free Speech
description: Five demonstrators sued New York City yesterday, saying their First Amendment rights were violated when they were arrested last January while trying to hang a protest banner during the World Economic Forum. The banner criticized the AIDS policies of President Bush and multinational corporations, the suit said. Charges of criminal trespass and unlawful posting were later dismissed, the suit said. A city corporation counsel spokeswoman declined to comment, saying the suit had not yet been reviewed. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

description: Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz to the Council on Foreign Relations, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/international.

title: Democrats Seek a Tax Rebate to Aid Growth
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Senate Democrats took on the administration's tax cut plan in earnest today with the release of a sharply different economic stimulus proposal, calling for a $300-a-person rebate check and $40 billion in aid to states and cities.

title: Estates Are Bought, But Not Fawned Over
description: At the peak of his high-flying fraud scheme, Martin R. Frankel had amassed a hoard of goodies: two homes on adjacent four-acre estates in the back country of Greenwich, a fleet of luxury cars, a stable of mistresses, as well as chauffeurs, chefs and armed bodyguards.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: COURT REJECTS SIEGE LAWSUITS A Moscow judge rejected three lawsuits brought by people held hostage during the seizure of a theater by Chechen rebels in October. The judge gave no reason for the dismissal, but under Russian law she must provide a written basis for her ruling by next week. The ruling seemed to indicate the fate of the 58 remaining suits in what has been an almost unheard of initiative by ordinary Russians to fight the government. The lawsuits, with claims totaling $60 million, were brought in December and seek damages over the siege, in which about 120 hostages were killed along with their captors when Russian commandos raided the theater. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: First No TV; Now Prison
description: A petty criminal whose sentence of no-television-viewing while under house arrest was overturned by a federal appeals court has instead been sentenced to prison. Edward Bello, of Orange County, N.Y., was originally sentenced to house arrest in a credit-card conspiracy case. After the no-television edict was overturned on appeal, the case was sent back for a new sentence. But before the judge, Alvin K. Hellerstein, could take up the matter, Mr. Bello was arrested last fall on separate state charges, including burglary, court records show. Those charges are pending, but the judge resentenced Mr. Bello in the credit-card case, to 15 months in prison. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: 'You'll Get Tired of That Color!'
description: ON a recent Saturday, I went coat shopping at Loehmann's in Manhattan with my mom. She was full of opinions. I tried on a narrow military trench, and she declared it too thin and tight. A thick sweater will never fit underneath, she said. A fur-trimmed shearling swallowed me up. An orange Les Copains peacoat fit nicely. But you'll get tired of that bright color, she told me. Why not try something more classic, like a boxy, wool Bill Blass with sleeves as roomy as sleeping bags? By the way, didn't you buy a winter coat three years ago? It's a big purchase. Maybe you don't need a new one yet.

title: Video, in Its Infancy, Had to Crawl Before It Could Walk
description: I like video art as much as most art critics, maybe more. Still, through ''Video Acts,'' the sprawling survey of early single channel videotapes at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, is not my idea of a thoroughly good time. Building a private collection of these works, as Pamela and Richard Kramlich of San Francisco did, strikes me as even less enjoyable.

title: Charles Henri Ford
description: Mitchell Algus Gallery

title: Pataki Offer On Airports Has 2 Goals, Aide Says
description: A top aide to Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that the idea to have the Port Authority pay New York City more than $500 million in increased rent at the city's two major airports was just one possibility for helping the financially strapped city. Still, the proposal would have to be fleshed out and then overcome charges that it would give the city much less than it is owed.

title: Middleton Takes Exception
description: Leave it to the Oakland Raiders' verbose offensive guard, Frank Middleton, to take exception to a few things that Tampa Bay Buccaneers defensive end Simeon Rice had to say this week.

title: Hitler's Secretary Looks Back in Sorrow
description: ''Blind Spot: Hitler's Secretary'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Elvis Mitchell's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 10; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The subtitled German-language documentary opens today in Manhattan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Farmingdale: Fire Leaves Scores Homeless
description: A fire that was apparently started by a dropped cigarette tore through an apartment house yesterday, injuring three firefighters and leaving at least 40 people homeless. At least a half-dozen pets in the building were killed, the authorities said. The fire broke out about 9:20 a.m. in a two-story building near the Farmingdale train station. Two firefighters suffered head injuries when the ceiling collapsed and were treated at the scene, along with another firefighter who suffered minor cuts, officials said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHFELD, AL
description: HIRSCHFELD-Al. Dear Al, thank you for all you have done for us throughout the years, especially after our own dear George's passing, when you guided me into the world of business. I will be forever grateful for your concern. There will never be another one like you and we will always remember your warmth and generosity, and we will keep you close in our hearts forever and treasure your memory and celebrate your life. Our most heartfelt condolences go out to Louise and family, and to Nina, Matthew and Margaret. George J. Goodstadt, Inc. Alexandra Goodstadt, Pres. Kristina Goodstatdt Helene Merrick

title: Tripping the Light Fantastic With Swells and Tramps
description: Four couples, the men in tails and the women dressed to overkill, enjoy an evening of romance in a grand 1930's supper club complete with a giant tilted mirror and Art Deco-tiled platforms. The Broadway musical they possibly attended might have featured a mock ballet with a torrid duet between a stripper and her guy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, ALLEN
description: ALLEN-Allen. Famous New York City restaurateur and raconteur died with his family at his side on January 23, 2003. Loving and adoring husband of Fay Allen. Devoted father of Jeffrey and Sheila, Mark and Donna, Bonnie and Ronald Allen. Most cherished grandfather to his ''earth angels'' Gregory, Greer, Meredith, Brett, Carly and Perry. His love, warmth and humor will be deeply missed by all. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Friday, 11:15AM. Interment Abraham and Sarah Cemetery, Paramus, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Friends of Karen or the Friars Club Foundation.

title: McGreevey Nominates Prosecutor for Attorney General
description: Peter C. Harvey, a veteran prosecutor, was nominated today to become New Jersey's new attorney general, and he vowed to make his top priorities the state's fight against terrorism and political corruption.

title: Ex-Publisher at Random House Is Moving to Penguin
description: Ann Godoff, the influential former president of the Random House Trade Group at Bertelsmann's Random House books division, has agreed to join a rival, the Penguin division of Pearson, as an editor, people involved in the talks said this evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACHETTI, RENATO
description: PACHETTI-Renato. It is with great sadness that RAI Radiotelevisione Italiana, Italy's public broadcasting system, acknowledges the loss of one of its most dedicated and beloved colleagues. For over 30 years, Renato Pachetti served RAI with the highest level of professionalism and enthusiasm whose legacy is RAI Corporation, the New York subsidiary of the Italian company. In addition to his career at RAI, starting as its United Nations correspondent rising to Chairman of RAI Corp., Mr. Pachetti also served as Chairman of the Foreign Press Association of the United States, Chairman of the International Council of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences and President of the Italian business association Gruppo Esponenti Italiani. He also served as the President of ''LaScuola d'Italia'' Guglielmo Marconi in New York City. He will be deeply missed by everyone in the RAI family as well as by all who knew him in the broadcast and journalism communities. We extend our most heartfelt sympathies to his wife Diane and his sons Alex, Nick, Edward and their families.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Corning Loss Widens To $709 Million
description: The largest maker of optical fiber for carrying telephone calls and data, Corning Inc., said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss widened to $709 million as sales fell 20 percent and it had costs for cutting jobs. The net loss was 60 cents a share in the period, which ended Dec. 31, compared with a loss of $655 million, or 69 cents, in the quarter a year earlier, a Corning spokeswoman, Monica Ott, said. Sales fell to $736 million from $917 million. The company has eliminated 18,800 jobs, or 44 percent of its work force, and is scaling back units like its fiber optic parts business. Plummeting demand for optical fiber, cable and gear has resulted in more than $6 billion in losses since June 2001. The shares fell to $4 in after-hours trading after the earnings announcement. They rose 29 cents, to $4.36, in regular trading. In the fourth quarter, Corning had $1.07 billion in after-tax expenses related to cutting jobs, shutting operations and the declining value of assets, the company said.

title: Settlement That Averted Strike Approved by Transit Workers
description: The city's transit workers ratified a new three-year contract yesterday by a 60 percent majority, despite a vigorous campaign by union dissidents to have the contract rejected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETTIT, SARAH
description: PETTIT-Sarah. A great spirit, a good friend. Condolences to her family and to her family of friends. Roz Lichter

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Easing Sidewalk Permitting
description: The Bloomberg administration's plan to streamline the process for restaurant owners to obtain permits for sidewalk cafes has taken a step closer to reality. The Consumer Affairs Committee of the City Council approved the measure by a vote of 6 to 0 on Wednesday. It will now go before the full Council for a vote. Under the plan, the permit approval process, which currently involves several city agencies and is considered overly complex, would be supervised by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. The average wait for restaurants would drop to fewer than 140 days from 465, city officials have projected. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: A Measured Mayoral Message
description: Delivering his second State of the City address yesterday, Mayor Michael Bloomberg did not needlessly pander, clutter his remarks with levity or pull a rabbit out of a hat. But on the coldest day of the year, amid a staggering financial crisis, he conveyed a sense of hope that New York City's challenges are surmountable. He pronounced the city ''strong, confident and undefeated.'' These words could easily apply to the mayor himself -- or at least to the image Mr. Bloomberg sought to convey of a leader undaunted by dipping popularity ratings.

title: Suit Says Chicago Housing Renewal Plan Perpetuates Segregation
description: A lawsuit was filed against the Chicago Housing Authority today on behalf of thousands of public housing residents who say they were steered to mostly black, high-crime and impoverished neighborhoods when they were forced to move as part of a plan to demolish the city's high-rise housing projects.

title: Civil Rights for Old Boys
description: The dean of admissions at Harvard, William Fitzsimmons, has defended so-called legacy allowances with heroic attention to data. He told The Wall Street Journal that he read personally ''all applications from children of alumni,'' which last year amounted to (an astonishing) 727. How heavy was the edge given to these applicants? Oh, not much: The average SAT score of legacies admitted is just two points below the school's overall average.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOELTERHOFF, HEINZ ALFONS MARTIN
description: HOELTERHOFF-Heinz Alfons Martin. Born in Germany on January 19, 1914, died January 14, 2003, at the Tolstoi Nursing Home in Valley Cottage, NY. Husband of Olga (Ollie) Christina Alexandrovna (nee Goertz) of Riga, Latvia. Father of Manuela Vali Hoelterhoff. Dispatched to Russia by a madman you despised, you miraculously survived the Battle of Stalingrad, returning scarred for life to a destroyed country you left as soon as you could. The streets here were not paved with gold, but you lived quietly with your small family, a friend of fish, snakes and turtles, and all the raccoons, geese, ducks, cats and dogs who came your way. There were many. Your girls miss you. Ollie, Manuela, Francesca, Marilyn, Sheila, Irene, Patricia, Sugar, Emma, and Pince-Pince

title: Don't Worry, Honey. It's an Investment!
description: LIKE the faithful at a revival meeting, the frenzied crowd swarmed toward the stage of the vast tent in the Arizona desert, checkbooks flapping like fans in the stifling heat.

title: Iraq Says Its Scientists Have Refused Private Interviews by U.N. Weapons Inspectors
description: Iraqi scientists have refused to be interviewed in private by United Nations weapons inspectors, a top Iraqi official said tonight, apparently voiding for the moment a central demand of the inspectors and the Bush administration.

title: Harris Completes Jaguars' Reorganization
description: The Jacksonville Jaguars completed their front-office reorganization today by naming James Harris their vice president for football operations.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Man They Say Attacked a Stranger
description: A 24-year-old man staying at a Christian Science compound in Princeton Township, N.J., barged into a neighboring home early yesterday, stabbed the owner during a frantic fight and was shot and killed by police officers responding to a 911 call, the authorities said.

description: To the Editor:

title: Glavine Changes Much More Than His Baseball Uniform
description: Tom Glavine had everything he needed to be a good husband, a good father, a good pitcher and, please, do not forget this one, a good golfer, within his valuable fingertips right here. No need to move an inch. Wake up, brush your teeth, and, voil, Glavine's happy, successful life was as picturesque to him as a rainbow.

title: Liquid Audio Gets a Buyer For Its Assets
description: In a move that could make it easier for record companies to sell and promote songs online, the music distributor for Wal-Mart has agreed to buy some of the assets of Liquid Audio, the troubled digital music pioneer.

title: An Inventor Trapped in Nazi Evil
description: At least since ''Z,'' his ferocious thriller about the 1967 military coup in Greece, Constantin Costa-Gavras has specialized in dramas about fallible, generally decent people who find themselves in intimate confrontation with political evil -- usually but not exclusively some variant of fascism. His movies, more often than not derived from actual events, tend to be explorations of the untenable choices that fascism forces on the liberal conscience.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Move By Sherry-Lehmann Fails
description: Sherry-Lehmann, perhaps New York's best-known wine shop, said yesterday that its plans to move across Madison Avenue into the Carlton House had failed. The company had hoped to occupy the site of the defunct Maxim's Restaurant in the Carlton House, a landmark at 680 Madison, by Labor Day. ''The negotiations involved several parties coming together like a Swiss watch, and we could not make the parts click,'' said Michael Aaron, Sherry-Lehmann's chairman. Ronald Solomon, a Rolfe Group broker, said, ''The cost of construction rose exponentially, and the transaction was no longer prudent for Sherry-Lehmann.'' Howard G. Goldberg (NYT)

description: Israel's last titans, the oldest of friends and rivals, embody the fears and yearnings -- and with them the political choices -- of the country they helped create.

title: Democrats in Trenton Block Vote on Campaign Financing
description: After an angry debate on the floor of the New Jersey Assembly, Democrats today blocked a vote on a measure to ban campaign contributions from state contractors.

title: A Bitter, Biting, Brutal Day, But the Worst May Be Over
description: A blast of arctic air plunged the region deeper into bitter cold yesterday, with temperatures in the teens and low 20's and icy winds making it feel much colder. It was the worst of an already menacing cold snap, which has stretched for 10 days and will most likely linger until Sunday.

title: Bank of America Unit Accused of Sex Bias
description: The Bank of America Corporation's investment banking unit has been sued in a sex bias suit by an analyst who says she was demeaned, harassed and denied job opportunities because of her sex.

title: Raiders' Ritchie Is a Studied Breath of Fresh Air
description: Do not be fooled by the bulbous welts on his forehead that make him look a bit like Frankenstein's monster without the bolts. Who else but Raiders fullback Jon Ritchie, English major at Stanford, fan of Middle English and Herman Melville, could accurately mock his own strange bruising patterns by comparing them to specific eras on the evolutionary timeline?

title: A Wife Betrayed Finds Sympathy at Murder Trial
description: No one disputes that on the evening of July 24, Clara Harris revved her Mercedes and ran over her husband in the parking lot of the hotel where she had discovered him with his mistress, killing him as his 16-year-old daughter from a previous marriage screamed in the passenger seat.

title: Milton Lipson, 89, Lawyer and a Former Bodyguard for Roosevelt
description: Milton Lipson, a lawyer and investigator who, as a Secret Service agent from 1938 to 1946, was a personal bodyguard for Presidents Roosevelt and Truman, died on Wednesday in Glen Cove, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Russian Court Frees Reporter In Case About Nuclear Waste
description: Grigory Pasko, a crusading Russian journalist who documented the Russian Navy's mishandling of nuclear waste, was released today on parole, the latest chapter in a case that human rights groups called a throwback to Soviet-era repressions.

title: National Briefing: Science And Health
description: SURGERY FOR SENATOR GRAHAM Senator Bob Graham of Florida, who has been weighing whether to seek the Democratic presidential nomination next year, said he would have surgery the week of Feb. 3 to replace a damaged heart valve. Mr. Graham, 66, said he decided to undergo the operation after tests showed that an aortic valve had deteriorated. His spokesman, Paul Anderson, said Mr. Graham would defer announcing whether he will run for president until March. David Stout (NYT)

title: Pentagon's Sturdy Design Saved Lives, Engineers Find
description: A ''forest of columns'' designed to support the Pentagon when it was built 60 years ago saved thousands of people who would otherwise have died when terrorists attacked it with a hijacked airliner on Sept. 11, 2001, an expert panel said in a report released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIKOON, IRWIN
description: RIKOON-Irwin. Age 77, died January 23. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Jonathan, Emily and Nancy. Dear brother of Marilyn Sperber. Beloved grandfather of Laura, Josh, Neal, Jacob and Daniel. Cherished father-inlaw of Ira & Craig. Services today 10:15am at Temple Israel of White Plains, Old Mamaroneck Rd, NY. Donations to Temple Israel Center.

title: No Positives in This Legal Double Negative
description: ''NEVER use double negatives,'' my teacher ordered back in the fifth grade. But Mrs. Whitney was not a lawyer.

title: Comeback Keeps Final In Family
description: When Serena Williams's compelling comeback against Kim Clijsters in the Australian Open semifinals ended in bright sunlight, with Venus Williams watching from the stands, the history-making sisters had added another achievement to their collective rsum. No other two players in the 35-year history of Open tennis have played each other in four consecutive Grand Slam finals: not Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert; not Steffi Graf and Monica Seles.

title: Alinghi Fined for Entering Team New Zealand Area
description: The cost of keeping tabs on the competition in the America's Cup went up Thursday, when the Swiss team Alinghi was fined $5,000 by the New Zealand maritime police for driving its chase boats into an area of the Hauraki Gulf reserved for Team New Zealand.

title: The Era of the Medici, Merchants Who Longed to Be Monarchs
description: Art patronage on a grand scale is about getting power, holding on to it and making it look pretty. That's a central premise of ''The Medici, Michelangelo and the Art of Late Renaissance Florence'' at the Art Institute of Chicago, a show packed like a bank vault with precious objects, many of them associated with a family of middle-class merchant-bankers who strove to be kings.

title: Teamsters Accuse Top Union Official of Scheming With Organized Crime
description: The Teamsters union has filed internal charges against its top official in New Jersey, accusing him of trying to help a member of the Genovese crime family arrange a sweetheart deal that would have hurt union members.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIS DAVID
description: COHEN-Harris David. January 25, 1967-August 13, 1985. As our family grows, we miss you more and more. Our memories are beautiful; our hearts are broken. Much Love, Mom, Dad, Jonathan, Lisa and Jake Harris

title: Raiders' Rice Still Defying Age and Defenses
description: The eyes that can detect angles through a defense sprout subtle lines at their corners. Beneath the helmet, the hairline is receding. Fingers bend oddly, souvenirs from thousands of collisions with footballs, and from crashes into pads. Jerry Rice, the brick mason's son who forced every football fan to figure out where Mississippi Valley State was, is 40 years old now, a number nearly as startling as the receiving statistics he has rolled up in his 18 seasons in pro football.

title: Spain Arrests 16 Suspected of Ties to Al Qaeda
description: Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar said today that Spanish police officials had arrested 16 militants suspected of links to Al Qaeda, breaking up two cells and confiscating electronic material and containers of unidentified chemicals.

title: Debating Belgium's War-Crime Jurisdiction
description: For two and half years in the late 1980's, Souleymane Guengueng was imprisoned in Chad, tortured and starved as he watched fellow inmates die around him. Packed into a 7-by-3-foot windowless cell that he shared with eight other prisoners, he pledged to inform the world of the ruthlessness of Chad's dictator, Hissne Habr, if he survived.

title: Stock Indexes And the Dollar Fall Sharply
description: The worsening outlook for corporate earnings and the threat of a war with Iraq weighed heavily on Wall Street yesterday, as the three leading stock gauges fell more than 2.9 percent, giving the stock market its second consecutive week of losses.

title: N.F.L. Ponders Changing How Overtime Is Played
description: After a season of parity and a postseason of controversy, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue announced today that the National Football League was considering a change in its overtime format.

title: Cold Snap Pushes Use Of Utilities Above Records
description: The region's four major power companies were reporting record high use during a cold spell that is expected to ease up briefly tomorrow, before more cold weather returns next week.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Atlanta And Water Utility Split
description: Atlanta and United Water announced an early end to a deal made in 1999 that called on the utility to deliver water to two million residents. The agreement, the biggest contract to privatize a water supply in the United States, was to have lasted 20 years. But it left both sides dissatisfied. In an announcement, the city and United Water, a subsidiary of a French company, Suez, said they had agreed that the deal, worth $21 million a year, was ''not in the best interest of either party.'' Douglas Jehl (NYT)

title: International Briefs | Europe: Ireland: Home Prices Rise
description: The average price of a house in Ireland rose 13.3 percent in 2002, up from 4.4 percent in 2001, according to research from Permanent/TSB, the country's largest mortgage lender, and the Economic and Social Research Institute. Overall inflation in Ireland was 5 percent for the year to December 2002, its highest level since June 2000, and more than double the European average. Demand was fueled by government tax incentives for first-time house buyers and for property investors. Housing has long dominated the inflation tables but has moderated since its peak of 29.9 percent in 1998. Dublin is the most expensive area, where average house prices range around 280,000 euros ($303,000). Brian Lavery (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: PROFILING CONVICTION FOR OFFICER A former police officer in West Memphis, E. Anthony Bradley, was convicted in Federal District Court in Little Rock of conspiracy to violate the civil rights of drivers stopped on Interstate 40 by illegally confiscating their money and of skimming from cash seized from drug suspects. Mr. Bradley faces up to 10 years in prison. A second former West Memphis officer, Joseph Applegate, was acquitted of similar charges. The F.B.I. began investigating after complaints that officers were unfairly profiling Hispanic drivers for traffic stops in eastern Arkansas. Two other former officers are to be tried later.    Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Rival Palestinian Groups Meet in Cairo to Discuss Ending Attacks on Israeli Civilians
description: Palestinian factions opened talks here today that their Egyptian hosts hoped would result in a cease-fire halting attacks against Israeli civilians.
