description: On the first day of a sweeping government overhaul, the Department of Homeland Security opened for business today with a skeleton staff that will take control of 22 existing federal agencies over the next several months, redirecting their mission to focus on the defense of American soil from the possibility of new terrorist attacks.

description: Rae Carlson, a psychologist who helped shape the study of personality with her 1971 paper ''Where Is the Person in Personality Research?'', died on Monday in Fairfax, Va. She was 76.

title: $8 BILLION SURPLUS WITHERS AT AGENCY INSURING PENSIONS
description: The federal agency that insures the pensions of some 44 million Americans has been pounded by a succession of big corporate bankruptcies and has burned through its entire $8 billion surplus in one year.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Cancer Diagnosis, and Her Life Fell Apart

description: The Nets and the Los Angeles Lakers were locked in an even battle tonight -- the battle of attrition.

description: A Nobel Prize-winning British biologist with a passion for hang gliding, Sir Paul M. Nurse, will become president of Rockefeller University on Nov. 3, the university announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, IRENE
description: DIAMOND-Irene. Jazz at Lincoln Center deeply mourns the death of our great friend and benefactor, Irene Diamond. Since our inception in 1991, she was steadfast in her interest and support of our organization and in her belief that Jazz music must take its rightful place as one of our nation's and the world's great art forms. To this end, the Irene Diamond Education Center, which she helped to make possible, is currently being created in her honor in our new home at Columbus Circle. Irene's extraordinary wisdom, unbending convictions and generous good humor combined with her youthful energy made her a treasure. Her wonderful spirit will live on in the hearts and minds of all of us at Jazz at Lincoln Center and through the work of the many organizations and causes which she supported so generously and passionately. The board, staff and artists of Jazz at Lincoln Center all loved her and will miss her greatly. Lisa Schiff, Chairman Wynton Marsalis, Artistic Director Gordon J. Davis, Founding Chairman Hughlyn F. Fierce, President & CEO

title: Only Question for Reyes Is When
description: Jos Reyes was the first player Fred Wilpon sought out today when the Mets' bus finally arrived at their complex here. Wilpon would address a group of players the Mets are training here, but Reyes was the one Mets executives were here to see.

title: HealthSouth Review Panel Said to Have Been Chosen
description: The HealthSouth Corporation is expected to announce appointments on Monday to a committee formed to look into the independence of its board and how the company is governed, according to people who have been briefed on the decision.

title: Mexico Is Struggling Under New President
description: Few people watch every economic indicator from Washington more closely than Mexico's president, Vicente Fox, and his economic team.

title: Giants Want to Re-Sign Garrett
description: The Giants have determined they will bring back Jason Garrett, who served as their third-string quarterback last season. The Giants cannot officially begin re-signing their own free agents until later in the off-season, but they expect to re-sign Garrett.

title: Religion Journal; Clothes That Make a Few Statements
description: Frederick Purifoy II, a representative for recording artists at a gospel music label and a man of style, has a strategy for conveying faith through fashion.

title: Pataki Aligns Himself With Bush Tax-Cut Plan to Stimulate Economy
description: Facing a deep deficit in the state budget, Gov. George E. Pataki today hitched New York's financial recovery to the Bush administration's plans for healing the national recession: a swift new round of tax cuts.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rare Start No Problem For Schwab
description: About once a month, Corey Schwab is called upon to leave his customary seat on the Devils' bench and spell the regular goaltender, Martin Brodeur, for a night.

title: Hundreds Turn Out In Newark to Grieve For a Too-Brief Life
description: They buried Faheem Williams today after a stirring, emotional funeral service that seemed an attempt to give him, in death, some of the love he lacked in life.

title: A Mother's Bitter Choice: Telling Kidnappers No
description: Angelina Atyam has faced an awful trauma, and an awful choice.

description: To the Editor:

title: In West Hollywood, a Cat's Right to Scratch May Become a Matter of Law
description: The West Hollywood City Council, which has already pronounced its opposition to apartheid, war in Iraq and the U.S.A. Patriot Act, is now turning its progressive eye to what it calls the barbaric practice of declawing cats.

title: Three Terrific Quarters, But 4th Does Knicks In
description: It was shaping up to be a dream game, one of their best performances of the season, the type of contest that could propel a team to something special.

title: 2 Frozen Bodies Fall From Jet in Shanghai
description: The Chinese authorities are investigating the deaths of two men who dropped from the undercarriage of an Air France Boeing 777 as the plane approached Shanghai airport after a flight from Paris.

title: Deficit Tripled, Los Angeles Archdiocese Says
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles, which cut 60 jobs and pared numerous programs last year in an effort to bridge a $4.3 million budget gap, has released figures showing that the deficit has more than tripled.

title: Snow Energizes Isles, Cools Off Flyers
description: The Islanders' Garth Snow drew three goaltender-interference penalties tonight, and he wished he could have been hit even more. He is like a linebacker who needs to be slapped on the side of the helmet so he can play harder.

title: If a Machine Creates Something Beautiful, Is It an Artist?
description: Ask most chess grandmasters if chess is art and they will say unequivocally, ''Yes.'' Ask them if chess is also a sport and the answer will again be yes. But suggest that chess might be just a very complex math problem and there is immediate resistance.

title: Plane Crash In Kenya Kills Labor Minister And 2 Others
description: A plane carrying senior members of Kenya's newly elected government crashed today in western Kenya, killing a cabinet minister and the two pilots and seriously injuring at least three other officials, the authorities said.

title: Girl, 4, Suffers No Serious Injuries After Falling Down Elevator Shaft
description: A 4-year-old girl fell four floors down an elevator shaft of a building in Clinton yesterday evening but did not appear to be seriously injured, the police said.

title: For kids (and parents) the angst starts early on : Homework in France
description: PARIS  Americans in Paris able to sidestep haughty sales help, sweet talk the cantankerous concierge, get the paperwork right the first time around at city hall, and convince the taxi driver to take them where they want to go, might imagine they have life in France in the bag. But that's before the arrival of children.

title: Acquisition Helps Lift Stanley Works' Profit
description: Stanley Works, a leading maker of hand tools, said today that fourth-quarter profit more than tripled as sales increased, helped by the acquisition of Best Lock.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a debate among antiwar demonstrators over the role of groups like International Answer, whose causes extend beyond its antiwar message, misspelled the surname of an organizer for United for Peace, who said her members welcomed a wide variety of perspectives from protesters at rallies. She is Leslie Cagan, not Cogan.

title: A Trans-Atlantic Rift Over Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Cab Drivers and Guards Detained in a Three-Month Immigration Sweep
description: Federal immigration authorities have rounded up 69 foreign-born cab drivers and private security guards in San Diego in what they said was an effort to ensure the security of this weekend's Super Bowl, officials said today.

title: Senator Says New York Cities Paying Many Security Costs
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, complaining that federal money for security had failed to reach most communities in New York State, said yesterday that local governments were bearing a disproportionate share of the cost of security since Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Heart Disease Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Worried About Recent Increase in Bank Robberies
description: It is a simple crime. A note that threatens violence, slipped to a teller, is all it takes to get a wad of cash. The average take is $1,700.

title: Data Show Rapid Growth in Federal Budget Shortfall
description: New government data show that the federal government's budget shortfall has grown sharply in the last few months, even before Congress takes up President Bush's plan to cut taxes by $670 billion over 10 years.

title: Before Man Stabbed Stranger, He Was Examined at Hospital
description: The 24-year-old student killed in a burst of police gunfire after he stabbed an investment banker in Princeton Township, N.J., early Thursday was examined at a hospital there and released a few hours before the attack, officials said.

title: Connect, Only Connect
description: The whiteboard in Duncan J. Watts's office at Columbia University was a thicket of squiggly blue lines, circles and calculus equations. Mr. Watts, an associate professor of sociology, had just begun a passionate disquisition on the virtues and liabilities of scale-free networks when the telephone rang. It was Alfred Berkeley, the vice chairman of Nasdaq, hoping to chat about the exchange's design.

title: CHRISTIE'S RAISES COMMISSION ON SALES ABOVE $100,000
description: Christie's International will raise commissions on sales to 12 percent from 10 percent on amounts above $100,000, the company said yesterday. The increase is effective March 1. The premium charged to buyers on the first $100,000 of a sale will remain the same at 19.5 percent. The changes will apply to property sold in New York, London and Geneva. Sotheby's Holdings Inc., Christie's primary competitor, raised its premium for sales above $100,000 to 12 percent from 10 percent two weeks ago, and increased its commission on the first $100,000 to 20 percent from 19.5 percent.

title: N.Y.U. Hospitals Center's President to Resign
description: The president of New York University Hospitals Center announced her resignation on Thursday after a stormy year in which the merger she had championed with Mount Sinai Hospital frayed beyond repair and it was disclosed that she had a personal relationship with the head of the hospital's largest union.

title: Hyundai Query Focuses on a Possible Payoff to North Korea
description: A complex financial scandal involving a major South Korean company raised the sensitive question today of whether money was surreptitiously used to help pay for President Kim Dae Jung's summit meeting in June 2000 with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Footlights column of The Arts on Thursday about ''Debating American Modernism: Stieglitz, Duchamp and the New York Avant-Garde,'' at the Georgia O'Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, included an erroneous identification from the show sponsor, the American Federation of Arts, for the Stieglitz picture shown. It was ''Marcel Duchamp, Fountain,'' not ''Equivalent.''

description: In percent

title: International Briefs | Asia: Japan: Broker Might Merge
description: E*Trade Japan K.K. and the Softbank Investment Corporation, both units of the Softbank Corporation, are in merger talks, the companies said. E*Trade Japan, an online broker that is 44 percent owned by the Softbank Finance Corporation, a wholly owned unit of the Softbank Corporation, has struggled as trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange has declined. Softbank Investment, a venture capital fund that invests primarily in Internet companies, lost 2.66 billion yen ($22.6 million) in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: With All Ears for Him, Licitra Seeks His Destiny
description: How was Salvatore Licitra? That was the question for much of the opera-going public and for the high-profile audience that filled Carnegie Hall for the Collegiate Chorale's concert performance of Verdi's ''Forza del Destino'' on Thursday night. Mr. Licitra, the 34-year-old tenor, made waves as a last-minute replacement for Luciano Pavarotti in ''Tosca'' at the Metropolitan Opera last spring; since then there has been much discussion about whether he is really all he's cracked up to be. On Thursday the outlook was bright.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: BROKER MIGHT MERGE E*Trade Ja- pan K.K. and the Softbank Investment Corporation, both units of the Softbank Corporation, are in merger talks, the companies said. E*Trade Japan, an online broker that is 44 percent owned by the Softbank Finance Corporation, a wholly owned unit of the Softbank Corporation, has struggled as trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange has declined. Softbank Investment, a venture capital fund that invests primarily in Internet companies, lost 2.66 billion yen ($22.6 million) in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30.   Ken Belson (NYT)

description: POLIVY-Anita. Age 75, on January 22, 2003. Beloved wife of Irwin, loving mother of Howard & Judy; Paul & Betsy; and Marilyn & Steve Wille; dear sister of Eli Levine; adored grandmother of Jonathan, Joelle, Evan, Laura, Charles, and Justin. Services at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY, Sunday, January 26, 11AM.

title: Expat adviser : Coping with college applications
description: [Q] I am a high school student living with my family in Geneva, and I will likely return to the United States to attend college in a few years. I'd like to find out what is involved in preparing for college from here regarding taking the Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) and the American College Test (ACT), and if there are any other challenges in preparing to apply for college from abroad.

title: LONGTIME EXECUTIVE AT MERRILL LYNCH RETIRES
description: Merrill Lynch & Company's vice chairman, Jerome Kenney, who led the firm's expansion into stock underwriting and investment banking in the 1980's, said he was retiring after 36 years with the company. Mr. Kenney joined Merrill in 1978 when it acquired White Weld & Company. His resignation follows that of John McKinley, head of Merrill's technology and corporate services group, on Thursday, and comes as E. Stanley O'Neal, who became president of the firm in July 2001, installs his own management team. For the last year, Mr. Kenney has been in charge of the company's client relationships group.

title: Marxist to Rightist, and Back to Court
description: Horst Mahler, a former Marxist urban guerrilla and lawyer for the Red Army Faction, now represents the extreme right-wing National Democratic Party. But the virulence of his views has not diminished, and his outspoken comments on the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States have landed him back where he was decades ago -- in court.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Conservation Groups Fight Shark Rules
description: Conservation groups sued the Commerce Department, saying a decision to relax restrictions on fishing for coastal sharks could threaten the recovery of depleted species. Last month, the National Marine Fisheries Service raised quotas 33 percent and shed some size limits that had protected juvenile fish. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Kmart Accuses Former Officials Of Misconduct
description: Former executives of Kmart engaged in a broad pattern of abusive practices -- like cutting off payments to suppliers, dispensing generous loans to themselves and masking personal air travel as ''store visits'' -- in the months leading up to its filing for bankruptcy protection, an internal investigation has concluded.

title: Cassandras of the Card Table Are Often Disregarded
description: Bridge teachers are in one respect like the Greek prophetess Cassandra, whose prophecies of doom were always disregarded. Students of the game are told that if they play quickly to the first trick bad things are likely to happen, but they pay no attention.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: UTAH: JUDGE VACATES DEATH SENTENCE The death sentence for the state's longest-serving death-row inmate was vacated when a judge ruled that the defense for the inmate, Elroy Tillman, left, was denied access to important evidence in his murder trial in 1983. The ruling by Judge Leslie Lewis of the Third District Court provides for a new sentencing hearing for Mr. Tillman, 67. He was sentenced to death for the bludgeoning murder of Mark Schoenfeld in 1982. Previously undisclosed files raised questions about the testimony from a trial witness. In her ruling, Judge Lewis said that the evidence would not have changed the verdict, but that it might have indicated that Mr. Tillman was not solely responsible. That may have changed the sentencing, she added.   (AP)

title: International Briefs | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Falls
description: Brazil's unemployment rate fell slightly to 10.5 percent in December, slightly below 2002's annual average of 11.7 percent, the government said. Using new methodology that lowers the minimum age of potential workers from 15 to 10 years of age and broadens the geographical area researched, the jobless rate in November was 10.9 percent, according to the government statistics institute. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the legal aftermath of a bombing error that killed Canadians in Afghanistan referred incorrectly in some copies to the procedure over which Col. Patrick M. Rosenow, a military judge, presided. It was a hearing to determine whether two Air National Guard pilots should face court-martial; it was not itself a trial or a court-martial.

title: Super Bowl Reprises Role In Lobbying
description: The campaign arm for House Republicans is planning a major fund-raising event at the Super Bowl, but other political groups say logistics and the new campaign finance law are complicating their efforts to cash in at what has historically been a premier venue for seeking contributions.

title: Friendly Hosts, Effective Lobbyists
description: Nancy Victory's lobbyist friends representing wireless phone companies threw her a party in 2001 when she was named the Bush administration's top telecommunications policy maker at the Commerce Department. The Associated Press reported this week that it took place only 10 days before Ms. Victory urged the Federal Communications Commission to repeal restrictions on how much airwave spectrum wireless companies could control in a single market.

title: Sports of The Times; Upshaw Has Directed Union Long Enough
description: In five months, Gene Upshaw will celebrate his 20th anniversary as executive director of the National Football League Players Association.

title: Doris Fisher, 87, Songwriter For Films and Ella Fitzgerald
description: Doris Fisher, a songwriter whose lighthearted, sentimental tunes became hits for the Ink Spots, Ella Fitzgerald and the Mills Brothers in the 1930's and 40's, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 87.

title: Agnelli's Brother to Steer Fiat and Holdings
description: The direction of the embattled Fiat conglomerate took an abrupt turn today with the death of the company's patriarch, Giovanni Agnelli, potentially opening the door to faster and more sweeping change at the company, especially for its floundering auto business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, NETTIE
description: ROSENTHAL-Nettie, 85. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Mark and Elly. Loving grandmother of Joshua and Lindsay. For information: Bloomfield-Cooper, 800-247-5235.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, DONALD
description: ROSS-Donald. On January 21, 2003, in NYC. Survived by two nephews, Thomas Pohlman and Douglas Herman, and sister Sandra Ross Herman. Service Tuesday noon, St. James Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street.

title: U.N. and U.S. Say Key Data Are Still Missing From Iraqis
description: Iraq has failed to provide United Nations weapons inspectors with new information they had requested to fill in missing pieces of a crucial weapons declaration, United Nations and American officials said today.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Nebraska: U.S. Ends Case Against Meatpacker
description: The Agriculture Department reached a settlement with a meatpacker in Omaha, Nebraska Beef, that ends the effort to close the company because of repeated violations of food safety rules. The case was spurred by the determination that Nebraska Beef supplied hamburger contaminated with E. coli bacteria last year. The United States attorney, Michael G. Heavican, refused to give details of the accord, which led a federal court in Omaha to dismiss the case. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: International Briefs | Asia: Japan: Stock Loss At Bank
description: The Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company said losses on its stockholdings grew 64 percent in the October-December quarter. The bank, the sixth largest in Japan, said it had paper losses of 193.6 billion yen ($1.6 billion). The Nikkei 225 fell 6.4 percent in the quarter. Sumitomo Trust and other Japanese banks are trying to sell their stockholdings to reduce their exposure to risky assets. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Rowland to Cut Jobs and Close Offices in Motor Vehicles and Labor
description: After initiating two painful rounds of layoffs earlier this month, Gov. John G. Rowland's administration said today that it also plans to close six Department of Motor Vehicles offices and four Department of Labor offices by the end of February.

title: No Love Lost
description: National Football League players rated Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium as the worst playing surface this season, according to a poll conducted by the players union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESFOR, SIDNEY
description: DESFOR-Sidney. On January 23, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Harriet. Loving father of the late Nanette. Cherished grandfather of Brian and Robin and great grandfather of Nina. Dear brother and devoted uncle. Graveside service Sunday, 11 AM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

description: Federal Pension Agency Said to Disclose Big Deficit

description: BASEBALL

title: Curbing Pentagon Snoopers
description: The Senate took an important first step Thursday in reining in the Total Information Awareness Program, a wide-ranging Pentagon monitoring scheme that could threaten the civil liberties of law-abiding Americans. Now the House must complete the job by agreeing to the Senate's language when the omnibus appropriations bill the amendment is attached to goes to conference, probably next week.

title: LIQUID AUDIO SETTLEMENT ALLOWS DIVIDEND PAYMENT
description: Liquid Audio Inc., a money-losing Internet music distributor, said it would pay a $58 million dividend to investors after settling a legal challenge by a unit of Bertelsmann. The unit, BeMusic Inc., objected to the $2.50-a-share dividend, claiming it would leave Liquid Audio unable to pay its share of damages and court costs in a patent infringement suit. Liquid Audio said its settlement with BeMusic includes a $7 million reserve to cover costs of the patent suit. The company, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., is selling assets as it moves to dissolve. It said it sold its digital music fulfillment business to Geneva Music for $3.2 million.

title: QUEST DIAGNOSTICS REDUCES ITS PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: Shares of Quest Diagnostics Inc., a medical laboratory, fell 9.4 percent yesterday after the company said first-quarter profit would be lower than analysts had expected. Quest said its first-quarter profit, excluding costs related to the planned acquisition of the Unilab Corporation, will be 82 cents to 87 cents a share, lower than the 91-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Stock in Quest, which is based in Teterboro, N.J., fell $5.60, or 9 percent, to $54.30 a share.

title: In Iraqi No-Flight Zones, 12 Years of Containment May End in Bombardment
description: Through a long season of undeclared war, America's pilots have spent so much time in the skies over Iraq that some of them have passed most of their careers there.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Jan. 14 with an article about Alzheimer's disease misstated the chance that a person would have two variants of a protein known as Apo E. People may have Apo E4, a variant that may increase risk of the disease, or Apo E3, which does not, or a combination; it is not just one or the other.

title: U.S. MAY NOT PRESS U.N. FOR A DECISION ON IRAQ FOR WEEKS
description: Seeking ways to defuse tensions with longtime European allies, Bush administration officials said today that they were considering a delay of possibly several weeks before pressing the United Nations for a decision about Iraq's compliance with Security Council resolutions.

title: In Performance
description: THEATER

title: Brazilian Leader Vows He Will Plead for the Poor in Davos
description: Urging the rich world to make peace not war, President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva pledged today to champion the cause of all poor countries when he addresses the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, this weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, ELIZABETH PARSONS
description: WARNER-Elizabeth Parsons in Brunswick, ME, January 23rd. Age 93. Author and resident of Brunswick and Vinalhaven, ME. Mother of Mark Warner of Newcastle, ME., and Lucy Kuemmerle of New York. Memorial contributions to Ivan Calderwood Homestead, Vinalhaven, ME. 04863.

title: National Briefing | Washington: F.T.C. Sues Weight-Loss Company
description: The Federal Trade Commission sued the marketer of a weight-loss product for what it called false advertising. The agency said the company, Slim Down Solution, of Boca Raton, Fla., and its partners ran infomercials saying the product would cause consumers to lose 10 pounds and two inches in 30 days without diets or exercising. The suit seeks refunds and an injunction against similar advertising. A lawyer for the company declined to comment.

title: Balanchinesque and Beyond
description: With each new dance, Christopher Wheeldon takes his audiences into a different room in the vast mansion inhabited by classical ballet. Mr. Wheeldon's ''Mercurial Manoeuvres,'' performed by the New York City Ballet last Saturday night at the New York State Theater, is a playful, buoyant group work that is elegantly designed and includes a duet that has all the hushed exalted beauty of the second-act pas de deux in George Balanchine's ''Midsummer Night's Dream.''

title: Council Says M.T.A. Can Put Off Fare Increase
description: The City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, said yesterday that financial statements from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority appeared to show that it had several hundred million dollars in surplus money that could be used to fill its projected budget gap and defer a fare increase for at least another year.

title: Schwab Hopes to Lure Clients With a $95 Financial Checkup
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, locked in a battle with other brokerage firms for investors' shrinking assets, is preparing to offer a new deal to lure people in for a financial checkup.

title: Gun Tests Said to Bolster Sniper Case Against Two
description: Ballistics tests on a handgun linked to the suspects in the Washington-area sniper attacks have now established that it was used to kill a woman in Alabama and wound two people in Maryland before the serial shootings by rifle fire began in this vicinity in October, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATES, STEPHEN
description: KATES-Stephen. The Violoncello Society of New York mourns the loss of our past president. He was an eloquent musician and teacher. His sense of humor, wit and zest for life was an inspiration.

title: Ex-I.N.S. Inspector Convicted of Fraud
description: A former federal immigration inspector was convicted yesterday of tax evasion and impersonating a federal official in a scheme that involved swindling Chinese immigrants by promising to help them bring their relatives to this country from China.

title: George Haimsohn, 77, Dies; a Writer of 'Dames at Sea'
description: George Haimsohn, who co-wrote the book and lyrics for ''Dames at Sea,'' a musical that has leavened summer stock and college repertories ever since its Off Broadway debut in 1968, died on Jan. 17 in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERENBAUM, RHEA
description: BERENBAUM-Rhea, 92. Of Aventura, Florida (formerly of Kew Gardens, NY.) Beloved wife of the late Saul Berenbaum. Cherished mother of Susan and Uri Mingelgrin, Michael and Melissa Berenbaum. Adored grandmother of David and Miriam, Dan and Hila Mingelgrin, Rabbi Ilana and Tal Grinblat, Lev, Joshua, and Mira Berenbaum and revered greatgrandmother of Shira, Maia and Karen Mingelgrin. Loving sister of Esther Miller and Max Kass. Shiva in Florida.

title: Diabetes Rate Has Doubled, City Reports
description: New York City is facing an epidemic of diabetes, health officials said yesterday, pointing to new figures showing that nearly 8 percent of adults in the city have the disease, double the rate of eight years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSORE, SUSANNE
description: TESSORE-Susanne, 71, on January 23rd, 2003. Beloved friend of many. She will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENDE, NATHAN
description: ENDE-Nathan. On January 18, 2003 at age 94. He is survived by Vera, his beloved wife of 63 years, his son Eric and daughter-in-law Karen and grandchildren Duncan, Elena and Scott. A quiet man, with a warm sense of humor, he was a most generous and devoted husband and father. He was dearly loved by his family and friends. An Attorney of the highest ethical standards and with a strong social conscience, he gave generously to a wide variety of organizations. He was a graduate of New York University and NYU Law School and practiced law in Manhattan for over 60 years. He was a Founder and served as Chairman of the Board of the NYU Club and was a member of the Town Hall Board of Trustees. He was an active supporter for many years of the NYU Alumni Federation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Trying For A Government
description: Politicians began the process of cobbling together a coalition government after Wednesday's general election, the closest in years. The conservative Christian Democrat Alliance ended with 44 seats in the 150-seat Parliament, just two more seats than the social democrat Labor Party. The uncommonly high turnout of 80 percent showed how much voters cared in this second election in less than a year. But unless the two main parties team up, reaching a stable government may take some negotiating among the biggest of the 11 parties that ran. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Hungary: Less Support For Europe
description: Hungarians are having second thoughts about their country's plans to join the European Union next year, a new poll shows. Among 1,500 eligible voters, support for joining the union fell to 56 percent from 67 percent in October, according to a poll by the Szonda Ipsos agency. Those who thought that joining the union would be good for Hungary fell to 45 percent from 62 percent. Nearly all of the 10 Eastern and Southern European countries that received invitations to join the Union in December are expected to hold referendums on membership this year. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The audience is never wrong. They have a huge appetite for this and we've got a responsibility to satisfy that appetite.''

title: Eddying Across the Psyche With Graham and Jung
description: At times in recent years, the Martha Graham Dance Company has performed as if it had had greatness thrust upon it. Dancers of an entirely different era and sensibility seemed intent on producing great art or taking on the mantles of those who had come before. Now, as shown on Wednesday in the second performance in a two-week season at the Joyce Theater, the company is simply dancing, and the results are exciting and heartwarming. The Graham troupe has stepped into the 21st century.

title: Be Patient With North, Seoul's Kim Urges the U.S.
description: Amid a flurry of diplomatic maneuvers over North Korea's nuclear weapons program, President Kim Dae Jung, the retiring lion of South Korean politics, advised the United States today to try patience and respect in dealing with the North.

title: An International Right to Know
description: In 1984, 40 tons of lethal gas leaked from a Union Carbide plant in Bhopal, India. Thousands of people were killed. The Bhopal disaster led Congress to pass a law requiring companies to disclose chemical emissions. But even though Bhopal was an overseas disaster, the law it inspired applies only in the United States. Dangerous pollutants are just one aspect of corporate behavior that can be hidden abroad. Companies should have to make public information about overseas activities that would be prohibited or subject to disclosure laws at home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, BERNARD
description: GORMAN-Bernard. Loving and dedicated husband of Dorothy. Loving father of the late Larry; Ira and Barry. A man who always put the needs of his family and friends first. Bernard, who loved life, and would not quit, who believed in fighting to the end, lost his battle with cancer, but died of a heart attack. He will always be missed but not forgotten. Services 11 AM, graveside, Sunday, January 26, 2003. For information contact Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 516 295-3100.

title: Weapons Producers Report Strong Increases in Sales
description: With war talk in the air and the United States increasing its military budget, the nation's largest weapons makers reported strong sales yesterday for the quarter and the year.

title: Smallpox Inoculations Begin With 4 Connecticut Doctors
description: The government's ambitious plans to vaccinate 500,000 civilian health care workers against smallpox got under way yesterday as Connecticut became the first state to inoculate volunteers.

title: Article 2003012593223263029 -- No Title
description: NORTH

title: Penguin Group Hires Publisher Fired by Rival
description: Ann Godoff, the influential book publisher who was fired last week by the Random House division of Bertelsmann, has agreed to join its largest competitor, the Penguin Group of Pearson, people involved in the talks said last night.

title: Powell Urges Venezuelans To Embrace Carter's Ideas
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell strongly urged the Venezuelan government and its opposition today to accept one of the two proposals offered by former President Jimmy Carter to end the 54-day-old strike that has filled Venezuela's streets with protesters, shut down businesses and paralyzed its oil industry.

title: A Trans-Atlantic Rift Over Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: International Briefs | Europe: Britain: Weak Year For Economy
description: The British economy grew at an annual rate of 2.2 percent in the last three months of 2002 as manufacturing production decreased, new data showed, compared with the third quarter's 2.1 percent pace. For all of 2002, the economy grew 1.7 percent, the slowest annual growth since 1992 but slightly above the government's forecast. The chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, has forecast that the economy will grow 2.5 to 3 percent this year.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Interior Dept. To Set Up Manatee Zones
description: The Interior Department agreed to establish new protected zones for manatees in three regions where collisions with boats have killed increasing numbers of the sea cows. The Fish and Wildlife Service negotiated an accord with a coalition of environmental groups that had sued over prolonged delays in establishing areas where boats would be banned or required to slow down. The new areas, to be set up by July, will include parts of the St. John's and Caloosahatchee Rivers. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Tax Breaks for S.U.V.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Overseer of Abuse Plan Lauds Boston
description: The head of a new office that is monitoring how well Roman Catholic dioceses adhere to sexual abuse guidelines praised the Boston archdiocese's efforts today to care for victims of sexual abuse.

title: Sunday in the Park With Christo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGULIS, MARTHA
description: MARGULIS-Martha. Martha Margulis, accomplished artist, died Friday after a brief illness. She is survived by her husband Melvin and three daughters Caryn, Shari and Beth and by her sister and four grandchildren. Memorial service Sunday, 11:00 AM at Ballard-Durand, White Plains, NY. Donations can be made to the NY State College of Optometry, NYC.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Turning Out A Red Light
description: The Minister of Women's Affairs, Mu Sochua, said the police had shut down one of the seediest landmarks of Phnom Penh, a brothel district in Svay Pak village commonly known, by its distance from the capital, as Kilometer 11. A warren of dirt alleys patrolled by thugs and touts, it emerged in the 1990's to serve the desires of United Nations peacekeepers. Many women who work there were trafficked from Vietnam, and many are under age. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: For Jets, Preseason Will Begin In Japan
description: The Jets will open their exhibition season in Japan next August against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in the American Bowl, National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue announced today. The Washington Redskins and the San Francisco 49ers played in the game this season.

title: International Briefs | Europe: Germany: Porsche's Profit Rises
description: The sports car maker Porsche said it expected to post a 14 percent increase in profit for the first half of its fiscal year. In preliminary results for the period, which ends Jan. 31, Porsche said it would post earnings of 101.7 million euros ($110.2 million), and a 19.6 percent increase in sales, to 2.2 billion euros. At the annual shareholders' meeting, the chief executive, Wendelin Wiedeking, said he expected pretax profit and sales for the full year to continue growing but said that a war in Iraq would have a serious effect on the company's business. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Exit Havel, to Muted Applause From Czechs
description: Some days ago, student pranksters scaled a scaffolding at Prague Castle and, by covering the left half of an immense red neon heart hung as a kind of playful homage to President Vaclav Havel, transformed it into a giant and highly visible question mark.

title: Ex-Legislator Has Costs Of Travel Questioned
description: Former Assemblywoman Gloria Davis, who pleaded guilty to accepting bribes earlier this month, received thousands of dollars in reimbursements for travel to the capital during a period when she said she was accepting free transportation from a state contractor, according to records released by the State Assembly yesterday.

title: Few Viewers Object as Unbleeped Bleep Words Spread on Network TV
description: Last Sunday was a banner day for obscenity on network television.

title: Justices Take Public Housing Trespass Case
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutional limits of a city's discretion to close a public housing project's streets and sidewalks to nonresidents.

title: Queens Boy, 17, Is Charged In Threat That Shut Schools
description: A 17-year-old boy from Queens was arrested yesterday and charged with making threats in an Internet chat room that he planned a Columbine-type shooting spree in a New York school, the police said. The comments made in the chat room, which put schools statewide in a state of alarm and ''lock down'' on Thursday, are considered to be a terrorist threat.

title: Parking Dispute in Buffalo Ends in 2 Deaths
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 25  A dispute over parking in a normally tranquil residential neighborhood ended in a killing and a suicide on Thursday, the police said.

Dear motherin-law of Richard Davison and Dr. Carroll Weinberg. Devoted sister of the late Fannie Zinberg, Minnie Straus, Celia Feingold, Abe Green and Sam Greenberg. Interment Oheb Shalom Memorial Park, Baltimore, MD. Please omit flowers. In mourning at her late residence, Baltimore, MD.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: FRANCE: NEW TESTS FOR FREED COLLABORATOR Maurice Papon, the former official convicted of collaborating with the Nazis, will undergo new medical tests after complaints that he was released from jail on the basis of reports that exaggerated his health problems. Justice Minister Dominique Perben ordered the appointment of three new experts to establish whether Mr. Papon, who is 92 and is living at his home east of Paris, is as ill as his lawyers say. He was set free in September after serving 3 years of a 10-year term for helping to organize the deportation of more than 1,500 Jews from Bordeaux during World War II.    (Agence France-Presse)

title: Identity Theft Tied to Ring That Included Store Workers
description: Cashiers and clerks at pharmacies, shoe stores and other retail businesses in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut stole credit card numbers from thousands of shoppers as part of a mob-connected identity-theft ring, the authorities said yesterday.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: F.T.C. SUES WEIGHT-LOSS COMPANY The Federal Trade Commission sued the marketer of a weight-loss product for what it called false advertising. The agency said the company, Slim Down Solution, of Boca Raton, Fla., and its partners ran infomercials saying the product would cause consumers to lose 10 pounds and two inches in 30 days without diets or exercising. The suit seeks refunds and an injunction against similar advertising. A lawyer for the company declined to comment.   (NYT)

title: Medicare Officials Order End to Instructive Services
description: Running short of money, Medicare officials have ordered immediate cuts in a wide range of services that provide information, advice and assistance to Medicare beneficiaries.

title: The Frustrations of Inspections
description: After years of Iraqi deceit, United Nations inspections now feel both frustrating and familiar. ''This looks like the rerun of a bad movie,'' President Bush said last week. In fact, that movie has been running for longer than he realizes. Nuclear weapons inspections are almost always difficult -- even if the country being inspected is a friend of the United States.

title: Italians Mourn the Man Who 'Created Work' and 'Gave Us Jobs'
description: Domenica Zaccuri came here in 1963 to what was then a booming industrial town, a young and hopeful bride in search of a future. Today, she stood at Gate 4 of the huge Fiat factory at Mirafiore, outside town, weeping for the man who gave it to them.

description: ROSEN-I. Jules. Beloved husband of the late Phyllis. Devoted father of Sherry Fountain and Marcia Anderson. Dear father-in-law of Ed Anderson. Proud grandfather of Cindy, Scott and Paul. Great grandfather of Rebecca and Zachary. Dear brother of Jack Rosen and the late Betty Friedland. Dear uncle of Gloria, Michael, Judy and the late Zena. Service Sunday, 2:15PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y. title: MONEY-LOSING AMERICAN ELECTRIC CUTS DIVIDEND
description: The American Electric Power Company, which reported a fourth-quarter loss of $837 million yesterday, said it would cut its dividend to preserve cash. The company also said it had eliminated 1,300 jobs in the quarter. The 42 percent dividend reduction will save $340 million a year, American Electric said. The company will also shed assets and may sell stock to reduce debt of $13 billion. American Electric, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, said it lost $124 million from its nonutility businesses in the quarter. The $837 million loss, or $2.47 a share, was in contrast to net income of $52 million, or 16 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 31 percent, to $3.8 billion.

title: Craig Kelly, 36; Helped Refine Snowboarding as Sport and Art
description: Craig Kelly, who played a major role in making snowboarding a modern-day sport and then a recreational outlet, died on Monday in an avalanche that killed seven skiers and snowboarders near Revelstoke, British Columbia. He was 36 and lived in Nelson, British Columbia.

title: Why Bush Won't Wait
description: President Bush says he has not yet decided whether to go to war with Iraq, but this week the signs were that he had all but given up on peace. Administration hawks, who had been worrying that American resolve would dissipate during a prolonged game of inspection cat-and-mouse, are suddenly being sent forth to proclaim the weapons hunt a farce. State Department officials, who thought they had maneuvered us off the short road to war, seem resigned to the fact that they have probably failed.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: JAPAN: CULT SURVEILLANCE EXTENDED A public security commission extended by three years its close surveillance of Aum Shinrikyo, the cult responsible for a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway in 1995, citing the risk that it may try to commit further massacres. The decision will allow security officials and the police to inspect cult sites and force it to report the names, addresses and other information of its followers every three months. "It is determined that there is danger of the organization committing indiscriminate mass murder," said a secretary for the Public Security Examination Commission. The gas attack killed 12 people and sickened thousands.    Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Don't Pester Europe on Genetically Modified Food
description: The Bush administration recently announced that it is considering taking action against the European Union because of its ban on imports of genetically modified foods. It's a profoundly bad idea.

title: Chairman Resigns From E*Trade; His Big Pay Package Angered Investors
description: Christos M. Cotsakos, the flamboyant chairman of the E*Trade Group whose huge pay packages have angered investors, resigned suddenly yesterday.

title: Democrats Seek A Tax Rebate In Growth Plan
description: Senate Democrats took on the administration's tax cut plan in earnest today with the release of a sharply different economic stimulus proposal, calling for a $300-a-person rebate check and $40 billion in aid to states and cities.

title: Mattel Wins Damages in Case
description: Mattel Inc., the world's largest toymaker, won $1.9 million in damages today when a jury found that a rival, Safety 1st, had infringed patents for portable bassinets and baby bouncers.

title: Unusual Factors Converge In Case Against War Pilots
description: Throughout the nine-day hearing here into whether two F-16 pilots should face a court-martial for bombing and killing four Canadian soldiers in Afghanistan last year, one question loomed: Why should these men be the first Air Force pilots to face homicide charges for an accidental attack in wartime?

title: MEDSOURCE STOCK PLUNGES AFTER IT LOWERS FORECAST
description: Shares of MedSource Technologies Inc., a medical instruments maker that held a public stock offering in March, lost almost half their value after the company cut its 2003 profit forecast because of lower sales. The stock fell $2.54, or 47 percent, to $2.91 a share. Profit for the fiscal year, excluding certain reorganization costs, is expected to be 18 cents to 22 cents a share, lower than its earlier estimate of 40 cents to 42 cents. Revenue will be $170 million to $174 million, down from $180 million to $184 million. MedSource said it would have reorganization costs of $25 million to $35 million before taxes through the end of fiscal 2006. The company, which is based in Minneapolis, will disclose net income and more details when it reports third-quarter results in April, its chief financial officer, William Kullback, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, HARRIET
description: NELSON-Harriet, age 68. A resident of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Woodmere, NY, passed away on Thursday, January 23, 2003, of pancreatic cancer. Harriet is survived by her beloved family which includes her husband Norton David Nelson, daughters Hillary (Peter Beckmann) Nelson, Elizabeth (Don) Scheiber, and Ilene Nelson, and grandchildren Max, Alexandra, Zoe, Jasper and Ryan. Harriet is also survived by her parents Martin and Minerva Schwartz of Ft. Lee, NJ, and sister Meryl Schwartz. Services will be held on Sunday, January 27, in Boca Raton, FL. Contributions may be made in memory of Harriet to Hospice By the Sea, Boca Raton, FL.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TODAY'S MAN INC., Moorestown, N.J., an operator of men's clothing stores, said it would lay off 56 workers at its corporate headquarters to cut costs while several of the laid-off executives pursue a possible investment in the company.

description: Since CBS's ''Survivor'' rushed to the top of the Nielsen ratings three years ago, network executives have known that reality shows can be enormously popular. This week convinced them that the shows will drastically alter the economics of the business itself.

title: A Slam to Call Her Own

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Profiling Conviction For Officer
description: A former police officer in West Memphis, E. Anthony Bradley, was convicted in Federal District Court in Little Rock of conspiracy to violate the civil rights of drivers stopped on Interstate 40 by illegally confiscating their money and of skimming from cash seized from drug suspects. Mr. Bradley faces up to 10 years in prison. A second former West Memphis officer, Joseph Applegate, was acquitted of similar charges. The F.B.I. began investigating after complaints that officers were unfairly profiling Hispanic drivers for traffic stops in eastern Arkansas. Two other former officers are to be tried later. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Fans Cheer For Jordan Finale In Chicago
description: His Airness said goodbye tonight. And on a frosted winter night, thousands poured into the sold-out United Center for a roaring farewell to Michael Jordan.

title: German Minister Says Al Qaeda Threat Is as Strong Now as Before Sept. 11
description: Germany's interior minister said today that Al Qaeda posed as great a global threat now as it did before the Sept. 11 attacks and that a war with Iraq could cause unrest and further terrorist attacks throughout Europe.

title: In Land of Vacant Apartments, a Renter's Market
description: Erik C. Strandberg and Lisa Sjostedt began their search for a Manhattan apartment last year with low expectations: they figured they would end up paying a fortune for a dark and dingy one-bedroom.

title: As Airlines' Fortunes Decline, So Do Delays in Flights at La Guardia
description: Two years ago, takeoffs and landings at La Guardia Airport were so badly backed up that the federal government said the delays there caused a quarter of all the nation's air traffic delays, and it stepped in to ration the right to land there. Now, airline traffic has fallen off so sharply that the airport is operating far below capacity, and on some days there are no delays at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EATON, JOHN MCCURDY
description: EATON-John McCurdy. Died on January 20, after a long illness. Son of Justine Allen Eaton and the late Fredrick M. Eaton. Brother of Frederick A. Eaton and Justine E. Auchincloss. Uncle of ten nephews and nieces. Memorial service at 10:30 AM, Thursday, January 30, St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Ave at 71st Street, New York City.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: A Fast 30 Years of Webern
description: Nearly 60 years have passed since Anton Webern died -- almost a century since he wrote his most revolutionary works -- and still his music seems in need of special treatment in the concert hall. This week Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic are providing just that. By devoting half the program to Webern, the orchestra can show his creative journey from the tone poem ''In the Summer Wind,'' which he wrote at 20, through the weighty Passacaglia (Op.1) and Six Pieces (Op. 6) of just a few years later to the Concerto for Nine Instruments (Op. 24) -- a journey of 30 years in fewer than 30 minutes.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page picture caption yesterday about the legal aftermath of a bombing error that killed Canadians in Afghanistan referred incorrectly in some copies to the procedure over which Col. Patrick M. Rosenow, a military judge, presided. It was a hearing to determine whether two Air National Guard pilots should face court-martial; it was not itself a trial or a court-martial.

title: Governor Pataki's Missing List
description: It is well known that the clock ticks at a different speed in Albany, where New York State's business always takes longer than is necessary. That habitual torpor, however, does not excuse Gov. George Pataki's failure to apply in a timely manner for federal funds designed to help make New York City more secure after Sept. 11. The governor has missed two deadlines and caused anxiety among city and state officials who are concerned that Washington may sense a lack of urgency, when there is much to be urgent about.

title: Ashcroft Soaks Up a World of Complaints
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft came here today to explain to the world's rich, powerful and just plain pushy the Bush administration's tactics in its campaign against terror. In the process, he faced a barrage of questions, not all of them from the usual suspects.

description: This 700-ton Coast Guard icebreaker set out just after sunrise, with the temperature hovering between 2 and 3 degrees and a few stars still visible in the sky above the Catskill Mountains.

title: In a Remote Corner, an Afghan Army Evolves From Fantasy to Slightly Ragged Reality
description: It is a sight seen nowhere else in Afghanistan: two lines of Afghan soldiers patrolling either side of the street of the main bazaar, past turbaned tribesmen and shopkeepers, and trailing a gaggle of children.

title: A Ruling The G.O.P. Loves To Hate
description: Thirty years after Roe v. Wade, many wonder how long the decision can survive when the Republican Party controls all of the branches of government. Republicans may well chip away at Roe v. Wade. But if they overturn it, they do so at their peril.

title: Schuettler Defeats Tired, Injured Roddick
description: Two young American tennis stars down, one much bigger American star to go.

title: Florida Official Criticized Amid Familiar Election Chaos
description: A former fashion model now in charge of the Broward County elections office, Miriam M. Oliphant is used to being in the spotlight. What she had not counted on was being under a microscope after overseeing two troubled elections, running up a budget deficit and reviving memories of the 2000 election fiasco in Florida.

title: Head of Inquiry On Olympic Ethics Has Link to Ward
description: Kenneth W. Duberstein, the chairman of the United States Olympic Committee's ethics panel, which exonerated the organization's chief executive, Lloyd Ward, of conflict of interest charges, has been paid $516,000 since 1999 as a lobbyist for General Motors, on whose board Ward serves.

title: International Briefs | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Share Repurchase
description: South Korea's leading mobile telephone service provider, SK Telecom, said it planned to buy back 3 percent of its shares, valued at more than $400 million. The plan was announced after SK's share price fell 21 percent in three days. At the same time, SK said it would reduce plant investment, which it had anticipated would exceed $2 billion this year. The company said the decision reflected ''growing investor concerns over profitability and shareholder dividends.'' Don Kirk (NYT)

title: The Legs Are Sturdy. The Nerves? Hmmm.
description: The radio reporter was trying to pose a deferential question to Tampa Bay kicker Martin Gramatica in the interview room Thursday. But as the journalist spoke more about the powerful leg of Oakland kicker Sebastian Janikowski, Gramatica folded his arms tighter and tighter against his chest.

title: Fatal Crash Is Linked To Slick Road With No Light
description: Icy road conditions and the failure of a mile-long string of highway lights were crucial factors in a chain-reaction crash last week on Interstate 95 in Fairfield, Conn., that killed four Yale students, federal and state investigators said today.

description: SOWINSKI-Stephen L., M.D. The Mount Sinai Hospital of Queens is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Stephen Sowinski on January 15, 2003. A valued member of our medical staff since 1986, he was a true advocate for patients, nurses and colleagues. Hirschfeld, who drew his inimitable caricatures of people in the performing arts for more than 75 years, died on Monday at 99.

title: Introduction
description: It was difficult to muster sympathy for the teenagers raising families in prison and on welfare, scores said, because they were so distracted by the repeated unplanned pregnancies. And over-the-counter remedies can give you a headache? What's next? readers asked.

title: A Car Man Who's Stuck in Drive
description: AS a young Toyota manager in Japan in the mid-70's, Fujio Cho was assigned to learn the Toyota Production System, which stresses efficient manufacturing methods, from its intimidating creator, Taichi Ohno. One day, Mr. Cho demonstrated to Dr. Ohno how he had shrunk inventories sharply, accomplishing what Mr. Cho had been taught was one of the system's primary tenets.

description: Special Teams

title: No Way To Run A Railroad, They Say
description: If it looks like a railroad and acts like a railroad, then gosh darn it, it is a railroad. That is what Staten Island Borough President James P. Molinaro says about the 12-mile-long Staten Island Railway, the borough's only train line. Stop treating it like a subway line, he says, and merge it with Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Traveling Into Country Constructed by the Eye
description: IT begins with roads. A white road scribbles through dark fields. A car flashes past a dead, coiled rattlesnake. A railroad bed like a newly stitched wound cuts the landscape. A banana peel and half a sandwich strewn on the seat are reflected in the windshield, where they hover like a double exposure over the empty highway and the dramatic scenery -- an image that captures both the tedium and exhilaration of a cross-country drive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANSCOMBE, ROBERT F.
description: BRANSCOMBE - Robert F. On January 21, 2003. Lifelong member of the West Side Tennis Club. Beloved husband of the late Jean M. Devoted father of Peter and John and father-in-law of Sarah Judd and Ana. Cherished grandfather of Claire and Julia. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Paying to Fix Radiator Leak in Co-op
description: Q. I own a co-op in Manhattan. A radiator in my apartment is partially in the wall inside an enclosure. Recently, it was discovered that either the radiator itself or the piping it is connected to started to leak, causing some damage in the apartment downstairs. The co-op board said that according to its reading of the proprietary lease, I am responsible for the repair bill. The lease provides, however, that a shareholder's responsibility ''shall not include gas, steam, water or other pipes or conduits within the walls, ceilings or floors or air-conditioning equipment or heating equipment which is part of the standard building equipment.'' Wouldn't the radiators and their pipes be considered part of the standard building equipment and, therefore, the responsibility of the co-op? . . . Peter G. Puttre, Manhasset

description: SIEGLER-Gertrude. 97, died on January 25, 2003. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Ira and Eugenia Siegler and Claire and David Brook. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Finding the First Rungs On the Career Ladder
description: The job market for new college graduates was pretty tight last year, and it's not expected to improve significantly in 2003. But many big-name employers are still setting aside entry-level positions, a recent study shows.

title: Scrambling to Get Defibrillators in Place
description: EARLIER this month, deaths of two students in New York City schools -- a 16-year-old girl in Staten Island who had Down syndrome, and a 19-year-old student in the Bronx who collapsed during a basketball game -- focused attention on a new state law that requires all New York schools to have defibrillators. The devices are used to restore a normal heartbeat after a life-threatening arrhythmia; neither of the two city schools had them.

title: An Uneasy Resting Place

title: 'The Interpreter'

Like a block party, this place, with those dopey eight-year-olds who should be in school, and their single mothers sick of shouting, and the bored men at each table still not at work. Morning is full here. Everyone's in it together, a communal experience, this day, this life. It is not her life, though. She does not know this. She does not want this. She looks up, instead, at a huge sign for the breakfast special across the window. Not much mystery there, food is plenty. In those days we seldom published cookbooks at Random House, where I was editorial director, but I wanted to know how Alice made her bouillabaisse and hesitated to ask her directly. So over an anise souffl, Alice and I agreed on terms for what would become her classic ''Chez Panisse Menu Cookbook,'' which has been the sacred text of high-style American cooking ever since. title: Casting Out the Inner Buppie
description: The heroine of Benilde Little's ''Acting Out'' (Free Press, $23) has a problem, and it seems all too apparent what that problem is. When her real estate broker husband announces that he's leaving, Ina must figure out how to reconstruct a life that has come to revolve around car pools and the P.T.A. Initially, it's hard to empathize with her Buppie ennui. All Ina wants to do is ''go upstairs and get into my big, feathered bed, feel the smooth 380-thread-count sheets against my body,'' and that's before she reads about his new girlfriend in a gossip column. The revelation that she was once dedicated to photography, but gave it up when she married, suggests she'll go through a fairly straightforward process of reinvention. Soon, though, ''Acting Out'' loses its prefab momentum and Ina's journey becomes far less predictable. Little begins to really work the first-person voice, blurring time frames and verbal styles to evoke the inner world of a woman who has lost her core -- or, perhaps, never had one. In the novel's most arresting passages, Ina relates her lack of identity to her own family's history and the historical legacy of all African-Americans. Black people ''have to be somewhat self-defining, because accepting what the culture hands us is unacceptable,'' she muses. ''But some people can change the markers, change things around -- names, backgrounds and faces -- and fit into ruling society. . . . Simple as that, well, till you have to look in the mirror.'' Ina's journey may not look like much from the outside, but Little's expressive prose lends it substance. Etelka Lehoczky

Those maximum allowable yearly limits are 7,000 pounds of lead, 1,500 pounds of mercury, 78 pounds of arsenic, 200 pounds of cadmium and 100 pounds of chromium. As we know, even small amounts of lead-based paint when eaten by children can cause serious neurological problems. The lead emitted daily from the Covanta plant lands in playgrounds, schoolyards and backyards. Now we learn that we are needlessly being subjected to low levels of radiation as well.
