description: IN many ways, air travelers have become blas about flying on bankrupt airlines because so many in the United States have gone in and out of bankruptcy court since the early 1990's.

title: Come Back, New Economy
description: WHY ECONOMIES GROW

title: Big Brother Is Also Being Watched, With New Alarm
description: FOR 26 years the F.B.I. watched the artist Arnold Mesches. Federal agents took note of his illustrations for political journals, and even for Mad magazine. They watched him march for peace and disarmament and demonstrate against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's House Un-American Activities Committee. They were also, during this time, compiling an 800-page dossier on him.

title: Light, Like Music, Can Help Establish the Rhythm
description: LIGHT is a difficult medium to explain in words. It is difficult to talk about it while being unable to demonstrate it -- like talking about music while being unable to play a note. Light doesn't exist until it hits something, so the something that it hits is always perceived first, more strongly and more clearly than the light that is revealing it.

title: INSIDE
description: Agassi Wins in Australia

title: NEW LEGISLATIVE MAP ORDERED
description: In a decision seen as a victory for Republicans, a state appellate court ruled last week that all 40 legislative districts must be redrawn, and in time for the election next fall for State Senate and Assembly. The current legislative map was adopted after the 2000 census to make the population equal in each district. But Republicans said that it favored Democrats by putting more minority voters into suburban districts. Indeed, Democrats took control of the Assembly for the first time in a decade and split the Senate. Democrats plan to appeal the ruling to the New Jersey Supreme Court. George James

title: Booklet Offers Advice To Solo Travelers
description: Tips for those planning a trip by themselves are available in a new booklet by Sharon B. Wingler, author of a book on the same subject, ''Travel Alone & Love It.''

title: In an Area Filled With Sky, A Tower Clouds the View
description: In 1974, few people expected that Hell's Kitchen would become a developer's paradise. But to make sure, the city created the Clinton Special District to preserve the neighborhood's low-rise charm, not far from the fabled playground of the Jets and Sharks.

title: Both Hope and Doubt Greet School Desegregation Plan
description: Word that state officials had agreed on a four-year, roughly $245 million plan to further desegregate the city's schools ricocheted this week through the suburbs, where reaction among parents, educators and taxpayers ranged from enthusiasm to skepticism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UELAND, EGIL (JOHN)
description: UELAND-Egil (John) passed away in Norway, January 24, 2003. Much loved husband and dear close friend of Jill (Roth). Cherished father of Hannah and Tom. Caring grandfather, devoted brother of Ole. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Heart Association.

title: Bachelor No. 1 And the Birth Of Reality TV
description: AS the creator and host of ''The Gong Show,'' the late-70's phenomenon in which excruciatingly bad singers, dancers and novelty acts were hooted and gonged off the stage, Chuck Barris was at the height of his celebrity. In the imaginative film about his life, ''Confessions of a Dangerous Mind,'' he is strolling by a pool on the grounds of the Playboy mansion when a beautiful naked swimmer recognizes him. Swimming toward him, she looks up seductively and purrs: ''I think you're the most insidious, despicable force in entertainment today. How dare you subject the rest of the world to your loathsome views of humanity, to mock some poor lonely people who are just craving a little attention in their lives?''

title: Mixed Feelings Next Door to Venezuela's Strife
description: Jeremias Guerrero may not seem like a successful entrepreneur. He sleeps by the side of the road and awakens every morning at 3, covered in bug bites, to start the business of waving at passing cars with a rubber hose.

title: Good Japanese, but You Must Find It First
description: MIDORI, in Oyster Bay, is almost invisible, which makes discovering it especially exciting. Hidden away behind the spotless Green Wagon Market, Midori, at 267 Pine Hollow Road (516-922-8070), is one of Long Island's better Japanese eating places. Yet it is over a year old and few people have ever heard of it, much less eaten there. I circled the market twice without finding the door to the restaurant.

title: Inquiry Into Rap Label Asks if 'Gangsta' Is More Than Genre
description: Irving Lorenzo was born in Hollis, Queens, in 1971, the youngest of eight siblings who, 12 years later, pooled their money to buy the boy his first D.J. rig. ''D.J. Irv'' became a minor star in Queens before crossing the East River and establishing himself as a producer with a golden ear, a star maker at Murder Inc., a gritty boutique label under the legendary Def Jam records. One day, a rapper called him ''Gotti'' in homage to the former Mafia boss; he has gone by the name ever since.

title: Drug Sales Bring Huge Profits, And Scrutiny, to Cancer Doctors
description: Among cancer doctors, it is called the chemotherapy concession. At a time when overall spending on prescription drugs is soaring, cancer specialists are pocketing hundreds of millions of dollars each year by selling drugs to patients -- a practice that almost no other doctors follow.

title: Saroyan's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Hiring Brings Up a Harrowing Case That Won't Go Away
description: Andra Schwarz, who was recently hired as assistant to the press secretary for Staten Island's borough president, James P. Molinaro, did not meet the press last Thursday afternoon, even though a small troupe of reporters, photographers and cameramen were gathered outside her workplace at Borough Hall.

title: For the Mentally Ill, a Long Search for a Bed
description: SPARKS can fly when a grown son lives in his parents' home, but things were usually quiet around John and Terri Hamet's house in Lake Ronkonkoma -- as long as their son, Tom, now 22, took his medication for bipolar disorder.

title: Role Players Get To Play the Lead As St. John's Wins
description: St. John's seemingly insurmountable lead had evaporated today, and the Red Storm watched Virginia Tech's confidence rise with each possession. There were 7 minutes 25 seconds remaining, and the Hokies had their first lead since the opening minute. Normally, Marcus Hatten would take over for St. John's, because that is what great scorers and leaders do. But there was nothing normal about the minutes he had put in so far. He just didn't have it.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing on Page 41 of Arts & Leisure today misstates the time for a recital by the soprano Felicity Lott today in Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center. It is 5 p.m., not 8.

title: January 19-25
description: MEXICO QUAKE — A powerful earthquake rolled across central Mexico, killing 29 people in three states and unnerving millions in Mexico City. Twenty-six of the dead were in the small coastal state of Colima, where several thousand people lost their homes. Most of the dead lived in adobe buildings, and many were very poor, very old or very young, the officials said.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Winston Lockett, Georgia, May 1963

title: From Latin Food to Dcor, Fusion Is Theme
description: BAMBOLEO, a swank, semi-hip-looking restaurant in Glastonbury, is not only nuevo Latino but nuevo generic. Some of the architecture is bold and striking, but it doesn't hold together well, as if someone visited a couple of dozen model restaurants elsewhere in the country but couldn't synthesize all the information.

title: A Casino Opens On U.S. Side of Niagara
description: People in the Buffalo area who once had to cross the border to gamble in the Niagara Falls casino in Canada no longer have to make that trip. The 7,000-member Seneca Nation has opened a casino in the former Niagara Falls Convention and Civic Center in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: Sports of The Times; Democracy in Action in F.A. Cup
description: NO American could imagine a weekend team from upstate New York playing the Yankees in a serious knockout tournament -- in jam-packed Yankee Stadium.

title: St. Dolly And Her Flock
description: VISITORS to Chasing Rainbows, the museum devoted to Dolly Parton's life history at Dollywood, Ms. Parton's theme park here in her hometown, are greeted at the door by Thomasina Bicer, 52. ''Hi there! Would you like a rainbow?'' She pats a rainbow sticker on the visitor's lapel and smiles: ''Now you can chase your dreams, just like Dolly.''

title: How Consumer Culture Sets Up Its Young Ducks
description: INSECURE, increasingly affluent and conveniently malleable, teenagers are a marketer's dream. In her new book, ''Branded: The Buying and Selling of Teenagers'' (Perseus, $25), Alissa Quart delivers a broadside attack on the way that consumer goods companies relentlessly go after the teenage audience as well as the ''tweens,'' usually defined as 9- to 13-year-olds.

title: Reagan's Son
description: In December, George W. Bush had one of those turbulent spells that can cause a president nightmares about tumbling over the falls in a barrel. First he purged his economic team, the kind of housecleaning that tends to be taken as an admission of failed policies. He ordered a North Korean freighter arrested at sea, on the way to Yemen with a suspicious cargo of missiles, then sheepishly let it go on its way -- an amateurish misstep in his war on terror. The man he proudly put forth to head an investigation of America's vulnerability to terrorists abruptly declined the job because it would interfere with his consulting business. The party's leader in the newly recaptured Senate blundered into a career-ending display of insensitivity that peeled open the party's history of race-baiting.

title: Debate Over Iraq Raises Fears Of a Shrinking Role for NATO
description: Just two months ago, the 19 members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization vowed publicly to streamline the 54-year-old alliance into an institution ready and able to rise to the challenges of fighting terrorism and protecting against weapons of mass destruction.

title: Air Travel Under a More Watchful Eye
description: TRACEY WEISBERG was holding her 4-year-old son, Clayton, while her daughter, Margot, 5, tugged at her sleeve. But Mrs. Weisberg was distracted. While her husband, Martin, was confirming the family's seats at an airline ticket counter here, Mrs. Weisberg was watching a federal screener from the Transportation Security Administration methodically unpack one of the family suitcases.

title: Ahead of Re-election Run, Indonesia's President Is Chased by Corruption Complaints
description: Elaborately dressed dancers, with feathered crowns and gold silken robes, performed outside the home of President Megawati Sukarnoputri this week, in honor of her birthday.

title: U.S. Spy Plane Crashes in South Korea, Injuring 5
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 26  A United States spy plane crashed 30 miles south of here today, injuring the pilot and four Koreans on the ground.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Evening Hours column last Sunday about the International Women's Health Coalition dinner at the American Museum of Natural History on Jan. 16 misidentified the woman shown with George Soros. She was Maureen White, finance chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, not Ellen Chesler.

title: BENEFITS
description: For African-American Life

title: 'It Must've Been Something I Ate'
description: TORO, TORO, TORO Aft here, drive 'em aft," I shouted. "Call all hands! Man the capstan! Blood and thunder! Lower away . . . and after him!"

title: Men in Black? Try Silver-and-Black Pinstripes if It's Steinbrenner and Davis
description: The last time the Raiders played in the Super Bowl, 19 years ago, the game was in Tampa, Fla., and Al Davis, their owner, stayed at George Steinbrenner's hotel. It was an exciting time for the baseball man, who in his younger days served as an assistant coach of the Northwestern and Purdue football teams.

title: POSTINGS: Spring Opening Planned for $40 Million Building at SUNY in Stony Brook; A Showcase for Asian Culture
description: A $40 million building designed as a showcase for the art and cultures of Asia is to open this spring at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: January 19-25: INTERNATIONAL; KUWAIT KILLINGS
description: An American civilian defense contractor, Michael Rene Pouliot, 46, was killed and his co-worker, David John Caraway, 37, seriously wounded when a Kuwaiti opened fire on their car near Camp Doha, the United States military headquarters. It was the third such attack since the American military buildup began last fall. Hours later, Saudi border guards arrested Sami Mohammed Al-Mutairi, 25, whom the police identified as a government worker and Osama bin Laden sympathizer. Patrick E. Tyler

title: A Rich History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUDA, JOSEPH S.
description: BAUDA-Joseph S. Pharmacist. January 18, Buffalo, NY. The Pharmacist's Society of the State of New York mourns the death of the Honorary Past President and extends deepest sympathy to his wife Rose, daughters Beverly and Carol Bauda. Bauda was a Major in WWII, a volunteer and officer in numerous professional and civic organizations and recipient of many deserved awards.

title: Full Disclosure
description: A few weeks ago, a patient reported to the police that his psychiatrist confessed in the privacy of the consulting room that he planned to murder six people. And if that isn't bad enough, the Nassau County police also say that the doctor tried to enlist his patient's help, asking him to find chum (chopped bait) and a gun with a silencer, thereby making the paying customer an unwilling accomplice to something as grisly as the innermost portions of the id. The plot included killing a female patient who had become the psychiatrist's lover, according to the woman's lawyer. The doctor was arrested in a Home Depot parking lot; snap, he was handcuffed; snap snap, he was marched away and later charged with three counts of weapons possession by the Nassau County D.A.'s office, charges he denies. If the analysand has not yet found another therapist, he should, to help him deal with the trauma of his treatment.

title: The New Momentum In Orbiting Brazil
description: INVESTORS dread contagion in emerging markets. But barely four weeks into 2003, Brazil is showing that living close to a big debtor can be good for its neighbors' health.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Jan. 5 about the introduction of room service and other hotel-style amenities at White Plains Hospital gave an outdated name for the company that collaborated on the hospital's food service. It is Sodexho (formerly Sodexho-Marriott), no longer part of the Marriott Corporation.

title: The Black Maria: Take Note, Edison
description: Now in its 22nd year, the Black Maria (pronounced ma-RI-uh) Film and Video Festival is an independent nonprofit event that annually exhibits 50 new experimental, documentary, animation and narrative works. It is New Jersey's only Academy Award-qualifying film festival for shorts -- meaning that short films that win at the festival can be entered in competition for the Oscar.

title: Sharpton Rallies the Faithful, But From a Different Pulpit
description: The stained-glass windows were a little taller, the ceiling considerably higher and the sound system far more sophisticated, but other than that, the Rev. Al Sharpton's relocated rally yesterday morning was the same as ever.

title: Over-the-Counter Headache
description: Your article on the side effects and potential dangers of over-the-counter drugs was a good one; I believe that we need more such examination of our reliance on drugs as a first, not last, recourse for any and all complaints. I just found out, the hard way, that the steroids commonly used to treat asthma can cause serious cataracts.

title: Indulging a Guilty Pleasure?
description: DURING the late 19th century and through the first third or so of the 20th, pianists with a virtuosic bent routinely made keyboard transcriptions of works composed for other instruments. Actually, the tradition goes back much farther: the Bach prelude that opens Vladimir Ashkenazy's collection of Rachmaninoff transcriptions and short original works exists as the Sinfonia to the Cantata No. 29, the Prelude of the E major Partita for solo violin and part of a suite for solo lute.

title: The View/From New Haven; As a Business Sets Up, A Group Takes Steps To Preserve a Landmark
description: FOR decades, northbound travelers on Interstate 95 knew they had arrived in New Haven when they spotted the Pirelli building on the left-hand side. With its five-story upper tower improbably supported by two slender shafts -- like a piece of wedding cake on toothpicks -- the Marcel Breuer creation has become an odd if distinctive symbol of the Elm City, especially for those just passing through.

title: A Takeout Joint Takes on a New Guise
description: Mighty Joe to Go, the takeout spinoff of the Hartsdale restaurant Mighty Joe Young's, closed six months ago, but its owners have a new takeout idea.. Fuzzy Garcia's Fresh Mexican Grill is scheduled to open late this week in the same building, a converted gas station adorned with tin awnings and sconces, at 26 South Central Avenue. Nick Skeadas, a partner in Mighty Joe Young's, and Spiro Chagares, part owner of Arthur's Steaks and Seafood on City Island, are waiting for approval from the town of Greenburgh to install seating for 30, but there will be no table service. There will, however, be a retail area called the ''wall of flame,'' where 70 different bottled hot sauces will be available for sale.

title: Bill and Meriwether's Excellent Adventure
description: I SHOULD BE EXTREMELY HAPPY IN YOUR COMPANY

title: After Gaza City Raid, Israel Considers Occupation
description: GAZA CITY, Jan. 26  Two days before Israeli elections, Israel's defense minister said that the army was weighing a re-occupation of the Gaza Strip, hours after soldiers killed 12 Palestinians in the deepest raid into this densely populated city in more than two years of conflict.

title: Pern, Pinochet and Patience
description: Venezuela is in its worst political crisis since the establishment of its constitutional democracy in 1958. At stake is not only Hugo Chvez's presidency, but the ability of any democratic leader to govern in the future. Public opinion polls show that most Venezuelans want Mr. Chvez out of office. They have good reasons. Since Mr. Chvez's election in 1998, his administration has mismanaged the economy, fomented violence and concentrated power, threatening Venezuela's core democratic institutions.

title: Commercial Property/Long Island; Office Plans on the Boards Remain on the Boards
description: EVEN though Long Island's job market is relatively strong, major office builders say that sluggishness in the leasing market and concern about the overall economy have made them cautious about building without a major tenant. This wariness is in sharp contrast with the situation about two years ago, when employment was strong and building on speculation was prevalent.

description: To the Editor:

title: L.I.R.R. Ridership Slipped Last Year
description: Ridership on the Long Island Rail Road slipped 1.9 percent last year to 84 million passengers, the lowest level in three years due to the economic downturn and the Sept. 11 attack that forced many businesses to relocate, the railroad said last week.

title: Dr. David B. Skinner, 67; Oversaw a Hospital Merger
description: Dr. David B. Skinner, who presided over the merger of New York Hospital and Presbyterian Hospital and served as president until his retirement in 1999, died on Friday. He was 67.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITCHMORE, MYRTLE OLIVE
description: LITCHMORE-Myrtle Olive. Passed on January 20th, 2003. Myrtle was an elegant, generous, loving, kind and private lady whose life achievements will continue to live on in the hearts of all those lives she touched. Myrtle is survived by one brother, Aston, and two sisters, Dasey and Lucibell, and her two children, Barbara and Alvin. Grandchildren include Alycia, Alston and Alleah; great grandchildren include Ajeya and Alakai. Services were held on Friday, January 24th at the Greater Allen Cathedral of New York, Jamaica, NY. The family requests, in lieu of flowers, donations in her memory be made to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY.

title: Crdoba Alert
description: To the Editor: This is a warning to travelers who ware walking in Cordoba, Spain. There are small groups, usually three teenage boys, known as jumpers. They sneak up behind a victim, place an arm under the victim's chin and press against the windpipe until the victim loses consciousness. At that point they take any money or other valuables and run away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, IRENE
description: DIAMOND - Irene. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and The Mount Sinai Hospital mourn the passing of Irene Diamond. A generous and visionary philanthropist, Irene Diamond was an outstanding supporter of programs on AIDS education, prevention and treatment. Mount Sinai also has been a beneficiary of Irene Diamond's generous support for immunology, influenza, and numerous important research programs. She will be missed. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Board The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth I. Berns, M.D., Ph.D. President and Chief Executive Officer, Mount Sinai Medical Center Larry H. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGDAN, BARBARA CATES
description: BOGDAN - Barbara Cates. Died peacefully on January 16. A longtime resident of New York City she was born in Salt Lake City, Utah on November 14, 1907, the daughter of Louis Shattuck and Helen Cates. She was the widow of Norbert Andrew Bogdan. Barbara is survived by two of her children from her first marriage to Robert Cullen Wilkin, Barbara Washburn of Ojai, California and Louis Shattuck Cates Wilkin of San Rafael, California. Her eldest daughter Julia Marks of Buffalo, New York predeceased her. Barbara Bogdan has nine grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. She will be remembered with love by all.

title: Bobby Socks Beauty
description: With the resurgence of 1950's styles in strikingly visual movies like ''Far From Heaven'' and in clothing collections by designers like Marc Jacobs, it follows that the beauty industry would catch the midcentury wave. Mass-market brands like Calgon bath products and Toni Perms, which became household names in the early 50's, have recently come out with repackaged versions of the original products. Next month, Dippity-do, the iconic bright pink or blue hair gel, will rerelease its original formula, along with the new Dippity-do Techno, a tweaked version for teenagers ($2.99 at CVS). In the higher-end cosmetic arena, Delux Beauty named its Tintsticks, sheer lip colors for spring, after 50's waitresses -- Flossie, Darling, Dot and Betty. And Stila's spring makeup line is based on the corals and reds of the classic 50's palette. ''The 50's look is very appealing right now because it's so cinematic,'' said Jeanine Lobell, creator of Stila. ''The look is all about black eyeliner, neutral eyeshadows, peachy coral cheeks and bright coral to red lips. It's a perfect complement to modern fashion because it has a slightly ironic, tongue-in-cheek quality.''

title: U.S. Considers Limits on Role Of the Reserves
description: Citing problems with the mass call-up of Reserve and National Guard forces, Pentagon leaders are rethinking the way America goes to war, even questioning whether relying on these citizen soldiers to perform some crucial duties hamstrings urgent military operations.

title: It's Vail in the Winter. Who Needs Skis?
description: OUR motley platoon of snowmobiles was chewing up a rippled meadow high on the southwestern flanks of the Gore Range near Vail, Colo., four bundles of motorized mayhem zigzagging across a brumal landscape. All of a sudden, the one bearing my wife came to a perplexing halt a few hundred yards down the white slope, and she seemed from afar to be peering with puzzlement into an unseen abyss.

title: Courtship Web
description: I persuaded a shy male friend to try Internet dating. He posted his profile and photo but never actually wrote to anyone. So I got him to let me take over. Now I am courting three women via e-mail, in the guise of a 35-year-old man. I am a woman (but, it turns out, I have a way with the ladies). This now feels a bit less innocent, but if it gets my shy friend together with a nice woman, is it wrong? Anonymous, New York

title: Alfred Kantor Dies at 79; Depicted Life in Nazi Camps
description: Alfred Kantor, whose watercolors and sketches recreating daily life in Auschwitz, Theresienstadt and Schwarzheide constitute one of the few visual records of existence in a Nazi concentration camp, died on Jan. 16 in Yarmouth, Me. He was 79.

title: Swastikas Painted on Cars
description: Vandals spray-painted swastikas on eight cars in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. It was the second incident of racist vandalism in Brooklyn in less than two weeks.

title: A Chateau to Call Your Own
description: DIVERSIONS in the province of Landes, in the French Aquitaine, are limited in early March. The famous mud and thermal baths around Dax don't open until the middle of the month. Museums are either closed or operating on limited schedules. In Biarritz, just to the south, action is still pretty light at the casino, and only the most intrepid surfers tackle the waves. Often, there is a lingering chill in the air, and the days can be dank and overcast. All in all, not a very auspicious destination -- unless it includes a chateau of your own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, SHIRLEY
description: KRAUS-Shirley. Age 86. Noted artist. On January 20, 2003, after a short illness, in Bridgeport, CT. Dear wife of Fred and mother of Peter, Kathy and Kenneth. Formerly of Stamford, CT. and New Rochelle, N.Y. Also survived by sister Constance, seven grandchildren and seven great grandchildren.

title: Ivory Coast Leader Appoints A Premier After a Peace Deal
description: President Laurent Gbagbo of Ivory Coast today formally accepted a peace plan here to end his country's four-month-old civil war and appointed a new prime minister to lead a reconciliation government.

title: The World; The Killing of Iraq's Ancient Marsh Culture
description: OF all Iraq's ethnic groups, the marsh Arabs of the southern reaches of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers may have the strongest claim to be Saddam Hussein's most bludgeoned victims. They alone can claim to have had a 6,000-year-old culture dating back to the ancient Sumerians, as well as the wetlands that nurtured that culture, obliterated by Mr. Hussein. Theirs, Western human rights groups say, is a story of genocide.

description: The Bush administration plans to expand its faith-based initiative with a proposal to allow religious groups to use federal housing money to build social service facilities at places of worship. Administration officials said it should help eliminate discrimination against religions in grants. But critics called the plan a clear breach of the separation of church and state. Eric Lichtblau

description: STATE officials across the country have been keeping their eyes on two sets of numbers, and it is sometimes difficult to tell which is growing faster. One is their projected budget shortfalls. The other is online retail sales, which they would like to tax to help fill the gaps.

title: Warren Zevon's last waltz.
description: In the lobby of the Ed Sullivan Theater, two perky handlers for ''The Late Show With David Letterman'' were giving their nightly pep talk to the people headed for the front rows. They encouraged laughter, the more enthusiastic the better. They warned against whistling, which could overload the microphones. They also had one more caution. ''If you hear sad news, don't make that sympathy sound,'' one instructed. ''You know, 'Awwwwww. . . . ' ''

title: Questions of Violence and Race Haunt a School and Its Principal
description: On Dec. 5, Siukwo Cheng, 18, a student at Lafayette High School in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, was beaten by a group of students who he said cursed at him about being Chinese. On Jan. 16, Kristina Martinez, 14, a Hispanic student, was attacked by a group of students who, her mother said, called her ''a white bitch'' and left her with a black eye and sprained fingers.

title: Neck Warmers Lighten Up
description: For women who are wearyof last fall's milelong mufflers in heavy, hand-knit yarns, designers are providing warmth for the second leg of winter in less bulky crochet. The crocheted mufflers, which evoke the granny-made afghan blankets and potholders of yore, come in a variety of yarn weights and patterns, and serve as a transition into spring, when crocheted capes and tops will take their place. At Saks Fifth Avenue, delicate scarves by Sophie Digard have floral, circle (left) and petal-shape patterns in rich pastel wool ($175). A dark plum scarf by Justine Brooke (center) does away with fringe and tassels and sports a slit in one end through which the other end can be fed ($150 at Bergdorf Goodman). Henri Bendel offers protection in the form of an extralong neck warmer, which appears to have been inspired by crocheted potholders (far left, $148). At Barneys New York , there are leaf-pattern shawls by Yadi Knits in metallic pastel cottons ($395). And on the other end of the disposable-income spectrum, American Eagle Outfitters has put its fringed muffler of crocheted squares on sale. It rings in at just over $7 at www.ae.com . Given these choices, what would Granny do?

description: THE last bloody deed was done. The stage darkened. Sophocles' ''Electra'' at Hartford Stage was over.

title: January 19-25: NATIONAL; MONITORING FOR BIOTERROR
description: The Bush administration started deploying a national system of environmental monitors to help protect Americans against bioterrorism. Starting with New York City, many of the Environmental Protection Agency's 3,000 air-quality monitoring stations will be adapted to register unusual quantities of a wide range of pathogens that incapacitate and kill. Stations will send samples to laboratories associated with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Officials hope it will give them more time to mobilize resources that could save thousands of lives during a germ strike. Judith Miller

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SEYMOUR
description: SCHWARTZ - Seymour, 65, Former New York Times Staff Member, dies. Seymour Schwartz, after a long and diverse career at The New York Times, died on January 1 in the Bronx. He was 65. Mr. Schwartz was born in Brooklyn, New York on November 9, 1937 to Joseph and Yetta Schwartz. Raised in Williamsburg, he attended the New York School of Printing during his high school years. Upon graduation, he was awarded a full graphics arts scholarship which he chose to forego in order to support his family during his father's severe and protracted illness. He proudly took on this responsibility and landed a job at The New York Times where he would work in varying capacities for the next forty years, until 1996. His career at The Times began as a proof press operator and he would eventually move on to become assistant supervisor of the Cut Department in the Composing Room. His final years at The Times were in the Advertising/Production Unit. On May 24, 1964 Seymour was married to Elaine Negrin at the Parkside Plaza in the Bronx. Following their honeymoon in Miami Beach, Florida, the couple settled on Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn. On September 6, 1967 they were blessed with their first of two children, Joseph David. The family moved to CoOp City in the Bronx in February 1970, where a second son, Mitchell Brian, was born to them on July 25, 1972. In October 1989, the family moved to Riverdale, New York. Seymour Schwartz is survived by his wife, Elaine, and his two children, Joseph and Mitchell, as well as by his three grandchildren, Jake, Chloe and Benjamin. He will be fondly remembered by his family and friends as a loving, kind family man who made many sacrifices, but was always happy to put others before himself.

These aerodynamic wing feathers could be a long-sought link between dinosaurs and the origin of birds and flight. One theory held that birds evolved from ground-living dinosaurs that ran so fast they became airborne. The four-winged creatures, scientists say, revived an older idea that birds evolved from arboreal animals, which got the hang of aerial travel by gliding from tree to tree like today's flying squirrels. title: 'Interracial Intimacies'
description: Slavery constituted the principal backdrop against which whites and blacks encountered one another for over two hundred years, from the 1660s to the 1860s. The overwhelming majority of slave owners were white, and the overwhelming majority of slaves black. There was probably more black-white sex during this period than at any other time (thus far) in American history. Most of it was unwanted sex, stemming from white males' exploitation of black women-the subject of many pages to come.? But what about mutually desired sex or what I refer to as sexual intimacy? Some commentators insist that there can have been no such thing as sexual intimacy between a black enslaved woman and any white man-a slave owner or overseer or even a mere stranger-because mutually desired sex requires choice, a power denied to slaves by bondage. According to this view, slavery created an extreme dependency that precluded the possibility of chosen as opposed to unwanted sex. As a result, all of the sex that took place between enslaved women and white men constituted some form of sexual assault. Professor Angela Davis is among those who make this argument. Criticizing the notion that a slave woman could consent to have sex with a master, Davis maintains that "there could hardly be a basis for 'delight, affection and love' as long as white men[,] by virtue of their economic position, had unlimited access to Black women's bodies."; Proponents of this view are right to stress the cruel coerciveness of slavery. While the specifics of bondage varied widely over time and from place to place, the condition itself always endowed masters with despotic personal power over their human property.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMPSEY, DEANNA
description: DEMPSEY-Deanna. Widow of the late heavyweight champion of the world, Jack Dempsey, passed away on January 23, 2003 after a short illness. She attended college and a year of law school in Italy before arriving to the United States. She was the owner of the Deanna Jewelry boutiques which were located in four hotels in Manhattan. Married to Mr. Dempsey since the early 1950's she traveled the world with him until shortly before his death. After his death she established the Jack Dempsey Humanitarian Award which is given out annually by St. Claire's Hospital in Manhattan. She supported the P.A.L. in NYC as well as several vocational schools in the US. Taught to sculpt by her friend Rube Goldberg, her North American animal pieces are now in private hands except for a bust of her husband. Always a supporter of women in business she helped many set up their businesses with great success. Fluent in five languages she translated for those who couldn't. Her greatest legacy was her intense devotion and loyalty to her family and close friends. She is survived by her daughter Barbara, her son-in-law Stephen and her grandson Andrew. In addition she leaves behind her very beloved and best friend Tom Steadman, her dear and devoted friend Ted Tyberg and her close friends Mort Coleman, John Shaefer, Anita, Laura, Rosemarie, Michelle, Suzanne, Alexander, Susan, Paul and Ruben. No Flowers. Interment Private. Memorial to be held at a future date.

description: In the last days of campaigning before national elections on Jan. 28, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon appeared to solidify the substantial lead of his right-wing party, Likud. Polls consistently showed that Likud's traditional rival, Labor, trailed by a margin that would leave it with fewer seats than it had ever held in the 120-seat parliament. Labor's leader, Amram Mitzna, who favors immediately returning to the negotiating table with the Palestinians, has pledged not to join a coalition government led by Mr. Sharon. Her goldfish suffered from depression, her father never touched her except when giving her a medical exam, and her mother was killed by a suicidal woman who jumped off Notre Dame and landed on her. Amlie (Audrey Tautou), who grows up to be a waitress in Montmartre, changes her life when she sets out to return a boyhood box-full of treasures to a middle-aged man she has never met. That project circuitously leads, as French films so often do, to love. ''Perhaps it's all a bit too much, and perhaps it doesn't add up,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, ''but the loose ends give the picture a jaunty, improvised feeling,'' which, he concluded, ''is ultimately part of its whimsical charm.'' Jean-Pierre Jeunet wrote and directed -- Monday at midnight and Friday/Early Saturday at 3:20 a.m. on Starz.

''They don't even know what they're taking, they just combine everything.'' And snort it.

title: Questions for Frank Gehry
description: Regarding my interview with Deborah Solomon (Jan. 5), the comments I made about the fees paid to the architectural teams that submitted proposals for ground zero were based on my opinion that when working on a commercial project that will certainly generate great financial gain, as opposed to when working solely on a memorial or something similar, everyone involved should be fairly compensated for the work. It might seem outrageous to anyone outside the profession, but I think most architects would agree that in any other situation a payment of $40,000 for this level of work wouldn't even go far enough for us to pay our own staff members for their efforts and their long nights. I shouldn't have chosen this situation to use as an example of my opinions about the profession in general, and I should have applauded my colleagues for the civic responsibility they've shown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLER, DAVID ANDERSON
description: FOWLER-David Anderson. 82. Died on November 1, 2002 at Bryn Mawr Hospital from complications arising from dialysis treatment for end stage renal failure. He had been ill for several years but never lost the twinkle in his eye, his infectious chuckle, or his youthful optimism. He was a graduate of Choate, Princeton and Harvard Law School. He served as a Lieutenat in WWII. He had been active for many years as a student at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, having been admitted based on his submitted portfolio. He enjoyed sailing and travel; he was a true Renaissance man. His professional life as a corporate real estate attorney included years at Scott Paper, Morgan, Lewis & Bockius and Atlantic Richfield. He was responsible in large part for the development of Ardspring Condominiums in Ardmore, PA, a lower income garden complex. His was a loving, non-judgemental, kind spirit and he will be greatly missed by family and friends. He leaves his loving and beloved wife, Virginia Lee Fowler, and three children: Emily Ennis of Washington D.C., Lindsay A. of Templeton, CA and Elizabeth Silver of Payson, AZ. Also surviving are brothers Alexander R. of Cumberland Foreside, ME and Howland A. Bethesda, MD., and six grandchildren. A memorial service was held on November 12 at The First Presbyterian Church of Ardmore, Pennsylvania. Interment was private.

title: Hirschfeld, Off Off Broadway
description: AL HIRSCHFELD, who died on Monday a few months short of his 100th birthday, is best known as a chronicler of show business. But he was also a distinguished chronicler of New York, the city where he spent nearly all his life. He was born early enough to have patronized speakeasies, and he was moved to record their place in history, struck by the strangeness of the mayor and the chief of police sitting down to drink in ostensibly illegal establishments. Indeed, Prohibition would be repealed the next year, and the speakeasy disappeared or was transformed forever. ''I drank during Prohibition,'' Hirschfeld told his archivist, David Leopold, ''but then it was a sign of patriotism.''

Slight of stature, conversing prestissimo in the high pitch of the lightest of tenors, he covers ground at a pace apt to leave a companion breathless. Certainly that was so last summer, when he met a traveler from New York in the Italian city of Verona. Mr. Scarduelli's mission is to rescue a priceless legacy of recordings by matchless classical musicians of yesteryear before it is too late. Many of them -- Maria Callas, Arturo Toscanini, Andrs Segovia, Pablo Casals -- are long gone. Others -- Renata Tebaldi, Giulietta Simionato, Giuseppe di Stefano -- are still with us, but for how long?

The crocheted mufflers, which evoke the granny-made afghan blankets and potholders of yore, come in a variety of yarn weights and patterns, and serve as a transition into spring, when crocheted capes and tops will take their place. At Saks Fifth Avenue, delicate scarves by Sophie Digard have floral, circle (left) and petal-shape patterns in rich pastel wool ($175). A dark plum scarf by Justine Brooke (center) does away with fringe and tassels and sports a slit in one end through which the other end can be fed ($150 at Bergdorf Goodman). Henri Bendel offers protection in the form of an extralong neck warmer, which appears to have been inspired by crocheted potholders (far left, $148). At Barneys New York, there are leaf-pattern shawls by Yadi Knits in metallic pastel cottons ($395). And on the other end of the disposable-income spectrum, American Eagle Outfitters has put its fringed muffler of crocheted squares on sale. It rings in at just over $7 at www.ae.com. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUDSON, EDWARD JOSEPH
description: HUDSON-Edward Joseph, 98, born on March 13, 1904, died on January 23, 2003. A long-time resident of Houston, Ed Hudson was born to Marion Dooley Hudson and Wilbur E. Hudson in Newark, New Jersey, the youngest child and only son in a family of five children. In 1926 Mr. Hudson graduated cum laude from Stevens Institute of Technology from which he held Mechanical Engineering and Doctor of Engineering degrees. He founded Hudson Engineering Corporation in Houston in 1933 and operated the company along with Hudson Products Corporation until its merger with J. Ray McDermott and Co., Inc. in 1969. Mr. Hudson continued as Chairman of the Board of McDermott for five years until his retirement in 1974. Between 1940 and 1969, Mr. Hudson organized and headed various corporations primarily to construct, own and operate gas processing plants and pipelines. These included Distillate Production Corporation, Acadia Corporation, Egan Oil Purchasing Company, Carthage Corporation, and Port Processing Corporation, all of which were merged into Hudson Gas and Oil Corporation, and sold to Continental Oil Company in 1963. Mr. Hudson served on the boards of McDermott, TransOcean Oil Corporation, Gulf Resources & Chemical Corporation, and Texas Commerce Bank. Mr. Hudson also developed and operated the Hudson Cattle Company on the Broken Triangle Ranch near Bay City, Texas, where he bred registered American Brahman cattle. While involved in ranching, Mr. Hudson also established a stable of thoroughbreds, and in conjunction with Lane's End Farm, he enjoyed breeding and racing horses in Kentucky. While successful in business, Mr. Hudson pursued many other interests. New York was among his favorite cities. During the late 1940's to 1970, Ed Hudson was a generous contributor to the New York City Ballet. He was among the early and avid supporters of George Balanchine and Barbara Horgan. He served as a trustee of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, and he was an active participant in building the Republican Party in Texas. He spent many years flying his own Beechcraft airplanes. He enjoyed backgammon and baseball, and he loved birds, gardens and flowers, particularly orchids. Through his life, he was blessed with remarkable good health and energy, and until age 98 he continued to visit his office each day where he managed his post-retirement interests. Ed Hudson's commitment to learning never wavered; he was an enthusiastic and generous contributor to education. Along with supporting Stevens Institute, he and his wife founded the Edward J. and Josephine G. Hudson Endowed Scholarship Fund at Baylor College of Medicine. To date the Hudson Scholarship fund has sponsored the training of more than 24 physician scientists through graduate and medical school. He also supported numerous other charitable organizations. Mr. Hudson is survived by his beloved wife, Josephine Gill Hudson, his two sons, Edward Joseph Hudson, Jr. and his wife, Lynne, of Houston, and Robert Lee Hudson and his wife, Becky, of Napa, California, five grandchildren, Sarah Hudson of New York, Wilhelmina Hudson of Houston, Edward Joseph Hudson II, Claire Hudson, and William Campbell Hudson of Napa. He is also survived by his three stepsons, Christopher Gill, Peter Gill and Richardson Gill, and their families, all of San Antonio, by Stacy, Wade and Colin Head of Houston, and by his nephew, Edward Joseph Toohey, and his wife, Phyllis, of South Hampton, New York. Mr. Hudson is mourned and will be missed greatly by his staff at home, Michael Lance and Victoria Loehr, and by his office staff, Cynthia Hughes, Mary Harris, Janette Burch, Lynn Einkauf and their familiies. The Hudsons wish to thank Dr. Michael DeBakey, Dr. George Noon, Dr. Mohammed Attar, Dr. John McCarthy, Dr. Peter Jones and the exceptional nursing staff of the CICU at Methodist Hospital for their dedication and loving care. A memorial service will be held for Mr. Hudson at St. Martin's Episcopal Church, 717 Sage Road, Houston, Texas on Monday, January 27 at 2 P.M. The Reverend Doctor Laurence A. Gipson will officiate. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Edward J. & Josephine G. Hudson Endowed Scholarship Fund, Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, Texas 77030.

title: CRIME
description: Over the course of his long and distinguished career as a homicide detective in the Garda Siochana, Chief Superintendent Peter McGarr has beaten the drums for Irish history, Irish legend and Irish literature, while doing his bit to curb the uncivil excesses of Irish politics, Irish religion and Irish criminal enterprise. So it seems only fitting that in his final case, in Bartholomew Gill's DEATH IN DUBLIN (Morrow, $24.95), he should take on ''the most culturally heinous crime possible in Ireland,'' the theft of that medieval talisman of Irish civilization, the Book of Kells, from its place of honor in the library of Trinity College. All the evidence points to the New Druids, an anti-Christian, neo-pagan group of zealots who promote ancestor worship and maybe do a little drug dealing on the side. But McGarr is too wise to the defiantly contradictory Hibernian character to settle for the obvious; and indeed, the political plot proves more devious and its resolution much bloodier than anyone could have predicted.

The books are printed in elongated cargo-pocket-sized editions specially pre-aged to look like the old Armed Services Editions and are handed out during the Christmas season in the lobby of the Pentagon, on missile-carrying frigates, in Bosnia. The book, $47 cloth and $19 paperback, is expected in stores in March. Divided into ''Downriver,'' ''Midriver'' and ''Upriver,'' it describes the original construction and subsequent lives of the 35 bridges, some dating back almost two centuries. The Riegelsville suspension bridge (pictured), more than 100 years old, is a successor to a wooden covered bridge built in the 1830's for $18,900. . Mr. Dale, a local historian specializing in Warren and Sussex counties, says he favored those old covered bridges. But the last of them over the Delaware was swept away in floods long ago. The most heavily trafficked Delaware bridge, at the Water Gap, is too new (1950's) to be called historic. Mr. Dale began crossing his beloved Delaware as a child, to visit relatives. Last week, Peter Olson, the chairman of Random House, which is owned by Bertelsmann, abruptly fired Ann Godoff, the highly regarded head of the Random House Trade Group. His reasoning could not have been blunter. Her group -- the hardcover literary core of Random House -- didn't meet its profit targets. Ms. Godoff has admirers, who praise her literary savvy, and she has detractors, some of whom point to the colossal advances that she, like many other editors, occasionally paid authors. But her unseemly firing caused widespread dismay in the publishing world, even though she is moving on to her own imprint at Penguin.

title: Struggling Canada Looks for Answers
description: The last time BRUCE WILSON wore a jersey sporting a red maple leaf was also the last time Canada played in a major international tournament. The date: June 9, 1986. The place: Irapuato, Mexico. The result: a 2-0 loss to the Soviet Union. Canada went home after three losses in the first round without scoring a goal. Wilson went home to western Canada, where he has since been the men's coach at the University of Victoria. Wilson was once considered a candidate to coach the national team right after that World Cup, when Tony Waiters stepped down. He would probably like to be considered again, particularly after Canada's dismal 4-0 loss to the United States on Jan. 18. (Next up for Canada is a trip to Libya for a game in Tripoli on Feb. 12.) The generally opinionated Wilson was careful to measure his words, to a point. ``It's tough because there is nothing for our players at home,'' Wilson said, echoing recent comments by the current coach of the national team, the German HELGER OSIECK. ``The coach does not have a deep pool of players he can count on.'' Canada's largely developmental squad was without European-based players like TOMASZ RADZINSKI, who plays in England with Everton, and JASON DeVOS, also in England with Wigan of the Second Division. But perhaps the worst slap in the face was the decision by OWEN HARGREAVES (Bayern Munich) several years ago to play internationally for England, not Canada, where he was born to an English father and a Welsh mother. ``The reason for Canada's success when I was playing was the North American Soccer League,'' said Wilson, who played for Vancouver, Toronto, Chicago and the Cosmos during his 14-year professional career. ``Now with M.L.S., Canadians are considered foreign players, so our best players go overseas, where they can get a bit more money. I have to give M.L.S. credit. They don't want Canadian teams, and they have said they want to help develop American players. They have been brilliant. In the N.A.S.L., Canadian and American players were equal. It was super for us.'' Only one Canadian, DWAYNE DeROSARIO (San Jose), plays in Major League Soccer, which has considered expanding to Canada but has yet to find suitable investors. Several Canadians play in the A-League, the second-tier operation that has clubs in the United States and Canada. Canada did not qualify for the 2002 World Cup and will probably have a better chance in 2006 since the Concacaf region could have four teams in the tournament. Canada is currently ranked 70th by FIFA, tied with Jordan, one place behind Venezuela, one ahead of Cuba _ hardly world-beaters. Canada's only claim to modest success was winning the 2000 Gold Cup, but only after it advanced past the first round by the toss of a coin. ``Winning the Gold Cup was really such a nonevent,'' Wilson said. ``By the reaction from some people, you would think we had won the World Cup. Being the national coach was a big issue for me at one time. Maybe it is again, I don't really know. But I don't understand how a coach fails to take a team to the World Cup and gets a new contract. Anywhere else in the world he would be gone.''

He is survived by his beloved wife Sascha Newman Sorin, his sons John Sorin and William Sorin, and three grandchildren. Private memorial service.

His prodigious dunks already the stuff of legend, the 20-year-old Stoudemire was supposed to hurt the rims and the Knicks yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

description: KENT-Stephen D. 84, of Newburgh, NY, died January 25, 2003. Survivors inlcude his wife of 62 years, Marian, and his children, Peggy Brooks and Peter (Mailis), as well as three grandchildren.

title: Bresaola Spread
description: Bresaola is a thin, air-cured, salted beef, originally from the Lombardy region of Italy. It can be enjoyed as an antipasto, drizzled with olive oil and lemon juice or paired with shavings of a strong cheese like parmesan. Here, however, we've paired it with mild, creamy mascapone to form a delicious spread. Enjoy on rustic bread or crackers.

title: Pfizer Is Shifting Lubriderm to BBDO
description: Pfizer is expanding a new relationship with the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, by shifting to the agency the creative duties on the account of the Lubriderm line of skin-care products in the United States. The account had been at J. Walter Thompson in New York, part of the WPP Group. Spending was estimated at $15 million to $30 million.

description: Even with a gray blanket looming in the sky and snow speckling parts of the city, New Yorkers rejoiced yesterday as temperatures rose above freezing for the first time in nearly two weeks.

description: President Bush is planning a major initiative to help small businesses obtain health insurance, but the proposal faces opposition from consumer groups and governors because the insurance would be largely exempt from state regulation.

title: China Court Rejects Appeal of Tibetan Monk
description: BEIJING, Monday, Jan. 27 - A 28-year-old ethnic Tibetan accused of plotting bomb attacks was executed on Sunday, soon after an appeals court in Sichuan Province upheld his December conviction, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARE, THOMAS E.
description: O'HARE-Thomas E. 74, of Centennial, CO, was born in New York, NY, on September 3, 1928. He died in Littleton, CO, on January 21, 2003. He was a Chemical Engineer, an inventor, a member of the Knights of Columbus, The Ancient Order of Hibernians and a veteran of the Korean War. He is survived by his wife Claire H. O'Hare; his children Nancy E. O'Hare, Terence G. O'Hare, Andrew T. O'Hare, Constance M. O'Hare, and Mary Kate O'Hare Sieg; his brother Edward J. O'Hare; also survived by eight grandchildren. Services were held Saturday, January 25, 2003 at St. Vincent de Paul Catholic Church, 2375 E. Arizona Ave, Denver, CO. Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery. The family suggests that memorial donations be made to The Children's Friendship Project for Northern Ireland c/o Glenn Martinsen, 7 Olde Manchester Rd, Derry, NH 03038. For information, contact Horan & McConaty Funeral Service, Aurora, CO.

description: Young Raiders fans in East Oakland marched in small clusters in the street chanting, ''Raiders! Raiders!'' after Oakland lost the Super Bowl today. Other fans drove up International Boulevard waving Raider flags and honking horns.

title: Baba Ghanouj and Hummus
description: Both baba ghanouj and hummus are made using the sesame paste called tahini. You can buy jarred tahini in most supermarkets, but if you want to make your own, toast a few tablespoons of sesame seeds in an oven or skillet. Process the seeds, slowly adding olive oil until it reaches a thick, paste-like consistency (about 2-3 minutes).

title: Show Trials Like Stalin's in Turkmenistan
description: In a darkened public meeting hall, Boris Shikhmuradov's face shone from a giant television screen. He spoke the words of his confession haltingly. He wore no expression. His eyes were cast downward.

title: Blix Tells Security Council That Iraq's Cooperation Is Limited
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 27  The United Nations' chief chemical and biological weapons inspector, Hans Blix, sharply criticized Iraq before the Security Council today, saying the Iraqis failed to cooperate adequately with inspectors seeking to assess Baghdad's ability to produce and use weapons of mass destruction.

title: Matisse, Picasso and Concerns About the Crowds
description: A certified blockbuster of an art show bearing a high-end ticket price is to open at the Museum of Modern Art in less than three weeks, with questions to be answered. Will those who want to see it make the trip to the Modern's temporary home in Queens? And if they do in anything like the numbers the show has drawn elsewhere, will the smaller space be able to handle them?

title: Raider Nation Takes to the Beach
description: Location is everything in California. You find a place close to the water, and everyone must pass by you. Black and silver has claimed the beach. Raiders fans, from the Bay area, inland and all other curious points, arrived at their rallying point Saturday evening on San Diego's Mission Beach. For most of the costumed characters, this was as close to the Super Bowl as they would get. For reasons of security, the N.F.L. has banned most costumes, props and hard hats with rubber studs. So, Pablo Navarro of San Diego was looking for a new location to watch the game. "I would feel naked there without my uniform," he said. "If one piece of me is missing, it's not the same." Clearly it's not the same in Chargers country, where Raiders fans have been given wide berth. Mark Pargas

title: Bucs' Rice Demonstrates Why Defense Wins Titles
description: Tampa Bay safety Dexter Jackson was named the most valuable player of Super Bowl XXXVII today, but if Oakland quarterback Rich Gannon had submitted a vote, he might have picked the rangy defensive end who kept smashing him from behind.

title: Mayor to Name 10 to Lead Overhaul of Public Schools
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will announce today the 10 regional superintendents for the overhauled Department of Education. At least five who are expected to be named are widely respected community school district superintendents and four of those currently oversee relatively high-performing districts.

title: Editors and Lobbyists Wage High-Tech War Over Letters
description: Newspapers and political organizations are engaged in technological one-upmanship over ''AstroTurf'' -- letters to the editor that look like authentic grass-roots responses from readers but are not.

title: Homeless Man Is Charged With Slashing on Subway Platform
description: A homeless man has been arrested and charged with the slashing of a 21-year-old college student on a downtown subway platform this month, the police said yesterday.

title: Australia Dispatches First Forces to Persian Gulf
description: Australia has sent its first forces to the Persian Gulf over the past several days, officials say.

title: Buyers Outpace Renters
description: The DVD continues to transform the home video market. In 2002, for the first time, annual sales of home videos in the United States surpassed money spent on rentals, according to the market research firm Alexander & Associates. And overall consumer spending on prerecorded home videos whether in the DVD or VHS format, including sales and rentals set a record in 2002, at $28.5 billion. That total was up 15 percent from a year earlier.

title: Police Panel Finds No Official Misconduct in Jogger Case
description: The New York Police Department said today that an internal review of its handling of the Central Park jogger investigation had found no wrongdoing by the police, and the report asserted that the five men recently cleared in the case had likely "participated in an attack upon the jogger."

title: Demonstrators Call for Resignation of Bishop
description: More than 200 people, including some who said they had been abused by clergy members, demonstrated outside St. Joseph's Cathedral here this morning to show support for victims of sexual abuse and to call for the resignation of Bishop John B. McCormack.

description: There is already a money-making music alternative to the CD, and it has nothing to with the Internet.

title: Falling Into The Gap
description: Adolfo Jesus Recio suffers from asthma, depression and unemployment. His left hand was badly injured in an accident and is now almost useless. He panhandles in the middle of a busy street in the shadow of the downtown Miami skyline.

title: F.C.C. Expected to Extend Satellite Operators' Reach
description: After months of rumors that a decision would be handed down ''any day now,'' the Federal Communications Commission is expected to announce this week that satellite voice and data companies can supplement their services with land-based wireless networks.

title: Rangers Overpowered by Capitals
description: As questionable as they may have thought the officiating was this afternoon, the Rangers had only themselves to blame for the 7-2 shellacking they received at the hands of the Washington Capitals at the MCI Center.

description: IN the midst of the shambles that used to be Raider Nation, Jon Gruden, who had led that nation for four seasons, hoisted the Lombardi trophy high overhead.

title: How Bush Can Avoid the Inspections Trap
description: As if the Iraq problem were not difficult enough, today Hans Blix, the head of the United Nations inspection team, will deliver his official report to the Security Council. Now the United States is firmly stuck in the ''inspections trap,'' and our French and German allies appear determined to keep us there. Paris and Berlin, along with their fellow travelers in Moscow and Beijing, are likely to seize on Mr. Blix's report to insist on delaying any military operation to enforce Iraq's disarmament.

title: Voices in Europe Urge Patience on Iraq
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 27  Europe reacted today to the report by the chief United Nations arms inspectors with a chorus of voices, mostly in favor of more time to deal with the confrontation with Iraq.

title: For Adventure, Try Boulez and Stay Till the End
description: An amusing and, in a way, emblematic incident took place during Friday night's concert by the Orchestre National de Lyon, the first of its two riveting programs at Carnegie Hall. David Robertson, the orchestra's brilliant music director, was conducting the final work, a group of five arresting ''Notations'' by Pierre Boulez. It was the second substantive Boulez score on this challenging program.

title: American Dream for an Immigrant Idol
description: ou're prettier in person than on television," a woman shrieked outside a terminal at Kennedy Airport as cameras flashed and the heartthrob, surrounded by a crowd of autograph-seekers, tried to inch forward.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: NEW YORK CITY TO GET $150 MILLION Gov. George E. Pataki plans to have the Battery Park City Authority, which he controls, provide New York City with a one-time cash infusion worth $150 million or more to help the city deal with its fiscal woes, a top administration official said yesterday. The Pataki aide, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the money would come from the savings realized by refinancing almost $1 billion in authority bonds. The Pataki plan also calls for the joint state-city authority to buy the undeveloped Pier A from the city as well as some other city land that could then be developed by the authority. (AP)

title: Hugh Trevor-Roper, 89, Dies; Historian of Hitler's Last Days
description: Hugh Trevor-Roper, a British historian who wrote a best-selling account of Hitler's final days in the Berlin bunker but damaged his reputation 35 years later by authenticating forged Hitler diaries, died yesterday in Oxford, England. He was 89.

title: Baseball Test May Soon Show If Time Is Right For Web Video
description: The discussion about the Super Bowl has hardly died down, and baseball's spring training is still a month away. But Major League Baseball and RealNetworks are already preparing to use this year's baseball season to test whether Internet broadcasting is more than just a minor league sport.

title: Gates Gives $200 Million For Research
description: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is giving $200 million to identify critical questions about the leading causes of death in developing countries and to create an international competition to entice scientists to solve them.

title: Titans Still Gather at Davos, Shorn of Profits and Bravado
description: When the Swiss police blocked off this Alpine village against a band of antiglobalization protesters on Saturday, one of the globe-trotting capitalists stuck outside was Sir Howard Stringer, the chief executive of the Sony Corporation of America.

title: An Island Of the Dead Fascinates The Living
description: The allure of Hart Island, a half-mile east of City Island in the Bronx, is not so much in the living but in the dead, in the people and places long forgotten. It is in the abandoned missile silos, the gutted jailhouse and the granite cross that reads, ''He calleth his children by name,'' marking the mass grave for the city's nameless children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEJUR, MARION ELLENBERG
description: DeJUR-Marion Ellenberg. Peacefully on January 23, in Bal Harbour, FL formerly of New York City, wife of the late Dr. Samuel Ellenberg, late Harry DeJur and late Herb Lowenstein, beloved mother of Dianne Ellenberg Davis and Shepard Ellenberg, beloved grandmother of Hal Scott and S. Lawrence Davis, and Jennifer Ellenberg; great-grandmother of Emma Elizabeth and Alexandre Jerard Davis. Survived by sister Lillian Flaster, of Connecticut, and stepdaughter Lee Lowenstein Kolenberg of Florida. Connie Scott was her devoted caregiver. Her driving force, visionary initiatives and philanthropy, inspired and touched many throughout the world.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Conviction Upheld In Bomb Plot
description: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan yesterday upheld the conviction and 24-year sentence of Mokhtar Haouari, an Algerian who assisted in a terrorist plot to bomb Los Angeles International Airport during the 2000 millennium celebrations. Mr. Haouari provided a fake driver's license and cash in the plot, according to the testimony of Ahmed Ressam, who was to have carried out the attack but was arrested as he entered the United States from Canada in December 1999. Mr. Haouari was convicted of conspiracy and four counts of fraud. The conviction was upheld by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: A Closer Eye on the Worst Sex Offenders
description: Half a dozen city and state law enforcement agencies would more closely scrutinize the worst of the city's convicted sex offenders after their release from prison as part of a new program to help reduce sex attacks -- the crime category that has climbed in the city despite drops in other offenses, officials said.

description: In percent

title: 49ers to Interview Cottrell
description: The Jets' defensive coordinator, Ted Cottrell, will be interviewed today for the head-coaching job of the San Francisco 49ers. The interview will be conducted by San Francisco General Manager Terry Donahue.

title: Sharon Leads Likud to Decisive Victory
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 28  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and his Likud party won decisively in this country's parliamentary election today as Israelis endorsed his tough approach to a bloody conflict with Palestinians that has ground on for more than two years.

title: The Neediest Cases; Help With Rent for Exhausted Family
description: Mayra Torres and her husband, Miguel Rodriguez, had not paid the rent in two months, and Ms. Torres was feeling the stress. Filled with anxiety and having trouble breathing, she skipped going to her young son's early-intervention class at Public School 5 in the Inwood section of Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Aid Workers Questioned
description: The authorities questioned five foreign aid workers, including an American woman, and accused them of working as journalists without accreditation. The workers, who are from the Lutheran World Federation and write for an in-house publication, say they were visiting several Lutheran aid projects in Zimbabwe. The police, who have not made any arrests, say the workers may be journalists working under cover. Under Zimbabwe's tough media law, all foreign journalists must receive an invitation from the Ministry of Information before working in the country. In an effort to reduce the number of published accounts of violence and lawlessness in the country, the government had made it harder for journalists to visit. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Women's Excommunication Upheld
description: The Vatican upheld the excommunication of seven women, including an American, who were ''ordained'' in Austria last June. The decree, signed by the Holy See's top doctrinal officer, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, said the ''penalty imposed is not only just, but also necessary, in order to protect true doctrine'' and ''safeguard the communion and unity of the church.'' The women had appealed the excommunication but the Vatican ruled they had not sufficiently asked forgiveness and cited efforts to rally support as ''open and divisive disobedience'' toward Pope John Paul II. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Crash in Tunnel Kills Two
description: Two trains collided head-on in an Alpine tunnel near the Italian border in southeast France early today, killing two people and injuring four seriously.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Unilever Sales Improve
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch food and soap company, said that its 400 leading brands, including Dove soap and Lipton iced tea, sold better in 2002 than originally forecast, growing 5.4 percent compared with the 4.5 to 5 percent projected last month. Earnings per share rose 20 percent before one-time items, good will and currency fluctuations, a percentage point more than predicted. Unilever has spent the last four years slimming down, eliminating 33,000 jobs and 75 percent of its product line. It has reinvested the resulting savings into marketing its top brands and further expanding into overseas markets, including South America. The company will release its annual results on Feb. 13. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Federal Study Shows High Number of Ground Zero Workers Had Health Problems Last Year
description: Among the first wave of ground zero workers who came forward for physical examinations at the Mount Sinai Medical Center last summer, nearly three-fourths had ear, nose or throat problems more than 10 months after the World Trade Center attack, doctors said yesterday. More than half still had lung complaints or abnormal results in pulmonary function tests.

description: Democratic response to the State of the Union as prepared for delivery by Governor Gary Locke.

description: Accessories Plucked as if From a Garden

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the political and social test posed in Nigeria by the sentencing of a woman to death by stoning used a misspelled given name in some copies for the country's president, who has had to walk a fine line. He is Olusegun Obasanjo, not Olesegun.

title: Iraq War: The First Question
description: A new book about Iraq by Con Coughlin describes Saddam's younger son, Qusay, giving a speech last year in an underground bunker before his father and top officials: ''With a simple sign from you, we can make America's people sleepless and frightened to go out in the streets. I only ask you, sir, to give me a small sign [to] turn their night into day and their day into a living hell.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Approval Sought For Nominee To Microsoft Panel
description: The federal judge who approved Microsoft's antitrust settlement with the government was asked yesterday to appoint Edward Stritter, a computer scientist, to a committee that will oversee the company's compliance. Mr. Stritter, former director of business development for Cisco Systems' wireless unit, was nominated by the other two prospective members of the panel. The Justice Department asked Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly to name Mr. Stritter along with the other two panel members, Harry Saal, a software industry executive, and Franklin Fite Jr., a former Microsoft manager. Mr. Saal was nominated by the government and Mr. Fite by Microsoft. The panel will referee complaints by competitors and customers that Microsoft is not complying with the terms of the settlement, negotiated after an appeals court upheld findings that the company illegally protected its Windows monopoly. Microsoft shares dropped 68 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $49.17.

title: Cleanup Begins In Oakland After Violence On Team's Loss
description: After the Oakland Raiders were defeated in the Super Bowl on Sunday night, disturbances led to the arrests of some 90 people, most of them for public intoxication. Today police investigators were scanning videotapes of rampaging crowds in an effort to identify other offenders, while business owners began cleaning up the mess.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Australia's dispatch of troops to the Persian Gulf referred incorrectly, in the opening sentence and the headline, to the precedent. As noted elsewhere in the article, Australian frigates have been helping enforce the United Nations maritime blockade of Iraq since 1991; the troops sent in the last week are not the first Australians there.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: $25 Billion In Extra Spending
description: The lower house of Parliament approved an extra budget worth $25 billion in new spending on public works projects and creating new jobs. The package is intended to offset adverse effects of the government's banking policy, which includes forcing lenders to cut off delinquent borrowers if needed. The government will issue about $42 billion in new bonds to pay for the budget and for expected shortfalls in tax revenue. Endorsement by the lower house ensures that the budget will be enacted. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Justices Deny Inmate Appeal In Execution Of Juveniles
description: The Supreme Court effectively shut the door today on reconsidering, at least in the foreseeable future, its precedents permitting the death penalty to be imposed on those who were 16 or 17 when they committed their capital crimes.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: UNILEVER SALES IMPROVE Unilever, the British-Dutch food and soap company, said that its 400 leading brands, including Dove soap and Lipton iced tea, sold better in 2002 than originally forecast, growing 5.4 percent compared with the 4.5 to 5 percent projected last month. Earnings per share rose 20 percent before one-time items, good will and currency fluctuations, a percentage point more than predicted. Unilever has spent the last four years slimming down, eliminating 33,000 jobs and 75 percent of its product line. It has reinvested the resulting savings into marketing its top brands and further expanding into overseas markets, including South America. The company will release its annual results on Feb. 13. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: In-Flight Selling of Food Gets High Marks in Test
description: I THINK I've seen the future of airline food in the coach cabin, and guess what: It ain't too bad.

title: Times Co. Net Income Rose 45% in 4th Quarter
description: The New York Times Company reported fourth-quarter results that were better than expected, as advertising and circulation revenues rose while newsprint expenses dropped.

title: Children's Book Awards Announced
description: The children's book awards sponsored by the American Library Association, announced today at its midwinter meeting, included surprise winners for both the Newbery and Caldecott Medals. There were also many honor, or runner-up, citations, often a help to publishers in difficult economic times because the gold and silver stickers that the cited books are entitled to bear attract book buyers.

title: Dostoyevsky's Twilight of Murder and Guilt
description: First, the names, since the story is Russian. There is Raskolnikov, a student, and Porfiry, the city magistrate. There is an angelic prostitute named Sonia. And there are Alyona Ivanovna, a pawnbroker, and Lizaveta, her half sister. These last two do not fare very well.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Fish Trade Dispute
description: In a preliminary finding, the Bush administration ruled that Vietnamese catfish farmers are guilty of dumping discount-priced frozen fish on the market in the United States and could be liable for import duties as high as 63 percent. In what is becoming a major trade war, American catfish farmers have persuaded Congress to bar Vietnam from using the name catfish for their exports and then filed the suit that led to yesterday's decision by the Commerce Department. For their part, the Vietnamese have condemned the suit as ''an unfair, protectionist act'' and a violation of the new trade agreement with the United States. They said their fish were priced lower because Vietnamese labor costs far less than American labor. In the last three years, Vietnamese catfish exports have soared from $13 million to $55 million, capturing 20 percent of the American market. A final decision is expected in June. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: LVMH to Sell Phillips Stake To Auction House Executives
description: LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton plans to sell its remaining 27.5 percent stake in the auction house Phillips de Pury & Luxembourg to the co-chief executives of Phillips, Simon de Pury and Daniella Luxembourg, the auction house said yesterday.
