title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: $80 Million Prescription Drug Settlement
description: Two large drug companies accused of conspiring to keep consumers from buying a cheaper generic form of a widely used blood pressure drug for 14 months in 1998 and 1999 have settled lawsuits filed against them. State Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that the companies, Aventis Pharmaceuticals Inc. and Andrx Corporation, have agreed to pay $80 million to consumers and medical insurance companies in all 50 states who allegedly overpaid for the patented version of the drug, Cardizem CD. About 70,000 New Yorkers and one million people nationwide take the drug, Mr. Spitzer said. Of the $21 million available to consumers, about $1.5 million will be available to New York residents who qualify. Mr. Spitzer handled the case with counterparts in other states. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: 911 Operator Mishandled Boaters' Call, Kelly Says
description: A 911 operator failed to properly classify a desperate cellphone call from one of the four teenagers who disappeared in the icy waters off the Bronx on Friday night, an error that delayed a police response for 14 hours, officials said yesterday.

description: Following is a transcript of the statement given by the chief inspector for biological and chemical weapons, Hans Blix, to the United Nations Security Council today, as recorded by the United Nations.

title: Worm Hits Microsoft, Which Ignored Own Advice
description: The frantic message came from the corporation's information technology workers: ''HELP NEEDED: If you have servers that are nonessential, please shut down.''

title: Sports of The Times; Face That Won Title Is New Face of N.F.L.
description: HE'S the new face, literally, of pro football. He's Jon Gruden, the Tampa Bay coach with the fascinating face.

title: In Some Countries Dangerous Legal Pitfalls Await the Unwary Visitor
description: An American telecommunications executive on business in Venezuela is involved in an automobile accident that severely injures the other driver. Even though he is not at fault, he is arrested.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Senators Introduce Bill On Identity Theft
description: Senators Dianne Feinstein of California and Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, both Democrats, and Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, introduced legislation yesterday to protect people from identity theft, with a focus on cases involving the Internet. The bill would require Social Security numbers to be removed from public records published on the Web; it would also prohibit the sale of Social Security numbers to the general public, and remove such numbers from government checks and driver's licenses. The measure would permit legitimate business and government use of the numbers. Last year, similar legislation was approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee. Identity theft topped the Federal Trade Commission's annual report on consumer complaints this year, accounting for 43 percent of the complaints lodged with the F.T.C. and losses for consumers of about $343 million.

title: Wrestling With Title IX
description: Title IX, the federal law that prohibits sex discrimination in educational programs receiving federal assistance, may be in for an overhaul. This week a committee appointed by the Bush administration will hold its final meetings before submitting its recommendations for changing the law to Secretary of Education Rod Paige. Since Title IX was enacted in 1972, it has been the subject of debate -- much of it misguided -- about its application to college athletics. At issue now is how to alter the law -- or not -- so that, as Secretary Paige has put it, we can find ways of ''expanding opportunities to ensure fairness for all college athletes.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Iraq appears not to have come to genuine acceptance -- not even today -- of the disarmament which was demanded of it and which it needs to carry out to win the confidence of the world and live in peace.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, picture captions on Saturday about the Czech president, Vaclav Havel, misstated the date of his state visit to Germany and the date when pranksters covered part of a neon sign on Prague Castle. Mr. Havel was in Berlin on Jan. 17, not last Friday. The prank occurred on Jan. 14, not last week.

title: Letters
description: Billions and Billions Fed

title: Serb Denies Guilt
description: Milan Milutinovic, the former president of Serbia, appeared at the United Nations war crimes tribunal for the first time today and pleaded not guilty to charges of deportation, murder, persecution and other crimes against ethnic Albanian civilians in Kosovo in 1999.

title: Mohegan Tribe to Own W.N.B.A. Team in Connecticut
description: The Women's National Basketball Association, having abandoned its policy of restricting franchises to N.B.A. cities, will grant ownership of a team today to the Mohegan tribe, which owns a casino in eastern Connecticut.

title: Closed or Not, Indian Point And Its Perils Won't Vanish
description: Two weeks after a state-sponsored report said emergency planning was inadequate to protect residents from an extensive radioactive release from the Indian Point nuclear plant, four nearby counties have come to the same conclusion and refused to certify the evacuation plan required by federal officials to keep the plant in operation.

title: Manhattan Makes It 11 in Row And 2 for 2 Against Big East
description: Manhattan still plays with a bit of a chip on its shoulder, its players decrying a perceived lack of respect and eager to prove wrong the larger universities that were not interested in recruiting them out of high school. It's a useful motivating tool, but their argument is starting to wear thin. Who doesn't know anymore that this is a good team?

title: 50 Selections for Registry
description: These are the first 50 items in added to the National Recording Registry, listed in chronological order:

title: New Slant on Jogger Case Lacks Official Certainty
description: Nearly 14 years after a jogger was raped in Central Park, police officials yesterday proposed a new version of the events -- a still-troubling but diluted narrative of the infamous crime spree offered to the world in 1989.

title: White House Expected to Disclose Evidence of Iraqi Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  The Bush administration, hoping to tighten its case against Iraq, plans to release new intelligence on concealed weapons and possible terror links as early as next week, government officials said today.

title: The Prince of Peace Was a Warrior, Too
description: Everyone, it seems, wants Jesus on his side. Nutritionists publish books with titles like ''What Would Jesus Eat?'' Environmentalists issue policy statements asking ''What Would Jesus Drive?'' With talk of war, we're now hearing ''How Would Jesus Vote on Iraq?'' -- assuming that he were a member of the United Nations Security Council.

title: Inspector Says Iraq Falls Short
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 27  Hans Blix, one of the chief United Nations weapons inspectors, gave a broadly negative report today on Iraq's cooperation with two months of inspections, providing support to the Bush administration's campaign to disarm Iraq by force if necessary.

title: A Bookworm as a Child, Now the Talk of the Town
description: RIGHT after The New Yorker magazine named Deborah Treisman, a West Villager with lifelong ties to the literati, as its fiction editor, a job that in the vivid imagination of fiction writers carries clout equivalent to St. Peter's at the Pearly Gates, a frisson of apprehension shot through the literary milieu. Ms. Treisman felt it, too.

title: Pleasure Dome for the Los Angeles Philharmonic
description: At 7 p.m. music lovers set off from Hollywood, Bel Air, Pacific Palisades or Malibu praying for smooth 30-minute passage eastward on Southern California's freeways. They cross an astonishing world of dislocated kingdoms. Iranians and Arabs flourish in Beverly Hills. Hindus and Russians fill the streets of the Fairfax district. The part of Kenmore that is Latino mingles with Vietnamese, Filipinos, Ugandans and Caribbean islanders. Drivers pass by Thai Town, Korea Town and Little Armenia. Overshooting their downtown destination brings Little Tokyo or Monterey Park, a sleek enclave of middle-class Chinese on whose streets the English speaker is not that easily come by.

title: Mayor Presents 2004 Budget
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg outlined a plan today to close a $3.4 billion budget gap next year that continues to rely heavily on help beyond the city's control, from state permission to impose a commuter tax to significant union concessions.

title: Senate Panel to Hear From U.S.O.C. Today
description: United States Olympic Committee officials will testify before the Senate Commerce Committee today about the organization's embattled leadership and governance, issues that were brought into sharp focus with the recent ethics investigation into Lloyd Ward, its chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the resignation of Christos M. Cotsakos as chairman and chief executive of the E*Trade Group misidentified the university from which he earned a doctorate. It is the University of London, not the London School of Economics.

title: Bush Tells Nation He Will Deal With Iraq and Economic Woes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  President Bush portrayed Saddam Hussein's Iraq tonight as an imminent threat to America and vowed to reinvigorate an economy that "is not growing fast enough, or strongly enough."

title: Shining a Light on the Health Benefits of Vitamin D
description: A visit to the office of Dr. Michael F. Holick in the Boston University Medical Center quickly conveys his enthusiasm for his favorite hormone, vitamin D.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: City Jails
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on prison guards, health care, budgets and other issues with the Department of Correction. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (718) 287-8762.

title: New Director Selected for World Health Organization
description: Dr. Jong Wook Lee, a South Korean expert on tuberculosis and vaccines who trained in the United States, was selected today to head the World Health Organization.

title: A Critical Test for Bush
description: This week, President Bush hopes to convince the country, and a largely skeptical world, that Saddam Hussein will never voluntarily disarm, leaving war as the only remaining answer.

title: Corrections
description: An article and an entry in the News Summary on Saturday about an ethics investigation concerning Lloyd Ward, chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee, referred imprecisely to a report on the case by a panel headed by Kenneth M. Duberstein. On Jan. 13 the panel found that Mr. Ward had ''created the appearance of a conflict of interest'' by directing a staff member to help advance a business proposal by a company run by his brother, and that he should have disclosed what he had done. Mr. Ward was not ''exonerated'' -- either by the ethics panel or by Mr. Duberstein personally.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: A PACT WITH JEWS The government signed an agreement with the country's leading Jewish organization, putting their relations on a formal legal footing and giving the organization the same legal status as the predominant churches. The signing of the accord by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and Paul Spiegel, above, head of the Central Council of Jews, came on the 58th anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz death camp. Mr. Spiegel called the treaty a milestone for the 100,000 Jews in Germany, and Mr. Schroder said it was a sign of the Jewish community's trust in German society. The government will provide $3.3 million annually to help train rabbis and teach Jewish rites.

title: War and Diplomacy: A Week of Decision on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Iran to Lift House Arrest For Dissident After 5 Years
description: In a surprise move, Iran will release its most senior dissident cleric from the house arrest that was imposed on him five years ago, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported today.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Justice For Women
description: President Hosni Mubarak announced the appointment of the country's first woman to serve as a judge. The appointment by presidential decree of a lawyer, Tahani el-Gebaly, as a judge on the Constitutional Supreme Court, is expected to end a decades-old debate over the right of women to become judges. Samar Aboul-Fotouh (NYT)

title: 'Illinois Miracle' Disputed After Child-Abuse Cases
description: Six adults were arrested and 12 children taken to emergency shelters this weekend in two incidents that horrified the authorities and renewed criticism of Illinois' child-welfare system, denounced a decade ago as a national nightmare but now heralded as a national model.

title: The Iraq Report
description: The mixed report on Iraqi weapons compliance presented yesterday by the United Nations' two chief weapons inspectors begins an intense week of diplomacy and decision-making on the next steps in the international campaign to disarm Saddam Hussein. Their findings argue strongly for giving the inspectors more time to pursue their efforts and satisfy international opinion that every reasonable step has been taken to solve this problem peacefully. As President Bush has repeatedly said, war, if it comes to that, must be a last resort.

title: Net Up at Military Concern
description: United Defense Industries Inc., a maker of Army vehicles and naval guns, said today that fourth-quarter profit rose more than sevenfold as the acquisition of a ship-repair company helped to make up for the cancellation of its $11 billion Crusader cannon program.

title: 41 Nobel Laureates Sign Declaration Against a War Without International Support
description: Forty-one American Nobel laureates in science and economics issued a declaration yesterday opposing a preventive war against Iraq without wide international support. The statement, four sentences long, argues that an American attack would ultimately hurt the security and standing of the United States, even if it succeeds.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Chatty Kathy

title: Super Buildup, But Unfulfilled Expectations
description: The Advertising Bowl inside this year's Super Bowl was perhaps the most cinematic ever. So why then did the evening seem more like ''Plan 9 From Outer Space'' than ''Citizen Kane''?

title: John Browning, 69, Pianist With Reserved, Elegant Style
description: John Browning, a leading light in a pioneering older generation of American pianists of seemingly limitless promise, died on Sunday at his home in Sister Bay, Wis. He was 69.

title: 4 Dress Rehearsals, And President Is Set For State of the Union
description: President Bush had two dress rehearsals today for his State of the Union speech, one in the morning and another in the late afternoon, as he put finishing touches on another address that the capital is once again calling the speech of his life.

title: The Sounds of Ethiopia, With a Hint of Mississippi
description: Music from Ethiopia rarely makes its way to New York concert stages. But when it did in a World Music Institute concert on Saturday night in the Great Hall at Cooper Union, it sounded oddly familiar, with the dance-floor drive of Delta blues and Appalachian hoedowns.

title: Gaming the Games
description: More enduring than the Olympic flame is the seamy context of scandal, tooth-and-claw politicking and world-class mismanagement that finds the United States Olympic Committee bumbling its way toward the Games in Athens next year. There is an urgent need to restructure the unwieldy committee and restore its focus to athletic competition rather than the turf combat and flirtation with corruption that have become its hallmark.

title: Man vs. Chess Machine
description: To the Editor:

title: War and Diplomacy: A Week of Decision on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: FAO SEEKS APPROVAL OF WORKER-RETENTION PLAN
description: FAO Inc., owner of the F. A. O. Schwarz and Zany Brainy toy-store chains, asked a bankruptcy court to approve a $2 million employee retention plan that includes $750,000 for the chief executive, Jerry Welch. The plan would pay 15 senior managers bonuses totaling $1.65 million, including Mr. Welch's bonus, while lower-level managers would share as much as $350,000, according to court papers filed Friday in bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del. The managers would be paid for staying with the company through its reorganization or until all assets are sold, court papers said. FAO sought bankruptcy Jan. 13 after failing to get easier credit terms.

title: STANDARD & POOR'S CUTS CREDIT OUTLOOK OF AT&T
description: The outlook for the credit rating of the AT&T Corporation was cut to negative by Standard & Poor's, which cited a drop in revenue from business customers. S.& P. reduced the outlook on $22.6 billion of AT&T debt from stable, indicating that the next move in the rating, though not imminent, would be lower. AT&T's long-term debt is rated BBB+ by S.& P., the third-lowest of 10 investment-grade levels. Fourth-quarter sales of phone, data and Internet service to companies, which accounts for two-thirds of sales, fell 3 percent, AT&T said last week. AT&T also said annual sales would fall for a fourth consecutive year in 2003.

title: Man Who Made '60 Minutes' To Make Way for New Blood
description: It has been no secret: CBS has been trying to ease out Don Hewitt, the founder and executive producer of ''60 Minutes.'' It wanted new blood. But the 80-year-old news executive said he would be carried out only in a wooden box.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Credit Card Bid
description: The largest processor of credit card transactions in the United States, the First Data Corporation, offered 91.6 million euros ($99.4 million) to buy an Irish credit card processor, the Alphyra Group, topping a bid made by the company's executives. First Data, which is based in Greenwood Village, Colo., made a preliminary offer of 2.80 euros a share and is in advanced talks with the company, Alphyra said. The offer is 14 percent more than Alphyra's management bid of 2.45 euros a share.

title: Murky Cloning Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Quick Exit: Loose Lip-Syncers Sink Hopes
description: At 11 on Wednesday night hundreds of people filed out of Irving Plaza, wondering if they had missed something. They had paid $50 for an evening of naughty fun, but what they got was neither fun nor naughty nor an evening. The show, which lasted about a half-hour, consisted mainly of women in shiny underwear wiggling their rear ends while lip-syncing (or worse, singing) show tunes.

title: The City Life; An Ice-Breaking Commute
description: I was late to work yesterday because my ferryboat was stuck in the ice. It wasn't exactly Sir Ernest Henry Shackleton's doomed Antarctic expedition of 1914, in which the Endurance was ultimately devoured by the ice. Still, it was certainly a different way of experiencing the Hudson River.

title: Iraq, Denouncing the U.S., Says It Has Done All It Can to Avoid a War
description: Iraq made a scathing attack on the United States today hours before a United Nations report on weapons inspections was delivered in New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Extended Federal Aid Urged
description: Local elected officials and community groups demanded yesterday that the Federal Emergency Management Agency extend a housing assistance program that is to expire on Friday. The FEMA program, started shortly after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks, has paid almost $100 million to nearly 11,000 applicants who lived or worked in Manhattan and have faced eviction or foreclosure. But, the officials said, the deadline should be extended, partly because of New York's continuing economic problems, and partly because the program has not done enough to reach out to potential applicants throughout the metropolitan area. The officials included Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Manhattan Democrat; William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller; and the Rev. Thomas W. Goodhue, executive director of the Long Island Council of Churches.

title: War and Diplomacy: A Week of Decision on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: A 9/11 Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Satellites Uncover Ancient Mideast Road Networks
description: In photographs taken by once-secret American surveillance satellites, traces of the buried past show through the arid surface of the Middle East like pentimento. The traces are as intriguing to archaeologists as the ghostly painted-over layers on a canvas are to art historians.

title: War and Diplomacy: A Week of Decision on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard Times: The Arts vs. the Iron Fiscal Fist
description: Peter B. Lewis recently exercised his philanthropic muscle by threatening Thomas Krens, the director of the Guggenheim Museum, with the loss of his job unless he sharply cut his budget. That bold move has been applauded not only by corporate hard-liners but also by the art establishment and the art press. The feeling seems to be that Mr. Krens, apparently disliked for his expansionism, his arrogance and his curatorial taste, has been put in his place.

title: Old Mexico for a New Generation; A Tiny Academy Teaches Children the Joys of Mariachi
description: The academy is in a cluttered, battered basement that also houses a karate school. But on this weeknight, surrounded by exercise equipment and drawings of martial arts fighters, six boys and four girls sat in a semicircle strumming guitars to the waltzy beat of a mariachi song.

title: Anti-French Rioting Rages On in Ivory Coast; Major Port Shut
description: Government supporters rioted for a second day today in the streets of Abidjan, Ivory Coast's main city, venting their anger with an accord signed on Saturday in Paris to end Ivoirians' civil conflict.

title: Excerpts from the State of the Union Address
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of President Bush's State of the Union address released by the White House.

title: BOYS' GUILT LIKELY IN RAPE OF JOGGER, POLICE PANEL SAYS
description: A panel commissioned by the New York City Police Department concluded yesterday that there was no misconduct in the 1989 investigation of the Central Park jogger case, and said that five Harlem men whose convictions were thrown out by a judge last month had ''most likely'' participated in the beating and rape of the jogger.

title: Valery Brumel Is Dead at 60; Russian Set High-Jump Marks
description: Valery Brumel, a Russian who during the cold war became perhaps the best high jumper in history but had his world-class career end when he almost lost a leg in a motorcycle accident, died Sunday in a Moscow hospital. He was 60.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Construction Merger
description: Sacyr, a Spanish builder, is in talks to merge with a leading real estate developer, Vallehermoso valuing Sacyr at as much as 1.27 billion euros ($1.4 billion). Vallehermoso will issue new shares worth 962 million euros ($1 billion) at Friday's closing price to merge with Sacyr, Vallehermoso's biggest shareholder. The boards of the companies plan to consider the deal tomorrow, according to a note to market regulators.

title: Changing Of Guard At W.H.O.
description: When she took charge of the World Health Organization four and a half years ago, Dr. Gro Harlem Brundtland was certain that she would move health issues to the top of the global agenda and leave her no-nonsense imprint on the giant, troubled agency.

title: Belgrade Journal; A Wartime Star Endures, Singing to a Torn Serbia
description: It would be difficult to find a more divisive figure in Serbia than Svetlana Raznatovic and her come-hither cleavage.

title: Britain Steps Up Pressure on Iraq
description: LONDON, Jan. 28  Britain today accused Iraq of being in "material breach" of the disarmament conditions laid down by the United Nations, echoing Washington's words to justify war against the regime of Saddam Hussein.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Challenge On Pollution Rules
description: The state challenged the Bush administration over its new clean air regulations, taking issue with the rules that nine Northeastern states oppose. The acting secretary of environmental protection, Kathleen A. McGinty, said Pennsylvania filed its petition because it had its own priorities and interests about the Environmental Protection Agency plan, to take effect on March 3. The plan would make it easier for factories and refineries to modernize without buying expensive pollution controls. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Steadfast in His Turban, A Lawyer Raises Awareness
description: When guards at Brooklyn's Metropolitan Detention Center demanded last September that a Newark lawyer let them search his turban before being admitted to visit a client, they may have not have known much about the traditions of his Sikh faith.

title: Mayor Dueling With Governor On Solutions To Shortfall
description: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki prepare to release their plans this week to close multibillion-dollar budget gaps, they are coming into conflict about how New York State should go about helping New York City.

title: Journalism Or Gossip?; A Horse-Whisperer's Tale Trails Dominick Dunne
description: Dominick Dunne began telling his tale of Gary Condit, Chandra Levy, the horse whisperer and the Middle Eastern procurer sometime in the fall of 2001. It was tantalizingly baroque; Mr. Dunne, the Vanity Fair columnist, mesmerized a group of New England newspaper editors with it over lunch at Foxwoods Resort Casino in Connecticut in November 2001.

title: Georgia's Flag Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Afghan Border, Warnings of Attacks Tied to Iraq War
description: Hundreds of Qaeda fighters and Taliban supporters -- now living with families in the rugged tribal area of South Waziristan in Pakistan -- are planning to intensify their attacks on Afghan territory if war breaks out in Iraq, interviews with three visitors from Pakistani tribal area indicate.

title: Israeli Voters Putting Security Issues First
description: It was a sunny, breezy, beautiful day, but only a handful of people walked the central shopping area here.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: APPROVAL SOUGHT FOR NOMINEE TO MICROSOFT PANEL The federal judge who approved Microsoft's antitrust settlement with the government was asked yesterday to appoint Edward Stritter, a computer scientist, to a committee that will oversee the company's compliance. Mr. Stritter, former director of business development for Cisco Systems' wireless unit, was nominated by the other two prospective members of the panel. The Justice Department asked Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly to name Mr. Stritter along with the other two panel members, Harry Saal, a software industry executive, and Franklin Fite Jr., a former Microsoft manager. Mr. Saal was nominated by the government and Mr. Fite by Microsoft. The panel will referee complaints by competitors and customers that Microsoft is not complying with the terms of the settlement, negotiated after an appeals court upheld findings that the company illegally protected its Windows monopoly. Microsoft shares dropped 68 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $49.17.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by newspaper editors to use Internet technology to weed out form letters from political organizations misstated the surname of an editorial writer for The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, who discussed a form letter from the Republican National Committee that appealed to many papers. She is J. R. Labbe, not Hill.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Mentor Posts Profit As Sales Increase
description: The Mentor Graphics Corporation, a maker of software used to design semiconductors, reported a fourth-quarter profit yesterday as sales to aerospace, military and consumer-electronics customers rose. The shares rose as much as 12 percent. The company had net income of $18.7 million, or 28 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $4.83 million, or 7 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 8.9 percent, to $180.1 million from $165.3 million. Business systems bookings increased 85 percent over the period a year earlier, led by orders from military, aerospace and consumer-electronics customers, the chief executive, Walden Rhines, said. After the report was released, the shares rose as high as $9 but ended the day with a loss of 32 cents, at $8.06. The stock has declined 69 percent in the last year.

title: Democrats Don't Wait for Bush's Speech to Criticize His Policies
description: President Bush was still working on his State of the Union address today, but that did not stop the two leading Democrats in Congress from rebutting it in advance in sharply critical speeches that accused the president of building a ''credibility gap'' between his words and actions.

title: With Strengths on Display, UConn Controls the Tempo
description: Connecticut has another talented and deep team this season, and the Huskies displayed many of their strengths in last night's 74-68 victory over St. John's at Madison Square Garden.

title: Ants, Mushroom and Mold: An Evolutionary Arms Race
description: One of the most remarkable examples of symbiosis, the interdependence of different species, involves a tropical ant called the attine, or leaf-cutter. The ants grow a mushroomlike fungus in vast underground gardens, and they protect the fungus against a devastating mold with antibiotics produced by a bacterium that lives in a patch on their skin.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: CONVICTION UPHELD IN BOMB PLOT A federal appeals panel in Manhattan yesterday upheld the conviction and 24-year sentence of Mokhtar Haouari, an Algerian who assisted in a terrorist plot to bomb Los Angeles International Airport during the 2000 millennium celebrations. Mr. Haouari provided a fake driver's license and cash in the plot, according to the testimony of Ahmed Ressam, who was to have carried out the attack but was arrested as he entered the United States from Canada in December 1999. Mr. Haouari was convicted of conspiracy and four counts of fraud. The conviction was upheld by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: U.N. Inspector Says Iraq Falls Short on Cooperation
description: Hans Blix, one of the chief United Nations weapons inspectors, gave a broadly negative report today on Iraq's cooperation with two months of inspections, providing support to the Bush administration's campaign to disarm Iraq by force if necessary.

title: Although Possible War Looms, Airlines Step Up Flights to U.S.
description: Despite the prospect of a war sure to cut sharply into international travel, airlines around the world are increasing service to and from the United States  especially over the Atlantic  as the battered industry presses its desperate hunt for profits.

title: Jackson Was the Surprise Inside the Box
description: Last season, Dexter Jackson did not feel like a part of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' defense. Sure, he was there at free safety replacing Damien Robinson, who had gone to the Jets, but Jackson was always used in the deep third of the field, never up into the action.

title: New Leaders Of Schools Are Called Demanding
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg named the 10 regional superintendents for the city's overhauled school system yesterday, choosing long-time New York City school administrators with reputations as demanding leaders.

title: War and Diplomacy: A Week of Decision on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article and an entry in the News Summary on Saturday about an ethics investigation concerning Lloyd Ward, chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee, referred imprecisely to a report on the case by a panel headed by Kenneth M. Duberstein. On Jan. 13 the panel found that Mr. Ward had ''created the appearance of a conflict of interest'' by directing a staff member to help advance a business proposal by a company run by his brother, and that he should have disclosed what he had done. Mr. Ward was not ''exonerated'' -- either by the ethics panel or by Mr. Duberstein personally.

title: Even in the Age of Prozac, Some Still Prefer the Couch
description: Four days a week, Rachel H. takes the subway uptown, waves to the doorman in the large prewar apartment building where her psychoanalyst keeps his office, lies down on a burgundy leather couch and begins to talk.

title: The Ice Is Old, but the Debate Is New
description: Lying like a beached whale in the middle of this vast area, a huge slab of ice lies below a three-foot-thick layer of rocks and boulders. Scientists say it is the world's oldest ice, a buried remnant of a monster glacier that passed by 12 million to 15 million years ago.

title: Pataki Pledges Fight Against Taxes as He Prepares Budget Proposal
description: Gov. George E. Pataki finished a series of speeches today intended to stake out his position as an antitax conservative before the battle over the state budget begins in earnest when he announces his spending plan on Wednesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: CBS and Don Hewitt Agree On a Change at '60 Minutes'

title: Delighting in Ruination With AIDS
description: DORIAN

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wachovia plans a strategy to invade the territory of big city banks like Citigroup and Chase.
description: THOUGH still digesting its merger with the First Union Corporation, the Wachovia Corporation is expanding into New York and other consumer banking markets.

title: Pataki Would End S.U.V. Tax Break in State
description: Even as he announces plans this week to expand some tax breaks for small businesses, Gov. George E. Pataki will propose taking away at least one: a provision that allows business owners and the self-employed to claim sizable deductions for buying giant sport utility vehicles.

title: Raiders Show Their Age, And Now Must Pay for It
description: The theme of the Raiders' season was that the team was built to win now, to leave the salary cap and the Geritol in the rearview mirror and make one last run at the Super Bowl. It was a narrow window of opportunity for an aging team, and now that it has slammed shut, it might not be pried open for a while.

title: Dragila Wants World Record Back
description: As always, Stacy Dragila sounded cheerful. She would have been more so if she were still the indoor world record-holder in the pole vault.

title: Stocks Plunge On Concerns About Iraq And Economy
description: Stocks fell on Wall Street and abroad yesterday as investors faced a week packed with uncertainty about a war with Iraq, the outlook for corporate earnings and the economy over all.

title: Service Academies Defend Use of Race in Their Admissions Policies
description: Even as the Bush administration sides with opponents of affirmative action at the University of Michigan, officials of the nation's service academies say their own minority admissions programs are necessary to maintain both integrated student bodies and officer corps.

title: As Winners, Bucs Can Rewrite History
description: Warren Sapp walked into a large tent outside Qualcomm Stadium on Sunday night -- he was hard to miss in his extra-wide fire-engine-red Buccaneers jersey -- and he immediately asked for a rewrite of history.

title: Nobel Laureates Sign Against a War Without International Support
description: Forty-one American Nobel laureates in science and economics issued a declaration yesterday opposing a preventive war against Iraq without wide international support. The statement, four sentences long, argues that an American attack would ultimately hurt the security and standing of the United States, even if it succeeds.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: University Hires President
description: The University of Alabama board hired a president, Robert E. Witt, 62, president of the University of Texas at Arlington. Mr. Witt, who starts his job on March 1, succeeds the interim president, Barry Mason, who returns to his position as dean of the business school. The president at Alabama last year, Andrew Sorensen, became president of the University of South Carolina. Mr. Witt's salary was not released. At Texas, he was paid $323,000 a year. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Billions and Billions Fed
description: To the Editor:

title: War and Diplomacy: A Week of Decision on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Rules F.C.C. Took Licenses Away in Error
description: The Federal Communications Commission had no right to cancel the valuable wireless communications licenses that a bankrupt company had won at auction and then could not pay for, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Hybrid Autos Quick to Pass Curiosity Stage
description: Hybrids, vehicles that save gasoline by combining electric motors with internal combustion engines, are emerging as the first alternative-powered cars to show signs of catching on with automakers and some consumers since the automobile's early days.

title: Europe Acts Against U.S. Effort on Ports
description: The European Union is taking legal action against four member countries for breaking ranks and signing up for a United States program meant to prevent the use of cargo containers by terrorists.

title: Deutsche Telekom Is Expected To Sell 6 Cable TV Networks
description: Deutsche Telekom is planning to announce today that it has agreed to sell six regional cable-television networks to a group of American investors for 1.725 billion euros, or about $1.87 billion, according to executives close to the negotiations.

title: Heading for the Airport, Nets Win a Ragged One
description: Less of a reward for a week in the West that felt like a month to the Nets, and more of a scheduling necessity, the Nuggets represented the only obstacle between the Nets and their charter to New Jersey tonight.

title: European Nations Fall Short Of Consensus on Iraq Report
description: At the headquarters of the European Union today, foreign ministers of the 15 member nations even succeeded -- briefly -- in forging a common reaction to the reports by the chief United Nations weapons inspectors in Iraq, signing on to a statement drafted by the four members now sitting on the United Nations Security Council -- Britain, France, Germany and Spain.

title: A Credibility Problem
description: Will tonight's State of the Union address restore George W. Bush's political fortunes?

title: War and Diplomacy: A Week of Decision on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: State of the Union Address
description: Following is the prepared text of President Bush's State of the Union address released by the White House.

title: Air Canada Selling Stake In Customer Reward Plan
description: Demonstrating that frequent-flier programs are as valuable to cash-hungry airlines as to their points-hungry passengers, Air Canada said today that it would raise $161 million (United States) through the sale of a 35 percent stake in its Aeroplan loyalty program.

title: A Cancer Regimen Abandoned
description: Doctors treating breast cancer patients often fail to use chemotherapy as frequently as federal guidelines recommend, especially when patients are older, a study reports. The older the woman is, researchers found, the less likely she is to be given the treatment.

title: More Viewers For Super Bowl
description: Tampa Bay's 48-21 blowout of Oakland in Super Bowl XXXVII on ABC Sunday night attracted 137.6 million viewers, the second-highest number for the N.F.L.'s championship game. The most watched Super Bowl was the Pittsburgh-Dallas matchup seven years ago, with 138.5 million viewers.

title: Shipwreck in the Gulf Clings Tenaciously to Its Mysteries
description: Those who believe in ghosts might conclude that those aboard a shipwreck at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico do not want to be disturbed.

title: Declaw All Cats
description: To the Editor:

title: A Financial Sign of the Times
description: On a cold, windy, snowy evening, 18,241 fans filed into the Corel Center last Saturday to cheer for the Senators, who had the best record in the N.H.L.

title: Library of Congress Begins Effort to Protect Recordings
description: The Library of Congress, in its first step to preserve American sound recordings that span the last century, said today that it had selected 50 recordings to start a national registry.

title: Labor Party Leader Concedes Defeat in Israeli Election
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 28 - Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and his Likud party won decisively in this country's parliamentary election today as Israelis endorsed his tough approach to a bloody conflict with Palestinians that has ground on for more than two years.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: A Pact With Jews
description: The government signed an agreement with the country's leading Jewish organization, putting their relations on a formal legal footing and giving the organization the same legal status as the predominant churches. The signing of the accord by Chancellor Gerhard Schrder and Paul Spiegel, above, head of the Central Council of Jews, came on the 58th anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz death camp. Mr. Spiegel called the treaty a milestone for the 100,000 Jews in Germany, and Mr. Schrder said it was a sign of the Jewish community's trust in German society. The government will provide $3.3 million annually to help train rabbis and teach Jewish rites. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Whose Life, Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixing Pregnancy With Cocktails
description: Fifteen percent of pregnant women surveyed as they waited in clinics for prenatal care said they had drunk alcohol during pregnancy, a new study reports.

title: In Manila, Kidnapping as a Business Expense
description: For this city's affluent ethnic Chinese business executives, kidnapping has been a fact of life -- an almost ritual form of extortion.

title: Sifting Through the Online Medical Jumble
description: Those who have combed the Internet for mainstream medical advice have, no doubt, been barraged with far more information than they could possibly want: scientific articles and pseudoscience; anecdotes of personal triumphs and tragedies; references to books and videos; and, of course, online support groups.

title: Review/Fashion; The Straight and Not So Narrow
description: ''Habill, habill, habill,'' chanted Tom Ford, using the French word for attire, as the fall 2003 men's collections swept out the shabby for the chic. But how to dress -- that is the question that had designers knocking themselves out over the weekend as mere mortals discussed war.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON SETTLES PATENT SUIT FOR $15 MILLION
description: Johnson & Johnson will pay $15 million and future royalties to settle a lawsuit claiming it infringed a patent for a screw used in spinal implants. Interpore International sued the DePuy AcroMed Inc. unit of Johnson & Johnson, saying the business used technology protected by Interpore patents. DePuy agreed to settle after a federal judge in Santa Ana, Calif., ruled against it, Interpore said. Analysts said the agreement might add as much as 19 cents a share to 2003 earnings and help the company claim more of the market for spinal implants.

title: A Goal for Ground Zero: Finding an Urban Poetry
description: Sometimes we actually do acknowledge poets to be legislators of the world. One of those rare moments may be here. As early as tomorrow, officials of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation are expected to choose one or two designs for the next phase of planning the future of ground zero. What if the decision were up to you?

title: F.B.I. Tells Offices to Count Local Muslims and Mosques
description: The F.B.I. is ordering field supervisors to count the number of mosques and Muslims in their areas as part of the antiterrorism effort.

title: Sharon Has Big Edge in Election Today, With Hard Coalition Task Ahead
description: Polls published today affirmed that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel is likely to retain his post in elections on Tuesday, and then to face the complex challenge of assembling a durable coalition from a fragmented Parliament.

title: NextWave Victory May Not Prove Too Lucrative
description: Investors cheered the Supreme Court victory of NextWave Telecom, sending the company's shares up 22 percent yesterday. But the ruling may end up being much less lucrative than the company and its founder and chief executive, Allen B. Salmasi, might have previously hoped.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Exports Rise
description: Industrial production in Singapore rose at its fastest pace in two years in December, helping avoid a recession, as drug factories more than doubled their output. Factory production expanded 19 percent from a year earlier, rebounding from a revised decline of 1.1 percent in November. From the previous month, production gained 6.6 percent, seasonally adjusted. Exports of electronics, which account for 60 percent of Singapore's exports, increased 15.6 percent, but officials said that was not enough to be considered a recovery in the industry.

title: 3 Charged in Kidnapping, Assault and Rape of 17-Year-Old
description: A Westchester woman, her husband and her brother have been charged in the kidnapping, assault and rape of a 17-year-old girl who the police said was lured from a relative's home in the Bronx and imprisoned in a Mount Kisco apartment.

title: A Mother's Last Words, An Actress's Memories
description: Now one of France's most admired stage actresses, Catherine Samie was barely 10 when she accompanied her mother in leading Jews along mountain paths to escape from Nazi-occupied France into Switzerland. They would go ahead, so that if stopped, the Jews could flee. But one night near the Swiss border, she recalled, a Jewish mother and her child were intercepted by a German patrol.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Judicial Revision
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, amended a Second Amendment decision issued last month to delete references to the work of a controversial scholar. The decision, which upheld California gun control laws, had cited two articles by Michael A. Bellesiles, who resigned as a history professor at Emory University after an academic panel had issued a report critical of his research for a book about the history of guns in America. The court did not explain why it ordered the deletions, which did not affect the ruling. Legal experts called the move quite unusual. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: College Loans Rise, Swamping Graduates' Dreams
description: Every so often, when the phones grow quiet and the copiers still, Margot E. Miles glances at the lawyers devouring cases around her and thinks: ''I could do that. I would love to do that.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Arrest In Killing Of Police Chief
description: State radio said that the suspected leader of a Maoist hit squad that assassinated the head of the country's Armed Police on Sunday had been arrested, Reuters reported. The official, Mohan Shrestha, left, was the highest ranking government official killed in the six-year insurgency. His wife and a bodyguard were also shot dead as they walked on the outskirts of Katmandu. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Findings Of U.N. Group Undercut U.S. Assertion
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency's report that Iraq has not resumed its nuclear program has challenged one of the Bush administration's main arguments for taking military action to topple the Iraqi government.

title: India Will Sell Stakes in 2 State-Owned Oil Companies
description: BANGALORE, India, Jan. 27  The Indian government restarted its stalled privatization program on Sunday, approving the sale of stakes in two asset-rich oil companies that had been blocked for months by political wrangling.

title: Bloomberg Unveils Budget
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg outlined a plan today to close a $3.4 billion budget gap next year that continues to rely heavily on help beyond the city's control, from state permission to impose a commuter tax to significant union concessions.

description: The Albany County district attorney has begun a formal criminal inquiry into the dealings of a private prison company that gained millions of dollars in state work while extending favors to several state lawmakers.

title: Azeri Outdistances Male Rivals for Top Award
description: Azeri's credentials may have been a bit flawed, but in an imperfect year, that did not seem to matter to an overwhelming majority of Horse of the Year voters. Beating out a lackluster group of male rivals, Azeri was named the 2002 Horse of the Year in ceremonies last night in Beverly Hills, Calif.

description: Ahmed Chalabi, an Iraqi opposition leader, announced today that he intends to travel to Iraq shortly to meet other opposition leaders and plan a provisional government to replace the regime of Saddam Hussein.

description: When British Telecom claimed in 2000 that it had patented the Web's ubiquitous hyperlink, the Internet erupted in a fit of protest that lasted until the company lost its test infringement case against Prodigy Communications last summer.

description: I was 13 and walking home from school on a residential street when a car pulled over to the curb next to me. The driver, a man of about 45, leaned over and opened the passenger door and called out to me: ''I dropped my keys and can't seem to find them. Can you please help me?''

description: Eddy Toledo, the director of the Mets' Dominican operations, called out in Spanish to the young players to gather around Fred Wilpon, the team's owner. With Toledo as his interpreter, Wilpon told the teenagers to work hard, to be proud of wearing a Mets uniform and representing their country, and to be good citizens.

title: China's Coal Miners Risk Danger for a Better Wage
description: Liu Fengtong does not need reminding that it is perilous to dig for coal in Chinese mines. He broke his foot and his shoulder when a tunnel collapsed on him six years ago, and he lost his front teeth when a rock fell on his face a few years later.

title: Explosion in a Gaza House Kills 2 Teenagers; Cause Is Disputed
description: Two teenagers were killed and 11 other people were injured just before midnight on Monday when an explosion tore through a house near Gaza City that belonged to a member of the militant Islamic group Hamas, hospital officials and a Hamas political leader said.

description: Doctors need to be much more aggressive in treating high blood pressure in people with diabetes, a new study says. Diabetics are three times as likely as the general population to have elevated readings.

title: Fans Pack the Home Stadium to Cheer Their Buccaneers
description: Giddy with joy and button-popping pride, Malcolm Glazer, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' owner, resembled the leader of a brass band as he led the procession of his Super Bowl championship team into Raymond James Stadium tonight. Holding the Vince Lombardi Trophy above his head, Glazer began the celebration this city had waited 27 years to hold.

title: PHARMACIA SATISFIES A CONDITION FOR SALE TO PFIZER
description: The Pharmacia Corporation will give up the rights to an experimental impotence drug to satisfy a condition for the company's acquisition by Pfizer. Pharmacia will return the rights for the drug, intranasal apomorphine, to the Nastech Pharmaceutical Company after the companies agreed almost a year ago to develop the nasal spray. Nastech will also get a $13.5 million payment, a Pharmacia spokesman, Paul Fitzhenry, said. Regulators in the United States and Europe are examining Pfizer's planned purchase of Pharmacia for about $54 billion. The Federal Trade Commission told Pharmacia to sell the product because the combination of the two drug makers would control too much of the market, Mr. Fitzhenry said. Pfizer makes the top-selling impotence treatment Viagra.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Vodafone Adds 4.9 Million Subscribers
description: The Vodafone Group, the world's biggest mobile phone company, said yesterday that the number of subscribers rose 4.7 percent in the fiscal third quarter, aided by the introduction of services like photo messaging. Vodafone added 4.9 million customers in the three months ended Dec. 31, almost twice as many as some analysts expected, taking the total number of subscribers to 112.5 million. Average revenue per subscriber also rose last year in Britain, Germany and Italy, the chief executive, Chris Gent, said on a conference call. Vodafone is the first European wireless company to release subscriber numbers after introducing services like games, e-mail and photo messaging. European mobile companies anticipate that such services will help them recoup the $100 billion they spent on permits to provide faster wireless services.

description: Out of timidity or reticence, television shows about combat used to stick to wars that could be explored at a safe remove; even ''M*A*S*H'' was set in Korea, not Vietnam.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: VIETNAM: FISH TRADE DISPUTE In a preliminary finding, the Bush administration ruled that Vietnamese catfish farmers are guilty of dumping discount-priced frozen fish on the market in the United States and could be liable for import duties as high as 63 percent. In what is becoming a major trade war, American catfish farmers have persuaded Congress to bar Vietnam from using the name catfish for their exports and then filed the suit that led to yesterday's decision by the Commerce Department. For their part, the Vietnamese have condemned the suit as "an unfair, protectionist act" and a violation of the new trade agreement with the United States. They said their fish were priced lower because Vietnamese labor costs far less than American labor. In the last three years, Vietnamese catfish exports have soared from $13 million to $55 million, capturing 20 percent of the American market. A final decision is expected in June. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: J. Crew Getting New Chief And Maybe His Gap Magic
description: Millard S. Drexler, the charismatic retail executive who made Gap famous, will now lead J. Crew, the floundering merchant of preppy clothing, which has had four chief executives in the last five years.

title: Finding Martian Landscapes, Here on Earth
description: Scientists who study Mars have been coming here for 30 years to learn how an ultracold, bone dry climate shapes the terrestrial, and perhaps Martian, landscape. But they never, until now, thought about monster glaciers that vanish like phantoms in the night.

title: Struggling Canada Looking for Answers
description: The last time BRUCE WILSON wore a jersey sporting a red maple leaf was also the last time Canada played in a major tournament.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, picture captions on Saturday about the Czech president, Vaclav Havel, misstated the date of his state visit to Germany and the date when pranksters covered part of a neon sign on Prague Castle. Mr. Havel was in Berlin on Jan. 17, not last Friday. The prank occurred on Jan. 14, not last week.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ruling A Blow To Nuclear Program
description: A court dealt a severe blow to the country's nuclear energy program, upholding the suspension of operations at an accident-plagued experimental reactor. The ruling by the Nagoya High Court on behalf of local residents, the first of its kind against nuclear reactor operations in Japan, nullified the central government's approval to operate the Monju plant, a so-called fast-breeder. ''It's virtually impossible now to resume operations at Monju,'' Miwako Ogiso, a representative of the plaintiffs, said at a news conference. The $6 billion reactor has been shut since a huge leak of sodium coolant in December 1995, but the government has intended to resume operations. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: ADVANTA TOLD TO PAY $29 MILLION TO FLEETBOSTON
description: The Advanta Corporation, a provider of credit cards to small businesses, must pay $29.4 million for duping the FleetBoston Financial Corporation into overpaying for a consumer credit card unit, a Delaware judge ruled. FleetBoston sued Advanta in Delaware Chancery Court in 1999 for understating liabilities in the sale and failing to disclose problems in coding the correct interest rates on accounts. The coding problem later forced FleetBoston to refund $41.8 million, according to court papers. In the Delaware case, Judge Jack B. Jacobs found that FleetBoston, which sought $141 million in damages over problems tied to the sale, was entitled to only $30.2 million. The judge awarded Advanta, which is based in Spring Hill, Pa., $854,907 on a counterclaim, reducing FleetBoston's verdict to $29.4 million.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I2 Technologies May Restate Some Results
description: A maker of software to help companies manage inventories and track shipments, I2 Technologies Inc., said yesterday that it might restate the last two years' results, and the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating how the company accounts for sales. Deloitte & Touche will reaudit the company's 2000 and 2001 results after allegations from two unnamed former executives about how sales were recorded, the software maker said. The audit firm, which replaced Arthur Andersen as I2's auditor in May, is trying to complete the work and its audit of 2002 results by the end of March, the company said. Companies and auditors are scrutinizing sales accounting after Enron's collapse. Software makers including SkillSoft, Peregrine Systems Inc. and Transaction Systems Architects Inc. have said they will restate results because of improperly booked sales. I2 shares fell 34 cents, or 27 percent, to 92 cents.

description: Freddie Mac, the buyer of home loans, said today that fourth-quarter profit rose 25 percent because it increased mortgage investments and benefited from low borrowing costs.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Global Hand-Held Computer Sales Fell In 2002
description: Global sales of hand-held computers fell 9.1 percent last year as businesses cut spending on computer-related products amid slowing economies, a market research company said yesterday. Worldwide shipments declined to 12.1 million units in 2002, Dataquest Inc., a unit of Gartner Inc., said in an e-mailed statement. Shipments by Palm Inc., the world's largest maker of hand-held computers, declined 12 percent last year, Dataquest said. Sales were hurt by the ''slow adoption'' of hand-held computers by companies, a Dataquest analyst, Todd Kort, said in the statement. Hand-held computer makers like Palm have been expanding their product lines for businesses to try to increase revenue at a time that consumers are reining in expenses. In the United States, shipments of hand-held computers declined 7.5 percent in 2002, Dataquest said. Palm's market share worldwide declined to 36.8 percent in 2002 from 38.1 percent in 2001, Dataquest said. Hewlett-Packard, the world's No. 2 maker of hand-held computers, declined to 13.5 percent, compared with a share of 16.9 percent in 2001.

title: A Heady Week
description: TUESDAY President Bush is to deliver his State of the Union address, in which he is expected to explain why Saddam Hussein poses a threat to peace.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Schools Sued Over Student Transfers
description: Two mothers whose children attend city schools brought a class-action lawsuit against the Department of Education yesterday, charging that it has not complied with a federal law allowing students to transfer out of failing schools. The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, says the department violated the law by not granting transfers immediately to all students who requested them. Of the 6,400 students who sought transfers this year, fewer than 24 percent, or 1,507, were granted them, according to the department. The suit also accuses the department of providing too little extracurricular tutoring in failing schools. Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that he was working as quickly as possible to bring the department into compliance. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Expands
description: Japan's trade surplus hit 791 billion yen ($6.7 billion) in December, growing 19.9 percent compared with the month a year ago. Economists had expected the surplus to expand twice as fast, but more expensive imports of oil offset strong growth in exports of automobiles and equipment used to produce semiconductors. Japan's trade surplus with the United States grew 18.6 percent, to 624 billion yen. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: New Works for Philharmonic Season
description: The New York Philharmonic's 2003-4 season, which was announced yesterday at Avery Fisher Hall by Zarin Mehta, the executive director, and Lorin Maazel, the music director, is to include the world premieres of works by Stephen Hartke and Poul Ruders, as well as festivals devoted to the music of Charles Ives and Beethoven.

title: WorldCom Will Sell Canadian Ranch
description: WorldCom, the telecommunications company seeking to emerge from bankruptcy protection, said today that it would sell Canada's largest working ranch after taking it over from the company's former chief executive, Bernard J. Ebbers.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  President Bush's choice for Treasury secretary, John W. Snow, voiced strong faith today in the president's tax and economic policies and said that a strong dollar "is in the national interest."

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about plans by Kaiser Permanente to post online the treatment guidelines used by its doctors misstated the name of a company that sells such guidelines to managed care companies. It is EBM Solutions, not EBS.

title: China Executes a Tibetan in Connection With Bombing Attacks
description: A 28-year-old ethnic Tibetan accused of plotting bomb attacks was executed on Sunday, soon after an appeals court in Sichuan Province upheld his December conviction, officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Park Vendor Permits Are Protested
description: The City Council chamber was filled yesterday with artists and others who oppose a bill that would require vendors of written materials in city parks to obtain a permit. The bill, requested by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, would authorize the Parks Department to regulate the time, place and manner of the selling of written material, including art, in all city parks. In testimony yesterday, the parks commissioner, Adrian Benepe, recommended that a lottery be used to determine vending spaces and that artists pay a fee, like $25, to sell their goods. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Federal Funds to Build Churches
description: The Bush administration's campaign to merge church and state continued last week when it announced plans to allow federal housing money to be used to erect buildings in which religious services occur. Spending taxpayer money to build religious structures is a radical move, and one that defies long-established constitutional precedents. The new policy should be challenged and, if the administration refuses to withdraw it, struck down by the courts.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Redistricting Review Sought
description: The commission that redrew New Jersey's legislative districts voted 6 to 5 yesterday to ask the State Supreme Court to review an appeals court decision striking down the districts as unconstitutional. The ruling last week by an appellate court threatens to disrupt the coming election. All 120 seats in the Legislature are on the ballot, and candidates have only until April 7 to file. The commission, known as the State Legislative Apportionment Commission, has five Democrats, five Republicans and an independent member. The independent member voted with the Democrats for a review of the court ruling. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, MARTIN M.
description: BERGER-Martin M. The Saltaire community is grieved beyond measure at the death of Mayor Martin M. Berger Monday, January 27, 2003. As public servant and as a human being, Martin personified so much that evoked our admiration - brilliance and ability of mind, passion and thoughtfulness of cause, unshakable honesty and integrity of character. Martin guided our village through nine difficult years and many times that number of decisions, firing us with his intellect, hard work and perseverance. His sense of humor, his steadfast loyalty, his dedication to justice and fairness never wavered or fell short. A man of nobility and grace, he summoned always the best within us. You have left us, Martin, with both an unfillable void and a shining legacy. ''He nothing common did or mean, upon that memorable scene.'' Our heartfelt sympathies to Kathleen, Bethany, Rachel, Elissa and Sarah. The Administration and the Citizens of the Incorporated Village of Saltaire

Yahoo already says it offers the most popular free advertising-supported radio service with more than four million users a month. (There are no ratings for Internet radio.) title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Where's The Plutonium?
description: An official at the government's nuclear safety office said that more than 450 pounds of plutonium, enough to produce 25 or more nuclear bombs, was unaccounted for at a troubled nuclear complex at Tokaimura on the Pacific coast, but he blamed faulty measurements rather than criminal activity. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the case had been reported to the International Atomic Energy Agency. About 205 pounds is presumed to have dissolved into waste water without being measured, the official said, adding that another 64 pounds disintegrated into a different type of element. The rest may have ''stuck to fuel tubes or mixed with waste water being processed to be solidified in glass and disposed of.'' Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZILDJIAN, ARMAND
description: ZILDJIAN-Armand. Of Scottsdale, Arizona, and Quechee, Vermont (formerly Hingham, MA), President and Chairman of the Zildjian Company in Norwell, MA, died Thursday at his home in Scottsdale. He was 81. Born in Quincy, he attended local schools, including Thayer Academy and Colgate University until called to serve in the Philippines in 1942. Upon his return, he entered the family business, the world's largest cymbal manufacturer and the oldest company in America. An amateur musician himself, Zildjian said he felt privileged to have been born into a musical dynasty, which dates back to 1623. Appointed President two years before his father's death, Armand took over the role of family patriarch in 1977. Zildjian was known for his charismatic personality and warm personal relationship with drummers. He had selected cymbals for such drummers as Gene Krupa, Buddy Rich, Max Roach, Jo Jones and many others and matched cymbals for the Boston Symphony and leading orchestras around the world. The foremost authority in cymbal sound, he created new product innovations in response to the ever-changing needs of musicians and remained deeply involved in the operation of the company until his death. Zildjian received an honorary doctorate from Berklee College of Music, was inducted into the Percussive Arts Society Hall of Fame, and Guitar Center's Rock Walk in Hollywood, and most recently received Moder Drummer Magazine Editors Achievement Award. In addition to his wife, Andra, he leaves four children, Wendy Mets, Craigie, Debbie & Robert Zildjian, three stepchildren, Kristy Thompson, Mark & Peter Field, eight grandchildren, Paula Charles, Cady & Emily Zildjian-Bickford, Samantha Zildjian, Dakota and Victoria Thompson, Kathryn and Spencer Field, two great-grandchildren, Ian and Gwen Charles, several cousins, nieces and nephews and a brother Robert. Private family services will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: Armand Zildjian Percussion Scholarship, c/o Berklee College of Music, 1140 Boylston Street, Boston, MA 02215; and the Zildjian Family Opportunity Fund, c/o Percussive Arts Society, 701 NW Ferris Ave, Lawton, OK 73507.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: AT&T WIRELESS NARROWS ITS LOSSES AT&T Wireless, the nation's third-largest wireless carrier, said yesterday that its loss in the fourth quarter of 2002 narrowed to $131 million, or 5 cents a share, from $1.23 billion, or 48 cents a share, in the period last year. AT&T Wireless pared its loss even as it struggled with a small decline in revenue per customer, to about $60 a month from $60.80, as fierce competition continued among the large carriers. AT&T Wireless had net subscriber additions of 705,000 in the quarter, a decline of 24 percent from a year earlier. John Zeglis, the chief executive, said he expected AT&T Wireless to achieve operating profitability, or financial results that do not include expenses like the acquisition of spectrum licenses, for the first time in its history in 2003. Shares fell 30 cents, or 4.5 percent, to $6.40.

description: To gauge response to President Bush's State of the Union address last night, The New York Times spoke to Americans who may be affected by the plans he laid out.

title: Sears Is Sued By Executive It Dismissed At Credit Unit
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, which dismissed the president of its credit division in October shortly before announcing unexpected losses at the unit, is being sued by the executive, Kevin T. Keleghan, for defamation and breach of contract.

title: Suffering Through Election Day
description: After a quick visit to the mall where we ate ice cream, exchanged our old gas masks for new ones and bought several yards of nylon sheeting, my wife and I dropped the kids at home and went to vote. We entered the polling station holding hands, heads lowered, knowing that the decision we each were about to make might determine our children's fate.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Debating Response To Burglar Alarms
description: The Los Angeles City Council, by a 7-to-7 vote, failed to overturn a Police Department policy barring officers from responding to most burglar alarms unless verified. But the Police Commission, which approved the policy, agreed not to put it into effect for 60 days while a task force studies what should constitute a verified alarm. About 92 percent of burglar alarm calls in recent years have been false, costing the city millions of dollars. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Biggest Abuse Payout By Church
description: A 28-year-old man who was sexually abused by a priest as a child received a compensation payment from the Archdiocese of Dublin of $325,000, the single largest settlement in the history of Ireland's clerical abuse scandals, according to the Irish state broadcaster RTE. Mervyn Rundle was abused as a 9-year-old altar boy in 1985 by the Rev. Thomas Naughton, who was transferred among three parishes, abusing children in each. He eventually served three years in prison for abusing Mr. Rundle. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Blake Is Key for U.S. With Roddick Absent
description: It's up to James Blake now.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a worsening of the federal government's budget shortfall in the last few months referred incorrectly in some copies to the amount of surplus foreseen last July by the Office of Management and Budget for the next 10 years. It was $1.7 trillion -- not billion.

title: Suffolk Votes to Ban Smoking, With a Grace Period of 3 Years
description: Suffolk County, which has a reputation for readily banning everything from detergents with phosphates to the release of balloons, is turning out to be less of a pioneer on curbing smoking.

title: Gambling Ring With Mob Ties Is Shut Down, Prosecutors Say
description: State prosecutors said today that they had shut down a Mafia gambling operation that used retired men in their 70's to collect bets totaling nearly $3 million a year across the New York region.

title: GEORGE LUCAS MOVES TO CONSOLIDATE HIS BUSINESSES
description: The filmmaker George Lucas is combining his movie production company, Lucasfilm, and related businesses. Lucasfilm's president, Gordon Radley, 56, said he was resigning to focus on other pursuits. Lucasfilm named the chief financial officer, Micheline Chau, 50, as chief operating officer. The other businesses are Lucas Digital, LucasArts Entertainment and Lucas Licensing. Mr. Lucas will remain chief executive and chairman of the closely held company, based in San Rafael, Calif.

title: Mayor's Budget Plan Relies on Help From Albany and Labor
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg outlined his latest plan yesterday to balance the city budget, this time shifting the focus away from city actions and placing his trust largely in Albany and the city's labor unions to help close a $3.4 billion gap.

description: The Devils had failed on 17 consecutive power plays at Continental Arena. But they made the most of a man advantage tonight that was something of a gift from the Red Wings.

title: It Wouldn't Sink Titanic, but It Can Stop a Ferry
description: Vincent McBrearty stood in the crow's nest of the Belford Ferry Terminal, and as he gazed north toward the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and the hazy skyline of Manhattan, all he could see was ice, unyielding and eerily quiet.

title: Tolerance and Hypocrisy On Gay-Straight Clubs
description: A YEAR AGO, a small group of students at Boyd County High School in rural eastern Kentucky asked to form a Gay-Straight Alliance club. They had a sponsor, Kaye King, who is an English teacher and a certified counselor. They did research and learned that there were 1,200 such clubs nationally. Tyler McClelland, a senior, says they just wanted a supportive group, where no one whispered ''queer'' behind their backs.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Currency To Float
description: After two years of managing the exchange rate of the Egyptian pound, the government will allow it to float freely beginning today. The decision, disclosed yesterday by several senior officials in different forums, comes as regional tensions have depressed the country's export and tourism earnings and when many Egyptians are on pilgrimages to Muslim holy sites in Saudi Arabia, where the currency is pegged to the dollar. Analysts said the Egyptian pound would almost certainly fall sharply in value from the current official rate of 4.64 to the dollar, making Egyptian exports more competitive but imported goods more expensive. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: 280 to Have a View From the Green Monster
description: They could be the most famous bar stools in this city since Norm and Cliff were regulars at Cheers.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline yesterday about a police panel's report on the 1989 Central Park jogger case referred imprecisely to its conclusions about the guilt of five defendants whose convictions were overturned after a serial rapist, Matias Reyes, confessed that he had acted alone in the attack. The report said the five were most likely guilty of having started an attack with sexual overtones on the jogger, who was later raped and beaten by Mr. Reyes. It did not say they were most likely guilty in the rape itself.

title: Iraqi Diplomat Says U.S. Is 'Blinded by Oil Fever'
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 29  As the Security Council met to consider its position on possible war with Iraq and ongoing weapons inspections there, Baghdad's ambassador to the United Nations offered a harsh assessment of President Bush's State of the Union address, likening it to British colonial aspirations of a century ago and dismissing the idea that the White House can present credible evidence next week that Iraq possesses weapons of mass destruction.

title: Mayor Lifts Ban for Chinese New Year Fireworks Shows
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is reversing a ban on firecrackers during the Lunar New Year celebration in Chinatown that begins Saturday, city officials said yesterday.

title: After Revamping, Xerox Returns to Profit
description: Xerox, which has been sharply cutting jobs and selling assets in a feverish effort to offset sluggish sales, said yesterday that it had earned $19 million, or a penny a share, in the fourth quarter of 2002. Excluding a revamping charge of 34 cents and a tax-related benefit of 11 cents, Xerox's earnings would have been 24 cents a share. Analysts had predicted a loss of 11 cents.

title: Bush's Speech Puts New Focus On State of Intelligence Data
description: In pressing his case for forceful action against Iraq, President Bush tonight cited intercepted communications, interrogations of prisoners, information from defectors and other unspecified intelligence as evidence that Saddam Hussein continues to build prohibited weapons and bankroll terrorist groups including Al Qaeda.

description: The governor chosen to present the Democratic response to President Bush tonight faulted the president's handling of the economy, other domestic policy and national security, saying that ''in too many ways, our country is headed in the wrong direction.''

title: Bush Proposal On AIDS Funds Shows Concern About Security
description: In proposing that Congress commit $15 billion to an emergency relief fund for AIDS in Africa, President Bush declared publicly tonight that AIDS is a humanitarian crisis. But he also recognized, without explicitly saying so, that by creating political and economic instability abroad, AIDS is also a national security threat that could breed the next generation of terrorists.

title: Airlines Look for Profits In Overseas Routes; War Looms, but Competition Is Less Fierce
