They include Cannondale's bicycle division in addition to the motor sports division.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Drug Maker's Profit Falls
description: One of India's largest drug makers, Dr. Reddy's Laboratories, the maker of a generic form of the antidepression drug Prozac, said it earned $19.4 million in its most recent quarter, a decline of 42 percent from a year earlier. The decline resulted from the expiration last February of a six-month period when Dr. Reddy's had the exclusive right to sell the generic version of Prozac in the United States. Sales in the period, which ended Dec. 31 and was the third quarter in Dr. Reddy's fiscal year, fell 3.7 percent. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIGHTNER, HELEN LUCILLE
description: LIGHTNER-Helen Lucille. Of Twin Falls, Idaho, formerly of New York City, died on January 24, 2003, following an extended battle with heart disease. After graduating from St. Mary's Academy and Marylhurst College, she taught school in southeastern Oregon at Crane for three years. In 1942, she left for New York City and a career in music. She attended classes at Juilliard, and earned her Master of Arts degree in Music Education at Columbia University. In the 1950's, Helen joined the Music Education faculty at New York University, where she taught voice for 28 years. During this time, she acquired her doctorate from Teachers College. She also gave many recitals at New York concert halls. In 1990, she retired from NYU. Helen enjoyed traveling and teaching abroad. After retiring in Twin Falls to be near her family, she became a member of the Magic Valley Symphony League and was active in the Catholic Church. She is survived by her sister, Joan Watt of Twin Falls, Idaho, and her brother, John Lightner of San Diego, California. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Edward's Catholic Church Building Fund. Contributions can be mailed to Reynolds Funeral Chapel, P.O. Box 1142, Twin Falls, Idaho 83303.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Inmate Accused Of Hiring Hit Man
description: An inmate at Rikers Island has been indicted for attempting to hire a hit man, officials said yesterday. The inmate, Jed Kass, is accused of seeking an assassin to murder two former co-workers who the authorities say are potential witnesses against Mr. Kass in the embezzlement case for which he is in custody. The Queens district attorney said that Mr. Kass met at the jail this month with an undercover detective posing as a hit man. Mr. Kass is accused of agreeing during that meeting to pay $25,000 for the killings. On Friday, Mr. Kass was indicted for conspiracy and criminal solicitation. Those charges can carry as much as 25 years in prison. Mr. Kass' attorney did not return calls seeking comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: 12-Year Sentence In Death Of Fetus
description: The State Supreme Court, in a 3-to-2 decision, upheld the homicide conviction of a woman whose cocaine use killed a fetus she was carrying. The woman, Regina D. McKnight, who gave birth to a stillborn five-pound girl around the 35th week of her pregnancy, was sentenced to 12 years in prison. The dissenting judges said the Legislature did not intend the homicide-by-child-abuse law under which Ms. McKnight was convicted to apply to fetuses. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: GOVERNMENT TO ACT ON FIREFIGHTERS As the country's 50,000 full-time firefighters marched out on their latest wage strike since mid-November, the government said it would introduce emergency legislation to impose a pay settlement. The powers permit the government to revive a 56-year-old law allowing it to decree pay and work conditions for firefighters. Strikers described the measure variously as "bullying" and "a form of dictatorship." As the strike started, military fire crews found the body of a woman in a blazing house in Northampton, north of London. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: The Results Are In, and Peace Lost
description: Amram Mitzna, the leader of the Labor Party, offered Israelis the most realistic solution to the Palestinian conflict. With Labor's defeat in yesterday's elections, prospects for peace are now even more remote and once again rest with the two men -- Ariel Sharon and Yasir Arafat -- whose unspoken alliance has frustrated the hopes of Israelis and Palestinians alike.

title: Arab Nations Unconvinced by Bush's Reasons for War
description: CAIRO, Jan. 29  President Bush's belligerent recapping of the need to remove Saddam Hussein from power sounded to Middle Eastern ears today more like a domestic pep rally for war than a convincing argument to validate such a drastic step.

title: Britain Accuses Baghdad, Deepening Rift in Europe
description: Fissures within Europe seemed to widen today as Britain openly accused Iraq of being in ''material breach'' of the disarmament conditions laid down by the United Nations, echoing Washington's language to justify war against the government of Saddam Hussein.

title: The Nation, the President, the War
description: President Bush sought to revive a sense of national resolve last night with a State of the Union address that readied the country for a showdown with Iraq and demanded another huge tax cut for wealthier Americans. No one watching the somber Mr. Bush's delivery could doubt his determination. But the combination created far too mixed a message. It was hard to reconcile the president who vowed not to ''pass along our problems to other Congresses, to other presidents and other generations'' with the one whose fiscal policies have helped create gigantic deficits for taxpayers of the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONSUEGRA, HUGO

He will be greatly missed by all who worked with him. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife and family.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; GOVERNOR WOULD SERVE

''Therefore, as to any orders I receive, I will do just as anyone else in my unit and follow them.''

title: U.S. to Seek Waiver on Weed Killer Harmful to Ozone Layer

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Broker Postpones Stock Offer

Cazenove, whose clients include the royal family, still intends to sell stock when the situation improves, the chief executive, Robert Pickering, said.

title: Only the Establishment, Not the Sushi, Is Modest
description: I HAVE a problem with good sushi: it doesn't come cheap. Good sushi demands the best ingredients. In French or Italian cooking, Chinese or Mexican, Indian or Middle Eastern or regional American, you can tart up the least expensive cuts of meat, stale bread or past-their-prime vegetables to make them taste good. Impoverished people have based their cuisines on the ability to do just that.

title: Hustling the American Dream on Gritty Streets

The content of the script, written by Tim Dowlin, is pretty familiar from television cop shows and movies about gangs, complete with a tragic conclusion involving teenagers with guns. And it takes the sympathetic, admonitory tone of an after-school special toward the excitable tough-talkers whose criminality is as culturally inevitable as, say, surfing is to the beachniks of Malibu.

title: Riffs on a Chocolate Theme
description: NOW that most New Year's resolutions have melted away like marshmallows in hot cocoa, it's time to indulge those chocolate cravings.

title: Counter Intelligence: Consider the Sampler Kits For the Dip and Sip Set
description: Most people who pop by Leaf Storm, a counter at 176 West 94th Street, want a quick cup of tea to go ($1.60) -- or soup or a muffin. The counter opens onto the street near Amsterdam Avenue. For sure, the choice of high-quality teas is broad: black, green, flavored black or green, fruit based and herbal, and all are full leaf, even in the bags that Amy L. Chen, the owner, uses to brew them on the spot. She also serves cider, hot chocolate and, yes, coffee.

title: Fearing War, Questioning Its Need
description: To gauge response to President Bush's State of the Union address last night, The New York Times spoke to Americans who may be affected by the plans he laid out.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; When A.I.G.'s longtime chief mentions a successor, Wall Street talks, and keeps talking.
description: TALKING with investors in New York yesterday, Maurice R. Greenberg, the venerable leader of the American International Group, touched on the issue of succession. And Wall Street began to buzz.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: A Move To Scrub The Reichstag
description: A group of conservative politicians wants to remove from the walls of the Reichstag building rude and obscene graffiti daubed by Soviet soldiers in May 1945. The scrawl was rediscovered seven years ago during renovation and left as a monument to the estimated 100,000 Soviet troops who died in the battle of Berlin. The conservatives say the scrawl is a burden on German-Russian relations and want to replace it with German symbols. Parliament has met in the building since the government moved from Bonn in 1999. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: The Empire Strikes First
description: There was no smoking gun last night. There was merely a smoky allusion.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Buys Neoworld For $276 Million
description: Nextel Communications Inc., the fifth-largest United States mobile phone company, has bought NeoWorld Communications Inc. from Boston Millennia Partners for $276 million in cash, Boston Millennia said yesterday. Boston Millennia, a private equity firm, made a profit on the March 2000 investment in NeoWorld, the firm said. It did not give details. NeoWorld was founded by Brian McAuley, a former chief executive of Nextel. Earlier this month, Nextel said it had its first full-year profit in 2002 as it met forecasts for subscriber growth. The company is the only publicly traded nationwide wireless United States carrier whose shares rose last year, increased by sales of a walkie-talkie feature that rivals have not matched. The company, which mainly sells to businesses, is trying to sell more of its push-to-talk phones to consumers and government agencies as the mobile phone industry adds users at the slowest pace ever. NeoWorld was formed to buy spectrum to build specialized mobile radio systems across the United States, Boston Millennia said.

title: Leona Helmsley on the Stand: The Moment They Waited For
description: Leona Helmsley spent 20 minutes on the witness stand yesterday defending herself against a former employee's accusation of bias against gays. That was all she needed to display anger, defiance, melancholy and confusion; to sob, smile and forget her ZIP code; and to zing her enemies with sarcastic pokes that left the packed courtroom in giggles.

title: Sexist Pigs Skewered Over a Flamethrower
description: The vengeful, bewitching heroine of ''Chaos'' goes by two names, Malika and Nomie. But as embodied by Rachida Brakni, who won a Csar (the French equivalent of an Oscar) last year as the most promising actress, she is indelible either way. Against all odds this beautiful, street-smart survivor of countless rapes and assaults at the hands of a gang that enslaved her and forced her to work the streets of Paris as a prostitute has retained her fighting spirit, and sex is her weapon. When she aims her fiery gaze into a man's eyes, he's a goner.

description: JANOWITZ-Adeline Tintner. Our deepest condolences to Dr. Janowitz and his family. Irwin and Suzanne Rosenthal Bill and Shelby Modell National Co-Founders Eugene A. Kestenbaum, Chairperson, Board of Trustees Rodger L. DeRose, President and CEO

description: The City Council Committee on Public Safety has scheduled a public hearing on the Central Park jogger case. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (718) 274-4500.

title: Hussein Under Growing Fire in Arab Lands; War Called Inevitable
description: Even as some senior Arab officials were suggesting today that arms inspectors in Iraq be given more time, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt began preparing his country for what he called an inevitable conflict.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Tax Cut Gets Backing Of Nominee
description: John W. Snow, President Bush's nominee as Treasury secretary, defended the administration's tax-cutting plans today against criticism from Senate Democrats who confronted him with his own previous statements about the need for balancing the budget.

description: WEIJL-Liselotte Dina. Poeia Weijl-Farcy has great sorrow in announcing the death of her mother, Liselotte Dina Weijl, nee Drukker, on December 23, 2002. Her wisdom, wit and charm will be sorely missed by her children, grandchidlren and many friends throughout the world. Ceremonies will be held in the south of France and the Netherlands at a later date to be announced.

description: Making Foreign-Language Education a Priority

title: Guests Put a Human Face On the President's Ideas
description: Sitting two seats from Laura Bush in the House gallery tonight was one of the more unusual guests ever invited by a White House to a State of the Union speech: an acknowledged former crack addict and prostitute who now runs a drug treatment program in a Louisiana Christian church.

title: Wining and Dining, the Bordeaux Way
description: THE wise old men of Bordeaux, whoever they were 60 or 70 years ago, made a remarkable discovery: the press. Not the kind that crushes grapes; the Romans knew about those presses. I mean the press that tells the world about Bordeaux wine. It is not too much of an exaggeration to say that few business groups anywhere are as astute as the Bordelais when it comes to presenting their image to the rest of the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTENSTEIN, SARI
description: WITTENSTEIN-Sari. Age 73, on Sunday, January 26th, in Boca Raton, FL. Predeceased by husband, Robert P. Wittenstein, and survived by her sons, Ira and Andrew; a daughter, Victoria, and four grandchildren. Formerly of New York City and Westport, CT., she was a long-time supporter of the arts and performed in several local and regional theater groups. Services Thursday, January 30th, at 11:00 AM, from Abraham L. Green & Son, 88 Beach Rd., Fairfield, CT. Memorial contributions to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, or United Jewish Appeal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTEIN, JEROME
description: BROWNSTEIN - Jerome. Born September 1, 1931, in Troy, NY. Died of colon cancer January 19, 2003, at the age of 71. A graduate of Russell Sage College and Albany Union Law School, he was a practicing attorney for 45 years. A true Renaissance man, he was also a calligrapher, entrepreneur, and passionate collector. He owned Gavit & Co. in Albany, NY, the oldest, continuously operating engraving company in the United States. He was a Master of the 32nd Degree Mason and a member of the Horological Society. A longtime resident of the Upper West Side, he is survived by his wife Honey Rodman; sons Richard, Paul, and Robert; daughters Sara Truebridge and Lisa Moore; and grandchildren Ian, Quinn, Cali, Colby, Devin, and Natalia. Donations in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, New York, New York 10087.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZENKER, MARJORIE
description: ZENKER-Marjorie. On December 29, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Norman. Dear mother of Ilene Cohen, Sandy, Wendy, Jill and Caryl. Services Tuesday, December 31, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

description: IT cost me $30. I call it the Monster of Braising. I use it almost every day.

title: Verizon Ends Relations With Lowe & Partners
description: Verizon Communications is ending its relationship with Lowe & Partners Worldwide in New York, completing a shift of creative assignments from the agency that began three months ago. Verizon spent $165 million for ads in major media during the first 10 months of 2002, according to CMR, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: Election Is Over, but the Arab-Israeli Violence Continues
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29  As Israel's political factions sorted through the results of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's overwhelming victory in elections Tuesday, violence flared again today in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Larry Goldberg, 69, Fabled Food and Diet Lover
description: Larry Goldberg, a food lover who owned three popular New York pizzerias and developed an unusual method of staying thin that he called controlled cheating, died on Sunday in Kansas City, Mo. He was 69.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Another Safeway Bidder
description: Philip Green, a retail entrepreneur, said that he planned to seek antitrust clearance for an offer for Safeway, a large British supermarket chain that is for sale. Mr. Green, in a statement released by Trackdean, a company controlled by his family, said he had met informally with regulators on Monday and planned to file a submission with the Office of Fair Trading before making a formal offer to acquire Safeway for cash. Safeway has so far attracted the interest of five suitors in addition to Mr. Green. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, ALBERT
description: FOX-Albert. On January 27, at 94 years of age. Beloved husband of the late Anita Fox, father of Marjorie Hilton and Barbara Fox, grandfather of Alexis Hilton Mintz and Alison Hilton, father-in-law of Joseph Hilton and James Freund. He lived a long and exemplary life and we will miss him terribly. Funeral services will be held this week in Rocky Mount, North Carolina, where his heart always remained. The family will be receiving on Monday, February 3, at 55 West 73rd Street, Apt. #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, STANLEY
description: MARTIN-Stanley. Formerly of Rye, NY, on December 23, age 97. Served in military intelligence, WWII. Retired senior editor, D.C. Heath and Company. Widower of Catherine Brod Martin. Survived by Kenneth of San Diego, Edward of Winchester, MA, and two granddaughters.

title: Ashcroft in Secret Spot During Bush Address
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft sat out the State of the Union speech in an undisclosed place, officials said tonight. And, for the first time, a member of the Congressional leadership, Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri, the majority whip, watched from an undisclosed location outside the chamber.

title: An Ugly Duckling Takes a Star Turn
description: CELERY root, an eyesore of a tuber that bears no resemblance to celery stalks, appears to be having a moment. Long a bistro staple, and typically served pured or as a tangy rmoulade, celery root, also known as celeriac, is taking on chic new trappings at restaurants like Otto, where it fronts a salad with citrus and Parmesan, and Aix, where it turns up in the crab meat cannelloni.

title: Ariel Sharon's Paradoxical Victory
description: After two years of unprecedented violence, insecurity and an ailing economy, Israelis voted yesterday to keep Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and his Likud Party in power. The strong Likud showing was something of a paradox, considering that opinion polls show that a consistent majority of Israelis favor exactly what Mr. Sharon has not done so far -- remove most Jewish settlements from the West Bank and Gaza Strip, establish a clear and defensible national border and help set up a Palestinian state next door. The outcome suggests that in this time of insecurity, Israelis feel safer under Mr. Sharon's hard-line leadership and see no Palestinian partner with whom to negotiate.

title: HOME DEPOT WILL COMBINE 2 REGIONAL DIVISIONS
description: Home Depot said yesterday that it would combine its New England and Eastern divisions to reduce costs. The expanded Eastern division, based in Atlanta, will oversee more than 600 stores with 110,000 employees, the company said. Merchandising and support operations will move to South Plainfield, N.J., from Canton, Mass. Home Depot decided on the consolidation after successfully combining its Southeast and Mid-Atlantic divisions last year. The combination will not hurt earnings, cause store closings or cut jobs, Home Depot said. The company also said it would open 10 stores in New England, creating 2,000 jobs.

title: The Naked Chef's Wicked Act
description: IN this city's fickle culinary world, where celebrity chefs can ripen and spoil as quickly as bananas on a hot stove, Jamie Oliver, otherwise known as the Naked Chef, seemed headed for a crash. Critics who had initially adored his laid-back style, his easy-to-follow recipes and his matey use of words like ''wicked'' and ''pukka'' (which also means ''wicked,'' sort of), were beginning to find him not only relentlessly overexposed but also faintly embarrassing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNING, JOHN
description: BROWNING-John. Manhattan School of Music is saddened by the loss of former faculty member, John Browning. One of America's most eminent pianists, he was a member of The School's piano faculty from 1980 to 1986. His intellect and vigor enriched the lives of his many students. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to his family. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Marta Istomin, President

Cherished aunt. We will miss her love and strength, and cherish her memory. Service Tuesday, December 31, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: An Unacceptable Nominee
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to vote tomorrow on Miguel Estrada, a nominee to the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals. Mr. Estrada comes with a scant paper trail but a reputation for taking extreme positions on important legal questions. He stonewalled when he was asked at his confirmation hearings last fall to address concerns about his views. Given these concerns, and given the thinness of the record he and his sponsors in the administration have chosen to make available, the Senate should vote to reject his nomination.

title: Lawyer Is Asked to Serve as SUNY Trustee
description: GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI has nominated former State Senator RONALD B. STAFFORD as a trustee of the State University of New York. The nomination, for a five-year term, is subject to confirmation by the State Senate. A graduate of St. Lawrence University and Columbia University School of Law, Mr. Stafford, 67, lives in Plattsburgh and practices law there and in Albany and New York City. He was first elected to the Senate in 1965 and was chairman of the Senate's higher education committee from 1966 to 1978 and finance committee chairman from 1993 until he left the Senate in December.

He was a published cartoonist who brought his wit with him wherever he went. He leaves his beloved wife Arlene, his cherished son Lt. Philip Sacks, his wonderful nephew Ethan (Masako) Sacks. Loving brother of the late Dr. Elliott Sacks. Dear son of the late Philip and Naomi Sacks.

title: Off-Season Changes Give Mets a Reason to Hope
description: The Mets unveiled the 2003 version of their club at Madison Square Garden yesterday, a group of fresh and familiar players clad in new orange practice jerseys and uttering clichs about being excited and being built to win. Other than the flaming orange jerseys, the scene looked familiar. Weren't the Mets giddy about their chances last winter after revamping the team, too?

description: In a game more lopsided than the final score indicated, Christ the King defeated Xaverian, 66-47, yesterday and claimed the top spot in the Catholic High School Athletic Association Western Division.

title: Times Co. Posts 45% Jump in Quarterly Profit
description: The New York Times Company posted a 45 percent increase in fourth-quarter profit yesterday on gains in advertising and circulation revenue and low newsprint costs.

title: Steeping in Style at the George V
description: Not all teas need the same steeping time. Taiwanese oolong takes five minutes, Chinese jasmine four and Indian darjeeling three. With that in mind, Les Cinq, the Michelin two-star restaurant in the Four Seasons George V hotel in Paris, has an elaborate tea-brewing table with a line of hourglasses, calibrated for three, four, five and six minutes. Naturally, ordinary hourglasses would not do. These were commissioned from Ercuis, a French silversmith.

description: RASKIN-Miriam (nee Weiss) of Delray Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Lewis. Dear mother of Barbara (Xavier) Kohan and the late Judi Yourman. Loving ''Nan'' to Nicholas and Scott Kohan, Lisa (Rick) Helbig, Dana (Marc) Dizon, 3 great-grandchildren. Devoted sister of Ruth Weiss. Services private.

title: White House Suggests Budget Deficit May Set a Record and Exceed $300 Billion
description: White House officials suggested today that the federal budget deficit could surpass $300 billion this year, setting a record as President Bush pushes plans for big tax cuts and new spending for the military and homeland security.

title: Mother's Poignant Farewell, As Nazis Brutalize Ukraine
description: Few filmmakers have an appreciation of faces like the documentary filmmaker Frederick Wiseman. His understanding of the strength in a simple image -- fixing his camera on a speaking person as the words spill out -- amounts to an overwhelming trust in the power of directness. This belief is evident in his wealth of documentaries, pictures that range from his early, innovative works ''Titicut Follies'' (1967) and ''High School'' (1968), through later films like ''Domestic Violence'' (2001). That faith is also the foundation of his riveting and short new fiction film, ''The Last Letter,'' opening today at the Film Forum.

title: Slowly, Knicks Are Starting to Make a Move
description: On a day when much of the talk centered on the All-Star Game rosters, the Knicks took the floor for a far less glamorous outing against the struggling Atlanta Hawks. Neither team had a player bound for the All-Star Game, not even with it being played in Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUIDA, JENNIE
description: GUIDA-Jennie. On January 27, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Antonio. Loving mother to Elizabeth McIntyre and Anthony Guida. Devoted grandmother to Suzanne Loomis, Kristen and Meghan Guida and great-grandmother to Stephen, Jenny and Billy Loomis. Mrs. Guida will always be remembered for her volunteer work at Frances Schrevier Nursing Home where she was instrumental in creating a Gift Shop she volunteered at for approximately 45 years. Reposing Wednesday 8:30-9:30 AM at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. Gifts in her memory may be made to D'youville Manor, 1750 Quarry Rd, Yardley, PA. 19067.

title: The Neediest Cases; Helping a Disabled Boy Return to Summer Camp
description: The first time James Futrell, 19, went to camp almost 10 years ago, he said he thought to himself, ''I just got out of a hospital, and now I have to go where?'' He had been living in a state medical institution with his twin brother from ages 4 to 8, and now, what he wanted most was to stay with the grandmother who had legally adopted them, Paula Bradum.

title: Bush Vows That He'll Disarm Iraq and Rebuild U.S. Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  In an assertive speech that covered the main themes of his administration, President Bush tonight combined an unflinching threat of military action against Saddam Hussein with sweeping proposals on the key domestic issues of health care and tax relief.

title: Still Waiting For a Smoking Gun
description: To gauge response to President Bush's State of the Union address last night, The New York Times spoke to Americans who may be affected by the plans he laid out.

title: 2 Top Muslims In Indonesia Rebuke U.S. On Iraq Policy
description: The leaders of Indonesia's two biggest Muslim groups have declined an invitation to go to Washington, saying that they were offended by the Bush administration's policy toward Iraq.

title: Take 2 for Delta and Its Low-Cost Carrier
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that its new low-cost carrier, Song, would start service on April 15 by flying between New York and West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Mayor Outlines Plan To Close Budget Gap
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released his latest plan to balance the city budget, this time shifting the focus away from city actions and placing his trust largely in Albany and the city's labor unions to help close a $3.4 billion gap.

title: Making Foreign-Language Education a Priority
description: MARY LOUISE PRATT, a professor of Spanish, Portuguese and comparative literature at New York University, has become president of the Modern Language Association, a scholarly association with more than 30,000 members in 100 countries. Professor Pratt said that she hoped to focus on issues like the crisis in scholarly publishing and the increased importance of foreign language education.

title: Bush's Twin Challenges
description: With his sweeping, if unproven, charge that Saddam Hussein ''aids and protects terrorists, including members of Al Qaeda,'' President Bush tonight delivered his strongest effort yet to convince doubting allies and anxious Americans that war with Iraq may be unavoidable, and the best way to protect the home front from ''a day of horror like none we have ever known.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a worsening of the federal government's budget shortfall in the last few months referred incorrectly in some copies to the amount of surplus foreseen last July by the Office of Management and Budget for the next 10 years. It was $1.7 trillion  not billion.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 1989 Murder Suspect Arrested
description: A fugitive wanted in connection with the 1989 murder of two garbage haulers was arrested Monday evening in a Bronx doughnut shop, officials announced yesterday. The murdered haulers had been credited with helping the authorities break a Mafia stranglehold on the Long Island garbage industry. The fugitive, Frank Pearl Federico, 75, disappeared in 1993, shortly before he was scheduled to provide blood and hair samples for comparison with samples found where the garbage carters, Robert M. Kubecka and Donald Barstow, brothers-in-law, were fatally shot. Yesterday, the authorities said that it was not clear where Mr. Federico, described as a soldier in the Luchese family, had been for the last 10 years, but that they believed he had spent time hiding in Europe. Mr. Federico was arrested in the Bronx, where he had planned to meet a former associate, officials said. He pleaded not guilty at his arraignment in Federal District Court in Brooklyn and was ordered held without bail. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Bush Enlarges Case For War by Linking Iraq With Terrorists
description: President Bush, enlarging the case for going to war with Iraq soon, said tonight that there was intelligence showing that Iraq was helping and protecting terrorists. He warned that Saddam Hussein could distribute weapons of mass destruction to terrorists who could use them against the United States.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Apple Cuts Power Mac Prices
description: Apple Computer Inc. added faster processors to its three Power Mac G4 models yesterday and lowered the price by as much as 20 percent, seeking to attract buyers after its first back-to-back quarterly losses since 1997. The latest Power Mac models will cost $1,499; $1,999; and $2,699, replacing models introduced in August selling for $1,699; $2,499; and $3,299, said Greg Joswiak, the head of marketing for Apple's hardware division. Apple also introduced a $1,299, 20-inch flat-screen monitor and cut the prices of two other displays for the Power Mac computers by as much as 43 percent. Apple's high-end desktop machines were the company's worst sellers in fiscal 2002 as graphic designers, advertisers and other customers trim budgets to cope with a slowdown in their industries. Shipments of Power Macs fell 25 percent last quarter from a year earlier, contributing to Apple's first six-month loss since its co-founder, Steve Jobs, returned as chief executive.

title: In Austere Budget Plan, Pataki Cuts Health and School Aid
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29  Gov. George E. Pataki, facing the worst fiscal crisis in New York's modern history, proposed a budget plan today that, if passed by the State Legislature, would reduce overall spending, deeply cut state aid to schools and curb what money the government gives the health care industry.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Armed Man Is Shot
description: An armed man was shot in the chest and critically wounded in a confrontation with the police in Sunset Park last night, the police said. Details about the shooting, which happened inside a house at 242 51st Street, were not immediately released. It was not clear if the police fired the shot that hit the man, said Sgt. Dennis Ferber. The police were sent to the house around 10:15 p.m. on a report of a man with a gun, Sergeant Ferber said. They confronted the man, whose name was not released, and at least one shot was fired. It was not immediately known if a gun was recovered. The man was being treated early today at Lutheran Medical Center, officials said. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Big Flavor From a Tiny, Nutty Grain
description: FOR most meals, grains are just quickly prepared side dishes that don't require much thought. When a grain does take center stage, it is almost always rice.

title: African Nations Applaud Bush Plan to Fight AIDS Epidemic
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 29 — Astonished officials here and across southern Africa cheered today as they learned that the Bush administration planned to spend a further $10 billion on AIDS drugs, education, specialized laboratories and doctors in 12 African nations ravaged by the disease.

title: Tough Road Ahead for Pittsburgh Symphony
description: When an orchestra loses, or is soon to lose, its music director, its managing director, its board president and chief executive, its development director and its resident conductor, and when it has a $2 million annual ''structural deficit,'' is facing tough labor negotiations this summer, has seen its once-munificent endowment plunge by nearly $50 million, has hinted at bankruptcy and has at least considered selling its hall and merging with the local arts umbrella organization, one might come to the conclusion that the orchestra is in trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MIHLRAD, JACK
description: MIHLRAD-Jack. 5/17/14-1/29/ 95. Eight years of loving, cherished memories. Love Always, Diane and Mom

title: 49ers to Give Cottrell an Answer Soon
description: The Jets' defensive coordinator, Ted Cottrell, has been told that the San Francisco 49ers would let him know by Sunday whether he will get the job to replace Steve Mariucci as head coach.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Wireless Narrows Its Losses
description: AT&T Wireless, the nation's third-largest wireless carrier, said yesterday that its loss in the fourth quarter of 2002 narrowed to $131 million, or 5 cents a share, from $1.23 billion, or 48 cents a share, in the period last year. AT&T Wireless pared its loss even as it struggled with a small decline in revenue per customer, to about $60 a month from $60.80, as fierce competition continued among the large carriers. AT&T Wireless had net subscriber additions of 705,000 in the quarter, a decline of 24 percent from a year earlier. John Zeglis, the chief executive, said he expected AT&T Wireless to achieve operating profitability, or financial results that do not include expenses like the acquisition of spectrum licenses, for the first time in its history in 2003. Shares fell 30 cents, or 4.5 percent, to $6.40. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Powell Will Press U.S. Case in Security Council Next Week
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will make a detailed presentation to the United Nations Security Council next week to press the Bush administration's case for eventual war with Iraq, administration officials said today as Russia appeared ready to change position and support an eventual attack.

title: 3 Are Found Dead in Queens, Apparently in Murder-Suicide
description: A 28-year-old Ecuadorean immigrant, her 7-month-old daughter and the man they were living with were found dead early yesterday in what the authorities said appeared to be a murder-suicide carried out by the man in their apartment in Jackson Heights, Queens.

description: RAISNER-Arnold. On January 25, 2003 at age 74. Beloved husband of Barbara, wonderful father to Jack (Ruthie) and Joanne Narad (Chuck). title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu Loss Narrows

The company has been hit hard by the downturn in investment by major telephone and mobile phone carriers and a decline in spending by the Japanese government. Although sales fell 4 percent over all, the company said demand for software services and flash memory semiconductors increased. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENTCHEFF, NICOLAS
description: PENTCHEFF-Nicolas. Died December 22, 2002, age 91, after a long illness. Born in Bulgaria. Educated in Bulgaria, London School of Economics (BS) and Columbia University, NY (MA). Reporter for Zora, Sofia's leading daily; sent to London in 1936. Became Press Attache to Bulgarian Legation, London, in 1940. Remained in England during WWII broadcasting for the BBC. Reinstated at Bulgarian Legation after the War, resigned in 1948 in protest against Bulgaria's Communist regime. Farmed for seven years in Surrey, England, during which time he married Mary Dean. Emigrated to the U.S. in 1956 at the request of Radio Free Europe; he became Chief of the Bulgarian Desk, RFE, NY in 1957. Continued working for RFE until 1991. Vice President of the International Federation of Free Journalists, Treasurer of Inter-American Federation of Newspapermen's Associations, in this capacity, he visited all the Latin American countries. A lecturer at Fairfield University, CT, 1970-1981. In 1990, following Bulgaria's emergence from Communism, he was able to contact and visit his family after 50 years of absence. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Mary, and his son, Nicholas Dean Pentcheff. Memorial service on Saturday, January 4, 12 noon, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Route 100, Somers, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: The Alzheimer's Association, 785 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: 1989 MURDER SUSPECT ARRESTED A fugitive wanted in connection with the 1989 murder of two garbage haulers was arrested Monday evening in a Bronx doughnut shop, officials announced yesterday. The murdered haulers had been credited with helping the authorities break a Mafia stranglehold on the Long Island garbage industry. The fugitive, Frank Pearl Federico, 75, disappeared in 1993, shortly before he was scheduled to provide blood and hair samples for comparison with samples found where the garbage carters, Robert M. Kubecka and Donald Barstow, brothers-in-law, were fatally shot. Yesterday, the authorities said that it was not clear where Mr. Federico, described as a soldier in the Luchese family, had been for the last 10 years, but that they believed he had spent time hiding in Europe. Mr. Federico was arrested in the Bronx, where he had planned to meet a former associate, officials said. He pleaded not guilty at his arraignment in Federal District Court in Brooklyn and was ordered held without bail. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: SHARMAN NETWORKS FILES COUNTERCLAIM Sharman Networks is seeking to turn the tables on a coalition of major entertainment companies accusing it of aiding wide-scale copyright infringement with its KaZaA Media Desktop. Sharman is arguing that the major record labels and Hollywood studios are misusing copyrights and trying to monopolize the market for digital entertainment. The counterclaim, filed by Sharman Networks in a Los Angeles federal court on Monday night, came two weeks after a judge ruled that the entertainment companies could pursue their copyright lawsuit against the company. Sharman has asked Judge Stephen V. Wilson to bar the labels and studios from enforcing copyrights on all music and movies until the practices it complained about have ended and their effects have dissipated. The Recording Industry Association of America said Sharman's claims are "laughable."   Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: TIMKEN WILL MISS FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT EXPECTATIONS
description: The Timken Company, the nation's largest maker of bearings for industry and automobiles, said first-quarter profit would fall behind analysts' estimates because of higher pension-plan expenses and costs for scrap metal and energy. Profit will be 17 cents to 21 cents a share this quarter and $1.10 to $1.25 this year, Timken said. The forecasts exclude certain items as well as any impact from the planned acquisition of the Ingersoll-Rand Company's Torrington unit. Pension costs will increase by $25 million this year before taxes. That expense and raw-material costs will weigh on profit margins, the company said. Timken is based in Canton, Ohio.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sidewalk Bill Approved
description: The City Council has approved Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to streamline the granting of permits for sidewalk cafes. The bill, approved in a 48-to-0 vote with 1 absentee and 2 vacancies, calls for the application process to be whittled to about 110 days from 465, and for unlicensed cafes to face fines of up to $2,000. ''We put an end to the mockery of the system,'' said Councilman Phillip Reed, chairman of the consumer affairs committee. ''It's a win for the business owner because the process will no longer take a year-and-a-half, and it's a win for the public because violators will be punished.'' Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: The Vaccine Gap
description: As the world struggles to fend off mysterious and complex plagues like AIDS and malaria, it must still find a sustainable way to assure that children do not die from diseases that vaccines can prevent. Unhappily, this year the supply of vaccines against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis will fall short of demand in many nations. Yellow fever and oral polio vaccines suffered recent scarcities. In general, the market has tightened for most vaccines used in developing countries.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit In Consumer Goods

title: Moving Lock, Stock and Trowel

description: President Bush's proposal to double federal spending on fuel cell research drew praise today from automakers and skepticism from environmentalists.

description: Edward M. Korry, the United States ambassador to Chile from 1967 to 1971, who was for years wrongly suspected of helping to plot a military coup to prevent a Marxist from becoming president there, died yesterday at his home in Charlotte, N.C. He was 81.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kremlin Faults Police On Rights
description: The Kremlin's chief human rights monitor said the Russian police had regularly violated the rights of Moscow's growing ethnic minority population, particularly since Chechen guerrillas took more than 750 people hostage in a Moscow theatre in October. The head of President Vladimir V. Putin's human rights commission, Ella Pamfilova, said the police had increasingly made illegal arrests, filed false criminal charges and at times had beaten members of minority groups. She urged the police to severely punish any officers found to be breaking the law. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Bush Officials Debate Release Of Iraq Secrets
description: President Bush's top national security aides are debating whether to declassify satellite photographs of suspected Iraqi weapons sites and truck convoys -- along with telephone intercepts and interviews with defectors and detainees -- to demonstrate that Iraq is defying inspections.

description: STEIN-Eleanor (Wiener). Beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, died on December 28, at the age of 89, after a short illness. She resided for many years with her late husband, Dr. Isidore Stein in Brooklyn, New York, before moving to Cliffside Park, New Jersey. Eleanor received her B.A. and M.A. degrees from New York University and taught health education in the New York City Public Schools. But it said the risk could be cut sharply by moving some of the spent fuel to dry casks near the reactors and making changes in how the rest is stored.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Sharman Networks Files Counterclaim
description: Sharman Networks is seeking to turn the tables on a coalition of major entertainment companies accusing it of aiding wide-scale copyright infringement with its KaZaA Media Desktop. Sharman is arguing that the major record labels and Hollywood studios are misusing copyrights and trying to monopolize the market for digital entertainment. The counterclaim, filed by Sharman Networks in a Los Angeles federal court on Monday night, came two weeks after a judge ruled that the entertainment companies could pursue their copyright lawsuit against the company. Sharman has asked Judge Stephen V. Wilson to bar the labels and studios from enforcing copyrights on all music and movies until the practices it complained about have ended and their effects have dissipated. The Recording Industry Association of America said Sharman's claims are ''laughable.'' Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, MARTIN M.
description: BERGER-Martin M., 75. Wonderful father and husband, respected Mayor of Saltaire, successful real estate attorney and passionate defender of civil liberties, died Tuesday from lung cancer. A brilliant legal mind, he often gave his legal and political talents to support those needing a champion, from civil rights workers to gay job applicants to affordable housing organizations. He helped found the Downtown Independent Democrats and was president of the Village Independent Democrats. He is remembered for his lively mind, ingenuity, commitment to social justice, joyful gardening, omnivorous curiosity and wry sense of humor. Survived by his wife of 36 years, Kathleen (Keen); his four daughters: Bethany, Rachel, Elissa, and Sarah; and his brother, Howard. They will always treasure his boundless love. Donations in his memory to: Doctors Without Borders, Box 1856, Merrifield, VA 22116. A memorial and celebration will be held on Sunday, March 2, at 4 PM at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square So NYC.

title: AMERICAN FARM EQUIPMENT MAKER OPENS OFFICE IN RUSSIA
description: Deere & Company, a leading maker of farm equipment, opened a representative's office in Russia and may build a factory in the country, one of the biggest potential markets for agricultural equipment, company officials said. The company opened an office in Moscow on Monday, the first step in setting up a dealer network throughout Russia, a Deere vice president, Alec McKee, said. ''Russia has said it wants to be more self-sufficient in agriculture, and it is going to become a major world player in agriculture,'' Mr. McKee said. ''And to do that it will need machinery.'' Mr. McKee added that the company might build a factory in Russia if demand warranted it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Motorcycle Curbs Urged
description: Two City Council members and Betsy Gotbaum, the city's public advocate, said yesterday that they would propose limits on motorcycle noise and daredevil riding. Under the legislation, the city would impound the motorcycles of first offenders and would force repeat offenders to pay fines of as much as $2,000 or spend four months in jail. Councilman Bill de Blasio, left, a sponsor of the bill, said the bill focuses on motorcycles like the Pop-a-Wheelie Kawasaki, which encourages riding on one wheel, and excessively loud Harley-Davidsons, one of which was on display yesterday at City Hall Park. Souped up with a 34-inch straight pipe, the Harley could wake Mayor La Guardia, Mr. de Blasio said. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: Briefly Noted
description: RUSSIA EXPELS AMERICAN SEEKING MILITANTS Russia has deported an American woman accused of using the Internet to contact Islamic extremists, an official at Russia's F.S.B. security service said yesterday. The official said she had contacted several groups and had offered them advice and assistance in performing acts of terror, especially in the United States. The woman, who was identified as Megan McRee and said to have been born in 1968, was placed on a flight to Los Angeles late last night. She had been living in Moscow without proper visa registration, which was the official reason for her deportation. The U.S. embassy in Moscow was not immediately available for comment. In an open letter on the Internet, Ms. McRee said she had fled the United States in the 1990's because she had been continuously persecuted by the CIA. "I was simply targeted by these people because I happen to have a high IQ," wrote McRee, who said she specialized in software programming. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, IRVING I.
description: SOLOMON-Irving I. January 28, 2003, in his 84th year of a life fully enjoyed. He was first the husband of the late Frieda Solomon who together were the parents of Maxinne (Irwin), Stephanie, Marc and Charisse and the grandparents of Lori, Gayle, Debra, Jason and Joshua, all of whom survive him and the late Adam. In terrible sadness, he leaves to mourn him as well his second wife, Shira Stein, who in the renaissance of his life helped Irving to believe that love can happen again. He is also survived by Wallace Jordan, whom he mentored and cared about deeply. Irving was special to so many, by dint of his patience and wise counsel, his unflagging optimism, his devotion to his family and all that he contributed in trying to make this world a more reasoned and compassioned place. We are blessed that the Eternal took him gently....this kind and wonderful man. A memorial service will be held at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street on Thursday, January 30, at 4PM. Contributions in Irving's memory may be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund or the Cantor's Discretionary Fund at Temple Shaaray Tefila.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: A Move To Drop 'London'
description: The city council of Londonderry passed a motion, led by nationalist parties, to begin a process to change the name of Northern Ireland's second-largest city back to Derry. ''London'' was added to the name of the majority Roman Catholic city by Royal Charter in the 1600's, and reversing that move requires an act of the British Parliament. The name of the local government authority was changed to Derry City Council in 1984. Unionist politicians, who are typically Protestant and favor strengthened ties with Britain, said they would lobby British officials in the province to stop the change. Brian Lavery (NYT)

description: The economy grew at a barely perceptible rate of 0.7 percent in the fourth quarter, the government said today, as consumers, who were the mainstay of growth for much of last year, spent their money at a much reduced rate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZILDJIAN, ARMAND
description: ZILDJIAN-Armand. Of Scottsdale, Arizona, and Quechee, Vermont (formerly Hingham, MA), President and Chairman of the Zildjian Company in Norwell, MA, died Thursday at his home in Scottsdale. He was 81. Born in Quincy, he attended local schools, including Thayer Academy and Colgate University until called to serve in the Philippines in 1942. Upon his return, he entered the family business, the world's largest cymbal manufacturer and the oldest company in America. An amateur musician himself, Zildjian said he felt privileged to have been born into a musical dynasty, which dates back to 1623. Appointed President two years before his father's death, Armand took over the role of family patriarch in 1977. Zildjian was known for his charismatic personality and warm personal relationship with drummers. He had selected cymbals for such drummers as Gene Krupa, Buddy Rich, Max Roach, Jo Jones and many others and matched cymbals for the Boston Symphony and leading orchestras around the world. The foremost authority in cymbal sound, he created new product innovations in response to the ever-changing needs of musicians and remained deeply involved in the operation of the company until his death. Zildjian received an honorary doctorate from Berklee College of Music, was inducted into the Percussive Arts Society Hall of Fame, and Guitar Center's Rock Walk in Hollywood, and most recently received Moder Drummer Magazine Editors Achievement Award. In addition to his wife, Andra, he leaves four children, Wendy Mets, Craigie, Debbie & Robert Zildjian, three stepchildren, Kristy Thompson, Mark & Peter Field, eight grandchildren, Paula Charles, Cady & Emily Zildjian-Bickford, Samantha Zildjian, Dakota and Victoria Thompson, Kathryn and Spencer Field, two great-grandchildren, Ian and Gwen Charles, several cousins, nieces and nephews and a brother Robert. Private family services will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: Armand Zildjian Percussion Scholarship, c/o Berklee College of Music, 1140 Boylston Street, Boston, MA 02215; and the Zildjian Family Opportunity Fund, c/o Percussive Arts Society, 701 NW Ferris Ave, Lawton, OK 73507.

title: F.D.A. WANTS MORE INFORMATION ABOUT ENZYME DRUG
description: BioMarin Pharmaceutical Inc. and the Genzyme Corporation must give federal regulators more information before they will approve the companies' Aldurazyme treatment for a life-threatening metabolic disorder. The two biotechnology companies said the Food and Drug Administration had asked about manufacturing plans and how Aldurazyme patients taking the medicine might be monitored. The F.D.A. will not require new human studies, said Dan Quinn, a spokesman for Genzyme. The companies still expect F.D.A. approval this year, he said. BioMarin is based in Novato, Calif., and Genzyme is based in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Labeling CD's Without the Peel-and-Stick Risk
description: High-speed CD-ROM drives provide faster data transfers, but they can run into trouble with self-adhesive CD labels. At high rotational speeds, the weight of the labels can throw the discs off balance, causing unpleasant vibration or even damaging the drive. Advised by manufacturers to avoid stick-on labels, most people have reverted to scribbling on their discs with a marker.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: GATEWAY REPORTS LOSS AS REVENUE DROPS Gateway Inc. yesterday reported its eighth quarterly loss in nine quarters as the company, a maker of personal computers, was hurt by stiff competition, a weak economy and slack technology demand. Gateway, based in Poway, Calif., reported a loss of $72 million, or 22 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, in contrast to net income of $9.4 million, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell to $1.06 billion from $1.14 billion. Analysts had forecast a loss of 19 cents a share on revenue of $1.06 billion, according to Multex. Gateway also said it had received a "Wells notice" from the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to its previously disclosed S.E.C. investigation, which Gateway believes relates to matters from fiscal 2000. A Wells notice gives a company time to mount a defense against a potential action from the S.E.C.   (Reuters)

title: City Offers New Spying Rules In Exchange for More Leeway
description: In a last-minute proposal to settle a dispute over spying on terror suspects, city officials said in federal court yesterday that the police would promise to adopt new guidelines to protect civil liberties if the court lifted a 20-year-old order that limits police surveillance and undercover operations.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: POLICE SHOOT ARMED MAN A police sergeant, answering a report of an armed man threatening to kill himself, struggled with the man and shot him, the authorities said yesterday. The man, identified as Sigfredo Sifre, 42, was grappling with his wife over a gun when the police arrived at the couple's apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, around 10:15 p.m. on Friday, the police said. The sergeant, whose name was not released, tried to subdue Mr. Sifre, who broke free. As he raised the gun toward the sergeant, the sergeant fired three times, striking Mr. Sifre in the chest, arm and abdomen, the police said. Mr. Sifre was taken to Lutheran Hospital, where he was listed in critical condition. The shooting, which follows four fatal shootings by the police this month, appeared to be within department guidelines, according to a preliminary investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENTCHEFF, NICOLAS
description: PENTCHEFF-Nicolas. Died December 22, 2002, age 91, after a long illness. Born in Bulgaria. Educated in Bulgaria, London School of Economics (BS) and Columbia University, NY (MA). Reporter for Zora, Sofia's leading daily; sent to London in 1936. Became Press Attache to Bulgarian Legation, London, in 1940. Remained in England during WWII broadcasting for the BBC. Reinstated at Bulgarian Legation after the War, resigned in 1948 in protest against Bulgaria's Communist regime. Farmed for seven years in Surrey, England, during which time he married Mary Dean. Emigrated to the U.S. in 1956 at the request of Radio Free Europe; he became Chief of the Bulgarian Desk, RFE, NY in 1957. Continued working for RFE until 1991. Vice President of the International Federation of Free Journalists, Treasurer of Inter-American Federation of Newspapermen's Associations, in this capacity, he visited all the Latin American countries. A lecturer at Fairfield University, CT, 1970-1981. In 1990, following Bulgaria's emergence from Communism, he was able to contact and visit his family after 50 years of absence. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Mary, and his son, Nicholas Dean Pentcheff. Memorial service on Saturday, January 4, 12 noon, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Route 100, Somers, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: The Alzheimer's Association, 785 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

title: Candles With Hidden Help
description: Olof Kolte of Sweden designed candlesticks (below) for Skultuna that have three ''steps'' inside that anchor candles up to an inch in diameter. No need to trim or melt to make candles fit. The candlesticks come in four sizes from around 7 inches high to about 21 inches. They are $100 to $222, in brass or silver plate at Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue (37th Street); (212) 879-9779. Mr. Kolte also designed indoor-outdoor torches (right, 28 inches tall) for Ikea, which expects to carry them later this year. The glow -- ''the same type of faint pilot lights that you find along the runways in an airport,'' he said -- comes from light-emitting diodes run by batteries; information is at www.olofkoltedesign.com.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: Remains May Be American Priest's
description: Officials may have found the remains of the Rev. James Carney, an American Jesuit who disappeared in 1983 while accompanying a small leftist rebel group on a doomed invasion. Investigators sent by a local prosecutor found the skeletal remains of about 10 people in a dense jungle near the Nicaraguan border. Some had bullet holes in the skull. Father Carney, who had been expelled from Honduras after an 18-year career ministering to the poor, was chaplain to 100 rebels who were captured and executed by Honduran soldiers soon after slipping into the country. Officials said it would take months to finish tests for a positive identification. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Cloning Case Rejected
description: A judge threw out a petition to appoint a guardian for a baby girl who was reported to be the first human clone when the president of Clonaid, the company claiming to have produced it, testified that the infant was living in Israel and had never been in the United States. In a case brought by a Fort Lauderdale lawyer, Judge John Frusciante of Broward County Circuit Court held the hearing to answer questions about the existence and location of the child, whom Clonaid contends was born in December to an American. The company's president, Dr. Brigitte Boisselier, above, testified that she had never met the infant and had only seen her on videotape. Clonaid is affiliated with a sect that believes space travelers created the human race by cloning. Dana Canedy (NYT)

In a letter to the president, Mr. Hastert said the ban was costing American farmers nearly $300 million a year. The National Corn Growers Association, a powerful farm group, also released a letter to Mr. Bush making the same demand. European officials have said they will lift the moratorium if imports are clearly marked as genetically modified food. Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said he wanted to bring the case before the World Trade Organization. Elisabeth Becker (NYT)

description: Shoppers can spend days scouring flea markets for vintage upholstery and drapery fabrics -- or they can buy inexpensive reproductions of 20th-century patterns from the Reprodepot Web site. The company carries designs from the 1920's through the 1980's. Most of the material is 100 percent cotton, although there are rayons and oilcloth for covering kitchen tables; many of the patterns are reminiscent of the ''I Love Lucy'' era. Alexander Barkcloth influenced by Alexander Girard's 1950's prints, would do the sofa proud. In four colors (gray, above, will be available in March), it is 56 inches wide and $21.95 a yard. There are also poodle prints at $8.25 a yard. Verner Panton's famous black-and-white pattern from the 60's is $46 for a half-yard. Of cotton and polyester, it is 55 inches wide. Information: www.reprodepot.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Phone Concern's Sales Rise
description: Europe's second-largest phone company, France Tlcom, said revenue increased 8.4 percent in 2002, to 46.6 billion euros ($50 billion). The revenue, which was in line with forecasts, was helped by sales in its mobile unit, Orange and its Internet services unit, Wanadoo. Revenue from Orange grew 11.7 percent and revenue from Wanadoo grew 30.4 percent. Last year, France Tlcom's customer base increased 8.1 percent, to 111.7 million, and the number of customers in Europe who signed up for broadband services tripled. Fixed-line services declined 5.2 percent. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: UKRAINE: NEW HEAD FOR EX-SOVIET CLUB President Leonid D. Kuchma was elected the first non-Russian president of the Commonwealth of Independent States, a loose confederation of 12 of the 15 countries that arose from the ashes of the Soviet Union in 1991. Mr. Kuchma, who has been ostracized by the United States because it believes Ukraine sold advanced radar to Iraq, was chosen to replace President Vladimir V. The organization includes all former Soviet republics except Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, but its political importance is slight; a record number of heads of state failed to show at this year's meeting.    Michael Wines (NYT)

title: An Elevator Tower Hangs in the Balance
description: Deconstructivism is being put to a vote in Brooklyn. An elevator tower, below left, added to the former Daily News printing plant, at 535 Dean Street in Prospect Heights, doesn't sit well with some condominium owners in the building. The $500,000 tower by Elena Kalman, the project's architect, is clad in aluminum panels and craggy stucco. It represents, she said, ''the rebirth of the neighborhood, the new emerging out of the old skin.'' But some owners think it jars with the building, and Boymelgreen Developers, who hired Ms. Kalman, is polling them. Linda G. Fine, the sales director, said the race ''between those who think it is cutting edge and those who are unhappy is very close so far.'' The Newswalk complex (interior, below right), has lofts priced from $399,000 to $1.5 million; seven units, with voting rights, remain to be sold. EVE M. KAHN

title: A Window Onto Schumann's Final Period
description: Schumann's heirs were both right and wrong to suppress his Violin Concerto. Written just before his final dip into madness, the piece is weakened by a chaotic last movement and an unedited quality that permeates all three. Present also, however, are the strengths that Schumann learned with age: a firm hand in control of materials and an economy of means that makes much of relatively few ideas.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  In an atmosphere rich with ethnic and judicial politics, the Senate Judiciary Committee voted along party lines today to approve the nomination of Miguel Estrada, a Washington lawyer, to be a judge on the federal appeals court based in Washington.

title: Slide-Rule Set, Nameless No More
description: WERNER SOBEK says he plans to design three houses in his life. Each will require 10 years of research. His first, completed two years ago, was built for his family in Stuttgart, Germany, and was made from 12 tons of steel and 20 tons of glass. It took just 11 weeks to build and has already become a Saturday morning destination for design pilgrims.

title: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER IS NAMED BY A.D.P.
description: Automatic Data Processing Inc., the world's biggest paycheck issuer, named Karen Dykstra as its chief financial officer after she and another executive had shared the duties for the last year and a half. Ms. Dykstra, 44, has worked for 22 years at Automatic Data, most recently as controller and vice president for finance. She succeeds Rich Haviland, who retired in June 2001, said Joan Harper, an Automatic Data spokeswoman. Automatic Data also processes stock trades, prepares payroll-tax returns and screens job candidates. Ms. Dykstra formerly shared the position with Rich Douville, who will remain vice president for finance, the company said.

title: BRITISH PLUMBING COMPANY BUYS 4 NORTH AMERICAN UNITS
description: Wolseley, a leading global distributor of plumbing products, said it had bought four distribution businesses in North America for a total of 37.1 million ($61.1 million). The businesses are the Triangle Supply Company and Wenco Distributors, both in Texas; the Corona, Calif., unit of the York International Corporation; and Meridian Specialties Inc. of Canada.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Shoot Armed Man
description: A police sergeant, answering a report of an armed man threatening to kill himself, struggled with the man and shot him, the authorities said yesterday. The man, identified as Sigfredo Sifre, 42, was grappling with his wife over a gun when the police arrived at the couple's apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, around 10:15 p.m. on Friday, the police said. The sergeant, whose name was not released, tried to subdue Mr. Sifre, who broke free. As he raised the gun toward the sergeant, the sergeant fired three times, striking Mr. Sifre in the chest, arm and abdomen, the police said. Mr. Sifre was taken to Lutheran Hospital, where he was listed in critical condition. The shooting, which follows four fatal shootings by the police this month, appeared to be within department guidelines, according to a preliminary investigation. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Sound-and-Light Show as a Stress Reducer
description: HAVE you ever been lulled into serenity by the flickering firelight of a fireplace? Can machines that produce flickering lights and synchronized audio tones similarly help you relax? Yes, say the users of sound and light machines, some of whom become so relaxed during a session that they fall asleep. What is less verifiable, however, are claims that the machines boost creativity and help alleviate attention deficit disorder, dyslexia and migraine headaches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKINNER, DAVID B., M.D.
description: SKINNER-David B., M.D. The Department of Surgery at Weill Medical College of Cornell University mourns the passing of Dr. David B. Skinner, President Emeritus of NewYork - Presbyterian Hospital and Professor of Surgery at Weill Cornell Medical College. Dr. Skinner's contributions to surgery of the esophagus were legendary, and he was beloved by his many patients for the care he provided them. His vision and management led to the building of the Greenberg Pavilion and the merger of the New York Hospital with the Presbyterian Hospital to form NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital. He was always an outstanding leader and advocate for our Department of Surgery and will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ellie, and his family.

title: From a Storybook, Playful Tools For Watering The Garden
description: After introducing products designed by Todd Oldham and Philippe Starck, Target has set its sights on the storybook set. It is rolling out David Kirk's Sunny Patch line of children's gardening implements, home furnishings including stepstools and hampers, and apparel. Mr. Kirk is known for books like ''Miss Spider's Tea Party.'' Before the Miss Spider books began selling in the millions, Mr. Kirk struggled as a toymaker in King Ferry, N.Y., creating mechanical toys now prized by collectors. His Target line will include sprinklers called the Caterpillar, Miss Spider (both $12.99) and Ladybug ($9.99), all above, and hoes and rakes ($4.99) that will require grown-up supervision. ''Kids are always interested in gardening if you can get them outside and away from video games,'' Mr. Kirk said. CHEE PEARLMAN

title: Preventing Terrorist Attacks
description: As the nation learned so painfully on Sept. 11, nothing is more important to security than good intelligence. That means not only collecting reliable information about terrorist threats but collating it under one roof so connections and patterns can be spotted and timely warnings issued. President Bush has taken a sensible step in that direction with his decision to establish a new Terrorist Threat Integration Center and place it under the command of George Tenet, the nation's spy chief.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: CLONING CASE REJECTED A judge threw out a petition to appoint a guardian for a baby girl who was reported to be the first human clone when the president of Clonaid, the company claiming to have produced it, testified that the infant was living in Israel and had never been in the United States. In a case brought by a Fort Lauderdale lawyer, Judge John Frusciante of Broward County Circuit Court held the hearing to answer questions about the existence and location of the child, whom Clonaid contends was born in December to an American. The company's president, Dr. Brigitte Boisselier, above, testified that she had never met the infant and had only seen her on videotape. Clonaid is affiliated with a sect that believes space travelers created the human race by cloning. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: British Tighten Oversight Rules For Auditors

title: Airlines and Pentagon Discuss Using Commercial Transport Fleet
description: The nation's airlines have held initial discussions with the Pentagon about mobilizing a fleet of commercial and air cargo planes for use in the event of a war with Iraq, aviation officials said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Unity Pushed
description: Russia's foreign minister appealed to Russian executives to present a united position on how Russia will supply oil to the world. The minister, Igor Ivanov, left, asked executives not to confuse Russia's foreign relations by plunging into competing oil export pipeline projects, which will tie Russia's future to neighboring countries for years to come. Russian oil companies are pushing several new export pipelines, including those to China and Russia's Far North, to get their crude oil to world markets. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: G.O.P. Links Judicial Nominees to Thwart Opponents

description: BEIJING, Jan. 30  The Chinese police have detained a United States citizen in connection with efforts by the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement to hijack Chinese television and radio stations earlier this year, the American Embassy here said.

title: Words Provide the Heat at Young Poets' Event
description: They were declaiming, proclaiming, instigating and proudly strutting about the stage. They were by turns beautiful, exuberant, arrogant and exhibitionistic, 28 teenage performance poets at the HBO studios in Midtown Manhattan on Monday night, competing for eight chances to win $1,000 each in scholarship money and to warm up the crowd for a taping of ''Russell Simmons Presents Def Poetry'' on HBO.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: STUDENT MELEE A protest by about 1,000 students at Montwood High School in El Paso turned violent, resulting in minor injuries and a school lockdown, the police said. About 10 people were arrested and nearly 30 injured. Students walked out of school to protest a switch to block scheduling, which means longer classes, and refused to return, according to the police, then began attacking security personnel with stones and glass bottles. The police used tear gas to control the crowd; about 20 students who were exposed were treated at the scene. (AP)

title: Preserving the Recorded Past
description: We live in a culture that thrives on replication, a fact driven in part by accelerating shifts in technology. An avid collector of Miles Davis might own "Kind of Blue" in half a dozen formats, and there seems to be no end in sight to the digitized morphing of one medium into another. Yet what that fever of replication conceals is how rapidly we're also losing the recorded artifacts of our civilization, and not just the early ones.

title: FISHER COMMUNICATIONS SELLS 2 TV STATIONS
description: Fisher Communications Inc., which owns television and radio stations mainly in the Pacific Northwest, said it had sold two television stations in Georgia to Southeastern Media Holdings Inc. for about $40 million. Fisher Communications said the sale would result in a loss of about $17 million. The stations, WFXG-TV in Augusta and WXTX-TV in Columbus, Ga., were sold partly because they ''weren't a good fit for Fisher geographically,'' a company spokesman, Christopher Wheeler, said. ''Fisher plans to be a regional player, and most of its stations are in Washington, Oregon and Idaho.''

Giovanni Agnelli was an extraordinary international leader whose sponsorship of cultural activities advanced the understanding, appreciation, and preservation of world art and architecture. He embodied all the qualities the World Monuments Fund seeks to honor with the Hadrian Award, and we extend our very deepest condolences to his family. Marilyn Perry, Chairman Bonnie Burnham, President World Monuments Fund, New York
