title: Bloomberg Gets Little Help From Pataki for City Budget
description: The state budget that Gov. George E. Pataki proposed here today blew a sizable new hole in the New York City budget plan that his fellow Republican, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, proposed just 24 hours earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHILL, KATHLEEN
description: CAHILL-Kathleen. On January 28, 2003. Loving sister of Rosaleen Fitz-Gibbon, also survived by many cousins. Friends may call at Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home, 1339 York Avenue at 72nd Street on Friday, January 31, 9 AM. Mass of Christian burial to follow at 10 A.M. Interment to take place at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Ridge Announces One-Stop Inspection System
description: MIAMI, Jan. 30  In a move that could shorten the obstacle course faced by travelers at international airports and other ports of entry, the newly created Department of Homeland Security announced today that it intended to create a one-stop inspection system for people arriving in the United States, meaning that a single government inspector would handle passport, customs and agricultural checks for each arriving passenger.

title: Dream Houses Get a Tryout in Vegas
description: TROY PETERSON is a short, compact man who gives the immediate impression that he can handle a hammer. Mr. Peterson, a contractor from Bellevue, Neb., was in Las Vegas last week to attend the International Builders' Show, the largest annual building trades event in the country. A record 92,000 people visited the four-day exhibition of materials, tools, appliances and services.

title: PATAKI SEEKS CUTS IN AID TO SCHOOLS AND HEALTH CARE
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, facing the worst financial crisis in New York since the Great Depression, proposed a budget plan today that would reduce overall spending, deeply cut state aid to schools and sharply curb the money the government spends on health care.

title: Freed From House Arrest, Iranian Vows to Speak Out
description: TEHRAN, Jan. 30  Freed after five years of house arrest, Iran's most senior dissident cleric vowed today to continue his struggle for justice and freedom in Iran's Islamic Republic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTERS, ROSE ''LITTLE ROSE''
description: WINTERS - Rose ''Little Rose'' of Miami Beach, died peacefully, Jan. 28. Beloved wife of late William Winters; mother of Constance; sister of late Mavis and Esta.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: No Third Term
description: Facing growing opposition, the governing party withdrew a bill from Parliament that would have amended the Constitution to allow President Bakili Muluzi to run for a third term. It was the second time in a year that Mr. Muluzi's supporters had unsuccessfully tried to push the matter. This week, angry crowds filled the streets in Blantyre, the commercial hub, and the police fired tear gas and bullets to disperse them. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Security Officials Considering Plan to Combine Terror Forces
description: Moving quickly on President Bush's plan to create a national terrorism threat center, national security officials said today that they were considering moving all counterterrorism operations at the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. into the same building.

title: John Thompson, 77, Leader Of Big Expansion of 7-Eleven
description: John P. Thompson, the leader of the Dallas family who built an ice business into 7-Eleven, the world's largest convenience store chain, died on Tuesday at his home in Dallas. He was 77.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Soros Invests Another $1 Million In Bluefly
description: The billionaire investor George Soros, who has accumulated an 87 percent stake in the money-losing Internet retailer Bluefly Inc., invested $1 million more in the company yesterday. Companies controlled by Mr. Soros received $1 million in convertible promissory notes and warrants to buy 25,000 shares of Bluefly at $1.12 a share, the company said. Mr. Soros has invested about $48 million in Bluefly since July 1999, the company's executive vice president, Jonathan B. Morris, said in an interview. Bluefly, which sells designer clothing at discounts of as much as 75 percent, has not had a profit since beginning its Web site in September 1998. Shares of Bluefly fell 1 cent, to 95 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEGNER, DOROTHY (NEE WAYLER)
description: GEGNER - Dorothy (nee Wayler). On December 27, of Brklyn, NY. Survived by nephews Dr. Alan Wayler and Dr. Barry Wayler. Employed by NYC school system for many years. Interment Monday, December 30, 2 PM, at Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: Blast in North Carolina
description: Three workers were killed and dozens injured when a powerful explosion tore apart a medical-supply factory in Kinston, N.C.

title: BIG S.& L. WILL DROP A.T.M. FEES IN TWO STATES
description: Washington Mutual Inc., a leading savings and loan company, will eliminate fees on automated teller machine withdrawals in New York and New Jersey, giving up revenue in its newest market to win more customers, the chief executive said. The company, which is based in Seattle and entered New York last year when it bought Dime Bancorp for $5.2 billion, would be the largest financial company offering free use of A.T.M.'s in the region. Most major banks charge $1.50 or more for people who do not have accounts to use their networks. The chief executive, Kerry Killinger, said that the elimination of fees in California and Washington had been a significant aid in accelerating new account growth.

title: India Cabinet Shakeup as Economic Reforms Falter
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 30  Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee expanded and shuffled his cabinet today in a move seen as intended to aid India's faltering economic reforms ahead of elections scheduled for late next year.

title: Iran Veers Between Admiration and Resentment of American Power
description: At the Friday Prayer sermon last week at the University of Tehran, Iran's official national pulpit, Ayatollah Mohammad Emami-Kashani condemned the United States for ''drunkenness'' in pursuing the goal of dominating the world.

title: The Mourning After
description: The reaction of Democratic political leaders to President Bush's next-to-final speech before liberating Iraq was the Scottish verdict ''Not proven.'' Hastening to agree that Saddam is a monster and a menace, they are careful to express reservations about removing him from power at this particular moment, or without U.N. approval.

title: Factory Explodes in North Carolina, Killing 3
description: Three workers were killed and dozens injured by a powerful explosion in a medical-supply plant here today that ignited a raging chemical fire, hurling fireballs and spewing plumes of acrid smoke across the eastern North Carolina sky.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Output Falls
description: Industrial production fell for the fourth consecutive month. Output fell 0.1 percent in December compared with November and companies built fewer machines and equipment used to make semiconductors. The government expects production to rise 2.1 percent in January and fall 1.1 percent in February. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Indonesia Clears Top Islamic Militant in Attacks on Christians
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 30 — An Indonesian court acquitted a prominent Islamic militant leader today on charges of inciting Muslims to attack Christians on the religiously divided Maluku Islands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, MARTHA
description: ZIMMERMAN-Martha. January 28, age 88. of Fort Lee, N.J. Loving wife of Edward and mother of Peter, both deceased. Loving mother of Richard. Beloved grandmother of Jason and Jennifer anddoting great-grandmother to Jordan, Corey and Lincoln. Her beauty and dignity will be missed. Graveside services 11:15AM, Jan 30, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, N.Y. Detail: 631-249-7000.

title: The State of the Union: Resolve and Doubt; War on Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Presses White House to Disclose Evidence Against Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The leaders of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee pressed the Bush administration today to sharpen its message and disclose its most damning evidence against Iraq, so that reluctant American allies and the American people know why war may be necessary.

title: The Israeli Vote: What Was the Message?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAO, DR. IVAN
description: CHAO-Dr. Ivan. Loving husband of Alice Chao. Father of Myrna S. Chao and Conklin Chao. Grandfather of Justy Chao DeWaal and Nyasia L. Chao DeWaal. Born in Shanghai, China. Died January 28, 2003 at age 93 in Brooklyn. Accomplished Professor of Philosophy and author. Ph.D. Harvard University. Member of underground resistance force against the Japanese occupation of Shanghai. Founder of Women's College in Shanghai. Taught at numerous universities including National Taiwan University, Zhang Zhe (National Political) University of Taiwan and University of New Mexico. Former President of Chinese American Culture Institute and Chairman, Overseas Chinese New Culture Association. A scholar and a gentleman. Graveside ceremony at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Farmingdale, 11AM, January 30th with a memorial banquet to follow later. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Brooklyn Heights Montessori School (Dr. Ivan Chao Memorial Fund for China Studies) would be appreciated.

title: A Pledge of Assistance for Bush From 8 European Leaders
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 — Assuming a somewhat frayed mantle as global diplomat, Prime Minister Tony Blair set off for the United States tonight to meet with President Bush, bearing an unusual pledge of support on Iraq from eight European leaders but leaving behind a continent ever more divided over the need for war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIDDINGS, RENEE ROSS
description: GIDDINGS-Renee Ross. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Daniel. Devoted mother of Jeoffrey and Wendy Jane Gold and the late Douglas Alan. Dear sister of Barclay H. Bloomgarden and late sister Fantine Joy Finberg. Loving grandmother and greatgrandmother. Services and interment were held Sunday, December 29.

title: Bush Administration to Seek Exemptions to 2005 Ban of a Pesticide
description: The Bush administration is moving to help industries keep using a pesticide that is to be banned under an international agreement to restore the earth's protective ozone layer, several government officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNING, JOHN
description: BROWNING - John. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the untimely passing of its beloved friend, the eminent American pianist John Browning, on January 26, 2003 at the age of 69. A Steinway Artist for more than 46 years, Mr. Browning was an articulate master of the piano who captivated audiences wherever he played. He leaves a legacy rich with historic performances and award-winning recordings. John Browning earned the wide respect of his colleagues and a special place in the hearts of Steinway employees and dealer representatives everywhere. To his family we extend our heartfelt condolences. He will be deeply missed. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Vying For Spare Change
description: Detroit is testing a new method of reducing the number of panhandlers: competing with them for loose change. Beginning on Saturday, plastic collection boxes will be set up in downtown shops, to attract donations that will go to aid the homeless. Shop owners have argued that panhandling hurts the city's campaign to spruce up downtown. Also under the new program, social workers will approach panhandlers on the street, informing them of a variety of services available to them, including shelters, drug treatment and job training.

title: The State of the Union: Resolve and Doubt; Pre-emptive Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MELVIN
description: BERNSTEIN-Melvin. Daddy, I will always be your little girl. Jane

title: South Korean President Defends Shift of Funds
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 30  Government auditors said today that nearly $200 million was moved through a large corporation to North Korea in advance of President Kim Dae Jung's summit meeting with the North Korean leader Kim Jong Il in June 2000.

title: New Yorkers Take Half the Slots In Finals of Top Science Contest
description: Half of the 40 finalists named yesterday in the national Intel Science Talent Search were from New York State.

title: Bush's Moral Rectitude Is a Tough Sell in Old Europe
description: On topics from AIDS and addiction to terrorism and Iraq, President Bush's State of the Union address was shot through with a quality that has come to mark his presidency: an unblinking brand of public moralism that most politicians would shrink from in a largely secular age.

title: Sports of The Times; Ownership By a Casino A Bad Spin
description: THE message is in the name. Now there is not only an American professional sports team playing at a gambling casino, but it is also named for the casino. The Connecticut Sun, the latest relocated team in the struggling Women's National Basketball Association, is not a tribute to glimmering sunsets across the Connecticut coast.

title: Correction Officers at Nassau Jail Stage Delay
description: About 60 correction officers at the Nassau County jail delayed reporting to their posts for about 45 minutes this morning because of what their union leader described as mounting concerns over unruly inmates and the lack of a special section in which to confine them.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: New Head For Ex-Soviet Club
description: President Leonid D. Kuchma was elected the first non-Russian president of the Commonwealth of Independent States, a loose confederation of 12 of the 15 countries that arose from the ashes of the Soviet Union in 1991. Mr. Kuchma, who has been ostracized by the United States because it believes Ukraine sold advanced radar to Iraq, was chosen to replace President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the commonwealth's summit meeting in Kiev. The organization includes all former Soviet republics except Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, but its political importance is slight; a record number of heads of state failed to show at this year's meeting. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Protesters Greet City's New Human Rights Panel With Chants of 'Hamas!'
description: The first meeting of the city's newly reappointed Human Rights Commission got off to a rocky start last night, as protesters stood up and loudly accused one of its members of having links to a terrorist group, prompting police officers to force them from the room.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: OIL UNITY PUSHED Russia's foreign minis- ter appealed to Russian executives to present a united position on how Russia will supply oil to the world. The minister, Igor Ivanov, left, asked executives not to confuse Russia's foreign relations by plunging into competing oil export pipeline projects, which will tie Russia's future to neighboring countries for years to come. Russian oil companies are pushing several new export pipelines, including those to China and Russia's Far North, to get their crude oil to world markets. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Europe Proposes Tougher Penalties for Counterfeiters
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 30  The European Commission proposed new measures against counterfeiters today, recommending that those who copy goods ranging from software programs to perfume should face jail sentences and stiffer fines, as well as having their bank accounts frozen.

title: Pakistan Asks U.S. to Reduce Restrictions on Its Citizens
description: Pakistan's foreign minister urged senior American officials today to ease regulations requiring Pakistani men in the United States to be registered and fingerprinted. He suggested that Islamabad would find it easier to defend American military action in Iraq if the rules were changed.

title: New Jerseyans Expect Doctors Not to Be In
description: As New Jersey braces for a work stoppage by doctors on Monday, physicians are canceling appointments, emergency rooms are planning for a sudden influx of patients, and many residents -- including the governor -- are beginning to fret about disruptions in health care.

title: Doubts Are Emerging as Bush Pushes His Medicare Plan
description: With President Bush on the road promoting his $400 billion plan to revamp Medicare, members of Congress from both parties expressed doubts about its feasibility today, forcing administration officials to reconsider important elements of the package.

title: Health Care Leaders Voice Doubts on Smallpox Inoculations
description: Serious doubts about the president's smallpox vaccination plan emerged today at a Senate hearing from the very health care professionals who have been asked to get or administer the vaccine.

title: Ex-G.E. Chief's Divorce Case Hits a Bump
description: The divorce proceedings between John F. Welch Jr., the former chairman and chief executive of General Electric, and his wife, Jane Beasley Welch, have hit another bump.

title: Barred as Race Fixer in 1980, a Jockey Seeks Reinstatement of His License
description: The 23 years of banishment are etched across Jose Amy's face as he sits in a Belmont Park kitchen arguing his case. They have taken his youth and his cockiness away and deprived him of millions in earnings. What's left is a graying exercise rider with a few creases pecking away at his features, a polite smile and an unmistakable need for redemption. He doesn't just ask for it; he pleads for it.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Growth Outlook Lowered
description: The German government lowered its economic growth forecast for 2003 to 1 percent from 1.5 percent, acknowledging that economic conditions will remain difficult in 2003, after growth in 2002 of 0.2 percent. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Bereft Writers Are Used to It
description: Inured. That best describes much of book publishing to the changes and rumors of changes swirling about it. What used to be considered catastrophic now seems routine. Live by a volcano and smoke becomes just part of the atmosphere.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Huge Cache Of Cocaine Seized
description: State and federal authorities said yesterday that they seized more than 4,000 pounds of cocaine from Mexico hidden in the walls of a railroad tanker car. The cocaine was seized on Tuesday night at a warehouse at 51-18 Grand Avenue in Maspeth, officials said. The raid was headed by investigators from the Office of the Special Narcotics Prosecutor and the federal Drug Enforcement Administration. Bridget G. Brennan, who heads the prosecutor's office, said the tanker car was parked on a rail spur outside the warehouse. Drug traffickers had siphoned off a quantity of vegetable oil concealing the drugs and cut through the tanker's internal walls to remove the cocaine. Four men were arrested on conspiracy and drug charges, said Anthony P. Placido, head of the D.E.A.'s New York office. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: France and Germany Praise U.S. Pledge to Disclose Evidence on Iraq
description: European and other leaders today welcomed President Bush's State of the Union announcement that the United States would disclose its evidence on Iraqi weapons programs, but other responses to the speech mirrored the disagreements that have long existed on the issue of any war with Iraq.

title: Mayor Says Response to Boys' 911 Call Shows a Need for More Training
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg questioned yesterday whether the Police Department's 911 operators and supervisors needed more training, as the city continued to explore why a supervisor mishandled a call for help from a Bronx teenager who disappeared with three friends in Long Island Sound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, STANLEY
description: MARTIN-Stanley. Formerly of Rye, NY, on December 23, age 97. Served in military intelligence, WWII. Retired senior editor, D.C. Heath and Company. Widower of Catherine Brod Martin. Survived by Kenneth of San Diego, Edward of Winchester, MA, and two granddaughters.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the effects of a new campaign finance law on political fund-raising events at the Super Bowl misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the National Football League, who dismissed complaints by some Democrats that Republicans are allowed to buy more tickets. He is Joe Browne, not Brown.

title: Red Light, Green Light: A 2-Tone L.E.D. to Simplify Screens
description: IT started in the Netherlands with work on organic light-emitting diodes, or O.L.E.D.'s, the glowing electronic devices made with plastics rather than silicon and other traditional semiconductors.

title: MetroStars Pursuing Spanish Player
description: The MetroStars are pursuing Mario Alberto Rosas Montero, a 22-year-old Spanish midfielder from the Alaves club of La Liga.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, JOSEPH
description: JACOBSON-Joseph. At 104 years old. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Devoted father of Stanley (Rhoda). Loving grandfather of Howard (Angela), Andrew (Deedee) and Marc. Great-grandfather of Haylie and Kyle. Dear brother of Lillian Hockstein and Etta Veder. Services Tuesday, 12:15 PM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162 - 05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Ireland to Ban Smoking in Workplaces
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 30 — Ireland will ban smoking in all workplaces, including pubs and restaurants, from the beginning of next year, Health Minister Micheal Martin said today. Tobacco manufacturers and pub operators criticized the ban as unenforceable and an infringement of personal liberties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEIS, AKEDA, MD.
description: GLEIS-Akeda, MD. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, N.J. mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Jeffrey R. Parker, President

title: Just When You Need It, A Nudge From an Online Nag
description: Need to track a project or a to-do list? Need the information to be online and always available? Do you want to receive reminders by e-mail or text message? Where project management software would be too complex and personal organizing software too simple, OnlineHomeBase.com steps in.

title: Antismoking Campaign Shifts Media Account
description: The American Legacy Foundation in Washington is shifting the media part of its ''Truth'' antismoking account to Media Head in New York, a new agency, from Arnold MPG in Boston, part of the Media Planning Group of Havas. The campaign spends an estimated $50 million to $60 million a year to try to discourage teenagers from smoking.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture on Tuesday showing troops in the Persian Gulf region, with a stretcher in the foreground, carried an incorrect caption in some copies, and in other copies their unit designation was misstated. The picture showed soldiers of Company B, First Battalion, 30th Infantry (not 130th), from Fort Benning, Ga., crouching around a soldier who was injured in a night training exercise in Kuwait. (A picture of troops aboard the assault ship Nassau had originally been scheduled for use.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, ROBERT W.
description: ROSENBLATT - Robert W. 80, on December 28. Loving and devoted husband of Helene (Scheuer). Father of Bill and Roberta, Ron and Susy, David and Robyn, Larry and Linda, Ann and Stuart. Brother of Richard and Lois, Peter and Naomi. Grandfather of Charles, Marc, Becky and Josh and Devon, Casson, Caren, Richard, Andrew, Rachel, Betsy, Katie. Bob loved being the kind and warm center of his ever-expanding family; we will all miss him so much. Private graveside service Tuesday. If desired, the family suggests contributions be made to the Robert W. Rosenblatt Memorial Fund, c/o Jewish Communal Fund, 130 E. 59 St, Suite 1204, NY, NY 10022; 212-752-8277.

title: A Biologist Will Lead Smithsonian Museum
description: The Smithsonian Institution has named Cristian Samper, a 37-year-old biologist, as director of the National Museum of Natural History.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Issues Rules For Satellite Companies
description: After more than two years of review, the Federal Communications Commission issued rules yesterday allowing satellite communications companies to set up land-based networks to carry their service in urban areas and indoor sites where satellite signals are obstructed. The agency also canceled the licenses of three small companies that had not met deadlines to construct satellites for proposed systems. It also reclaimed 30 megahertz of spectrum that had been assigned for satellite service but not used. That spectrum will be auctioned off to land-based cellular companies. The rules appear to be a victory for satellite companies like ICO Global Communications over the opposition of land-based cellular carriers like Verizon and AT&T, but the agency has not yet published crucial technical specifications covering devices like handsets. Such details, which could be delayed until next week, will affect the cost and convenience of any expanded satellite service. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: A Poetic Underground-Comic Vision
description: At Documenta in Kassel, Germany, where exhaustingly righteous and civically well-meaning art was spread voluminously across the city last year, the sight of Raymond Pettibon's lurid drawings came as a relief and tonic. His work, especially in that context but also otherwise, has the virtue of its dark, antic eccentricity, a certain underground comic book messiness that is really graphic virtuosity in disguise -- not to mention that it is also poetic, the opposite of pedantic.

title: Disney Net Is Down 42%, But Its Revenue Rises 6%
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that an increase in visitors to its United States theme parks and a strong television advertising market helped bolster results in its most recent quarter, though a write-down of aircraft-related leases dragged down net income.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Canon's Profit Doubles
description: Profit at Canon doubled in the last quarter of 2002 as sales of digital cameras and other consumer products surged. The company, the world's largest office equipment maker, earned 60 billion yen ($503 million), twice the profit of the period a year earlier. Sales grew 14.4 percent. For all of 2002, sales and profit set records. Canon's net income was 191 billion yen, a 13.8 percent increase over the previous year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: With Antiwar Poetry Set, Mrs. Bush Postpones Event
description: Laura Bush has postponed a White House symposium on the works of Emily Dickinson, Langston Hughes and Walt Whitman after some of the poets invited said they hoped to use the event to protest American military action in Iraq.

title: Two Quick Goals in 3rd Delay 4th Loss in a Row
description: Just about everyone else at Madison Square Garden roared after the Rangers scored twice in 28 seconds to grab a late lead last night, but not the man in the checkered charcoal-gray suit blithely chewing bubble gum behind the bench.

title: State Dept. Link Will Open Visa Database to Police Officers
description: Law enforcement officials across the country will soon have access to a database of 50 million overseas applications for United States visas, including the photographs of 20 million applicants.

title: Can You Speak Pataki?
description: New York City's mayor, Michael Bloomberg, and Gov. George Pataki must be speaking different languages. The Bloomberg budget proposal, complete with eye-straining, number-laden charts, begged for help. Mr. Pataki's plan answered with a snub. As the long process of reconciling state and city needs begins, the governor must understand that he cannot afford to let his budget stall the urban engines that run the entire state.

description: Bush Expected to Propose Expansion of Savings Plans

title: Police Study The Killing Of a Couple In Brooklyn
description: Investigators were weighing several theories yesterday in the slaying of a Brooklyn woman and her husband, and much of the evidence suggests that they were killed by someone they knew, the authorities said.

title: Elections in 2 German States May Be Setback to Schrder
description: The poster says, ''Choose peace,'' and it shows Chancellor Gerhard Schrder next to Sigmar Gabriel, the candidate for Mr. Schrder's Social Democratic Party in a local election campaign viewed here as a referendum on the national government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ANDREW S.
description: COHEN-Andrew S. Age 44, of St. Paul, died unexpectedly on January 27, 2003. Andrew was born March 3, 1958, in Washington, DC. He grew up in Manhattan and attended The Dalton School and various colleges including Hampshire College, the University of Vermont and George Washington University. Andrew moved to Minnesota in 1991 where he met and married Bridget Murphy. Together they had two sons, Oliver, now age 6, and Benjamin, age 5. Andrew worked for the past three years at GiftCerticates.com as a senior computer network engineer. He volunteered many hours of his time for the Minnesota Literacy Council and Alcoholics Anonymous. Andrew loved reading (even while in the shower), long motorcycle trips, talking about and eating great food, East Hampton, Bob Dylan, falling asleep virtually anywhere and being with his family and many friends. But Andrew will be remembered most as a profoundly kind and gentle man who loved his sons above all else. Embodying a unique and wonderful mix of intelligence, curiosity, wry humor, sweetness, and a limitless capacity for unconditional love, Andrew, a man like no other, will be greatly missed. Survived by sons Oliver and Benjamin; ex-wife Bridget Murphy Cohen; parents Richard and Evelyn; sister Frances Cohen (Alan Green); sister Emilie Cohen (John Williams); sister Sarah Jane Grossbard (Michael); nieces Isobel Green, Summer Williams, Lily Grossbard and Lucy Grossbard; nephew Henry Green. Funeral services Sunday, February 2, 1:00 P.M., Jewish Center for the Hamptons, Montauk Highway, East Hampton, LI. For further information, contact Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1-800-448-1939. Memorial service to celebrate Andrew's life, Thursday, February 6, at 7:30 P.M., Mark Stanton's home, 213 Mount Hope Drive in St. Paul, MN. Memorials preferred to the Oliver and Benjamin Cohen Fund, 400 Minnesota Building, 46 East 4th St, St. Paul, MN, 55105 or The Dalton School, 108 East 89th St., New York, NY 10028.

title: Dr. Alexander Thomas, 89; Studied Human Temperament

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Palisades Park: Counterfeiting Arrest
description: A businessman has been accused of counterfeiting $1.2 million worth of designer handbags and other accessories, including Coach products. The police chief, Michael Vietri, said yesterday that officers found sewing machines and rolls of material with the Coach logo inside the warehouse of the businessman, Habib Fermano, in Palisades Park during an unrelated visit for a burst water pipe on Saturday. Mr. Fermano, 48, of Closter, owner of Lovely Handbag, was arrested Wednesday and charged with counterfeiting a trademark. His lawyer, Frank B. Lucianna, said Mr. Fermano bought the material legally and was unaware of the trademark. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Sign of Drug Ring's Presence: Tenant Meeting Was Quiet, Too Quiet
description: Last March, the police went to a tenant association meeting at a Brooklyn housing development expecting an earful about a growing drug problem in Coney Island. But when a detective asked the gathered residents about drug sales, he was met with silence.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: SAP Reports Rise In Profit And Sales
description: Europe's largest software maker, SAP, increased its operating profit margin and sales for the full year 2002, beating its own target and market expectations. The company increased its operating margin of 20 percent in 2001 to 22.7 percent, while sales rose 1.4 percent, to 7.4 billion euros ($8 billion), gaining market share both from smaller rivals and leading American competitors in the business-software sector. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: TV's Sinking Language
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNY Says It Must Raise Tuition but Will Try to Limit Increase
description: The City University of New York will have to raise tuition next year, its chancellor, Matthew Goldstein, said yesterday, but will try to keep the increase below the $1,200 authorized in Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget.

title: New Beverage From Snapple Seeks to Avoid Stigma of Dieting
description: Trying to take some of the public embarrassment out of dieting, Snapple yesterday announced a new meal-replacement product that it hopes looks less like a weight-loss aid and more like, well, a Snapple.

title: With Mexican Peso Falling, Officials Search for Answers
description: The Mexican peso is falling, and no one seems to be able to say exactly why, or to do much to slow its fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMETTERER, ROSALIE
description: SCHMETTERER - Rosalie, 87, died peacefully in her sleep at her home, Plantation Village, in Wilmington, NC. Born Rosalia Fernandez in Westfield, MA, she and her husband Robert (deceased 1980) lived most of their lives in Hillsdale, NJ. A remarkable woman, who spent her life giving to others, Rosalie was a great inspiration to all who knew her. There was always an honest word and an answer to every question. She was an insatiable reader, conversationalist, lover of music, animals, scrabble and most of all, her family and friends. She led an extremely full life and left us with so many wonderful memories that the thoughts of her will always be with a smile, and even sometimes with a giggle. She was our hero and will be sorely missed by all. A memorial service will be held in NJ. She is honored by her two sons and their wives, Bob and Stacy of NYC, Richard and Donna of Wilmington, NC, and her three grandchildren and their partners, Adam and Erika of Stockholm, Sweden, Tyler and Sharon of NYC, and Tracy and Michael of Los Angeles, CA. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Ocean Reef Cat Rescue (ORCAT), 24 Dockside Lane, #

title: Doctor Accuses Merck of Fraud in Drug Sales
description: A Louisiana doctor is contending that Merck defrauded the federal Medicare and Medicaid programs as it marketed its heartburn drug, Pepcid, to hospitals and nursing homes in the 1990's, according to court records that were recently unsealed.

title: Though Wigginton Blends In, He Is Hoping to Stand Out
description: If he had not been wearing a blue-and-yellow bowling shirt at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan yesterday, Ty Wigginton would have blended in with the crowd at John Franco's charity event. Blending in is what Wigginton usually does, even though he is -- for now -- the starting third baseman for the Mets.

title: 2 Hit Men Get 23-Year Terms For Killing Wife of a Rabbi
description: The two men who admitted killing the wife of a prominent South Jersey rabbi in 1994 were sentenced today to 23 years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGER, GEORGE
description: BRAGER-George, 80. Of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Loving, compassionate, and devoted husband, father, and grandfather whose empathy, wit and charm affected all around him, died on January 29, 2003 of complications from cardio - pulmonary disease. Brager was a highly respected social worker whose career and writing profoundly influenced his field. During the early 1960's he joined with other activists to found and direct Mobilization for Youth, the social action organization on Manhattan's Lower East Side, which provided the organizational model for the social programs of War on Poverty. In the 1970's Brager joined the Faculty of the Columbia University School of Social Work, where he served as Dean from 1981 to 1986. Brager was particulary proud of his role helping to establish and develop the Center for Urban Community Services (CUCS) to which contributions can be made in Bragers honor in lieu of flowers. Services will be held at noon today at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mt Vernon, N.Y. with visitation at the family home following the funeral.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Commerce One Posts Wider 4th-Quarter Loss
description: Commerce One Inc., an unprofitable maker of software for buying goods over the Internet, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss widened as sales fell. The net loss widened to $279.5 million, or $9.57 a share, from $168.3 million, or $5.90, a year earlier, the company said. Sales dropped to $19.5 million from $56 million, or 65 percent. Sales have plummeted as Commerce One's software for setting up Internet marketplaces has failed to attract enough buyers.

title: Empty Promises
description: Everyone expects a certain amount of hokum in a State of the Union address. But for artful misdirection it's hard to top the three paragraphs in which President Bush promised to protect the environment while promoting energy independence. Set aside for the moment the meagerness of his menu, as well as the plain fact that he has spent the last two years rolling back laws and regulations that have long guarded the nation's air, water and public lands. The real tipoff to his intentions lies in the three proposals themselves. Whatever their long-term promise, none would do much good in the short term and some would actually do harm.

title: 'After and Before' -- 'Documenting the A-Bomb'
description: Roth Horowitz

title: Satellites Said to See Activity At North Korean Nuclear Site
description: American spy satellites over North Korea have detected what appear to be trucks moving the country's stockpile of 8,000 nuclear fuel rods out of storage, prompting fears within the Bush administration that North Korea is preparing to produce roughly a half dozen nuclear weapons, American officials said today.

title: Top Lawyer In Maryland Calls for End To Executions
description: With as many as seven inmates in his state facing execution in the next few months, Maryland's attorney general called yesterday for the abolition of the death penalty.

title: Unrepentant Shoe Bomber Is Given a Life Sentence For Trying to Blow Up Jet
description: Richard C. Reid, who said he was a member of Al Qaeda and pleaded guilty to trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight with explosives concealed in his shoes, was sentenced today to life in prison.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Estimates Rebuilding Iraq Will Cost $30 Billion
description: The United Nations, stepping up the pace of its contingency planning for rebuilding Iraq after war, has concluded the costs will run to at least $30 billion in the first three years, according to the organization's top development official.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend last Friday about ''Cookin' at the Cookery,'' a play about the blues singer Alberta Hunter after her return to the stage in 1977 at age 82, misstated the occupation she practiced for the previous 20 years at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island. (The error also occurred in her obituary on Oct. 19, 1984; in a Topics column on the editorial page on Oct. 21, 1984; and in a brief review in the New Jersey section on Jan. 27, 2002.) She was a licensed practical nurse, not a scrub nurse.

title: Editorial Observer; Why Today's Europeans Object to America's Worldview
description: When you fly into the Basel airport, you have a choice between two exits. One leads to Switzerland and Germany, the other to France. Little effort is devoted to indicating which is which. There are fewer armed guards visible than at any major airport in America. You can wander accidentally into the wrong country. Considering that three different languages are spoken within a mile and that the Rhine River nearby flowed for centuries with the blood of conflict, the airport's casual borders are a reminder of what contemporary Europe has become -- a near-haven of harmonious coexistence.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZILDJIAN, ARMAND
description: ZILDJIAN-Armand. Of Scottsdale, Arizona, and Quechee, Vermont (formerly Hingham, MA), President and Chairman of the Zildjian Company in Norwell, MA, died Thursday at his home in Scottsdale. He was 81. Born in Quincy, he attended local schools, including Thayer Academy and Colgate University until called to serve in the Philippines in 1942. Upon his return, he entered the family business, the world's largest cymbal manufacturer and the oldest company in America. An amateur musician himself, Zildjian said he felt privileged to have been born into a musical dynasty, which dates back to 1623. Appointed President two years before his father's death, Armand took over the role of family patriarch in 1977. Zildjian was known for his charismatic personality and warm personal relationship with drummers. He had selected cymbals for such drummers as Gene Krupa, Buddy Rich, Max Roach, Jo Jones and many others and matched cymbals for the Boston Symphony and leading orchestras around the world. The foremost authority in cymbal sound, he created new product innovations in response to the ever-changing needs of musicians and remained deeply involved in the operation of the company until his death. Zildjian received an honorary doctorate from Berklee College of Music, was inducted into the Percussive Arts Society Hall of Fame, and Guitar Center's Rock Walk in Hollywood, and most recently received Moder Drummer Magazine Editors Achievement Award. In addition to his wife, Andra, he leaves four children, Wendy Mets, Craigie, Debbie & Robert Zildjian, three stepchildren, Kristy Thompson, Mark & Peter Field, eight grandchildren, Paula Charles, Cady & Emily Zildjian-Bickford, Samantha Zildjian, Dakota and Victoria Thompson, Kathryn and Spencer Field, two great-grandchildren, Ian and Gwen Charles, several cousins, nieces and nephews and a brother Robert. Private family services will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: Armand Zildjian Percussion Scholarship, c/o Berklee College of Music, 1140 Boylston Street, Boston, MA 02215; and the Zildjian Family Opportunity Fund, c/o Percussive Arts Society, 701 NW Ferris Ave, Lawton, OK 73507.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Illegal Pesticides Discovered
description: Federal inspectors have found hundreds of cases of illegal and potentially deadly pesticides made in China and Germany and sold in Chinatown and other Asian neighborhoods in the city, officials said yesterday. The Environmental Protection Agency said that in an inspection last week, it discovered more than 500 cases of illegal pesticides at three Queens distribution centers. Two of the three distributors have disposed of the products and the third is about to return them to the manufacturers, officials said. The pesticides were used in cleaners, as well as in products to kill roaches and mice. The products were sold under names like Zebra Mosquito Coils, Miraculous Chinese Chalk and Fuzhou Ant Killer. Daisy Hernandez (NYT)

title: Using Ditsy Maxims for Erotic Self-Help
description: ''The Guru'' has a canny, genre-bending gleam in its eye. If a martial-arts fantasy like ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon'' can break the bank by taking Hong Kong-style action-adventure into the international mainstream, it supposes, how about mixing and matching a conventional romantic comedy with an Indian extravaganza: Hollywood meets Bollywood?

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Investigators Entered U.S. With Fake Names and ID's
description: On a day the new Homeland Security Department wanted to trumpet streamlined and tightened border inspections for travelers entering the United States, the agency had to explain why undercover investigators had been able to cross into the country using counterfeit identification papers and bogus names.

title: Baseball Players See a Down Market but Smell Collusion
description: A perennial All-Star catcher and Gold Glove winner, he played for the Texas Rangers the past five years under a $42 million contract, and last week Ivan Rodriguez -- unable to secure a high-paying multiyear deal -- signed a one-year contract with the Florida Marlins for what amounted to less than $10 million.

title: Crime Wave With Shades of the Past
description: TWO entirely different new network crime shows are scheduled opposite each other on Sunday night.

title: Syphilis Cases in the City Rise By 55%, Health Officials Say
description: The number of syphilis cases in New York City rose by 55 percent last year from 2001, with the increase primarily among gay and bisexual men, health department officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, EMMA (ROSE)
description: WINTER-Emma (Rose). Of Needham, MA, formerly of New York City, on Friday, December 27, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sidney C. Winter. Devoted mother of Irene J. Winter and her husband Robert Hunt, Pearl W. Bartelt and her husband David and Frederick A. Winter and his wife Joan Smith. Loving grandmother of four and great-grandmother of two. Also survived by loving nieces. Services at the Levine Chapel, 470 Harvard Street, Brookline, MA, on Tuesday, December 31, at 11 AM.

title: Hard Lessons in a Devilishly Devious C.I.A.
description: ''The Recruit,'' which opens nationwide today, takes place within the shadowy world of the Central Intelligence Agency, where, we are repeatedly told, nothing is what it seems. This is true of the movie as well: it seems like a spy thriller, but it really isn't. Sure, there are car and foot chases, some gunplay, a lot of breathless exposition and the frenetic uploading and downloading of files that is a staple of the modern high-tech Hollywood suspense film.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOO, DR. ROBERT K.
description: LOO-Dr. Robert K. Professor at Queensborough Community College. Passed peacefully on December 25, 2002, in Queens, NY. Born in Hawaii on May 1, 1937. Survived by wife Dr. Margaret T. Pan-Loo, four sons and four grandchildren. His family and friends were blessed with his love. The family will receive friends on Monday, December 30, from 3-7 PM, at Chun Fook Funeral Home, 134-35 Northern Blvd, Flushing, NY. Funeral Mass at 9:45 AM, Tuesday, December 31 at St. Kevin Catholic Church, 45-21 194th St, Flushing, NY. Graveside service at 11 AM, in Flushing Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBMAN, REBECCA
description: LIEBMAN - Rebecca. Died January 29, 2003 in her 91st year. Lifelong resident of Woodmere, NY. Daughter of Fanny Saul Liebman and Morris Liebman. Beloved sister of the late Emily Greenwald Meyer and devoted aunt of the late Diana Greenwald and Alice Greenwald Ward and David Ward. Greataunt of Leda and Nat Ward. Former grade school teacher in Mineola and owner of The Uniform Shop, Woodmere. Contributions to UJA in lieu of flowers. Graveside service, 10:30 AM, February 2nd, Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: For Future Subway Riders, Automation at the Station
description: In the animated television series ''Futurama,'' set in New York City in the 31st century, mass transit has become so seamless that it requires almost no one to run it. Passengers are simply blown headfirst around the city through shiny pneumatic tubes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORSE, THELMA
description: MORSE-Thelma. 10 years since you left us. Always in our thoughts and hearts. Stan, Peter and Richar

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BELGIUM: PARLIAMENT APPROVES GAY MARRIAGES Belgium's Parliament passed a law yesterday permitting same-sex marriages, making the country the second in Europe to do so, after the Netherlands. The Belgian law, approved by 91 deputies, with 22 against and 9 abstentions, will give homosexual couples most of the rights of heterosexual ones, including inheritance rights. But it will not allow gay couples to adopt children legally. The law, which had already been passed by the Senate, will take effect four months after its official registration.    Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: MAKING KENNEDY AIRPORT SAFER Decades after wind shear caused a plane to crash at Kennedy International Airport, the federal government has installed equipment designed to detect such deadly shifts in surface winds. On Wednesday, the Federal Aviation Administration installed what is known as terminal Doppler weather radar at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn. The F.A.A. was prompted to invent the technology after an Eastern Airlines plane crashed at Kennedy International in 1975. The F.A.A. began installing the radar at airports in 45 other cities nine years ago. But political disputes about where to put the radar, a 37-foot ball atop an 82-foot tower, delayed its installation to serve Kennedy.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.+ means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only.+++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for performances last Saturday night only.

title: After Long Delay, New York Submits Plan for Terror Aid
description: Nearly a year and a half after the Sept. 11 attacks, the Pataki administration has finally told the federal government how it plans to spend hundreds of millions of available dollars to make New York State better prepared to deal with future terrorist attacks.

title: Glimpse of the Ceramics Trove Collected by a Syracuse Museum
description: By 1916 Adelaide Alsop Robineau (1865-1929) of Syracuse, a world-class studio potter who had been awarded international prizes for her porcelains, thought she deserved a little local recognition. She wrote to Fernando Carter, then director of the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts (now the Everson Museum of Art), pointing out that the city could boast of two unique products: the salt mined from its beds and her pots.

title: The Neediest Cases; Brothers and Family Get Help in Regaining Financial Footing
description: ''I got no eyes,'' said Daniel Tanner, 8, smiling.

title: A Blue Collar Doctor Tracks Ground Zero Workers
description: HIGH-PROFILE healers don't opt to practice occupational medicine: it's a blue collar science, dominated by asbestos and asthma and lead poisoning. Only a fellow fixated on being a doctor since he was 6 but captivated in the 60's by the effect one's station in life has on one's health would willingly veer off the beaten path -- a surgery internship at Bellevue and a psychiatry residency at St. Luke's -- into this branch of medicine.

title: Levittown by the Bay? Looks Can Deceive
description: To the Editor:

title: A Classic Fable of Life After Loss, With New York as Backdrop
description: ''The Winter's Tale'' was one of Shakespeare's last plays, and, beginning with the title, it overflows with the signals of resignation, accrued wisdom and compassion that attend age and experience.

title: European Leaders Divide Between Hawks and Doves
description: Assuming a somewhat frayed mantle as global diplomat, Prime Minister Tony Blair flew to the United States tonight to meet President Bush, bearing an unusual pledge of support from nine European leaders but leaving a Continent ever more divided over the need for a war against Iraq.

title: Leslie Fiedler Dies at 85; Provocative Literary Critic
description: Leslie Fiedler, the maverick man of letters whose best-known book, ''Love and Death in the American Novel,'' attempted to tear away traditional masks of literary discourse and engage the deeper autobiographical and psychological considerations that might motivate the critic, died on Wednesday at his home in Buffalo. He was 85.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Ex-Intelligence Chief Jailed In Attack Plot
description: The former head of Serbian intelligence under Slobodan Milosevic was jailed for seven years for covering up the attempted murder of a leading opposition politician in a 1999 car crash. Radomir Markovic, who has been imprisoned since 2001 for revealing state secrets, had denied there was ever a plot to kill Vuk Draskovic, the opposition leader, who survived the crash with minor injuries. Mr. Draskovic's brother-in-law and three others traveling in a convoy with him were killed. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Father and Son Race to Decide Who Will Take Charge of the Motorcycle Club
description: What is an actor with the crunching gravitas of Laurence Fishburne doing in a flimsy motorcycle movie like ''Biker Boyz''? Glowering behind a Fu Manchu mustache, he plays Smoke, the ''King of Cali'' and leader of the Black Knights, an underground California motorcycle club made up of white-collar African-Americans who shed their business attire off-hours to put on leather and go racing.

title: Blair and Bush Agree That Time Is Running Out for Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, meeting at the White House this afternoon, said they think alike in how to deal with what Mr. Blair called "the twin threats" of terrorism and weapons of mass destruction.

title: PROTEST TO F.B.I.
description: Three Democrats in Congress have called on Attorney General John Ashcroft to ''immediately terminate'' a new F.B.I. program that requires the bureau's 56 field offices to count the number of mosques and Muslims in their local regions. The F.B.I. says the survey, part of a broader effort to collect data on terrorism ''vulnerabilities,'' will not be used to set investigative goals or quotas. But Representatives Jerrold Nadler of New York and John Conyers Jr. of Michigan and Senator Russell Feingold of Wisconsin said in a letter to Mr. Ashcroft on Wednesday that the survey borders on ethnic and religious profiling and ''is just the latest episode in what seems to be an unconstitutional abuse of power.'' The Justice Department said it would review the letter but had no immediate comment. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: South Korean leader says move was meant to aid 'sunshine' policy : Payment to North puts Seoul on defense
description: SEOUL:  President Kim Dae Jung fought Thursday to salvage his "sunshine" policy of reconciliation with North Korea in the midst of a payoff scandal and the resumption of threats of war by North Korea.

title: Israeli Forces Raid 2 Cities in West Bank
description: Israeli forces staged two major operations in the West Bank today, fatally shooting two Palestinians in Tulkarm and sending scores of soldiers into this battered city, where they closed television stations and demolished a blocklong fruit and vegetable market.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Online City Purchasing
description: To streamline cumbersome contracting procedures, the City Council wants the city to update its computer system so vendors can bid for business on the Internet. The Council said many companies were reluctant to do business with the city because of red tape. A report issued yesterday reasoned that an online procurement system would increase competition and drive down costs. The report also called for staging online reverse auctions, where companies could compete to offer lower prices. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, ELLEN M.
description: HERZ-Ellen M. Beloved mother of Frank and Steve, grandmother of Michael, Erik, Justin and nicole, greatgrandmother of Amanda, Jackson, Ian and Ethan, and her sister, Lore Simon, died on January 26, 2003, one month before her 97th birthday. She will be missed by all of her family, as she was a devoted and loving person. She and her husband Kurt, who died in 1992, were Holocaust survivors. Ellen was born in Kreuznach, Germany. She attended Columbia University and became a social worker, working for child welfare for NYC. On retiring, she helped found the Morningside Retirement and Health Services, where she was very active. Among the many ways she helped people was as a volunteer in the National Council of Jewish Women, receiving one of its highest awards. Her memories of the Holocaust were recorded by the Shoah project. To quote from the NCJW award article, ''Grace, compassion and commitment constitute the essence of her being''.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: 3 STATES PLAN TO SUE E.P.A. The attorneys general of Connecticut, Massachusetts and Maine said they would sue the Environmental Protection Agency to force it to restrict carbon dioxide using the Clean Air Act. The officials, all Democrats, said the heat-trapping gas should be added to the "criteria pollutants" regulated under the act because data show that rising concentrations of carbon dioxide threaten ecosystems, agriculture and human health. Industry and conservative groups have said no restrictions are justified because no clear harm has been shown and because curbs would hurt the economy. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Aretha Franklin Subpoenaed in Arson Case
description: A judge signed a subpoena yesterday requiring the singer Aretha Franklin and three other people to testify about an arson on Oct. 25 that destroyed a $1.5 million house that belonged to Ms. Franklin. It was one of three that she owns in Bloomfield, Mich., a suburb of Detroit.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: DRUG MAKER'S PROFIT FALLS The European drug maker AstraZeneca said that fourth-quarter profit fell 41 percent, as its products faced increased competition from generic drugs. AstraZeneca argued in court to keep generic versions of its best-selling ulcer drug, Prilosec, off the market, but lost that case in October. Fourth-quarter net income was $428 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $726 million, or 42 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Now the company, which was created by the 1999 merger of Astra of Sweden and the Zeneca Group of Britain, is hoping that new drugs, like one to lower cholesterol coming out this year under the name Crestor, will help lift profit. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: California Pension Fund to Pay $250 Million Age Bias Settlement
description: The federal government announced its largest settlement ever in a discrimination lawsuit yesterday when California's giant state pension fund agreed to pay $250 million to disabled public safety officers who sued over age discrimination.

title: Kmart wants its customers to know that the blue light is still shining.
description: ATTENTION Kmart shoppers: the entire chain is not disappearing before your eyes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, DR. LOUIS
description: ZIMMERMAN-Dr. Louis. On December 28, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Helen Helfstein Zimmerman. Devoted father of Peter Max Zimmerman and Mindy Zimmerman Colton. Dear fatherin-law of Paul Franklin Colton. Dear brother of the late Ida Revitz and Zeta Turtle. Also survived by other loving family members and dear friends. Services at Sol Levinson & Bros Inc., Baltimore, MD, 800-338-1701, on Tuesday, December 31, at 12 noon. Interment Beth El Memorial Park, Randallstown, MD. Contributions in his memory may be directed to the University of Arkansas Medical School, 4301 West Markham St., Little Rock, AR 72205; or The American College of Cardiology, 9111 Old Georgetown Rd, Bethesda, MD 20814.

title: Woman Expelled From Russia Is Released
description: A 34-year-old American woman expelled from Russia after being accused of offering to help Islamic terrorists stage attacks in the United States was released by the federal authorities early today after being interviewed several hours at Los Angeles International Airport.

title: Palestinian Gunman and Bystander Killed in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 31  Israeli forces shot and killed a Hamas militant in the West Bank city of Jenin today, in a gun battle outside a fire station in which a bystander was also killed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCHHORN, RAE
description: HIRSCHHORN-Rae. 50 years since you left and as always, I feel bereft. Your influences still remain and in retrospect help ease the pain. Herbert

title: Buy a New Lexus, Get a Massage
description: ''THE new blue'' is what dealers call the bright, almost electric hue of the cylindrical tower and sine-wave-shaped entrances of hundreds of Honda dealerships around the country. Honda's new blue buildings catch the eye of the passing motorist as quickly as the distinctive look and logos of McDonald's, the Gap or Exxon, and the company would like to make its signature just as familiar as theirs.

title: Approval of Snowmobiles Contradicts Park Service Study
description: Last November, the Bush administration announced that new technology for snowmobiles had made the machines cleaner and quieter and that as a result it would allow them to continue to ply the snow-covered byways of Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks.

title: Van Gundy Has An All-Star Plan
description: Jeff Van Gundy, who was often criticized for coaching a dull brand of basketball during his tenure with the Knicks, would apparently like to snatch some of the pizazz from the All-Star Game.

title: Budget Crisis Ends Program That Lured Jobs To New Jersey
description: New Jersey is shutting down a state incentive program that has infuriated New York officials by luring companies from Manhattan, creating a high-rise skyline on the western side of the Hudson River.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: New Cabinet Minister
description: Arun Shourie, a central figure in the program to privatize many of India's state-owned companies, was given an expended portfolio in a revamping of Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee's cabinet. Mr. Shourie, left, was named to lead the communications and technology ministries, which control a vastly expanding industry with wireless companies, limited-mobility and fixed-line operators fighting over licensing issues. Mr. Shourie succeeds Pramod Mahajan, who opposed privatization. Telecommunications stocks surged on the outlook for the sale of government shares in the leading companies. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: An Impossible Dream: Making 'Don Quixote'
description: It's been said that it takes just as much work to make a bad movie as a good one; the HBO making-of-a-movie reality series ''Project Greenlight'' showed not only that the road to hell was paved with good intentions, but also that Satan's contractors were taking bids on the job. After watching the fascinating and compelling new documentary ''Lost in La Mancha,'' you may forever wonder how it is that movies are made at all. ''Lost'' may not be a great piece of filmmaking, but it is a great story; its directors display dramatic intelligence.

title: Taxes in the Balance
description: Throughout his career, one constant thread in Gov. George E. Pataki's politics has been his belief in lowering taxes to prompt economic growth.

title: Ivory Coast's Residents Look for the Exit
description: First, it was the Africans. Immigrants who could afford to return home to neighboring Burkina Faso, Mali and Liberia packed up and left this rattled, war-torn country. Today, it was the Europeans, mostly the French, Ivory Coast's former colonial rulers, who crowded into the departure lounge of the newly refurbished airport here and hunted for an exit.

description: BASEBALL

description: Fredipus Rex, A Blind Fool

title: Diocese Pays $800,000 to 10 In Abuse Cases Against Priests
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Metuchen has agreed to pay $800,000 to 10 people who said that diocesan priests had sexually abused them.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Teacher Jailed For Threat To U.S. Diplomat
description: A state security court sentenced a 42-year-old English-language schoolteacher to one year in prison for sending an e-mail message that threatened an American ambassador. The message was sent to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in December, before a two-day visit by Ambassador David Welch to the southern region of Assuit. Mr. Welch's visit went as planned, and the police arrested the teacher a few days later. Samar Aboul-Fotouh (NYT)

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18
