title: Search for Boys No Longer a Rescue Mission
description: The younger police divers were not too much older than her missing son, crawling in and out of water so cold it hurt. They seemed to look out for one another the way young friends do.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Reaches Out To Vatican
description: President Vladimir V. Putin made a conciliatory gesture to the Vatican yesterday, calling for closer dialogue as a means of dealing with issues like terrorism. Mr. Putin made the statement in the Kremlin as he received the credentials of Archbishop Antonio Mennini. The Russian Orthodox Church has accused the Vatican of proselytizing and was infuriated by the creation of four Catholic dioceses in Russia last year, and Russian authorities refused to issue visas to several Catholic priests who had been serving in Russia. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Spy Who Came In On Some DVD's
description: ''Once we had Guinness on board, we were able to empty the National Theater of its cast,'' John le Carr said this week by telephone from Cornwall. As the British super agent George Smiley, Alec Guinness anchored the BBC television adaptations of Mr. le Carr's novels ''Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy,'' released on DVD in September by Acorn Media, and ''Smiley's People,'' issued by Acorn this week on three discs.

title: If an Injury Forces Kidd to Sit, An Unlikely Duo Will Fill In
description: Jason Kidd pulled his Mercedes out of the parking lot at the Nets' practice center, laughing as he approached a group of reporters. A sheet of paper with a large question mark on it was taped to the driver's side window.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Ratings Cut
description: Fitch Ratings cut the credit ratings of Japan's largest banking groups, citing their weakening finances and the lack of strong government action to resolve the widespread problem of nonperforming loans. Banks in the Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group had their ratings cut one notch to A-, while banks in the Mizuho, UFJ and Sumitomo Mitsui groups were cut to BBB+. Fitch maintained its negative outlook for the banks. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, MOLLIE BUELER
description: BLACK-Mollie Bueler. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Mollie Bueler Black, beloved mother of Frieda Furman, and mother-in-law of Roy Furman. The Furmans are cherished friends of UJAFederation who express an unwavering dedication to the Jewish community through their extraordinary generosity and commitment to UJAFederation and our beneficiary agencies. We extend our deepest sympathies to Frieda and Roy and to the entire Furman and Bueler families. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: South Korean Leader Assailed on Funds Transfer to North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 31  President Kim Dae Jung faced mounting pressure today to provide a detailed account of why nearly $200 million was moved to North Korea shortly before he flew to Pyongyang for his summit meeting with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, in June 2000.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Charges In Coral Theft
description: Two men have been indicted by a federal grand jury in Los Angeles in a scheme to unlawfully ship 100 tons of rock and coral between Hawaii and the mainland. Those named in the 49-count indictment were John Marquardsen, 50, of Haleiwa, Hawaii, and Rodolfo Tagle, 50, of Santa Ana, Calif. Mr. Marquardsen is accused of unlawfully collecting the rock and coral off Oahu. Mr. Tagle is accused of selling the material to Los Angeles fish and marine supply stores for use in aquariums. Three other people have pleaded guilty in the case. Damage to the reef system was estimated at more than $5 million. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Upton: New Brookhaven Chief
description: Brookhaven National Laboratory announced yesterday that Praveen Chaudhari, 65, would be its new director and would start April 1. He succeeds Peter Paul, who became the interim laboratory director when the previous director, John Marburger, left to become the science adviser to President Bush. Dr. Chaudhari is currently senior manager of research at the International Business Machines Corporation. In his 36 years at I.B.M., he has published more than 160 research papers and has been awarded 22 patents. Brookhaven, one of 10 laboratories financed by the federal Department of Energy, has 2,800 workers and a $463 million annual budget. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, ELEANOR (WIENER)
description: STEIN-Eleanor (Wiener). Beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, died on December 28, at the age of 89, after a short illness. She resided for many years with her late husband, Dr. Isidore Stein in Brooklyn, New York, before moving to Cliffside Park, New Jersey. Eleanor received her B.A. and M.A. degrees from New York University and taught health education in the New York City Public Schools. She was active up until the time of her death and volunteered her time teaching aerobics to senior citizens. Eleanor is survived by her three children, Richard Stein, Diane Dobrow and Janie Narcisi; her grandchildren, Heather, Larry, Julie, David, Lara, Ilyse and Scott; and her great-granddaughter Isabella. She was known as ''Grandma Hearts'' and will be missed by all who knew and loved her. Services will be held on Tuesday, December 31, at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, NJ, at 12 noon. For further information, please call 201-971-0015.

title: Schwab to Give Up of Chief Executive at Brokerage Firm
description: Charles Schwab Corporation said today that its founder and chairman, Charles R. Schwab, would relinquish the title of co-chief executive in May, although Mr. Schwab, who is 65, intends to continue plotting the company's strategy.

title: Flogging The French
description: Ah, for the halcyon days of a year ago, when we fretted about why Arabs hate us. Now the question is: Why does everybody hate us?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUGUST, NEIL, M.D.
description: AUGUST-Neil, M.D. On January 29, 2003 in West Palm Beach, FL. Formerly of Ossining and Denver. Devoted to family, wise and dedicated physician, and dear friend. We will miss his camaraderie, counsel and love. Barbara and Jerry Rosmarin

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Contract Awarded To BAE
description: The British military contractor BAE Systems was awarded a 3 billion ($4.9 billion) contract to build two aircraft carriers for the British Navy. About one-third of the work on the ships, including their design, will be subcontracted to the losing bidder, Thales of France. Construction is to begin in 2006, with delivery in 2012 and 2015. Eric Pfanner (IHT)

title: Spy Who Came In on Some DVD's
description: nce we had Guinness on board, we were able to empty the National Theater of its cast," John le Carre said this week by telephone from Cornwall. As the British super agent George Smiley, Alec Guinness anchored the BBC television adaptations of Mr. le Carre's novels "Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy," released on DVD in September by Acorn Media, and "Smiley's People," issued by Acorn this week on three discs.

title: Relatives of Sept. 11 Victims Face a Suspect in Germany
description: Spectators and even the court-appointed interpreter wept in court today as the horror of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks -- planned in this city -- coursed through the accounts of relatives of victims, who for the first time confronted a man charged with conspiring in the attacks with their loss and suffering.

title: China Holds U.S. Falun Gong Member for Disrupting Broadcast
description: The Chinese authorities have detained an American citizen in connection with efforts by the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement to disrupt Chinese television and radio broadcasts, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Rangers Lose in Overtime in Sather's First Game
description: Nearly a decade after saying he would never coach another National Hockey League game, Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, appointed himself the club's 31st head coach yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERGER, AGNES
description: EISENBERGER - Agnes. Dearest friend, sleep in peace next to your Jim. I'll miss you always. Eva

title: Tomorrow, Dial 11 Digits (if You're Lucky)
description: To the Editor:

title: Tomorrow, Dial 11 Digits (if You're Lucky)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip Maker Narrows Loss
description: Hynix Semiconductor, the memory chip maker, lost 917 billion won ($787 million) in the fourth quarter, but that number was relatively encouraging to the creditors who own the company. The figure for losses was down from the loss of 1.37 trillion in the period last year. The company said losses were reduced as a result of a rise in semiconductor prices in the fall and approval by its creditors of a 4.9 trillion won plan for exchanging debt for equity and extending debts. The company's leading creditor, Korea Exchange Bank, has approved a plan for the company to sell off 1.1 trillion won of noncore assets. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, SARA
description: GOLDMAN-Sara. Beloved and devoted mother of Rhoda Cohen and David. Loving grandmother of Jonathan, Amy Burke, Diane and Eric. Dearest great-grandmother. Service today, 12:15 PM, from ''Parkside'' Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: HASBRO EXTENDS DEAL ON STAR WARS TOYS BY 10 YEARS
description: Hasbro, the toy company, said yesterday that it had won a 10-year extension of an agreement with Lucas Licensing to make Star Wars toys and games. The agreement, which was extended through 2018, lowers the minimum payment guaranteed to the film producer George Lucas because of less-than-expected sales. The minimum payment was reduced by $85 million, to $505 million. Hasbro has made Star Wars action figures, vehicles and games for 27 years.

title: Land of Kiwi Fruit and Lamb Pushes Arts Industry
description: When Helen Clark, a concertgoer, was elected prime minister of New Zealand in 1999, she promptly declared herself minister of arts, culture and heritage as well. And within months she injected tens of millions of dollars into a ''cultural recovery package,'' an unprecedented step in this small South Pacific nation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: The Perils Of Power
description: The Irish government jet broke down for the second time in less than two weeks, forcing Prime Minister Bertie Ahern and a trade delegation to take a last-minute ''air taxi'' to Prague, at a cost of nearly $39,000, for a meeting with Vaclav Havel, the departing Czech president. At the end of a visit to Mexico earlier this month, Mr. Ahern was preparing to board the plane, a 12-year-old Gulfstream, in front of a ceremonial guard of honor when the jet was found to have a faulty fuel tap; he and his partner flew home on a KLM commercial flight through Amsterdam. In Parliament, opposition parties demanded that the jet be replaced before Ireland assumes the European Union presidency next year. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: With Bells, Whistles And Passages of Silence
description: Albert Evans took on three difficult scores by John Cage for his ''Haiku.'' The pleasure of the piece, performed by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, is that Mr. Evans and his six dancers found their way inside the music to create a work as mysterious and elegant as its accompaniment.

title: When College Breaks the Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. Takes Second Look At Many Superfund Sites
description: After bringing hundreds of polluted sites into compliance with regulatory standards in the last decade, the Environmental Protection Agency has learned that a contaminant found at many of those sites may be more harmful than previously thought. As a result, the agency is scrambling to re-evaluate its cleanup efforts.

title: Japanese Economy Stalled by Unemployment and Spending Declines
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31  Japan's jobless rate hit a record high in December, one of several indicators that show that the economy stalled in the last quarter of 2002.

title: Quick Escapes
description: TIRED of the cold? Who isn't? If you need a quick break to warmer climes to remind your body that there are physical sensations other than shivering, here are some possibilities for the weekend of Feb. 7 to 9.

title: Shredder Ended Work Backlog, U.S. Says
description: Tens of thousands of pieces of mail come into the huge Immigration and Naturalization Service data processing center in Laguna Niguel, Calif., every day, and as at so many government agencies, it tends to pile up. One manager there had a system to get rid of the vexing backlog, federal officials say. This week the manager was charged with illegally shredding as many as 90,000 documents.

title: A 5-8 Freshman Plays Big Role for St. Peter's
description: When Keydren Clark, the freshman guard at St. Peter's College, was 12 years old, he was making jump shot after jump shot in a pickup game until it began to rain. His mother, Rosie Clark, walked downstairs from their apartment at 140th Street and Hamilton Place in Harlem and asked Clark to come home. The downpour was creating puddles on the playground, but Clark kept tossing in swish after swish.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: U.S. Consulate Investigates Bad Visas
description: The United States Consulate in Nuevo Laredo, on the Texas border, shut down on Wednesday as officials looked into allegations that it had illegally or improperly issued visas. State Department officials said the investigation and the closing would last at least several days. The consulate is one of the busiest in the world in terms of the number of visas it grants, and the border post sees thousands of travelers crossing each day. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Instruments In All Kinds Of Groupings
description: The Firebird Ensemble, a young group from Boston, made its New York debut with an ambitious and eclectic program on Wednesday evening at Elebash Hall, the attractive recital space at the CUNY Graduate Center. Like many groups of its kind, Firebird draws on a fairly large complement of performers so that just about any combination of instruments is possible. Even so, much of the program focused more firmly on individual strengths within the ensemble.

title: INDONESIAN CLERIC ACQUITTED
description: An Indonesian court acquitted a prominent Islamic militant leader on charges of inciting Muslims to attack Christians on the religiously divided Maluku Islands. The cleric, Jaffar Umar Thalib, the head of a paramilitary group called Laskar Jihad, was also acquitted on a charge of defaming President Megawati Sukarnoputri. Judge Mansur Nasution said the prosecutors had failed to prove that Mr. Jaffar was guilty of inciting violence in a speech at a mosque last April. Jane Perlez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROLL, MAY
description: CROLL-May. On January 25, 2003 at 95 years of age. Beloved wife of Irving Croll, cherished mother of Burney and Don, grandmother of Wendy and Andrew Halpern and Andrea and Jonathan Freeman, great-grandmother of Benjamin Isaac Halpern, mother-in-law of Harriet Croll, friend of Jan Gartenberg, companion of Kerita Moulton. She endows all who loved her with a legacy of love, compassion, wisdom and spirituality. She will be missed dearly.

title: Trump Plans to Try Again With Casino Bond Offering
description: Donald J. Trump is hoping to raise nearly $500 million in junk bonds, almost nine months after he canceled a similar offering because investors demanded too high an interest rate.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: BANK RATINGS CUT Fitch Ratings cut the credit ratings of Japan's largest banking groups, citing their weakening finances and the lack of strong government action to resolve the widespread problem of nonperforming loans. Banks in the Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group had their ratings cut one notch to A-, while banks in the Mizuho, UFJ and Sumitomo Mitsui groups were cut to BBB+. Fitch maintained its negative outlook for the banks. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the first of 16 charter flights between mainland China and Taiwan, cited as an important step toward restoring transportation links between them, misstated the amount of Taiwanese investment on the mainland. It is $100 billion, not $100 million.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, GERTRUDE (NEE SIMKOWITZ)
description: FRIEDMAN-Gertrude (nee Simkowitz). 96 years young, died on January 30, 2003. A resident of Great Neck. Most beloved wife of the late Louis Friedman. Loving mother of Herbert and Dorothy, and Harold and Linda. Dear grandmother of Lori and Seth Hauser, Gary and Donna, Lianne, Alyssa, Jeffrey and Peter. Special great-grandmother of Emily and Dean Hauser, Bradley, Annabelle and Matthew Friedman. Devoted sister and aunt. Her family was her world. Services Friday, 2 PM, at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: When College Breaks the Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: J2 GLOBAL COMMUNICATIONS, Los Angeles, a provider of Internet-based messaging and communications, said it had acquired Cyberbox, Hong Kong, a message-management company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bush to Ask Congress for $16 Billion to Fight AIDS in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  President Bush said today that he would ask for $16 billion in next year's federal budget, a 7 percent increase over current spending, to prevent and treat AIDS in the United States. He also announced steps to provide wider access to AIDS tests that can deliver results within minutes.

title: Revenue Miscalculation Forces Delay in Vote on State Budget
description: The Connecticut General Assembly was forced to delay a vote yesterday on a plan to balance the state's $13.4 billion budget after the legislature's fiscal analysts miscalculated revenue projections by $280 million.

title: Pension Insurer Cites $3.6 Billion Deficit and Suspects Worse
description: The agency that insures company pension plans reported a $3.6 billion deficit today, its largest ever, and said it was studying whether the way businesses now calculate pension values was masking even deeper weaknesses in the system.

title: GILLETTE SAYS ITS PROFIT ROSE 73% IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: Gillette, the razor maker, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit increased 73 percent, to $346 million, or 33 cents a share, from $200 million, or 19 cents, a year earlier, when the company wrote down the value of some overseas units. Profit, excluding a restructuring gain, was 2 cents a share less than analyst forecast. Profit from the razor-and-blade business rose 1 percent, less than the 15 percent gain expected by analysts. Demand for Duracell batteries, the company's second-biggest business, declined for a fifth quarter. Overall sales rose 4.6 percent, to $2.53 billion, the company said.

title: Lester Osterman, 88, Producer of Broadway Hits and Flops
description: Lester Osterman, a Broadway theater producer and theater owner who won three Tony Awards for his productions of ''Da,'' ''The Shadow Box'' and ''A Moon for the Misbegotten,'' died on Tuesday at a hospital in Norwalk, Conn. He was 88.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: United Airlines Reports Loss of $1.5 Billion
description: The UAL Corporation , the parent company of United Airlines, reported today a net loss of $1.5 billion in the fourth quarter, capping off the most horrendous year in the airline's storied history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEGNER, DOROTHY (NEE WAYLER)
description: GEGNER - Dorothy (nee Wayler). On December 27, of Brklyn, NY. Survived by nephews Dr. Alan Wayler and Dr. Barry Wayler. Employed by NYC school system for many years. Interment Monday, December 30, 2 PM, at Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: Knicks' Drive to Make Playoffs Will Now Be Going on the Road
description: A few weeks ago, a Knicks official scoffed at the popular notion that the Knicks had a string of games against teams they absolutely, positively ought to beat, sub-.500 teams like Chicago, Atlanta and Miami.

title: Devils Keep Surging At Flyers' Expense
description: Heading into their final game before the All-Star Game, the top two teams in the Atlantic Division were heading in different directions. The first-place Devils had nine victories, a tie and an overtime loss in their previous 11 games, while the second-place Philadelphia Flyers had lost three in a row, scoring just one goal in that span.

title: Invoking the Bible In the War Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Offering Delayed By South Africa
description: The South African government announced today that the first public offering of shares in its national telecommunications company would take place on March 4.

title: Elvis, Liberace . . . and You
description: IF you're looking to sleep in the shadow of midcentury movie stars, there is perhaps no better place to buy a vacation home than in the desert resort of Palm Springs, Calif. This is a town with one foot (perhaps two) planted firmly in its own Hollywood past. Streets have nostalgic names like Bob Hope Drive and Dinah Shore Drive. At the Racquet Club, octogenarians nibble shrimp cocktail under fading photographs of Marilyn Monroe, Clark Gable, Jane Russell and Bing Crosby, all of whom graced the nearby tennis courts with their presence many decades ago. And Melvyn's, the bar where Frank Sinatra tossed back drinks with his friends, is packed these days with eager weekenders looking to do it his way.

title: To Guarantee Universal Coverage, Require It
description: Among President Bush's top priorities, he said in the State of the Union address, is ''high quality, affordable health care for all Americans.'' Yet he offered precious few specifics. With nearly three million Americans losing their health insurance in the last two years alone and health care costs rising at the highest rate in a decade, America needs a bold plan.

title: With a Nod to Cole Porter, Songs for Night and Day
description: For her concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, Felicity Lott sidestepped the conventions of the vocal recital format and offered a program that was refreshingly jumbled, yet also thematically unified. Instead of groups by individual or like-minded composers, Dame Felicity presented each half of the program as a unified set. Composers who worked in different languages and musical styles were heard side by side with no applause between them at Dame Felicity's request.

title: Invoking the Bible in the War Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefly Noted
description: 4 G.I.'s DIE IN CRASH Four Americans died when a United States Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed about six miles east of the Bagram air base in Afghanistan, military officials said. Commander Dan Gage, a spokesman for the United States Central Command in Tampa, Fla., said there were no indications that hostile fire was responsible for the crash. The helicopter "was on a routine training mission," he said, when it crashed and all four aboard were killed. Details remained sketchy about the crash, including the weather conditions and if the helicopter came down near populated areas. The military was withholding the names of the dead until families were notified. Thom Shanker

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAMBRICK, MARY A.
description: BAMBRICK-Mary A. Of Rosedale, NY on January 30, 2003. Loving wife of Eugene P., beloved mother of Eugene P., Jr., Mary Ellen, Peter J., Julianne, Alicia and Gerard B., cherished grandmother of seven. Fond sister of the late Peter W. Thompson, Jr. Friends may call on Sunday at the O'Reilly Funeral Home. 137-40 Brookville Blvd, Rosedale from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Clare RC Church Monday at 9:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Election Board Chief
description: John A. Ravitz, a former assemblyman and chairman of the Manhattan Republican Party, was selected yesterday as executive director of the New York City Board of Elections. Mr. Ravitz succeeds Daniel DeFrancesco, who retired in December. Mr. Ravitz begins his duties at the board today. He said his first task would be to prepare for four special elections to be held Feb. 25 for two seats in the Assembly and two in the City Council. Mr. Ravitz, who served in the Assembly for 12 years, did not seek re-election last year, after losing a special election for a state Senate seat representing the East Side of Manhattan. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: 4 G.I.'s DIE IN CRASH
description: Four Americans died when a United States Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed about six miles east of the Bagram air base in Afghanistan, military officials said. Cmdr. Dan Gage, a spokesman for the United States Central Command in Tampa, Fla., said there were no indications that hostile fire was responsible for the crash. The helicopter ''was on a routine training mission,'' he said, when it crashed and all four aboard were killed. Details remained sketchy about the crash, including the weather conditions and if the helicopter came down near populated areas. The military was withholding the names of the dead until families were notified. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: Nicky Nodjoumi
description: Stefan Stux Gallery

title: Blix Says He Saw Nothing to Prompt a War
description: Days after delivering a broadly negative report on Iraq's cooperation with international inspectors, Hans Blix on Wednesday challenged several of the Bush administration's assertions about Iraqi cheating and the notion that time was running out for disarming Iraq through peaceful means.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDWIN, WILLIAM H.
description: BALDWIN-William H. At the age of 82 on December 23, 2002. Dearly loved and loving husband, father, brother and granddad. Survived by his wife Margot, sons Glenn and Mark, brothers Charles and Paul (Billingham), sister Elizabeth Rowland, grandchildren Matthew and Dana and a host of friends. The family will receive friends Thursday, January 16, 5-8 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street with a memorial service, Friday, January 17, at 4 PM, at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the organization of your choice. To die but not to perish is to be eternally present.

title: New Works With the Beauty of a Haydn
description: Many lovers of traditional classical music just assume that concerts of contemporary works are brainy, esoteric affairs for insiders only. Well, they should have heard the preposterously beautiful sounds emanating from the stage of Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night in the middle of a set of songs by the living master Gyorgy Ligeti as the compelling mezzo-soprano Mary Nessinger sang a jittery tune in Hungarian accompanied by the harmonically blurry nasal buzzings of four harmonicas.

title: With Ted Turner Afield, Will Vitriol Now Flow?
description: Ted Turner, the ''mouth from the South,'' has left the building. Now, executives and employees at AOL Time Warner, where Mr. Turner resigned as vice chairman on Wednesday, wonder what he will say next.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL AGREES TO BUY BENDIX UNIT OF HONEYWELL
description: Federal-Mogul, an auto-parts supplier operating under court protection from creditors, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a Honeywell International business that makes brake pads. The business, the Bendix unit, has annual sales of about $700 million and about 5,600 employees, a Honeywell spokesman said. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The purchase would let Federal-Mogul expand one of its largest business lines. The agreement hinges on a bankruptcy judge's agreeing to shield Honeywell from current and future asbestos liabilities resulting from Bendix.

title: Who Stands With U.S.? Europe Is of Two Minds
description: As Europe struggles to define its position toward Iraq, the debate is generating not an Iraq problem but a Europe problem, a growing split between nations like France and Germany that are defending a narrower, European interest and those looking to a broader, North Atlantic alliance.

title: Laura Parnes
description: Participant

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIDDINGS, RENEE ROSS
description: GIDDINGS-Renee Ross. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Daniel. Devoted mother of Jeoffrey and Wendy Jane Gold and the late Douglas Alan. Dear sister of Barclay H. Bloomgarden and late sister Fantine Joy Finberg. Loving grandmother and greatgrandmother. Services and interment were held Sunday, December 29.

title: Kim plagued by payoff scandal and North Korean threats of war : 'Sunshine' policy dims for Seoul leader
description: SEOUL:  President Kim Dae Jung fought Thursday to salvage his "sunshine" policy of reconciliation with North Korea in the midst of a payoff scandal and the resumption of threats of war by North Korea.

title: Executive Gave Legislators Meals, Sources in Lobbying Inquiry Say
description: A vice president of a private prison company that received millions of dollars in New York State contracts treated a group of legislators to more than 50 meals in recent years, according to people involved in inquiries into the company's activities in Albany.

title: Weekender | Pine Plains, N.Y.
description: PINE PLAINS is horse country, and the horses are thoroughbreds. One breeding farm, Berkshire Stud, produced Private Emblem, the winner of last year's Arkansas Derby and an early favorite in the 2002 Kentucky Derby. Another, Dutchess Views Farm, is a thoroughbred business owned and operated by Michael and Debra Lischin, who moved here from Midway, Ky., five years ago.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 2 London Subway Lines Closed For Weeks
description: Operators of the London Underground subway said two lines carrying hundreds of thousands of commuters a day would remain closed for two more weeks after an accident last Saturday. The closing will add to the woes of travelers facing snarled roads and uncertain rail service. More than 30 people were injured when a train carrying 800 passengers hit a wall on Saturday after parts of its motor sheared off and fell onto the track. London Underground said the bolts holding motors in place would be replaced on 85 trains that ply the Central Line and Waterloo and City Line. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Editors' Note; Parking Rules
description: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Americana Sells Well, Considering
description: The Americana sales this month were remarkably strong, given the economy. Christie's auctions of important Americana, Pennsylvania German folk art, the Russell B. Aitken Collection of Decoys and the Benjamin F. Edwards III Collection of Chinese Imari Porcelain Part II, totaled $13.7 million (against an estimate of $9.2 million to $14.3 million). Sotheby's sales of Americana, including furniture, folk art, silver and early military accouterments, totaled $15.9 million. Those sales had been expected to bring $12.9 million to $18.9 million.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: F.C.C. ISSUES RULES FOR SATELLITE COMPANIES After more than two years of review, the Federal Communications Commission issued rules yesterday allowing satellite communications companies to set up land-based networks to carry their service in urban areas and indoor sites where satellite signals are obstructed. The agency also canceled the licenses of three small companies that had not met deadlines to construct satellites for proposed systems. It also reclaimed 30 megahertz of spectrum that had been assigned for satellite service but not used. That spectrum will be auctioned off to land-based cellular companies. The rules appear to be a victory for satellite companies like ICO Global Communications over the opposition of land-based cellular carriers like Verizon and AT&T , but the agency has not yet published crucial technical specifications covering devices like handsets. Such details, which could be delayed until next week, will affect the cost and convenience of any expanded satellite service.    Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HERZSTEIN, HAROLD LEON
description: HERZSTEIN-Harold Leon. Dec 28, 1904-Dec 30, 1962 and Jean L. Herzstein, May 17, 1909-June 14, 2002. In loving memory, Bob

title: IRISH DRUG MAKER TO SELL UNIT TO KING PHARMACEUTICALS
description: Elan, an Irish drug maker, has agreed to sell its primary care division, which consists of the rights to its insomnia drug Sonata and the muscle relaxant Skelaxin, for $850 million to King Pharmaceuticals. King, based in Bristol, Tenn., will add 400 sales representatives with the acquisition. The deal is part of a program by Elan to sell $1.5 billion worth of assets by the end of this year as it deals with a sharp decline in its stock price last year that was set off by accounting irregularities. The sale to King will cut Elan's work force to fewer than 2,900, from 4,700 last July. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Shadow of Impending War Darkens Kuwaitis' Horizons
description: Shaikha Ali Jaber al-Sabah says she is like other young, affluent Kuwaitis, living in ''la-la land,'' a surreal detachment that comes from playing host to a foreign army that has taken over one-third of Kuwait to prepare for an invasion of Iraq that many here find profoundly disturbing.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Making Kennedy Airport Safer
description: Decades after wind shear caused a plane to crash at Kennedy International Airport, the federal government has installed equipment designed to detect such deadly shifts in surface winds. On Wednesday, the Federal Aviation Administration installed what is known as terminal Doppler weather radar at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn. The F.A.A. was prompted to invent the technology after an Eastern Airlines plane crashed at Kennedy International in 1975. The F.A.A. began installing the radar at airports in 45 other cities nine years ago. But political disputes about where to put the radar, a 37-foot ball atop an 82-foot tower, delayed its installation to serve Kennedy. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARASH, DAVID
description: BARASH-David. December 28, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Muriel. Devoted father of Laura Goodfriend and Stephanie Becker. Cherished grandfather of Scott Becker, Lisa and Galen Giebler, Lawrence and Jennifer Goodfriend, Amy and Jon Nussbaum. Proud great-grandfather of Cadie Mae. Loving companion of Sis Goldstein. He was a CPA, partner of Barash, Friedman, Friedberg and Adasko, avid golfer and Chairman Emeritus of the Corinthian. He was loved and will be missed by all who knew him. Services Tuesday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Demonstrators Storm Airport in Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Jan. 31  Several hundred young Ivoirians stormed the international airport early today, trying to block French citizens from leaving the country, and hurling stones at the French soldiers charged with protecting their countrymen.

title: Ford Motor's Future in Brazil Is Now on the Line
description: At Ford Motor's high-tech factory here, rows of shiny off-road vehicles roll off the production line, swelling the preintroduction stocks of the EcoSport.

title: Isles Turn Game Around With Pair of Late Goals
description: What's going on here, Islanders Coach Peter Laviolette wondered just after the first period tonight. He had seen his team pepper the Canadiens with 15 shots from up, down and sideways. He had seen Montreal produce only six shots. And yet, the Canadiens led by 1-0.

title: Bush to Propose Expansion Of I.R.A.-Like Investments
description: The Bush administration is working on a major shift in retirement savings plans that would allow most Americans to increase greatly the amount of money they could put away in tax-free accounts for retirement and other purposes, administration officials and Congressional staff members said yesterday.

title: A War Crime Or an Act of War?
description: It was no surprise that President Bush, lacking smoking-gun evidence of Iraq's weapons programs, used his State of the Union address to re-emphasize the moral case for an invasion: ''The dictator who is assembling the world's most dangerous weapons has already used them on whole villages, leaving thousands of his own citizens dead, blind or disfigured.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the murder of a prominent Republican fund-raiser and her husband in Brooklyn misstated the given name of an official with the New York Republican State Committee who discussed the couple's party activities. He is Luther Mook, not Lester.

title: Radio Giant Defends Its Size at Senate Panel Hearing
description: The chief executive of the nation's largest radio conglomerate faced pointed questions today about his company's business practices at a Senate committee hearing on the consolidation of media owners.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Invitation For Texas Governor
description: Speaker Tim Ford of the Mississippi House asked Gov. Rick Perry of Texas to visit Mississippi after Mr. Perry was quoted in The Dallas Morning News as saying, ''I don't want to become Mississippi.'' Governor Perry, a Republican, was referring to the budget crisis in Texas. In a letter, Mr. Ford, a Democrat, noted that despite its fiscal crisis, Mississippi was pushing forward with substantial raises for teachers and providing incentives to encourage Nissan to build an assembly plant.

title: Freed Iran Cleric Vows to Continue to Fight for Justice
description: Freed after five years of house arrest, Iran's senior dissident cleric vowed today to continue his struggle for justice and freedom in Iran's Islamic Republic.

title: Russia Softens Opposition To Military Action in Iraq
description: Few would call them bellwethers, but there are signs this week that Russia is softening its long-stated skepticism and even hostility toward American military action in Iraq even as the rumble of war appears to be ever closer.

title: Albany Says It Can't Certify Indian Pt. Plan
description: New York State said yesterday that it could not approve an emergency plan for the area around the Indian Point nuclear plant, asking the federal government to take the next step in the fierce battle over the two reactors in Westchester County.

title: Schwab to Give Up Post of Chief Executive at Brokerage Firm
description: Charles Schwab Corporation said today that its founder and chairman, Charles R. Schwab, would relinquish the title of co-chief executive in May, although Mr. Schwab, who is 65, intends to continue plotting the company's strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, DR. SIDNEY
description: LEVINE-Dr. Sidney. The Yeshiva University family is deeply saddened by the passing of a prominent pediatrician in Rockland County who was also a highly respected Torah scholar. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Shirley and to his children Dr. Joseph I. Levine, member of the Yeshiva College Board of Directors, and his wife, Karen, Guardians of Yeshiva University; Bruce (and Ann) Levine, Barbara (and Michael) Jacob; to his brothers Melvin (and Shirley) Levine, and Robert (and Nina) Levine, and eight grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Joshua L. Muss, Chairman YC Board of Directors

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: S.I. District Attorney Won't Seek Re-election
description: After 20 years in office, William L. Murphy, the Staten Island district attorney, said yesterday that he would not run for re-election this year, a decision that is likely to ignite a vigorous race to succeed him.

title: Rei Naito -- 'One Place on the Earth'
description: D'Amelio Terras

title: South Korean Leader Assailed on Funds Transfer to North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 31  President Kim Dae Jung faced mounting pressure today to provide a detailed account of why nearly $200 million was moved to North Korea shortly before he flew to Pyongyang for his summit meeting with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, in June 2000.

title: Turning Everything White but the Skin
description: The house where Whoopi Goldberg and Danny Glover live in ''Good Fences'' is, I'm guessing, the whitest house you are ever going to see. (With the possible exception of John Lennon and Yoko Ono's place in the Dakota in the 70's.) The sofas, the carpet, the marble floors, the columns, the china cabinet, even the gleaming dining-room table are all white, and so is the neighborhood.

title: NEC's Losses Narrow on Rise In Chip Prices
description: The NEC Corporation, one of Japan's biggest makers of semiconductors and telecommunications equipment, said today that a rebound in chip prices in the fourth quarter of 2002 had narrowed its losses for the period.

title: Marsden Hartley's World: A Body Electric
description: MARSDEN HARTLEY is one of the great artists and certainly one of the most intriguing art historical subjects of all time. Tall, awkward, driven, with preternaturally visionary eyes and an eagle-like profile, he arrived in New York in 1899 at age 22. He came from Lewiston, Me., where he was born in 1877, by way of Cleveland, already seasoned by solitude and a sense of his difference. That is to say, he knew he was gay and he had survived a childhood of nearly Dickensian proportions, including the early death of his mother, abandonment by his father and poverty that required him to leave school at 15 and work in a shoe factory. ''My childhood was vast with terror and surprise,'' he later wrote.

title: Advisory Panel Backs Easing Rules For Title IX
description: In a final meeting today marked by exasperation and confusion, a Bush administration commission recommended easing some standards for satisfying Title IX, the law that expanded opportunities for girls and women in sports.

title: Slim Growth For Economy In 4th Quarter
description: The economy eked out a meager growth rate of 0.7 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, as the first positive gain for business investment in two years was not enough to compensate for consumers' dwindling appetite for new cars and trucks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENTCHEFF, NICOLAS
description: PENTCHEFF-Nicolas. Died December 22, 2002, age 91, after a long illness. Born in Bulgaria. Educated in Bulgaria, London School of Economics (BS) and Columbia University, NY (MA). Reporter for Zora, Sofia's leading daily; sent to London in 1936. Became Press Attache to Bulgarian Legation, London, in 1940. Remained in England during WWII broadcasting for the BBC. Reinstated at Bulgarian Legation after the War, resigned in 1948 in protest against Bulgaria's Communist regime. Farmed for seven years in Surrey, England, during which time he married Mary Dean. Emigrated to the U.S. in 1956 at the request of Radio Free Europe; he became Chief of the Bulgarian Desk, RFE, NY in 1957. Continued working for RFE until 1991. Vice President of the International Federation of Free Journalists, Treasurer of Inter-American Federation of Newspapermen's Associations, in this capacity, he visited all the Latin American countries. A lecturer at Fairfield University, CT, 1970-1981. In 1990, following Bulgaria's emergence from Communism, he was able to contact and visit his family after 50 years of absence. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Mary, and his son, Nicholas Dean Pentcheff. Memorial service on Saturday, January 4, 12 noon, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Route 100, Somers, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: The Alzheimer's Association, 785 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

title: Jeff Chiplis -- 'Excited Inner Gases'
description: White Box

title: 2 More Iraq Scientists Reject Private Interviews With Inspectors
description: Two more Iraqi scientists declined to be interviewed in private by United Nations weapons inspectors today, and Iraq invited the two chief United Nations inspectors back here before their next report to the Security Council in mid-February.

title: Cheney, Little Seen by Public, Plays a Visible Role for Bush
description: As the White House buzzed with preparations for the State of the Union address and some allies protested the administration's march toward war in Iraq, President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney pulled up their chairs on Monday for their weekly lunch.

title: Suzanne Caporael -- 'Littoral Drift'
description: Artemis Greenberg Van Doren

description: WITTELSHOEFER - Julius. On January 30th, 2003. Beloved husband of Eleanor and the late Sophie. Loving brother of Stanley and dear uncle. Service Friday, 10:00AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Crackdown On Drug Production
description: The Cuban government has announced a crackdown on vice, acknowledging that the country not only has a problem with drug use, but also with domestic production. The campaign was announced this week in Granma, the Communist Party newspaper, which said that those found guilty of using, selling or growing drugs would lose their homes, among other penalties. The government decree also singled out prostitution and other antisocial offenses. The decree is the first public acknowledgment that some farmers were growing marijuana in the countryside. Although the government has always maintained that domestic drug use is lower than in surrounding islands, it has grown in recent years, at least partly because of Cuba's increased flow of tourists. Similarly, prostitution has flourished in recent years, catering to Europeans and other tourists. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, YETTA
description: SPECTOR-Yetta. Of Del Ray, FL, on December 28. Beloved wife of Nathan. Devoted mother of Arthur Spector and David Spector. Dear sister of Minnie Altmann. Loving grandmother of Joel, Andrew, Brian and Stacey. Services will be held at ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, on Monday, December 30, at 12:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, STANLEY
description: MARTIN-Stanley. Formerly of Rye, NY, on December 23, age 97. Served in military intelligence, WWII. Retired senior editor, D.C. Heath and Company. Widower of Catherine Brod Martin. Survived by Kenneth of San Diego, Edward of Winchester, MA, and two granddaughters.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, ROGER, D.D.S.
description: SACKS-Roger, D.D.S. A man of honor, great courage and dignity. He was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School 1954, Columbia College 1958, and Columbia College of Dentistry 1962. He was a published cartoonist who brought his wit with him wherever he went. He leaves his beloved wife Arlene, his cherished son Lt. Philip Sacks, his wonderful nephew Ethan (Masako) Sacks. Loving brother of the late Dr. Elliott Sacks. Dear son of the late Philip and Naomi Sacks.

title: Treatment Found for 2 Heart Ailments
description: For the first time, researchers have found a way to treat two deadly heart ailments that are caused by a protein that folds into an abnormal shape.

title: 36 Hours | Taos, N.M.
description: TAOS, N. M., is viewed too often as a kind of Southwestern theme village. And it does have nice adobe. But it is also a vital, idiosyncratic community, where locals practice yoga and dirt biking and argue about a proposed Wal-Mart or snowboarding at Taos Ski Valley. This facet of the town, vivid and intriguing, is most in evidence now, in mid-winter, when the tourist traffic is light and the days are brisk. People stroll, the high-country snow sparkles, the air smells of burning pinyon and incense, and even the adobe seems unexpected and fresh. GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

title: Bureau Tells of New Job And Progress on Terror
description: The F.B.I. will create a position to oversee intelligence operations and is making ''monumental strides'' in its ability to predict and prevent terrorist attacks, the director of the agency, Robert S. Mueller III, said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BMW's Mini Leads Sales Gain
description: Propelled by the Mini, BMW reported a 9.9 percent increase in sales last year, to $45.8 billion. Sales of the Mini, an updated version of the beloved British car, which BMW produces at a factory in Oxford, England, increased almost six times, to 144,119 vehicles. BMW sold more than one million vehicles for the first time. The company, based in Munich, has forecast that its unit sales will jump 40 percent by 2008. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Verizon Asks Judge To Stay Court Order
description: Verizon Communications asked a federal judge yesterday to stay his court order requiring the company to disclose the identity of an Internet subscriber to the Recording Industry Association of America. Verizon is appealing the case, which will determine whether copyright holders can use a shortcut subpoena process to gain access to personal information about Internet subscribers they suspect of illegally copying material online. The company said yesterday that it was asking Judge John Bates to block his order in Federal District Court in Washington until the United States Court of Appeals could review the case. The company argues that the recording industry's view of its rights under copyright law is incorrect and unconstitutional because it would violate the privacy of its subscribers. The recording industry association said it would oppose Verizon's effort to block the order. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about problems at the Pittsburgh Symphony misstated the birthplace of its former conductor Lorin Maazel. He was born of American parents in France, not in Pittsburgh. The article also misstated the city's population. It was just under 335,000 in the 2000 census; it has not fallen to 275,000.

description: THE INFLUENTIALS

title: At Least 16 Killed in Afghan Bus Explosion
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 31 - At least 16 people, including women and children, were killed when their bus exploded on a bridge just outside the southern city of Kandahar, in an attack that the local police attributed to the Taliban or other rebel forces.

title: Minivan Life With a Motto: Be Prepared
description: ON many days, Randi Strumlauf, at right with her children, Rachel, 11, and Elliot, 14, spends five hours in her Ford Windstar minivan. She drives her children back and forth between their home in Lilburn, Ga., and an Atlanta middle school 21 miles away; ferries them to activities; picks up supplies for her needlework guild and the Girl Scout troop she leads; makes trips to the doctor with an elderly family friend; and takes a course on court reporting. It is a routine that requires strategic preparation, and the proof of Ms. Strumlauf's talent for organization is in the orderly stocks of supplies she routinely keeps on hand in the minivan. SUSAN BRENNA

description: With its new plan to rein in the state's ballooning Medicaid budget, the Pataki administration has dealt a severe blow to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is seeking relief from the city's growing health care costs.

description: President Bush all but set a timetable for war today, warning Saddam Hussein that Iraq has ''weeks, not months'' to disarm or face an invasion led by the United States.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: A restaurant as tiny as the Savoy doesn't seem as if it could subdivide, but it has. After nearly 13 years the restaurant has shed its Garbo-like image of secrecy, transforming the ground floor into a modern-looking cafe with diner overtones. The upstairs bar has been moved downstairs, the entrance to the restaurant has been shifted northward to the corner of Prince and Crosby Streets, and huge windows now make the Savoy's interior almost shockingly visible to the outside world. The upstairs remains old-fashioned and intimate. The brick fireplace survives intact.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Primary Law Struck Down
description: A federal judge has struck down a state election law, calling its requirements for candidates to qualify for the primary ballot unconstitutionally burdensome. On Wednesday, Judge Peter C. Dorsey of United States District Court here struck down as unfair the requirement that candidates receive support from at least 15 percent of a party's delegates in their district before challenging an incumbent. The suit's plaintiffs, former candidates and community watchdog groups, hailed the decision. The attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, said yesterday that he would not appeal the ruling and urged the General Assembly to adopt a system allowing candidates to petition voters to qualify for the ballot. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: A Refrigerator Magnet And Other Agents of Death
description: Once you get past its supremely nonsensical title, ''Final Destination 2,'' a smooth and sharp slice of teen-gothic cheese, is kind of fun. If your memory of the first ''Final Destination'' is fuzzy, the sequel is generous with reminders. Back then -- a year before the new picture takes place, three years ago in real calendar time -- a group of young people escaped death in a terrible plane crash after one of them foresaw the catastrophe. But death, it turns out, hates cheaters and so contrived to pick the survivors off one by one in some imaginatively gruesome ways.

title: U.S. Lists Guatemala's Anti-Drug Cooperation as Inadequate
description: The Bush administration has concluded that Guatemala is deeply mired in corruption and no longer deserves to be listed among allies of the United States in the fight against drug trafficking, officials said today.

Cherished grandfather of Kerry Mack, Christopher Mack, Kevin Mack, Devin McGuire, Michael McGuire and Jack Perry. Dear brother of Catherine Pilgram. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Monday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, 10 AM, Tuesday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: TRADING IN PRE-PAID LEGAL IS UNDER INVESTIGATION
description: Pre-Paid Legal Services said yesterday that federal prosecutors and the Securities and Exchange Commission were investigating trading in its shares before the company announced on Jan. 3 that membership had dropped for the first time in 10 years. That announcement sent its shares down 26 percent. Pre-Paid Legal, which sells insurance policies that pay for legal services, said it learned of an informal S.E.C. investigation and received a subpoena from the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York earlier this week. The company said both sought information about stock trading before the Jan. 3 announcement. Pre-Paid was a primary holding of a New York hedge fund, Gotham Partners. The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, is investigating Gotham's activities with regard to Pre-Paid. Shares of Pre-Paid legal fell 27 cents, to $18.20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, STEPHEN
description: KAHN-Stephen, 83. Of Scarsdale, NY, died January 29, 2003. Beloved husband of Eva. Father of Wendy, Jeffrey, and James. Grandfather of six. President of Hofor Tobacco, veteran, ardent historian, linguist, mineralogist. He will be dearly missed. Service 11 AM Friday, Congregation Kol Ami, White Plains, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Drug Maker's Profit Falls
description: The European drug maker AstraZeneca said that fourth-quarter profit fell 41 percent, as its products faced increased competition from generic drugs. AstraZeneca argued in court to keep generic versions of its best-selling ulcer drug, Prilosec, off the market, but lost that case in October. Fourth-quarter net income was $428 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $726 million, or 42 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Now the company, which was created by the 1999 merger of Astra of Sweden and the Zeneca Group of Britain, is hoping that new drugs, like one to lower cholesterol coming out this year under the name Crestor, will help lift profit. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZ, MILTON
description: SPITZ-Milton. Dear husband of Lucille and the late Beatrice. Devoted father of the late Louise Lehman and Carol Shein. Step-father of Richard and Jean Feinberg. Loved grandpa of Karen (Eric) Gurwin, Cathy (Rob) Gursha, Thomas (Suzy) Lehman Jr., Judy (David) Weiniger, Linda (Greg) Alonzo, Jill (Bill) Gellert, William Shein, Sonya and Aaron Feinberg. Adored BG of 17. Graveside services at Mt. Nebo, Totowa, NJ, today, at 1 PM.

title: Explosion Extinguishes One of a North Carolina Town's Few Bright Spots
description: Before Wednesday, the 255 people who worked at this town's bustling medical-supply plant counted themselves lucky to work hard shifts mixing hot chemicals and stamping out syringes for $11 or $12 an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUBUSSON, CHRYSTIAN
description: AUBUSSON-Chrystian. The longtime French antiques dealer, Chrystian Count Aubusson de Cavarlay, passed away January 29, at the age of 82 in his Easthampton home. He was a much beloved and esteemed Manhattan antiques dealer who maintained his shop, Chrystian Aubusson Antiques, starting in New York shortly after his arrival from his native France after WWII, until his retirement in 2001. His wit and wisdom, elegance and good humor will be dearly missed by all those fortunate enough to know him. His many kindnesses will be well remembered. Daniel Barney, Daniel Barney Antiques Charles Kriz, Stewart Schreiber, Old Versailles Inc Roger Gross, George Rodriguez, Victor Alonzo, Objets Plus Inc Ben and Marie Claude Passalacqua, Paris Antiques Alberto de Caro, Enrique Rodriguez Hidalgo, Circea Antiques Hubert des Forges, Oscar Moore, Hubert des Forges Inc

title: In Idled Venezuela, Psychiatrists Work Overtime
description: They are the stressed and the nervous, the phobic and depressed, and on this day they filled the waiting room of Edmundo Chirinos, a psychiatrist well known here for having provided advice to President Hugo Chvez.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: PORNOGRAPHY SENTENCE FOR EX-PRIEST A former Roman Catholic priest who said he had molested more boys than he could remember was sentenced to 15 years in federal prison for possession of child pornography. The defendant, Vincent McCaffrey, was not charged in any molestations, but prosecutors used them to seek a lengthy sentence. Prosecutors said that the molestations took place from 1977 to 1989 and that the statute of limitations had run out on them. Testimony revealed that the Chicago Archdiocese knew of Mr. McCaffrey's abuses as early as 1980 but returned him to parish duties after he underwent inpatient treatment. He was removed from parish duties in 1991. (AP)

title: People
description: * Ray Warren was named managing director at OMD USA, New York, part of the OMD media services unit of the Omnicom Group, succeeding Dan Rank, who left in November to become an executive vice president for advertising sales at the Universal Television Group, part of Vivendi Universal. Mr. Warren had most recently been president and chief executive at the New York office of Raycom Sports, part of Raycom Media.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about delays in the city's plan to open waste transfer stations omitted a full name for the City Council member who said he was frustrated by the delay. He is Michael E. McMahon.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Jan. 21 about the use of antibiotics to treat periodontal disease misstated the specialty of Dr. Norman Trieger, former chairman of the department of dentistry, oral and maxillofacial surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center. He is a physician and oral surgeon, not a periodontist. The article also misstated the background of Dr. Kenneth Bueltmann of the American Academy of Periodontology. He is a past president, not the current one.

title: AOL Time Warner at Age 2 Seems as Unruly as Ever
description: In the two years since America Online's ill-fated acquisition of Time Warner, Richard D. Parsons has proved to be a master of the arts of corporate politics and peacemaking. But now he has to work to persuade investors that he is equally suited to lead AOL Time Warner out of the rubble of the merger's aftermath, a task that he said this week could take as long as another full year.

title: North Korea Presses Demand for Direct Talks With U.S.
description: BEIJING, Jan. 31  Blaming the current impasse on deceit and hostility by the Bush administration, a North Korean diplomat today renewed Pyongyang's demand for direct negotiations with the United States on nuclear weapons.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Ex-Mayor Pleads Guilty
description: The former mayor of Carson, Pete Fajardo, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to extortion charges related to the solicitation of bribes for votes while serving on the Carson City Council. As part of the agreement, Mr. Fajardo, 60, admitted to extorting about $50,000 from the owner of an apartment complex in Carson, just south of Los Angeles. Mr. Fajardo also pleaded guilty to attempting to extort about $70,000 from an engineering company seeking to build a bridge. The agreement recommends a sentence of 24 to 27 months in federal prison. Had he been convicted, he could have faced a sentence of 20 years. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: BERLIN EMBASSY SHUT
description: The American Embassy in Berlin suspended its consular services a day after the German police received a warning of possible terrorist attacks against American and Israeli buildings. Embassy officials decided to close the consulate through Friday, an embassy spokeswoman said. ''We are taking necessary security precautions,'' said the spokeswoman, who refused to comment on the nature of the threat. On Wednesday, the German police reported having received a warning from the Israeli Embassy in Berlin about possible attacks. Additional security and surveillance measures were added at American and Israeli buildings around Berlin.

title: She's Tempted By a Stepson Who's a Hunk
description: Martha Graham is probably best known for dances that plumb the psyches and sexuality of women in ancient Greek mythology and drama. But the new program presented by the Martha Graham Dance Company on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater makes an even stronger case for Graham as a choreographer of exhilarating spirituality.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MATTUS, JOHN D.

description: A gun-control group has begun a new campaign against large sniper rifles, asserting that the rifles together with armor-piercing ammunition that bursts into flames on impact pose a serious threat to airliners at airports.

title: COCA-COLA TO LAY OFF 1,000 EMPLOYEES IN NORTH AMERICA
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it would lay off 1,000 employees in North America. The layoffs, which are a part of the company's plan to realign its business in North America by combining its soda, fountain drink, Minute Maid and water divisions, are expected to be completed by the end of March, Douglas N. Daft, Coke's chairman and chief executive, said in a memo to employees. Five hundred of the job cuts will be made in Atlanta, the company said. Mr. Daft also said the company would simplify its supply chain and combine its information technology, human resources, sales and finance staffs. Coke's last major round of layoffs was in January 2000, when it eliminated 5,000 jobs. The company employs 12,000 workers in the United States and 30,000 people worldwide. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: A Once-Doomed Nomination Wins Senate Panel Approval
description: In an atmosphere rich with ethnic and judicial politics, the Senate Judiciary Committee voted along strict party lines today to approve the nomination of Miguel Estrada, a Washington lawyer, to be a judge on the federal appeals court based in Washington.

description: Andrew Kreps

title: Europe Offers Plan to Fight Counterfeit Goods
description: The European Commission proposed new measures against counterfeiters today, recommending that those who copy goods like software programs and perfume should receive jail sentences, have their bank accounts frozen and pay much stiffer fines.

Her wisdom, wit and charm will be sorely missed by her children, grandchidlren and many friends throughout the world. Ceremonies will be held in the south of France and the Netherlands at a later date to be announced.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: U.A.W. Sues Union-Owned Company
description: The United Automobile Workers has sued Ullico, a union-owned insurer, demanding that it release a report by former Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois into accusations of improper stock trading by board members, a report the board voted to keep secret. The U.A.W., which owns 150,000 shares of Ullico stock, filed its federal suit in Detroit. A federal grand jury in Washington, the Labor Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission are investigating stock trades in which several Ullico board members made more than $200,000. title: Shopping List | Home Away From Home
description: WHO doesn't love checking in to a nice hotel? You never have to make your bed or wash the towels, and no matter what you crave -- more shampoo, an extra blanket, a cheeseburger at 2 a.m. -- someone is on call to meet your needs. But regardless of how many stars a hotel has, there is one thing all guest rooms lack: the warm feeling of home, sweet home. To give your room the cozy flavor of your humble abode, just pack a few extra things -- a small piece of art, your favorite pajamas, and perhaps some new travel accouterments. All stores are in Manhattan. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, LAURENCE C. III.
description: LEEDS-Laurence C. III. Our wonderful Cary, devoted son, beloved brother, uncle, grandson and nephew. We admired and respected you so much. Strong, kind, sensitive, caring, generous, proud, brave, independent, beautiful soul. Gallant, chivalrous, charismatic. Handsome, graceful, marvelous athlete. Brilliant, world ranked tennis star. Wimbledon semi-finalist. Graduate of Collegiate School and Yale University, class of 1979, attended the Wharton Graduate School of Business. Inquisitive, thoughtful, successful entrepreneur. Always the sought after, kind and loyal friend. You made an indelible impression everywhere you went and on everyone you met. You brightened our days, made us laugh, cry, and then laugh more. We wanted to be where you were. You changed our lives. Cary, you are the shining star in the eyes of Samuel, Michael, Benjamin, Nicholas and Olivia. You will always be their hero and ours. You were so brave always, overcoming great adversity, rebuilding your world, finding happiness. You inspired us with your courage and we will always take great pride in your achievements. You left us at the prime of your life and we will miss you with all our heart everyday. A beautiful soul. Dalia, Larry, Tracy, Evan, Ashley, Christopher. A service will be held on Sunday, February 2, at 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. 212-288-3500. In lieu of flowers, donations in Cary's memory may be sent to The New York Junior Tennis League, 24-16 Queens Plaza South, Long Island City, NY 11101, an organization that provides free tennis programs in NYC's public elementary and middle schools.

Sure, if you're willing to endure the cold, you can see tufted titmice and black-capped chickadees clinging to bare branches in the parks or a few ducks bobbing along the shoreline. But what about those dark, dreary days when the birds themselves go into hiding?

title: How to Get Inside a Student's Head
description: The scant mention of education in President Bush's State of the Union address suggests that the administration feels its work on the subject is done, at least for now. Last year's sweeping bill was a significant achievement, but as with most federal initiatives, it dealt primarily with administrative issues like financing and achievement tests. Little attention was given to the actual process of education: how events in the classroom affect the minds of the students.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Parliament Approves Gay Marriages
description: Belgium's Parliament passed a law yesterday permitting same-sex marriages, making the country the second in Europe to do so, after the Netherlands. The Belgian law, approved by 91 deputies, with 22 against and 9 abstentions, will give homosexual couples most of the rights of heterosexual ones, including inheritance rights. But it will not allow gay couples to adopt children legally. The law, which had already been passed by the Senate, will take effect four months after its official registration. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRECA, LAURENCE E.
description: BARRECA-Laurence E., 85, of Palm Beach, FL. died at his home Sunday, January 26th. A native New Yorker, he attended P.S. 97, James Madison High School and NYU. Mr. Barreca teamed up with Frederick Jambes to acquire and develop several townhomes on East 61st and 5000 acres of mixed use property in Wappingers Falls, before moving to Palm Beach in 1968 where he became a major supporter of the Bascom Palmer Eye Institute, the Good Samaritan Hospital in W. Palm Beach & Florida Atlantic University. Known to his friends and associates as a very modest, unassumming, selfless gentle man, when named as the Bascom Palmer ''Person of Vision'' in 1998 for his founding gift to their Palm Beach County campus, he was asked why he gave, he said: ''It's important to pitch in as much as you can in support of your community and the services it makes available to its citizenry.'' Son of Rose and Joseph Barreca, and one of nine children. Survived by his brother, Hugo Barreca of NYC, sister-in-laws Rose Barreca of NYC and Sally Barreca of Boynton Beach, FL. and numerous nieces and nephew. Memorial services were held Wednesday January 29th at noon at St. Edwards Church, 144 N. County Rd., Palm Beach and final interment Saturday, February 1st at Ferncliff Cemetery, 280 Secor Road, Hartsdale, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to Bascom Palmer Eye Institute, 7108 Fairway Drive, Ste 340, Palm Beach Gardens, FL. 33410.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHEY, MICHAEL I.
description: LEAHEY-Michael I. The Columbia University Department of Surgery mourns the sudden, untimely passing of Michael Leahey. As the founding director of the Office of Clinical Trials at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, Michael understood the fundamental role of clinical trials in the advancement of medical science. He used his background in business to create an office that completed the often onerous administrative tasks associated with clinical trials. He assisted virtually everyone on our faculty over the past decade, as he eased our way through paperwork and allowed us to focus on our clinical research project. Moreover, he managed this complex operation while also pursuing a separate career as the author of several successful novels and directing the Edward B. Leahey, Jr. Foundation. He was a remarkable man who will be missed by all who worked with him. We extend sincere condolences to his wife, Lynn, his two young children, and his entire family. Eric A. Rose, M.D., Chairman Columbia University Department of Surgery, Columbia Prestyterian Medical Center NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nomura Posts Profit
description: Japan's largest brokerage firm, Nomura Holdings, earned 15 billion yen ($125 million) in the three months to December, nearly eight times its profit in the period a year ago. The stronger returns were fueled by profits from the bond trading division and by cost-cutting efforts. While stock prices in Japan are toying with two-decade lows, the bond market has rallied in the last year. Nomura has also sold about $1.9 billion of foreign-currency bonds that yield more than yen-denominated issues. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: 3 States Plan To Sue E.P.A.
description: The attorneys general of Connecticut, Massachusetts and Maine said they would sue the Environmental Protection Agency to force it to restrict carbon dioxide using the Clean Air Act. The officials, all Democrats, said the heat-trapping gas should be added to the ''criteria pollutants'' regulated under the act because data show that rising concentrations of carbon dioxide threaten ecosystems, agriculture and human health. Industry and conservative groups have said no restrictions are justified because no clear harm has been shown and because curbs would hurt the economy. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Bush to Ask Congress for $16 Billion to Fight AIDS in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  President Bush said today that he would ask for $16 billion in next year's federal budget, a 7 percent increase over current spending, to prevent and treat AIDS in the United States. He also announced steps to provide wider access to AIDS tests that can deliver results within minutes.

title: Moscow Journal; For Flashier Russians, Euro Outshines the Dollar
description: This country's official money is the ruble, but it takes only a stroll through an auto dealership, a pricey restaurant or a classy jewelry store here to learn which currency is truly king. A check of price tags there, and in thousands of other establishments, reveals that most expensive items are denominated not in rubles, but in U.E., pronounced ''oo-yeh.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: New Valley Cancels Bid For Globalstar
description: The New Valley Corporation yesterday abandoned plans to take control of Globalstar, the bankrupt satellite telephone company, after failing to reach an agreement with creditors. New Valley, an investment banking and real estate company, offered this month to invest $55 million in Globalstar. The financing would have given New Valley a majority stake in the reorganized company, with creditors including Loral Space and Communications Ltd. owning the rest. Members of the creditors committee, which represents holders of Globalstar bonds, indicated that they planned to provide debtor-in-possession financing, a Globalstar spokesman, Mac Jeffery, said in an interview. Globalstar filed for bankruptcy protection last February after spending more than $4 billion to build a satellite telephone network. Shares of New Valley fell 30 cents, or 6.8 percent, to $4.15.
